Chapter 1

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Merton Densher returns to England from a trip. The previous afternoon, he arrived by train at Euston station at five o'clock, having sent a wire to Kate Croy from Liverpool. She met him at the station. They went to the station's refreshment room and had tea at a corner table. Kate told Densher she had to be at Lancaster Gate by six o'clock to see her Aunt Maud. She arranged to meet Densher the next morning at the National Gallery. The next day, they meet at the gallery. They sit and talk. Kate stands up suddenly and makes a comment about a picture. Densher remarks on the stuffiness of the room and suggests they go outside. As they move to another part of the gallery, they encounter a young American woman, Miss Theale. Later, after having lunch with the American women, Densher and Kate separate from them. Kate then asks Densher to put her in a cab, and she leaves. Densher takes a long walk by himself, heading north. He reaches Regent's Park and sits down on a bench. He recalls asking Kate earlier if her Aunt Maud (Mrs. Lowder) knew of his return. Kate had replied that she did not, but said she would speak to her that night and arrange for Densher to visit. After a while, Densher gets up from the bench and resumes his walk.

"I say, you know, Kate—you did stay!" had been Merton Densher's punctual remark on their adventure after they had, as it were, got out of it; an observation which she not less promptly, on her side, let him see that she forgave in him only because he was a man. She had to recognise, with whatever disappointment, that it was doubtless the most helpful he could make in this character. The fact of the adventure was flagrant between them; they had looked at each other, on gaining the street, as people look who have just rounded together a dangerous corner, and there was therefore already enough unanimity sketched out to have lighted, for her companion, anything equivocal in her action. But the amount of light men did need!—Kate could have been eloquent at this moment about that.

Translation

"You stayed, you know, Kate—you actually did!" Merton Densher had said, predictably, once they'd emerged from their experience. She let him understand, with no less immediacy, that she excused this observation only because he was a man. She had to acknowledge, however disappointed she might be, that it was probably the most useful thing he could say in that capacity. The reality of their shared adventure was obvious. They'd looked at each other, as they stepped onto the street, the way people do after narrowly avoiding disaster. There was already enough shared understanding between them to illuminate, for him, the ambiguous nature of her actions. And how much illumination men seemed to require! Kate could have been quite expressive on that topic right now.

What, however, on his seeing more, struck him as most distinct in her was her sense that, reunited after his absence and having been now half the morning together, it behooved them to face without delay the question of handling their immediate future. That it would require some handling, that they should still have to deal, deal in a crafty manner, with difficulties and delays, was the great matter he had come back to, greater than any but the refreshed consciousness of their personal need of each other. This need had had twenty minutes, the afternoon before, to find out where it stood, and the time was fully accounted for by the charm of the demonstration. He had arrived at Euston at five, having wired her from Liverpool the moment he landed, and she had quickly decided to meet him at the station, whatever publicity might attend such an act.

Translation

What struck him most distinctly, as he observed her further, was her feeling that, reunited after his absence and having spent half the morning together, they needed to address their immediate future without delay. The fact that it would require some management, that they would still need to navigate difficulties and delays craftily, was the main issue he had returned to—more significant than anything except the renewed awareness of their personal need for one another. This need had had twenty minutes, the previous afternoon, to assess itself, and the time had been entirely consumed by the delight of its expression. He'd arrived at Euston at five, having wired her from Liverpool the instant he'd landed, and she had swiftly decided to meet him at the station, regardless of any public attention it might draw.

When he had praised her for it on alighting from his train she had answered frankly enough that such things should be taken at a jump. She didn't care to-day who saw her, and she profited by it for her joy. To-morrow, inevitably, she should have time to think and then, as inevitably, would become a baser creature, a creature of alarms and precautions. It was none the less for to-morrow at an early hour that she had appointed their next meeting, keeping in mind for the present a particular obligation to show at Lancaster Gate by six o'clock.

Translation

When he complimented her for it as he got off the train, she'd replied frankly that they should seize the moment. She didn't care who saw her that day, and she reveled in her joy. Tomorrow, inevitably, she'd have time to think and would then, inevitably, become a lesser creature, full of anxieties and precautions. It was still for tomorrow, at an early hour, that she'd set their next meeting, keeping in mind a particular commitment to be at Lancaster Gate by six o'clock.

She had given, with imprecations, her reason—people to tea, eternally, and a promise to Aunt Maud; but she had been liberal enough on the spot and had suggested the National Gallery for the morning quite as with an idea that had ripened in expectancy. They might be seen there too, but nobody would know them; just as, for that matter, now, in the refreshment-room to which they had adjourned, they would incur the notice but, at the worst, of the unacquainted. They would "have something" there for the facility it would give. Thus had it already come up for them again that they had no place of convenience.

Translation

She had offered, with profuse apologies, her excuse—people were coming for tea, an endless stream of them, and a promise to Aunt Maud; but she'd been generous enough in the moment and had suggested the National Gallery for the morning, as if the idea had been brewing in her mind, waiting to be expressed. They might be seen there, too, but no one would recognize them; just as, for that matter, now, in the refreshment room to which they'd retreated, they'd only be noticed, at most, by strangers. They would "have something" there for the convenience it provided. Thus it had already occurred to them again that they had no suitable place to be.

"You know, Kate—you really did stay!" Merton Densher said as soon as they had recovered from their adventure, a remark she forgave him only because he was a man. She had to acknowledge, even with some disappointment, that this was likely the best he could do in that role. The reality of the adventure was clear between them. They'd looked at each other, once they were on the street, like people who had just survived a dangerous moment.

Translation

"You know, Kate—you really did stay!" Merton Densher said as soon as they had recovered from their adventure, a remark she forgave him only because he was a man. She had to acknowledge, even with some disappointment, that this was likely the best he could do in that role. The reality of the adventure was clear between them. They'd looked at each other, once they were on the street, like people who had just survived a dangerous moment.

This meant there was already enough agreement for him to understand any ambiguity in her actions. But how much clarification men needed! Kate could have been very expressive on the subject at that moment. However, what seemed most apparent to him was her sense that, having been reunited after his absence and spent half the morning together, they needed to address how to handle their immediate future without delay.

Translation

This meant he already knew enough to read between the lines. Yet men needed so much explaining! Kate could have elaborated at that moment. But what he took from it was her feeling that, having found each other again after his absence and spent half the morning together, they needed to settle their immediate plans without further delay.

That it would take some skillful planning and that they would have to continue to navigate difficulties and delays was the main issue he had returned to—more important than anything but the renewed awareness of their personal need for each other. This need had had twenty minutes the previous afternoon to figure itself out, and the time was entirely devoted to the pleasure of the reunion. He had arrived at Euston at five, having wired her from Liverpool the moment he landed, and she had decided to meet him at the station, regardless of any public attention it might draw. When he praised her for it after getting off the train, she had answered frankly enough that such things should be approached boldly.

Translation

The real problem he had come back to, the thing that overshadowed everything else except their rediscovered need for each other, was that they'd need to plan carefully and keep dealing with problems and setbacks. The need had been given twenty minutes to work itself out the previous afternoon, time completely spent in the joy of their reunion. He'd gotten to Euston at five, after wiring her from Liverpool the instant his feet touched ground, and she'd decided to meet him, no matter the onlookers. He'd complimented her on it after getting off the train, and she'd answered, frankly, that these things had to be done boldly.

She didn't care who saw her that day, and she enjoyed it. Tomorrow, inevitably, she'd have time to think and then, inevitably, become more cautious and anxious. Nonetheless, she had scheduled their next meeting for early the following morning, keeping in mind for the present a specific obligation to be at Lancaster Gate by six o'clock. She had given her reason with exasperation: people coming for tea, constantly, and a promise to Aunt Maud.

Translation

She didn't care about being seen that day, and she loved it. Tomorrow, she knew, she would have time to think, and then, inevitably, become more careful and worried. But she had set their next meeting for early the next morning, keeping in mind for the moment a specific requirement to be at Lancaster Gate by six o'clock. She had explained her reason with exasperation: people coming over for tea, all the time, and a promise to Aunt Maud.

However, she had been generous in the moment, suggesting the National Gallery for the morning, as if the idea had been brewing in anticipation. They might be seen there too, but nobody would know them. Similarly, in the refreshment room they had gone to, they would only be noticed, at worst, by strangers. They would "have something" there for the ease it would provide.

Translation

Nevertheless, she'd been generous just then, proposing the National Gallery for the morning, as if the notion had been in the works. They might be seen there too, but no one would recognize them. Likewise, in the tea room they'd chosen, they would only be observed, at most, by strangers. They would "have something" there for the convenience of it.

It had already become clear to them again that they had no convenient place to meet. He found himself on English soil with all sorts of feelings, but he hadn't quite faced having to reckon with a certain ruefulness in regard to that subject as one of the strongest. He was aware later on that there were questions his impatience had shirked; whereby it actually rather smote him, for want of preparation and assurance, that he had nowhere to "take" his love. He had taken it thus, at Euston—and on Kate's own suggestion—into the place where people had beer and buns, and had ordered tea at a small table in the corner; which, no doubt, as they were lost in the crowd, did well enough for a stop-gap.

Translation

It was clear to them again that they had no easy place to meet. He found himself on English soil with all sorts of emotions, but he hadn't yet faced the fact that a certain regret about that subject was one of the strongest. He realized later that there were questions he'd avoided in his impatience; as a result, he was actually quite distressed, due to lack of preparation and confidence, that he had nowhere to "take" his love. He had taken it like this, at Euston—and at Kate's own suggestion—into the place where people had beer and buns, and had ordered tea at a small table in the corner; which, no doubt, as they were lost in the crowd, worked well enough for the time being.

It perhaps did as well as her simply driving with him to the door of his lodging, which had had to figure as the sole device of his own wit. That wit, the truth was, had broken down a little at the sharp prevision that once at his door they would have to hang back. She would have to stop there, wouldn't come in with him, couldn't possibly; and he shouldn't be able to ask her, would feel he couldn't without betraying a deficiency of what would be called, even at their advanced stage, respect for her: that again was all that was clear except the further fact that it was maddening. Compressed and concentrated, confined to a single sharp pang or two, but none the less in wait for him there on the Euston platform and lifting its head as that of a snake in the garden, was the disconcerting sense that "respect," in their game, seemed somehow—he scarce knew what to call it—a fifth wheel to the coach.

Translation

It possibly served its purpose as well as her simply driving with him to the door of his lodging, which was the only idea he'd come up with. The truth was, his resourcefulness had crumbled a bit at the sudden realization that they would have to stop once they reached his door. She would have to stay there, wouldn't come in with him, couldn't possibly; and he shouldn't be able to ask her, would feel he couldn't without revealing a lack of what would be called, even at their current point, respect for her: that was, again, all that was clear, except for the additional fact that it was maddening. Compressed and concentrated, confined to a single sharp pang or two, but nonetheless waiting for him there on the Euston platform and lifting its head like a snake in the garden, was the unsettling feeling that "respect," in their game, seemed somehow—he barely knew what to call it—a fifth wheel to the coach.

It was properly an inside thing, not an outside, a thing to make love greater, not to make happiness less. They had met again for happiness, and he distinctly felt, during his most lucid moment or two, how he must keep watch on anything that really menaced that boon. If Kate had consented to drive away with him and alight at his house there would probably enough have occurred for them, at the foot of his steps, one of those strange instants between man and woman that blow upon the red spark, the spark of conflict, ever latent in the depths of passion. She would have shaken her head—oh sadly, divinely—on the question of coming in; and he, though doing all justice to her refusal, would have yet felt his eyes reach further into her own than a possible word at such a time could reach.

Translation

It was truly an intimate thing, not an external one, something to enhance love, not diminish happiness. They had come together again for happiness, and he clearly understood, during his clearest moments, that he must remain vigilant against anything that truly threatened that joy. If Kate had agreed to drive with him and stop at his house, enough would probably have occurred between them at his doorstep—one of those peculiar moments between a man and a woman that stoke the red spark, the spark of conflict, always hidden within the depths of passion. She would have shaken her head—oh, sadly, divinely—at the thought of coming inside; and he, while respecting her refusal, would still have felt his gaze penetrate hers more deeply than any possible words could at that moment.

This would have meant the suspicion, the dread of the shadow, of an adverse will. Lucky therefore in the actual case that the scant minutes took another turn and that by the half-hour she did in spite of everything contrive to spend with him Kate showed so well how she could deal with things that maddened. She seemed to ask him, to beseech him, and all for his better comfort, to leave her, now and henceforth, to treat them in her own way. He found himself in England with a complex mix of emotions.

Translation

This would have meant suspicion, the dread of a looming shadow, a conflicting desire. It was fortunate, then, that the brief encounter took a different course. The half-hour Kate did spend with him demonstrated her ability to manage situations that could have driven him to madness. She seemed to implore him, for his own well-being, to leave her alone, to allow her to handle things as she saw fit. He found himself back in England, wrestling with a tangle of emotions.

However, he hadn't fully acknowledged that a certain regret regarding this matter was among the most prominent. He later realized he'd avoided dealing with certain issues because of his impatience. As a result, he felt rather deflated, unprepared and uncertain, because he had no appropriate place to express his affection. He had done so at Euston station—at Kate's suggestion—in the area where people ate and drank, ordering tea at a small table in a corner.

Translation

Nevertheless, a significant regret had taken hold, one of the most noticeable. He subsequently understood he’d sidestepped specific problems due to his own lack of patience. Consequently, he felt disheartened, unready, and unsure, lacking a suitable outlet for his feelings. He’d already attempted this at Euston station—at Kate's urging—in the food and beverage area, taking tea at a small table in a corner.

It was probably adequate as a temporary solution, considering they were surrounded by crowds. Perhaps it was as effective as her simply driving him to his lodgings, which had been the only idea he could come up with. The truth was, his resourcefulness had faltered slightly at the clear anticipation that they would have to hold back once they reached his door. She would have to stay there; she wouldn't come inside, and couldn't possibly.

Translation

It was likely a decent enough stopgap, given the press of people all around them. Maybe it worked just as well as her driving him back to his place, which was the only plan he’d managed to concoct. The fact was, his ingenuity had waned somewhat, anticipating the moment they’d have to stop once they arrived at his door. She'd have to stay put; she wouldn't come in, couldn't possibly.

He couldn't ask her, he felt he shouldn't, without appearing to lack what would be called, even at their stage, respect for her. That, too, was perfectly clear, along with the fact that it was infuriating. Concentrated and focused, limited to a few sharp pains, but nonetheless lying in wait for him on the Euston platform, rearing its head like a snake in the garden, was the unsettling feeling that "respect," in their relationship, seemed—he barely knew how to describe it—an unnecessary complication. It belonged on the inside, not the outside; something that should enhance love, not diminish happiness.

Translation

He couldn't ask her, he didn't think he should, without seeming to disrespect her, even at this point. That much was also obvious, as was how irritating it was. Focused and intense, reduced to a few sharp pangs, but still waiting for him on the Euston platform, rearing up like a snake in the garden, was the disconcerting feeling that "respect," in their relationship, seemed—he struggled to find the words—an unnecessary obstacle. It belonged on the inside, not the outside; something that should enrich love, not reduce joy.

They had come together for happiness, and during his most lucid moments, he clearly understood he had to be vigilant against anything that threatened that joy. If Kate had agreed to drive with him and stop at his house, they would have likely experienced, at his doorstep, one of those peculiar moments between a man and a woman that spark the conflict, the spark always hidden within passion. She would have sadly, yet gracefully, declined the invitation to enter. Although he would have acknowledged her refusal, he would still have felt his gaze penetrate her own, reaching deeper than any possible words at that moment.

Translation

They'd gotten together for happiness, and in his clearest moments, he knew he had to watch out for anything that endangered that. If Kate had agreed to drive with him and stop at his place, they probably would have had one of those weird moments, the ones between a man and a woman that kick off the conflict, the spark always hidden inside the passion, right at his front door. She would have turned down the invitation to come in, sadly but gracefully. Even though he would have accepted her decision, he still would have felt his eyes searching hers, reaching further than any words could at that instant.

This would have meant the suspicion, the fear of the shadow of an opposing will. Therefore, he was fortunate that the brief minutes took another turn, and that Kate, despite everything, managed to spend half an hour with him, demonstrating her ability to navigate maddening situations. She seemed to ask him, to implore him, for his own well-being, to allow her, from that moment on, to manage their relationship in her own way. She had still met it in naming so promptly, for their early convenience, one of the great museums; and indeed with such happy art that his fully seeing where she had placed him hadn't been till after he left her.

Translation

This would have meant suspicion, the fear of an opposing will's shadow. So, he was lucky the brief minutes changed course, and Kate, despite everything, managed to spend half an hour with him, showing her knack for navigating infuriating situations. She seemed to ask him, to implore him, for his own good, to let her, from then on, manage their relationship her own way. She’d already accomplished it by so promptly naming, for their early convenience, one of the great museums; and in fact, with such skill that he didn’t fully realize where she had placed him until after he left her.

His absence from her for so many weeks had had such an effect upon him that his demands, his desires had grown; and only the night before, as his ship steamed, beneath summer stars, in sight of the Irish coast, he had felt all the force of his particular necessity. He hadn't in other words at any point doubted he was on his way to say to her that really their mistake must end. Their mistake was to have believed that they could hold out—hold out, that is, not against Aunt Maud, but against an impatience that, prolonged and exasperated, made a man ill. He had known more than ever, on their separating in the court of the station, how ill a man, and even a woman, could feel from such a cause; but he struck himself as also knowing that he had already suffered Kate to begin finely to apply antidotes and remedies and subtle sedatives.

Translation

His weeks away from her had changed him, and his needs, his wants, had intensified. Just the night before, as his ship sailed under summer stars, near the Irish coast, he’d felt the full weight of his need. In other words, he’d never doubted that he was on his way to tell her their error had to stop. Their mistake was believing they could hold on—not against Aunt Maud, but against an impatience that, prolonged and exasperated, made a man sick. He’d known, more than ever, when they’d parted at the station, how sick a man, or even a woman, could become because of this. But he also understood that he’d already allowed Kate to begin expertly applying her antidotes, remedies, and subtle sedatives.

It had a vulgar sound—as throughout, in love, the names of things, the verbal terms of intercourse, were, compared with love itself, horribly vulgar; but it was as if, after all, he might have come back to find himself "put off," though it would take him of course a day or two to see. His letters from the States had pleased whom it concerned, though not so much as he had meant they should; and he should be paid according to agreement and would now take up his money. It wasn't in truth very much to take up, so that he hadn't in the least come back flourishing a cheque-book; that new motive for bringing his mistress to terms he couldn't therefore pretend to produce. The ideal certainty would have been to be able to present a change of prospect as a warrant for the change of philosophy, and without it he should have to make shift but with the pretext of the lapse of time.

Translation

It sounded crude—as always, in love, the names of things, the language used for intimacy, were, compared to love itself, horribly vulgar; but it was as if, after all, he might have come back to find himself “dumped,” though it would take him a day or two to see. His letters from the States had pleased the relevant party, though not as much as he’d hoped; and he would be paid as agreed and could now collect his money. It wasn’t much to collect, so he hadn’t returned waving a checkbook; he couldn’t, therefore, pretend to present that new reason to get his mistress to agree. The ideal outcome would have been to be able to offer a new opportunity as a reason to change his philosophy, and without it he would have to make do with the excuse of the time that had passed.

The lapse of time—not so many weeks after all, she might always of course say—couldn't at any rate have failed to do something for him; and that consideration it was that had just now tided him over, all the more that he had his vision of what it had done personally for Kate. This had come out for him with a splendour that almost scared him even in their small corner of the room at Euston—almost scared him because it just seemed to blaze at him that waiting was the game of dupes. Not yet had she been so the creature he had originally seen; not yet had he felt so soundly safely sure. It was all there for him, playing on his pride of possession as a hidden master in a great dim church might play on the grandest organ.

Translation

The passage of time—a matter of a few weeks, she could always say—must have changed him, however slightly. That thought had just gotten him through, especially given his clear image of the effect it had had on Kate. This struck him with a brilliance that almost frightened him, even in their small corner of the room in Euston—almost scared him because it just seemed to scream at him that waiting was for fools. She still wasn't the woman he had first seen; he still didn't feel so utterly and completely secure. It was all right there for him, manipulating his pride of ownership like a hidden master in a great, dim church might play the most magnificent organ.

His final sense was that a woman couldn't be like that and then ask of one the impossible. She'd been quick to name a major museum for their initial meeting, doing so with such skill that he didn't realize where she'd placed him until after he left. His absence of several weeks had intensified his needs and desires, and the night before, as his ship sailed under the summer stars, near the Irish coast, he felt the full force of his particular need. In other words, he'd never doubted he was going to tell her their mistake must end.

Translation

His ultimate thought was that a woman couldn't be that way and then expect the impossible from him. She'd been quick to suggest a major museum for their first meeting, phrasing it so cleverly that he didn't realize where he stood until afterward. His time away, several weeks in length, had made his wants and cravings stronger, and the night before, while his ship sailed beneath the summer stars near the Irish coast, he felt the full weight of his specific yearning. In other words, he'd never questioned that he would tell her their error had to stop.

Their mistake was believing they could endure—not against Aunt Maud, but against an impatience that, prolonged and aggravated, made a man sick. He'd known, when they separated at the station, how ill such a thing could make a man, or even a woman, feel. However, he also believed Kate had begun to subtly apply her remedies. It sounded crude—as the language of love always was, compared to love itself, horribly vulgar; but it was as if he might return to find himself "rejected," though it would take him a day or two to accept it.

Translation

The error was in thinking they could withstand it—not Aunt Maud, but a certain restlessness that, when prolonged and inflamed, would sicken a man. He’d understood, when they parted at the station, how unwell such a thing could make a person. He also thought Kate had started, subtly, to use her treatments. It sounded crude—as the language of love always did, compared to love itself, utterly vulgar; but it was as if he might come back to find himself "rejected," though it would take him a day or two to accept it.

His letters from America had pleased her, though not as much as he'd intended. He would be paid as agreed and would now collect his money. It wasn't a large sum, so he couldn't return waving a checkbook to pressure her. The ideal scenario would have been to offer a change of prospects to justify a change in their relationship, but without it, he'd have to use the passage of time as his excuse.

Translation

Her pleasure in his letters from America had been genuine, even if it fell short of his hopes. He would receive his payment as arranged, and would soon have the money in hand. The amount wasn't significant enough to allow him to return and try to win her over with financial displays. The best outcome would have involved a shift in his circumstances that might account for a shift in their connection. But without that, he would have to rely on the passage of time as his justification.

Time—not that many weeks, she might say—had to have affected him in some way; that consideration had just helped him through the journey, especially because he understood what it had done for Kate. This realization struck him with a splendor that almost frightened him, even in their small corner of the room at Euston—almost scared him because it made him see that waiting was for fools. She wasn't yet the woman he'd initially seen; he hadn't yet felt so completely and safely assured. It was all there for him, playing on his pride of possession like a hidden master in a grand, dim church playing the organ.

Translation

Time—not even a handful of weeks, she'd likely say—had to have changed him somehow; that thought had just gotten him through the trip, particularly because he understood what it had done for Kate. This awareness hit him with a brilliance that almost scared him, even in their little nook at Euston—almost frightened him because it showed him that waiting was for suckers. She wasn't the woman he'd first imagined; he didn't yet feel entirely and securely confident. It was all there for him, manipulating his sense of ownership like a hidden maestro in a vast, shadowy church playing the organ.

His final thought was that a woman couldn't be like that and then expect the impossible from him. She had been like that afresh on the morrow; and so for the hour they had been able to float in the mere joy of contact—such contact as their situation in pictured public halls permitted. This poor makeshift for closeness confessed itself in truth, by twenty small signs of unrest even on Kate's part, inadequate; so little could a decent interest in the interesting place presume to remind them of its claims. They had met there in order not to meet in the streets and not again, with an equal want of invention and of style, at a railway-station; not again, either, in Kensington Gardens, which, they could easily and tacitly agree, would have had too much of the taste of their old frustrations.

Translation

His final thought was that a woman couldn't act that way and then expect the impossible from him. She'd been like that again the next day. For the hour they were together, they'd floated in the simple joy of contact—the kind of contact their setting in those imagined public halls allowed. This weak substitute for intimacy revealed itself to be inadequate, by twenty little signs of unease even on Kate's part. A mere interest in the interesting place was not enough to remind them of its demands. They'd met there to avoid meeting in the streets, and to avoid, with an equal lack of imagination and style, meeting again at a railway station. They'd also avoided Kensington Gardens, which, they easily and silently agreed, would have tasted too much of their old frustrations.

The present taste, the taste that morning in the pictured halls, had been a variation; yet Densher had at the end of a quarter of an hour fully known what to conclude from it. This fairly consoled him for their awkwardness, as if he had been watching it affect her. She might be as nobly charming as she liked, and he had seen nothing to touch her in the States; she couldn't pretend that in such conditions as those she herself believed it enough to appease him. She couldn't pretend she believed he would believe it enough to render her a like service.

Translation

The feeling of the moment, the feeling they shared that morning in the imagined halls, had been a variation on a theme. Yet after fifteen minutes, Densher knew exactly what to make of it. This knowledge was a small comfort, as if he were simply observing her reaction. She could be as wonderfully charming as she pleased – and he hadn't seen anyone to match her in America – but she couldn’t pretend that in their current circumstances, she thought it was enough to satisfy him. She couldn’t pretend she believed he would do the same for her.

It wasn't enough for that purpose—she as good as showed him it wasn't. That was what he could be glad, by demonstration, to have brought her to. He would have said to her had he put it crudely and on the spot: "Now am I to understand you that you consider this sort of thing can go on?" It would have been open to her, no doubt, to reply that to have him with her again, to have him all kept and treasured, so still, under her grasping hand, as she had held him in their yearning interval, was a sort of thing that he must allow her to have no quarrel about; but that would be a mere gesture of her grace, a mere sport of her subtlety. She knew as well as he what they wanted; in spite of which indeed he scarce could have said how beautifully he mightn't once more have named it and urged it if she hadn't, at a given moment, blurred, as it were, the accord.

Translation

It wasn't adequate for that particular goal; she practically showed him it wasn't. That was the situation he could be grateful to have led her to, as demonstrated. He would have asked her, had he phrased it bluntly and without delay: "Am I to understand you believe this situation can continue?" She would have, of course, been able to reply that having him back, having him completely to herself and cherished, so still under her control, as she had held him during their period of longing, was something she couldn't possibly be expected to object to. But that would be a mere act of generosity on her part, a display of her cleverness. She knew exactly what they both desired; in spite of this, he could hardly say how perfectly he might have named it again, and urged it on her, if she hadn't, at a crucial moment, disrupted the agreement.

They had soon seated themselves for better talk, and so they had remained a while, intimate and superficial. The immediate things to say had been many, for they hadn't exhausted them at Euston. They drew upon them freely now, and Kate appeared quite to forget—which was prodigiously becoming to her—to look about for surprises. He was to try afterwards, and try in vain, to remember what speech or what silence of his own, what natural sign of the eyes or accidental touch of the hand, had precipitated for her, in the midst of this, a sudden different impulse.

Translation

They soon sat down to converse more comfortably, and they stayed that way for a time, close yet unprofound. They had a lot to say right away, since they hadn't run out of things to say at Euston Station. They spoke freely now, and Kate seemed to forget—which was extraordinarily appealing—to be looking around for anything surprising. Afterwards, he would try, and try in vain, to recall which word or pause of his, which natural expression of his eyes or accidental touch of his hand, had triggered a sudden, contrasting feeling in her in the middle of it all.

She had got up, with inconsequence, as if to break the charm, though he wasn't aware of what he had done at the moment to make the charm a danger. She had patched it up agreeably enough the next minute by some odd remark about some picture, to which he hadn't so much as replied; it being quite independently of this that he had himself exclaimed on the dreadful closeness of the rooms. He had observed that they must go out again to breathe; and it was as if their common consciousness, while they passed into another part, was that of persons who, infinitely engaged together, had been startled and were trying to look natural. It was probably while they were so occupied—as the young man subsequently reconceived—that they had stumbled upon his little New York friend.

Translation

She stood up abruptly, as if she wanted to dispel the spell. He didn’t realize at the time that he’d done anything to make the spell dangerous. She had smoothed things over quickly enough with an offhand comment about a picture he hadn’t even responded to. It was completely unrelated to that, when he’d remarked on how stifling the rooms were. He’d suggested they go outside for some air, and as they moved into another room, it was as if they both felt they were deeply connected, but had been startled and were trying to appear normal. It was likely while they were still distracted—as the young man later remembered—that they’d encountered his friend from New York.

He thought of her for some reason as little, though she was of about Kate's height, to which, any more than to any other felicity in his mistress, he had never applied the diminutive. She had felt that way again the next day. They had been able to revel in the simple joy of being near each other, as much as their situation in the public art gallery allowed. This attempt at closeness, however, revealed its flaws through several subtle signs of Kate's own unease.

Translation

He thought of her as small for some reason, even though she was around Kate’s height, a diminutive he’d never used for her, or for any of the other good qualities he saw in his mistress. She had felt that way again the next day. They had reveled in the simple joy of being near each other, to the extent their public gallery setting allowed. But this attempt at closeness showed its cracks through the many subtle signs of Kate's discomfort.

A mere interest in the art around them wasn't enough to distract them from their true desires. They had met there to avoid meeting on the streets and, with a similar lack of imagination, at a train station. They'd also avoided Kensington Gardens, which, they both knew, would have been a reminder of their past frustrations. This current setting, the art gallery that morning, offered a change, but within fifteen minutes, Densher had already understood its implications.

Translation

Their shared interest in the art couldn't fully conceal what they truly wanted. They had chosen this place to avoid encounters on the streets, and, just as unimaginatively, the train station. Kensington Gardens was also off-limits, a mutual understanding to avoid revisiting past disappointments. The art gallery that morning offered a fresh start, but within fifteen minutes, Densher already grasped its limitations.

This knowledge somewhat eased his discomfort, as if he'd been watching it affect her. She could be as wonderfully charming as she liked, and he hadn't seen anything to rival that charm in America. But she couldn't pretend that this was enough to satisfy him. She couldn't pretend she thought he would believe it enough to offer her the same consideration.

Translation

The awareness of her predicament lessened his unease, like an observer witnessing her struggle. She possessed a remarkable, almost dazzling allure, unparalleled by anything he'd encountered in America. But she couldn't feign satisfaction with the present. She couldn't pretend she believed he would be fooled, enough to reciprocate her restraint.

It wasn't enough for that, as she subtly showed him. He was glad to have brought her to that realization. He might have asked her, bluntly, "Are you suggesting this can continue?" She could have responded that having him with her again, keeping him close, as she had during their time apart, was something she couldn't give up. But that would have been a mere gesture of her charm, a playful display of her intelligence.

Translation

That wasn't the point, as she subtly indicated. He was pleased to have brought her to this understanding. He could have asked her directly, "Are you suggesting this is sustainable?" She might have replied that having him back, keeping him close like she had during their separation, was something she couldn't relinquish. But that would have been just a performance of her charm, a playful exhibition of her wit.

She knew as well as he did what they truly wanted. Despite that, he couldn't say how beautifully he might have named it again, if she hadn't, at a certain moment, disrupted their harmony. They had soon sat down for a better conversation and remained there for a while, intimate but superficial. There was much to discuss, as they hadn't exhausted their topics at Euston Station.

Translation

She understood their desires perfectly. Even so, he couldn't describe how exquisitely he would have articulated them again, if she hadn't, at a certain point, broken their rhythm. They'd quickly sat down for a more considered discussion and lingered, close but shallow. They still had a great deal to talk about, as they'd barely scratched the surface at Euston Station.

They spoke freely, and Kate seemed to forget—which was incredibly becoming—to search for any surprises. Afterward, he would try in vain to recall what he had said or what silence he had maintained, what gesture of his eyes, or accidental touch of his hand had caused her to suddenly shift her mood. She had stood up abruptly, as if to break the spell, even though he wasn't aware of having done anything at that moment to make the spell a threat. She'd smoothed things over quickly with a strange comment about a painting, to which he hadn't even responded.

Translation

They spoke openly, and Kate seemed to forget—a quality that was incredibly charming—to look for hidden meanings. Later, he would try and fail to remember what he had said, or what silence he had kept, what look in his eyes, or accidental brush of his hand had caused her to suddenly change. She had stood, abruptly, as if to break the mood, even though he didn't realize he'd done anything in that moment to make the mood feel dangerous. She had quickly smoothed things over with a strange comment about a painting, which he hadn't even acknowledged.

It was independently of this that he himself had commented on the stifling atmosphere of the rooms. He had suggested they go outside to breathe. It was as if their shared awareness, as they moved to another part of the gallery, was that of two people, deeply connected, who had been startled and were trying to appear normal. It was probably while they were so preoccupied—as the young man later remembered—that they had encountered his young friend from New York.

Translation

It was unrelated to that when he’d remarked on how stuffy the rooms felt. He'd suggested they go outside for some air. As they moved to another area of the gallery, their shared understanding seemed to be that of two people, deeply intimate, who had been surprised and were attempting to act casual. It was likely during their distraction—as the young man would later recall—that they'd run into his young friend from New York.

He thought of her as "little" for some reason, even though she was about Kate's height. He never used that diminutive for her, nor for any other aspect of his mistress's perfection. What was to be in the retrospect more distinct to him was the process by which he had become aware that Kate's acquaintance with her was greater than he had gathered. She had written of it in due course as a new and amusing one, and he had written back that he had met over there, and that he much liked, the young person; whereupon she had answered that he must find out about her at home.

Translation

He thought of her as "little" for some reason, even though she was about Kate's height. He never used that diminutive for her, nor for any other aspect of his mistress's perfection. What was to be in retrospect more distinct to him was the process by which he had become aware that Kate's acquaintance with her was greater than he had realized. She had written of it in due course as a new and amusing one, and he had written back that he had met her over there, and that he much liked the young person; whereupon she had answered that he must find out about her at home.

Kate, in the event, however, had not returned to that, and he had of course, with so many things to find out about, been otherwise taken up. Little Miss Theale's individual history was not stuff for his newspaper; besides which, moreover, he was seeing but too many little Miss Theales. They even went so far as to impose themselves as one of the groups of social phenomena that fell into the scheme of his public letters. For this group in especial perhaps—the irrepressible, the supereminent young persons—his best pen was ready.

Translation

Kate, in the end, hadn't returned to the subject, and he, naturally, with so many other things to investigate, had been preoccupied. Little Miss Theale's personal history wasn't material for his newspaper; in addition, he was, moreover, encountering too many Little Miss Theales. They even went so far as to insert themselves into the category of social phenomena that were the subject of his public letters. For this group in particular—the irrepressible, the extraordinary young women—his best pen was poised.

Thus it was that there could come back to him in London, an hour or two after their luncheon with the American pair, the sense of a situation for which Kate hadn't wholly prepared him. Possibly indeed as marked as this was his recovered perception that preparations, of more than one kind, had been exactly what, both yesterday and to-day, he felt her as having in hand. That appearance in fact, if he dwelt on it, so ministered to apprehension as to require some brushing away. He shook off the suspicion to some extent, on their separating first from their hostesses and then from each other, by the aid of a long and rather aimless walk.

Translation

So it was that he could recall, in London, an hour or two after their lunch with the American couple, the feeling of a situation for which Kate hadn't completely readied him. Possibly his renewed sense of it was as significant as this: that preparations, of more than one kind, had been precisely what, both yesterday and today, he felt she had been engaged in. That impression, if he focused on it, fueled his unease to the point where it needed to be dispelled. He shook off the suspicion to a degree, after they separated first from their hostesses and then from each other, by means of a long and somewhat directionless walk.

He was to go to the office later, but he had the next two or three hours, and he gave himself as a pretext that he had eaten much too much. After Kate had asked him to put her into a cab—which, as an announced, a resumed policy on her part, he found himself deprecating—he stood a while by a corner and looked vaguely forth at his London. There was always doubtless a moment for the absentee recaptured—the moment, that of the reflux of the first emotion—at which it was beyond disproof that one was back. His full parenthesis was closed, and he was once more but a sentence, of a sort, in the general text, the text that, from his momentary street-corner, showed as a great grey page of print that somehow managed to be crowded without being "fine." The grey, however, was more or less the blur of a point of view not yet quite seized again; and there would be colour enough to come out.

Translation

He was scheduled to go to the office later, but he had the next few hours free, and he told himself that he'd simply eaten too much. After Kate had asked him to get her a cab—which, as a newly-declared policy of hers, he found himself disliking—he stood for a moment on the corner and stared vaguely out at his London. There was always, undoubtedly, a moment for the re-acclimatized absentee—the moment, the return of the first feeling—when it became irrefutable that he was back. His full parenthesis was closed, and he was once more merely a sentence, of a kind, in the larger narrative, the narrative that, from his temporary street-corner vantage, appeared as a great grey page of print that managed to be crowded without being "fine." The grey, however, was more or less the blur of a perspective he hadn't fully reclaimed; and there would be plenty of color to emerge.

He was back, flatly enough, but back to possibilities and prospects, and the ground he now somewhat sightlessly covered was the act of renewed possession. What stood out most clearly to him later was how he had realized Kate knew the woman better than he thought. Kate had written about her in a recent letter, describing her as a new and entertaining acquaintance. He had replied that he had met the young woman there and liked her very much.

Translation

He was back, plainly enough, but back to possibilities and prospects, and the space he now somewhat sightlessly traversed was the act of renewed possession. What stood out most clearly to him later was how he had realized Kate knew the woman better than he thought. Kate had written about her in a recent letter, describing her as a new and entertaining acquaintance. He had replied that he had met the young woman there and liked her very much.

In response, Kate had written back that he should find out more about her when he got home. But, as it turned out, Kate hadn't brought up the subject again, and he had been preoccupied with other things. The young Miss Theale’s personal history wasn't something he could write about in his newspaper; also, he was already encountering too many young women like her. They had even become one of the social phenomena he included in his public letters.

Translation

Kate’s reply was that he should learn more about the woman once he returned. However, Kate hadn't mentioned her again, and he'd been focused on other matters. The young Miss Theale’s background wasn't something he could cover in his articles; besides, he was already running into too many young women like her. They had even become a social phenomenon that he wrote about in his published letters.

He always had his best writing ready for that particular group—the overly assertive, superior young women. Thus, a few hours after lunching with the American pair, he felt a sensation in London that Kate hadn't fully prepared him for. Maybe even more striking was his sudden realization that she had been making preparations of several kinds, yesterday and today. That idea, if he focused on it, caused so much anxiety that he had to try to dismiss it.

Translation

He always kept his most cutting prose for that type—those aggressively confident, condescending young women. So, a few hours after his lunch with the American duo, a feeling washed over him in London that Kate hadn’t quite prepared him for. Perhaps even more unnerving was his sudden awareness that she'd been actively preparing things, yesterday and today. The thought, if he allowed himself to dwell on it, provoked such unease that he had to force it from his mind.

He shook off his suspicion somewhat by taking a long, wandering walk after they'd separated from their hostesses and then from each other. He planned to go to the office later, but he had two or three hours to spare, and he told himself it was because he’d eaten too much. After Kate had asked him to put her in a cab—a decision she had announced and resumed, which he was finding himself disliking—he stood for a while on a corner, gazing vaguely at London. There was always a moment for the returned absentee, the moment of the first emotion’s return, when it became clear that he was back.

Translation

He partially dismissed his suspicions with a long, aimless walk after they'd left their hostesses and then each other. He’d intended to go to the office later, but he had two or three hours free. He told himself it was because he’d overeaten. After Kate had asked him to take a cab—a decision she’d announced and was repeating, which he was beginning to resent—he stood on a corner for a while, idly observing London. There was always that moment for the returning exile, the moment of the first emotion’s return, when it was clear that he was back.

His extended absence was over, and he was, once again, a part of the greater narrative, the narrative that, from his street-corner, appeared as a large, grey page of print, somehow crowded without being “refined.” The grey, however, was mostly the blur of a perspective that hadn't fully returned yet, and there would be plenty of color to come. He was back, simply put, back to possibilities and prospects, and the ground he now walked on, somewhat without looking, was the act of reclaiming possession. He walked northward without a plan, without suspicion, quite in the direction his little New York friend, in her restless ramble, had taken a day or two before. He reached, like Milly, the Regent's Park; and though he moved further and faster he finally sat down, like Milly, from the force of thought.

Translation

His long absence was over. He was once more a participant in the broader story, the story that, viewed from his street corner, resembled a large, gray page of text. It was somehow crowded without being "refined." However, the gray was mostly the haze of a perspective that hadn't completely readjusted. Color would soon return. He was back, simply put, back to possibilities and prospects. The act of reclaiming possession was the ground he now walked on, somewhat absentmindedly. He walked north without a plan, without suspicion, in the same direction his young New York friend, in her restless wanderings, had taken a day or two earlier. Like Milly, he reached Regent's Park. And though he moved further and faster, he eventually sat down, like Milly, under the weight of his thoughts.

For him too in this position, be it added—and he might positively have occupied the same bench—various troubled fancies folded their wings. He had no more yet said what he really wanted than Kate herself had found time. She should hear enough of that in a couple of days. He had practically not pressed her as to what most concerned them; it had seemed so to concern them during these first hours but to hold each other, spiritually speaking, close.

Translation

For him, too, in this situation – and it was possible he sat on the very same bench – different anxieties began to settle. He hadn’t yet expressed his deepest desire any more than Kate had had a chance. She would hear enough about that in a couple of days. He had barely pressed her on their primary concern; that had seemed paramount during their first hours together, though all they truly needed was to be close.

This at any rate was palpable, that there were at present more things rather than fewer between them. The explanation about the two ladies would be part of the lot, yet could wait with all the rest. They were not meanwhile certainly what most made him roam—the missing explanations weren't. That was what she had so often said before, and always with the effect of suddenly breaking off: "Now please call me a good cab." Their previous encounters, the times when they had reached in their stroll the south side of the park, had had a way of winding up with this special irrelevance.

Translation

This much, at least, was clear: there was more between them now than before. The explanation regarding the two women would be included, but could wait along with everything else. They weren’t what made him wander, not those missing explanations. She had often said that before, always with the effect of abruptly stopping: “Now please call me a good cab.” Their previous encounters, the times their strolls had taken them to the south side of the park, had always ended with this particular irrelevance.

It was effectively what most divided them, for he would generally, but for her reasons, have been able to jump in with her. What did she think he wished to do to her?—it was a question he had had occasion to put. A small matter, however, doubtless—since, when it came to that, they didn't depend on cabs good or bad for the sense of union: its importance was less from the particular loss than as a kind of irritating mark of her expertness. This expertness, under providence, had been great from the first, so far as joining him was concerned; and he was critical only because it had been still greater, even from the first too, in respect to leaving him.

Translation

Effectively, that was what divided them. He, for her reasons, would have generally been able to jump in with her. What did she think he wanted to do to her? It was a question he'd had to ask. It was a small matter, though, no doubt, since when it came down to it, their sense of union didn't depend on good or bad cabs. Its importance was less from the particular loss than as a kind of irritating sign of her expertise. This expertise, under providence, had been considerable from the start, as far as joining him was concerned. He was only critical because it had been even greater, right from the start, when it came to leaving him.

He had put the question to her again that afternoon, on the repetition of her appeal—had asked her once more what she supposed he wished to do. He recalled, on his bench in the Regent's Park, the freedom of fancy, funny and pretty, with which she had answered; recalled the moment itself, while the usual hansom charged them, during which he felt himself, disappointed as he was, grimacing back at the superiority of her very "humour," in its added grace of gaiety, to the celebrated solemn American. Their fresh appointment had been at all events by that time made, and he should see what her choice in respect to it—a surprise as well as a relief—would do toward really simplifying. It meant either new help or new hindrance, though it took them at least out of the streets.

Translation

He had posed the question to her again that afternoon, prompted by her repeated requests—asked her once more what she imagined his intentions to be. He remembered, as he sat on his bench in Regent's Park, the uninhibited, amusing, and charming way she had responded. He recalled the specific moment, as the customary hansom cab approached them, during which he found himself, despite his disappointment, grimacing at the superiority of her "humor"—its added elegance and cheerfulness—compared to the renowned, serious American. Their next meeting had been arranged by that point, and he would discover how her decision regarding it—a surprise, and a relief—would contribute to genuine simplification. It could indicate either new assistance or further obstruction, though at least it removed them from the streets.

And her naming this privilege had naturally made him ask if Mrs. Lowder knew of his return. He walked north without a specific goal, without any inkling of trouble, following the path his young friend from New York, in her restless wanderings, had taken a day or two earlier. Like Milly, he ended up in Regent's Park; and though he moved further and faster, he eventually sat down, also like Milly, overwhelmed by his thoughts.

Translation

And her mentioning this privilege had naturally caused him to wonder if Mrs. Lowder was aware of his return. He walked north without a clear destination, without any sense of impending difficulty, tracing the path his young friend from New York had followed a day or two before, during her restless wanderings. Like Milly, he ended up in Regent's Park; and though he moved further and faster, he eventually sat down, also like Milly, overtaken by his thoughts.

In this position, it's worth noting—and he might have even sat on the same bench—various troubling thoughts settled upon him. He still hadn't fully expressed what he wanted, just as Kate hadn't found the time either. She would hear enough of that in a couple of days. He hadn't pressed her about what concerned them most; it had seemed so crucial during their first few hours to simply remain connected to each other on an emotional level.

Translation

In this state, it was interesting to observe—and he might even have occupied the very same bench—that several distressing thoughts began to occupy his mind. He still hadn't completely articulated his desires, just as Kate hadn't had the opportunity. She would be hearing about that soon enough. He hadn't pushed her about their most pressing concern; it had seemed more important in those initial hours to just be present for each other, emotionally.

One thing was clear: there were more issues between them now rather than fewer. The explanation about the two women would be part of it all, yet it could wait alongside everything else. They certainly weren't the main reason he was wandering—those missing explanations weren't. That was what she had so often said before, always abruptly cutting herself off: "Now please call me a good cab." Their previous meetings, those times when they'd reached the south side of the park during their walks, always ended with this peculiar, unrelated request.

Translation

It was obvious: their problems had multiplied, not diminished. The story of the two women would factor in, but it could wait, along with everything else. It wasn’t the primary reason he was adrift—those absent explanations weren't. That was something she'd said repeatedly, always abruptly cutting herself off: "Now please call me a good cab." Their prior encounters, when they reached the park's south side on their walks, consistently concluded with this strange, disconnected demand.

It was essentially what separated them, because he would generally have been happy to get in a cab with her, if she hadn't had her reasons. What did she think he wanted to do to her?—it was a question he'd had occasion to ask. It was probably a minor issue, though—since they didn't need good or bad cabs to feel united: its significance came less from the specific loss and more as an irritating sign of her skill. This skill, fortunately, had been great from the beginning, at least in terms of joining him; and he was only critical because it had been even greater, even from the start, when it came to leaving him.

Translation

That was basically the thing between them, because he would have gone anywhere with her, if she hadn’t had her own agenda. What did she think he wanted from her?—he’d wondered aloud before. Probably nothing important, in the big picture—they didn’t need any kind of ride to feel close: the real sting came from how effortlessly she could do it. This ability, luckily, had been exceptional from the start, at least when it came to being with him; and the only reason he was bothered was because she'd been even better, right away, at walking out.

He had asked her that question again that afternoon, when she repeated her request—asked her once more what she thought he wanted. He remembered, sitting on his bench in Regent's Park, the carefree, amusing, and charming way she had answered; he remembered the moment itself, as the usual cab approached, during which he felt himself, despite his disappointment, grimacing at the superiority of her "humor," with its added grace and cheerfulness, compared to the famously serious American. They had made a new plan by then, and he would see what her choice regarding it—a surprise as well as a relief—would do to truly simplify things. It meant either new support or new problems, although it at least got them off the streets.

Translation

He had posed the question again that afternoon, as she reiterated her request—he asked again what she thought he wanted. He recalled, as he sat on his bench in Regent's Park, the casual, funny, and attractive way she had replied; he recalled the moment itself, as the usual cab drew up, in which he found himself, despite his disappointment, wincing at the superiority of her "wit," with its added elegance and brightness, compared to the famously earnest American. They had made a new plan by then, and he would see what her decision concerning it—a surprise and a relief—would do to truly streamline things. It meant either fresh backing or fresh complications, though it at least removed them from the streets.

And her mentioning this privilege naturally made him ask if Mrs. Lowder knew he was back. "Not from me," Kate had replied. "But I shall speak to her now." And she had argued, as with rather a quick fresh view, that it would now be quite easy.

Translation

And her mentioning this privilege naturally prompted him to ask if Mrs. Lowder knew he was back. "Not from me," Kate had replied. "But I shall speak to her now." And she had argued, with a surprisingly quick and fresh perspective, that it would now be quite easy.

"We've behaved for months so properly that I've margin surely for my mention of you. You'll come to see her, and she'll leave you with me; she'll show her good nature, and her lack of betrayed fear, in that. With her, you know, you've never broken, quite the contrary, and she likes you as much as ever. We're leaving town; it will be the end; just now therefore it's nothing to ask.

Translation

"We've been so well-behaved for months that I'm certain I can bring you up. You'll come see her, she'll leave you with me; she'll show her good nature, her lack of fear, in that. With her, you know, you've never had a falling out, quite the opposite, and she likes you as much as ever. We're leaving town; it will be the end; so it's nothing to ask, right now."

I'll ask to-night," Kate had wound up, "and if you'll leave it to me—my cleverness, I assure you, has grown infernal—I'll make it all right." "Not from me," Kate had replied. "But I will talk to her now." She had reasoned with a surprisingly fresh perspective that it would be simple. "We've been so well-behaved for months that I can certainly bring you up.

Translation

"I'll ask tonight," Kate had concluded, "and if you leave it to me—my cleverness, I assure you, has become utterly diabolical—I'll fix everything." "Not from me," Kate had responded. "But I will speak to her immediately." She had reasoned, with a surprisingly clear understanding, that it would be easy. "We've been so well-behaved for months that I can definitely bring you up.

You'll visit her, and she'll leave you with me. She'll demonstrate her kindness, her lack of obvious fear, through that. You've never had a falling out with her, quite the opposite, and she still likes you. We're leaving town soon; this will be the end.

Translation

You'll go see her, and she'll send you over to me. She'll show her kindness, the fact that she isn't obviously afraid, by doing that. You haven't had any problems with her, actually it's the opposite, and she still likes you. We're getting out of here soon; this is the finish.

So asking now is easy. I'll ask tonight," Kate concluded, "and if you trust me—my cleverness, I assure you, has become incredibly sharp—I'll fix everything." He had of course thus left it to her and he was wondering more about it now than he had wondered there in Brook Street. He repeated to himself that if it wasn't in the line of triumph it was in the line of muddle.

Translation

"So, it's easy to ask now. I'll ask tonight," Kate finished, "and if you trust me—my cleverness, I assure you, has become incredibly sharp—I'll fix everything." Of course, he'd left it to her. Now he was wondering more about it than he had in Brook Street. He repeated to himself that if it wasn't a triumph, it was a mess.

This indeed, no doubt, was as a part of his wonder for still other questions. Kate had really got off without meeting his little challenge about the terms of their intercourse with her dear Milly. Her dear Milly, it was sensible, was somehow in the picture. Her dear Milly, popping up in his absence, occupied—he couldn't have said quite why he felt it—more of the foreground than one would have expected her in advance to find clear.

Translation

This, no doubt, was part of his wondering about other questions. Kate had truly avoided his little challenge concerning the terms of their dealings with her dear Milly. His dear Milly, it made sense, was somehow in the picture. Her dear Milly, appearing in his absence, occupied—though he couldn't say precisely why he felt this—more of the foreground than he'd have anticipated.

She took up room, and it was almost as if room had been made for her. Kate had appeared to take for granted he would know why it had been made; but that was just the point. It was a foreground in which he himself, in which his connexion with Kate, scarce enjoyed a space to turn round. But Miss Theale was perhaps at the present juncture a possibility of the same sort as the softened, if not the squared, Aunt Maud.

Translation

She took up space, and it was almost as if space had been created for her. Kate seemed to assume he understood why it had been created; but that was precisely the issue. It was a foreground in which he himself, in which his connection with Kate, barely had room to maneuver. But Miss Theale was, perhaps at the moment, a possibility of the same kind as the softened, if not the placid, Aunt Maud.

It might be true of her also that if she weren't a bore she'd be a convenience. It rolled over him of a sudden, after he had resumed his walk, that this might easily be what Kate had meant. The charming girl adored her—Densher had for himself made out that—and would protect, would lend a hand, to their interviews. These might take place, in other words, on her premises, which would remove them still better from the streets.

Translation

It might also be true of her that if she weren't a bore, she'd be an asset. It struck him suddenly, after he'd started walking again, that this could very well be what Kate had meant. The charming girl adored her—Densher had come to that conclusion himself—and would protect, would assist with, their meetings. These meetings could, in other words, take place on her property, which would distance them even further from the streets.

That was an explanation which did hang together. It was impaired a little, of a truth, by this fact that their next encounter was rather markedly not to depend upon her. Yet this fact in turn would be accounted for by the need of more preliminaries. One of the things he conceivably should gain on Thursday at Lancaster Gate would be a further view of that propriety.

Translation

That explanation did hold up. It was slightly undermined, it's true, by the fact that their next meeting wouldn't, in any significant way, depend on her. Still, that fact could be explained by the need for more preparation. One thing he might gain on Thursday at Lancaster Gate would be a better understanding of that propriety.

He had, of course, entrusted the situation to her, and he was thinking about it more now than he had been in Brook Street. He told himself that if it wasn't a triumph, it was a mess. This was, no doubt, a part of his overall confusion, since there were other questions as well. Kate had, in effect, avoided his little challenge concerning their interactions with her beloved Milly.

Translation

He had, naturally, placed the situation in her hands, and it occupied his thoughts more now than it had in Brook Street. He told himself that if it wasn’t a success, then it was a failure. No doubt this was due to his general state of confusion, as other issues were also coming to mind. Kate had, in essence, sidestepped his small test regarding their dealings with the adored Milly.

Her dear Milly, reasonably, was somehow involved. Her dear Milly, appearing while he was away, was, for reasons he couldn't quite explain, more prominent than he would have predicted. She took up space, and it was almost as if space had been created for her. Kate seemed to assume he would understand why this space was created, but that was the issue.

Translation

His beloved Milly was involved somehow, that much was clear. His beloved Milly, showing up while he was gone, was, for reasons he couldn't quite put his finger on, more important than he would have guessed. She took over, and it was almost as if space had been made just for her. Kate seemed to expect him to understand why this space was created, but that was the problem.

In this foreground, neither he nor his relationship with Kate had enough room to maneuver. However, Miss Theale might be a possibility similar to the softened, or perhaps the neutralized, Aunt Maud. It could be said of her, too, that if she wasn't a nuisance, she would be convenient. Suddenly, as he continued walking, it occurred to him that this might be what Kate intended.

Translation

In this scenario, neither he nor his relationship with Kate had sufficient scope for action. However, Miss Theale presented a potentiality akin to the softened, or perhaps the neutralized, Aunt Maud. It could be argued that, if she wasn't a hindrance, she would be useful. Abruptly, as he kept walking, it dawned on him that this might be Kate's objective.

The charming girl adored her—Densher had concluded that much—and would protect their meetings, would facilitate them. These meetings might, in other words, occur at her home, removing them even further from the public eye. That was a coherent explanation. It was slightly undermined, truthfully, by the fact that their next meeting wouldn't depend on her.

Translation

The appealing girl adored Kate—Densher had figured that out—and would shield their rendezvous, would make them easier. These meetings could, in other words, happen at her residence, sheltering them even more from notice. That made sense. It was somewhat weakened, frankly, by the fact that their next meeting wouldn't rely on her.

Still, this fact could be explained by the need for more preparation. One thing he might gain on Thursday at Lancaster Gate was a clearer understanding of that arrangement.

Translation

However, this detail could be attributed to the necessity of further planning. A clearer understanding of the situation might be obtained by him on Thursday at Lancaster Gate.

Chapter 2

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
On a Thursday, Kate meets with Densher. She explains that they cannot meet at the house of the American ladies because the ladies are accountable to her Aunt Maud. Densher says their situation is unworkable and must end. Kate tells him that Milly Theale, one of the American ladies, likes him and that he should "make something of that." Densher asks Kate if she will take him "just as I am." He then takes hold of her and asks repeatedly if she loves him. She closes her eyes, and they share a long embrace. Afterward, they continue to discuss their situation. Densher calls their need to be secretive a "game." Kate asks him to leave the planning to her and embraces him again. After the second embrace, Densher agrees to her plan. Kate tells him that Milly is in love with him and will help them because she knows Aunt Maud opposes their relationship. She urges him to visit Milly. Densher questions this, and Kate reveals that Milly does not know that Kate cares for him. Kate explains that she and Milly have never spoken of him, and that Aunt Maud pretends their relationship does not exist. Kate reminds Densher he has to leave. He asks where they can meet, and she again tells him to visit Milly, promising to meet him there. When he asks how they will get privacy, she tells him to "try it and you'll see." Densher asks Kate why she will not come to his rooms. She deflects the question. He then asks if her plan is to make Milly believe that Kate hates him. Becoming impatient, Kate ends the discussion. She signals for him to open the door and walks with him to the stairs, telling him not to spoil what she sees.

It was extraordinary enough that he should actually be finding himself, when Thursday arrived, none so wide of the mark. Kate hadn't come all the way to this for him, but she had come to a good deal by the end of a quarter of an hour. What she had begun with was her surprise at her appearing to have left him on Tuesday anything more to understand. The parts, as he now saw, under her hand, did fall more or less together, and it wasn't even as if she had spent the interval in twisting and fitting them.

Translation

It was remarkable that by Thursday he wasn't completely off base. Kate hadn't come all this way just for him, but she had achieved a great deal within fifteen minutes. Her initial reaction was surprise that he had needed anything more explained to him after Tuesday. As he now understood, under her guidance the pieces did more or less align, and it wasn't as though she had spent the time contorting or adjusting them.

She was bright and handsome, not fagged and worn, with the general clearness; for it certainly stuck out enough that if the American ladies themselves weren't to be squared, which was absurd, they fairly imposed the necessity of trying Aunt Maud again. One couldn't say to them, kind as she had been to them: "We'll meet, please, whenever you'll let us, at your house; but we count on you to help us to keep it secret." They must in other terms inevitably speak to Aunt Maud—it would be of the last awkwardness to ask them not to: Kate had embraced all this in her choice of speaking first. What Kate embraced altogether was indeed wonderful to-day for Densher, though he perhaps struck himself rather as getting it out of her piece by piece than as receiving it in a steady light. He had always felt, however, that the more he asked of her the more he found her prepared, as he imaged it, to hand out.

Translation

She was bright and handsome, not tired and worn, with a general clarity. It was certainly obvious that if the American ladies weren't going to be won over, which was ridiculous, they presented the necessity of trying Aunt Maud again. One couldn't say to them, as kind as she had been to them: "We'll meet, if you please, whenever you'll allow us, at your house; but we're relying on you to help us keep it secret." They inevitably had to speak to Aunt Maud in other terms—it would be terribly awkward to ask them not to: Kate had understood all this when she chose to speak first.
