What Kate understood altogether was, in fact, wonderful for Densher today, though perhaps he felt like he was extracting it from her bit by bit, rather than receiving it in a steady light. However, he had always felt that the more he asked of her, the more prepared she was, as he imagined it, to provide.

He had said to her more than once even before his absence: "You keep the key of the cupboard, and I foresee that when we're married you'll dole me out my sugar by lumps." She had replied that she rejoiced in his assumption that sugar would be his diet, and the domestic arrangement so prefigured might have seemed already to prevail. The supply from the cupboard at this hour was doubtless, of a truth, not altogether cloyingly sweet; but it met in a manner his immediate requirements. If her explanations at any rate prompted questions the questions no more exhausted them than they exhausted her patience. And they were naturally, of the series, the simpler; as for instance in his taking it from her that Miss Theale then could do nothing for them.

Translation

He had told her more than once, even before he was away: “You have the key to the cupboard, and I bet that when we’re married you’ll be the one portioning out my sugar, by the lump.” She had responded that she was delighted he assumed sugar would be his diet, and the home life they envisioned seemed to already exist. The offerings from the cupboard at that moment weren’t, it was true, overwhelmingly sweet, but they satisfied his immediate needs. If her explanations, at the very least, spurred him to ask questions, the questions never wore them out more than they wore out her patience. And they were, in this line of inquiry, the simpler ones; for instance, understanding from her that Miss Theale couldn’t do anything for them then.

He frankly brought out what he had ventured to think possible. "If we can't meet here and we've really exhausted the charms of the open air and the crowd, some such little raft in the wreck, some occasional opportunity like that of Tuesday, has been present to me these two days as better than nothing. But if our friends are so accountable to this house of course there's no more to be said. And it's one more nail, thank God, in the coffin of our odious delay." He was but too glad without more ado to point the moral.

Translation

He simply revealed what he had dared to consider a possibility. "If we can't meet here, and if we've truly exhausted the appeal of being outside and of being around other people, then some small, temporary solution, some chance encounter like the one on Tuesday, has seemed preferable to nothing at all these last few days. But if our friends are so beholden to this house, of course there's nothing more to be said. And it's one more blessing, thank God, on the death of our awful waiting." He was only too happy to draw the obvious conclusion, and to do it quickly.

"Now I hope you see we can't work it anyhow." II It was quite a surprise that, by Thursday, he wasn't far off the mark. Kate hadn't come all this way for him, but she had achieved a great deal within fifteen minutes.

Translation

"I hope you see we can't make this work, no matter what." It was a surprise, but by Thursday, he wasn't wrong. Kate hadn't come for him, but she'd accomplished a lot in fifteen minutes.

She started by expressing her surprise that she seemed to have left him with anything more to figure out on Tuesday. As he now understood, the pieces did fit together under her guidance, and it wasn't as if she'd spent the time twisting and manipulating them. She was cheerful and attractive, not tired or worn, with a general sense of composure. It was obvious that if they couldn't persuade the American ladies—which was ridiculous—they'd have to try Aunt Maud again.

Translation

She began by saying she was surprised he still had anything to puzzle over from Tuesday. As he now realized, everything fell into place under her direction, and it wasn't like she had spent the time contorting or manipulating things. She was pleasant and attractive, not fatigued or stressed, with an overall air of self-possession. It was clear that if they couldn't convince the American women—which was absurd—they'd have to try Aunt Maud again.

He couldn't say to them, as nice as they'd been, "We'll meet, please, whenever you'll allow us, at your house; but we need your help to keep it a secret." They inevitably had to speak to Aunt Maud; it would be extremely awkward to ask them not to. Kate had considered all this when she chose to speak first. What Kate accepted overall was remarkable today for Densher, although he felt like he was getting it bit by bit rather than receiving it all at once. He'd always believed that the more he asked of her, the more she was ready to provide.

Translation

He couldn't say, no matter how kind they were, "We'll come over whenever you'll have us, but we need you to keep it quiet." They would have to involve Aunt Maud; it would be horribly difficult to tell them not to. Kate had thought of all this when she'd decided to speak first. What Kate was allowing, overall, was amazing to Densher today, though it felt like he was figuring it out piece by piece instead of getting the whole picture at once. He'd always thought the more he asked of her, the more she was willing to give.

He'd said to her more than once before he left, "You have the key to the cupboard, and I foresee that when we're married you'll give me my sugar in lumps." She'd replied that she was happy he assumed sugar would be his diet, and the domestic arrangement he described seemed to already be in place. The sugar supply at that moment wasn't excessively sweet, but it met his immediate needs. Her explanations prompted questions, but the questions didn't exhaust either her answers or her patience. And the questions were, naturally, the easier ones.

Translation

He'd told her, before he departed, more than once, "You have the key to the cupboard, and I imagine that when we're married you'll give me my sugar in lumps." She'd answered that she was glad he was assuming sugar would be his diet, and the domestic life he described already seemed to exist. The sugar supply at that moment wasn't overly sweet, but it did meet his current requirements. Her explanations sparked questions, though the questions didn't exhaust her answers or her patience. And the questions, of course, were the easiest.

"Your idea's beautiful when one remembers that you hadn't a word except for Milly." But she was as beautifully good-humoured.

She showed the effect of them in ways less trite. This was what happened now: he didn't think in truth that she wasn't really minding. She took him up, none the less, on a minor question. "You say we can't meet here, but you see it's just what we do.

Translation

This was the situation: he didn't actually believe she was ignoring him. Even so, she'd latched onto a minor point. "You said we couldn't meet here, but look, that's precisely what we're doing. Isn't this just perfect?"

It wasn't to torment him—that again he didn't believe; but he had to come to the house in some discomfort, so that he frowned a little at her calling it thus a luxury. Wasn't there an element in it of coming back into bondage? The bondage might be veiled and varnished, but he knew in his bones how little the very highest privileges of Lancaster Gate could ever be a sign of their freedom. They were upstairs, in one of the smaller apartments of state, a room arranged as a boudoir, but visibly unused—it defied familiarity—and furnished in the ugliest of blues.

Translation

He didn't think she was trying to torture him, either. But still, he'd had to come to the house feeling somewhat uneasy, so he frowned slightly when she called it a luxury. Didn't it feel a little bit like returning to a state of being trapped? The chains might be hidden and polished, but he knew instinctively that even the most extravagant perks of Lancaster Gate could never truly mean they were free. They were upstairs, in one of the smaller, more formal rooms, a space styled as a boudoir, but clearly untouched—it resisted any sense of comfort—and decorated in the most dreadful shades of blue.

He had immediately looked with interest at the closed doors, and Kate had met his interest with the assurance that it was all right, that Aunt Maud did them justice—so far, that was, as this particular time was concerned; that they should be alone and have nothing to fear. But the fresh allusion to this that he had drawn from her acted on him now more directly, brought him closer still to the question. They were alone—it was all right: he took in anew the shut doors and the permitted privacy, the solid stillness of the great house. They connected themselves on the spot with something made doubly vivid in him by the whole present play of her charming strong will.

Translation

He'd immediately glanced with interest at the closed doors, and Kate had met his interest with the assurance that everything was fine, that Aunt Maud did them justice—at least, so far as this particular moment was concerned; that they were to be alone and had nothing to fear. But the renewed reference to this, which he'd gleaned from her, affected him more directly now, drawing him closer still to the question. They were alone—it was all right: he took in anew the shut doors and the permitted privacy, the solid stillness of the great house. They connected themselves on the spot with something made doubly vivid in him by the whole present force of her charming will.

What it amounted to was that he couldn't have her—hanged if he could!—evasive. He couldn't and he wouldn't—wouldn't have her inconvenient and elusive. He didn't want her deeper than himself, fine as it might be as wit or as character; he wanted to keep her where their communications would be straight and easy and their intercourse independent. The effect of this was to make him say in a moment: "Will you take me just as I am?"

Translation

What it came down to was that he couldn't have her—he just couldn't!—she was too evasive. He couldn't and he wouldn't—wouldn't have her be inconvenient and elusive. He didn't want her to be more complex than he was, even if she had a brilliant mind or an interesting personality; he wanted to keep her where their conversations would be straightforward and their relationship uncomplicated. The consequence of all this was that he blurted out, "Will you take me just as I am?"

He didn't think she meant to torment him—again, he didn't believe that. But he had to visit her at the house feeling somewhat uncomfortable, so he frowned a little at her calling it a luxury. Wasn't there an aspect of returning to a kind of imprisonment? The imprisonment might be hidden and disguised, but he knew instinctively that even the most exclusive privileges of Lancaster Gate could never truly represent their freedom.

Translation

He didn't think she was trying to torment him, and again, he didn't think that was the case. Yet, he still felt uneasy having to go to her house, and he frowned when she called it a luxury. Didn't it feel like returning to a kind of imprisonment? The imprisonment might be subtle, but he knew in his gut that even the most exclusive advantages of Lancaster Gate could never truly be their freedom.

They were upstairs, in one of the smaller, formal rooms, a space arranged as a boudoir, but obviously unused—it resisted any sense of familiarity—and decorated in the ugliest shades of blue. He had immediately looked with interest at the closed doors, and Kate had responded to his interest with the reassurance that everything was fine, that Aunt Maud was being fair to them—at least, for the present occasion; that they would be alone and have nothing to worry about. But the recent reference to this, which he had gotten from her, had a more immediate effect on him now, bringing him even closer to the central question. They were alone—it was all right: he took in again the closed doors and the permitted privacy, the solid stillness of the large house.

Translation

They were upstairs, in one of the smaller, formal rooms. It was set up as a boudoir, though clearly no one used it. It refused to feel familiar, decorated in the most hideous shades of blue. He’d immediately turned his attention to the closed doors. Kate had met his gaze with reassurances that everything was fine, that Aunt Maud was being fair to them—at least, for the time being. They’d be alone and have nothing to worry about. But her recent reference to this, the one he’d gotten from her, had a more immediate effect on him now, bringing him closer to the central question. They were alone—it was all right. He took in the closed doors and the permitted privacy, the solid stillness of the big house.

These things connected themselves instantly to something made doubly vivid in him by the whole current display of her charming, strong will. What it all came down to was that he couldn't have her—he'd be damned if he could!—she was so evasive. He couldn't and he wouldn't—he wouldn't have her be inconvenient and elusive. He didn't want her more complex than himself, however refined she might be in her wit or character; he wanted to keep her where their conversations would be direct and easy, and their relationship independent.

Translation

These considerations immediately resonated with something made doubly intense within him by her current exhibition of a charming, formidable will. Ultimately, he couldn't have her—he’d be damned if he could!—she was so elusive. He wouldn't and couldn't—he wouldn't allow her to be inconvenient and out of reach. He didn't want her more complicated than himself, regardless of her refined wit or character; he wanted to keep her where their conversations were straightforward, and their relationship autonomous.

The result of this was that he said immediately, "Will you take me just as I am?" She turned a little pale for the tone of truth in it—which qualified to his sense delightfully the strength of her will; and the pleasure he found in this was not the less for her breaking out after an instant into a strain that stirred him more than any she had ever used with him. "Ah do let me try myself! I assure you I see my way—so don't spoil it: wait for me and give me time.

Translation

Consequently, he asked, without hesitation, "Will you accept me unconditionally?" Her complexion paled slightly, acknowledging the authenticity of his query, which, to his satisfaction, was a testament to the resilience of her will. The delight he experienced was magnified when, a moment later, she responded with an intensity he'd never encountered before. "Please, allow me to try! I promise I understand—so don't interfere: wait for me, and give me time."

Dear man," Kate said, "only believe in me, and it will be beautiful." He hadn't come back to hear her talk of his believing in her as if he didn't; but he had come back—and it all was upon him now—to seize her with a sudden intensity that her manner of pleading with him had made, as happily appeared, irresistible. He laid strong hands upon her to say, almost in anger, "Do you love me, love me, love me?" and she closed her eyes as with the sense that he might strike her but that she could gratefully take it. Her surrender was her response, her response her surrender; and, though scarce hearing what she said, he so profited by these things that it could for the time be ever so intimately appreciable to him that he was keeping her.

Translation

"My dear," Kate said, "just believe in me, and it will be wonderful." He hadn't returned to listen to her tell him to believe in her, as though he didn't already; but he *had* returned—and now it was all upon him—to take hold of her with a sudden intensity that her way of begging him had, thankfully, made irresistible. He took her roughly, almost angrily, and demanded, "Do you love me, love me, love me?" She closed her eyes, as if expecting a blow, but gladly accepting it. Her submission was her answer, her answer was her submission; and, though barely hearing what she said, he gained so much from these things that for the moment, it was incredibly clear to him that he was possessing her.

The long embrace in which they held each other was the rout of evasion, and he took from it the certitude that what she had from him was real to her. It was stronger than an uttered vow, and the name he was to give it in afterthought was that she had been sublimely sincere. That was all he asked—sincerity making a basis that would bear almost anything. This settled so much, and settled it so thoroughly, that there was nothing left to ask her to swear to.

Translation

The long embrace they shared was the end of all pretense, and he took from it the certainty that what she received from him was genuine. It was stronger than any spoken promise, and the name he would later give it was that she had been utterly sincere. That was all he wanted—sincerity forming a foundation that could withstand almost anything. This resolved so much, and resolved it so completely, that there was no need to ask her for any further assurance.

Oaths and vows apart, now they could talk. It seemed in fact only now that their questions were put on the table. He had taken up more expressly at the end of five minutes her plea for her own plan, and it was marked that the difference made by the passage just enacted was a difference in favour of her choice of means. Means had somehow suddenly become a detail—her province and her care; it had grown more consistently vivid that her intelligence was one with her passion.

Translation

With no need for pledges or commitments, they could finally speak. It was as if their questions were only now being openly addressed. Having just spent five minutes focusing on her plan, he recognized that the shift brought about by what had just occurred favored her choice of action. The specifics of how things were done had, in a sense, become secondary—her domain and concern; it was increasingly clear that her intellect and her fervor were intertwined.

"I certainly don't want," he said—and he could say it with a smile of indulgence—"to be all the while bringing it up that I don't trust you." She became slightly pale because of the truth in his words. This, to him, was a delightful balance to her strong will. His pleasure was heightened as she immediately launched into a way of speaking that moved him more than ever before.

Translation

"I certainly don't want," he said—and he could say it with a smile of indulgence—"to keep harping on the fact that I don't trust you." She paled slightly, acknowledging the truth in his words. To him, this was a delightful counterpoint to her strong will. His pleasure increased as she immediately began speaking in a way that moved him more than ever.

"Please, let me try," Kate said. "I promise, I know what I'm doing. Don't ruin it. Wait for me and give me time.

Translation

"Please, let me," Kate said. "I promise, I know what I'm doing. Don't mess it up. Wait for me, and give me a moment."

Please, believe in me. It will be wonderful." He hadn't returned to hear her talk about his need to believe in her, but he had returned, and now it was upon him to embrace her suddenly. Her manner of pleading, as it turned out, was irresistible.

Translation

Please, have faith in me. It'll be amazing." He hadn't come back to listen to her tell him to believe in her, but he had come back, and now it was his turn to suddenly embrace her. Her way of pleading, as it happened, was impossible to resist.

Gripping her firmly, he asked, almost angrily, "Do you love me? Do you love me?" She closed her eyes, as if prepared to be struck, but also grateful to accept it. Her surrender was her answer, and her answer was her surrender. Though barely hearing her words, he profited so much that he knew he was keeping her.

Translation

He held her tight, nearly shouting, "Do you love me? Tell me you love me!" She shut her eyes, as though bracing for a blow, yet welcoming it all the same. Her submission was her response, and her response was complete surrender. Though her words were almost lost on him, he was so rewarded that he knew he could keep her.

Their long embrace ended any pretense. From it, he gained the certainty that what she gave him was real. It was stronger than any vow, and he would later say that she had been utterly sincere. That was all he wanted, sincerity providing a foundation that could handle almost anything.

Translation

The embrace dissolved any lingering doubts. He emerged from it convinced of the genuineness of her feelings. It transcended any formal declaration; he would later attest to her complete honesty. That, above all else, was his desire—a foundation of truth strong enough to weather any storm.

This settled so much, so completely, that there was no need to ask her to swear to anything. With oaths and vows set aside, they could finally talk. Their questions could be openly discussed. He had quickly accepted her plea to follow her plan.

Translation

This resolved everything so thoroughly that no oaths or assurances were necessary. With promises unsaid, they were free to converse. Their questions could be voiced without reservation. He had immediately assented to her proposal.

The difference made by their recent embrace was a shift toward her choice. The means had suddenly become a detail, her domain and her concern. It was clear that her intelligence was intertwined with her passion. "I certainly don't want," he said, with a tolerant smile, "to constantly bring up my lack of trust."

Translation

The aftermath of their recent embrace had steered things in her direction. The method became suddenly inconsequential, her prerogative, and her worry. It was evident that her intellect and her ardor were linked. "I definitely don't want," he said with an amused smile, "to keep harping on my distrust."

"I should hope not! What do you think I want to do?" He had really at this to make out a little what he thought, and the first thing that put itself in evidence was of course the oddity, after all, of their game, to which he could but frankly allude. "We're doing, at the best, in trying to temporise in so special a way, a thing most people would call us fools for." But his visit passed, all the same, without his again attempting to make "just as he was" serve.

Translation

"I should hope not!" she exclaimed. "What do you think I want to do?" He'd actually considered it at this point, tried to formulate what he thought, and the first thing that became clear was the absurdity, when it was all said and done, of their game, to which he could only allude directly. "At best, in trying to temporize in such a peculiar way, we're doing something most people would consider idiotic." But his visit passed, all the same, without him again attempting to make "just as he was" suffice.

He had no more money just as he was than he had had just as he had been, or than he should have, probably, when it came to that, just as he always would be; whereas she, on her side, in comparison with her state of some months before, had measureably more to relinquish. He easily saw how their meeting at Lancaster Gate gave more of an accent to that quantity than their meeting at stations or in parks; and yet on the other hand he couldn't urge this against it. If Mrs. Lowder was indifferent her indifference added in a manner to what Kate's taking him as he was would call on her to sacrifice.

Translation

He was no better off financially now than he had been, or than he likely ever would be. Meanwhile, she, compared to where she had been a few months earlier, had much more to give up. He understood how their meeting at Lancaster Gate emphasized that difference more than meetings in public spaces did; even so, he couldn't hold it against her. If Mrs. Lowder was indifferent, her indifference increased the sacrifice Kate would make by accepting him as he was.

Such in fine was her art with him that she seemed to put the question of their still waiting into quite other terms than the terms of ugly blue, of florid Sèvres, of complicated brass, in which their boudoir expressed it. She said almost all in fact by saying, on this article of Aunt Maud, after he had once more pressed her, that when he should see her, as must inevitably soon happen, he would understand. "Do you mean," he asked at this, "that there's any definite sign of her coming round? I'm not talking," he explained, "of mere hypocrisies in her, or mere brave duplicities.

Translation

Her skill with him was such that she seemed to reframe the question of their continuing to wait, removing it from the context of ugly blue, ornate porcelain, and intricate brass, the elements that defined their boudoir. In effect, she communicated almost everything by saying, when he once again pressed her about Aunt Maud, that he would understand when he saw her, as was bound to happen soon.
