Translation

Meanwhile, she sees you're frustrated, because she knows about Aunt Maud's position. That—"Kate was emphatic—"gives her the chance to be kind to you." "And what does it give me," the young man asked, with a surprising amount of reason, "the chance to be? A complete fraud to her?"

Kate so possessed her facts, as it were, that she smiled at his violence. "You'll extraordinarily like her. She's exquisite. And there are reasons.

Translation

Kate, as if in possession of every detail, smiled at his outburst. "You'll adore her. She's wonderful. And there are reasons."

I mean others." "What others?" "Well, I'll tell you another time. Those I give you," the girl added, "are enough to go on with."

Translation

"I mean, other people."

"What others?"

"Well, I'll tell you some other time. Those I'm giving you," the girl added, "are enough to work with for now."

"To go on to what?" "Why, to seeing her again—say as soon as you can: which, moreover, on all grounds, is no more than decent of you." He of course took in her reference, and he had fully in mind what had passed between them in New York. It had been no great quantity, but it had made distinctly at the time for his pleasure; so that anything in the nature of an appeal in the name of it could have a slight kindling consequence.

Translation

"To what end?"

"To seeing her again—as soon as you can, actually. Which, besides, is the least you can do." He understood the reference, of course, and recalled what had happened between them in New York. There hadn't been much of it, but it had certainly been enjoyable while it lasted. So, any appeal made in its name might have a mildly stirring effect.

"Oh I shall naturally call again without delay. Yes," said Densher, "her being in love with me is nonsense; but I must, quite independently of that, make every acknowledgement of favours received." "And what good does this do me?" the young man asked, trying to be reasonable. "The chance to be a total fraud towards her?"

Translation

"Oh, I'll be sure to call again right away. Yes," Densher said, "her being in love with me is ridiculous; but I still must, quite apart from that, acknowledge the favors I've received." "And what does this do for me?" the young man asked, trying to sound reasonable. "The chance to be a complete fraud toward her?"

Kate seemed to know exactly what she was talking about, so she smiled at his outburst. "You'll really like her. She's wonderful. And there are other reasons.

Translation

Kate appeared to understand precisely what he meant, and so she smiled at his sudden expression of frustration. "You will genuinely enjoy her company. She's a remarkable person. And there are other factors involved."

I mean, besides that." "What other reasons?" "Well, I'll tell you some other time. The ones I've given you," the girl added, "are enough to start with."

Translation

"I mean, beyond that." "What else is there?" "I'll tell you about the other reasons later. What I've already told you," the girl added, "is enough for now."

"Start to do what?" "Well, to see her again—as soon as you can. It's the least you can do, and the right thing to do." He understood what she was referring to, and he remembered what had happened between them in New York.

Translation

"Start doing what?" "Well, see her again—as soon as you can. It's the least you can do, and it's the right thing." He knew who she meant, and he recalled their time in New York.

It hadn't been much, but he'd enjoyed it at the time, so the suggestion of a favor made him feel slightly hopeful. "Oh, of course I'll call again soon. Yes," Densher said. "That she's in love with me is ridiculous, but regardless, I should thank her for her kindness."

Translation

It hadn't amounted to much, but he'd enjoyed it when it was happening, so the idea of a favor gave him a little lift. "Oh, certainly, I'll call her again soon. Yes," Densher said. "That she's in love with me is absurd, but still, I should thank her for her generosity."

It appeared practically all Kate asked. "Then you see. I shall meet you there." "I don't quite see," he presently returned, "why she should wish to receive you for it."

Translation

That seemed to be pretty much everything Kate wanted. "So, you see. I'll meet you there." "I'm not exactly clear," he replied after a moment, "why she'd want to have you over for this."

"She receives me for myself—that is for her self. She thinks no end of me. That I should have to drum it into you!" Yet still he didn't take it.

Translation

"She likes me for me—that's because of who *she* is. She's crazy about me. Can you believe I have to spell this out for you?" But he still didn't get it.

"Then I confess she's beyond me." Well, Kate could but leave it as she saw it. "She regards me as already—in these few weeks—her dearest friend. It's quite separate.

Translation

"So, I'll admit, she's too much for me." Kate decided to just let it go. "She thinks of me as—in just a few weeks—her best friend. It's totally different."

We're in, she and I, ever so deep." And it was to confirm this that, as if it had flashed upon her that he was somewhere at sea, she threw out at last her own real light. "She doesn't of course know I care for you. She thinks I care so little that it's not worth speaking of." That he had been somewhere at sea these remarks made quickly clear, and Kate hailed the effect with surprise. "Have you been supposing that she does know—?"

Translation

"We're deeply connected, she and I." And to confirm this, as if it had just occurred to her that he was somehow adrift, she finally revealed her true feelings. "Of course, she doesn't know I care about you. She thinks I care so little that it's not even worth mentioning." These words immediately made it clear that he had been feeling lost, and Kate was surprised by the effect. "Have you been assuming that she does know—?"

It seemed that was all Kate needed to say. "So, you understand. I'll meet you there." He responded after a moment, "I don't really understand why she would want to see you."

Translation

That was apparently all Kate needed to say. "So, you understand. I'll meet you there." He responded after a moment, "I don't really understand why she would want to see you."

"She wants to see me for who I am – because she likes me. She thinks the world of me. Can you believe I have to explain this to you?" Still, he didn't seem to grasp it.

Translation

"She wants to see me for me, because she likes me. She thinks the world of me. Can you believe I have to spell this out for you?" But he still didn't get it.

"Then I admit she's a mystery to me." Well, Kate could only let it be. "She considers me her dearest friend already, even after only a few weeks. It's separate from everything else.

Translation

"So, I'll say she's a puzzle to me." Kate had no choice but to let it go. "She already thinks of me as her best friend, even though we've only known each other a few weeks. It's not about anything else."

We're close, she and I, very close." And to make sure he understood, as if it suddenly occurred to her that he was completely lost, she finally revealed the truth. "Of course, she doesn't know I care about you. She thinks I care so little that it's not worth mentioning." Those words immediately cleared up his confusion, and Kate was surprised by the effect. "Have you been assuming she *does* know…?"

Translation

We are close, she and I, very close." To ensure he understood, as if it had just dawned on her that he was completely bewildered, she finally admitted the truth. "Of course, she doesn't know I care about you. She believes I care so little it isn't worth bringing up." Those words immediately cleared up his confusion, and Kate was surprised by the effect. "Have you been assuming she *does* know…?"

"About our situation? Certainly, if you're such friends as you show me—and if you haven't otherwise represented it to her." She uttered at this such a sound of impatience that he stood artlessly vague. "You have denied it to her?" She threw up her arms at his being so backward.

Translation

"About us? Of course. If you two are the friends you seem to be, and if you haven't told her something different." The sound of impatience she made then caused him to look completely confused. "You've denied it to her?" She threw her arms up in the air at his hesitancy.

"'Denied it'? My dear man, we've never spoken of you." "Never, never?" "Strange as it may appear to your glory—never."

Translation

"'Denied it'? Seriously? We've never even mentioned you." "Never? Never ever?" "As bizarre as it might seem—never."

He couldn't piece it together. "But won't Mrs. Lowder have spoken?" "Very probably.

Translation

He couldn't make sense of it. "But wouldn't Mrs. Lowder have said something?" "Quite possibly.

But of you. Not of me." This struck him as obscure. "How does she know me but as part and parcel of you?"

Translation

"But of you. Not of me." This seemed confusing to him. "How would she know me except as an extension of you?"

"How?" Kate triumphantly asked. "Why exactly to make nothing of it, to have nothing to do with it, to stick consistently to her line about it. Aunt Maud's line is to keep all reality out of our relation—that is out of my being in danger from you—by not having so much as suspected or heard of it. She'll get rid of it, as she believes, by ignoring it and sinking it—if she only does so hard enough.

Translation

"How?" Kate asked triumphantly. "Because she wants to make it disappear, to have nothing to do with it, to stick firmly to her position. Aunt Maud's position is to keep reality out of our relationship—that is, out of my being in danger from you—by never suspecting or hearing anything about it. She'll get rid of it, she thinks, by ignoring it and making it sink—if she just tries hard enough."

Therefore she, in her manner, 'denies' it if you will. That's how she knows you otherwise than as part and parcel of me. She won't for a moment have allowed either to Mrs. Stringham or to Milly that I've in any way, as they say, distinguished you."

Translation

So, in her way, she denies it, if you like. That's how she can know you without you being connected to me. She wouldn't, not for a second, let Mrs. Stringham or Milly believe that I’ve, as they put it, shown any special interest in you.

"About our situation? Certainly, if you're as friendly as you seem—and if you haven't told her anything different." Her tone expressed such irritation that he looked bewildered. "You haven't mentioned it to her?" She threw her hands up, exasperated by his slowness.

Translation

"About us? Of course, if you're as friendly as you appear—and if you haven't given her a different impression." Her voice held such annoyance that he seemed confused. "You haven't told her?" She threw her hands up, exasperated by his slowness.

"'Mentioned it'? Good heavens, we've never discussed you." "Never, never?" "As unbelievable as it may seem—never."

Translation

"'Mentioned it'? Heavens, we've never talked about you." "Never, ever?" "As impossible as it sounds—never."

He couldn't make sense of it. "But surely Mrs. Lowder has said something?" "Very likely.

Translation

I haven't the slightest idea what she might have said."

But about you. Not about me." This seemed unclear. "How does she know me except as a part of you?"

Translation

But what about you? Not me." It was confusing. "How would she know me, other than as a part of you?"

"How?" Kate asked triumphantly. "By completely ignoring it, dismissing it, sticking firmly to her plan. Aunt Maud's strategy is to avoid the reality of our relationship—specifically, the danger of you—by not suspecting it or even hearing about it. She believes she can eliminate it by ignoring and suppressing it—if she tries hard enough.

Translation

"How?" Kate asked, her voice triumphant. "By ignoring it completely, dismissing it, sticking strictly to her plan. Aunt Maud's strategy is to avoid the reality of our relationship—specifically, the threat of you—by not suspecting it or even hearing about it. She thinks she can make it disappear by ignoring it and suppressing it—if she tries hard enough."

Therefore, in her way, she 'denies' it, if you like. That's how she knows you apart from my connection to you. She hasn't for a moment suggested to Mrs. Stringham or to Milly that I've, in any way, as they say, shown any interest in you."

Translation

So, in her own manner, she “denies” it, if you will. That’s how she distinguishes you from my connection to you. Not once has she hinted to Mrs. Stringham or to Milly that I’ve, in any way, as they say, shown any interest in you.

"And you don't suppose," said Densher, "that they must have made it out for themselves?" "No, my dear, I don't; not even," Kate declared, "after Milly's so funnily bumping against us on Tuesday." "She doesn't see from that—?" "That you're, so to speak, mad about me.

Translation

"And you don't suppose," Densher said, "that they must have figured it out for themselves?"

"No, my dear, I don't; not even," Kate declared, "after Milly so comically bumped into us on Tuesday."

"She doesn't realize from that—?"

"That you're, so to speak, crazy about me."

Yes, she sees, no doubt, that you regard me with a complacent eye—for you show it, I think, always too much and too crudely. But nothing beyond that. I don't show it too much; I don't perhaps—to please you completely where others are concerned—show it enough." "Can you show it or not as you like?" Densher demanded.

Translation

"Yes, she sees, no doubt, that you find me pleasing—because you make it obvious, I think, always too much and too bluntly. But nothing more than that. I don't make it obvious; I perhaps don't—in order to please you completely, as far as other people are concerned—make it obvious enough."

"Can you control whether you show it or not?" Densher asked.

It pulled her up a little, but she came out resplendent. "Not where you are concerned. Beyond seeing that you're rather gone," she went on, "Milly only sees that I'm decently good to you." "And you don't think," Densher asked, "that they figured it out on their own?"

Translation

It gave her pause, but she recovered with brilliance. "Not in your case. Besides recognizing that you're rather infatuated," she continued, "Milly only sees that I'm reasonably kind to you." "And you don't think," Densher asked, "they put it together themselves?"

"No, darling, I don't. Not even," Kate responded, "after Milly's peculiar encounter with us on Tuesday." "She doesn't understand from that—?" "That you're, to put it plainly, infatuated with me.

Translation

"No, darling, I don't. Not even," Kate responded, "after Milly's peculiar encounter with us on Tuesday." "She doesn't understand from that—?" "That you're, to put it plainly, infatuated with me."

Yes, I'm sure she sees that you look at me with fondness—because I think you're often too obvious and straightforward about it. But that's all. I don't display it excessively; perhaps I don't show it enough—to fully satisfy you in front of others." "Can you control how you express it?" Densher questioned.

Translation

Yes, I'm sure she notices you're fond of me—because I think you're often too obvious and straightforward about it. But that's all. I don't make a big show of it; maybe I don't show enough—to fully satisfy you when we're with others." "Can you control your expressions?" Densher asked.

Her answer hesitated, but then she became radiant. "Not when it involves you. Beyond seeing that you're quite captivated," she continued, "Milly only sees that I treat you with proper kindness." "Very good indeed she must think it!"

Translation

Her reply was hesitant, but then she brightened. "Not when it concerns you. Aside from noticing that you're quite charmed," she went on, "Milly only sees that I'm kind to you." "That's exactly what she must think!"

"Very good indeed then. She easily sees me," Kate smiled, "as very good indeed." The young man brooded. "But in a sense to take some explaining."

Translation

"Perfect then. She sees me," Kate smiled, "as being very, very good." The young man frowned. "But it needs some explaining, in a way."

"Then I explain." She was really fine; it came back to her essential plea for her freedom of action and his beauty of trust. "I mean," she added, "I will explain." "And what will I do?" "Recognise the difference it must make if she thinks." But here in truth Kate faltered.

Translation

"Then I'll explain." She felt fantastic, it came down to her core need for autonomy and his beautiful, trusting nature. "I mean," she continued, "I will explain." "And what will I do?" "Recognize the difference it will make if she thinks that." But here, in truth, Kate hesitated.

It was his silence alone that, for the moment, took up her apparent meaning; and before he again spoke she had returned to remembrance and prudence. They were now not to forget that, Aunt Maud's liberality having put them on their honour, they mustn't spoil their case by abusing it. He must leave her in time; they should probably find it would help them. But she came back to Milly too.

Translation

It was his silence that, for the moment, absorbed her apparent meaning. Before he spoke again, she had regained her sense of remembrance and prudence. They mustn't forget that Aunt Maud's generosity had placed them under an obligation. They couldn't ruin their situation by taking advantage of it. He would have to leave her eventually; they would likely discover it was helpful. But she also returned to thoughts of Milly.

"Mind you go to see her." "She must think this is all very good!" "Yes, it is very good. She easily sees me," Kate smiled, "as being very good."

Translation

"Be sure to visit her." "She must think this is all wonderful!" "Yes, it is wonderful. She sees me," Kate smiled, "as being very wonderful."

The young man seemed to be considering this. "But, in a way, it requires some explanation." "Then, I will explain." She was truly in top form; it went back to her core request for her freedom and his beautiful trust. "I mean," she added, "I will explain."

Translation

The young man appeared to be mulling this over. "However, it does require some clarification, in a sense." "Then I will clarify." She was truly at her best; it all stemmed from her deep desire for freedom and his profound faith in her. "I mean," she repeated, "I'll clarify."

"And what should I do?" "Acknowledge the difference it will make if she thinks." But here, Kate truly hesitated. It was his silence alone that, for the moment, took up her implied meaning; and before he spoke again, she had returned to remembering and being cautious. They were not to forget that, with Aunt Maud's generosity having placed them in a position of responsibility, they mustn't ruin their situation by taking advantage of it.

Translation

"So, what's my move?" "Admit it will change things if she actually thinks." But here, Kate genuinely faltered. His silence was the only thing that filled in the unspoken; and before he could speak again, she was back to remembering and being careful. They weren't to forget that Aunt Maud's generosity had put them in a position of responsibility, and they couldn't screw it up by exploiting it.

He must leave her in due time; they would likely find that it would help them. But she returned to the thought of Milly as well. "Make sure you go to see her." Densher still, however, took up nothing of this.

Translation

He would have to leave her eventually; it would probably be for the best. But she also went back to thinking about Milly. "Make sure you visit her." Densher, though, didn't react at all.

"Then I may come again?" "For Aunt Maud—as much as you like. But we can't again," said Kate, "play her this trick. I can't see you here alone."

Translation

"Then can I come back?" "For Aunt Maud's sake—as much as you want. But we can't do this to her again," Kate said, "play her this trick. I can't see you here alone."

"Then where?" "Go to see Milly," she for all satisfaction repeated. "And what good will that do me?" "Try it and you'll see."

Translation

"Then where do I go?" she asked. "Go see Milly," she repeated, as if this would resolve everything. "And what's that going to do for me?" "Try it, and you'll find out."

"You mean you'll manage to be there?" Densher asked. "Say you are, how will that give us privacy?" "Try it—you'll see," the girl once more returned. "We must manage as we can."

Translation

"So you'll actually be there?" Densher asked. "Even if you say you will, how's that going to give us any privacy?" "Just try it—you'll see," the girl said again. "We have to do what we can."

"That's precisely what I feel. It strikes me we might manage better." His idea of this was a thing that made him an instant hesitate; yet he brought it out with conviction. "Why won't you come to me?" Densher remained unconvinced by what she had said.

Translation

"That's exactly how I feel. I think we might do better." His thought on this made him pause for a moment, but he stated it firmly. "Why don't you come to me?" Densher remained unconvinced by her words.

"So, I can visit again?" "For Aunt Maud's sake, as often as you want. But," Kate said, "we can't pull this stunt again. I can't have you here alone."

Translation

"So, I can come back?" "For Aunt Maud's sake, as often as you like. But," Kate said, "we can't do this again. I can't have you here by yourself."

"So, where then?" "Go visit Milly," she replied, offering this as the solution. "And what good will that do?" "Try it, and you'll find out."

Translation

"So, where do I go then?" "Go visit Milly," she replied, offering this as the solution. "And what good will that do?" "Try it, and you'll find out."

"You mean you'll find a way to be there?" Densher asked. "Even if you are, how does that give us a private moment?" "Try it—you'll see," the girl responded once more. "We'll have to make it work somehow."

Translation

"So, you're saying you'll manage to be there?" Densher asked. "Even if you are, how does that give us a chance to be alone?" "Just try—you'll see," the girl repeated. "We'll have to make it happen."

"That's exactly how I feel. I think we could make it work better." He hesitated for a moment, thinking of his alternative, but he finally asked it with certainty. "Why won't you come to me?" It was a question her troubled eyes seemed to tell him he was scarce generous in expecting her definitely to answer, and by looking to him to wait at least she appealed to something that she presently made him feel as his pity.

Translation

"That's exactly how I feel. I think we could make this work better." He paused, considering his other option, but then asked the question with resolve. "Why won't you come to me?" Her troubled eyes seemed to say that it was presumptuous of him to expect her to answer directly. In looking to him to wait, she appealed to something that she then made him feel as his own pity.

It was on that special shade of tenderness that he thus found himself thrown back; and while he asked of his spirit and of his flesh just what concession they could arrange she pressed him yet again on the subject of her singular remedy for their embarrassment. It might have been irritating had she ever struck him as having in her mind a stupid corner. "You'll see," she said, "the difference it will make." Well, since she wasn't stupid she was intelligent; it was he who was stupid—the proof of which was that he would do what she liked.

Translation

It was the way she showed that particular kind of affection that brought him up short. He questioned both his mind and his body about what they could give her, but she returned to the topic of her unusual solution to their problem. It might have annoyed him if he thought her mind was ever closed off. "You'll see," she said, "how much it will change things." Well, since she wasn't stupid, she was smart; it was he who was stupid—the proof being that he would do whatever she wanted.

But he made a last effort to understand, her allusion to the "difference" bringing him round to it. He indeed caught at something subtle but strong even as he spoke. "Is what you meant a moment ago that the difference will be in her being made to believe you hate me?" Her worried eyes seemed to say that he was being rather unfair to expect an immediate answer, and by looking at him as if to ask him to wait, she played on something he eventually realized was his sympathy.

Translation

But he made a final effort to understand, her reference to the "difference" bringing him back to it. He actually seized on something subtle but powerful even as he spoke. "Did you mean a moment ago that the difference will be her believing you hate me?" Her worried eyes seemed to say he was being unreasonable to expect an immediate answer, and by looking at him as if to ask him to wait, she played on something he eventually realized was his sympathy.

It was on this particular kind of tenderness that he found himself dwelling. While he asked himself and his emotions what kind of compromise they could come to, she brought up again her unusual solution to their problem. It might have annoyed him if she had ever seemed to him to be unintelligent. "You'll see," she said, "how much of a change it will bring about."

Translation

He focused on the nature of her affection. As he and his feelings wrestled with the possibility of resolution, she returned to her unorthodox fix. He might have been irritated if she had ever struck him as simple-minded. "You'll see," she said, "how much things will shift."

Well, since she was not unintelligent, she was intelligent; it was he who was unintelligent—the proof being that he would do what she wanted. But he made one last attempt to understand, her reference to the "change" bringing him back to the issue. He grasped at something delicate but firm even as he spoke. "Are you implying that the change will be her believing you hate me?"

Translation

Because she wasn't unintelligent, she was intelligent. He was the unintelligent one—the proof being he would do what she wanted. He made a final effort to understand, her mention of "change" returning him to the question. He latched onto something delicate yet firm as he spoke. "Are you saying the change will be her believing you hate me?"

Kate, however, had simply, for this gross way of putting it, one of her more marked shows of impatience; with which in fact she sharply closed their discussion. He opened the door on a sign from her, and she accompanied him to the top of the stairs with an air of having so put their possibilities before him that questions were idle and doubts perverse. "I verily believe I shall hate you if you spoil for me the beauty of what I see!"

Translation

Kate, however, simply displayed one of her more pronounced fits of impatience at this crude way of putting things. With this, she abruptly ended their discussion. He opened the door at her signal, and she went with him to the top of the stairs, acting as though she had presented their options so clearly that further questions were pointless and doubts were perverse. "I truly believe I will hate you if you ruin the beauty of what I see!"

Chapter 3

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A man named Densher receives a telegram from Mrs. Lowder inviting him to dinner. He arrives at her home to find her alone. Shortly after, Mrs. Stringham arrives, also alone, explaining that her companion, Milly Theale, is ill. Kate enters the room, followed by two other male guests. During and after dinner, the group discusses the absent Milly Theale and her social success. Mrs. Lowder tells stories about it, and the other guests contribute. They question Densher about his role in Milly's "discovery" in America. Mrs. Lowder asks if Milly was as successful in America as she is in London. One guest suggests Londoners have better taste. Mrs. Stringham objects, stating Milly was very popular in Boston. Mrs. Stringham then turns to Densher and tells him he knows nothing about her friend. Densher defends himself, saying Milly was kind to him in New York and notes that Mrs. Stringham was not present at the time. Mrs. Lowder and Kate agree with Densher, and Mrs. Lowder jokes about what might have happened between him and Milly. Densher states he did not gossip about Milly and insists he is not an authority on her. Kate agrees that Milly is not easy to know. She tells Densher that while he may have discovered Milly, the rest of them have "developed" her. Mrs. Stringham insists Milly has not changed. Kate concludes by telling Densher he must accept the new situation on trust, and he agrees. The dinner ends.
One afternoon, Gilbert found her seated on the terrace, sketching in a notebook. He approached her cautiously, as if expecting to be rebuffed. She looked up as he neared, and he saw a flicker of annoyance in her eyes. "May I sit with you?" he asked. Kate hesitated for a moment, then shrugged, gesturing towards the empty chair beside her. He sat, carefully avoiding any physical contact. The silence stretched between them, punctuated only by the chirping of birds and the rustle of the wind through the trees. Finally, Gilbert cleared his throat. "I have been thinking about what you said the other day," he began. Kate did not respond, continuing to sketch in her notebook. "About… the things we talked about," he stammered, his usual confidence seemingly diminished. "And I wanted to…" He trailed off, struggling for words. "I wanted to understand." Kate finally looked up, her expression unreadable. "Understand what, exactly?" "Everything," he replied, his voice barely a whisper. "Everything you want."

He was really, notwithstanding, to hear more from her of what she saw; and the very next occasion had for him still other surprises than that. He received from Mrs. Lowder on the morning after his visit to Kate the telegraphic expression of a hope that he might be free to dine with them that evening; and his freedom affected him as fortunate even though in some degree qualified by her missive. "Expecting American friends whom I'm so glad to find you know!" His knowledge of American friends was clearly an accident of which he was to taste the fruit to the last bitterness.

Translation

Despite everything, he truly wanted to hear more from her about her perspective. The very next opportunity presented him with even greater surprises. The morning after his visit with Kate, he received a telegram from Mrs. Lowder, hoping he could dine with them that evening. His availability felt like a stroke of luck, even though it came with a caveat. "Expecting American friends whom I'm so glad to find you know!" His acquaintance with these American friends would prove to be an accident, and he would experience its consequences to the bitter end.

This apprehension, however, we hasten to add, enjoyed for him, in the immediate event, a certain merciful shrinkage; the immediate event being that, at Lancaster Gate, five minutes after his due arrival, prescribed him for eight-thirty, Mrs. Stringham came in alone. The long daylight, the postponed lamps, the habit of the hour, made dinners late and guests still later; so that, punctual as he was, he had found Mrs. Lowder alone, with Kate herself not yet in the field.

Translation

However, we should add that this worry diminished somewhat, at least for the moment. The immediate event was that, at Lancaster Gate, five minutes after he was scheduled to arrive at eight-thirty, Mrs. Stringham entered alone. The lingering daylight, the delayed lamps, and the customs of the time meant that dinners and guests often arrived late. Therefore, though he was punctual, he had found Mrs. Lowder alone, with Kate still absent.

He had thus had with her several bewildering moments—bewildering by reason, fairly, of their tacit invitation to him to be supernaturally simple. This was exactly, goodness knew, what he wanted to be; but he had never had it so largely and freely—so supernaturally simply, for that matter—imputed to him as of easy achievement. It was a particular in which Aunt Maud appeared to offer herself as an example, appeared to say quite agreeably: "What I want of you, don't you see? is to be just exactly as I am." The quantity of the article required was what might especially have caused him to stagger—he liked so, in general, the quantities in which Mrs.

Translation

He had thus experienced with her several bewildering moments—bewildering, really, because they silently encouraged him to be unnaturally simple. This was precisely, heaven knows, what he wanted; but he had never had it so extensively and freely—so unnaturally simply, for that matter—implied as easily attainable. It was a detail in which Aunt Maud seemed to set herself as an example, seeming to say quite agreeably: "What I want from you, don't you see? is for you to be exactly as I am." The amount demanded was what might especially have caused him to hesitate—he appreciated so, in general, the amounts in which Mrs.

Lowder dealt. He would have liked as well to ask her how feasible she supposed it for a poor young man to resemble her at any point; but he had after all soon enough perceived that he was doing as she wished by letting his wonder show just a little as silly. He was conscious moreover of a small strange dread of the results of discussion with her—strange, truly, because it was her good nature, not her asperity, that he feared. Asperity might have made him angry—in which there was always a comfort; good nature, in his conditions, had a tendency to make him ashamed—which Aunt Maud indeed, wonderfully, liking him for himself, quite struck him as having guessed.

Translation

He would have liked to ask her how likely she thought it was for a poor young man to be like her in any way. However, he soon enough realized he was pleasing her by allowing his wonder to appear a bit silly. Furthermore, he was aware of a small, odd fear of the outcomes of talking with her. It was strange, truly, because he feared her good nature, not her sharpness. Sharpness might have angered him, a state which always offered some comfort. Good nature, in his circumstances, tended to make him ashamed, which Aunt Maud, wonderfully, and liking him for himself, seemed to have completely understood.

To spare him therefore she also avoided discussion; she kept him down by refusing to quarrel with him. This was what she now proposed to him to enjoy, and his secret discomfort was his sense that on the whole it was what would best suit him. Being kept down was a bore, but his great dread, verily, was of being ashamed, which was a thing distinct; and it mattered but little that he was ashamed of that too. It was of the essence of his position that in such a house as this the tables could always be turned on him.

Translation

To spare him, she also avoided conversation. She kept him subdued by refusing to argue with him. This was what she now offered him to enjoy, and his hidden unease was his feeling that, on the whole, it would suit him best. Being kept down was a nuisance, but his great dread was, truly, of being ashamed, which was a separate thing; and it mattered little that he was also ashamed of that. It was the core of his position that, in a house such as this, the tables could always be turned on him.

"What do you offer, what do you offer?"—the place, however muffled in convenience and decorum, constantly hummed for him with that thick irony. The irony was a renewed reference to obvious bribes, and he had already seen how little aid came to him from denouncing the bribes as ugly in form. That was what the precious metals—they alone—could afford to be; it was vain enough for him accordingly to try to impart a gloss to his own comparative brummagem. The humiliation of this impotence was precisely what Aunt Maud sought to mitigate for him by keeping him down; and as her effort to that end had doubtless never yet been so visible he had probably never felt so definitely placed in the world as while he waited with her for her half-dozen other guests.

Translation

"What do you offer, what do you offer?"—the place, despite being muffled in comfort and good manners, constantly buzzed for him with that thick irony. The irony was a repeated reference to obvious bribes, and he'd already seen how little help he got from calling the bribes ugly. That was what the valuable things—and they alone—could afford to be; it was futile for him to try to give a veneer to his own cheap imitations. The humiliation of this helplessness was exactly what Aunt Maud wanted to lessen by keeping him down; and as her effort to that end had probably never been so obvious, he'd likely never felt so clearly situated in the world as while he waited with her for her other half-dozen guests.

She welcomed him genially back from the States, as to his view of which her few questions, though not coherent, were comprehensive, and he had the amusement of seeing in her, as through a clear glass, the outbreak of a plan and the sudden consciousness of a curiosity. She became aware of America, under his eyes, as a possible scene for social operations; the idea of a visit to the wonderful country had clearly but just occurred to her, yet she was talking of it, at the end of a minute, as her favourite dream. He didn't believe in it, but he pretended to; this helped her as well as anything else to treat him as harmless and blameless. She was so engaged, with the further aid of a complete absence of allusions, when the highest effect was given her method by the beautiful entrance of Kate.

Translation

She greeted him with a warmth that returned him from the States, and her few questions, though disorganized, addressed his opinions on the place; he was amused to see the sudden formulation of a plan and the emergence of curiosity in her, as if through a pane of glass. Under his gaze, she came to consider America as a potential setting for social endeavors; the notion of visiting the remarkable country had only just occurred to her, but she spoke of it, after a minute, as her most cherished dream. He didn’t believe it, but he pretended to; this allowed her to regard him as harmless and without fault. She was so absorbed, with the additional support of avoiding any references, that the greatest effect of her method was achieved by Kate’s elegant entrance.

The method therefore received support all round, for no young man could have been less formidable than the person to the relief of whose shyness her niece ostensibly came. The ostensible, in Kate, struck him altogether, on this occasion, as prodigious; while scarcely less prodigious, for that matter, was his own reading, on the spot, of the relation between his companions—a relation lighted for him by the straight look, not exactly loving nor lingering, yet searching and soft, that, on the part of their hostess, the girl had to reckon with as she advanced. It took her in from head to foot, and in doing so it told a story that made poor Densher again the least bit sick: it marked so something with which Kate habitually and consummately reckoned. Kate, however, simply showed her strong impatience with this crude way of putting things.

Translation

The method, therefore, was universally embraced, because no young man could have been less threatening than the one whose shyness her niece ostensibly came to alleviate. This ostensible aspect, in Kate, struck him as extraordinary on this occasion; while nearly as extraordinary was his immediate understanding of the connection between the two women—a connection illuminated for him by the direct look, not exactly loving or lingering, yet searching and gentle, which the girl had to contend with as she approached, coming from her hostess. It took her in from head to foot, and in doing so, it told a story that made poor Densher feel slightly ill again: it highlighted something with which Kate habitually and expertly reckoned. Kate, however, simply demonstrated her strong impatience with this crude way of putting things.

She abruptly ended their conversation. He opened the door at her signal, and she accompanied him to the top of the stairs, acting as if she'd clearly explained their possibilities to him, making further questions or doubts pointless. "I honestly believe I'll hate you if you ruin the beauty of what I see for me!" III

Translation

She cut off their discussion abruptly. At her nod, he opened the door, and she went with him to the landing, behaving as if she’d thoroughly outlined their options, rendering any further questions or reservations moot. "I truly think I’ll despise you if you spoil the beauty of what I envision!"

He was to hear more from her about what she saw; the next time they met, he received even more surprises. The morning after his visit to Kate, Mrs. Lowder sent a telegram, hoping he was free to dine with them that evening. He felt fortunate to be free, even though her message had some caveats.

Translation

He would learn more about her perspective. Their next encounter held even more in store. The day after his visit with Kate, Mrs. Lowder sent a telegram, inquiring if he was available for dinner that night. He was pleased to have a clear schedule, despite the fact that her message came with some conditions.

"Expecting American friends whom I'm so glad you know!" His familiarity with these American friends was clearly an accident, and he was destined to suffer the consequences. However, this concern was somewhat diminished. Arriving at Lancaster Gate five minutes after the designated time of 8:30, Mrs. Stringham arrived alone.

Translation

"I'm expecting some American friends, and I'm so glad you know them!" His prior acquaintance with these Americans was obviously coincidental, and he would have to deal with the fallout. Still, this apprehension was somewhat lessened. Arriving at Lancaster Gate five minutes after the specified time of eight-thirty, Mrs. Stringham showed up alone.

The long daylight, the late lighting of the lamps, and the customary lateness of the hour meant that dinners and guests were always behind schedule. Despite his punctuality, he found Mrs. Lowder alone, with Kate not yet present. He had a few bewildering moments with her—bewildering because they implicitly encouraged him to be unnaturally simple.

Translation

The lingering daylight, the late time before lamps were lit, and the general tardiness of the evening meant that dinners and guests were always running late. Though he was on time, he found Mrs. Lowder alone, Kate not yet there. He spent a few confusing moments with her—confusing because they seemed to push him to be unnaturally straightforward.

This was exactly what he wanted, but he'd never been so openly and freely—so unnaturally simply, for that matter—told it was easily achievable. Aunt Maud seemed to offer herself as an example, as if to say, "What I want from you is to be exactly like me." The amount of effort required to be like her might have shocked him—he usually liked how Mrs. Lowder did things in a grand way. He would have liked to ask her how feasible it was for a young man to resemble her, but he realized he was pleasing her by showing a bit of silly wonder.

Translation

This was precisely his goal, yet he'd never been so candidly and readily—so unnaturally plainly, for that matter—informed of its attainability. Aunt Maud seemed to present herself as a model, as if to imply, "My expectation of you is to become my duplicate." The magnitude of exertion needed to emulate her might have astonished him—he typically appreciated Mrs. Lowder's flair for the extravagant. He'd have liked to inquire about the practicality of a young man resembling her, but he understood he was gratifying her by feigning a touch of naive astonishment.

He was also slightly afraid of discussing things with her, which was strange because he feared her kindness more than her sharpness. Sharpness might have made him angry, which was at least a comfort. Kindness, in his situation, tended to make him ashamed, something Aunt Maud seemed to understand, remarkably, by liking him for himself. To spare him, she avoided discussion as well, keeping him down by refusing to argue with him.

Translation

He also felt a certain trepidation about speaking with her. This was odd, as he was more intimidated by her kindness than her occasional sharpness. Sharpness could provoke anger, which offered a perverse sort of solace. But her kindness, in his circumstances, often induced a feeling of shame, a sensation Aunt Maud seemed to comprehend, remarkably, by accepting him unconditionally. To avoid causing him further distress, she also refrained from engaging in discussions, passively keeping him subdued by refusing to contradict him.

She now proposed that he enjoy this, and his secret discomfort was the feeling that, on the whole, it was what suited him best. Being kept down was a bore, but his greatest fear was truly being ashamed, which was different. It didn't matter much that he was ashamed of that too. His situation meant that the tables could always be turned on him.

Translation

She suggested he enjoy this, and his secret discomfort was the sense that, all things considered, it was what suited him best. Being subdued was a drag, but his deepest fear was genuine shame, which was another thing entirely. It didn't really matter that he was ashamed of that, too. His situation meant that the advantage could always shift to his disadvantage.

"What do you offer, what do you offer?"—the place, however comfortable and proper, constantly echoed with that thick irony for him. The irony referred to the obvious bribes, and he'd already seen how little help he got from denouncing the bribes as ugly. Only precious metals—those alone—could afford to be above such things. So it was useless for him to try to give a false shine to his own cheap trinket.

Translation

"What do you offer, what do you offer?" The phrase, despite the place being so comfortable and respectable, rang with that thick irony in his ears. The irony was aimed at the overt corruption, and he had learned that calling it ugly accomplished nothing. Only precious metals were in a position to be above such things. Therefore, it was pointless for him to try to make his own cheap, insignificant things appear valuable.

The humiliation of this powerlessness was what Aunt Maud sought to alleviate by keeping him down. And as her efforts to this end had probably never been so visible, he had probably never felt so definitively positioned in the world as when he waited with her for her half-dozen other guests. She warmly welcomed him back from the States, and her few, though disjointed, questions about his views amused him. He saw in her, as if through a clear glass, the emergence of a plan and the sudden awareness of curiosity.

Translation

It was the sting of helplessness that Aunt Maud wanted to temper by keeping him in his place. And because her efforts in this direction were likely more pronounced than ever, he'd probably never felt so fixed in the world as when he waited with her for her other half-dozen guests. She offered him a warm welcome back from the States, and he was amused by her few, albeit scattered, inquiries about his opinions. He saw in her, as though through a pane of clear glass, the genesis of a scheme and the sudden bloom of curiosity.

She saw America, through his eyes, as a possible place for social operations. The idea of visiting the wonderful country had only just occurred to her, yet she was already talking about it as her favorite dream. He didn't believe it, but he pretended to, which helped her treat him as harmless and blameless. She was so engaged, with no allusions, when Kate made her beautiful entrance, which was the highest effect of her method.

Translation

She saw America, through his accounts, as a potential venue for her social maneuvering. The thought of visiting the magnificent country had only just occurred to her, but she was already speaking of it as her most cherished fantasy. He didn't believe it, but he feigned agreement, which allowed her to regard him as inoffensive and without fault. She was so engrossed, without any pretense, when Kate made her stunning entrance, which was the most impressive culmination of her strategy.

The method then received support from all sides, because no young man could have been less threatening than the person to whose shyness her niece was ostensibly coming to assist. Everything about Kate seemed prodigious on this occasion, and his own immediate understanding of the relationship between his companions was nearly as impressive. That relationship was illuminated by the direct look, not exactly loving or lingering, yet searching and soft, that their hostess gave the girl as she entered. It took her in from head to foot, and in doing so, it told a story that made poor Densher feel a little sick again: it emphasized something Kate constantly and expertly considered.

Translation

The plan gained traction, endorsed by everyone because the man her niece was supposedly helping overcome his shyness posed no threat. On this occasion, everything about Kate seemed extraordinary, and his own immediate grasp of the dynamic between his companions was almost as remarkable. That dynamic was revealed by the direct gaze—not quite affectionate or lingering, but searching and gentle—that their hostess gave the girl as she walked in. It took her in from head to toe and, in the process, told a story that made poor Densher feel a little sick again: it highlighted something Kate was consistently and skillfully assessing.

That was the story—that she was always, for her beneficent dragon, under arms; living up, every hour, but especially at festal hours, to the "value" Mrs. Lowder had attached to her. High and fixed, this estimate ruled on each occasion at Lancaster Gate the social scene; so that he now recognised in it something like the artistic idea, the plastic substance, imposed by tradition, by genius, by criticism, in respect to a given character, on a distinguished actress. As such a person was to dress the part, to walk, to look, to speak, in every way to express, the part, so all this was what Kate was to do for the character she had undertaken, under her aunt's roof, to represent.

Translation

That was the story—that she was always prepared, for her helpful dragon; living up, every hour, but especially at celebrations, to the “value” Mrs. Lowder had placed on her. High and fixed, this assessment dominated the social scene at Lancaster Gate on each occasion. He now recognized it as similar to the artistic idea, the defining material, imposed by tradition, genius, or criticism on a distinguished actress in a particular role. Just as that person must dress, walk, look, and speak in a way that expressed the part, so Kate was to do the same for the character she had agreed to represent under her aunt’s roof.

It was made up, the character, of definite elements and touches—things all perfectly ponderable to criticism; and the way for her to meet criticism was evidently at the start to be sure her make-up had had the last touch and that she looked at least no worse than usual. Aunt Maud's appreciation of that to-night was indeed managerial, and the performer's own contribution fairly that of the faultless soldier on parade. Densher saw himself for the moment as in his purchased stall at the play; the watchful manager was in the depths of a box and the poor actress in the glare of the footlights. But she passed, the poor performer—he could see how she always passed; her wig, her paint, her jewels, every mark of her expression impeccable, and her entrance accordingly greeted with the proper round of applause.

Translation

The character was constructed of specific elements and qualities—all easily assessed by critics. The way for her to face criticism was clearly to ensure, at the outset, that her appearance was flawless and that she looked, at the very least, as good as she usually did. Aunt Maud’s approval that evening was, in truth, akin to a director’s; the performer’s own contribution was much like a soldier’s, faultlessly executing a parade. Densher, for a moment, saw himself seated in his purchased theater box; the watchful director was hidden in the depths of a box, and the poor actress was in the glare of the footlights. But she succeeded, the poor performer—he could see how she always succeeded; her wig, her makeup, her jewelry, every expression, was impeccable, and her entrance was accordingly met with the appropriate applause.

Such impressions as we thus note for Densher come and go, it must be granted, in very much less time than notation demands; but we may none the less make the point that there was, still further, time among them for him to feel almost too scared to take part in the ovation. He struck himself as having lost, for the minute, his presence of mind—so that in any case he only stared in silence at the older woman's technical challenge and at the younger one's disciplined face. It was as if the drama—it thus came to him, for the fact of a drama there was no blinking—was between them, them quite preponderantly; with Merton Densher relegated to mere spectatorship, a paying place in front, and one of the most expensive. This was why his appreciation had turned for the instant to fear—had just turned, as we have said, to sickness; and in spite of the fact that the disciplined face did offer him over the footlights, as he believed, the small gleam, fine faint but exquisite, of a special intelligence.

Translation

These kinds of fleeting impressions, as we observe them in Densher, occurred and vanished, it must be acknowledged, in far less time than it takes to write them down. But we can still say that there was still time for him to feel almost too frightened to participate in the applause. He felt he’d lost his composure for a moment—so that in any case, he only stared silently at the older woman’s technical skill and the younger woman’s composed face. It was as if the drama—and he couldn’t ignore that it was indeed a drama—was between the two women, primarily between them; with Merton Densher relegated to mere observation, a paying customer in an expensive seat. This was why his appreciation had turned momentarily to fear—had just turned, as we said, to something like nausea; and despite the fact that the disciplined face did offer him, as he thought, a small, subtle but exquisite glimmer of a special understanding across the footlights.

So might a practised performer, even when raked by double-barrelled glasses, seem to be all in her part and yet convey a sign to the person in the house she loved best. That was the situation: she was always ready for her protective guardian, living up, every hour, especially during celebrations, to the high "value" Mrs. Lowder had assigned to her. This high and unwavering assessment dictated the social atmosphere at Lancaster Gate on every occasion.

Translation

A practiced performer, even when scrutinized by peering eyes, could appear completely absorbed in her role while still sending a signal to the person she loved most in the house. That was the reality: she was always prepared for her protector, constantly upholding, at all times and especially during festivities, the high “value” Mrs. Lowder had placed upon her. This elevated and unyielding assessment governed the social climate at Lancaster Gate on every occasion.

He now recognized it as an artistic concept, the essential element shaped by tradition, talent, and scrutiny, in relation to a particular individual, like a famous actress. Just as such a person must dress, walk, look, and speak in order to express the character, so Kate was meant to do the same for the role she played in her aunt's house. The character consisted of specific features and details—all subject to careful examination. Her way of dealing with scrutiny was clearly to ensure her appearance was perfect, and that she looked as good as she usually did.

Translation

He now understood it as an artistic construct. Its fundamental elements were tradition, talent, and constant observation, all applied to a single person, much like a celebrated actress. In the same way that an actress must dress, move, and speak to embody her character, Kate had to do the same for the role she played in her aunt's house. This character consisted of specific traits and details—all subject to careful assessment. Her method of dealing with this scrutiny was clear: she had to be impeccable, looking as polished as she usually did.

Aunt Maud’s assessment tonight was indeed like that of a stage manager, and the actress's performance was akin to a flawless soldier on parade. Densher felt like he was in his purchased seat at the theater; the watchful manager was hidden in a box, and the poor actress was under the bright lights. Yet, she passed—the poor performer—he could see how she always succeeded; her wig, her makeup, her jewelry, every detail of her expression impeccable, and her entrance appropriately greeted with applause. These impressions, experienced by Densher, occurred quickly, though recording them takes more time.

Translation

Aunt Maud's scrutiny this evening was exactly that of a stage manager, and the actress's portrayal was like a faultless soldier on parade. Densher felt like he occupied his purchased seat in the theater; the watchful manager was obscured in a box, and the wretched actress was beneath the bright lights. And yet, she succeeded—the poor performer—he could see how she always triumphed; her wig, her makeup, her jewelry, every detail of her expression impeccable, and her entrance rightly acknowledged with applause. These impressions, as experienced by Densher, occurred with rapidity, though recording them takes more time.

There was, however, still time for him to feel almost too intimidated to join in the applause. He felt he had momentarily lost his composure, so that he only stared in silence at the older woman's professional challenge and the younger one's composed face. It was as if the drama—and there was no denying that it was a drama—existed between them, primarily between them; with Merton Densher reduced to a spectator, holding a costly ticket in the audience. This was why his appreciation had momentarily turned to fear—had, as we said, turned to distress; despite the fact that the disciplined face offered him, he believed, a small, subtle, and exquisite sign of shared understanding.

Translation

However, he still had a moment to be almost too intimidated to clap. He felt he’d lost himself for a second, just staring in silence at the older woman’s professional challenge and the younger woman’s collected expression. It was as if the drama—and there was no denying that it was a drama—happened between them, primarily between them; with Merton Densher diminished to an observer, clutching his expensive ticket in the audience. That was why his appreciation had momentarily become fear—had, as we said, turned to distress; despite the fact that the composed face, he thought, offered him a tiny, delicate, and exquisite hint of mutual understanding.

A skilled performer, even when closely scrutinized, might seem completely absorbed in their role while still conveying a private message to the person they cherished most in the audience. The drama, at all events, as Densher saw it, meanwhile went on—amplified soon enough by the advent of two other guests, stray gentlemen both, stragglers in the rout of the season, who visibly presented themselves to Kate during the next moments as subjects for a like impersonal treatment and sharers in a like usual mercy. At opposite ends of the social course, they displayed, in respect to the "figure" that each, in his way, made, one the expansive, the other the contractile effect of the perfect white waistcoat. A scratch company of two innocuous youths and a pacified veteran was therefore what now offered itself to Mrs.

Translation

A skilled performer, even under intense scrutiny, could appear completely lost in their part while simultaneously sending a private message to the person they loved most in the audience. The drama, at any rate, as Densher saw it, continued—soon amplified by the arrival of two other guests, both of them wandering gentlemen, stragglers in the social whirl, who visibly presented themselves to Kate in the following moments as targets for the same impersonal attention and recipients of the same customary grace. At opposite ends of the social spectrum, they displayed, concerning the "figure" that each, in his own way, cut, the expansive and the contracted effect of the perfect white waistcoat. A motley crew of two harmless young men and a mellowed old-timer, then, was what now offered itself to Mrs.

Stringham, who rustled in a little breathless and full of the compunction of having had to come alone. Her companion, at the last moment, had been indisposed—positively not well enough, and so had packed her off, insistently, with excuses, with wild regrets. This circumstance of their charming friend's illness was the first thing Kate took up with Densher on their being able after dinner, without bravado, to have ten minutes "naturally," as she called it—which wasn't what he did—together; but it was already as if the young man had, by an odd impression, throughout the meal, not been wholly deprived of Miss Theale's participation. Mrs.

Translation

Stringham, a bit flustered and apologetic about arriving solo. Her date had taken ill at the last minute—absolutely unable to come, and so she'd been dispatched, urged to attend with apologies, with profound regrets. This matter of their delightful friend's sickness was the first thing Kate brought up to Densher when they were able, after dinner, to have ten minutes "naturally," as she put it—which was not how he operated—together; yet it was as if, strangely, the young man hadn't been entirely without Miss Theale's presence during the meal. Mrs.

Lowder had made dear Milly the topic, and it proved, on the spot, a topic as familiar to the enthusiastic younger as to the sagacious older man. Any knowledge they might lack Mrs. Lowder's niece was moreover alert to supply, while Densher himself was freely appealed to as the most privileged, after all, of the group. Wasn't it he who had in a manner invented the wonderful creature—through having seen her first, caught her in her native jungle?

Translation

Lowder had made dear Milly the topic, and it proved, on the spot, a topic as familiar to the enthusiastic younger man as to the sagacious older man. Any knowledge they might lack Mrs. Lowder's niece was moreover alert to supply, while Densher himself was freely appealed to as the most privileged, after all, of the group. Wasn't it he who had in a manner invented the wonderful creature—through having seen her first, caught her in her native jungle?

Hadn't he more or less paved the way for her by his prompt recognition of her rarity, by preceding her, in a friendly spirit—as he had the "ear" of society—with a sharp flashlight or two? The situation, as Densher understood it, continued. It soon expanded with the arrival of two more guests, both gentlemen, stragglers left over from the social season. They presented themselves to Kate as individuals to be treated impersonally, and who would receive a similar, routine courtesy.

Translation

Didn't he, in a way, clear the path for her? He'd done so by immediately recognizing how special she was, by introducing her in a welcoming spirit—because he was so well-connected—with a few well-placed remarks. As Densher understood it, the situation persisted. It quickly grew when two more guests arrived, both gentlemen, stragglers left over from the social calendar. They presented themselves to Kate as people to be handled without any personal connection, who would be given the same polite, standard treatment.

They were at opposite ends of the spectrum, with one gentleman exhibiting the expansive effect, and the other the constricted effect, of a perfectly white waistcoat. Therefore, Mrs. Stringham was now presented with a makeshift group of two harmless young men and a veteran who had been appeased. She arrived, breathless and apologetic for having had to come alone.

Translation

One man’s perfectly white waistcoat had a broadening effect, while the other’s had a tightening effect. Thus, Mrs. Stringham was now faced with a temporary group: two harmless young men and a satisfied veteran. She arrived, winded and apologetic for being alone.

Her companion had taken ill at the last moment, and was genuinely unwell. So, the companion had insisted on sending Mrs. Stringham with apologies and deep regret. Kate brought up the matter of their dear friend's illness with Densher, as soon as they could spend ten minutes together “naturally,” as she put it.

Translation

Her companion had been struck by a sudden illness and was truly unwell. That person had, therefore, insisted that Mrs. Stringham attend, offering apologies and expressing deep regret. Kate brought up the subject of their dear friend’s illness with Densher as soon as they had an opportunity to spend ten minutes together “naturally,” as she phrased it.

Densher didn’t. But it seemed, oddly, that throughout dinner the young man hadn’t been completely without Miss Theale’s presence. Mrs. Lowder had made dear Milly the subject of conversation, and it quickly became a familiar topic to the enthusiastic younger man as well as the insightful older man.

Translation

Densher didn't. Yet, oddly enough, even during dinner, the young man hadn't been entirely without Miss Theale's presence. Mrs. Lowder had steered the conversation towards dear Milly, and it became a quickly familiar topic for both the enthusiastic younger man and the insightful older man.

Any information they lacked, Mrs. Lowder’s niece was eager to provide, while Densher himself was regarded as the most privileged member of the group. Hadn’t he, in a way, invented this wonderful woman by being the first to see her, to discover her in her original environment? Hadn’t he paved the way for her by quickly recognizing her unique qualities, by going before her, in a friendly manner—as he had the ear of society—with a few revealing observations?

Translation

Any gaps in their knowledge were happily filled by Mrs. Lowder’s niece, and Densher was considered the most favored among them. Hadn't he, in a sense, created this marvelous woman by being the first to truly see her, to know her in her own world? Hadn't he cleared the path for her by quickly recognizing her special qualities, by going ahead of her—in a friendly way, as he was well-connected—with some insightful remarks?

He met, poor Densher, these enquiries as he could, listening with interest, yet with discomfort; wincing in particular, dry journalist as he was, to find it seemingly supposed of him that he had put his pen—oh his "pen!"—at the service of private distinction. The ear of society?—they were talking, or almost, as if he had publicly paragraphed a modest young lady. They dreamt dreams, in truth, he appeared to perceive, that fairly waked him up, and he settled himself in his place both to resist his embarrassment and to catch the full revelation. His embarrassment came naturally from the fact that if he could claim no credit for Miss Theale's success, so neither could he gracefully insist on his not having been concerned with her.

Translation

Densher fielded these questions as best he could, listening with interest, but also with discomfort. He winced, a dry journalist by trade, at the notion that he'd put his pen—oh, his "pen!"—to the service of private gain. The ear of society?—they were practically implying he'd written a public puff piece for a demure young woman. They were dreaming dreams, he realized, that jolted him awake, and he settled into his position, determined to fight his embarrassment and glean the full truth. His embarrassment stemmed from the fact that if he couldn't take credit for Miss Theale's success, neither could he gracefully deny having played a part in it.

What touched him most nearly was that the occasion took on somehow the air of a commemorative banquet, a feast to celebrate a brilliant if brief career. There was of course more said about the heroine than if she hadn't been absent, and he found himself rather stupefied at the range of Milly's triumph. Mrs. Lowder had wonders to tell of it; the two wearers of the waistcoat, either with sincerity or with hypocrisy, professed in the matter an equal expertness; and Densher at last seemed to know himself in presence of a social "case." It was Mrs.

Translation

What affected him most was that the event had the feel of a memorial dinner, a celebration of a bright, if short, life. More was said about the absent heroine than there would have been otherwise, and he found himself stunned by the scope of Milly's victory. Mrs. Lowder had marvelous things to say about it. The two men who wore the waistcoat, whether sincere or not, showed equal knowledge of the subject. Densher, at last, felt that he understood a social "case." It was Mrs.

Stringham, obviously, whose testimony would have been most invoked hadn't she been, as her friend's representative, rather confined to the function of inhaling the incense; so that Kate, who treated her beautifully, smiling at her, cheering and consoling her across the table, appeared benevolently both to speak and to interpret for her. Kate spoke as if she wouldn't perhaps understand their way of appreciating Milly, but would let them none the less, in justice to their good will, express it in their coarser fashion. Densher himself wasn't unconscious in respect to this of a certain broad brotherhood with Mrs. Stringham; wondering indeed, while he followed the talk, how it might move American nerves.

Translation

Stringham, obviously, would have been the one whose testimony would have mattered most, had she not, as her friend's stand-in, been largely occupied with absorbing the atmosphere. So Kate, who was lovely to her, smiling, encouraging, and soothing her from across the table, seemed generously to both speak and explain for her. Kate spoke as if she might not necessarily grasp how they appreciated Milly, but she'd allow them to express it in their less nuanced manner, in deference to their good intentions. Densher himself felt a sense of shared experience with Mrs. Stringham in this; in fact, as he listened to the conversation, he wondered how it might affect American sensibilities.

He had only heard of them before, but in his recent tour he had caught them in the remarkable fact, and there was now a moment or two when it came to him that he had perhaps—and not in the way of an escape—taken a lesson from them. They quivered, clearly, they hummed and drummed, they leaped and bounded in Mrs. Stringham's typical organism—this lady striking him as before all things excited, as, in the native phrase, keyed-up, to a perception of more elements in the occasion than he was himself able to count. She was accessible to sides of it, he imagined, that were as yet obscure to him; for, though she unmistakeably rejoiced and soared, he none the less saw her at moments as even more agitated than pleasure required.

Translation

He had only heard of them before, but during his recent trip, he'd found them in the remarkable actuality, and now there was a moment or two when it struck him that he had perhaps—and not as a means of avoidance—learned something from them. They vibrated, clearly; they hummed and drummed, they leaped and bounded within Mrs. Stringham's typical organism—this woman struck him as, above all else, excited, or, in the local vernacular, keyed-up, to a perception of more elements within the occasion than he could himself enumerate. He imagined that she was receptive to dimensions of it that remained obscure to him; for, though she undeniably rejoiced and exulted, he nonetheless saw her, at times, as even more agitated than the pleasure warranted.

It was a state of emotion in her that could scarce represent simply an impatience to report at home. Her little dry New England brightness—he had "sampled" all the shades of the American complexity, if complexity it were—had its actual reasons for finding relief most in silence; so that before the subject was changed he perceived (with surprise at the others) that they had given her enough of it. He had quite had enough of it himself by the time he was asked if it were true that their friend had really not made in her own country the mark she had chalked so large in London. It was Mrs.

Translation

It was an emotional state in her that could hardly be just an eagerness to share the news back home. Her dry, New England cheerfulness—he had "sampled" all the nuances of the American temperament, if that's what it was—had its real reasons for finding peace mostly in silence. So, before the topic changed, he realized (surprised by the others) that they had given her enough of it. He himself had had quite enough of it by the time he was asked if it was true that their friend hadn't truly made the mark in her own country that she had achieved so prominently in London. It was Mrs.

Lowder herself who addressed him that enquiry; while he scarce knew if he were the more impressed with her launching it under Mrs. Stringham's nose or with her hope that he would allow to London the honour of discovery. The less expansive of the white waistcoats propounded the theory that they saw in London—for all that was said—much further than in the States: it wouldn't be the first time, he urged, that they had taught the Americans to appreciate (especially when it was funny) some native product. He didn't mean that Miss Theale was funny—though she was weird, and this was precisely her magic; but it might very well be that New York, in having her to show, hadn't been aware of its luck.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder herself posed the question. He wasn't sure what struck him more: that she’d dared to ask it right under Mrs. Stringham’s nose, or her apparent hope that he'd give London the credit for discovering their friend. The man in the less flamboyant white waistcoat proposed a theory: that in London, they saw much more than they did in the States. It wouldn’t be the first time, he insisted, that they'd taught Americans to appreciate certain homegrown products, especially when they were funny. He didn't mean that Miss Theale was funny—though she was strange, and that was precisely her charm. It might very well be that New York, in having her, hadn't known how lucky it was.

There were plenty of people who were nothing over there and yet were awfully taken up in England; just as—to make the balance right, thank goodness—they sometimes sent out beauties and celebrities who left the Briton cold. The Briton's temperature in truth wasn't to be calculated—a formulation of the matter that was not reached, however, without producing in Mrs. Stringham a final feverish sally. She announced that if the point of view for a proper admiration of her young friend had seemed to fail a little in New York, there was no manner of doubt of her having carried Boston by storm.

Translation

There were many people who amounted to nothing back home and were surprisingly popular in England. Likewise—and thankfully, to keep things balanced—they sometimes exported beauties and celebrities who left the British unimpressed. The British temperament was impossible to predict, a conclusion that was only reached after Mrs. Stringham had her final, impassioned outburst. She declared that even if the appropriate appreciation of her young friend seemed to have faltered a bit in New York, there was no question that she had taken Boston by storm.

It pointed the moral that Boston, for the finer taste, left New York nowhere; and the good lady, as the exponent of this doctrine—which she set forth at a certain length—made, obviously, to Densher's mind, her nearest approach to supplying the weirdness in which Milly's absence had left them deficient. She made it indeed effective for him by suddenly addressing him. "You know nothing, sir—but not the least little bit—about my friend." Poor Densher dealt with these questions as best he could.

Translation

It demonstrated the principle that, for those with refined sensibilities, Boston was superior to New York; and the good woman, as the advocate of this idea—which she explained at considerable length—came as close as possible, in Densher’s opinion, to providing the oddity that Milly’s absence had created. She made it even more potent for him by suddenly speaking directly to him. “You know nothing, sir—not even the slightest bit—about my friend.” Poor Densher handled these inquiries as well as he could.

He listened with interest, but also with discomfort. As a dry journalist, he especially cringed when people seemed to assume he'd used his pen—oh, his "pen!"—to serve a personal agenda. Were they talking as if he'd publicly praised a modest young woman in a newspaper article? He realized they were dreaming, which in turn woke him up.

Translation

He listened with interest, but also with unease. As a detached journalist, he particularly winced when people seemed to believe he had employed his writing—oh, his "writing!"—to further a personal aim. Were they speaking as though he had celebrated a reserved young woman in a newspaper piece? He understood they were fantasizing, which in turn brought him to his senses.

He settled into his position, both to manage his embarrassment and to fully understand the situation. His embarrassment came from the fact that he couldn't take credit for Miss Theale's success. Neither could he convincingly deny any involvement with her. What truly affected him was that the event felt like a celebratory banquet, a feast to honor a remarkable, albeit short, life.

Translation

He composed himself, attempting to both hide his discomfort and grasp the significance of what was happening. His awkwardness stemmed from his inability to claim responsibility for Miss Theale's achievements. Nor could he credibly disavow any connection to her. What struck him most was the event’s atmosphere, a festive gathering, a tribute to a life that was extraordinary, if brief.

More was said about the heroine because she wasn't present. Densher was somewhat stunned by the extent of Milly's triumph. Mrs. Lowder had amazing stories to tell.

Stringham or by her hope that he would give London the credit for discovering her.
