Translation

It was conceivable that New York, in presenting her, had failed to recognize its good luck. Many individuals who were insignificant in America were highly esteemed in England. Thankfully, to maintain equilibrium, they occasionally dispatched attractive people and celebrities who didn't resonate with the British. The British were unpredictable.

This point wasn't fully developed, but it did cause Mrs. Stringham to make one last passionate remark. She announced that while proper admiration for her young friend may have been lacking in New York, there was no doubt that she had captivated Boston. It proved that, for the more discerning, Boston surpassed New York.

Translation

The idea wasn't fully explored, but it did prompt Mrs. Stringham to make one final, impassioned statement. She declared that though New York might have failed to properly appreciate her young friend, there was no question that Boston had been utterly charmed. This demonstrated, for those with any real understanding, that Boston was superior to New York.

The good woman, as the spokesperson for this viewpoint, which she expressed at length, obviously, in Densher's opinion, came the closest to providing the missing strangeness that Milly's absence had created. She achieved this effect by suddenly addressing him. "You know nothing, sir—not even the slightest bit—about my friend." He hadn't pretended he did, but there was a purity of reproach in Mrs.

Translation

Stringham's declaration that gave Densher a peculiar pleasure. It was as if she were taking him seriously. He felt a desire to defend himself, but he only gave a slight smile. He was, in truth, almost as ignorant about the girl, who now seemed so remote, as it was possible to be. He was aware of this, and he found he could live with it.

Stringham's face and tone, a purity charged apparently with solemn meanings; so that for a little, small as had been his claim, he couldn't but feel that she exaggerated. He wondered what she did mean, but while doing so he defended himself. "I certainly don't know enormously much—beyond her having been most kind to me, in New York, as a poor bewildered and newly landed alien, and my having tremendously appreciated it." Stringham, I've never forgotten how much I owe her." He paused. Mrs. Stringham's disapproval was softened, but not entirely removed. She gazed at him, and her answer, when it came, was measured. "One can see that, Mr. Marcher."

Stringham, that you weren't even present." "Ah, there it is!" Kate exclaimed with delight, though he couldn't grasp the precise nuance of her reaction at that moment. "You weren't there, darling," Mrs. Lowder agreed, her tone full of conviction.

"Oh, that's exactly my point, that Mr. Densher couldn't have had many chances." And then she smiled at him. "I wasn't gone for long, you know." "You weren't there at all, darling," Mrs.

Lowder agreed, her voice rich and full. "You have no idea," she went on, her mood playfully cheerful, "how far things might have progressed." He could see it was genuinely disorienting for the woman. She had more going on in her mind than any of them did, perhaps with the exception of Kate.

"Oh, the whole point is that Mr. Densher couldn't have had many chances." Then she smiled at him. "I wasn't gone for very long, you know." It made everything, in the oddest way in the world, immediately right for him.

"The whole problem is that Mr. Densher didn't have a lot of time," she said. Then she smiled at him. "I wasn't away for long, you know." That made everything, in the strangest way, instantly feel right for him.

"And I wasn't there long, either." He positively saw with it that nothing for him, so far as she was concerned, would again be wrong. "She's beautiful, but I don't say she's easy to know." I myself also left—went far away to wonderful places where there was much more to see." "But you didn't forget her!" Aunt Maud interjected, a trace of accusation in her voice. "No, of course not. You don't forget such captivating memories.

But I never," he stated clearly, "talked about her to other people." "She'll thank you for that, sir," said Mrs. Stringham with a flushed firmness. "Yet doesn't silence in such a case," Aunt Maud blandly enquired, "very often quite prove the depth of the impression?"

Translation

"However," he declared plainly, "I never spoke of her to anyone else." "She would be grateful for that, sir," Mrs. Stringham replied, her face flushed and resolute. "But doesn't silence in a situation like this," Aunt Maud inquired mildly, "often reveal the true intensity of the feelings involved?"

He would have been amused, hadn't he been slightly displeased, at all they seemed desirous to fasten on him. "Well, the impression was as deep as you like. But I really want Miss Theale to know," he pursued for Mrs. Stringham, "that I don't figure by any consent of my own as an authority about her."

Translation

He would have been amused, if he hadn't been a little annoyed by how eager they seemed to involve him. "The impression was definitely strong. But I really want Miss Theale to understand," he continued, speaking to Mrs. Stringham, "that I'm not some kind of expert on her, not by choice."

Kate came to his assistance—if assistance it was—before their friend had had time to meet this charge. "You're right about her not being easy to know. One sees her with intensity—sees her more than one sees almost any one; but then one discovers that that isn't knowing her and that one may know better a person whom one doesn't 'see,' as I say, half so much." Translation

Kate came to his aid—if aid it was—before their friend could even react to this accusation. "You're correct, she's not easy to know. Stringham said, her face red but resolute. "But in situations like this," Aunt Maud asked calmly, "doesn't silence often reveal the true depth of the feelings involved?" Translation

Stringham said, her face flushed but firm. "However, in situations such as this," Aunt Maud asked levelly, "doesn't a lack of response often expose the genuine intensity of the emotions?" But I really need Miss Theale to understand," he continued, speaking directly to Mrs. Stringham, "that I'm not offering myself as an expert on her life." Kate intervened—if that's what it was—before their friend could respond to this. "You're right, she's not easy to understand.

Translation

"However, I need Miss Theale to understand," he continued, addressing Mrs. Stringham directly, "that I am not presenting myself as an expert on her life." Kate intervened—or perhaps it seemed that way—before their friend could respond to this. "You're right, she's not easy to understand.

You focus on her intently—you see her more than you see just about anyone else; but then you realize that isn't really knowing her, and you might understand someone better even if you don't 'see' them, as I said, nearly as much." The discrimination was interesting, but it brought them back to the fact of her success; and it was at that comparatively gross circumstance, now so fully placed before them, that Milly's anxious companion sat and looked—looked very much as some spectator in an old-time circus might have watched the oddity of a Christian maiden, in the arena, mildly, caressingly, martyred. It was the nosing and fumbling not of lions and tigers but of domestic animals let loose as for the joke. Even the joke made Mrs.

Translation

Stringham, who had the intention of being a guest, feel very sorry. She couldn't keep from saying so. "How extraordinarily hard it is!"

"Very hard," the gentleman accepted. But he didn't appear to be taking pleasure in it. "And it's a great comfort to know that it wasn't my fault."

"Was it hers?"

"Oh, everything is hers." He said this in a tone that was very clear, as if he meant to get it over with, as if it was something he didn't want to elaborate on. The doctor, meanwhile, was holding up one hand in a gesture of friendly restraint.

Stringham uneasy, and her mute communion with Densher, to which we have alluded, was more and more determined by it. He wondered afterwards if Kate had made this out; though it was not indeed till much later on that he found himself, in thought, dividing the things she might have been conscious of from the things she must have missed. If she actually missed, at any rate, Mrs. Stringham's discomfort, that but showed how her own idea held her.

Translation

Stringham was uneasy, and her silent communication with Densher, which we've mentioned before, was increasingly defined by it. Afterward, he wondered if Kate had figured this out; though it wasn't until much later that he found himself, in his thoughts, separating the things she could have known from the things she must have missed. If she actually missed, at any rate, Mrs. Stringham's discomfort, that only showed how much her own idea preoccupied her.

Her own idea was, by insisting on the fact of the girl's prominence as a feature of the season's end, to keep Densher in relation, for the rest of them, both to present and to past. "It's everything that has happened since that makes you naturally a little shy about her. You don't know what has happened since, but we do; we've seen it and followed it; we've a little been of it." The great thing for him, at this, as Kate gave it, was in fact quite irresistibly that the case was a real one—the kind of thing that, when one's patience was shorter than one's curiosity, one had vaguely taken for possible in London, but in which one had never been even to this small extent concerned. The little American's sudden social adventure, her happy and, no doubt, harmless flourish, had probably been favoured by several accidents, but it had been favoured above all by the simple spring-board of the scene, by one of those common caprices of the numberless foolish flock, gregarious movements as inscrutable as ocean-currents.

Translation

Her idea, by emphasizing the girl's importance at the end of the season, was to keep Densher connected to the present and the past for the rest of them. "It's everything that's happened since that makes you a little nervous around her. You don't know what's happened since, but we do; we've seen it and followed it; we've been a small part of it." The great thing for him, as Kate presented it, was that the case was real—the kind of thing one vaguely considered possible in London when one's patience was shorter than one's curiosity, but in which one had never been involved, not even to this small extent. The young American's sudden social success, her happy and, no doubt, harmless flourish, had probably been helped by several chance events, but above all, it was favored by the simple springboard of the scene, by one of those common whims of the countless foolish flock, gregarious movements as mysterious as ocean currents.

The huddled herd had drifted to her blindly—it might as blindly have drifted away. There had been of course a signal, but the great reason was probably the absence at the moment of a larger lion. The bigger beast would come and the smaller would then incontinently vanish. It was at all events characteristic, and what was of the essence of it was grist to his scribbling mill, matter for his journalising hand.

Translation

The huddled group had been drawn to her blindly—they could just as easily have drifted away. There had of course been a signal, but the main reason was probably the absence at the moment of a larger threat. The bigger beast would come, and the smaller would then quickly disappear. In any case, it was characteristic, and its essential nature was grist for his writing mill, material for his journaling hand.

That hand already, in intention, played over it, the "motive," as a sign of the season, a feature of the time, of the purely expeditious and rough-and-tumble nature of the social boom. The boom as in itself required—that would be the note; the subject of the process a comparatively minor question. Anything was boomable enough when nothing else was more so: the author of the "rotten" book, the beauty who was no beauty, the heiress who was only that, the stranger who was for the most part saved from being inconveniently strange but by being inconveniently familiar, the American whose Americanism had been long desperately discounted, the creature in fine as to whom spangles or spots of any sufficiently marked and exhibited sort could be loudly enough predicated. The judgment of others was intriguing, but it kept bringing them back to Milly's success.

Translation

That hand, even then, was already toying with it, the "motive," like a sign of the times, a defining characteristic of the era, of the purely opportunistic and chaotic nature of the social explosion. The boom was the point—that would be the focus; the subject of the process a relatively insignificant detail. Anything was boomable when nothing else had more momentum: the author of the "trashy" book, the beauty who wasn't, the heiress who had nothing else going for her, the stranger who was mostly saved from being annoyingly strange by being annoyingly familiar, the American whose American-ness had long been dismissed, the individual, in short, to whom any sufficiently flashy or noticeable traits could be loudly attributed. The judgments of others were fascinating, but they kept bringing them back to Milly's success.

Milly's worried friend, Mrs. Stringham, focused on this very obvious fact, just like someone watching a young Christian woman in an old circus ring, being gently martyred. It wasn't the sniffing and pawing of lions and tigers, but rather the playful antics of harmless pets. Even the joke made Mrs.

Translation

Stringham’s concern seem less acute, as though she were observing, with an empathetic gaze, the gradual destruction of the innocent. It was all so terribly harmless, and yet it was all going to kill her. Mrs. Stringham was sure of it, and, despite the fact that the show was only just beginning, she could already predict the final act.

Stringham uneasy, and her silent communication with Densher, which we mentioned earlier, was increasingly shaped by it. Densher later wondered if Kate saw this, though it wasn't until much later that he started separating the things Kate might have noticed from the things she must have missed. If she really missed Mrs. Stringham's discomfort, it only showed how focused she was on her own intentions.

Translation

Stringham felt ill at ease, and this unease increasingly colored her wordless communication with Densher, as previously discussed. Densher would later question whether Kate noticed this, though it was only with the passage of time that he began to distinguish between what Kate might have observed and what she must have overlooked. If she truly missed Mrs. Stringham's distress, it only revealed the extent of her fixation on her own objectives.

Kate's idea was to emphasize the girl's prominence at the end of the season, to keep Densher connected to the present and the past. "Everything that's happened since then makes you understandably shy around her. You don't know what's happened since, but we do; we've seen it all, we've followed it; we've been a small part of it." The most compelling thing for Densher, as Kate presented it, was that this was real—the sort of thing one might vaguely imagine as possible in London when their patience was shorter than their curiosity, but one had never actually been involved in. The little American's sudden social adventure, her happy and probably harmless success, had likely been aided by several coincidences.

Translation

Kate’s plan was to highlight the young woman’s importance at the season’s close, to keep Densher anchored to the present and the past. “Everything that’s happened since then makes you understandably reserved with her. You don’t know what’s gone on since, but we do; we’ve witnessed it all, we’ve kept up with it; we’ve played a small role in it.” What was most intriguing to Densher, as Kate described it, was that this was genuine—the sort of thing one might vaguely believe possible in London when their patience was wearing thin but their curiosity was not, yet had never actually experienced firsthand. The young American’s sudden social rise, her joyful and likely innocent success, had probably been helped along by a number of coincidences.

But, above all, it was favored by the simple springboard of the scene, by one of those random whims of the countless foolish masses, a group phenomenon as mysterious as ocean currents. The huddled crowd had blindly drifted toward her—and could just as blindly drift away. There had of course been a reason, but the main reason was probably the absence of a more dominant figure at the time. The bigger beast would arrive, and the smaller one would quickly disappear.

Translation

However, more than anything, it was the situation itself that helped her. It was one of those fleeting trends of the countless foolish people, a collective phenomenon as inexplicable as the ocean's tides. The huddled crowd had blindly flocked to her—and could just as blindly move on. There was, of course, a reason for it, but the main reason was probably the absence of a more commanding presence at the time. The larger figure would appear, and the smaller one would quickly vanish.

In any case, it was a typical situation, and what made it important was that it would be grist for his writing, material for his journal. His hand, in his mind, was already at work on it, the "motive," as a sign of the season, a feature of the time, the purely opportunistic and chaotic nature of a social phenomenon. The phenomenon itself was the important thing—that would be the focus. The individual involved was a secondary question.

Translation

Regardless, it was a familiar scenario, and its significance lay in its usefulness as fodder for his writing, fuel for his journal entries. In his mind, his hand was already at work on it, the "cause," a sign of the times, a characteristic of this era, the purely opportunistic and chaotic nature of a social trend. The phenomenon itself was the crucial element—that would be the primary focus. The individual involved was a secondary consideration.

Anything was boomable enough when nothing else was: the author of the "bad" book, the beauty who wasn't beautiful, the heiress who was only that, the stranger who was mostly saved from being too strange by being too familiar, the American whose American-ness had long been dismissed, the person, in short, to whom any sufficiently obvious and showcased qualities could be loudly attributed. So he judged at least, within his limits, and the idea that what he had thus caught in the fact was the trick of fashion and the tone of society went so far as to make him take up again his sense of independence. He had supposed himself civilised; but if this was civilisation—! One could smoke one's pipe outside when twaddle was within.

Translation

Anything was worth exploiting when nothing else was: the author of the "bad" book, the beauty who wasn't beautiful, the heiress whose only attribute was her wealth, the stranger who was mostly saved from being too strange by being too familiar, the American whose American-ness had long been dismissed, the person, in short, to whom any sufficiently obvious and showcased qualities could be loudly attributed. So he judged, at least, within his limits, and the idea that what he had thus caught in the act was the trick of fashion and the tone of society went so far as to make him take up again his sense of independence. He had thought himself civilized; but if this was civilization—! One could smoke one's pipe outside when drivel was inside.

He had rather avoided, as we have remarked, Kate's eyes, but there came a moment when he would fairly have liked to put it, across the table, to her: "I say, light of my life, is this the great world?" There came another, it must be added—and doubtless as a result of something that, over the cloth, did hang between them—when she struck him as having quite answered: "Dear no—for what do you take me? Not the least little bit: only a poor silly, though quite harmless, imitation." What she might have passed for saying, however, was practically merged in what she did say, for she came overtly to his aid, very much as if guessing some of his thoughts. She enunciated, to relieve his bewilderment, the obvious truth that you couldn't leave London for three months at that time of the year and come back to find your friends just where they were. As they had of course been jigging away they might well be so red in the face that you wouldn't know them.

Translation

As we've noted, he'd mostly avoided looking at Kate, but there was a moment when he wanted to ask her, right across the table: "Tell me, darling, is this supposed to be the great world?" There came another moment too—probably because of something unspoken that hung between them—when she seemed to have answered him: "Heavens, no—what do you think of me? Not in the slightest: I'm just a silly, harmless copy." But what she might have said was lost in what she actually did say, because she came to his rescue, as if guessing what he was thinking. To relieve his confusion, she stated the obvious truth that if you left London for three months at that time of year, you couldn't come back and expect your friends to be the same. They'd been moving around so much, they could very well be so changed that you wouldn't recognize them.

She reconciled in fine his disclaimer about Milly with that honour of having discovered her which it was vain for him modestly to shirk. He had unearthed her, but it was they, all of them together, who had developed her. She was always a charmer, one of the greatest ever seen, but she wasn't the person he had "backed." He made a judgment, within the scope of his understanding.

Translation

She accepted his denial about Milly, considering it alongside the honor of having discovered her, which it was pointless for him to humbly avoid. He had found her, but it was they—all of them together—who had shaped her. She was always charming, one of the most charming ever, but she wasn’t the person he had “supported.” He made a judgment, within the limits of his comprehension.

He concluded that what he'd witnessed was merely a performance of social trends, and this realization rekindled his sense of independence. He had considered himself cultured, but if this was culture—! He could always step outside for a smoke if the conversation inside became unbearable. He had, as mentioned before, been avoiding Kate's gaze, but a moment arrived when he wanted to ask her directly across the table, "My dear, is this really the height of society?" Another moment came, likely due to something that transpired between them, when she seemed to have answered him: "Certainly not—what do you think of me?

Translation

He decided that what he'd seen was just a performance, a reflection of the current social climate. This realization made him feel independent again. He'd thought of himself as sophisticated, but if this was sophistication—! He could always go outside for a cigarette if the conversation got too much. As mentioned before, he'd been avoiding Kate's eyes, but then a moment came when he wanted to ask her, straight across the table, "Darling, is this really the best society has to offer?" Another moment followed, probably because of something that passed between them, when she seemed to answer him: "Of course not—what do you take me for?"

Not in the slightest: just a foolish, harmless copy." What she might have implied was practically the same as what she actually said, because she overtly supported him, as if she had sensed his thoughts. To alleviate his confusion, she stated the obvious truth: you couldn't leave London for three months during that time of year and expect to find your friends unchanged. Having been swept away by the latest trends, they might well be so changed that you wouldn't recognize them. Ultimately, she reconciled his reservations about Milly with the honor of having discovered her, which he modestly tried to avoid.

Translation

"Not at all: just a silly, innocuous imitation." What she meant to say was almost the same as what she did say, because she plainly agreed with him, as if she'd read his mind. To ease his uncertainty, she stated the obvious: you couldn't leave London for three months at that time of year and expect your friends to stay the same. Caught up in the latest fashions, they could easily be so transformed that he wouldn't know them. Finally, she smoothed over his doubts about Milly with the prestige of having introduced him to her, something he humbly tried to downplay.

He had found her, but they, all of them together, had transformed her. She was always captivating, one of the most remarkable people ever, but she wasn't the woman he had "supported." Densher was to feel sure afterwards that Kate had had in these pleasantries no conscious, above all no insolent purpose of making light of poor Susan Shepherd's property in their young friend—which property, by such remarks, was very much pushed to the wall; but he was also to know that Mrs. Stringham had secretly resented them, Mrs.

Translation

He had found her, but they, all of them together, had changed her. She was always captivating, one of the most remarkable people ever, but she wasn't the woman he had "supported." Densher was to feel sure afterward that Kate had no conscious, and above all, no insolent intention in these pleasantries of belittling poor Susan Shepherd's claim on their young friend—a claim that was, by such remarks, very much pushed to the margins. But he was also to know that Mrs. Stringham had secretly resented them, Mrs.

Stringham holding the opinion, of which he was ultimately to have a glimpse, that all the Kate Croys in Christendom were but dust for the feet of her Milly. That, it was true, would be what she must reveal only when driven to her last entrenchments and well cornered in her passion—the rare passion of friendship, the sole passion of her little life save the one other, more imperturbably cerebral, that she entertained for the art of Guy de Maupassant. She slipped in the observation that her Milly was incapable of change, was just exactly, on the contrary, the same Milly; but this made little difference in the drift of Kate's contention. She was perfectly kind to Susie: it was as if she positively knew her as handicapped for any disagreement by feeling that she, Kate, had "type," and by being committed to admiration of type.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham believed—a belief he would eventually understand—that all the Kate Croys in the world were insignificant compared to her Milly. This sentiment, she would only admit when backed into a corner by her own strong feelings—the rare intensity of friendship, the only true passion in her life besides her detached intellectual interest in the work of Guy de Maupassant. She casually mentioned that her Milly was incapable of change, still the same Milly she always was, but this didn't affect the thrust of Kate's argument. Kate was perfectly agreeable to Susie: it was as if she understood Susie's limitations, knowing Susie wouldn't disagree, partly because Kate had "type" and was committed to admiring it.

Kate had occasion subsequently—she found it somehow—to mention to our young man Milly's having spoken to her of this view on the good lady's part. She would like—Milly had had it from her—to put Kate Croy in a book and see what she could so do with her. "Chop me up fine or serve me whole"—it was a way of being got at that Kate professed she dreaded. It would be Mrs.

Translation

Kate later, somehow, found a chance to tell our young man that Milly had told her about this opinion of the good lady's. Milly wanted—she’d heard it from Milly—to put Kate Croy in a book and see what she could do with her. “Chop me up fine or serve me whole”—it was a way of being targeted that Kate claimed to dread. It would be Mrs.

Stringham's, however, she understood, because Mrs. Stringham, oddly, felt that with such stuff as the strange English girl was made of, stuff that (in spite of Maud Manningham, who was full of sentiment) she had never known, there was none other to be employed. These things were of later evidence, yet Densher might even then have felt them in the air. They were practically in it already when Kate, waiving the question of her friend's chemical change, wound up with the comparatively unobjectionable proposition that he must now, having missed so much, take them all up, on trust, further on.

Translation

Kate understood Mrs. Stringham's reasoning, though. Mrs. Stringham, strangely, believed that the strange English girl, with the kind of material she was made of—material that she had never encountered before, despite Maud Manningham's emotional nature—was the only subject to be considered. All of this came later, but Densher might have sensed it already. The feeling was practically there when Kate, dismissing the question of her friend’s transformation, concluded with the relatively harmless suggestion that, since he’d missed so much, he must now trust them all, and continue forward.

He met it peacefully, a little perhaps as an example to Mrs. Stringham—"Oh as far on as you like!" This even had its effect: Mrs. Stringham appropriated as much of it as might be meant for herself. The nice thing about her was that she could measure how much; so that by the time dinner was over they had really covered ground.

Translation

He accepted this peaceably, perhaps as a demonstration for Mrs. Stringham—“Oh, as far as you wish!” This gesture even had its effect: Mrs. Stringham took what seemed intended for her. The good thing about her was her ability to measure how much; that by the time dinner concluded, they had genuinely made progress.

Densher would later believe that Kate's jokes weren't deliberately or spitefully intended to belittle Susan Shepherd's claim on their young friend. Those jokes really undermined Susan's position. But Densher would also know that Mrs. Stringham secretly resented the jokes.

Translation

Densher would later think that Kate hadn't meant her jokes to tear down Susan Shepherd's claim on their young friend, or to be intentionally mean. The jokes certainly did damage Susan's standing. But Densher would also be aware that Mrs. Stringham secretly disliked the jokes.

Mrs. Stringham believed—a belief he'd eventually glimpse—that all the Kate Croys in the world were nothing compared to her Milly. That belief, of course, was something she would only reveal when she was backed into a corner by her intense passion—her passionate friendship, which was the only real passion in her life besides her unwavering intellectual interest in the art of Guy de Maupassant. She casually mentioned that her Milly was incapable of changing, that she was, in fact, exactly the same Milly.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham held the conviction—a conviction Densher would later come to understand—that all the Kate Croys in existence paled in comparison to her Milly. This belief, naturally, was something she'd only disclose when cornered by her own intense ardor—her passionate friendship, which constituted the sole genuine passion in her life, aside from her steadfast intellectual fascination with the artistry of Guy de Maupassant. She'd casually remarked that her Milly was incapable of change, that she was, in essence, utterly and completely the same Milly.

But this didn't change the direction of Kate's argument. She was perfectly kind to Susie, as if she knew Susie was unable to disagree because she, Kate, was "a type," and because Susie was committed to admiring that type. Later on, Kate would somehow mention to Densher that Milly had told her about Susie's view. Milly said she thought Mrs.

Translation

But this didn't deter the course of Kate's argument. She treated Susie with perfect kindness, as though she understood Susie couldn't contradict her, because Kate was "a type," and because Susie was dedicated to appreciating that type. Later, Kate would somehow tell Densher that Milly had told her about Susie's opinion. Milly had said she thought Mrs.

Stringham wanted to write a book about Kate Croy to see what she could do with her. Kate said she dreaded being "chopped up fine or served whole" in that way. She knew, however, that Mrs. Stringham would be the one to do it.

Translation

Stringham intended to write a book about Kate Croy to explore her possibilities as a subject. Kate admitted she dreaded being dissected or presented in her entirety in such a manner. She was certain, however, that Mrs. Stringham would be the one to undertake the project.

Mrs. Stringham felt that because of the strange makeup of the English girl—a makeup she'd never encountered, even in sentimental Maud Manningham—there was no other way to approach it. These things would become clear later, but Densher might have sensed them even then. They were practically in the air when Kate, ignoring the question of her friend's transformation, concluded with the relatively harmless suggestion that Densher should trust them and pick up where they'd left off.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham believed that the unique nature of the English girl—a nature she hadn't found even in the overly sentimental Maud Manningham—required a certain approach. These things would become apparent later, but Densher may have felt them even then. They were almost palpable when Kate, dismissing the question of her friend's change, concluded with the relatively innocuous suggestion that Densher should trust them and continue their prior conversation.

He accepted this peacefully, perhaps to set an example for Mrs. Stringham: "Oh, as far as you like!" This even had an effect: Mrs. Stringham took what she thought was meant for her. The wonderful thing about her was that she knew how much was meant for her.

Translation

He accepted this without protest, perhaps to set a good example for Mrs. Stringham. "Oh, absolutely! Go on, by all means!" This had an impact, as Mrs. Stringham understood the implication. The remarkable thing about her was her ability to gauge precisely what was meant for her.

And so, by the time dinner was over, they had really made progress.

Translation

And so, by the end of dinner, they had genuinely advanced.

Chapter 4

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
After men have coffee and sing songs upstairs, a young man, Densher, and a young woman, Kate, sit together in the drawing room and agree they can meet without causing offense. Later, on a balcony, Densher and Kate sit together on a small sofa. Kate tells him they must interact to distract her Aunt Maud. Kate then informs Densher that another woman, Milly, is unwell and did not attend the gathering. She suggests Milly’s illness is serious and says Milly postponed a trip abroad for him. Densher repeatedly asks what is wrong with Milly. Kate eventually explains that Milly, who is very wealthy and has become a social success, is seriously ill but hides it well. She reveals Milly is seeing a prominent doctor, Sir Luke Strett. Kate asks Densher to befriend and console Milly for the life and fortune she stands to lose. A man named Lord Mark arrives and Kate introduces him to Densher. Lord Mark asks about Milly’s health before walking away with Kate for a private conversation. He then joins the others on the balcony. Kate returns to Densher. He asks about Lord Mark, and she confirms he is the man her aunt favors for her. Kate then tells Densher that she has explained her own unmentioned relationship with him to Milly. Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud) and Mrs. Stringham reappear as the party breaks up. Kate tells Densher he must leave, then goes to speak with Lord Mark in a corner. Mrs. Stringham bids Densher goodnight. Aunt Maud stops Densher and tells him not to neglect Milly, mentioning her charm and immense fortune. She tells him that she and Kate will also travel abroad and that he can visit them there. She then reveals she has told "the proper lie" for him and now depends on him to "make me right." After leaving the house, Densher stops on the street and realizes what Aunt Maud’s lie was: she has assured Milly, through Mrs. Stringham, that Kate does not care for Densher and that his affection is one-sided, thereby deceiving Milly.

The younger of the other men, it afterwards appeared, was most in his element at the piano; so that they had coffee and comic songs upstairs—the gentlemen, temporarily relinquished, submitting easily in this interest to Mrs. Lowder's parting injunction not to sit too tight. Our especial young man sat tighter when restored to the drawing-room; he made it out perfectly with Kate that they might, off and on, foregather without offence. He had perhaps stronger needs in this general respect than she; but she had better names for the scant risks to which she consented.

Translation

The younger of the other men, as it later became clear, was most comfortable at the piano. Therefore, they had coffee and comic songs upstairs – the gentlemen, temporarily abandoned, yielding easily to Mrs. Lowder's parting instruction not to sit too close, in this interest. Our particular young man sat closer when back in the drawing-room; he and Kate understood perfectly that they could meet, on and off, without causing offense. He may have had greater needs in this general regard than she did; but she had better words for the limited risks she allowed.

It was the blessing of a big house that intervals were large and, of an August night, that windows were open; whereby, at a given moment, on the wide balcony, with the songs sufficiently sung, Aunt Maud could hold her little court more freshly. Densher and Kate, during these moments, occupied side by side a small sofa—a luxury formulated by the latter as the proof, under criticism, of their remarkably good conscience. "To seem not to know each other—once you're here—would be," the girl said, "to overdo it"; and she arranged it charmingly that they must have some passage to put Aunt Maud off the scent. She would be wondering otherwise what in the world they found their account in.

Translation

The advantage of a large house was that spaces between rooms were generous, and on an August night, the windows were open. Thus, at a certain point, on the broad balcony, after the songs had been sufficiently performed, Aunt Maud could hold her small court with greater ease. Densher and Kate, during these moments, sat side by side on a small sofa—a luxury that Kate had deemed proof, when scrutinized, of their remarkably clear consciences. "To pretend we don't know each other—once you're here—would be," the girl said, "to overdo it"; and she cleverly ensured they had some interaction to distract Aunt Maud. Otherwise, she would wonder what on earth they found appealing about each other.

For Densher, none the less, the profit of snatched moments, snatched contacts, was partial and poor; there were in particular at present more things in his mind than he could bring out while watching the windows. It was true, on the other hand, that she suddenly met most of them—and more than he could see on the spot—by coming out for him with a reference to Milly that was not in the key of those made at dinner. "She's not a bit right, you know. I mean in health.

Translation

Nevertheless, the value of brief, stolen moments, snatched interactions, was limited and unsatisfying for Densher. At the moment, there were more things on his mind than he could express while looking out at the windows. On the other hand, it was true that Kate instantly addressed most of his concerns—and more than he could have anticipated—by bringing up Milly in a way that didn't fit the tone of their dinner conversation. "She isn't well at all, you know. I mean, in terms of her health."

Just see her to-night. I mean it looks grave. For you she would have come, you know, if it had been at all possible." IV

Translation

See her tonight. It’s serious. For you, she would have come, you know, if it had been at all possible.

The younger of the other men, as it turned out, was most comfortable when he was playing the piano. They went upstairs for coffee and humorous songs—the gentlemen, temporarily forgotten, readily agreed to Mrs. Lowder's departing instruction to not stay up too late. Our particular young man sat closer to Kate when they were back in the drawing-room; he and Kate both understood that they could occasionally meet without causing any trouble.

Translation

The younger of the two other men, as it happened, was most at ease when he was at the piano. They went upstairs for coffee and a round of humorous songs—the gentlemen, temporarily left to their own devices, readily assented to Mrs. Lowder’s parting instruction to retire early. Our young man in particular sat closer to Kate once they were back in the drawing-room; he and Kate both knew they could meet from time to time without causing any difficulties.

Perhaps he had a greater need for this than she did, but she had better justifications for the small risks she was taking. It was the benefit of a large house that there was plenty of space, and, on an August night, that the windows were open. In this way, at a certain time, on the wide balcony, with the songs having ended, Aunt Maud could host her small gathering with a fresher atmosphere. During these times, Densher and Kate sat together on a small sofa—a comfort that Kate explained as proof of their remarkably clear consciences.

Translation

Maybe he needed it more, but her reasons for taking these small chances were better. The advantage of a big house was the extra room, and, on an August night, the open windows. That way, at a certain time, on the wide balcony, after the songs were over, Aunt Maud could host her small gathering with a fresher feel. During these times, Densher and Kate sat together on a small sofa—a comfort Kate said was proof of their remarkably clear consciences.

"To act like we don't know each other—once you're here—would be," the girl said, "to overdo it"; and she cleverly arranged things so that they would have some way of distracting Aunt Maud. Otherwise, Aunt Maud would wonder what they were getting out of it. However, for Densher, the advantage of these stolen moments was incomplete and inadequate; there were more things on his mind than he could express while watching the windows. It was true, on the other hand, that she suddenly addressed most of those thoughts—and more than he could see at that moment—by bringing up Milly in a way that was different from the way she was spoken about at dinner.

Translation

"To pretend we don't know each other—once you're here—would be," the girl said, "too much"; and she cleverly devised a way for them to distract Aunt Maud. Otherwise, Aunt Maud would question their motives. But for Densher, the value of these private moments was limited and insufficient; he had more on his mind than he could articulate while staring at the windows. It was true, on the other hand, that she unexpectedly addressed many of those thoughts—and more than he could perceive at that moment—by bringing up Milly in a way that differed from their dinner conversations.

"She's not at all well, you know. I mean, her health. Just look at her tonight. I mean, it looks serious.

Translation

"She's really not doing well, you know. I mean, her health. Just look at her tonight. I mean, it seems serious."

She would have come for you, you know, if it had been at all possible." He took this in such patience as he could muster. "What in the world's the matter with her?" But Kate continued without saying.

Translation

"She would have come for you, you know, if it were even remotely feasible." He absorbed this with as much restraint as he could manage. "What on earth is wrong with her?" But Kate pressed on without responding.

"Unless indeed your being here has been just a reason for her funking it." "What in the world's the matter with her?" Densher asked again. "Why just what I've told you—that she likes you so much." "Then why should she deny herself the joy of meeting me?"

Translation

"Unless, of course, your presence here was just an excuse for her to chicken out." "What in the world is wrong with her?" Densher asked again. "Why, just what I've told you—that she likes you so much." "Then why should she deny herself the joy of meeting me?"

Kate cast about—it would take so long to explain. "And perhaps it's true that she is bad. She easily may be." "Quite easily, I should say, judging by Mrs.

Translation

Kate considered—it would be a lengthy explanation. "And perhaps it’s true that she’s a bad person. It's quite possible." "Extremely possible, I'd say, judging by Mrs.

Stringham, who's visibly preoccupied and worried." "Visibly enough. Yet it mayn't," said Kate, "be only for that." "For what then?"

Translation

Stringham, who looks deeply troubled and worried." "Troubled, certainly. But it might not," Kate said, "be just because of that." "Because of what, then?"

But this question too, on thinking, she neglected. "Why, if it's anything real, doesn't that poor lady go home? She'd be anxious, and she has done all she need to be civil." He endured this as patiently as he could.

Translation

But upon reflection, she disregarded this question as well. "Why doesn't that poor woman, if there's anything to it, just go home? She must be worried, and she's done everything necessary to be polite." He bore this as patiently as possible.

"What's wrong with her?" But Kate kept talking without answering. "Unless, of course, your presence here has just caused her to back out." "What's wrong with her?" Densher repeated.

Translation

"What's wrong with her?" But Kate continued speaking, ignoring him. "Unless, of course, your being here has just made her want to quit." "What's wrong with her?" Densher asked again.

"Just what I told you—she likes you a lot." "Then why would she deprive herself of the pleasure of meeting me?" Kate hesitated—it would take too long to explain. "And perhaps it's true she's ill.

"Just what I said—she's really into you." "Then why wouldn't she want to meet me?" Kate paused—it would take too long to go into it. "And maybe she's actually sick."

Translation

"She's clearly nervous, and she's been accommodating long enough." "I think," Densher observed, "that she's been remarkably courteous." One of them would make her hurry back, but the other makes her stay. She's commissioned to tell Milly all about you." "Well then," said the young man between a laugh and a sigh, "I'm glad I felt, downstairs, a kind of 'drawing' to her. Wasn't I rather decent to her?"

Translation

One of these concerns would make her want to leave, while the other keeps her here. She's been hired to tell Milly everything about you." Stringham seems to respond just to create that impression." "Well," Densher said with some humor, "life is very interesting! Translation

Translation

I trust that you find it as captivating as you present it to others, and especially to me. You seem to paint it as exciting for those women, and in distinct ways for each: Aunt Maud, Susan Shepherd, Milly. But," he concluded, "what's the issue? Do you mean she's actually as ill as she appears?"

Kate's face struck him as replying at first that his derisive speech deserved no satisfaction; then she appeared to yield to a need of her own—the need to make the point that "as ill as she looked" was what Milly scarce could be. If she had been as ill as she looked she could scarce be a question with them, for her end would in that case be near. She believed herself nevertheless—and Kate couldn't help believing her too—seriously menaced. There was always the fact that they had been on the point of leaving town, the two ladies, and had suddenly been pulled up.

Translation

Kate's expression seemed to initially suggest his mocking words were unworthy of a response. Then, she seemed to give in to an inner compulsion—the need to clarify that Milly was, in fact, not as ill as she appeared. If Milly were truly as sick as she looked, then her condition would be beyond debate, and her time would be short. Kate still believed—and couldn't help but believe—that Milly was seriously threatened. There was also the undeniable fact that the two women had been preparing to leave town, and then abruptly changed their plans.

"We bade them good-bye—or all but—Aunt Maud and I, the night before Milly, popping so very oddly into the National Gallery for a farewell look, found you and me together. They were then to get off a day or two later. But they've not got off—they're not getting off. When I see them—and I saw them this morning—they have showy reasons.

Translation

"We said goodbye—or almost—to Aunt Maud and me the night before Milly, rather strangely, popped into the National Gallery for a farewell look, where she found you and me together. They were supposed to leave a day or two later. But they haven't left—they aren't leaving. When I see them—and I saw them this morning—they give ostentatious reasons."

They do mean to go, but they've postponed it." With which the girl brought out: "They've postponed it for you." He protested so far as a man might without fatuity, since a protest was itself credulous; but Kate, as ever, understood herself. "You've made Milly change her mind. She wants not to miss you—though she wants also not to show she wants you; which is why, as I hinted a moment ago, she may consciously have hung back to-night. She doesn't know when she may see you again—she doesn't know she ever may.

Translation

"They do intend to leave, but they've postponed it." With that, the girl announced, "They've postponed it for you." He protested, as much as a man could without seeming vain, since any protest implied belief. But Kate, as usual, understood. "You've caused Milly to change her plans. If Milly was as ill as she appeared, her time with them was finite; her death was imminent. Nevertheless, Milly felt gravely imperiled, and Kate couldn't help but share this feeling. Translation

They were meant to depart in a day or two. But they haven't. And they won't. When I see them—and I did this morning—they offer detailed explanations. They insist that they still intend to leave, but they've pushed it back.” Then the girl stated, “They’ve postponed it because of you.”

He objected as much as he could without appearing vain, since any protest implied he believed her; but Kate, as always, understood the situation perfectly. "You've made Milly change her plans. Translation

Translation

"But please, let her have her adventures. Some disasters aren't adventures." "Well—if there are also adventures that aren't disasters!" Densher conceded, but circled back to his point. Translation

Translation

She won't slowly live. She won't smell of medicine. She won't taste like it. No one will know.

"Then what," he demanded, frankly mystified now, "are we talking about? In what extraordinary state is she?" Kate went on as if, at this, making it out in a fashion for herself. "I believe that if she's ill at all she's very ill.

Translation

"So then," he asked, now completely baffled, "what exactly are we discussing? What kind of impossible condition is she in?" Kate continued as if she were figuring it out for herself. "I think that if she's sick at all, she's very sick."

I believe that if she's bad she's not a little bad. I can't tell you why, but that's how I see her. She'll really live or she'll really not. She'll have it all or she'll miss it all.

Translation

I believe that if she's unwell, she's seriously unwell. I can't explain it, but that's my impression of her. She will either truly live or she won't at all. She'll either have everything or lose it all.

Now I don't think she'll have it all." Densher had followed this with his eyes upon her, her own having thoughtfully wandered, and as if it were more impressive than lucid. "You 'think' and you 'don't think,' and yet you remain all the while without an inkling of her complaint?" "So," he asked, completely baffled, "what exactly are we discussing?

Translation

"Now I don't think she'll have it all." Densher kept his eyes on her, while hers had drifted away in thought, as if what she said was more powerful than clear. "You 'think' and you 'don't think,' but all this time you still have no idea what's wrong with her?" "So," he asked, completely lost, "what are we even talking about?"

What's wrong with her?" Kate continued, as though she were just figuring it out herself. "I think that if she's sick at all, she's very sick. I believe that if she's bad, she's very bad.

Translation

"What's wrong with her?" Kate went on, as if she were only just now coming to that conclusion. "I think that if she's sick at all, she's really sick. I believe that if she's bad, she's really bad."

I can't explain it, but that's how I see her. It's really life or death for her. She'll either have everything or miss out on everything. And I don't think she'll have it all."

Translation

I can't put my finger on it, but that's how I perceive her. It's truly a matter of life or death for her. She'll either have it all or lose out on everything. And I don't think she'll have it all.

Densher watched her intently as she spoke, her gaze drifting thoughtfully as if the meaning was more powerful than clear. "You 'think' and you 'don't think,' but you still don't have any idea what's actually wrong with her?" "No, not without an inkling; but it's a matter in which I don't want knowledge. She moreover herself doesn't want one to want it: she has, as to what may be preying upon her, a kind of ferocity of modesty, a kind of—I don't know what to call it—intensity of pride.

Translation

Densher observed her closely as she spoke, her eyes becoming distant, thoughtful, as if the meaning was more potent than apparent. "You 'think' and you 'don't think,' but you still have no real understanding of what ails her?" "No, not with any certainty; but it is a matter in which I prefer ignorance. Furthermore, she herself doesn't want anyone to seek understanding: she possesses, in regard to what may be afflicting her, a sort of fierce discretion, a kind of—I can't say exactly—an intense form of pride."

And then and then—" But with this she faltered. "And then what?" "I'm a brute about illness. I hate it.

Translation

And then, and then..." But at this, she hesitated. "And then what?" "I'm a brute when it comes to sickness. I despise it."

It's well for you, my dear," Kate continued, "that you're as sound as a bell." "Thank you!" Densher laughed. "It's rather good then for yourself too that you're as strong as the sea." She looked at him now a moment as for the selfish gladness of their young immunities.

Translation

"It's good for you, my dear," Kate continued, "that you're as healthy as can be." "Thank you!" Densher laughed. "It's also rather good for you that you're as strong as the sea." She looked at him for a moment, as if to consider their selfish joy in their youth's protection.

It was all they had together, but they had it at least without a flaw—each had the beauty, the physical felicity, the personal virtue, love and desire of the other. Yet it was as if that very consciousness threw them back the next moment into pity for the poor girl who had everything else in the world, the great genial good they, alas, didn't have, but failed on the other hand of this. "How we're talking about her!" Kate compunctiously sighed. But there were the facts.

Translation

It was all they had together, but they had it, at least, without a flaw—each possessed the other's beauty, physical well-being, personal merit, love, and desire. Yet, that very realization seemed to thrust them back the next moment into pity for the poor girl who had everything else in the world, the great, hearty good that they, alas, didn't have but, on the other hand, lacked this. "How we're talking about her!" Kate sighed with compunction. But the facts remained.

"From illness I keep away." Yes, I have some idea, but it's something I don't want to know about. Besides, she doesn't want anyone to know either. When it comes to what might be bothering her, she has a fierce modesty, a sort of—I don't know what to call it—an intense pride.

Translation

"I steer clear of sickness." Yes, I have a suspicion, but it's something I'd rather not dwell on. Besides, she wants to keep it private, too. When it comes to her troubles, she's fiercely modest, almost—I don't know what to call it—a deep sense of pride.

And then, and then—" But she hesitated. "And then what?" "I'm terrible when it comes to illness. I hate it.

Translation

And then, and then—" But she paused. "And then what?" "I'm awful with sickness. I loathe it.

It's a good thing for you, my dear," Kate went on, "that you're perfectly healthy." "Thanks!" Densher laughed. "It's also good for you that you're as strong as can be." She looked at him for a moment, as if to acknowledge their shared, selfish joy in their youth and health.

Translation

"It's a good thing for you, my dear," Kate continued, "that you're perfectly healthy." "Thanks!" Densher laughed. "It's also good for you that you're as strong as can be." She looked at him for a moment, as if to acknowledge their shared, selfish joy in their youth and health.

It was the only thing they had together, but at least it was perfect. Each of them had the beauty, the physical well-being, the personal goodness, the love and desire of the other. Yet, as if that very awareness plunged them into sympathy for the poor woman who had everything else in the world, all the good things they, sadly, didn't have, but who was lacking this one thing. "How we keep talking about her!" Kate sighed, feeling guilty.

Translation

It was the only thing they shared, but at least it was perfect. Each of them possessed beauty, physical health, personal integrity, and the love and desire of the other. Still, as if that very realization drew them into a shared compassion for the unfortunate woman who had everything else in the world, all the good things they didn't, but who lacked this one thing. "We never stop talking about her!" Kate sighed, feeling a pang of guilt.

But the facts were there. "I try to avoid illness altogether." "But you don't—since here you are, in spite of all you say, in the midst of it." "Ah I'm only watching—!"

Translation

But the reality was undeniable. "I strive to avoid getting sick." "But you don't—because here you are, despite everything you claim, in the middle of it." "Oh, I'm just observing—!"

"And putting me forward in your place? Thank you!" "Oh," said Kate, "I'm breaking you in. Let it give you the measure of what I shall expect of you.

Translation

"And you're offering me up instead? Thanks!" "Oh," Kate said, "I'm training you. Let this give you an idea of what I'll be expecting from you."

One can't begin too soon." She drew away, as from the impression of a stir on the balcony, the hand of which he had a minute before possessed himself; and the warning brought him back to attention. "You haven't even an idea if it's a case for surgery?" "I dare say it may be; that is that if it comes to anything it may come to that.

Translation

"One should start early." She stepped back, as if she felt a movement on the balcony. He'd been holding her hand a moment before, and this alert brought him back to himself. Of course she's in the highest hands." "But you are here, despite your words, right in the middle of it all." "Oh, I'm just observing!" "And using me as a stand-in?

Translation

"Thanks a lot!" "Oh," Kate said, "I'm training you. Let this show you what I'll expect. You can't start too early."

She moved away, as if sensing movement on the balcony, releasing his hand, which he had been holding. The warning brought him back to reality. "You don't even know if this requires serious intervention?" "I suppose it might; that is, if it develops into anything, it might.

Translation

She stepped back, as if detecting someone on the balcony, and let go of his hand, which he'd been holding. The warning brought him back to himself. "You don't even know if this needs serious work?" "I guess it might; I mean, if it turns into something, it might."

Of course, she's with the best doctors." "The doctors are after her then?" "She's after them—it's the same thing. I think I'm free to say it now—she sees Sir Luke Strett."

"Of course, she's seeing the best doctors." "So the doctors are after her?" "She's after them—it's the same thing. I think I can say it now—she's seeing Sir Luke Strett."

Translation

Only do as I tell you." For a moment now, in silence, he took it all in, might have had it before him. "What you want of me then is to make up to a sick girl." "Ah but you admit yourself that she doesn't affect you as sick.

Translation

"Just do as I say." For a moment, in silence, he absorbed it all, might have already considered it. "So what you want from me is to console a sick girl." "Ah, but you admit she doesn't seem sick to you."

You understand moreover just how much—and just how little." "It's amazing," he presently answered, "what you think I understand." Translation

"You understand, in addition, precisely how much, and how little." "It's astonishing," he replied after a moment, "what you believe I comprehend." "So, the doctors are involved with her now?" "It's the other way around; she's pursuing them. It's essentially the same thing. I believe I can say this now – she's seeing Sir Luke Strett."

Translation

"So, the doctors are treating her now?" "No, it's the opposite; she's seeking them out. Which is more or less the same thing. I think I can tell you this now – she's seeing Sir Luke Strett."

Translation

That made him flinch. "Oh, blast it!" He paused, then added, "I can guess." But she waved him off. "Don't guess."

Just do as I ask." For a moment, he considered it all in silence, as if he could visualize it. "So, what you're asking me to do is to feign affection for a sick girl." "But you've already admitted that she doesn't seem sick to you.

Translation

"Just do as I ask." He fell silent, mulling it over, as if picturing it. "So, what you want me to do is pretend to care for a sick girl." "But you've already said she doesn't seem sick to you."

You understand perfectly well, both how much and how little." "It's astounding," he replied after a pause, "what you believe I comprehend." "Well, if you've pushed me to this point, my dear," she responded, "that's your method of handling me. Besides, regarding pretending affection, there will be plenty of others doing the same."

Translation

"You know exactly what I mean, in both senses of the word." He paused before answering, "It's incredible what you think I understand." "If you've driven me to this, my dear," she said, "it's because that's how you work. And anyway, when it comes to feigning affection, I won't be the only one."

Densher for a little, under this suggestion, might have been seeing their young friend on a pile of cushions and in a perpetual tea-gown, amid flowers and with drawn blinds, surrounded by the higher nobility. "Others can follow their tastes. Besides, others are free." "But so are you, my dear!"

Translation

Densher, for a moment, seemed to envision their young friend on a stack of cushions, always in a tea gown, surrounded by flowers and with the blinds drawn, in the company of the upper class. "Others are allowed to indulge their preferences. Besides, others are unburdened." "But so are you, my dear!"

She had spoken with impatience, and her suddenly quitting him had sharpened it; in spite of which he kept his place, only looking up at her. "You're prodigious!" "Of course I'm prodigious!"—and, as immediately happened, she gave a further sign of it that he fairly sat watching. The door from the lobby had, as she spoke, been thrown open for a gentleman who, immediately finding her within his view, advanced to greet her before the announcement of his name could reach her companion.

Translation

She had spoken with impatience, and her sudden departure had intensified it; despite that, he remained where he was, simply looking up at her. "You're amazing!" "Of course I'm amazing!"—and, as if on cue, she gave a further display of it that he found himself watching. The door from the lobby had, as she spoke, opened for a gentleman who, seeing her immediately, walked forward to greet her before his name could be announced to her companion.

Densher none the less felt himself brought quickly into relation; Kate's welcome to the visitor became almost precipitately an appeal to her friend, who slowly rose to meet it. "I don't know whether you know Lord Mark." And then for the other party: "Mr. Merton Densher—who has just come back from America." For a moment, Densher could imagine their young friend lounging on cushions, constantly in a tea gown, surrounded by flowers and with the blinds drawn, in the company of the elite.

Translation

Densher nonetheless felt himself quickly drawn into the situation; Kate's greeting to the visitor became almost instantly an appeal to her friend, who slowly rose to meet him. "I don't know whether you know Lord Mark." And then, for the other man: "Mr. Merton Densher—who has just returned from America." "Others can indulge their whims. Besides, others are unburdened." "But so are you, darling!" She spoke impatiently, and her abrupt departure amplified it.

Translation

"Some people can do what they want. They don't have responsibilities." "But neither do you, darling!" Her impatience was evident in her voice, and her sudden exit only made it worse.

Despite this, he remained where he was, simply looking up at her. "You're incredible!" "Of course I'm incredible!"—and, as if to prove it, she offered further evidence that he watched with fascination. The door from the hall opened, revealing a gentleman who, upon seeing her, immediately moved forward to greet her before his name could be announced to Densher.

Translation

He stayed put, just gazing up at her. "You're amazing!" "Of course I'm amazing!"—and, to prove it, she did something else that held his rapt attention. The hall door swung open, and a man appeared. He saw her and instantly came forward to greet her, before his name could even be announced to Densher.

Nonetheless, Densher felt immediately involved; Kate's greeting to the visitor was almost a plea to her friend, who slowly stood to meet him. "I'm not sure if you know Lord Mark." Then, turning to the other man, she said, "Mr. Merton Densher—who has just returned from America." "Oh!" said the other party while Densher said nothing—occupied as he mainly was on the spot with weighing the sound in question.

Translation

Densher was immediately caught up in the scene. Kate's greeting to the man felt almost like a desperate appeal to her friend, who rose slowly to meet him. "I'm not sure if you know Lord Mark." Then, turning to the other man, she said, "Mr. Merton Densher—who has just returned from America." "Oh!" the newcomer replied, while Densher remained silent, mostly occupied with assessing the tone of the greeting.

He recognised it in a moment as less imponderable than it might have appeared, as having indeed positive claims. It wasn't, that is, he knew, the "Oh!" of the idiot, however great the superficial resemblance: it was that of the clever, the accomplished man; it was the very specialty of the speaker, and a deal of expensive training and experience had gone to producing it. Densher felt somehow that, as a thing of value accidentally picked up, it would retain an interest of curiosity. The three stood for a little together in an awkwardness to which he was conscious of contributing his share; Kate failing to ask Lord Mark to be seated, but letting him know that he would find Mrs.

Translation

Densher understood the "Oh!" instantly. It was less mysterious than it had seemed, and he realized it had a specific purpose. He knew it wasn't the "Oh!" of a fool, despite the surface similarity. Instead, it was the sound of a smart, sophisticated man. It was the speaker's particular skill, something developed through a great deal of costly training and experience. Densher felt that this "Oh!" had intrinsic value, something interesting he'd stumbled upon. The three of them stood together for a moment in an awkward silence, and he knew he was partly responsible. Kate didn't offer Lord Mark a seat, but let him know that Mrs.

Lowder, with some others, on the balcony. "Oh!" the other person exclaimed, while Densher remained silent, mostly focused on analyzing the sound. He realized instantly that it wasn't as insignificant as it seemed; it actually had substance. It wasn't, he knew, the "Oh!" of a fool, despite a superficial similarity.

Translation

Lowder, along with some others, was on the balcony. "Oh!" the other person exclaimed, while Densher remained silent, mostly focused on analyzing the sound. He realized instantly that it wasn't as insignificant as it seemed; it actually had substance. It wasn't, he knew, the "Oh!" of a fool, despite a superficial similarity.

It was the "Oh!" of a smart, skilled man. It was the speaker's particular trademark, the product of considerable expensive training and experience. Densher felt that this sound, picked up by chance, would retain a certain intriguing quality. The three of them stood together for a moment in an uncomfortable silence, and he knew he was contributing to it.

Translation

It was the “Oh!” of a clever, practiced man. It was the speaker’s personal signature, the result of extensive and costly training and expertise. Densher sensed that this sound, overheard by chance, would continue to hold a certain compelling quality. The three of them stood together for a moment in an awkward silence, and he knew he was the one making it that way.

Kate didn't offer Lord Mark a seat, but informed him that Mrs. Lowder and some others were on the balcony. "Oh and Miss Theale I suppose?—as I seemed to hear outside, from below, Mrs. Stringham's unmistakeable voice."

Translation

Kate didn’t ask Lord Mark to sit. She told him that Mrs. Lowder and some others were on the balcony. "Oh, and Miss Theale, I suppose, because I thought I heard Mrs. Stringham's voice from downstairs."

Translation

"Oh, definitely."

"That's exactly what I mean," Kate smiled.

Translation

"There he is. Now you can see for yourself."

"See what?"

"Judge him."

"Why should I judge of him?" Densher asked. "I've nothing to do with him." "Then why do you ask about him?" "To judge of you—which is different."

Translation

"Why should I judge him?" Densher asked. "I have no reason to be involved with him."

"Then why do you ask about him?"

"To judge you—that's a different matter."

Kate seemed for a little to look at the difference. "To take the measure, do you mean, of my danger?" He hesitated; then he said: "I'm thinking, I dare say, of Miss Theale's. How does your aunt reconcile his interest in her—?"

Translation

Kate appeared to consider the distinction for a moment. "To assess, you mean, the extent of my risk?" He paused, then responded: "I suppose I'm wondering about Miss Theale's. How does your aunt account for his interest in her—?"

"With his interest in me?" "With her own interest in you," Densher said while she reflected. "If that interest—Mrs. Lowder's—takes the form of Lord Mark, hasn't he rather to look out for the forms he takes?"

Translation

"With his interest in me?"

"With her own interest in you," Densher said while she considered. "If that interest—Mrs. Lowder's—takes the form of Lord Mark, doesn't he have to be wary of the forms that he takes?"

Kate seemed interested in the question, but "Oh he takes them easily," she answered. "The beauty is that she doesn't trust him." "Assess him." "Why would I assess him?" Densher asked.

Translation

Kate appeared intrigued by the question, but replied, "Oh, he takes those forms easily. The beauty is that she doesn't trust him." "Assess him," Densher said. "Why would I assess him?"

"I have nothing to do with him." "Then why are you asking about him?" "To assess you – which is different." Kate seemed to ponder the difference.

Translation

"I have nothing to do with him." "Then why are you asking about him?" "To assess you – which is different." Kate seemed to ponder the difference.
