Not really." Densher was surprised. "She accepts him and still thinks he's deceitful?" "Yes," Kate replied, "that's how people are.

Translation

"Not really." Densher was surprised. "She accepts him and still thinks he's deceitful?" "Yes," Kate replied, "that's how people are."

What they think of their enemies is bad enough, but I'm even more struck by what they think of their friends. Milly's mindset, though," she continued, "is fortunate. That's Aunt Maud's protection, though she doesn't fully grasp it yet—as well as Milly's own." "You think it's a genuine advantage not to care for him?"

Translation

"Their opinions of their enemies are bad enough, but what strikes me more is what they think of their friends. Milly's way of thinking, however," she continued, "is fortunate. That's Aunt Maud's protection, though she doesn't fully understand it yet—and Milly's own as well." "You think it's a real benefit to not care for him?"

She shook her head, showing gentle disapproval. "You shouldn't push me to say too much. But I'm glad I don't." "Don't say too much?"

Translation

She indicated disagreement with a subtle movement. "You shouldn't try to get me to reveal too much. But I am pleased that I don't." "Not reveal too much?"

"Don't care for Lord Mark." "Oh!" Densher answered with a sound like his lordship's own. To which he added: "You absolutely hold that that poor girl doesn't?" "Ah you know what I hold about that poor girl!" It had made her again impatient.

Translation

"I don't care for Lord Mark." "Oh!" Densher replied, mimicking his lordship's tone. Then he added: "You truly believe that the poor girl doesn't?" "Ah, you know what I think about that poor girl!" It had made her impatient again.

Yet he stuck a minute to the subject. "You scarcely call him, I suppose, one of the dukes." "Mercy, no—far from it. He's not, compared with other possibilities, 'in' it.

Translation

He paused on the topic, though. "You wouldn't consider him a duke, I imagine." "Heavens, no—not at all. He doesn't have a chance, relative to the competition. He's not 'in' the running."

Milly, it's true," she said, to be exact, "has no natural sense of social values, doesn't in the least understand our differences or know who's who or what's what." "I see. That," Densher laughed, "is her reason for liking me." "Precisely.

Translation

"Milly, it's true," she said, to be precise, "has no innate understanding of social values; she doesn't grasp our differences or know who's important or what matters."

"I see. That," Densher laughed, "is her reason for liking me."

"Precisely."

She doesn't resemble me," said Kate, "who at least know what I lose." "Oh!" Densher replied, echoing her tone. He then asked, "You truly believe that poor girl doesn't?" "You know how I feel about her!" she said, sounding impatient again.

Translation

"She doesn't resemble me," Kate said, "because I at least know what I'm losing." "Oh!" Densher replied, mimicking her tone. He then asked, "Do you really think that poor girl doesn't?" "You know how I feel about her!" she said, her voice again edged with impatience.

But he persisted for a moment. "I imagine you don't think he's in the running with the other candidates." "Good heavens, no—not even close. Compared to other options, he doesn't have a chance.

Translation

Densher pressed a little further. "I assume you don't believe he's a serious contender." "God, no—not at all. He's not even a possibility compared to the others."

Milly, to be precise," she added, "lacks a natural understanding of social standing. She doesn't comprehend our distinctions or know who's important or how things work." "I see. That," Densher laughed, "is why she likes me."

Translation

"Milly, to be clear," she continued, "doesn't have a natural grasp of social hierarchy. She doesn't understand our class differences or know who matters or how things function." "I understand. That," Densher said, laughing, "is why she likes me."

"Exactly. She's not like me," Kate said, "who at least understands what I'm missing." Well, it had all risen for Densher to a considerable interest. "And Aunt Maud—why shouldn't she know?

Translation

"Precisely. She's not like me," Kate said, "who at least understands what I'm lacking." Well, everything had become quite interesting for Densher. "And Aunt Maud—why shouldn't she know?"

I mean that your friend there isn't really anything. Does she suppose him of ducal value?" "Scarcely; save in the sense of being uncle to a duke. That's undeniably something.

Translation

"What I'm saying is that your friend there doesn't amount to much," he said. "Does she think he's worth a fortune?" "Hardly; unless you count being the uncle of a duke. That's certainly worth something."

He's the best moreover we can get." "Oh, oh!" said Densher; and his doubt was not all derisive. "It isn't Lord Mark's grandeur," she went on without heeding this; "because perhaps in the line of that alone—as he has no money—more could be done. But she's not a bit sordid; she only counts with the sordidness of others.

Translation

"He's the best option we have."

"Oh, really?" Densher said, and not all of his skepticism was mocking.

"It's not Lord Mark's social status," she continued, ignoring him. "Because, perhaps, in that respect alone, and since he has no money, there might be more to consider. But she's not at all materialistic; she only takes into account the materialism of others."

Besides, he's grand enough, with a duke in his family and at the other end of the string. The thing's his genius." Densher found the situation quite intriguing. "And Aunt Maud—why shouldn't she know?

Translation

Besides, he's impressive enough, with a duke in his family pulling the strings, so to speak. The key is his brilliance." Densher was finding the situation quite interesting. "And Aunt Maud—why shouldn't she know?

I mean, that friend of yours isn't really a catch. Does she think he's a potential duke?" "Hardly; except that he's an uncle to a duke. That certainly has its advantages.

Translation

"I mean, that friend of yours isn't exactly a prize, is she? Does she think he's going to be a duke?" "Hardly. Except that he's related to one, an uncle. That certainly comes with benefits."

Besides, he's the best option available." "I see," Densher replied, and his skepticism wasn't entirely mocking. "It's not Lord Mark's social standing," she continued, unconcerned. "Because, perhaps if that were all that mattered—since he has no money—we could do better.

Translation

"Besides, he's the best option we have." "I see," Densher replied, his skepticism only partially feigned. "It's not Lord Mark's social status," she continued, unfazed. "Because, perhaps if that were the only thing that mattered—since he has no money—we could do better."

But she's not at all materialistic; she only takes into account other people's greed. Besides, he has enough prestige, with a duke in the family and at the top of the social ladder. The key is his exceptional nature." "And do you believe in that?"

Translation

"But she isn't materialistic at all; she just considers how greedy others are. Besides, he has plenty of prestige, with a duke in his family and his place at the apex of society. The important thing is his exceptional character." "And do you believe that?"

"In Lord Mark's genius?" Kate, as if for a more final opinion than had yet been asked of her, took a moment to think. She balanced indeed so that one would scarce have known what to expect; but she came out in time with a very sufficient "Yes!" "Political?" "Universal.

Translation

"In Lord Mark's brilliance?" Kate considered for a moment, as if deciding on a more definitive opinion than anyone had yet asked her for. She hesitated, such that one could hardly guess what she was thinking. But she answered decisively, "Yes!" "Political?" "All-encompassing."

I don't know at least," she said, "what else to call it when a man's able to make himself without effort, without violence, without machinery of any sort, so intensely felt. He has somehow an effect without his being in any traceable way a cause." "Ah but if the effect," said Densher with conscious superficiality, "isn't agreeable—?" "Oh but it is!"

Translation

I don't know, at least," she said, "what else to call it when a man is able to make himself, without effort, without violence, without any sort of machinery, so intensely felt. He somehow has an effect without being a traceable cause." "Ah, but if the effect," said Densher, with a superficiality he was aware of, "isn't agreeable—?" "Oh, but it is!"

"Not surely for every one." "And do you believe that?" Kate, as if considering a more definitive answer than she'd been asked for, paused to consider. She took her time, so you couldn't guess what she'd say.

Translation

"Not necessarily for everyone." "And do you really believe that?" Kate paused, as if she were contemplating a more thorough response than the question warranted. She took her time, and you couldn't tell what she was going to say.

But eventually, she gave a very firm, "Yes!" "In politics?" "In everything. I don't know," she said, "what else to call it when a man can make himself so impactful without trying, without force, without any obvious methods.

Translation

But finally, she said, very firmly, "Yes!" "In politics?" "In everything. I don't know," she said, "what else to call it when a man can have such an effect on things without even trying, without any effort, without any clear plan of action."

He just has this certain effect, without being a clear cause." "But if the effect," Densher said with a touch of sarcasm, "isn't enjoyable—?" "Oh, but it is!" "Surely not for everyone."

Translation

He just has this certain effect, without being a clear cause." "But if the effect," Densher said with a touch of sarcasm, "isn't enjoyable—?" "Oh, but it is!" "Surely not for everyone."

"If you mean not for you," Kate returned, "you may have reasons—and men don't count. Women don't know if it's agreeable or not." "Then there you are!" "Yes, precisely—that takes, on his part, genius."

Translation

"If you're saying it isn't agreeable to you," Kate countered, "you might have your reasons, but men don't matter. Women don't know whether it's enjoyable or not." "There you go!" "Exactly—that requires genius on his part."

Densher stood before her as if he wondered what everything she thus promptly, easily and above all amusingly met him with, would have been found, should it have come to an analysis, to "take." Something suddenly, as if under a last determinant touch, welled up in him and overflowed—the sense of his good fortune and her variety, of the future she promised, the interest she supplied. "All women but you are stupid. How can I look at another? You're different and different—and then you're different again.

Translation

Densher stood before her, as if he wondered what everything she so promptly, easily, and above all amusingly countered him with would have amounted to, had it been subject to analysis, to "take." Something welled up suddenly in him, as if under a last determinant touch, and overflowed—the sense of his good fortune, of her variety, of the future she promised, of the interest she supplied. "All women but you are stupid. How can I look at another? You're different and different—and then you're different again."

No marvel Aunt Maud builds on you—except that you're so much too good for what she builds for. Even 'society' won't know how good for it you are; it's too stupid, and you're beyond it. You'd have to pull it uphill—it's you yourself who are at the top. The women one meets—what are they but books one has already read?

Translation

No wonder Aunt Maud relies on you—except that you're far too good for what she wants to use you for. Even "society" won't realize how beneficial you could be; it's too unintelligent, and you're above it. You'd have to drag it upwards—you're the one already at the summit. The women one encounters—what are they but books one's already read?

You're a whole library of the unknown, the uncut." He almost moaned, he ached, from the depth of his content. "Upon my word I've a subscription!" "If you're not interested," Kate replied, "you might have your reasons, and men don't matter. Women don't know if they like something or not."

Translation

You are an entire library of the unexplored, the unedited." He nearly groaned, aching with the profundity of his satisfaction. "I swear, I'm signing up!" "If you aren't intrigued," Kate responded, "you could have your own reasons, and men don't actually matter. Women never know whether they actually like something or not."

"Exactly!" "Yes, exactly—that requires genius from him." Densher stood before her, as if he was wondering what all of her quick, easy, and above all, amusing responses amounted to, if they were analyzed. Something suddenly swelled up inside him, as if given a final push, and overflowed—the feeling of his good luck and her varied personality, of the future she promised, the excitement she provided.

Translation

"Precisely!" "Yes, precisely—that takes real brilliance on his part." Densher stood before her, as if considering the sum of her quick, easy, and, above all, amusing responses, if he were to analyze them. Something suddenly welled up inside him, as if given a final push, and overflowed—the feeling of his good fortune and her varied personality, of the future she promised, the excitement she offered.

"All women except you are boring. How can I even look at someone else? You're unique, you're different, and then you're different again. It's no surprise that Aunt Maud relies on you—except you're too good for what she wants.

Translation

"Every other woman is dull. How could I possibly be interested in anyone else? You're one of a kind, endlessly fascinating. It's no wonder Aunt Maud depends on you—though you're clearly above her needs."

Even 'society' won't realize how good you are for it; it's too dull, and you're above it. You'd have to elevate it—you're the one at the top. The women one encounters—what are they but books one has already read? You're a whole collection of unknown, unread books." He almost groaned, he was aching with his happiness.

Translation

Even the so-called 'elite' won't grasp how beneficial you are. They're too boring, and you're simply better than them. You'd have to lift them up—you're already at the highest level. The women one meets—what are they, if not books one has already finished? You're a whole library of undiscovered, unread volumes." A near groan escaped him, he was overwhelmed by his own joy.

"I'm completely captivated!" She took it from him with her face again giving out all it had in answer, and they remained once more confronted and united in their essential wealth of life. "It's you who draw me out. I exist in you.

Translation

"I am utterly enthralled!" She received the object from him, her face radiating the sum total of her response, and once more they stood facing each other, joined in their fundamental richness of life. "It is you who brings me forth. I live within you."

Not in others." It had been, however, as if the thrill of their association itself pressed in him, as great felicities do, the sharp spring of fear. "See here, you know: don't, don't—!" "Don't what?"

Translation

Not in others." However, it was as if the excitement of their connection was, like all great joys, pressing down on him, bringing with it the sharp sting of fear. "Look, you know: don't, don't—!" "Don't what?"

"Don't fail me. It would kill me." She looked at him a minute with no response but her eyes. "So you think you'll kill me in time to prevent it?" She smiled, but he saw her the next instant as smiling through tears; and the instant after this she had got, in respect to the particular point, quite off.

Translation

"Don't fail me. It would kill me." She stared at him for a moment, her eyes the only reply. "So you think you'll kill me before I can stop it?" She smiled, but then he saw her smile dissolve into tears; and in the very next instant, she had completely changed her mind about the matter.

She had come back to another, which was one of her own; her own were so closely connected that Densher's were at best but parenthetic. Still she had a distance to go. "You do then see your way?" She put it to him before they joined—as was high time—the others. And she made him understand she meant his way with Milly.

Translation

She had returned to a different idea, one that was hers. Her thoughts were so interconnected that Densher's were, at most, an aside. Yet, she still needed to resolve something. "So, do you know what you're doing?" She asked him before they rejoined the others—which was long overdue. And she made him understand that she was referring to his interactions with Milly.

She accepted it from him, her expression fully mirroring her feelings in response, and they found themselves again face to face, united in their shared, fundamental richness of experience. "You're the one who brings out the best in me. I find my purpose through you. Not through anyone else."

Translation

She took what he offered, her face reflecting her emotions perfectly. They were once again looking at each other, connected by the core wealth of what they’d lived through together. "You're the reason I'm at my best. You're the one who gives my life meaning. No one else does that."

However, it was as if the excitement of their connection, as often happens with profound joys, also brought forth a sudden jolt of fear within him. "Listen, you know: please, please—!" "Please what?" "Don't let me down.

Translation

But, as often happens with the most intense happiness, their bond seemed to have stirred in him a sudden fear. "Listen, you know: please, please—!" "Please what?" "Don't let me down."

It would destroy me." She gazed at him for a moment, her eyes conveying all she felt. "Do you think you'll destroy me first, to prevent that?" She smiled, but the next moment he saw her smiling through tears; and immediately after that, she had moved away from that specific topic entirely. She had shifted back to a different subject, one of her own choosing; hers were so interconnected that Densher's were, at best, secondary.

Translation

"It would destroy me." She looked at him, her eyes expressing everything. "Do you think you'll destroy me first, to stop that from happening?" She smiled, but the next instant he saw her smiling through tears; then, just as quickly, she had changed the subject. She moved on to something else, something she had chosen; her thoughts were so intertwined that Densher's were, at most, an afterthought.

But she still needed to clarify something. "Do you then see how you'll handle things?" She asked him before they rejoined the others—it was definitely time—and she made it clear she was asking about his strategy with Milly. He had dropped a little in presence of the explanation; then she had brought him up to a sort of recognition. He could make out by this light something of what he saw, but a dimness also there was, undispelled since his return.

Translation

But she still needed to know. "So, how do you see yourself handling things?" She asked him before they went back to the others—it was definitely time—and she was clearly asking about his approach to Milly. He'd seemed diminished by her explanation; then she'd brought him to a kind of understanding. He could make out something of what he saw in this light, but a shadow remained, undiminished since his return.

"There's something you must definitely tell me. If our friend knows that all the while—?" She came straight to his aid, formulating for him his anxiety, though quite to smooth it down. "All the while she and I here were growing intimate, you and I were in unmentioned relation?

Translation

"You absolutely have to tell me something. If our friend knows that all this time—?" She jumped in to help him, putting his worries into words, though her intention was clearly to ease them. "All this time that she and I were becoming close, you and I were in an unspoken relationship?"

If she knows that, yes, she knows our relation must have involved your writing to me." "Then how could she suppose you weren't answering?" "She doesn't suppose it." His initial reaction to the explanation was a slight letdown, but then she helped him grasp the situation.

Translation

If she knows that, then yes, she knows our relationship must have involved you writing to me." "Then how could she suppose you weren't answering?" "She doesn't suppose it." His initial reaction to the explanation was a slight letdown, but then she helped him grasp the situation.

He could understand some of what was happening, even though a certain haziness remained since his return. "There's one crucial thing you need to tell me. If our friend knew everything along—?" She immediately jumped in to clarify his worries, though with the intention of calming him.

Translation

He could follow parts of what was going on, though a fog still clung to him since coming back. "One important thing I need to know. If our friend knew everything all along—?" She cut him off at once, eager to clear up his concerns, but aiming to soothe him.

"While she and I were becoming close, you and I had this unspoken connection? If she knows that, then yes, she knows our relationship meant you must have been writing to me." "So why wouldn't she assume you were responding?" "She doesn't."

Translation

"While she and I were getting close, did you and I have this unspoken thing? If she knows that, then yes, she knows our relationship meant you were writing me." "So why wouldn't she assume you wrote back?" "She doesn't."

"How then can she imagine you never named her?" "She doesn't. She knows now I did name her. I've told her everything.

Translation

"So how could she possibly think you never mentioned her?" "She doesn't. She knows now that I did. I've told her everything."

She's in possession of reasons that will perfectly do." Still he just brooded. "She takes things from you exactly as I take them?" "Exactly as you take them."

Translation

"She has the facts, enough to satisfy her." He remained lost in thought. "Does she understand things the same way I do?" "Precisely."

"She's just such another victim?" "Just such another. You're a pair." "Then if anything happens," said Densher, "we can console each other?"

Translation

"Another victim, is she?" "Just another one. You're two of a kind." "So if anything goes wrong," Densher said, "we can comfort each other?"

"Ah something may indeed happen," she returned, "if you'll only go straight!" He watched the others an instant through the window. "What do you mean by going straight?" "Not worrying.

Translation

"Something might very well happen," she replied, "if you'd just behave!" He glanced at the others through the window. "What do you mean, behaving?" "Not worrying."

Doing as you like. Try, as I've told you before, and you'll see. You'll have me perfectly, always, to refer to." "How can she possibly believe you never mentioned her?"

Translation

"Doing what you want. Just try it, like I said before, and you'll see. You'll always have me, perfectly, to turn to." "How can she possibly believe you never brought her up?"

"She doesn't believe that. She knows I did mention her. I've told her everything. She understands my reasons completely."

Translation

"She doesn't believe that, either. She knows I talked about her. I've told her everything. She understands my reasons, completely."

He remained thoughtful. "Does she understand things the same way I do?" "Exactly the same way." "So she's another person who's been hurt?"

Translation

He fell silent, considering. "Does she see it the way I do?" "Precisely." "So she's another one who's suffered?"

"Exactly. You're alike." "Then if anything goes wrong," Densher said, "we can comfort each other?" "Something might happen, yes," she replied, "if you just behave properly!"

Translation

"Precisely. You're kindred spirits." "Then if something goes awry," Densher said, "we can console one another?" "That's possible, yes," she replied, "provided you act appropriately!"

He glanced at the others through the window. "What do you mean by behaving properly?" "Not being anxious. Doing what you want.

Translation

He looked out the window at the others. "What do you mean by behaving properly?" "Not being anxious. Doing what you want.

Try it, as I've said before, and you'll see. You can always come to me for support." "Oh rather, I hope! But if she's going away?"

Translation

"Give it a shot, like I told you. You'll see. You can always count on me." "Oh, I hope so! But if she's leaving?"

It pulled Kate up but a moment. "I'll bring her back. There you are. You won't be able to say I haven't made it smooth for you."

Translation

Kate hesitated for a moment. "I'll bring her back. There. You won't be able to say I didn't make things easy for you."

He faced it all, and certainly it was queer. But it wasn't the queerness that after another minute was uppermost. He was in a wondrous silken web, and it was amusing. "You spoil me!"

Translation

He confronted the situation, and it was undeniably strange. But, after a minute, the strangeness wasn't the most prominent thing. He was caught in a marvelous, silken web, and it was entertaining. "You're spoiling me!"

He wasn't sure if Mrs. Lowder, who at this juncture reappeared, had caught his word as it dropped from him; probably not, he thought, her attention being given to Mrs. Stringham, with whom she came through and who was now, none too soon, taking leave of her. They were followed by Lord Mark and by the other men, but two or three things happened before any dispersal of the company began.

Translation

He wasn’t sure if Mrs. Lowder, who reappeared at this moment, had heard him. He doubted it; her focus was on Mrs. Stringham, whom she was with as they entered the room. Mrs. Stringham was finally, thankfully, leaving. Lord Mark and the other men followed, but several things happened before the party began to break up.

One of these was that Kate found time to say to him with furtive emphasis: "You must go now!" Another was that she next addressed herself in all frankness to Lord Mark, drew near to him with an almost reproachful "Come and talk to me!"—a challenge resulting after a minute for Densher in a consciousness of their installation together in an out-of-the-way corner, though not the same he himself had just occupied with her. Still another was that Mrs. Stringham, in the random intensity of her farewells, affected him as looking at him with a small grave intimation, something into which he afterwards read the meaning that if he had happened to desire a few words with her after dinner he would have found her ready. This impression was naturally light, but it just left him with the sense of something by his own act overlooked, unappreciated.

Translation

One of these things was that Kate found time to say to him with furtive emphasis, "You must go now!" Another was that she next addressed herself with complete frankness to Lord Mark, drew near him with an almost reproachful, "Come and talk to me!"—a challenge that, after a minute, resulted in Densher's awareness of their installation together in a secluded corner, though not the same one he had just occupied with her. Still another thing was that Mrs. Stringham, in the random intensity of her farewells, affected him as looking at him with a small, grave intimation. Afterwards, he read into it the meaning that if he had happened to desire a few words with her after dinner, he would have found her ready. This impression was naturally faint, but it just left him with the sense of something overlooked and unappreciated due to his own actions.

It gathered perhaps a slightly sharper shade from the mild formality of her "Good-night, sir!" as she passed him; a matter as to which there was now nothing more to be done, thanks to the alertness of the young man he by this time had appraised as even more harmless than himself. This personage had forestalled him in opening the door for her and was evidently—with a view, Densher might have judged, to ulterior designs on Milly—proposing to attend her to her carriage. What further occurred was that Aunt Maud, having released her, immediately had a word for himself. It was an imperative "Wait a minute," by which she both detained and dismissed him; she was particular about her minute, but he hadn't yet given her, as happened, a sign of withdrawal.

Translation

It took on a slightly sharper edge, perhaps, from her mild, formal "Good night, sir!" as she passed him. There was nothing more he could do about that, thanks to the quickness of the young man, whom he now judged to be even more harmless than himself. This person had opened the door for her first and was evidently—Densher thought, in hopes of some future plans with Milly—going to walk her to her carriage. What happened next was that Aunt Maud, having let her go, immediately had a word for him. It was an imperative "Wait a minute," with which she both kept him there and dismissed him. She was very precise about her minute, but he hadn't yet, as it turned out, signaled that he was leaving.

"Oh, I certainly hope so! But what if she's leaving?" It gave Kate pause, but only for a moment. "I'll bring her back.

Translation

"Oh, I certainly hope so! But what if she's leaving?" The thought gave Kate a moment's hesitation, but only a moment. "I'll bring her back.

There. You won't be able to say I haven't smoothed things over for you." He considered the situation, and it was undeniably strange. But the strangeness wasn't the most prominent thing on his mind after another minute.

Translation

There. Now you can't accuse me of not making things better for you." He assessed the situation, and it was undeniably odd. But after another minute, the oddness wasn't the most pressing thing he was thinking about.

He was caught in a wonderfully delicate trap, and it was entertaining. "You're spoiling me!" He wasn't sure if Mrs. Lowder, who reappeared at that moment, had heard his words.

Translation

He was ensnared in a marvelously intricate trap, and it was amusing. "You're ruining me!" He wasn't certain if Mrs. Lowder, who reentered the scene just then, had overheard his statement.

Probably not, he thought, since she seemed focused on Mrs. Stringham, whom she was with as they came through. Mrs. Stringham was now, thankfully, taking her leave.

Translation

He didn't think so, because she appeared to be occupied with Mrs. Stringham, who was with her as they entered. Mrs. Stringham was thankfully departing.

Lord Mark and the other men followed them, but several things happened before the gathering began to disperse. One of these was that Kate found time to tell him, with a hidden urgency, "You must leave now!" Another was that she then spoke frankly to Lord Mark, approaching him with an almost accusatory, "Come talk to me!"—a challenge that, after a minute, resulted in Densher realizing they were together in a secluded corner, though not the same one he had just been in with her. Still another thing was that Mrs. Stringham, in the scattered intensity of her goodbyes, gave him the impression that she was looking at him with a subtle, serious hint.

Translation

Lord Mark and the other men followed, but several things occurred before the party started to break up. One was that Kate found a moment to tell him, with a concealed urgency, "You have to go now!" Another was that she then spoke candidly to Lord Mark, going up to him with an almost accusatory, "Come talk to me!"—a challenge that, after a minute, led Densher to realize they were together in a private corner, though not the same one he'd just been in with her. Yet another thing was that Mrs. Stringham, in the scattered intensity of her farewells, gave him the impression that she was looking at him with a subtle, serious hint.

He later interpreted this to mean that if he had wanted a few words with her after dinner, she would have been available. This impression was naturally faint, but it left him with the feeling that he had overlooked or failed to appreciate something because of his own actions. This feeling perhaps grew slightly sharper from the polite formality of her "Good-night, sir!" as she passed him. There was nothing more to be done about that now, thanks to the quick-wittedness of the young man he had now decided was even more harmless than himself.

Translation

Later, he understood this to mean that she would have been open to a private conversation with him after dinner, if he had expressed interest. The impression was subtle, of course, but it left him with the sense that he'd missed or misread something because of his own behavior. This feeling may have intensified with her formal "Good-night, sir!" as she walked past him. There was nothing to be done about it now, thanks to the quick thinking of the young man, whom he now considered even less of a threat than himself.

This person had already opened the door for her and was clearly—Densher guessed, hoping to make plans for Milly—about to escort her to her carriage. What happened next was that Aunt Maud, having released Mrs. Stringham, immediately had a word for him. It was an urgent "Wait a minute," which both held him back and dismissed him; she insisted on her minute, but he hadn't yet, as it turned out, signaled that he was leaving.

Translation

This individual had already opened the door for her and, clearly—Densher surmised, wanting to arrange something with Milly—was about to walk her to her carriage. What happened next was that Aunt Maud, having let Mrs. Stringham go, immediately wanted a word with him. It was an urgent "Wait a minute," which both held him back and dismissed him; she insisted on her minute, but he hadn't yet, as it turned out, indicated that he was leaving.

"Return to our little friend. You'll find her really interesting." "If you mean Miss Theale," he said, "I shall certainly not forget her. But you must remember that, so far as her 'interest' is concerned, I myself discovered, I—as was said at dinner—invented her."

Translation

"Go back to our little friend. You'll find her quite interesting." "If you mean Miss Theale," he said, "I won't forget her, certainly. But you should remember that I, as far as her 'interest' is concerned, discovered her myself, I—as was mentioned at dinner—invented her."

"Well, one seemed rather to gather that you hadn't taken out the patent. Don't, I only mean, in the press of other things, too much neglect her." Affected, surprised by the coincidence of her appeal with Kate's, he asked himself quickly if it mightn't help him with her. He at any rate could but try.

Translation

"Well, one got the impression you hadn't cornered the market. I just mean, don't let her fall by the wayside because you're busy with other things." Affected, and surprised by how similar her request was to Kate's, he quickly wondered if he could use it to his advantage. At the very least, he could try.

"You're all looking after my manners. That's exactly, you know, what Miss Croy has been saying to me. She keeps me up—she has had so much to say about them." Let's go back to our young friend.

Translation

"You're all focused on my etiquette. That's precisely, you know, what Miss Croy has been telling me. She hounds me—she's had so much to say about it." Let's return to our young friend.

You'll find her quite intriguing." "If you're referring to Miss Theale," he responded, "I won't forget her. "Well, it sounded like you didn't have a copyright on her.

Translation

"You'll find her quite intriguing." "If you're referring to Miss Theale," he replied, "I won't forget her. Just don't let her fall by the wayside because you're busy with other things." He was affected, surprised by the similarity of her request to Kate's. He quickly wondered if this could somehow help him with Kate. He thought he should try.

Translation

"Just don't neglect her because you're distracted," he said, moved, surprised that her request echoed Kate's. He wondered if he could somehow leverage this to help Kate. He decided to try.

"You're all monitoring my behavior. That's precisely what Miss Croy has been telling me. She keeps me in line—she's had so much to say about it." He found pleasure in being able to give his hostess an account of his passage with Kate that, while quite veracious, might be reassuring to herself.

Translation

"You're all watching me. That's exactly what Miss Croy has been saying. She keeps me in check—she's had a lot to say about it." He felt a certain satisfaction in relating his time with Kate to his hostess, a story that, while truthful, could also be comforting to her.

Translation

"Even so, I'm not resisting in the slightest. I find Miss Theale charming." He took pleasure in recounting his time with Kate to his hostess. Though his account was genuine, its purpose was also to soothe her concerns.

However, Aunt Maud, looking him directly in the eye, received his words as if her confidence needed no reinforcement. If she saw his intention, she didn't waver, either in doubt or agreement. She simply responded calmly, "Yes, Kate will do anything for a friend, as long as she's also practicing what she preaches." Densher wondered if Aunt Maud knew how far Kate's dedication went.

Translation

Yet Aunt Maud, meeting his gaze unflinchingly, seemed to receive his words as if her own certainty required no bolstering. If she understood his meaning, it didn’t alter her, either in suspicion or in consent. She replied, evenly, “Yes, Kate will do anything for a friend, provided she’s also following her own advice.” Densher wondered if Aunt Maud grasped the full extent of Kate’s devotion.

He was also a bit confused by their agreement. He understood the situation perfectly. She was attempting to bribe him, and she was doing it—it would have been absurd if the stakes weren't so high—using Miss Theale's money. He risked being sarcastic, treating her offer as an excessive gesture. "I'm very grateful for your generous offer—" "Of what isn't mine?" She showed no embarrassment.

Distinct he felt her pressure; he felt, given her basis, her consistency; he even felt, to a degree that was immediately to receive an odd confirmation, her truth.

Translation

"Can't you see? I told the perfect lie for your sake." He just kept offering that strained, flushed smile. But, speaking with force, as though he might understand if he just thought for a moment, she turned from him. "Now I'm counting on you to fix it!"

The minute's reflexion he was of course more free to take after he had left the house. He walked up the Bayswater Road, but he stopped short, under the murky stars, before the modern church, in the middle of the square that, going eastward, opened out on his left. Translation

The moment he had a minute to think, he was, of course, freer to do so, now that he was out of the house. He walked up Bayswater Road, but he stopped suddenly, under the dim stars, in front of the modern church, in the middle of the square that, heading east, opened up on his left. He'd had his brief moment of stupidity, but now he understood. She had given Milly Theale a guarantee, through Mrs.

Stringham that Kate didn't care for him. She had affirmed through the same source that the attachment was only his. He made it out, he made it out, and he could see what she meant by its starting him. She had described Kate as merely compassionate, so that Milly might be compassionate too.

Translation

Stringham, that Kate wasn't interested in him. Through the same person, she'd stated that the feelings were only his. He figured it out, he understood, and he could see how she meant to provoke him. She'd painted Kate as simply sympathetic, so that Milly might also be sympathetic.

"Proper" indeed it was, her lie—the very properest possible and the most deeply, richly diplomatic. So Milly was successfully deceived. He had more freedom to think, of course, once he was away from the house. Translation

"Proper," indeed it was, her lie—the most proper possible and the most deeply, richly diplomatic. So Milly was successfully deceived. He had more freedom to think, of course, once he was away from the house. He walked up the Bayswater Road, but he stopped, under the dim stars, in front of the modern church, in the middle of the square that opened to his left as he went eastward.

He’d been momentarily foolish, but now he understood. She had assured Milly Theale, through Mrs. Stringham, that Kate wasn't interested in him. She'd claimed, through the same source, that he was the only one with feelings.

Translation

He'd been an idiot for a moment, but now it made sense. Through Mrs. Stringham, she'd told Milly Theale that Kate wasn't interested in him. Through the same person, she'd said he was the only one who felt anything.

He figured it out, he figured it out, and he could see why it had surprised him. She had portrayed Kate as simply sympathetic, so that Milly might also be sympathetic. "Proper," her lie truly was—the most proper and deeply, richly diplomatic. So Milly was successfully deceived.

Translation

He got it, he finally understood, and he could see why it had thrown him. She'd painted Kate as merely kind, so Milly would also feel kind. Her lie was truly "proper"—the most proper and deeply, richly diplomatic. So Milly was successfully deceived.

Chapter 5

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A man named Densher calls on Milly Theale at her hotel to inquire about her health. He finds her at home, turning from a table where she was writing. He asks about her health, and she dismisses his concern, stating she is well. They talk, and he changes the subject from his activities to her experiences in London. He asks about her future plans. She tells him she is going abroad for a few weeks but is vague about when she will return. He asks her to promise she will come back. During their conversation, Milly says she would return for her friends, including Kate. A carriage arrives outside. Milly gets up, and they both go to the balcony to look at it. She then invites Densher to go for a drive. They go back inside, where a servant announces the carriage is ready. Densher accepts her invitation. Milly tells the servant they will leave in ten minutes, then exits the room to get ready. While Densher waits, a servant announces Kate Croy. Kate enters, sees Densher, and he explains that Milly is preparing for their drive. The servant leaves. Kate says she will not wait for Milly. Before leaving, she and Densher talk. He approaches her and holds out his hands; she takes them, then he lets go. He agrees to do what she wishes. Kate goes to the door, tells him how to explain her departure to Milly, and leaves. A few minutes later, Milly returns, dressed to go out. Densher tells her about Kate’s brief visit and departure, and Milly accepts his explanation.
"Oh, it's so nice," she said. "I do like it so." "It's charming, isn't it?" "Yes, and so much better than I expected. I hadn't imagined it, really—not as nice as this." Kate smiled at her. "Then you were disappointed?" "Well, you know," Milly replied. "I thought it would be a little cold." Kate waited. "Cold?" "Yes—a little empty. But it isn't. It's so full." "Full?" "Of everything. Of—of you." Kate, at this, considered her own shoes. "Oh, I'm a dreadful bore." "No, you're not!" Milly protested. "You're splendid. It's the others who are bores, but you're not. You're the one person here who isn't!" Kate’s eyes rose to meet hers. "Who are the others?" "Oh, the people, you know." Milly waved her hand vaguely. "The ones who are here all the time." "The hotel?" "The people who come and go, who are always coming and going. The ones who stare at me, or the ones I stare at—I don't know which. I'm afraid I stare at them; I think they stare at me." "You stare at them because you're shy," Kate explained. "They stare at you because you're charming. That's the whole mystery." "Do you think I'm charming?" "Yes, I think so. Don't you?" Milly looked, for a moment, almost embarrassed. "No, I don't." "Then you should begin to. It's very simple." Milly gave a little sigh. "I don't know about that. But I do know this is much better than I supposed." "You mean it's more amusing?" "Oh, much more." "You weren't afraid it would be dull?" "Yes, I was afraid it would be dull." "Well, you must stay, then." Milly turned, her hand upon the balustrade. "You think so?" "I'm sure of it." Kate spoke with confidence. Milly appeared to consider this. "Do you think I shall be here a long time?" "As long as you like." "That's just it. That's what I don't know." Kate said nothing, but she looked at Milly. "Do you know?" Milly asked. Kate continued to regard her with a smile. "I'm always trying to find out."

To see her alone, the poor girl, he none the less promptly felt, was to see her after all very much on the old basis, the basis of his three visits in New York; the new element, when once he was again face to face with her, not really amounting to much more than a recognition, with a little surprise, of the positive extent of the old basis. Everything but that, everything embarrassing fell away after he had been present five minutes: it was in fact wonderful that their excellent, their pleasant, their permitted and proper and harmless American relation—the legitimacy of which he could thus scarce express in names enough—should seem so unperturbed by other matters. They had both since then had great adventures—such an adventure for him was his mental annexation of her country; and it was now, for the moment, as if the greatest of them all were this acquired consciousness of reasons other than those that had already served. Densher had asked for her, at her hotel, the day after Aunt Maud's dinner, with a rich, that is with a highly troubled, preconception of the part likely to be played for him at present, in any contact with her, by Kate's and Mrs.

Translation

To see her alone, the poor girl, he nonetheless instantly felt that he was seeing her very much on the old footing, the same as during his three visits to New York. The new element, once he was face to face with her again, really amounted to little more than a recognition, with a touch of surprise, of how much of the old footing remained. Everything else, everything awkward, disappeared after he had been there for five minutes. It was actually remarkable that their excellent, pleasant, permissible, proper, and harmless American relationship—a relationship whose legitimacy he could barely express in sufficient words—should seem so undisturbed by other things. They had both experienced significant changes since then—for him, his mental appropriation of her country was one such change. And now, for the moment, it was as though the greatest of all of these changes was his newly acquired awareness of motivations beyond those that had already been in play. Densher had asked for her at her hotel the day after Aunt Maud’s dinner, burdened—that is, deeply troubled—by a preconceived notion of the role that Kate’s and Mrs.

Lowder's so oddly conjoined and so really superfluous attempts to make her interesting. She had been interesting enough without them—that appeared to-day to come back to him; and, admirable and beautiful as was the charitable zeal of the two ladies, it might easily have nipped in the bud the germs of a friendship inevitably limited but still perfectly open to him. What had happily averted the need of his breaking off, what would as happily continue to avert it, was his own good sense and good humour, a certain spring of mind in him which ministered, imagination aiding, to understandings and allowances and which he had positively never felt such ground as just now to rejoice in the possession of. Many men—he practically made the reflexion—wouldn't have taken the matter that way, would have lost patience, finding the appeal in question irrational, exorbitant; and, thereby making short work with it, would have let it render any further acquaintance with Miss Theale impossible.

Translation

Densher had requested to see her at her hotel the day after Aunt Maud’s dinner, weighed down—or rather, deeply troubled—by a preconceived notion of the role that Kate and Mrs. Lowder’s oddly connected, and ultimately superfluous, attempts to make her interesting played. She had been interesting enough without them—that now seemed clear to him. As admirable and beautiful as the two ladies’ charitable zeal was, it might have easily stifled the budding of a friendship that was inevitably limited but still perfectly open to him. What had happily prevented his breaking off, and what would continue to prevent it, was his own good sense and good humor, a certain resilience of mind that, with the help of his imagination, facilitated understanding and tolerance. He’d never felt so grateful for its presence as he did now. Many men—he practically reflected—wouldn’t have handled the matter that way, would have lost patience, finding the request in question irrational and excessive; and, by doing so, would have brought any further acquaintance with Miss Theale to an end.

He had talked with Kate of this young woman's being "sacrificed," and that would have been one way, so far as he was concerned, to sacrifice her. Such, however, had not been the tune to which his at first bewildered view had, since the night before, cleared itself up. It wasn't so much that he failed of being the kind of man who "chucked," for he knew himself as the kind of man wise enough to mark the case in which chucking might be the minor evil and the least cruelty. It was that he liked too much every one concerned willingly to show himself merely impracticable.

Translation

He'd discussed with Kate this young woman being "sacrificed," and that would have been one way, as far as he was concerned, to sacrifice her. However, that wasn't the way his initially confused view had cleared itself up since the night before. It wasn't so much that he wasn't the kind of man who would "chuck," for he knew he was the kind of man wise enough to recognize when chucking might be the lesser evil and the least cruel option. It was that he enjoyed too much everyone involved to willingly appear merely impractical.

He liked Kate, goodness knew, and he also clearly enough liked Mrs. Lowder. He liked in particular Milly herself; and hadn't it come up for him the evening before that he quite liked even Susan Shepherd? He had never known himself so generally merciful.

Translation

He liked Kate, God knows, and he clearly liked Mrs. Lowder, too. He particularly liked Milly herself; and hadn't it come to him the evening before that he even quite liked Susan Shepherd? He had never known himself to be so universally forgiving.

It was a footing, at all events, whatever accounted for it, on which he should surely be rather a muff not to manage by one turn or another to escape disobliging. Should he find he couldn't work it there would still be time enough. The idea of working it crystallised before him in such guise as not only to promise much interest—fairly, in case of success, much enthusiasm; but positively to impart to failure an appearance of barbarity. Despite everything, he immediately realized that seeing her alone was essentially like the three times he'd visited her in New York.

Translation

It was a starting point, at any rate, whatever the reason, that he'd be an idiot not to exploit in order to avoid being uncooperative. If he found he couldn't pull it off, there'd be time enough. The plan to make it work took shape in his mind in such a way as not only to promise a great deal of interest—honestly, in case of success, a great deal of enthusiasm—but actually to make failure seem barbaric. Despite it all, he immediately realized that seeing her alone was essentially like the three times he'd visited her in New York.

The new aspects of their relationship, once he was with her again, weren't that significant, just a slightly surprising recognition of the solid foundation they already had. After being together for five minutes, everything awkward vanished. It was amazing how their positive, pleasant, permissible, proper, and harmless American relationship – which he struggled to describe with enough approving words – remained unaffected by outside pressures. Both of them had had major experiences since then.

Translation

Once they were together again, the new elements of their relationship weren't really that important, just a mild surprise at the strong base they already shared. After five minutes, all the awkwardness was gone. It was remarkable how their positive, pleasant, permissible, proper, and harmless American relationship – which he had trouble praising enough – hadn't been touched by external forces. Both of them had been through a lot since then.

For him, it was his intellectual embrace of her country. Now, it felt like the most significant experience was this newfound awareness of reasons for his interest that went beyond what he'd felt before. Densher had asked for her at her hotel the day after Aunt Maud's dinner, expecting that Kate and Mrs. Lowder's strangely coordinated and ultimately unnecessary efforts to make her intriguing would complicate things.

Translation

For him, it was about connecting with her country on an intellectual level. Now, it seemed like the most important part was this new understanding of why he was drawn to her, going beyond what he'd felt before. Densher had gone to her hotel the day after Aunt Maud's dinner, expecting that Kate and Mrs. Lowder's weirdly planned and ultimately useless efforts to make her interesting would make things difficult.

She was interesting enough on her own, he realized now. As admirable and generous as the two women were, they could easily have stifled a potential friendship, one that would naturally have limits but was still possible for him. What had prevented him from ending things, and what would hopefully continue to do so, was his own good judgment and sense of humor, a certain mental agility that, with his imagination's help, fostered understanding and tolerance, which he'd never felt so grateful to possess. He considered that many men wouldn't have approached the situation in that way; they would have become impatient, finding her request unreasonable and excessive.

Translation

He understood now that she was interesting enough on her own merits. Admirable and generous as the two women were, they could have easily suffocated a friendship that, while naturally limited, was still possible for him. What had kept him from walking away, and what he hoped would continue to do so, was his own sound judgment and sense of humor. He valued his mental agility, which, aided by his imagination, encouraged understanding and tolerance—qualities he'd never been so thankful to have. He imagined that many men would not have approached the situation in the same way; they would have become impatient, considering her request unreasonable and excessive.

They would have given up, making any further acquaintance impossible. He had discussed with Kate how this young woman was being "sacrificed," and that would have been one way, as far as he was concerned, to sacrifice her. However, that wasn't how he'd understood things after the night before. It wasn't that he couldn't bring himself to "quit," because he knew he was the type of person who could recognize when quitting was the lesser of two evils and the least cruel option.

Translation

They would have abandoned the effort, ending any potential relationship. He and Kate had talked about how this young woman was being "sacrificed," and that would have been one way, as far as he was concerned, to sacrifice her. But that wasn't how he saw things after the previous night. It wasn't that he couldn't bring himself to "quit," because he knew he was the kind of person who could recognize when quitting was the best of bad options and the least painful one.

It was that he liked everyone involved too much to be deliberately difficult. He liked Kate, goodness knows, and he clearly liked Mrs. Lowder. He especially liked Milly herself, and hadn't he realized the night before that he even quite liked Susan Shepherd?

Translation

It wasn't that he was unwilling to be difficult, but that he genuinely enjoyed the company of everyone involved. He was fond of Kate, that much was certain, and he clearly held Mrs. Lowder in high regard. He was particularly drawn to Milly, and hadn't he come to the realization the previous night that he even found himself quite enjoying Susan Shepherd's presence?

He had never felt so generally sympathetic. Whatever the reason, he was in a position where he'd be foolish not to find a way to avoid causing offense. If he couldn't make it work, there'd be time enough. The idea of making it work became clear to him in a way that not only promised great interest – even enthusiasm if he succeeded – but also made failure seem barbaric.

Translation

He'd never felt so understanding of everyone. Whatever the cause, he was now in a position where it would be stupid not to find a way to avoid causing problems. If he couldn't pull it off, there'd be time to reconsider. The idea of succeeding became clear to him in a way that not only offered great interest—even enthusiasm, if he succeeded—but also made failure feel unacceptable.

Arriving thus in Brook Street both with the best intentions and with a margin consciously left for some primary awkwardness, he found his burden, to his great relief, unexpectedly light. The awkwardness involved in the responsibility so newly and so ingeniously traced for him turned round on the spot to present him another face. This was simply the face of his old impression, which he now fully recovered—the impression that American girls, when, rare case, they had the attraction of Milly, were clearly the easiest people in the world. Had what had happened been that this specimen of the class was from the first so committed to ease that nothing subsequent could ever make her difficult?

Translation

Arriving in Brook Street with the best of intentions, and consciously prepared for initial awkwardness, he was unexpectedly relieved to find his burden light. The awkwardness of the responsibility, so recently and cleverly defined, instantly shifted and showed him a different aspect. It was simply his old impression, now fully recovered: that American girls, when, as in Milly's rare case, they were attractive, were the most uncomplicated people in the world. Could it be that this particular example was from the start so dedicated to being easygoing that nothing could ever make her difficult?

That affected him now as still more probable than on the occasion of the hour or two lately passed with her in Kate's society. Milly Theale had recognised no complication, to Densher's view, while bringing him, with his companion, from the National Gallery and entertaining them at luncheon; it was therefore scarce supposable that complications had become so soon too much for her. His pretext for presenting himself was fortunately of the best and simplest; the least he could decently do, given their happy acquaintance, was to call with an enquiry after learning that she had been prevented by illness from meeting him at dinner. And then there was the beautiful accident of her other demonstration; he must at any rate have given a sign as a sequel to the hospitality he had shared with Kate.

Translation

That struck him now as even more likely than during the hour or two he'd recently spent with her in Kate's company. Milly Theale had shown no complexity, as far as Densher could tell, while taking him and his friend from the National Gallery and hosting them for lunch; it was therefore hardly believable that complications had overwhelmed her so quickly. His reason for showing up was, fortunately, the best and simplest; the least he could decently do, given their pleasant acquaintance, was to call to inquire after her, after learning she'd been prevented by illness from joining him for dinner. And then there was the beautiful coincidence of her other gesture; he had to at least follow up on the hospitality he'd shared with Kate.

Well, he was giving one now—such as it was; he was finding her, to begin with, accessible, and very naturally and prettily glad to see him. He had come, after luncheon, early, though not so early but that she might already be out if she were well enough; and she was well enough and yet was still at home. He had an inner glimpse, with this, of the comment Kate would have made on it; it wasn't absent from his thought that Milly would have been at home by her account because expecting, after a talk with Mrs. Stringham, that a certain person might turn up.

Translation

Well, he was giving one now—such as it was; he was finding her, to begin with, accessible, and very naturally and prettily glad to see him. He had come, after lunch, early, though not so early but that she might already be out if she were well enough; and she was well enough and yet was still at home. He had an inner glimpse, with this, of the comment Kate would have made on it; it wasn't absent from his thought that Milly would have been at home by her account because expecting, after a talk with Mrs. Stringham, that a certain person might turn up.

He even—so pleasantly did things go—enjoyed freedom of mind to welcome, on that supposition, a fresh sign of the beautiful hypocrisy of women. He went so far as to enjoy believing the girl might have stayed in for him; it helped him to enjoy her behaving as if she hadn't. She expressed, that is, exactly the right degree of surprise; she didn't a bit overdo it: the lesson of which was, perceptibly, that, so far as his late lights had opened the door to any want of the natural in their meetings, he might trust her to take care of it for him as well as for herself. She had begun this, admirably, on his entrance, with her turning away from the table at which she had apparently been engaged in letter-writing; it was the very possibility of his betraying a concern for her as one of the afflicted that she had within the first minute conjured away.

Translation

He even—so pleasantly did things go—enjoyed the freedom of mind to welcome, on that assumption, another instance of women's beautiful hypocrisy. He went so far as to enjoy believing the girl might have stayed in for him; it helped him to enjoy her behaving as if she hadn't. That is, she expressed precisely the right degree of surprise; she didn't overdo it at all: the lesson of which was, perceptibly, that, insofar as his recent insights had opened the door to any unnaturalness in their meetings, he could trust her to handle it for him as well as for herself. She had begun this admirably on his entrance, with her turning away from the table at which she had apparently been engaged in letter-writing; it was the very possibility of his betraying concern for her as one of the afflicted that she had dismissed in the first minute.

She was never, never—did he understand?—to be one of the afflicted for him; and the manner in which he understood it, something of the answering pleasure that he couldn't help knowing he showed, constituted, he was very soon after to acknowledge, something like a start for intimacy. When things like that could pass people had in truth to be equally conscious of a relation. It soon made one, at all events, when it didn't find one made. She had let him ask—there had been time for that, his allusion to her friend's explanatory arrival at Lancaster Gate without her being inevitable; but she had blown away, and quite as much with the look in her eyes as with the smile on her lips, every ground for anxiety and every chance for insistence.

Translation

She was never, never—did he understand?—to be one of the afflicted for him. The way he understood this, and the answering pleasure he couldn't help but show, would soon become, he would later admit, a kind of beginning for intimacy. When things like that could happen, people had to be equally aware of a relationship. It quickly formed one, at least, when one wasn't already there. She had let him ask—there had been time for that, his reference to her friend's explanation for arriving at Lancaster Gate without her, which wasn't inevitable—but she had dispelled, just as much with the look in her eyes as with the smile on her lips, every reason for concern and every opportunity for him to press the issue.

How was she?—why she was as he thus saw her and as she had reasons of her own, nobody else's business, for desiring to appear. Kate's account of her as too proud for pity, as fiercely shy about so personal a secret, came back to him; so that he rejoiced he could take a hint, especially when he wanted to. The question the girl had quickly disposed of—"Oh it was nothing: I'm all right, thank you!"—was one he was glad enough to be able to banish. It wasn't at all, in spite of the appeal Kate had made to him on it, his affair; for his interest had been invoked in the name of compassion, and the name of compassion was exactly what he felt himself at the end of two minutes forbidden so much as to whisper.

Translation

How was she? Why she was the way he saw her, and why she had her own reasons, none of which were anyone else's concern, for wanting to present herself in that manner. Kate's description of her as too proud for pity, as fiercely private about such a personal secret, came back to him. He was pleased he could take a hint, particularly when he wanted to. The question the girl had quickly dismissed—"Oh, it was nothing; I'm all right, thank you!"—was one he was happy to be rid of. It wasn't, not at all, despite Kate's plea, his concern. His interest had been engaged in the name of compassion, and the name of compassion was precisely what he was forbidden, after two minutes, even to whisper.

He had been sent to see her in order to be sorry for her, and how sorry he might be, quite privately, he was yet to make out. Didn't that signify, however, almost not at all?—inasmuch as, whatever his upshot, he was never to give her a glimpse of it. Thus the ground was unexpectedly cleared; though it was not till a slightly longer time had passed that he read clear, at first with amusement and then with a strange shade of respect, what had most operated. Extraordinarily, quite amazingly, he began to see that if his pity hadn't had to yield to still other things it would have had to yield quite definitely to her own.

Translation

He’d been tasked with visiting her to offer his sympathy, and he hadn't yet determined how much of that he'd privately feel. But didn't that really mean, practically speaking, nothing at all?—since, no matter his own conclusions, he was never to let her see any sign of them. This unexpectedly simplified things; although it wasn’t until a bit later that he fully understood, at first with a sense of amusement, then with a strange kind of respect, what had truly been at play. Remarkably, unbelievably, he began to realize that even if other factors hadn’t intervened, his pity would have ultimately been trumped by her own stance.

That was the way the case had turned round: he had made his visit to be sorry for her, but he would repeat it—if he did repeat it—in order that she might be sorry for him. His situation made him, she judged—when once one liked him—a subject for that degree of tenderness: he felt this judgement in her, and felt it as something he should really, in decency, in dignity, in common honesty, have very soon to reckon with. When he arrived at Brook Street, he had good intentions, expecting some initial awkwardness. However, to his surprise and relief, the situation felt much easier than he anticipated.

Translation

The tables had turned. He'd come to offer her his condolences, but if he returned—and he probably would—it would be so she could offer hers to him. He could tell she now saw his circumstances as something that, once you warmed to him, invited a certain kind of tenderness. He felt her assessment, and understood that, out of a sense of decency, of dignity, of basic honesty, he'd soon have to acknowledge it. When he'd arrived at Brook Street, he'd had good intentions and anticipated some initial awkwardness. But, to his surprise and relief, the situation felt much simpler than he'd expected.

The potential for awkwardness, stemming from his recently acquired responsibility, quickly shifted, revealing a different aspect. It presented the same feeling he had always had – that American girls, especially those as attractive as Milly, were remarkably easygoing. Did this mean Milly was so naturally comfortable that nothing could ever make her difficult? This seemed even more likely now than it did during the brief time he spent with her and Kate.

Translation

The potential for discomfort, a consequence of his new burden, soon dissolved, giving way to something else. It evoked the same sensation he'd always had—that American women, particularly those as appealing as Milly, possessed an extraordinary, natural ease. Did this imply Milly's temperament was so inherently relaxed that nothing could ever unsettle her? This seemed more plausible now than during his brief acquaintance with her and Kate.

Milly Theale hadn't shown any complications, as far as Densher could tell, when she brought him and his friend from the National Gallery and then hosted them for lunch. It was therefore unlikely that complications had suddenly overwhelmed her. His reason for visiting was simple and appropriate. Given their pleasant acquaintance, the least he could do was check on her after learning she had been unable to join him for dinner due to illness.

Translation

Milly Theale hadn't seemed complicated, from Densher's perspective, when she'd introduced him and his friend from the National Gallery and then invited them for lunch. It was thus improbable that she'd suddenly become complicated. His motivation for visiting was straightforward and appropriate. Considering their amiable relationship, the least he could do was inquire after her well-being after learning she'd been prevented by illness from attending dinner.

Moreover, there was the fortunate coincidence of her being at home. He had to acknowledge that he'd made a gesture following the hospitality he'd received from Kate. Well, he was doing so now, and he found her accessible and genuinely pleased to see him. He had come early, after lunch, although not so early that she might have gone out if she had been feeling well.

Translation

Furthermore, the happy chance of her being at home was a factor. He had to concede that he was reciprocating Kate’s kindness. Indeed, he was doing so now, and found her approachable and plainly glad to see him. He had arrived early, after lunch, though not so early that she might have gone out if she had been well.

However, she was well enough to be at home. He imagined what Kate might say about it; it occurred to him that Milly might have stayed home because she knew, after talking to Mrs. Stringham, that a certain person might come by. He was even amused by the possibility, welcoming it as another example of women's pleasant deception.

Translation

However, she was well enough to be at home. He imagined what Kate might say about it; it occurred to him that Milly might have stayed home because she knew, after talking to Mrs. Stringham, that a certain person might come by. He was even amused by the possibility, welcoming it as another example of women's pleasant deception.

He even enjoyed the thought that she might have stayed in for him, which allowed him to appreciate her acting as if she hadn't. She expressed the appropriate level of surprise, never exaggerating. The lesson was clear: if his recent behavior had hinted at any unnaturalness in their interactions, he could trust her to handle it as skillfully as she handled herself. She had started this perfectly the moment he entered, turning away from the table where she'd been writing.

Translation

He found pleasure in the idea that she'd remained at home for him, which let him admire her performance of innocence. Her surprise was perfectly measured, never excessive. The implication was clear: if his recent conduct had suggested any awkwardness in their relationship, he could depend on her to navigate it with the same finesse she applied to her own conduct. She had begun this flawlessly the instant he'd arrived, turning away from the table where she had been writing.

She had instantly dispelled any potential for him to express concern for her as someone who was unwell. He was never, ever – did he understand? – to consider her someone to be pitied. And the way he understood this, the pleasure he couldn't help showing in response, was, he later acknowledged, the beginning of their intimacy.

Translation

She'd nipped in the bud any possibility of him worrying over her as if she were under the weather. He was never—never, do you hear me?—to think of her as someone deserving of his pity. And his understanding of this, the open delight he couldn't hide, was, he would later admit, the genesis of their closeness.

When such unspoken agreements were made, people were truly aware of their relationship. It quickly established one, or at least confirmed one that was already there. She allowed him to ask – there had been time for that, his reference to her friend's explanation for arriving at Lancaster Gate without her being inevitable – but she eliminated, with the look in her eyes and the smile on her lips, any reason for worry or further questions. How was she?

Translation

When these unspoken understandings were reached, the nature of their connection became crystal clear. It swiftly cemented a bond, or at least validated one that already existed. She let him ask—there had been an opportunity for it, his allusion to her friend's account of how she'd come to Lancaster Gate without her was unavoidable—but she, with a look and a smile, quashed any basis for concern or additional inquiries. Was she alright?

Well, she was as he saw her, and, for her own reasons, she wanted to appear that way. Kate's description of her as too proud to be pitied and fiercely private about her illness came to mind, and he was glad he could understand a hint, especially when he wanted to. The question she had quickly dismissed with, "Oh, it was nothing; I'm all right, thank you!" was one he was relieved to avoid. Despite Kate's urging, it wasn't his concern.

Translation

She was exactly as he perceived her, and for her own reasons, she wanted to maintain that facade. Kate's assessment of her—too proud to accept pity, fiercely protective of her privacy regarding her illness—surfaced in his thoughts. He appreciated his ability to pick up on subtleties, especially when it suited him. The question she'd quickly brushed aside with "Oh, it was nothing; I'm all right, thank you!" was one he was grateful to sidestep. Regardless of Kate's prodding, it wasn't his place to pry.

His interest was meant to be rooted in compassion, but compassion was the last thing he could offer. He was sent to see her to offer sympathy, but how he felt privately, he had yet to determine. Perhaps it didn't matter at all, because, regardless of his feelings, he wouldn't show them. The situation unexpectedly simplified.

Translation

His concern was supposed to be genuine, yet empathy was beyond his grasp. He was there to express his condolences, but his personal feelings remained a mystery, even to himself. Perhaps it was irrelevant, because, regardless of what he felt, he wouldn't reveal it. The situation unexpectedly became less complicated.

It wasn't until a while later that he understood, first with amusement and then with a strange respect, what had truly happened. He realized that if his pity hadn't had to yield to other things, it would have had to yield to hers. She had turned the situation around: he came to feel sorry for her, but he would return – if he returned at all – so that she could feel sorry for him. His situation, she seemed to think, made him a subject for tenderness once you liked him.

Translation

It took some time for him to understand, initially with amusement, then with a peculiar respect, what had actually occurred. He saw that even if his pity hadn’t been preempted, it still would have been overtaken by hers. She'd managed to flip the script: he ended up feeling sorry for her, but he would come back – if he came back at all – so that she could pity him. He was, as she seemed to think, someone you could feel tender toward, once you liked him.

He felt this judgment coming from her, and he knew he would soon have to deal with it, out of decency, dignity, and basic honesty. Odd enough was it certainly that the question originally before him, the question placed there by Kate, should so of a sudden find itself quite dislodged by another. This other, it was easy to see, came straight up with the fact of her beautiful delusion and her wasted charity; the whole thing preparing for him as pretty a case of conscience as he could have desired, and one at the prospect of which he was already wincing. If he was interesting it was because he was unhappy; and if he was unhappy it was because his passion for Kate had spent itself in vain; and if Kate was indifferent, inexorable, it was because she had left Milly in no doubt of it.

Translation

He sensed her judgment, and he understood he'd have to face it soon, driven by his sense of what was proper, his pride, and basic honesty. Strangely enough, the original question, the one Kate had posed, had been completely displaced by another. It was obvious the new question was about her beautiful delusion and the charity she'd wasted; the whole thing was setting up a moral dilemma for him, a predicament he'd actually hoped for, and the thought of it made him wince. He was interesting because he was unhappy; and he was unhappy because his passion for Kate had been futile; and if Kate was indifferent and unyielding, it was because she had made Milly fully aware of her feelings.

That above all was what came up for him—how clear an impression of this attitude, how definite an account of his own failure, Kate must have given her friend. His immediate quarter of an hour there with the girl lighted up for him almost luridly such an inference; it was almost as if the other party to their remarkable understanding had been with them as they talked, had been hovering about, had dropped in to look after her work. The value of the work affected him as different from the moment he saw it so expressed in poor Milly. Since it was false that he wasn't loved, so his right was quite quenched to figure on that ground as important; and if he didn't look out he should find himself appreciating in a way quite at odds with straightness the good faith of Milly's benevolence.

Translation

Above all else, that's what came to him—how vividly Kate must have conveyed this attitude, how precise an account of his failure she must have given her friend. His fifteen minutes there with the girl illuminated such an inference for him almost grotesquely; it was as if the other party to their unusual understanding had been with them as they spoke, had been nearby, had come to oversee her project.
