The value of the project seemed different to him from the moment he saw it expressed in poor Milly. Since it wasn't true that he wasn't loved, his right to be considered significant on that basis was completely extinguished; and if he wasn't careful, he would find himself appreciating, in a way that was entirely at odds with integrity, the sincerity of Milly's generosity.

There was the place for scruples; there the need absolutely to mind what he was about. If it wasn't proper for him to enjoy consideration on a perfectly false footing, where was the guarantee that, if he kept on, he mightn't soon himself pretend to the grievance in order not to miss the sweet? Consideration—from a charming girl—was soothing on whatever theory; and it didn't take him far to remember that he had himself as yet done nothing deceptive. It was Kate's description of him, his defeated state, it was none of his own; his responsibility would begin, as he might say, only with acting it out.

Translation

That was the point to start being careful; he absolutely had to pay attention to what he was doing. If he couldn't enjoy being appreciated based on something completely false, what was to stop him from eventually pretending to be aggrieved so he could still have that sweet feeling? Being appreciated—by a charming girl—was comforting, regardless; and he didn't have to think hard to remember he hadn't actually done anything deceitful yet. It was Kate who'd described him, his defeated state, not him; his own responsibility would only begin when he started acting it out, so to speak.

The sharp point was, however, in the difference between acting and not acting: this difference in fact it was that made the case of conscience. He saw it with a certain alarm rise before him that everything was acting that was not speaking the particular word. "If you like me because you think she doesn't, it isn't a bit true: she does like me awfully!"—that would have been the particular word; which there were at the same time but too palpably such difficulties about his uttering. Wouldn't it be virtually as indelicate to challenge her as to leave her deluded?—and this quite apart from the exposure, so to speak, of Kate, as to whom it would constitute a kind of betrayal.

Translation

The crux of the matter, however, lay in the difference between acting and not acting: that very distinction defined the problem of conscience. He saw, with a certain alarm, that anything that wasn't speaking the specific word was, in fact, acting. "If you like me because you think she doesn't, it's not true at all: she actually likes me a lot!"—that would have been the specific word; and simultaneously, there were palpable difficulties in his saying it. Wouldn't challenging her be virtually as insensitive as allowing her to be deluded?—and this was completely separate from the exposure, so to speak, of Kate, which would constitute a kind of betrayal.

Kate's design was something so extraordinarily special to Kate that he felt himself shrink from the complications involved in judging it. Not to give away the woman one loved, but to back her up in her mistakes—once they had gone a certain length—that was perhaps chief among the inevitabilities of the abjection of love. Loyalty was of course supremely prescribed in presence of any design on her part, however roundabout, to do one nothing but good. It was certainly strange that the original question, the one Kate had raised, was suddenly replaced by another.

Translation

Kate's design was something so extraordinarily special to her that he recoiled from the complications of judging it. Not to betray the woman one loved, but to support her in her mistakes—once they'd gone a certain distance—that was perhaps the most crucial of the inevitabilities in the degradation of love. Loyalty was, of course, absolutely required in the presence of any plan on her part, however indirect, to do only good things for him. It was certainly strange that the original question, the one Kate had raised, was suddenly replaced by another.

This new question, it was easy to see, came directly from her beautiful delusion and the charity she had wasted on him. This presented a moral dilemma for him, a situation he found himself already dreading. He was interesting because he was unhappy. He was unhappy because his passion for Kate had failed.

Translation

The new question, it was plain to see, sprang directly from her exquisite self-deception and the goodwill she'd squandered on him. This posed a moral problem for him, a predicament he already knew he would hate. His appeal stemmed from his unhappiness. He was unhappy because his love for Kate had failed.

Kate, being indifferent and unyielding, had clearly convinced Milly of his unsuitability. That, above all, was what emerged for him—how definite an idea of this attitude, how precise an account of his failure, Kate must have given her friend. His recent conversation with Milly revealed this to him in an almost shocking way. It was as if the other person involved in their peculiar understanding had been present, hovering nearby, as if she had come to check on her work.

Translation

Kate, in her indifference and refusal to give way, had obviously persuaded Milly that he wasn't right for her. That, more than anything, was what became clear to him—the distinctness of this impression, how specific an explanation of his shortcomings Kate must have provided to her friend. His recent talk with Milly showed him this in a way that was almost jarring. It was as if the other party to their unusual understanding had been there, nearby, watching, as if she had come to inspect her handiwork.

The value of that "work" appeared different from the moment he saw it expressed in poor Milly. Since it was not true that he wasn't loved, his claim to importance on that basis was gone; and if he wasn't careful, he would find himself appreciating Milly's generosity in a way that was dishonest. That was where his moral concerns began; there, he absolutely needed to be careful. If it was wrong for him to enjoy the attention based on a false premise, how could he be certain that, if he continued, he wouldn't soon pretend to have been wronged just to avoid missing out on the pleasure?

Translation

The worth of that "work" shifted the moment he saw it reflected in poor Milly. Since it wasn't true that he wasn't loved, his claim to significance, founded on that lie, had evaporated. If he wasn't careful, he'd end up appreciating Milly's kindness in a way that felt wrong. That was where his moral anxieties started; he had to be vigilant there. If it was wrong for him to relish the attention based on a false pretense, how could he be certain that, if he kept going, he wouldn't soon pretend to be the victim simply to keep from missing out on the pleasure?

Attention—from a charming girl—was soothing no matter the basis; and he quickly remembered that he hadn't yet done anything deceptive. It was Kate's portrayal of him, his defeated state; it wasn't of his own doing. His responsibility would start, as he might say, only with acting it out. The crucial point, however, was the difference between acting and not acting: this difference, in fact, was what created the moral problem.

Translation

Attention—from an appealing young woman—soothed him no matter the cause; and he quickly reminded himself that he hadn't yet done anything deceptive himself. It was Kate's depiction of him, his defeated state; it wasn't his doing. His responsibility, he might say, would only begin with the acting. The crucial point, however, was the difference between acting and not acting: this difference, in fact, was what created the moral problem.

He saw with some fear that everything was acting that didn't involve him speaking the specific words. "If you like me because you think she doesn't, it's not true at all: she really does like me!"—those would have been the particular words; which, however, it was obvious to him, he would have great difficulty saying. Wouldn't it be almost as insensitive to challenge her as it would be to let her remain deluded?—and this, aside from the exposure, so to speak, of Kate, which would constitute a betrayal. Kate's plan was so extraordinarily unique to Kate that he felt reluctant to consider the complications.

Translation

He realized, with a touch of dread, that everything was a performance unless he was actually speaking the lines. "If you're into me because you think she's not, it's totally not true: she really is into me!"—those were the specific words. But it was clear to him that he'd have a hell of a time saying them. Wouldn't it be almost as cruel to confront her as it would be to let her stay in the dark?—and that was ignoring, so to speak, the exposure of Kate, which would be a betrayal. Kate's plan was so completely and utterly Kate's that he was hesitant to contemplate the mess it created.

Not to reveal the woman one loved, but to support her mistakes—once they had gone a certain distance—was perhaps a central aspect of the humiliation of love. Loyalty was, of course, absolutely required when it involved any plan of hers, no matter how indirect, to only do good for him. Densher had quite to steady himself not to be awestruck at the immensity of the good his own friend must on all this evidence have wanted to do him. Of one thing indeed meanwhile he was sure: Milly Theale wouldn't herself precipitate his necessity of intervention.

Translation

To protect the woman he loved by supporting her mistakes—after they'd gone far enough—might be the core of love's humiliation. Loyalty was, without question, essential when it involved her plans, however subtle, to only benefit him. Densher had to work to keep from being overwhelmed by how much good his own friend must, according to all this, have wanted to do for him. In the meantime, he was certain of one thing: Milly Theale wouldn't herself force him to intervene.

She would absolutely never say to him: "Is it so impossible she shall ever care for you seriously?"—without which nothing could well be less delicate than for him aggressively to set her right. Kate would be free to do that if Kate, in some prudence, some contrition, for some better reason in fine, should revise her plan; but he asked himself what, failing this, he could do that wouldn't be after all more gross than doing nothing. This brought him round again to the acceptance of the fact that the poor girl liked him. She put it, for reasons of her own, on a simple, a beautiful ground, a ground that already supplied her with the pretext she required.

Translation

She would never, under any circumstances, ask him: "Is it really so impossible that she will ever care for you deeply?" Without that, there was nothing less graceful than for him to aggressively correct her. Kate could do that if Kate, in some moment of caution, some remorse, for some better reason, decided to change her plan. But he asked himself what, without that, he could do that wouldn't, in the end, be more crude than doing nothing. This brought him back to the acceptance of the fact that the poor girl was fond of him. She phrased it, for her own reasons, in simple, beautiful terms, terms that already provided her with the excuse she needed.

The ground was there, that is, in the impression she had received, retained, cherished; the pretext, over and above it, was the pretext for acting on it. That she now believed as she did made her sure at last that she might act; so that what Densher therefore would have struck at would be the root, in her soul, of a pure pleasure. It positively lifted its head and flowered, this pure pleasure, while the young man now sat with her, and there were things she seemed to say that took the words out of his mouth. These were not all the things she did say; they were rather what such things meant in the light of what he knew.

Translation

The foundation was there—in the impression she had received, retained, and cherished. The excuse, beyond that, was the excuse to act upon it. The fact that she now believed what she did made her certain, finally, that she could act. So, what Densher would have attacked would be the root, in her soul, of a pure pleasure. This pure pleasure positively lifted its head and blossomed while the young man sat with her. She seemed to say things that took the words right out of his mouth. These weren't all the things she said, but rather what such things signified in the light of what he already knew.

Her warning him for instance off the question of how she was, the quick brave little art with which she did that, represented to his fancy a truth she didn't utter. "I'm well for you—that's all you have to do with or need trouble about: I shall never be anything so horrid as ill for you. So there you are; worry about me, spare me, please, as little as you can. Don't be afraid, in short, to ignore my 'interesting' side.

Translation

Her cautioning him, for instance, away from the question of her health, the quick, brave little performance with which she did that, represented to his imagination a truth she didn't speak aloud. "I'm well for you—that's all you have to do with or need trouble about: I shall never be anything so awful as ill for you. So there you have it; worry about me, spare me, please, as little as you can. Don't be afraid, in short, to ignore my 'interesting' side."

It isn't, you see, even now while you sit here, that there aren't lots of others. Only do them justice and we shall get on beautifully." This was what was folded finely up in her talk—all quite ostensibly about her impressions and her intentions. She tried to put Densher again on his American doings, but he wouldn't have that to-day. As he thought of the way in which, the other afternoon, before Kate, he had sat complacently "jawing," he accused himself of excess, of having overdone it, having made—at least apparently—more of a "set" at their entertainer than he was at all events then intending.

Translation

You see, even now, as you sit here, there are plenty of others. Just give them a fair chance, and we'll be fine." That was the unspoken message of her words—all of which ostensibly concerned her impressions and intentions. She tried to redirect Densher's attention to his activities in America, but he wasn't having it today. He thought back to how, the other afternoon, he had sat there complacently "talking," and he accused himself of going too far, of overdoing it, of having made—or at least seeming to have made—more of an "impression" on their hostess than he had actually intended at the time.

He turned the tables, drawing her out about London, about her vision of life there, and only too glad to treat her as a person with whom he could easily have other topics than her aches and pains. He spoke to her above all of the evidence offered him at Lancaster Gate that she had come but to conquer; and when she had met this with full and gay assent—"How could I help being the feature of the season, the what-do-you-call-it, the theme of every tongue?"—they fraternised freely over all that had come and gone for each since their interrupted encounter in New York. Densher had to restrain himself from being overwhelmed by the incredible kindness his friend must have wanted to show him, based on all the evidence. However, he was sure of one thing: Milly Theale wouldn't force him to intervene.

Translation

He changed the subject, asking her about London, about her view of life there. He was happy to talk to her about things besides her illnesses. He told her, above all else, about the impression he'd gotten at Lancaster Gate—that she'd arrived only to win. And when she agreed, cheerfully, "How could I not be the talk of the town, the whatchamacallit, the main topic of conversation?"—they bonded over everything that had happened since their interrupted meeting in New York. Densher had to stop himself from being bowled over by the incredible generosity that his friend must have wanted to show him, based on all that had happened. But one thing was certain: Milly Theale wouldn't force him to get involved.

She would never ask him, "Is it so impossible that I could ever truly care for you?" Without that, it would be inappropriate for him to aggressively correct her. Kate could do that if she, in some wisdom or regret, or for a better reason, changed her mind. But Densher wondered what he could do, apart from that, that wouldn't be as bad as doing nothing. This brought him back to accepting the fact that the poor girl liked him.

Translation

She would never ask him, "Is it really so impossible that I could ever truly love you?" Without that, it wouldn't be right for him to confront her directly. Kate could do that, should she, with wisdom or regret, or for a better reason, change her mind. But Densher wondered what he could do, besides that, that wouldn't be as bad as doing nothing. This brought him back to accepting that the poor girl was fond of him.

She explained it, for her own reasons, in a simple, beautiful way, which already gave her the reason she needed. The foundation was there, in the impression she had formed, remembered, and treasured; the reason, beyond that, was the reason to act on it. Because she now believed as she did, she was certain that she could act; so what Densher would be attacking was the source of a pure joy in her soul. This pure joy visibly flourished as the young man sat with her, and there were things she seemed to say that he would have said himself.

Translation

She explained it, for her own purposes, in a way that was simple and lovely, which already provided her with the rationale she required. The bedrock was already there, in the impression she'd made, recalled, and cherished; the justification, beyond that, was the reason to act upon it. Because she now believed as she did, she was sure she could act; so what Densher would be attacking was the origin of a pure joy within her. This pure joy visibly blossomed as the young man sat with her, and there were things she seemed to say that he would have said himself.

These weren't all the things she said; they were what those things meant, given what he knew. For example, her warning him not to ask about her health, the quick and brave way she did it, showed him a truth she didn't speak aloud. "I'm well for your sake—that's all you need to know or worry about. I'll never be something as awful as being ill for you.

Translation

These weren't her exact words, but the underlying meaning, considering what he understood. For instance, her swift, defiant refusal to discuss her health revealed something unspoken. "My health is fine, for your sake—that's all you need to know or concern yourself with. I will never allow myself to become a burden to you through illness."

So there you have it; worry about me as little as possible. In short, don't be afraid to ignore my 'interesting' side. There are, even now while you're here, plenty of others who do. Just be fair to them, and we'll get along beautifully." This was what was subtly implied in her conversation—which was all apparently about her impressions and plans.

Translation

That's the gist of it: don't fret over me. Basically, feel free to overlook my more… eccentric qualities. There are plenty of others who do, even now, while you're here. Just treat them right, and we'll be perfectly fine." That was the unspoken message woven into her words, which, on the surface, were all about her opinions and future endeavors.

She tried to get Densher to talk about his American activities again, but he wouldn't. Thinking about how he'd sat there and "chatted" comfortably the other afternoon, in front of Kate, he accused himself of going too far, of exaggerating, of at least seeming to make more of an effort to impress their hostess than he'd intended. He changed the subject, asking her about London, about her view of life there, and was glad to treat her as someone he could talk to about other things besides her pains and discomforts. He spoke to her about the evidence he'd seen at Lancaster Gate that she had come to conquer, and when she happily agreed - "How could I help being the star of the season, the whatchamacallit, the talk of everyone?" - they shared a comfortable understanding of everything that had happened for each of them since their interrupted meeting in New York.

Translation

She tried to get Densher to open up about what he'd been doing in America, but he wouldn't. Recalling how he'd sat and “chatted” so easily the other day, in front of Kate, he chided himself for getting carried away, for exaggerating, for at least appearing to try harder to impress her than he had meant to. He changed the topic, asking her about London, about her experience of it, and was relieved to treat her as someone he could talk to about things other than her ailments. He asked her about the evidence he’d seen at Lancaster Gate that she’d come to conquer, and when she happily agreed—“How could I help being the star of the season, the whatchamacallit, the talk of everyone?”—they shared a comfortable understanding of everything that had happened to them since their interrupted meeting in New York.

At the same time, while many things in quick succession came up for them, came up in particular for Densher, nothing perhaps was just so sharp as the odd influence of their present conditions on their view of their past ones. It was as if they hadn't known how "thick" they had originally become, as if, in a manner, they had really fallen to remembrance of more passages of intimacy than there had in fact at the time quite been room for. They were in a relation now so complicated, whether by what they said or by what they didn't say, that it might have been seeking to justify its speedy growth by reaching back to one of those fabulous periods in which prosperous states place their beginnings. He recalled what had been said at Mrs.

Translation

At the same time, though so many things quickly arose for them, and especially for Densher, perhaps nothing was so striking as the peculiar effect of their current circumstances on their understanding of the past. It was as though they hadn't realized how close they had once been, as if, in a way, they were remembering more intimate moments than had actually occurred. Their relationship was now so complex, both in what they said and what they left unsaid, that it seemed to be trying to justify its rapid development by reaching back to one of those legendary periods in which successful nations locate their origins. He thought back to what had been said at Mrs.

Lowder's about the steps and stages, in people's careers, that absence caused one to miss, and about the resulting frequent sense of meeting them further on; which, with some other matters also recalled, he took occasion to communicate to Milly. The matters he couldn't mention mingled themselves with those he did; so that it would doubtless have been hard to say which of the two groups now played most of a part. He was kept face to face with this young lady by a force absolutely resident in their situation and operating, for his nerves, with the swiftness of the forces commonly regarded by sensitive persons as beyond their control. The current thus determined had positively become for him, by the time he had been ten minutes in the room, something that, but for the absurdity of comparing the very small with the very great, he would freely have likened to the rapids of Niagara.

Translation

At the same time, though so many things quickly arose for them, and especially for Densher, perhaps nothing was so striking as the peculiar effect of their current circumstances on their understanding of the past. It was as though they hadn't realized how close they had once been, as if, in a way, they were remembering more intimate moments than had actually occurred. Their relationship was now so complex, both in what they said and what they left unsaid, that it seemed to be trying to justify its rapid development by reaching back to one of those legendary periods in which successful nations locate their origins. He thought back to what had been said at Mrs. Lowder's about the steps and stages, in people's careers, that absence caused one to miss, and about the resulting frequent sense of meeting them further on; which, with some other matters also recalled, he took occasion to communicate to Milly. The matters he couldn't mention mingled themselves with those he did; so that it would doubtless have been hard to say which of the two groups now played most of a part. He was kept face to face with this young lady by a force absolutely resident in their situation and operating, for his nerves, with the swiftness of the forces commonly regarded by sensitive persons as beyond their control. The current thus determined had positively become for him, by the time he had been ten minutes in the room, something that, but for the absurdity of comparing the very small with the very great, he would freely have likened to the rapids of Niagara.

An uncriticised acquaintance between a clever young man and a responsive young woman could do nothing more, at the most, than go, and his actual experiment went and went and went. Nothing probably so conduced to make it go as the marked circumstance that they had spoken all the while not a word about Kate; and this in spite of the fact that, if it were a question for them of what had occurred in the past weeks, nothing had occurred comparable to Kate's predominance. Densher had but the night before appealed to her for instruction as to what he must do about her, but he fairly winced to find how little this came to. She had foretold him of course how little; but it was a truth that looked different when shown him by Milly.

Translation

A casual, unquestioned relationship between a smart young man and a receptive young woman could only progress so far, and his actual experiment just kept going and going and going. Nothing likely fueled its momentum as much as the significant fact that they hadn't mentioned Kate at all; this despite the fact that, if they were to discuss what had transpired in recent weeks, nothing had been as prominent as Kate's presence. Densher had, only the night before, sought her guidance on what he should do regarding Kate, but he actually recoiled at how insignificant this now seemed. Of course, she had predicted it would amount to little; but it was a truth that appeared different when Milly revealed it to him.

It proved to him that the latter had in fact been dealt with, but it produced in him the thought that Kate might perhaps again conveniently be questioned. He would have liked to speak to her before going further—to make sure she really meant him to succeed quite so much. With all the difference that, as we say, came up for him, it came up afresh, naturally, that he might make his visit brief and never renew it; yet the strangest thing of all was that the argument against that issue would have sprung precisely from the beautiful little eloquence involved in Milly's avoidances. At the same time, while many things happened rapidly for them, especially for Densher, nothing was as striking as the strange way their current situation affected how they viewed their past.

Translation

This showed him that the whole thing was settled, but it also made him think that Kate could be questioned again, as if it were easy. He wanted to talk to her before going any further—to make sure she really wanted him to succeed so completely. Given all the change that had come over him, he found himself thinking, as you would expect, that he could make the visit brief and never repeat it. But the strangest thing was that the reason against leaving would have come directly from Milly's subtle way of dodging the subject. At the same time, while a lot of things happened quickly for them, especially for Densher, nothing was as striking as the strange way their current situation changed how they saw the past.

It was as if they hadn't realized how close they had become initially, as if they were now remembering more intimate moments than had actually occurred. Their relationship was so complex now, shaped by what they said and didn't say, that it seemed to be justifying its rapid development by reaching back to an imagined origin, similar to how successful nations create their own histories. He recalled a conversation at Mrs. Lowder's about how much of people's lives you miss due to absence, and how you frequently encounter them later on.

Translation

It was as though they hadn't understood the depth of their early connection, as if they were now embellishing memories, inflating intimacy beyond the actual moments shared. Their bond was now so intricate, defined by unspoken as much as spoken words, that it seemed to legitimize its quick evolution by fabricating a past, not unlike how thriving nations invent their own narratives. He thought of a discussion at Mrs. Lowder's regarding the vast swaths of a person's life that go unseen due to separation, and how often one unexpectedly encounters those same people later.

He shared this memory with Milly, along with some other thoughts. The things he couldn't mention blended with those he did, so it would have been difficult to say which group had a greater influence. He was forced to confront this young woman by a force inherent in their situation, which affected his nerves with a speed that sensitive people often consider uncontrollable. By the time he'd been in the room for ten minutes, this determined current had become something he would have compared to the rapids of Niagara, if it weren't so absurd to compare such a small thing to something so great.

Translation

He related this memory to Milly, along with some other observations. The things he couldn't articulate mingled with those he could, making it hard to say which had a stronger effect. He was driven to face this young woman by a power inherent in their circumstances, which impacted his composure with a swiftness that highly-strung people often find impossible to regulate. Within ten minutes of being in the room, this insistent pressure had grown to something he might have likened to the Niagara's currents, if it weren't so ridiculous to compare something so insignificant to something so monumental.

A simple friendship between a clever young man and a receptive young woman could only go so far, but his experiment kept going and going. Perhaps the main reason it continued was that they hadn't said a word about Kate, even though Kate's influence had been the most significant thing that had happened in recent weeks. Densher had asked Kate for guidance the previous night, but he was surprised to see how little that request seemed to matter now. She had predicted how little it would matter, of course, but the reality looked different when Milly presented it to him.

Translation

A straightforward friendship between a smart young man and a responsive young woman could only develop so much, but his experiment persisted. Maybe the main reason it continued was that they hadn't spoken about Kate, even though Kate's influence had been the most important event of the past few weeks. Densher had asked Kate for guidance the previous night, but he was surprised to see how little that request seemed to matter now. She had predicted how little it would matter, of course, but the reality looked different when Milly presented it to him.

It showed him that Milly had, in fact, been manipulated, but it also made him consider whether Kate might be questioned again. He would have liked to speak to her before proceeding—to be sure she really wanted him to succeed so completely. With all the new possibilities now available to him, he could, of course, make his visit brief and never return; yet the strangest thing was that the argument against that course of action would have come precisely from the subtle eloquence of Milly's silences. Precipitate these well might be, since they emphasised the fact that she was proceeding in the sense of the assurances she had taken.

Translation

It revealed that Milly had, in fact, been manipulated, but it also made him wonder if Kate might be questioned again. He would have preferred to talk to her before moving forward—to confirm that she truly wanted his complete success. Considering all the new possibilities available to him, he could, of course, make his visit short and never return; yet the strangest thing was that the argument against that option would have stemmed from the subtle eloquence of Milly's silences. To rush things now might be unwise, since they emphasized that she was following through on the assurances she had given.

Over the latter she had visibly not hesitated, for hadn't they had the merit of giving her a chance? Densher quite saw her, felt her take it; the chance, neither more nor less, of help rendered him according to her freedom. It was what Kate had left her with: "Listen to him, I? Never!

Translation

Over the latter, she hadn’t visibly hesitated. After all, didn't they give her a chance? Densher clearly saw her, felt her seize it—the chance, neither more nor less, of helping him as she saw fit. It was what Kate had left her with: "Listen to him? Never!"

So do as you like." What Milly "liked" was to do, it thus appeared, as she was doing: our young man's glimpse of which was just what would have been for him not less a glimpse of the peculiar brutality of shaking her off. The choice exhaled its shy fragrance of heroism, for it was not aided by any question of parting with Kate. She would be charming to Kate as well as to Kate's adorer; she would incur whatever pain could dwell for her in the sight—should she continue to be exposed to the sight—of the adorer thrown with the adored. It wouldn't really have taken much more to make him wonder if he hadn't before him one of those rare cases of exaltation—food for fiction, food for poetry—in which a man's fortune with the woman who doesn't care for him is positively promoted by the woman who does.

Translation

"So do as you like." What Milly "liked" was to do, it seemed, what she was doing. The young man's realization of this was also a realization of the peculiar brutality of dismissing her. The choice carried a shy fragrance of heroism, because it wasn't connected to the question of separating from Kate. She would be charming to Kate, as well as to Kate's admirer; she would endure whatever pain might reside within her to witness—should she continue to be exposed to the sight—the admirer's devotion to the adored. It wouldn't really have taken much more for him to wonder if he wasn't witnessing one of those rare cases of exaltation—food for fiction, food for poetry—in which a man's fortune with the woman who doesn't love him is actually aided by the woman who does.

It was as if Milly had said to herself: "Well, he can at least meet her in my society, if that's anything to him; so that my line can only be to make my society attractive." She certainly couldn't have made a different impression if she had so reasoned. All of which, none the less, didn't prevent his soon enough saying to her, quite as if she were to be whirled into space: "And now, then, what becomes of you? Do you begin to rush about on visits to country-houses?" These decisions were inevitable, as they highlighted the fact that she was acting according to the promises she had made.

Translation

It was as if Milly had thought to herself: "Well, he can at least see her in my presence, if that matters to him; so my only option is to make my presence appealing." She couldn't have conveyed a different impression, even if she had thought this through. Nonetheless, this didn't stop him from soon enough asking her, as if she were about to be launched into the void: "So, what about you, then? Do you start rushing off to visit country houses?" These questions were unavoidable, since they underscored the fact that she was behaving as she had pledged to.

She clearly hadn't hesitated on the latter, since they offered her an opportunity. Densher understood her, he felt her seize it; the opportunity, nothing more or less, to assist him in any way she chose. This was what Kate had told her: "Listen to him? Never!

Translation

She had clearly jumped at the chance, since it presented her with a possibility. Densher understood her, he felt her embrace it; the chance, nothing more and nothing less, to help him in any way she saw fit. This was what Kate had told her: "Listen to him? Never!"

Do as you please." What Milly "pleased" to do, as it turned out, was exactly what she was doing. This realization gave our young man a glimpse of the cruel reality of rejecting her. Her choice possessed a quiet heroism, since it didn't involve separating from Kate. She would be pleasant to Kate and to Kate's admirer; she would endure any pain she might feel by witnessing—if she continued to be exposed to the sight—the admirer in the company of the adored.

Translation

"Do as you please." As it happened, what Milly "pleased" to do was precisely what she was already doing. This understanding offered our young man a brutal view of the consequences of turning her down. Her choice was quietly heroic, as it did not mean leaving Kate. She would be pleasant to Kate and to Kate's admirer; she would bear any pain that might come from observing—should she continue to witness it—the admirer with the woman he loved.

It wouldn't have taken much more for him to wonder if he was witnessing one of those rare instances of elevated emotion—material for fiction, material for poetry—in which a man's chances with the woman who isn't interested in him are actually improved by the woman who is. It was as if Milly had thought, "Well, at least he can see her in my presence, if that helps; so, my only option is to make my presence appealing." She couldn't have made a different impression if she had thought this way. Yet, despite all this, he soon asked her, as if she were about to disappear: "And now, what will you do? Will you start visiting country houses?"

Translation

It wouldn't have taken much more for him to wonder if he was witnessing one of those rare moments of heightened emotion—the stuff of fiction, the stuff of poetry—where a man's chances with the woman who doesn't love him are somehow improved by the woman who does. It was as if Milly had thought, "Well, if he can at least see her when I'm around, that's something; so, I just have to make myself pleasant to be around." She couldn't have conveyed a different impression, even if she'd thought that way. Nevertheless, he soon asked her, as if she were about to vanish: "And now, what will you do? Will you start visiting country houses?"

She disowned the idea with a headshake that, put on what face she would, couldn't help betraying to him something of her suppressed view of the possibility—ever, ever perhaps—of any such proceedings. They weren't at any rate for her now. "Dear no. We go abroad for a few weeks somewhere of high air.

Translation

She dismissed the notion with a shake of her head. No matter how she tried to conceal it, her reaction couldn’t help but betray her hidden feelings about such a possibility—ever, perhaps ever—of such a thing. At any rate, it wasn’t for her, not now. "Oh, no. We’re going abroad for a few weeks, somewhere with good air."

That has been before us for many days; we've only been kept on by last necessities here. However, everything's done and the wind's in our sails." "May you scud then happily before it! But when," he asked, "do you come back?"

Translation

"We've been at this for ages; only dire circumstances have held us back. But everything's sorted, and we're ready to go."

"May you have a smooth journey! But when," he asked, "do you return?"

She looked ever so vague; then as if to correct it: "Oh when the wind turns. And what do you do with your summer?" "Ah I spend it in sordid toil. I drench it with mercenary ink.

Translation

Her gaze drifted, then, as if correcting herself, she said, "Oh, when the wind changes. And how do you spend your summer?"

"Ah, I spend it in grinding labor. I drown it in mercenary ink."

My work in your country counts for play as well. You see what's thought of the pleasure your country can give. My holiday's over." She dismissed the notion with a shake of her head that, no matter how composed she tried to be, couldn't help but reveal to him a hint of her hidden belief regarding the possibility—ever, perhaps—of such a thing.

Translation

My work in your country is considered a pastime, too. You see how little value is placed on what your country offers for enjoyment. My vacation is over.” She dismissed the idea with a shake of her head that, despite her best efforts to appear collected, betrayed a subtle hint of her secret belief regarding the possibility – if there was one at all – of such a thing ever existing.

It was certainly not happening for her at the moment. "Absolutely not. We're going abroad for a few weeks, somewhere with clean air. That's been the plan for ages; we've only been delayed by last-minute obligations here.

Translation

It was definitely not in the cards for her right now. "Absolutely not. We're going abroad for a few weeks, somewhere with clean air. That's the plan we've had for ages; we've only been held up by last-minute obligations here."

However, everything is finished now, and we're ready to go." "I hope you have a pleasant journey! But," he asked, "when will you be back?" She appeared uncertain for a moment; then, as if correcting herself: "Oh, when the weather changes.

Translation

"However, all of that's wrapped up, and we're ready to leave." "I hope you enjoy your trip! But," he asked, "when are you coming back?" She hesitated briefly, then, as if correcting herself, said: "Oh, when the weather turns."

And what will you be doing this summer?" "Oh, I'll be toiling away, working hard. I'll be filling it with writing for money. My work in your country feels like leisure.

Translation

"And what will you be doing this summer?" "Oh, I'll be grinding, working my tail off. I'll be cramming it full of writing to make a living. My work in your country feels like a vacation."

You see what people think of the fun your country offers. My holiday is over." "I'm sorry you had to take it," said Milly, "at such a different time from ours. If you could but have worked while we've been working—"

"Perhaps I'd be enjoying myself while you are? The difference doesn't matter much to me. I experience a bit of both, work and play, in everything I do. But you, and Mrs.

Stringham, with Miss Croy and Mrs. Lowder—you all," he went on, "have been given up, like navvies or niggers, to real physical toil. Your rest is something you've earned and you need. My labour's comparatively light."

Translation

Stringham, Miss Croy, and Mrs. Lowder—you all," he continued, "have been dedicated, like laborers or servants, to actual physical exertion. Your rest is deserved and necessary. My work is comparatively easy."

"It doesn't leave you exhausted?" "Not at all. I don't get tired when I'm engaged. I could go on for quite a while."

Translation

"Doesn't it wear you out?"

"Not at all. I don't get tired when I'm focused. I could keep going for quite a while."

He bethought himself. "Then why don't you?—since you've got here, as I learn, the whole place in your pocket." "Well, it's a kind of economy—I'm saving things up. I've enjoyed so what you speak of—though your account of it's fantastic—that I'm watching over its future, that I can't help being anxious and careful.

Translation

He considered. "Then why don't you—since you've arrived here, as I understand it, with the whole operation at your fingertips."

"Well, it's a kind of conservation—I'm saving things. I've enjoyed so much what you're talking about—even though your version of it is outlandish—that I'm watching over its future, that I can't help but be anxious and careful."

I want—in the interest itself of what I've had and may still have—not to make stupid mistakes. The way not to make them is to get off again to a distance and see the situation from there. Translation

Can you give me that promise?" Her face fairly lighted at his asking for a promise; but she made as if bargaining a little. "Isn't London rather awful in winter?" He had been going to ask her if she meant for the invalid; but he checked the infelicity of this and took the enquiry as referring to social life.

Translation

"Will you swear it?" Her features practically glowed with joy at his request for a pledge; however, she feigned a degree of reluctance. "Isn't London absolutely dreadful during winter?" He'd been about to ask if she meant for the sick person, but he suppressed the awkwardness of the question, interpreting her statement as pertaining to the social scene.

"No—I like it, with one thing and another; it's less of a mob than later on; and it would have for us the merit—should you come here then—that we should probably see more of you. So do reappear for us—if it isn't a question of climate." She looked at that a little graver. "If what isn't a question—?"

Translation

"No—I like it, with its ups and downs; there are fewer crowds then than later in the year; and it would be to our advantage—should you visit then—that we would likely see more of you. So, do come back to us—if it's not a matter of the weather." She considered that a bit more seriously. "If what isn't a question—?"

"Why the determination of your movements. You spoke just now of going somewhere for that." Her face brightened when he asked for a promise, but she pretended to be hesitant. "Isn't London terrible in the winter?"

Translation

"Why do you need to know where I'm going? You just mentioned going somewhere for that purpose." Her expression lit up when he asked for a promise, but she acted like she was unsure. "Isn't London awful in the winter?"

He almost asked if she meant it was awful for the sick person, but he stopped himself, deciding she was talking about social life. "No, I like it. There's less of a crowd than later in the year. If you came, we'd have the advantage of seeing more of you.

Translation

He nearly asked if she meant London was awful for whoever was sick, but he caught himself, figuring she was talking about social engagements. "No, I enjoy it. Fewer people around than other times of the year. If you came, we'd have the pleasure of your company more often."

So, please, come back to us, unless the weather is a problem." She looked more serious. "Unless what is a problem?" "Your reasons for traveling.

Translation

"So, please, come back, unless the weather's an issue." Her expression turned more serious. "Unless what's an issue?" "Your reasons for traveling."

You mentioned going somewhere for those reasons." "For better air?"—she remembered. "Oh yes, one certainly wants to get out of London in August." "Rather, of course!"—he fully understood.

Translation

"You told me you were traveling for those reasons." "For cleaner air?" she recalled. "Yes, one does want to leave London in August." "Indeed!" he agreed, understanding perfectly.

"Though I'm glad you've hung on long enough for me to catch you. Try us at any rate," he continued, "once more." "Whom do you mean by 'us'?" she presently asked. It pulled him up an instant—representing, as he saw it might have seemed, an allusion to himself as conjoined with Kate, whom he was proposing not to mention any more than his hostess did.

Translation

"But I'm happy you've stayed around long enough for me to find you. Give us a shot, anyway," he went on, "one more time." "Who do you mean by 'us'?" she asked after a moment. It stopped him cold for a second—it seemed to imply, as he realized it might, that he was including himself with Kate, whom he was trying not to bring up any more than his hostess had.

But the issue was easy. "I mean all of us together, every one you'll find ready to surround you with sympathy." It made her, none the less, in her odd charming way, challenge him afresh. "Why do you say sympathy?"

Translation

The problem was simple. "I mean all of us, together, everyone who is ready to surround you with sympathy." It still made her, in her own odd, charming way, challenge him once more. "Why do you say sympathy?"

"For a change of scenery?" she recalled. "Of course, you really do need to leave London in August." "Absolutely!" he agreed. "Though I'm happy you stayed long enough for me to see you.

Translation

"For a change of pace?" she remembered. "You really do need to get out of London in August, of course." "Certainly!" he said. "Though I'm glad you stayed long enough for me to see you."

Please, consider it," he continued, "one more time." "Who are you including in 'us'?" she asked after a moment. This gave him pause for a second. He realized that this question could be interpreted as a reference to himself and Kate, whom he had decided not to bring up, just as she hadn't.

Translation

"Please, think about it," he said, "just once more."

"Who do you mean by 'us'?" she asked after a moment.

This made him hesitate for a second. He realized that this question could be interpreted as a reference to himself and Kate, whom he had decided not to mention, just as she hadn't.

However, it was a simple matter to address. "I mean all of us, everyone who will offer you support." Despite this, she still felt inclined to question him, in her uniquely captivating way. "Why did you use the word 'support'?"

Translation

He found the reply straightforward. "I mean all of us, everyone who will offer you assistance." Despite this, she was still inclined to question him, in her uniquely captivating manner. "Why did you use the word 'assistance'?"

"Well, it's doubtless a pale word. What we shall feel for you will be much nearer worship." "As near then as you like!" With which at last Kate's name was sounded. "The people I'd most come back for are the people you know.

Translation

"It's probably a weak word, a pale word at best. What we'll feel for you will be much closer to worship." "As close as you like, then!" At that, Kate's name was finally spoken. "The people I'd most want to return for are the people you know."

I'd do it for Mrs. Lowder, who has been beautifully kind to me." "So she has to me," said Densher. "I feel," he added as she at first answered nothing, "that, quite contrary to anything I originally expected, I've made a good friend of her."

Translation

I'd do it for Mrs. Lowder, who's been wonderfully kind to me." "She has to me, too," Densher said. "I feel," he added when she didn't respond at first, "that, completely opposite to what I'd originally thought, I've become a good friend of hers."

"I didn't expect it either—its turning out as it has. But I did," said Milly, "with Kate. I shall come back for her too. I'd do anything"—she kept it up—"for Kate."

Translation

"I never would have predicted things would go this way. But I did," Milly said, "with Kate. I will come back for her, too. I would do anything"—she continued—"for Kate."

Looking at him as with conscious clearness while she spoke, she might for the moment have effectively laid a trap for whatever remains of the ideal straightness in him were still able to pull themselves together and operate. He was afterwards to say to himself that something had at that moment hung for him by a hair. "Oh I know what one would do for Kate!"—it had hung for him by a hair to break out with that, which he felt he had really been kept from by an element in his consciousness stronger still. The proof of the truth in question was precisely in his silence; resisting the impulse to break out was what he was doing for Kate.

Translation

Looking at him with such deliberate clarity while she spoke, she might have, for a moment, effectively set a trap for any remaining shred of integrity that could still pull itself together and function. He would later tell himself that something had, at that moment, hung precariously in the balance for him. "Oh, I know what one would do for Kate!"—it had come close to him blurting that out, which he felt he had actually been restrained from saying by an even stronger force within his own awareness. The proof of the truth in question was precisely his silence; resisting the urge to speak was what he was doing for Kate.

This at the time moreover came and went quickly enough; he was trying the next minute but to make Milly's allusion easy for herself. "Of course I know what friends you are—and of course I understand," he permitted himself to add, "any amount of devotion to a person so charming. That's the good turn then she'll do us all—I mean her working for your return." "Well, it's a weak way of putting it, I suppose.

Translation

This passed quickly enough; the very next minute, he was trying to smooth over Milly's reference. "Of course I know how close you are—and of course I understand," he allowed himself to add, "any amount of devotion to someone so charming. That's the good turn she'll do us all—I mean, her working for your return." "Well, it's a weak way of putting it, I suppose."

What we'll feel for you will be closer to worship." "Absolutely! I'm here for you, no matter what!" And then, at last, Kate's name was mentioned. "The people I'd most want to return for are the people you both know.

Translation

"Our feelings for you will be akin to reverence." "Exactly! I'm here for you, no matter what!" Then, finally, Kate's name was brought up. "The people I'd most want to come back for are the people you both know."

I'd do it for Mrs. Lowder, who has been incredibly kind to me." "She's been kind to me as well," Densher said. "I feel," he continued, as she didn't immediately reply, "that, completely contrary to what I anticipated, I've actually become good friends with her."

Translation

"I'd do it for Mrs. Lowder. She's been so incredibly good to me." "She's been good to me, too," Densher said. "I feel," he continued, as she didn't respond right away, "that, completely against what I thought would happen, I've actually become quite friendly with her."

"I didn't expect that either—how things have turned out. But with Kate, I did. I will also come back for her. I'd do anything"—she insisted—"for Kate."

Translation

"I didn't expect things to go this way, either. But with Kate, I knew. I'll come back for her, too. I'd do anything," she insisted, "for Kate."

Looking at him with apparent intention as she spoke, she might have been setting a trap, ready to catch any last traces of the honest and straightforward man he used to be. He would later say to himself that he'd almost given himself away. "Oh, I know what one would do for Kate!"—he'd almost said that, but he'd been stopped by a stronger force within himself. The truth of the matter was shown in his silence; he was resisting the urge to speak out, doing what he could for Kate.

Translation

Her gaze fixed on him as she spoke, as if she were laying a trap, hoping to ensnare any lingering remnants of the open, honest man he once was. He would later reflect that he'd almost revealed himself. "Oh, I know what one would do for Kate!"—he'd nearly spoken those words, but an inner strength had held him back. The truth was evident in his silence; he was fighting the urge to speak, doing what he could for Kate.

This all happened very quickly, and in the next moment, he was trying to make Milly's words easier for her. "Of course I know how close you two are—and of course I understand," he added, "how much you care for someone as charming as her. That's the favor she'll do us all—I mean, by working to bring you back." "Oh you don't know," said Milly, "how much I'm really on her hands."

Translation

The entire exchange had transpired at lightning speed, and in the very next instant, he found himself attempting to soften the impact of Milly’s words. “I’m certainly aware of your closeness—and I understand,” he added, “how much you must care for someone as captivating as her. That’s the favor she’ll do us all—I mean, by working to bring you back.” “Oh, you have no idea,” Milly responded, “how much I’m actually dependent on her.”

He could but accept the appearance of wondering how much he might show he knew. "Ah she's very masterful." "She's great. Yet I don't say she bullies me."

Translation

He could only feign curiosity, wondering how much he should reveal of his knowledge. "Ah, she's very masterful." "She's great. But I wouldn't say she bullies me."

"No—that's not the way. At any rate it isn't hers," he smiled. He remembered, however, then that an undue acquaintance with Kate's ways was just what he mustn't show; and he pursued the subject no further than to remark with a good intention that had the further merit of representing a truth: "I don't feel as if I knew her—really to call know." "Well, if you come to that, I don't either!" she laughed.

Translation

"No, that's not it. Or at least, it's not how she is," he said, smiling. He remembered, though, that showing too much knowledge of Kate's ways was the last thing he should do. He dropped the subject, adding only, with the intention of being helpful—which also had the benefit of being true—"I don't feel I truly know her."

"Well, if you want to get right down to it, me neither!" she laughed.

The words gave him, as soon as they were uttered, a sense of responsibility for his own; though during a silence that ensued for a minute he had time to recognise that his own contained after all no element of falsity. Strange enough therefore was it that he could go too far—if it was too far—without being false. His observation was one he would perfectly have made to Kate herself. And before he again spoke, and before Milly did, he took time for more still—for feeling how just here it was that he must break short off if his mind was really made up not to go further.

Translation

The words he'd just spoken immediately made him feel accountable for them, even though he had a minute of silence to consider that they weren't, at their core, dishonest. It was strange that he could overstep—if he even had—without being deceitful. What he'd said was something he could have easily told Kate herself. Before he spoke again, and before Milly did, he took more time—to feel exactly where he'd need to stop if he really was committed to not going further.

It was as if he had been at a corner—and fairly put there by his last speech; so that it depended on him whether or no to turn it. The silence, if prolonged but an instant, might even have given him a sense of her waiting to see what he would do. It was filled for them the next thing by the sound, rather voluminous for the August afternoon, of the approach, in the street below them, of heavy carriage-wheels and of horses trained to "step." A rumble, a great shake, a considerable effective clatter, had been apparently succeeded by a pause at the door of the hotel, which was in turn accompanied by a due display of diminished prancing and stamping. "You've a visitor," Densher laughed, "and it must be at least an ambassador."

Translation

He felt boxed in, cornered by what he'd just said. It was up to him whether or not to take the next step. If the silence stretched out even a moment longer, he might have felt that she was waiting for him to make his move. The silence was broken by the sound of carriage wheels and horses’ hooves approaching in the street below—the sort of sounds you'd expect on a late summer afternoon. A rumble, a great shake, a substantial clatter, then a pause at the hotel door, accompanied by a show of prancing and stamping. “You have a visitor,” Densher laughed, “and it must be an ambassador, at least.”

"Oh, you have no idea," Milly said, "how much she depends on me." He could only pretend to wonder how much he was allowed to know. "Ah, she's very strong-willed." "She's wonderful.

Translation

"Oh, you have no idea," Milly said, "how much she relies on me." He could only feign curiosity about how much he was permitted to understand. "Ah, she's quite strong-willed." "She's amazing.

But I wouldn't say she bosses me around." "No, that's not her style. At least, not as far as I can tell," he smiled. However, he then remembered that he shouldn't seem too familiar with Kate's behavior.

Translation

"But I wouldn't say she orders me about." "No, that's not her way. Or so it seems to me," he said with a smile. However, he then reminded himself that he shouldn't appear too knowledgeable about Kate's conduct.

So, he dropped the subject and made a well-meaning comment that happened to be true: "I don't feel like I really know her, not truly." "Well, if you want the truth, neither do I!" she laughed. As soon as she said those words, he felt responsible for his own. Though a minute of silence followed, he realized that his comment was completely honest.

Translation

He let it go, then offered a harmless observation that was, coincidentally, the truth: "I don't feel like I really know her, not truly."

"Well, if you want the truth, neither do I!" she laughed.

As soon as she said those words, he felt responsible for his own. Though a minute of silence followed, he realized that his comment was completely honest.

It was odd, though, that he could go too far, if that's what it was, without being dishonest. He would have made the same observation to Kate herself. Before he spoke again, and before Milly did, he paused to consider—feeling that this was where he had to stop if he truly intended not to go any further. It was as if he'd been put in a corner by his last statement, and it was up to him whether or not to turn it.

Translation

It was strange, though, that he could cross a line, if that's what it was, without being insincere. He would have said the same thing to Kate herself. Before he spoke again, and before Milly did, he paused to think—feeling that this was the point at which he had to stop if he truly meant to go no further. It was as if his last statement had backed him into a corner, and it was now his decision whether or not to turn.

The silence, if it had lasted even a moment longer, might have made him feel like she was waiting to see what he would do. The silence was broken by the sound, rather loud for an August afternoon, of carriage wheels and horses approaching on the street below. A rumble, a big shake, and a considerable clatter had apparently ceased at the hotel's entrance, which was then followed by some prancing and stamping. "You have a visitor," Densher laughed, "and it must be at least an ambassador."

Translation

The silence, had it lingered even a moment longer, might have made him feel like she was gauging his next move. The quiet was shattered by the sound, quite loud for a summer afternoon, of carriage wheels and horses drawing closer on the street below. A rumble, a heavy shake, and a sizable clatter had seemingly ended at the hotel's entrance, which was then followed by some pawing and stomping. "You have a visitor," Densher laughed, "and it must be at least an ambassador."

"It's only my own carriage; it does that—isn't it wonderful?—every day. But we find it, Mrs. Stringham and I, in the innocence of our hearts, very amusing." She had got up, as she spoke, to assure herself of what she said; and at the end of a few steps they were together on the balcony and looking down at her waiting chariot, which made indeed a brave show. "Is it very awful?"

Translation

"It's just my carriage. It does that—isn't it amazing?—every day. But Mrs. Stringham and I, in our naiveté, find it highly entertaining."

She rose as she spoke, to confirm her statement. After a few steps, they stood together on the balcony, looking down at her waiting chariot, which was indeed quite impressive. "Is it really that bad?"

It was to Densher's eyes—save for its absurd heaviness—only pleasantly pompous. "It seems to me delightfully rococo. But how do I know? You're mistress of these things, in contact with the highest wisdom.

Translation

To Densher, the carriage seemed only pleasantly pompous, save for its absurd weight. "It seems delightfully rococo to me. But what do I know? You're the expert on these things, in contact with the highest wisdom."

You occupy a position, moreover, thanks to which your carriage—well, by this time, in the eye of London, also occupies one." But she was going out, and he mustn't stand in her way. What had happened the next minute was first that she had denied she was going out, so that he might prolong his stay; and second that she had said she would go out with pleasure if he would like to drive—that in fact there were always things to do, that there had been a question for her to-day of several in particular, and that this in short was why the carriage had been ordered so early. They perceived, as she said these things, that an enquirer had presented himself, and, coming back, they found Milly's servant announcing the carriage and prepared to accompany her. This appeared to have for her the effect of settling the matter—on the basis, that is, of Densher's happy response.

Translation

Furthermore, you hold a position that, in London's eyes, your carriage also occupies. But she was leaving, and he shouldn't impede her. What happened next was that she first denied she was going out, perhaps to extend his visit. Then, she said she would gladly go out if he wanted to drive—that, in fact, there were always things to do, that several specific things needed attending to that day, and that was why the carriage had been ordered so early. As she said this, they realized someone had arrived to inquire about something. Returning, they found Milly's servant announcing the carriage and ready to go with her. This seemed to settle the matter for her—based, that is, on Densher's positive reaction.

Densher's happy response, however, had as yet hung fire, the process we have described in him operating by this time with extreme intensity. The system of not pulling up, not breaking off, had already brought him headlong, he seemed to feel, to where they actually stood; and just now it was, with a vengeance, that he must do either one thing or the other. He had been waiting for some moments, which probably seemed to him longer than they were; this was because he was anxiously watching himself wait. He couldn't keep that up for ever; and since one thing or the other was what he must do, it was for the other that he presently became conscious of having decided.

Translation

Densher's delighted response, however, had yet to materialize, the process we've described in him now operating with extreme intensity. The system of not stopping, not interrupting, had already brought him headlong, he seemed to feel, to where they actually stood; and right now it was, with a vengeance, that he must do either one thing or the other. He had been waiting for some moments, which probably seemed to him longer than they were; this was because he was anxiously watching himself wait. He couldn't keep that up forever; and since one thing or the other was what he must do, it was for the other that he presently became conscious of having decided.
