force. The habit of not stopping, not breaking off, had already, he felt, propelled him headlong to where they stood; and now he absolutely had to do one thing

Translation

Force. The compulsion to continue, to never pause or withdraw, had, he sensed, already driven him headfirst to this point; and now he was absolutely compelled to do one thing.

or the other. He had been waiting for some moments, which seemed to him longer than they were, because he was anxiously watching himself wait.

Translation

Or the other. He had been waiting for a few moments, which felt longer than they actually were, because he was anxiously observing himself as he waited.

He couldn't continue that forever; and since he had to do one thing or the other, he realized he'd decided on the other. If he had been drifting, it settled itself with the force

Translation

He couldn't keep that up indefinitely; and since he had to choose one path or the other, he understood he'd opted for the second. If he'd been unmoored, it resolved itself with the force

of a violent collision against a solid object in the stream. "Oh yes; I'll go with you, I'd love to. It's a

Translation

matter of the greatest indifference to me." He wasn't even aware of what he was saying.

charming idea." She gave no look to thank him—she rather looked away; she only said at once to her servant, "In ten minutes"; and then to her visitor, as the man went out, "We'll go somewhere—I shall like that. But I must ask of you time—as little as possible—to get ready." She looked over the room to provide for him, keep him there. "There are books and things—plenty; and I dress very quickly." He caught her eyes only as she went, on which he thought them pretty and touching.

Translation

"It's a charming idea." She didn't bother looking at him to show thanks—she actually looked away. She simply told her servant, "Ten minutes." Then, once the man had left, she said to her visitor, "We'll go somewhere—I'll like that. But I need to ask you to wait—as little as possible—while I get ready." She looked around the room to give him things to do, to keep him there. "There are books and things—plenty of them; and I get dressed very quickly." He only caught her eyes as she went, and thought they were pretty and touching.

Why especially touching at that instant he could certainly scarce have said; it was involved, it was lost in the sense of her wishing to oblige him. Clearly what had occurred was her having wished it so that she had made him simply wish, in civil acknowledgement, to oblige her; which he had now fully done by turning his corner. He was quite round it, his corner, by the time the door had closed upon her and he stood there alone. Alone he remained for three minutes more—remained with several very living little matters to think about.

Translation

Why especially touching at that instant he could certainly hardly have said; it was complex, it was obscured by the feeling of her wanting to help him. Clearly what had happened was that she had wanted something so much that she had made him simply want, in polite agreement, to help her; which he had now fully done by turning the corner. He was completely around it, his corner, by the time the door had closed and he stood there alone. Alone he remained for three minutes more—remained with several very vibrant little things to think about.

One of these was the phenomenon—typical, highly American, he would have said—of Milly's extreme spontaneity. It was perhaps rather as if he had sought refuge—refuge from another question—in the almost exclusive contemplation of this. Yet this, in its way, led him nowhere; not even to a sound generalisation about American girls. It was spontaneous for his young friend to have asked him to drive with her alone—since she hadn't mentioned her companion; but she struck him after all as no more advanced in doing it than Kate, for instance, who wasn't an American girl, might have struck him in not doing it.

Translation

One of these was the phenomenon—typical, highly American, he would have said—of Milly's extreme spontaneity. It was perhaps as if he had sought refuge—refuge from another question—in the almost exclusive contemplation of this. Yet this, in its way, led him nowhere; not even to a sound generalization about American girls. It was spontaneous for his young friend to have asked him to drive with her alone—since she hadn't mentioned her companion; but she struck him after all as no more advanced in doing it than Kate, for instance, who wasn't an American girl, might have struck him in not doing it.

Besides, Kate would have done it, though Kate wasn't at all, in the same sense as Milly, spontaneous. And then in addition Kate had done it—or things very like it. Furthermore he was engaged to Kate—even if his ostensibly not being put her public freedom on other grounds. On all grounds, at any rate, the relation between Kate and freedom, between freedom and Kate, was a different one from any he could associate or cultivate, as to anything, with the girl who had just left him to prepare to give herself up to him.

Translation

Besides, Kate would have done it, though Kate wasn't spontaneous at all in the same way as Milly. And also, Kate had done it—or things very similar. Furthermore, he was engaged to Kate—even if his not ostensibly putting her public freedom on other grounds. At any rate, on all grounds, the relationship between Kate and freedom, between freedom and Kate, was different from any he could associate or cultivate with the girl who had just left him to prepare to give herself up to him.

It had never struck him before, and he moved about the room while he thought of it, touching none of the books placed at his disposal. Milly was forward, as might be said, but not advanced; whereas Kate was backward—backward still, comparatively, as an English girl—and yet advanced in a high degree. However—though this didn't straighten it out—Kate was of course two or three years older; which at their time of life considerably counted. She didn't glance at him in thanks; instead, she looked away.

Translation

He hadn’t considered it before, and he paced the room while he pondered, not touching any of the available books. Milly was bold, one might say, but not sophisticated, while Kate was reserved—still, comparatively, for an English girl—yet highly sophisticated. Though this didn’t clarify the matter, Kate was, of course, two or three years older, which at their age was significant. She didn’t look at him to express her gratitude; instead, she looked away.

She simply told her servant, "In ten minutes." Then, to her visitor, as the servant left, she said, "We'll go somewhere—I'd like that. But I'll need some time—as little as possible—to get ready." She surveyed the room as if to keep him there. "There are books and things—plenty of them; and I dress very quickly." He caught her eye as she left, and he thought her eyes were pretty and moving. He couldn't have said why they were especially moving at that moment; it was wrapped up in the sense that she wanted to accommodate him.

Translation

She told her servant flatly, "Ten minutes." After the servant had gone, she said to her guest, "We'll go somewhere—I'd like that. But I'll need some time—as little as possible—to get ready." She glanced around the room, as if to make sure he'd stay put. "There are books and things—plenty of them; and I dress very quickly." As she left, their eyes met, and he found her eyes pretty and affecting. He couldn't say why they were particularly affecting at that moment; it was bound up with the feeling that she wanted to please him.

Clearly, she had wanted to do something that had made him simply want, out of politeness, to accommodate her; which he had fully done by agreeing. He had made up his mind by the time the door closed behind her, leaving him alone. He remained alone for three more minutes, with several lively matters to consider. One of these was the phenomenon—typically American, he would have said—of Milly's extreme spontaneity.

Translation

It was obvious she'd proposed something that he'd only gone along with, out of a courteous desire to be agreeable, which he had, in fact, done. By the time the door shut and she was gone, leaving him on his own, he'd made up his mind about that. He remained alone for another three minutes, occupied by several interesting thoughts. One was this—characteristically American, he'd have said—the phenomenon of Milly's remarkable spontaneity.

Perhaps he had sought refuge—refuge from another question—by focusing almost exclusively on this. Yet, in its own way, this didn't lead him anywhere, not even to a sound generalization about American girls. It was spontaneous of his young friend to have asked him to drive with her alone—since she hadn't mentioned her companion; but she seemed to him, after all, no more forward in doing it than Kate, who wasn't an American girl, might have seemed in not doing it. Besides, Kate would have done it, though Kate wasn't at all, in the same way as Milly, spontaneous.

Translation

Maybe he had been looking for an escape—an escape from another question—by fixating almost entirely on this. Still, it didn't get him anywhere, not even to a solid conclusion about American girls. It was spontaneous of his young friend to have asked him to drive with her alone—since she hadn't mentioned her companion; but she seemed to him, when it was all said and done, no more forward in doing it than Kate, who wasn't American, might have seemed in not doing it. Besides, Kate would have done it, even though Kate wasn't spontaneous in the same way that Milly was.

And also, Kate had done it—or things very like it. Furthermore, he was engaged to Kate—even if his not mentioning her put her freedom in public on other terms. At any rate, the relationship between Kate and freedom, between freedom and Kate, was different from any he could connect with the girl who had just left him to get ready to devote herself to him. This had never struck him before, and he paced around the room while thinking about it, not touching any of the books she had offered.

Translation

Kate had, too—or something similar. He was, after all, engaged to her, even if he didn't bring her up, which somehow cast her free will in a different light. Regardless, the link between Kate and freedom, between freedom and Kate, was unlike anything he could associate with the girl who had just departed to prepare herself for him. This thought had never occurred to him, and he walked around the room pondering it, not bothering to look at any of the books she'd given him.

Milly was forward, so to speak, but not advanced; whereas Kate was reserved—still reserved, relatively speaking, as an English girl—and yet advanced to a high degree. However—though this didn't clarify matters—Kate was, of course, two or three years older; which, at their ages, made a considerable difference. Thus ingeniously discriminating, Densher continued slowly to wander; yet without keeping at bay for long the sense of having rounded his corner. He had so rounded it that he felt himself lose even the option of taking advantage of Milly's absence to retrace his steps.

Translation

Milly was, one could say, bold, but not sophisticated. Kate, on the other hand, was demure—still demure, comparatively speaking, as an English girl would be—and yet exceptionally sophisticated. However—though this didn't make things any clearer—Kate was, naturally, two or three years older, which, at their ages, was a substantial difference. Thinking in such an ingenious way, Densher continued to walk about slowly; but he couldn't keep at bay for long the feeling that he had turned a corner. He had turned it so fully that he felt he'd lost even the possibility of using Milly's absence to go back the way he'd come.

If he might have turned tail, vulgarly speaking, five minutes before, he couldn't turn tail now; he must simply wait there with his consciousness charged to the brim. Quickly enough moreover that issue was closed from without; in the course of three minutes more Miss Theale's servant had returned. He preceded a visitor whom he had met, obviously, at the foot of the stairs and whom, throwing open the door, he loudly announced as Miss Croy. Kate, on following him in, stopped short at sight of Densher—only, after an instant, as the young man saw with free amusement, not from surprise and still less from discomfiture.

Translation

If he could have run away, to put it crudely, five minutes earlier, he couldn't now; he simply had to stay put, his mind filled to the breaking point. Furthermore, the matter was settled quickly, from the outside; in the next three minutes, Miss Theale's servant came back. He was leading a visitor he'd obviously met at the foot of the stairs, and whom, throwing open the door, he announced loudly as Miss Croy. Kate, following him in, stopped at the sight of Densher—only, after a moment, the young man saw with amusement, not from surprise or embarrassment, but something else entirely.

Densher immediately gave his explanation—Miss Theale had gone to prepare to drive—on receipt of which the servant effaced himself. Densher, employing his clever mind, continued to stroll, though he couldn't avoid the feeling that he'd reached a turning point. He'd gone so far that going back, even taking advantage of Milly's absence, was no longer possible. While he might have retreated, to put it plainly, a few minutes earlier, he couldn't now; he had no choice but to remain and face the situation, fully aware of everything.

Translation

Densher explained immediately: Miss Theale had gone to get ready to leave. Upon hearing this, the servant withdrew. Densher, using his quick mind, kept walking, even though he couldn't help but feel he'd reached a turning point. He'd gone so far that turning back, even taking advantage of Milly's absence, was no longer possible. He could have retreated, to be frank, a few minutes earlier, but not now; he had no choice but to stay and face the situation, completely aware of everything.

And very quickly, matters were settled by external forces; within three minutes, Miss Theale's servant was back. He was leading in a visitor whom he had clearly encountered downstairs, and, flinging open the door, he announced loudly: Miss Croy. Kate, following him in, paused when she saw Densher—but, as the young man quickly realized, not out of shock or embarrassment. Densher immediately explained that Miss Theale had left to get ready for a drive, after which the servant withdrew.

Translation

And things quickly resolved themselves, spurred by outside forces. Within three minutes, Miss Theale's servant returned. He was ushering in a visitor he’d apparently met downstairs. He threw open the door, announcing loudly, “Miss Croy.” Kate entered behind him and stopped when she saw Densher—but, as the young man instantly understood, not because she was shocked or embarrassed. Densher immediately explained that Miss Theale had gone to prepare for a drive, and then the servant withdrew.

"And you're going with her?" Kate asked. "Yes—with your approval; which I've taken, as you see, for granted." "Oh," she laughed, "my approval's complete!" She was thoroughly consistent and handsome about it. "What I mean is of course," he went on—for he was sensibly affected by her gaiety—"at your so lively instigation."

Translation

"And you're going with her?" Kate asked.

"Yes—with your approval; which I've taken, as you see, for granted."

"Oh," she laughed, "my approval's complete!" She was thoroughly consistent and handsome about it.

"What I mean is of course," he went on—for he was sensibly affected by her gaiety—"at your so lively instigation."

She had looked about the room—she might have been vaguely looking for signs of the duration, of the character of his visit, a momentary aid in taking a decision. "Well, instigation then, as much as you like." She treated it as pleasant, the success of her plea with him; she made a fresh joke of this direct impression of it. "So much so as that? Do you know I think I won't wait?"

Translation

She’d glanced around the room, perhaps vaguely searching for evidence of how long he’d been there, clues to the nature of his visit, something to help her make up her mind. “Alright, then, instigation, if that’s what you want.” She found his agreement amusing, the success of her request; she made another joke out of how directly it had affected him. “Really? Do you know, I think I won’t wait.”

"So, you're going with her?" Kate inquired. "Yes—with your blessing; which I've, as you can see, assumed I had." "Oh," she said with a laugh, "you have my full support!" She was completely resolute and beautiful in her response. "What I mean, of course," he continued—for he was genuinely touched by her good spirits—"is that it's all because of your enthusiastic encouragement."

Translation

"So, you're going with her?" Kate asked. "Yes—with your blessing; which I've, as you can see, assumed I had." "Oh," she said with a laugh, "you have my full support!" She was completely resolute and beautiful in her response. "What I mean, of course," he continued—for he was genuinely touched by her good spirits—"is that it's all because of your enthusiastic encouragement."

She had glanced around the room—perhaps she was subtly searching for clues about how long he'd been there, or the nature of his visit, something to help her make up her mind. "Alright, then, encouragement, if you wish." She treated it as a good thing, that he had agreed to her request; she made a fresh joke out of how direct an effect she'd had on him. "Is it really that strong? You know, I don't think I'll stick around."

Translation

She scanned the room, possibly trying to figure out how long he'd been there, or why he was there, anything to help her decide what to do. "Fine, encouragement, if that's what you want to call it." She was pleased that he had gone along with her; she turned his compliance into another joke about her influence. "Is it really that potent? You know, I don't think I'll stay."

"Not to see her—after coming?" "Well, with you in the field—! I came for news of her, but she must be all right. If she is—"

Translation

"Not to see her—after coming all this way?" "Well, with you out there—! I came for news of her, but she must be fine. If she is—"

But he took her straight up. "Ah how do I know?" He was moved to say more. "It's not I who am responsible for her, my dear. It seems to me it's you." She struck him as making light of a matter that had been costing him sundry qualms; so that they couldn't both be quite just.

Translation

But he brought her directly to the point. "How should I know?" He was inclined to say more. "I'm not the one responsible for her, my dear. It seems to me you are." He thought she was trivializing something that had been causing him considerable anxiety, so that it was impossible for them both to be completely fair.

Either she was too easy or he had been too anxious. He didn't want at all events to feel a fool for that. "I'm doing nothing—and shall not, I assure you, do anything but what I'm told." "Not to see her—after I've arrived?"

Translation

Perhaps she was too compliant, or he had been too worried. In any case, he refused to feel like a fool. "I'm doing nothing—and I assure you, I won't do anything other than what I'm told." "Not see her—after I've arrived?"

"Well, with you involved—! I came for news about her, but she must be fine. If she is—" But he cut her off immediately.

Translation

"Well, with you involved—! I came for news about her, but she must be fine. If she is—" But he stopped her abruptly.

"How would I know?" He felt compelled to say more. "I'm not the one responsible for her, my dear. It seems to me, it's you." He felt she was trivializing something that had been causing him considerable worry.

Translation

"How should I know?" He couldn't help but continue. "I'm not the one in charge of her, darling. Seems to me, it's you." He thought she was making light of something that had been seriously concerning him.

It seemed they couldn't both be correct. Either she was too carefree, or he had been too concerned. Above all, he didn't want to look foolish for his anxiety. "I'm doing nothing—and I assure you, I won't do anything unless instructed."

Translation

It appeared they couldn't both be right. Either she was too unconcerned, or he had been overly worried. More than anything, he didn't want his anxiety to make him look foolish. "I'm not doing anything—and I swear, I won't do anything unless I'm told to."

Their eyes met with some intensity over the emphasis he had given his words; and he had taken it from her the next moment that he really needn't get into a state. What in the world was the matter? She asked it, with interest, for all answer. "Isn't she better—if she's able to see you?"

Translation

They locked eyes, the weight of his words hanging between them. Then, in the next moment, she conveyed that he needn’t get worked up. What was the problem, anyway? She asked, genuinely curious, as her reply. "Isn't she doing better—if she's able to see you?"

"She assures me she's in perfect health." Kate's interest grew. "I knew she would." On which she added: "It won't have been really for illness that she stayed away last night." "For what then?"

Translation

"She insists she's perfectly fine." Kate's curiosity intensified. "I knew it," she said. Then she added, "It wasn't really because she was sick that she stayed away last night." "What was it, then?"

"Well—for nervousness." "Nervousness about what?" "Oh you know!" She spoke with a hint of impatience, smiling however the next moment. "I've told you that."

Translation

"Well, it was nerves." "Nerves about what?" "Oh, you know!" She sounded a bit annoyed, though she smiled a second later. "I've already told you."

He looked at her to recover in her face what she had told him; then it was as if what he saw there prompted him to say: "What have you told her?" They exchanged a meaningful glance, triggered by the weight he’d put on his words. She immediately sensed he was getting worked up over something. "What's wrong?" she asked, genuinely curious.

Translation

He searched her expression, trying to find the answer she'd given him. Whatever he saw there seemed to make him ask, "What did you tell *her*?" They shared a significant look, the importance of his question hanging in the air. She could tell right away that something was bothering him. "What is it?" she asked, genuinely curious.

"Isn't she doing better, if she's willing to see you?" "She claims she's perfectly fine." Kate's interest deepened. "I knew it.

Translation

"Isn't she doing better, if she's willing to see you?" "She claims she's perfectly fine." Kate's interest deepened. "I knew it."

It wasn't really because she was sick that she missed last night." "Then why?" "Well, because she was nervous." "Nervous about what?"

Translation

"It wasn't really because she was sick that she missed last night." "Then why?" "Well, because she was nervous." "Nervous about what?"

"Oh, you know!" She sounded slightly exasperated, though she smiled a second later. "I've already explained that." He looked at her, trying to recall her explanation. Then, as if what he saw in her face spurred him on, he asked, "What have you told *her*?"

Translation

"Oh, you know!" She sounded a little exasperated, but smiled a moment later. He looked at her, trying to remember what she had said. Then, as if something he saw on her face had emboldened him, he asked, "What did you tell *her*?"

She gave him her controlled smile, and it was all as if they remembered where they were, liable to surprise, talking with softened voices, even stretching their opportunity, by such talk, beyond a quite right feeling. Milly's room would be close at hand, and yet they were saying things—! For a moment, none the less, they kept it up. "Ask her, if you like; you're free—she'll tell you.

Translation

"Do what you think is best. Don't worry about what you think I might have said or not said. I'm fine with her," said Kate. "So there you have it." "If you mean here I am," he answered, "it's obvious."

If you also mean that her believing in you is all I have to do with you're so far right as that she certainly does believe in you." She offered him her composed smile, and it was as if they both suddenly remembered their situation, aware of possible interruptions, speaking in hushed tones, even pushing their luck with this conversation, perhaps overstepping appropriate boundaries. Milly's room was nearby, and yet they were saying these things! However, for a brief moment, they continued.

Translation

"If you're suggesting that my only involvement with you is her faith in you, then you're absolutely correct. She does believe in you, without a doubt." She gave him a calm smile, and it was as if they both suddenly remembered where they were, conscious of the potential for being overheard, and speaking in whispers, even risking going too far with their conversation, perhaps crossing a line. Milly's room was just down the hall, and yet here they were, saying these things! But, for a short while, they kept going.

"Ask her, if you wish; you have my permission—she'll be honest with you. Do what you believe is best; don't worry about what you think I might or might not have shared with you. I have a good relationship with her," Kate said. "So there you have it."

Translation

"You can ask her, if you want to. I don't mind. She'll tell you the truth. Do what you think is right; don't concern yourself with what you think I may or may not have told you. I get along with her," Kate said. "That's all there is to it."

"If you're saying I'm here," he replied, "that's obvious. If you're also suggesting that her trust in you is my only concern regarding you, you're correct in that she certainly does believe in you." "Well then take example by her." "She's really doing it for you," Densher continued.

Translation

"It's clear I'm here," he answered. "If you're implying that her faith in you is my sole interest, you're right; she does believe in you." "Then follow her example." "She's doing this for you, really," Densher added.

"She's driving me out for you." "In that case," said Kate with her soft tranquillity, "you can do it a little for her. I'm not afraid," she smiled. He stood before her a moment, taking in again the face she put on it and affected again, as he had already so often been, by more things in this face and in her whole person and presence than he was, to his relief, obliged to find words for.

Translation

"She's getting rid of me for your sake." "If that's the case," Kate said with her usual calm, "you can do a little bit for her. I'm not afraid," she smiled. He stood before her for a moment, taking in once more the expression she adopted, and was again affected, as he had been so often already, by more things in that face, and in her whole person and presence, than he was, thankfully, compelled to put into words.

It wasn't, under such impressions, a question of words. "I do nothing for any one in the world but you. But for you I'll do anything." "Good, good," said Kate.

Translation

Under such impressions, it wasn't a matter of words. "I do nothing for anyone in the world but you. But for you, I'll do anything." "Good, good," Kate said.

"That's how I like you." "Well, then, learn from her." "She's really doing this for you," Densher said. "She's sending me away for your sake."

Translation

"That's the way I want you to be." "Alright then, take a page from her book." "She's actually doing this for you," Densher said. "She's sending me away because of you."

"If that's the case," Kate said with her usual calm, "you can do a little for her. I'm not worried," she smiled. He stood before her for a moment, taking in the expression on her face and again feeling, as he often had, moved by more things about her face, her whole self, and her presence than he needed to put into words. It wasn't about words when he felt like this.

Translation

"If that's how it is," Kate said, as composed as ever, "you can do a little something for her. I'm not concerned," she smiled. He stood there for a moment, absorbing her expression and once more experiencing, as he often did, an emotional response to her face, her very being, and her presence that surpassed his ability to articulate it. Words failed him in moments like these.

"I don't do anything in the world for anyone but you. But for you, I'll do anything." "Good, good," Kate said. "That's exactly what I want to hear."

Translation

"I don't do anything for anyone in this world except you. But for you, I'll do anything." "Good, good," Kate said. "That's exactly what I want to hear."

He waited again an instant. "Then you swear to it?" "To 'it'? To what?"

Translation

He paused for another moment. "So, you promise?" "Promise what?"

"Why that you do 'like' me. Since it's all for that, you know, that I'm letting you do—well, God knows what with me." She gave at this, with a stare, a disheartened gesture—the sense of which she immediately further expressed. "If you don't believe in me then, after all, hadn't you better break off before you've gone further?"

Translation

"Why, that you do like me. Because it's all for that, you know, that I'm letting you do—well, God knows what with me." She faltered at this, with a stare, a disheartened gesture—the meaning of which she immediately further expressed. "If you don't believe in me, then, after all, hadn't you better break off before you've gone further?"

"Break off with you?" "Break off with Milly. You might go now," she said, "and I'll stay and explain to her why it is." He wondered—as if it struck him.

Translation

"Break off with you?" "Break off with Milly. You could leave now," she said, "and I'll stay and explain it to her." He seemed to consider this, as if it had just occurred to him.

"What would you say?" "Why that you find you can't stand her, and that there's nothing for me but to bear with you as I best may." He paused, waiting a moment. "So, you swear?"

Translation

"What would you say?" "Why, that you find you can't stand her, and that there's nothing for me but to put up with you as best I can." He paused, waiting a moment. "So, you swear?"

"Swear to what?" "To liking me. Since that's the only reason I'm letting you do—well, whatever you're doing to me." She reacted, staring and making a gesture of despair, which she then elaborated on.

Translation

"Swear to what?" "To liking me. Because it's the only reason I'm letting you—well, do whatever you're doing." She reacted, staring, and made a gesture of despair, which she then elaborated on.

"If you don't believe in me, shouldn't you just end this now, before it goes any further?" "End things with you?" "End things with Milly. You could leave now," she said, "and I'll stay and tell her why."

Translation

"If you don't trust me, wouldn't it be better to just stop this, before it gets worse?" "End things with you?" "End things with Milly. You could leave now," she said, "and I'll stay and explain why."

He seemed surprised, as if it were a new thought. "What would you tell her?" "That you can't stand her, and that the only thing left for me is to put up with you as best I can." He considered of this.

Translation

He looked taken aback, as though the suggestion had never occurred to him. "What would you tell her?" "That you can't stand her, and that I'm left to put up with you as best I can." He gave it some thought.

"How much do you abuse me to her?" "Exactly enough. As much as you see by her attitude." Again he thought.

Translation

"How often do you complain about me to her?" "Just the right amount. As much as you can tell from her behavior." He paused to consider.

"It doesn't seem to me I ought to mind her attitude." "Well then, just as you like. I'll stay and do my best for you." He saw she was sincere, was really giving him a chance; and that of itself made things clearer.

Translation

"I don't think her attitude should bother me." "Alright, suit yourself. I'll stick around and do my best for you." He could see she was sincere, really giving him a chance; and that in itself clarified things.

The feeling of how far he had gone came back to him not in repentance, but in this very vision of an escape; and it Was not of what he had done, but of what Kate offered, that he now weighed the consequence. "Won't it make her—her not finding me here—be rather more sure there's something between us?" He pondered this. "How much do you badmouth me to her?"

Translation

The realization of how far he’d gone resurfaced, not as regret, but as a vision of escape. He wasn't considering his actions, but the potential offered by Kate, as he contemplated the ramifications. "Won't it make her—her not finding me here—be rather more sure there's something between us?" He considered this. "How much do you badmouth me to her?"

"Precisely the right amount. Just look at her behavior, and you'll have your answer." He reflected again. "It seems to me I shouldn't care about her attitude."

Translation

"Exactly the right amount. Just observe her reaction, and you'll know." He paused, considering. "It seems to me I shouldn't be concerned with how she feels."

"Then do as you wish. I'll stay and do my utmost for you." He understood she was being genuine, was truly giving him an opportunity; and that in itself clarified matters. The realization of how far he had strayed resurfaced, not as regret, but in this very vision of a way out.

Translation

"Then do what you want. I'll stay and do everything I can for you." He knew she meant it, was actually offering him a chance; and that, in itself, cleared things up. The awareness of how lost he'd been returned, not as remorse, but as the vision of a path forward.

And it wasn't what he had done, but what Kate offered, that he now considered the ramifications of. "Won't it make her—her not finding me here—make her more certain there's something between us?" Kate thought. "Oh I don't know.

Translation

And it wasn't his actions, but Kate's offer, that he was now weighing the consequences of. "Won't it make her—her not finding me here—make her more sure there's something between us?" Kate wondered. "Oh, I don't know.

It will of course greatly upset her. But you needn't trouble about that. She won't die of it." "Do you mean she will?" Densher presently asked.

Translation

"It will, of course, upset her a great deal. But you don't need to worry about that. She won't die from it."

"Do you mean she will?" Densher asked after a moment.

"Don't put me questions when you don't believe what I say. You make too many conditions." She spoke now with a shade of rational weariness that made the want of pliancy, the failure to oblige her, look poor and ugly; so that what it suddenly came back to for him was his deficiency in the things a man of any taste, so engaged, so enlisted, would have liked to make sure of being able to show—imagination, tact, positively even humour. The circumstance is doubtless odd, but the truth is none the less that the speculation uppermost with him at this juncture was: "What if I should begin to bore this creature?" And that, within a few seconds, had translated itself.

Translation

"Don't ask me questions if you don't trust what I tell you. You're setting too many conditions." Her tone held a hint of weary reason, making his lack of cooperation, his unwillingness to accommodate her, seem small and unpleasant. It suddenly struck him that his shortcomings in the qualities a man of his situation would want to possess—imagination, tact, even humor—were exposed. It's strange, but the fact remained that his primary thought at that moment was, "What if I start to bore her?" And that thought, within seconds, had resolved itself.

"If you'll swear again you love me—!" Kate considered. "I'm not sure. It will, naturally, upset her terribly.

Translation

"If you swear again that you love me—!" Kate considered it. "I'm not sure. It will, naturally, upset her terribly."

But don't worry about that. She won't die from it." "Are you saying she will?" Densher asked after a moment. "Don't ask questions when you don't believe me.

Translation

But don't concern yourself with that. She won't die from it." "Are you implying she will?" Densher inquired after a pause. "Don't press me when you don't trust me.

You make too many demands." Her voice held a hint of weary reason, making his inflexibility, his unwillingness to cooperate, seem petty and unpleasant. What it all boiled down to, suddenly, was his own lack of qualities a man in his position would want to possess—imagination, sensitivity, even a sense of humor. Odd as it may seem, what occupied his thoughts at that moment was, "What if I'm starting to bore this woman?" And that thought quickly transformed into: "If you swear you love me again—!"

Translation

You ask too much. Her voice was tinged with a weary logic, which made his rigidity and his refusal to bend seem small and mean. Suddenly, it all came down to his own deficiencies—the absence of the traits a man in his situation really needed: imagination, sensitivity, even a sense of humor. Strange as it was, his thoughts were focused on, "What if I'm starting to bore her?" And that quickly morphed into: "If you swear you love me again—!"

She looked about, at door and window, as if he were asking for more than he said. "Here? There's nothing between us here," Kate smiled. "Oh isn't there?" Her smile itself, with this, had so settled something for him that he had come to her pleadingly and holding out his hands, which she immediately seized with her own as if both to check him and to keep him.

Translation

She glanced around, at the door and window, as if he were requesting more than he'd vocalized. "Here? There's nothing between us here," Kate said, smiling. "Oh, isn't there?" Her smile, with that statement, had resolved something for him to the point that he approached her, pleading, holding out his hands, which she immediately grasped with hers, as if to both restrain him and hold him close.

It was by keeping him thus for a minute that she did check him; she held him long enough, while, with their eyes deeply meeting, they waited in silence for him to recover himself and renew his discretion. He coloured as with a return of the sense of where they were, and that gave her precisely one of her usual victories, which immediately took further form. By the time he had dropped her hands he had again taken hold, as it were, of Milly's. It was not at any rate with Milly he had broken.

Translation

By holding him like that for a moment, she stopped him. She held him long enough, their eyes locked, while they waited in silence for him to regain his composure and his discretion. He flushed, as if remembering where they were, and that gave her one of her usual victories, which immediately took further shape. By the time he had let go of her hands, he had, in a sense, taken hold of Milly’s again. At any rate, it wasn’t with Milly he had broken.

"I'll do all you wish," he declared as if to acknowledge the acceptance of his condition that he had practically, after all, drawn from her—a declaration on which she then, recurring to her first idea, promptly acted. She glanced around, at the door and window, as if he was asking for more than he was saying. "Here? There's nothing between us here," Kate smiled.

Translation

"I'll do all you want," he declared, as if to recognize his acceptance of the terms he’d essentially extracted from her. It was a declaration she then immediately acted upon, returning to her initial thought. She looked around at the door and window, as if he were asking for more than he was saying. "Here? There's nothing between us here," Kate smiled.

"Oh, isn't there?" With that, her smile had resolved something for him, and he approached her, practically begging, holding out his hands, which she immediately clasped in her own, as though to both restrain him and keep him. Keeping him that way for a moment did, in fact, restrain him. She held him long enough, while they gazed deeply into each other's eyes, waiting in silence for him to regain his composure and exercise more restraint. He blushed as if he was remembering where they were, and that gave her exactly one of her typical victories, which immediately took further shape.

Translation

"Oh, really?" His question was met with the resolution of her smile, and he moved toward her, almost pleading, his hands extended. She took them in her own at once, as if to both hold him back and keep him close. For a moment, it did hold him back. She held him that way, gazing into each other's eyes, silent as they waited for him to collect himself and show more control. He blushed, as if remembering where they were, and this offered her one of her usual wins, which she seized immediately.

By the time he released her hands, he had, in a sense, once again taken hold of Milly. At any rate, it wasn't with Milly that he had broken up. "I'll do all you want," he declared as if accepting the terms of their agreement that he had, in the end, essentially drawn from her. Promptly returning to her initial idea, she acted on that declaration.

Translation

When he let go of her hands, he had, in a way, regained his hold on Milly. Either way, it wasn't Milly he'd broken up with. "I'll do anything," he said, as if accepting the terms of an agreement he'd ultimately gotten from her. She immediately acted on that declaration, returning to her original idea.

"If you are as good as that I go. You'll tell her that, finding you with her, I wouldn't wait. Say that, you know, from yourself. She'll understand."

Translation

"If you're that confident, then I'll leave. Tell her that if she found you with her, I wouldn't stick around. Say that, you know, just make it your own. She'll get it."

She had reached the door with it—she was full of decision; but he had before she left him one more doubt. "I don't see how she can understand enough, you know, without understanding too much." "You don't need to see." He required then a last injunction.

Translation

She was at the door, ready to go, and clearly resolved, but before she left, he voiced one final concern. "I don't know if she can grasp it without understanding everything." "You don't need to witness it." He then needed one last instruction.

"I must simply go it blind?" "You must simply be kind to her." "And leave the rest to you?" "Leave the rest to her," said Kate disappearing.

Translation

"So I just have to go in blind?" "You just have to be kind to her." "And leave everything else to you?" "Leave everything else to her," Kate said, disappearing.

It came back then afresh to that, as it had come before. Milly, three minutes after Kate had gone, returned in her array—her big black hat, so little superstitiously in the fashion, her fine black garments throughout, the swathing of her throat, which Densher vaguely took for an infinite number of yards of priceless lace, and which, its folded fabric kept in place by heavy rows of pearls, hung down to her feet like the stole of a priestess. He spoke to her at once of their friend's visit and flight. "She hadn't known she'd find me," he said—and said at present without difficulty.

Translation

It hit him again, just like it had before. Three minutes after Kate left, Milly came back, looking the part. Her big black hat, not quite in style, her elegant black clothes, the way her throat was wrapped—Densher imagined it was yards and yards of priceless lace, and it hung to her feet like a priestess's stole, held in place by heavy strings of pearls. He told her right away about their friend's visit and then her sudden departure. "She didn't know I'd be here," he said—and right then, it was easy to say.

He had so rounded his corner that it wasn't a question of a word more or less. "If you're that good, I'm leaving. Tell her that, since you were with her, I wouldn't wait. Tell her that, you know, just say it.

Translation

He had navigated his position so well that it didn't matter what words he used. "If you're so sure of yourself, I'm leaving. Tell her that, since you were with her, I wouldn't stick around. Just tell her that, you understand, just say it."

She'll understand." She was at the door, determined. But before she left, he had one more worry. "I don't see how she can understand enough, you know, without understanding too much."

Translation

"She will," he said. She was at the door, her mind made up. But before she walked out, one more thought struck him. "I don't know how she can grasp it all, without understanding more than she should."

"You don't need to see." He then needed one last instruction. "So I just do this blindly?" "Just be kind to her."

Translation

"You don't need to see." He needed one final bit of direction. "So I just do this blindly?" "Just be kind to her."

"And leave the rest to you?" "Leave the rest to her," Kate said, and disappeared. It came back to that, as it had before. Milly, three minutes after Kate left, returned in her outfit—her large black hat, a bit out of style, her elegant black clothes, the covering around her neck, which Densher assumed was an endless amount of expensive lace.

Translation

"And leave the rest to you?" "Leave the rest to her," Kate said, and then she was gone. It came down to that, just like it had before. Milly, three minutes after Kate departed, reappeared in her ensemble—her enormous black hat, slightly outdated, her graceful black garments, the scarf around her neck, which Densher presumed was yards and yards of expensive lace.

It was held in place by heavy rows of pearls, and it hung down to her feet like a priestess's stole. He immediately told her about their friend's visit and departure. "She didn't know she'd find me," he said—and said it easily now. He'd reached a point where it didn't matter what words he used.

Translation

The scarf was fastened with thick strands of pearls, draping down to her ankles like a priestess's garment. He immediately filled her in on their friend's arrival and exit. "She didn't know I'd be here," he said—and the words flowed effortlessly now. He'd arrived at a place where the specifics of his phrasing held no consequence.

She took this account of the matter as quite sufficient; she glossed over whatever might be awkward. "I'm sorry—but I of course often see her." He felt the discrimination in his favour and how it justified Kate. This was Milly's tone when the matter was left to her. Well, it should now be wholly left.

Translation

Her understanding of the situation was complete; she chose to ignore anything that might cause difficulty. "I apologize—though I do see her often, naturally." He recognized the preferential treatment, and how it exonerated Kate. This was the manner in which Milly handled things when the decision was hers. Very well, it would be entirely up to her now.

Chapter 6

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
After Kate and Densher leave them, Milly and Mrs. Stringham (Susie) face each other. Milly places a hand on her heart. She acknowledges that Mrs. Stringham has met with a doctor, Sir Luke Strett, and that she (Milly) has used their guests as a barrier to avoid discussing it. Milly asks what Mrs. Stringham thinks of Mr. Densher, and Mrs. Stringham calls him handsome. Milly tells Mrs. Stringham that together they must "see me through." They embrace. Milly states that she does not want to know what the doctor said, only that Mrs. Stringham will support her on his terms. Mrs. Stringham reveals that the doctor said she could help Milly, that he told her nothing dreadful, and that Milly should do as she likes. The next morning, Mrs. Stringham goes to Mrs. Lowder’s house at Lancaster Gate. Upon arriving, she begins to cry, explaining she could not do so in front of Milly. After Mrs. Lowder dismisses a footman, Mrs. Stringham recounts her meeting with Sir Luke Strett. She says the doctor is interested in Milly, that Milly does not have the illness she feared, but that she has a different, unnamed condition. The doctor's advice is that Milly must be made happy, and she is to return to him in three months. Mrs. Stringham and Mrs. Lowder discuss this prescription for happiness. Mrs. Stringham asks if Kate Croy cares for Mr. Densher. Mrs. Lowder hesitates, then states that Kate *thinks* she cares for him but is mistaken. She instructs Mrs. Stringham to deny Kate’s interest to Milly if asked. Mrs. Lowder then agrees to help facilitate a relationship between Milly and Mr. Densher, explaining that this will also help her own plans for Kate. She formulates a plan for Mrs. Stringham and Milly to stay a few days longer and meet Mr. Densher at dinner. Mrs. Lowder asks again what Mrs. Stringham thinks of Densher. Mrs. Stringham calls him charming, and Mrs. Lowder agrees.

Chapter 7

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Milly states her intention to visit Sir Luke Strett to thank him for his tolerance of her behavior. A meeting concludes after Mrs. Lowder laughs at a remark from Mrs. Stringham (Susie) about Merton Densher. Later, Milly tells Susie that Sir Luke is only being easy on her because he pities her. Susie disagrees, saying he likes her. Milly asks Susie to "work for me" and embraces her. Afterwards, Milly does not give Susie an account of her visit to the doctor. At the meeting, Milly thanks Sir Luke for his kindness. He tells her she is looking remarkably well. She says he has already done her so much good, but he replies that she is difficult to treat and must go away soon. She tells him she is leaving for the Tyrol and then Venice on the fourteenth. Sir Luke states that he also plans to be in Venice in October with his niece, and they will meet there. He asks about her companions, and Milly confirms Mrs. Stringham and two other women will be traveling with her. She identifies one companion as Miss Croy and mentions Miss Croy has a male friend, Mr. Densher, who always follows her and will likely be in Venice. Sir Luke asks if they are lovers; Milly smiles and says he is, but she is not interested in him. When Sir Luke notes that they won't be four women alone, Milly states that Mr. Densher will not have come for her. She asks Sir Luke if he can help Mr. Densher. As the visit ends, Milly stands and gives Sir Luke her hand to say goodbye. He tells her she is "all right," and she asks him to "keep me so." He offers to do anything he can for Mr. Densher. Milly thinks, smiles, and says there is nothing that can be done.

When Kate and Densher abandoned her to Mrs. Stringham on the day of her meeting them together and bringing them to luncheon, Milly, face to face with that companion, had had one of those moments in which the warned, the anxious fighter of the battle of life, as if once again feeling for the sword at his side, carries his hand straight to the quarter of his courage. She laid hers firmly on her heart, and the two women stood there showing each other a strange front. Susan Shepherd had received their great doctor's visit, which had been clearly no small affair for her; but Milly had since then, with insistence, kept in place, against communication and betrayal, as she now practically confessed, the barrier of their invited guests.

Translation

When Kate and Densher left her with Mrs. Stringham the day she introduced them at lunch, Milly, confronting that companion, experienced a moment. In this moment, the person warned, the anxious combatant in the battle of life, as if reaching for their sword, instinctively touched the source of their courage. She placed her hand firmly on her heart, and the two women faced each other with a strange composure. Susan Shepherd had hosted the great doctor’s visit, an event of significance for her. Since then, Milly had maintained the barrier of their invited guests, against communication and betrayal, as she was now effectively admitting.

"You've been too dear. With what I see you're full of you treated them beautifully. Isn't Kate charming when she wants to be?" She accepted this explanation without further questioning, avoiding anything that might be uncomfortable.

Translation

"You've been too kind. Considering how much you had to deal with, you treated them wonderfully. Isn't Kate charming when she puts her mind to it?" She accepted this assessment without further discussion, steering clear of any potentially awkward topics.

"I apologize, but naturally, I see her frequently." He sensed the advantage he had and how it validated Kate. This was Milly's approach when she was left to deal with something. Well, now she would be left to handle it entirely. BOOK SEVEN

Translation

"I'm sorry, but of course, I see her all the time." He understood the power he held, and how it affirmed Kate. This was Milly's way of handling things when she was left to do them. Well, now she would be left to handle everything completely. BOOK SEVEN

I When Kate and Densher left her with Mrs. Stringham after their meeting and brought them together for lunch, Milly, alone with her companion, experienced a moment similar to those in which someone warned and anxious about the struggles of life, as if instinctively reaching for their sword, would instead put their hand directly on their source of courage. She placed her hand firmly on her heart, and the two women stood facing each other with an unusual intensity.

Translation

When Kate and Densher departed, leaving her with Mrs. Stringham after their rendezvous and arranging a luncheon, Milly, alone with her friend, felt a sensation akin to those instances when someone, apprehensive and wary of life's hardships, would instinctively reach for their weapon, but instead, instinctively grasp at their source of fortitude. She pressed her hand against her chest, and the two women faced each other, an uncommon intensity passing between them.

Susan Shepherd had received the visit from their esteemed doctor, which had clearly been a significant event for her. But since then, Milly had, with determination, maintained the separation, resisting any disclosure or betrayal, as she now essentially admitted, the barrier between them and their guests. "You've been too kind. Considering what you know, you treated them wonderfully.

Translation

Susan Shepherd's meeting with their doctor had been important, that much was obvious. But since then, Milly had resolutely kept herself apart, refusing any explanation or admission, revealing, as she was now doing, the dividing line between them and their visitors. "You've been too good. Given everything you know, you treated them beautifully."

Isn't Kate delightful when she wants to be?" Poor Susie's expression, contending at first, as in a high fine spasm, with different dangers, had now quite let itself go. She had to make an effort to reach a point in space already so remote. "Miss Croy?

Translation

"Isn't Kate delightful when she wants to be?" Poor Susie's expression, previously struggling, as if in a high, sharp spasm, with various anxieties, had now completely relaxed. She had to make an effort to connect with a concept that already felt so distant. "Miss Croy?

Oh she was pleasant and clever. She knew," Mrs. Stringham added. "She knew."

Translation

Oh, she was pleasant and clever. She knew, Mrs. Stringham added. She knew.

Milly braced herself—but conscious above all, at the moment, of a high compassion for her mate. She made her out as struggling—struggling in all her nature against the betrayal of pity, which in itself, given her nature, could only be a torment. Milly gathered from the struggle how much there was of the pity, and how therefore it was both in her tenderness and in her conscience that Mrs. Stringham suffered.

Translation

Milly steeled herself—but mostly felt a profound sympathy for her friend at that moment. She could see Mrs. Stringham was struggling—struggling with every fiber of her being against the expression of pity. This, in itself, given her character, could only be an agony. From this struggle, Milly understood how deeply the pity ran, and how much Mrs. Stringham suffered, both in her sensitivity and in her conscience.

Wonderful and beautiful it was that this impression instantly steadied the girl. Ruefully asking herself on what basis of ease, with the drop of their barrier, they were to find themselves together, she felt the question met with a relief that was almost joy. The basis, the inevitable basis, was that she was going to be sorry for Susie, who, to all appearance, had been condemned in so much more uncomfortable a manner to be sorry for her. Mrs.

Translation

The immediate effect of this realization was to steady the girl. She wryly wondered how, now that their mutual defenses had dropped, they would possibly manage to be comfortable together. The question brought a relief that bordered on elation. The foundation, the unavoidable foundation, was that she would feel sorry for Susie, who, it seemed, had been condemned in a far more distressing way to feel sorry for her. Mrs.

Stringham's sorrow would hurt Mrs. Stringham, but how could her own ever hurt? She had, the poor girl, at all events, on the spot, five minutes of exaltation in which she turned the tables on her friend with a pass of the hand, a gesture of an energy that made a wind in the air. "Kate knew," she asked, "that you were full of Sir Luke Strett?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham's sorrow would wound Mrs. Stringham, but how could her own ever inflict pain? The poor girl had, in that moment, five minutes of exhilaration during which she turned the tables on her friend with a wave of her hand, a gesture of such force that it created a breeze. "Kate knew," she inquired, "that you were obsessed with Sir Luke Strett?"

Susie's face, which had been tense at first, as if enduring a painful struggle, had finally relaxed. She had to make a real effort to recall something that seemed so far in the past. "Miss Croy? Oh, she was nice and smart.

Translation

Susie's face, initially taut as if in the grip of a difficult battle, had finally softened. She had to strain to remember something that now seemed very distant. "Miss Croy? Oh, she was kind and clever.

She knew things," Mrs. Stringham said, emphasizing her point. "She knew." Milly steeled herself, but she was mainly aware of a deep sympathy for her friend.

Translation

"She knew things," Mrs. Stringham repeated, driving the point home. "She knew." Milly braced herself, but felt mostly a profound empathy for her friend.

She could see Susie fighting—fighting with all her strength against showing pity, which, considering her personality, would be torture. Milly understood from this struggle how much pity Susie felt, and thus how much her tenderness and conscience were causing her suffering. It was amazing and wonderful how this realization immediately calmed Milly. With a rueful question of how, now that their defenses were down, they would be able to relate to each other, she felt a sense of relief that bordered on joy.

Translation

She watched Susie struggling, fighting with everything she had not to show pity, which, considering who she was, would be a kind of torment. From this effort, Milly understood the depth of Susie’s pity, and, by extension, how much her compassion and conscience were hurting her. This realization was instantly and surprisingly calming. With a rueful thought about how, now that their guards were down, they could possibly interact, she felt a wave of relief that came close to joy.

The foundation, the unavoidable foundation, was that she was going to feel sorry for Susie, who, it seemed, had been forced in a much more painful way to feel sorry for her. Mrs. Stringham's sorrow would hurt her, but how could Milly's sorrow ever hurt? She had, the poor girl, at that moment, five minutes of elation where she turned the tables on her friend with a wave of her hand, a gesture of such force that it created a breeze.

Translation

The inescapable, fundamental truth was that she was going to feel sorry for Susie, who, it seemed, had been forced to endure a much more agonizing experience of pity for her. Mrs. Stringham's sorrow would wound her, but how could Milly's sorrow ever be harmful? The poor girl had, in that moment, five minutes of pure elation, as she reversed their roles with a wave of her hand, a gesture of such power that it stirred the air.

"Kate knew," she asked, "that you were infatuated with Sir Luke Strett?" "She spoke of nothing, but she was gentle and nice; she seemed to want to help me through." Which the good lady had no sooner said, however, than she almost tragically gasped at herself. She glared at Milly with a pretended pluck. "What I mean is that she saw one had been taken up with something.

Translation

"Did Kate know," she asked, "that you were in love with Sir Luke Strett?" "She didn't mention anything, but she was kind and friendly; she seemed to want to help me get through it." But the moment the good lady said this, she gasped at herself, almost tragically. She glared at Milly with forced courage. "What I mean is that she saw someone was preoccupied with something."

When I say she knows I should say she's a person who guesses." And her grimace was also, on its side, heroic. "But she doesn't matter, Milly." The girl felt she by this time could face anything. "Nobody matters, Susie.

Translation

"When I say she knows, I should say she's a person who guesses." And her grimace was, in its own way, heroic. "But she doesn't matter, Milly." The girl felt she could face anything by this point. "Nobody matters, Susie."

Nobody." Which her next words, however, rather contradicted. "Did he take it ill that I wasn't here to see him? Wasn't it really just what he wanted—to have it out, so much more simply, with you?" She didn't say much, but she was kind and pleasant; it seemed like she wanted to support me.

Translation

"Nobody," which her next words, however, rather contradicted. "Did he take it badly that I wasn't here to see him? Wasn't it really just what he wanted—to have it out, so much more simply, with you?" She didn't say much, but she was kind and pleasant; it seemed like she wanted to support me.

But the woman immediately recoiled, as if horrified by her own words. She faced Milly with a show of bravery. "What I mean is, she realized you were preoccupied with something. When I say she knows, I mean she's someone who makes assumptions." Her grimace was, in its way, admirable.

Translation

But the woman immediately drew back, as though frightened by what she'd said. She turned to face Milly, displaying a semblance of courage. "What I mean is, she understood you were distracted. When I say she knows, I mean she's the type to jump to conclusions." Her expression of disgust was, in a strange way, impressive.

"But she's not important, Milly." The girl felt she could handle anything at this point. "No one is important, Susie. No one." But her next words contradicted that.

Translation

"But she's not important, Milly." The girl felt she could handle anything at this point. "No one is important, Susie. No one." But her next words contradicted that.

"Was he upset that I wasn't here to see him? Wasn't that actually what he preferred—to have the discussion, much more easily, with you?" "We didn't have anything 'out,' Milly," Mrs. Stringham delicately quavered.

Translation

"Did he mind that I wasn't around? Wasn't it better for him if I wasn't, so he could talk to you without any trouble?" Mrs. Stringham whispered, carefully. "There wasn't anything wrong between us, Milly," she continued.

"Didn't he awfully like you," Milly went on, "and didn't he think you the most charming person I could possibly have referred him to for an account of me? Didn't you hit it off tremendously together and in fact fall quite in love, so that it will really be a great advantage for you to have me as a common ground? You're going to make, I can see, no end of a good thing of me." "My own child, my own child!" Mrs.

Translation

"Didn't he just adore you," Milly continued,

"and didn't he think you were the most charming person

I could have possibly recommended he speak to about me?

Didn't you two get along brilliantly and, in fact, fall in love a bit,

so that it'll actually be a huge benefit for you to have me as

a common interest? You're going to get, I can see,

an incredible amount of enjoyment out of me."

"My dear girl, my dear girl!" Mrs.

Stringham pleadingly murmured; yet showing as she did so that she feared the effect even of deprecation. "Isn't he beautiful and good too himself?—altogether, whatever he may say, a lovely acquaintance to have made? You're just the right people for me—I see it now; and do you know what, between you, you must do?" Then as Susie still but stared, wonderstruck and holding herself: "You must simply see me through. Any way you choose.

Translation

Stringham murmured, her voice pleading, even though she also showed that she feared the effect of her plea. "Isn't he beautiful and good too? Altogether, whatever he may say, he's a lovely acquaintance to have made. You're just the right people for me—I see it now; and do you know what, between you, you must do?" Then, as Susie still stared, wonderstruck and holding herself back, "You must simply see me through. Any way you choose."

Make it out together. I, on my side, will be beautiful too, and we'll be—the three of us, with whatever others, oh as many as the case requires, any one you like!—a sight for the gods. I'll be as easy for you as carrying a feather." Susie took it for a moment in such silence that her young friend almost saw her—and scarcely withheld the observation—as taking it for "a part of the disease." This accordingly helped Milly to be, as she judged, definite and wise. "He's at any rate awfully interesting, isn't he?—which is so much to the good.

Translation

Make it work together. I, for my part, will be beautiful too, and we'll be—the three of us, along with anyone else, oh, as many as necessary, anyone you like!—a sight to behold. I'll be as easy for you as holding a feather." Susie remained silent for a moment, and her young friend almost saw her—and barely stopped herself from saying—that she thought it was "part of the illness." This helped Milly, as she saw it, to be decisive and sensible. "He's terribly interesting, at any rate, isn't he?—which is a great advantage.

We haven't at least—as we might have, with the way we tumbled into it—got hold of one of the dreary." "We didn't reveal anything, Milly," Mrs. Stringham said in a hesitant tone. "Didn't he adore you?" Milly continued.

Translation

"At least we haven't—unlike the way we blundered into this—ended up with one of those boring types." "We kept everything hidden, Milly," Mrs. Stringham said, a little uncertain. "Didn't he just adore you?" Milly pressed on.

"And didn't he believe you were the most charming person I could have asked to describe me? Didn't you two get along wonderfully and practically fall in love, so it will actually be beneficial for you to have me as a shared interest? I can see that you're going to gain a lot from knowing me." "My dear, my dear!" Mrs.

Translation

"And didn't he think you were the most charming person imaginable to describe me? Weren't you two getting along famously, practically falling in love, so it'll actually be a benefit to you to have me as a shared interest? I can see you're going to get a lot out of knowing me." "My dear, my dear!" Mrs.

Stringham pleaded, showing that she was even afraid of disagreeing. "Isn't he handsome and kind? Truly, he's a delightful person to know, whatever he might say. You are the perfect people for me—I can see it now.

Translation

"Oh, my dear, my dear!" Stringham implored, looking terrified to argue. "Isn't he handsome and kind? Truly, he's a lovely person to know, no matter what he says. You're the perfect people for me—I can see it now."

And do you know what the two of you must do?" Then, as Susie just stared, astonished and composed, she said, "You must simply support me. However you decide. Figure it out together. Translation

"You know what you two have to do?" Susie just stared, surprised but collected. She continued, "You just have to support me. Whatever you decide. Figure it out together. Translation

I'll be as easy for you to handle as something that weighs nothing at all." "Interesting, dearest?"—Mrs.

Stringham felt her feet firmer. "I don't know if he's interesting or not; but I do know, my own," she continued to quaver, "that he's just as much interested as you could possibly desire." "Certainly—that's it. Like all the world."

Translation

Stringham felt her feet more stable. "I don't know if he's interesting or not; but I do know, my dear," she continued to stammer, "that he's just as interested as you could possibly want." "Exactly—that's it. Like everyone else."

"No, my precious, not like all the world. Very much more deeply and intelligently." "Ah there you are!" Milly laughed. "That's the way, Susie, I want you.

Translation

"No, darling, not like everyone else. Much more deeply and intelligently." "Ah, there you are!" Milly laughed. "That's what I want, Susie."

So 'buck' up, my dear. We'll have beautiful times with him. Don't worry." "I'm not worrying, Milly." And poor Susie's face registered the sublimity of her lie.

Translation

So cheer up, my dear. We'll have wonderful times with him. Don't worry.” “I'm not worrying, Milly.” And poor Susie’s face registered the sublime nature of her lie.

It was at this that, too sharply penetrated, her companion went to her, met by her with an embrace in which things were said that exceeded speech. Each held and clasped the other as if to console her for this unnamed woe, the woe for Mrs. Stringham of learning the torment of helplessness, the woe for Milly of having her, at such a time, to think of. Milly's assumption was immense, and the difficulty for her friend was that of not being able to gainsay it without bringing it more to the proof than tenderness and vagueness could permit.

Translation

It was then that her companion, pierced too keenly, went to her. They met in an embrace, words passing between them that were more profound than any spoken. Each held and clasped the other, as if to console for this unspoken sorrow: the sorrow of Mrs. Stringham, learning the torment of helplessness, and the sorrow for Milly, having to think of her at such a time. Milly's understanding was vast, and the difficulty for her friend was that she couldn't contradict it without confirming it more completely than tenderness and vagueness would allow.

Nothing in fact came to the proof between them but that they could thus cling together—except indeed that, as we have indicated, the pledge of protection and support was all the younger woman's own. "I don't ask you," she presently said, "what he told you for yourself, nor what he told you to tell me, nor how he took it, really, that I had left him to you, nor what passed between you about me in any way. It wasn't to get that out of you that I took my means to make sure of your meeting freely—for there are things I don't want to know. I shall see him again and again and shall know more than enough.

Translation

The only concrete fact established between them was their ability to cling to each other. Furthermore, as we've noted, the promise of protection and support was entirely the younger woman's responsibility. "I won't ask you," she finally said, "what he told you about yourself, nor what he told you to tell me, nor how he really felt about my leaving him to you, nor what you said to each other about me. I didn't arrange for us to meet freely in order to find out those things—because there are some things I prefer not to know. I'll be seeing him again and again, and I'll learn more than enough."

All I do want is that you shall see me through on his basis, whatever it is; which it's enough—for the purpose—that you yourself should know: that is with him to show you how. I'll make it charming for you—that's what I mean; I'll keep you up to it in such a way that half the time you won't know you're doing it. And for that you're to rest upon me. There.

Translation

All I want is for you to support me in relation to him, whatever that entails. You know what it is, and that's enough for now. He'll show you how to do it. I'll make it enjoyable for you, that's my promise. I'll keep you engaged in a way that you won't even realize you're doing it half the time. And you can rely on me for all of that. There.

Stringham asked, feeling more confident. "I don't know if he's interesting or not, but I do know, dear," she continued in a shaky voice, "that he's as interested as you could possibly want him to be." "Absolutely—that's it. Like everyone else."

Translation

At this, her companion, deeply affected, went to her and embraced her. In that embrace, words were exchanged that were more powerful than actual speech. They held and clung to each other as if comforting one another for this unspoken suffering: the suffering for Mrs. Stringham of realizing her helplessness, the suffering for Milly of having to worry about her, at such a time.

Translation

At this, her friend, deeply moved, went to her and embraced her. In that embrace, words were exchanged that transcended speech. They held each other tightly, as if comforting each other for their shared, unspoken pain: the pain for Mrs. Stringham of realizing her helplessness, and the pain for Milly of having to worry about her, at such a time.

Milly's certainty was remarkable, and the difficulty for her friend was that she couldn't contradict it without proving it, something that tenderness and ambiguity wouldn't allow. In truth, nothing was proven between them except their ability to hold onto each other—except, as we've said, that the promise of protection and support came entirely from the younger woman. "I'm not asking you," she said later, "what he told you for yourself, or what he told you to tell me, or how he really felt about me leaving him in your care, or anything that was said about me between you two. That's not why I made sure you could meet freely—there are things I don't want to know.

Translation

Milly possessed an unwavering conviction, and the challenge for her friend was that to challenge it would be to validate it, a prospect tenderness and unspoken understandings couldn’t accommodate. Actually, the only thing confirmed between them was their capacity to sustain one another—except, as we’ve noted, the pledge of protection and backing originated solely with the younger woman. "I'm not asking," she said later, "about what he confided to you, or what he instructed you to say to me, or how he truly felt about my leaving him in your care, or anything discussed about me between the two of you. That's not the reason I arranged for you to meet freely—there are things I prefer not to know.

I'll see him again and again, and I'll learn more than enough. All I want is for you to support me based on his perspective, whatever it is; it's enough—for this purpose—that you understand it: that is, to show you how he sees it. I'll make it pleasant for you—that's what I mean; I'll keep you going in such a way that half the time you won't even realize you're doing it. And you can rely on me for that.

Translation

I'll be seeing him repeatedly, and I'll find out plenty. All I need from you is to back me up, based on his point of view, whatever it is. That's sufficient, for this purpose: that you understand it. In other words, to show you how he sees things. I'll make it agreeable for you, that's what I'm saying; I'll keep you going in a way that you won't even realize you're doing it half the time. And you can count on me for that.

There. It's settled. We'll support each other, and you can absolutely trust that I won't fall apart. So, since you don't even have to worry about a nudge in the ribs, how could you possibly be safer?"

Translation

There. It's agreed. We'll have each other's backs, and I promise, I won't crack. Since you don't even need a little push, how could you be any more secure?

"He told me I can help you—of course he told me that," Susie, on her side, eagerly contended. "Why shouldn't he, and for what else have I come out with you? But he told me nothing dreadful—nothing, nothing, nothing," the poor lady passionately protested. "Only that you must do as you like and as he tells you—which is just simply to do as you like."

Translation

"He said I could help you—of course he said that," Susie argued eagerly. "Why wouldn't he, and what else have I come out here with you for? But he didn't tell me anything awful—nothing, nothing, nothing," the poor woman protested with passion. "Only that you must do as you wish and as he tells you—which is simply to do as you wish."

"I must keep in sight of him. I must from time to time go to him. But that's of course doing as I like. It's lucky," Milly smiled, "that I like going to him."

Translation

"I have to keep an eye on him. I have to see him every now and then. But that's just doing what I want, of course. It's fortunate," Milly smiled, "that I enjoy visiting him."

Mrs. Stringham was here in agreement; she gave a clutch at the account of their situation that most showed it as workable. "That's what will be charming for me, and what I'm sure he really wants of me—to help you to do as you like." Susie, on her end, insisted with enthusiasm, "He said I could help you—of course he told me that."

Translation

Mrs. Stringham concurred, embracing the description of their circumstances that painted it in a favorable light. "Why I shouldn't have a long, wonderful life?" Milly understood this instantly, as if she were taking a beat to consider it. But she brushed it aside. "Oh, of course, I know that." She spoke as though her friend's point didn't matter. Mrs.

Translation

Stringham attempted to expand on it. "Well, what I mean is that he didn't tell me anything that he hasn't told you." "Really?—I would in his position!" She may have been disappointed, but she retained her good humor. "He tells me to live"—and she strangely emphasized the word.
