Translation

Susie felt a bit lost. "Then what else do you want?" "My dear," the girl replied a moment later, "I don't 'want,' I assure you, anything. Still," she added, "I am living."

Oh yes, I'm living." It put them again face to face, but it had wound Mrs. Stringham up. "So am I then, you'll see!"—she spoke with the note of her recovery.

Translation

Oh yes, I am living." That put them face to face again, but it had riled up Mrs. Stringham. "So am I then, you'll see!"—she said, her voice conveying a sense of revival.

Yet it was her wisdom now—meaning by it as much as she did—not to say more than that. She had risen by Milly's aid to a certain command of what was before them; the ten minutes of their talk had in fact made her more distinctly aware of the presence in her mind of a new idea. It was really perhaps an old idea with a new value; it had at all events begun during the last hour, though at first but feebly, to shine with a special light. That was because in the morning darkness had so suddenly descended—a sufficient shade of night to bring out the power of a star.

Translation

Yet it was her wisdom now—and she meant a great deal by that—to say no more than what she had. She had gained, with Milly's help, a certain mastery over the situation; the ten minutes they’d just spent together had actually made her more distinctly conscious of a new idea in her mind. It was likely an old idea with a new significance; at any rate, it had started to shine with a special light during the last hour, though at first it was faint. That was because the morning had been so abruptly darkened—a shadow sufficient to reveal the strength of a star.

The dusk might be thick yet, but the sky had comparatively cleared; and Susan Shepherd's star from this time on continued to twinkle for her. It was for the moment, after her passage with Milly, the one spark left in the heavens. She recognised, as she continued to watch it, that it had really been set there by Sir Luke Strett's visit and that the impressions immediately following had done no more than fix it. Milly's reappearance with Mr.

Translation

The twilight may have been dense, but the sky had comparatively cleared. From that point on, Susan Shepherd's star continued to twinkle for her. It was, at the moment, after her time with Milly, the sole spark left in the heavens. As she kept watching it, she recognized that Sir Luke Strett's visit had truly put it there, and that the immediate aftereffects had only served to secure it. Milly's reappearance with Mr.

Densher at her heels—or, so oddly perhaps, at Miss Croy's heels, Miss Croy being at Milly's—had contributed to this effect, though it was only with the lapse of the greater obscurity that Susie made that out. The obscurity had reigned during the hour of their friends' visit, faintly clearing indeed while, in one of the rooms, Kate Croy's remarkable advance to her intensified the fact that Milly and the young man were conjoined in the other. If it hadn't acquired on the spot all the intensity of which it was capable, this was because the poor lady still sat in her primary gloom, the gloom the great benignant doctor had practically left behind him. Mrs.

Translation

Densher trailing behind—or, oddly enough, perhaps behind Miss Croy, with Miss Croy behind Milly—had helped create this impression, though Susie didn’t fully grasp it until the worst of the darkness had lifted. The obscurity had been dominant during their friends' visit, faintly receding as Kate Croy's striking move towards her in one of the rooms intensified the sense that Milly and the young man were linked together in the other. If it hadn't become completely overwhelming on the spot, that was because the poor woman still sat in her original gloom, the gloom the kind, great doctor had essentially left in his wake. Mrs.

Stringham attempted to expand on the subject. "Well, what I mean is, he didn't tell me anything he hasn't already told you." "Really? I would if I were him!" She may have been disheartened, but she maintained her good spirits.

Translation

Stringham attempted to elaborate. "Well, what I'm trying to say is, he didn't share anything with me that he hadn't already shared with you." "Really? I certainly would have!" She might have been disappointed, but she remained in good humor.

"He tells me to live"—and she emphasized the word in a peculiar way. It left Susie somewhat perplexed. "Then what more do you want?" "My dear," the girl said after a moment, "I don't 'want,' I assure you, anything.

Translation

"He tells me to live"—and she emphasized the word in a peculiar way. It left Susie somewhat perplexed. "Then what more do you want?" "My dear," the girl said after a moment, "I don't 'want,' I assure you, anything.

Still," she added, "I am living. Oh yes, I am living." It brought them back to facing each other, but it had energized Mrs. Stringham.

Translation

"Nevertheless," she added, "I am living. Oh yes, I am living." It brought them back to facing each other, but it had energized Mrs. Stringham.

"So am I then, you'll see!"—she said with the tone of someone recovering. Yet it was her wisdom now—given what she understood—not to elaborate. Milly had helped her attain a certain understanding of what lay before them; the ten minutes of their conversation had, in fact, made her more clearly aware of the presence of a new idea in her mind. It was, perhaps, an old idea with a new significance; at any rate, it had begun to shine with a special light during the last hour, though initially very weakly.

Translation

"I am too, you'll see!" she declared, her voice regaining its strength. It was her wisdom now, based on her new understanding, not to say more. Milly had helped her understand what was ahead of them; their ten-minute conversation had, in fact, given her a clearer awareness of a new concept in her mind. Maybe it was an old idea with a new meaning; at any rate, it had begun to glow with a special light during the last hour, though at first it was very faint.

That was because the morning darkness had suddenly fallen—a sufficient amount of shadow to highlight the power of a star. The twilight might still be thick, but the sky had comparatively cleared; and Susan Shepherd's star continued to twinkle for her from that point on. It was, for the moment, after her time with Milly, the only spark remaining in the heavens. She recognized, as she continued to observe it, that it had truly been placed there by Sir Luke Strett's visit and that the impressions immediately following had only served to solidify it.

Translation

That was because the morning darkness had abruptly arrived—enough shadow to emphasize a star's power. The twilight might still be heavy, but the sky had relatively cleared; and Susan Shepherd's star kept twinkling for her from then on. For the moment, after her time with Milly, it was the only spark left in the sky. She realized, as she kept watching it, that Sir Luke Strett's visit had truly put it there, and that the immediate aftereffects had only served to make it stronger.

Milly's reappearance with Mr. Densher trailing behind her—or, in a strange way, following Miss Croy, with Miss Croy beside Milly—had contributed to this effect, though it was only with the passing of the greater obscurity that Susie realized this. The obscurity had reigned during their friends' visit, gradually clearing while, in one of the rooms, Kate Croy's remarkable approach to her intensified the fact that Milly and the young man were together in the other. If it hadn't acquired all of its potential intensity immediately, it was because the poor lady still remained in her original gloom, the gloom the great, benevolent doctor had practically left behind him.

Translation

Milly's return, with Mr. Densher in tow—or, oddly enough, following Miss Croy, with Miss Croy at Milly's side—had something to do with it, though Susie only understood this once the worst of the darkness had lifted. This darkness had held sway during their friends' visit, gradually dissipating as, in one of the rooms, Kate Croy's extraordinary behavior toward her emphasized the fact that Milly and the young man were together in the other. If this hadn't fully taken hold immediately, it was because the poor woman was still shrouded in her original gloom, the gloom the kind doctor had, in effect, left behind.

The intensity the circumstance in question might wear to the informed imagination would have been sufficiently revealed for us, no doubt—and with other things to our purpose—in two or three of those confidential passages with Mrs. Lowder that she now permitted herself. She hadn't yet been so glad that she believed in her old friend; for if she hadn't had, at such a pass, somebody or other to believe in she should certainly have stumbled by the way. Discretion had ceased to consist of silence; silence was gross and thick, whereas wisdom should taper, however tremulously, to a point.

Translation

The informed imagination would have clearly grasped the intensity of the situation—along with other relevant details—from two or three of the private conversations she now allowed herself with Mrs. Lowder. She'd never been so grateful for her faith in her old friend. Without someone to confide in at this critical moment, she surely would have faltered. Discretion no longer meant silence; silence was crude and heavy, while wisdom, however hesitantly, should sharpen to a point.

She betook herself to Lancaster Gate the morning after the colloquy just noted; and there, in Maud Manningham's own sanctum, she gradually found relief in giving an account of herself. An account of herself was one of the things that she had long been in the habit of expecting herself regularly to give—the regularity depending of course much on such tests of merit as might, by laws beyond her control, rise in her path. She never spared herself in short a proper sharpness of conception of how she had behaved, and it was a statement that she for the most part found herself able to make. What had happened at present was that nothing, as she felt, was left of her to report to; she was all too sunk in the inevitable and the abysmal.

Translation

The morning after the aforementioned conversation, she went to Lancaster Gate. There, in Maud Manningham's private space, she slowly found solace in providing an account of herself. Giving an account of herself was something she had long been accustomed to doing regularly, the frequency dependent on measures of worth that might, by forces outside her control, appear in her life. In short, she never avoided a clear understanding of her own behavior, and generally, she could articulate it. But now, she felt that there was nothing of herself left to report. She was consumed by the unavoidable and the profound.

To give an account of herself she must give it to somebody else, and her first instalment of it to her hostess was that she must please let her cry. She couldn't cry, with Milly in observation, at the hotel, which she had accordingly left for that purpose; and the power happily came to her with the good opportunity. She cried and cried at first—she confined herself to that; it was for the time the best statement of her business. Mrs.

Translation

To give an account of herself, she had to give it to someone else, and her first offering to her hostess was that she needed to be allowed to cry. She couldn't cry in the hotel with Milly watching, which was why she had left. Fortunately, she found the ability now that she had the right opportunity. She cried and cried at first—she focused solely on that; for the moment, it was the best statement of her situation. Mrs.

Lowder moreover intelligently took it as such, though knocking off a note or two more, as she said, while Susie sat near her table. She could resist the contagion of tears, but her patience did justice to her visitor's most vivid plea for it. "I shall never be able, you know, to cry again—at least not ever with her; so I must take it out when I can. Even if she does herself it won't be for me to give away; for what would that be but a confession of despair?

Translation

Lowder, for her part, understood perfectly. She even added a few observations of her own, she later explained, while Susie sat by her table. Mrs. Lowder could resist the impulse to cry, but she lent her patience to her visitor's most heartfelt request. "I'll never be able to cry again, you know, at least not in front of her. So I have to get it out when I can. Even if she cries herself, it won't be something I can share. That would just be admitting defeat."

I'm not with her for that—I'm with her to be regularly sublime. Besides, Milly won't cry herself." The gravity of the situation, for anyone who understood it, would have been apparent from the conversations with Mrs. Lowder, which she was now allowing.

Translation

I'm not doing this for that reason. I'm with her to experience a constant sense of the sublime. Moreover, Milly won't cry. Anyone who understood the circumstances would have seen their significance in the discussions with Mrs. Lowder, which she was now making public.

She was so grateful to believe in her old friend; without someone to trust at this moment, she would have certainly faltered. Silence was no longer the best approach; it was crude and dense, while wisdom should be pointed and precise, even if it wavered. She went to Lancaster Gate the morning after their last discussion. There, in Maud Manningham's private space, she found some relief in explaining her situation.

Translation

She felt immense gratitude to trust in her old friend; without someone to confide in right then, she would have crumbled. Silence had lost its appeal; it was clumsy and opaque, while wisdom needed to be focused and sharp, even if it wavered. She went to Lancaster Gate the morning after their last conversation. There, in Maud Manningham's private space, she found some solace in explaining her circumstances.

She had long been accustomed to assessing her own behavior regularly, the frequency depending on the challenges that unexpectedly arose. She was always sharp in her self-assessment and usually found herself capable of it. But now, she felt that there was nothing left of her to report; she was consumed by the unavoidable and the profound. To explain herself, she had to confide in someone else, and her first installment to her hostess was simply to let her cry.

Translation

She was used to taking stock of herself, a habit she adjusted depending on the curveballs life threw. She was usually clear-eyed and efficient in her self-analysis. But now, it felt like there was nothing left to examine; she was overwhelmed by the inevitable and the essential. To make sense of it all, she needed to open up, and her initial offering to her hostess was just to break down.

She couldn't cry in the hotel while Milly was present, so she had left for that specific purpose, and fortunately, she was able to. At first, she just cried and cried—that was all she did; for the time being, it best expressed her distress. Mrs. Lowder understood this as well, although, as she said, she was working on some notes while Susie sat at the table.

Translation

She couldn't cry in the hotel with Milly there, so she'd gone out to do exactly that, and thankfully, she could. At first, she just cried and cried—that was all she did; for the time being, it was the best way to show her pain. Mrs. Lowder understood, though, even though, as she said, she was working on some notes while Susie sat at the table.

She resisted the urge to cry, but her patience was in full support of her visitor's passionate request. "I'll never be able to cry again—at least not in front of her; so I must do it when I can. Even if she does, it won't be for me to respond, because that would be an admission of hopelessness. I'm not with her for that—I'm with her to be consistently composed.

Translation

She fought back tears, but her forbearance was entirely dedicated to her guest's heartfelt plea. "I'll never be able to cry again—at least not in front of her; so I have to do it when I can. Even if she does, I can't react, because that would be an admission of defeat. I'm not with her for that—I'm with her to remain perpetually composed."

Besides, Milly won't cry." "I'm sure I hope," said Mrs. Lowder, "that she won't have occasion to." "She won't even if she does have occasion.

Translation

Besides, Milly won't cry." "I certainly hope not," said Mrs. Lowder, "that she'll have no reason to." "She won't, even if she does.

She won't shed a tear. There's something that will prevent her." "Oh!" said Mrs. Lowder.

Translation

She won't cry. Something will stop her. "Oh!" said Mrs. Lowder.

"Yes, her pride," Mrs. Stringham explained in spite of her friend's doubt, and it was with this that her communication took consistent form. It had never been pride, Maud Manningham had hinted, that kept her from crying when other things made for it; it had only been that these same things, at such times, made still more for business, arrangements, correspondence, the ringing of bells, the marshalling of servants, the taking of decisions. "I might be crying now," she said, "if I weren't writing letters"—and this quite without harshness for her anxious companion, to whom she allowed just the administrative margin for difference.

Translation

"Yes, her pride," Mrs. Stringham clarified, despite her friend's skepticism, and it was with this that her statement gained coherence. It hadn't been pride, Maud Manningham had suggested, that prevented her from crying when other circumstances might have triggered it; it was only that those same circumstances, at such moments, further necessitated business, arrangements, correspondence, ringing the telephone, organizing the staff, and making decisions. "I might be crying now," she stated, "if I weren't writing letters"—and this without any severity towards her concerned companion, to whom she conceded only the administrative space for a contrasting opinion.

She had interrupted her no more than she would have interrupted the piano-tuner. It gave poor Susie time; and when Mrs. Lowder, to save appearances and catch the post, had, with her addressed and stamped notes, met at the door of the room the footman summoned by the pressure of a knob, the facts of the case were sufficiently ready for her. It took but two or three, however, given their importance, to lay the ground for the great one—Mrs.

She won't cry. Something will stop her." "Oh!" said Mrs. Lowder.

Translation

"She won't cry. Something will stop her." "Oh!" said Mrs. Lowder.

"Yes, her pride," Mrs. Stringham clarified, despite her friend's skepticism. This became the main point of her explanation. Maud Manningham had suggested that it wasn't pride that kept her from crying when she had reason to; it was that these reasons also demanded action: tasks, planning, letters, ringing bells, organizing staff, and making decisions.

Translation

"Yes, her pride," Mrs. Stringham specified, despite her friend's doubt. That became the core of her reasoning. Maud Manningham had proposed that it wasn't pride that prevented tears when she had cause for them; rather, these causes also demanded action: duties, scheduling, correspondence, summoning, managing employees, and making decisions.

"I might be crying now," she had said, "if I weren't writing letters"—and this was said without any real criticism of her worried companion, to whom she gave just enough room for disagreement. She hadn't interrupted her any more than she would have interrupted the piano tuner. It gave poor Susie time to think; and when Mrs. Lowder, to maintain decorum and catch the mail, met the footman at the door with her addressed and stamped letters—the footman summoned by a button—the key details were clear enough.

Translation

"I might be crying right now," she had said, "if I weren't writing letters"—and she said this without criticizing her worried friend, leaving her just enough room to disagree. Stringham.

"He is. He wants to see her."

"He'll never do that, you know."

"He has a reason."

"Oh!"

"He has a reason that, if you once see it, will be enough for you."

"And I don't see it?"

"You don't."

Stringham. "Do you mean in her case?" "He says it isn't a case." "What then is it?"

Translation

Stringham. "Do you mean in her situation?" "He claims it's not a situation." "Then what is it?"

"It isn't, at least," Mrs. Stringham explained, "the case she believed it to be—thought it at any rate might be—when, without my knowledge, she went to see him. She went because there was something she was afraid of, and he examined her thoroughly—he has made sure. She's wrong—she hasn't what she thought."

I mean that he sees what he can do with me." Mrs. Lowder took it rightly. "For her."

Translation

I mean, he's figuring out how he can use me." Mrs. Lowder understood. "For her."

Translation

"For her. Anything at all, he'll do it, he has to. He can bleed me dry, and he enjoys that, at least. He says the most important thing is for her to be happy."

"It's surely the great thing for every one. Why, therefore," Mrs. Lowder handsomely asked, "should we cry so hard about it?" "I didn't ask for anything," Susie said, sounding defeated, "I just took what he offered.

Lowder considered, her bulk shifting slightly, reflecting on Sir Luke Strett's perspective. She remained seated, legs spread wide, resembling a matron at a market stall, earrings glinting. Translation

"Is that the only reason he approached you, to tell you she has to be happy?" "That she must be made happy, that's the core of it. When he described it, it seemed sufficient," Mrs. Stringham replied, "he made it sound like an enormous yet attainable objective."

"Well, if he can pull it off!" "I mean, he's the one who makes it all seem so important. He gave me this role, my part to play. Everything else is up to him."

He assigned me my part, you see. The rest is up to him." "And what exactly does 'the rest' entail?" Mrs. Lowder inquired.

"I have no idea. That's his business. He plans to manipulate her." "So why did you say it wasn't a 'case'?"

Translation

"And what does he discover?" "Oh," Mrs. Stringham exclaimed, "I hope I never find out!" "He didn't tell you?"

But poor Susie had regained her composure. "What I mean is, if it exists, I'll know eventually. He's thinking it over, but I trust him implicitly, because I believe he trusts me. He's thinking," she repeated.

Translation

But poor Susie had pulled herself together. "What I mean is, if it's true, I'll find out. He's still considering it, but I have complete faith in him, because I believe he trusts me. He's thinking," she said again.

"He's in other words not sure?" "Well, he's watching. I think that's what he means. She's to get away now, but to come back to him in three months."

Translation

"So, he's undecided?" "Well, he's waiting. I think that's the idea. She has to leave for now, but return to him in three months."

"Then I think," said Maud Lowder, "that he oughtn't meanwhile to scare us." It roused Susie a little, Susie being already enrolled in the great doctor's cause. This came out at least in her glimmer of reproach. "Does it scare us to enlist us for her happiness?"

Translation

"Then I think," said Maud Lowder, "that he shouldn't frighten us in the meantime." It roused Susie a little, Susie already being a supporter of the great doctor's cause. This emerged, at least, in her glimmer of reproach. "Does it scare us to commit ourselves to her happiness?"

Mrs. Lowder was rather stiff for it. "Yes; it scares me. I'm always scared—I may call it so—till I understand.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder was quite resistant to the idea. "Yes; it does scare me. I'm always scared—I can say that much—until I understand."

What happiness is he talking about?" Mrs. Stringham at this came straight. "Oh you know!"

Translation

"What happiness is he talking about?" Mrs. Stringham immediately joined the conversation. "Oh, you know!"

She had really said it so that her friend had to take it; which the latter in fact after a moment showed herself as having done. A strange light humour in the matter even perhaps suddenly aiding, she met it with a certain accommodation. "Well, say one seems to see. The point is—!" But, fairly too full now of her question, she dropped.

Translation

She had phrased it in a way that left her friend no choice but to engage, which the latter, after a moment, did. Perhaps aided by a strange, sudden humor in the situation, she responded with a degree of acceptance. "Well, let's say one sees. The point is—!" But, overwhelmed by her own question, she trailed off.

"So, he's uncertain?" "Well, he's observing. I think that's his meaning. She's supposed to leave now, but return to him in three months."

Translation

"So, he's unsure?" "More like he's watching. That's what I gather. She's meant to go, but come back in three months."

"Then I believe," Maud Lowder said, "that he shouldn't frighten us in the meantime." This perked Susie up a bit, given her support for the renowned doctor. This became clear in her hint of disapproval. "Does it frighten us to be involved in her happiness?"

Translation

"Then I think," Maud Lowder said, "he shouldn't scare us while we wait." This seemed to cheer Susie up a bit, considering her fondness for the famous doctor. This was apparent in her subtle hint of disapproval. "Does it scare us to be invested in her happiness?"

Mrs. Lowder was quite firm in response. "Yes; it frightens me. I'm always frightened—I might as well say it—until I understand.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder responded with definite conviction. "Yes, it does scare me. I am always frightened—I might as well admit it—until I understand."

What kind of happiness is he referring to?" Mrs. Stringham, at this, became direct. "Oh, you know!"

"What kind of happiness is he talking about?" Mrs. Stringham asked directly. "Oh, you know!"

She had phrased it in such a way that her friend had to accept it; which, after a moment, the latter revealed she had. But, now quite preoccupied with her question, she stopped.

"By being given the chance." "For God's sake," Mrs. Stringham wailed, "make it happen! You practically have him wrapped around your finger."

Maud Lowder's eyes at this rested on her friend's. "Is that your impression of him?" "It's my impression, dearest, of you. You handle every one."

Translation

Maud Lowder's gaze now met her friend's. "Is that how you see him?" "That's how I see you, darling. You manipulate everyone."

Mrs. Lowder's eyes still rested, and Susan Shepherd now felt, for a wonder, not less sincere by seeing that she pleased her. But there was a great limitation. "I don't handle Kate."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder's eyes remained fixed, and Susan Shepherd, for once, was strangely comforted by the knowledge that she'd pleased her. Still, a significant boundary existed. "I don't control Kate."

It suggested something that her visitor hadn't yet had from her—something the sense of which made Mrs. Stringham gasp. "Do you mean Kate cares for him?" That fact the lady of Lancaster Gate had up to this moment, as we know, enshrouded, and her friend's quick question had produced a change in her face.

Translation

It hinted at something her guest hadn't yet obtained from her—something the implication of which made Mrs. Stringham gasp. "Do you mean Kate cares for him?" That fact, the lady of Lancaster Gate had, until this moment, concealed, and her friend's pointed question had caused a shift in her expression.

She blinked—then looked at the question hard; after which, whether she had inadvertently betrayed herself or had only reached a decision and then been affected by the quality of Mrs. Stringham's surprise, she accepted all results. What took place in her for Susan Shepherd was not simply that she made the best of them, but that she suddenly saw more in them to her purpose than she could have imagined. A certain impatience in fact marked in her this transition: she had been keeping back, very hard, an important truth, and wouldn't have liked to hear that she hadn't concealed it cleverly.

Translation

She blinked, scrutinizing the question. Then, whether she’d inadvertently given herself away or simply reached a conclusion and been taken aback by Mrs. Stringham’s surprise, she embraced the consequences. What occurred within her for Susan Shepherd wasn't just making the best of it, but suddenly perceiving more utility in the situation than she could have conceived. A certain impatience, in fact, characterized this transition: she had been withholding a crucial truth, and wouldn't have welcomed hearing that she hadn’t hidden it skillfully.

Susie nevertheless felt herself pass as not a little of a fool with her for not having thought of it. What Susie indeed, however, most thought of at present, in the quick, new light of it, was the wonder of Kate's dissimulation. She had time for that view while she waited for an answer to her cry. "Kate thinks she cares.

Translation

Susie, however, felt foolish for not having considered it. What Susie was really thinking about, in the quick, new way she saw it, was how extraordinary Kate's deception was. She had time to think that while she waited for an answer to her question. "Kate thinks she cares."

Translation

"I don't control Kate." This statement seemed to imply something her visitor didn't yet understand—a revelation that caused Mrs. Stringham to gasp. "Are you suggesting Kate has feelings for him?"

That fact, as we know, the woman of Lancaster Gate had hidden until now, and her friend's quick question changed her expression. She blinked, then carefully considered the question. After that, whether she had accidentally revealed her secret or had only made a decision and then been affected by Mrs. Stringham's surprise, she accepted the consequences.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham's implication was a secret the woman from Lancaster Gate had kept hidden. Her friend's sudden inquiry shifted her features. She blinked, studying the question. Then, whether her secret had slipped out or she had simply made a choice and been surprised by Mrs. Stringham's reaction, she accepted the implications.

What happened within her for Susan Shepherd wasn't just that she made the best of things, but that she suddenly saw more within them that served her purpose than she could have imagined. In fact, a certain impatience marked her in this transition: she had been holding back, with great effort, an important truth, and wouldn't have liked to hear that she hadn't concealed it well. Susie nevertheless felt she appeared rather foolish for not having considered it. What Susie indeed, however, most considered at the moment, in the new light of it, was how amazing Kate's deception was.

Translation

For Susan Shepherd, what occurred wasn't merely a matter of making the best of a bad situation, but a sudden discovery of previously unimagined possibilities within it, possibilities that suited her needs. An element of impatience even colored her as she went through this transformation. She had been, with great effort, withholding a crucial truth, and she wouldn't have welcomed the news that she'd failed to conceal it effectively. Yet Susie also felt somewhat foolish for not having considered it before. What Susie truly considered most at that moment, bathed as she was in this new understanding, was how astonishing Kate's deception had been.

She had time for that thought while waiting for an answer to her question. "Kate believes she's interested. But she's wrong. And no one knows it." These clear and definite statements were Mrs.

Shepherd's alone. It wasn't the sort of opinion she would have voiced publicly, or even to the sympathetic ears of a friend. "Deny she cares for him?" "Deny she even thinks she does. Completely and utterly. Deny you've even heard about it."

Translation

"Well," Mrs. Stringham said after a moment, "Milly won't." Mrs. Lowder seemed puzzled.

"Are you sure?" "Yes, the more I think of it. And luckily for me. I lie badly."

Translation

"Are you certain?" "Absolutely, the more I consider it. Which is fortunate for me. I'm a terrible liar."

"I lie well, thank God," Mrs. Lowder almost snorted, "when, as sometimes will happen, there's nothing else so good. One must always do the best. But without lies then," she went on, "perhaps we can work it out." Translation

"I, on the other hand, am quite good at it, thank God," Mrs. Lowder almost snorted, "when, as sometimes happens, nothing else will do. One must always do what's best. But without lies, then," she continued, "perhaps we can make this work." Her interest perked up; her friend saw her, within a few moments, more engaged and excited—presently felt within her what had changed things.

Mrs. Stringham, it was true, descried this at the time but dimly; she only made out at first that Maud had found a reason for helping her. The reason was that, strangely, she might help Maud too, for which she now desired to profess herself ready even to lying. What really perhaps most came out for her was that her hostess was a little disappointed at her doubt of the social solidity of this appliance; and that in turn was to become a steadier light.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham, it was true, had a vague sense of this at the time. Initially, she only understood that Maud had found a reason to help her. That reason, strangely, was that she might also be able to help Maud. To do so, she was now willing to lie. What was most apparent to her was that her hostess was somewhat disappointed by her skepticism regarding the social acceptability of this arrangement. That, in turn, began to clarify things.

The truth about Kate's delusion, as her aunt presented it, the delusion about the state of her affections, which might be removed—this was apparently the ground on which they now might more intimately meet. Translation

Densher's?—success in which indeed might entail other successes. Before that job, unfortunately, her heart had already failed. Translation

Densher's presence? Success in that, actually, might lead to other kinds of success. But before that could happen, unfortunately, her heart gave out. All of this was confused within her—a cloud of questions from which Maud Manningham's large, seated figure began to take shape. It became increasingly distinct, and assumed the role of an oracle for this advisory relationship.

From the oracle the sound did come—or at any rate the sense did, a sense all accordant with the insufflation she had just seen working. "Yes," the sense was, "I'll help you for Milly, because if that comes off I shall be helped, by its doing so, for Kate"—a view into which Mrs. Stringham could now sufficiently enter. Translation

The oracle's pronouncements arrived—or at least the gist of them did, an impression perfectly aligned with the maneuvering she'd just observed. Suddenly, strangely enough, she found herself completely willing to act in a way that would disadvantage Kate, or at least in a way that would benefit Kate as Mrs.

Lowder with a noble anxiety measured it. She found herself in short not caring what became of Kate—only convinced at bottom of the predominance of Kate's star. Kate wasn't in danger, Kate wasn't pathetic; Kate Croy, whatever happened, would take care of Kate Croy. She saw moreover by this time that her friend was travelling even beyond her own speed.

Translation

Lowder deemed noble, measured by anxiety. In short, she found herself not caring what became of Kate, only convinced, at the bottom of it all, of Kate's ascendance. Kate wasn't in danger, Kate wasn't pathetic. Kate Croy, whatever happened, would manage Kate Croy. Moreover, she saw by this time that her friend was progressing faster than she herself.

Mrs. Lowder had already, in mind, drafted a rough plan of action, a plan vividly enough thrown off as she said: "You must stay on a few days, and you must immediately, both of you, meet him at dinner." Mrs. Stringham, in truth, didn't fully grasp it at the time. She only understood, initially, that Maud had found a reason to help her. That reason was, oddly, that she might also help Maud, and for this, she now offered to be willing to lie. What truly struck her, maybe, was that her hostess was slightly disappointed by her uncertainty about the social efficacy of this tactic; and that, in turn, would become a clearer comprehension. The truth about Kate's delusion, as her aunt presented it, the delusion regarding her feelings, which could be rectified—this, apparently, was the foundation of their newfound closeness.

Mrs. Stringham saw herself recruited to remove Kate's delusion—by methods, however, that she still couldn't quite grasp. Or was it perhaps only to remove Mr. Densher's?—success in which, indeed, might lead to other successes.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham saw herself enlisted to dispel Kate's delusion—though she still didn't fully understand the means. Or, perhaps, was it simply to dispel Mr. Densher's? Success in that, she realized, could very well pave the way for other victories.

But before that, unfortunately, her resolve had already weakened. She felt that she instinctively believed what Milly believed, which would make working for Milly such a difficult uphill struggle. All of this was vaguely present within her—a collection of questions from which Maud Manningham's large, seated presence emerged, however, as a more and more distinct figure, taking on, in the context of their consultation, something of the form of an oracle. From the oracle came the sound—or at least the meaning, a meaning perfectly aligned with the suggestion she had just seen working.

Translation

But before that, her determination had unfortunately already started to waver. She felt a natural inclination to believe what Milly believed, which would make advocating for Milly such a challenging endeavor. All of this was vaguely present in her thoughts—a collection of uncertainties from which Maud Manningham’s imposing, seated form emerged. It took on, in the context of their discussion, a more and more distinct shape, becoming something akin to an oracle. From the oracle came the sound—or at least the meaning, a meaning perfectly aligned with the suggestion she had just witnessed in action.

"Yes," the meaning was, "I'll help you for Milly, because if that works out, I will be helped, in its success, for Kate"—a perspective Mrs. Stringham could now understand. She found herself suddenly, surprisingly, completely willing to act in a way that would harm Kate, or at least in a way that would benefit Kate as Mrs. Lowder, with a noble concern, understood it.

Translation

"Yes," the implied message ran, "I will assist you on Milly's behalf because, if this succeeds, I will also benefit, for Kate's sake"—a viewpoint Mrs. Stringham now grasped. She realized, with a sudden and unsettling clarity, that she was entirely prepared to behave in a manner detrimental to Kate, or at least in a way that, according to Mrs. Lowder's elevated understanding, would ultimately serve Kate's interests.

In short, she found herself not caring what happened to Kate—only convinced, deep down, of Kate's ultimate triumph. Kate wasn't in danger, Kate wasn't a victim; Kate Croy, whatever happened, would take care of Kate Croy. She also saw by this point that her friend was moving even faster than she was. Mrs.

Translation

Stringham saw, in essence, that she didn't give a damn about Kate's immediate circumstances, only that Kate would prevail in the end. Kate was not imperiled, not vulnerable; Kate Croy would handle Kate Croy, no matter what. She perceived, as well, that her friend was progressing even more rapidly than she. Mrs.

Lowder had already, in her mind, formulated a general plan of action, a plan vividly expressed as she said, "You must stay a few days, and you must both immediately meet him at dinner." In addition to which Maud claimed the credit for having, by an instinct of compassion, of prophetic insight, done a great deal, two nights before, to prepare the ground. "The poor girl, when I was with her while you were getting your shawl, completely revealed herself to me." "Oh I remember how you afterwards put it to me. Though it was nothing more," Susie did herself the justice to observe, "than what I too had quite felt."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder had already, in her mind, devised a basic strategy. This plan was clearly evident when she said, "You must stay for a few days, and you must both dine with him right away." Beyond that, Maud took credit for having, through an instinctive compassion and prophetic intuition, already accomplished a great deal two nights earlier, laying the groundwork. "The poor girl, while I was with her while you were getting your shawl, completely opened up to me." "Oh, I remember how you put it to me afterward. Although," Susie conceded fairly, "it was nothing more than what I myself had already felt."

But Mrs. Lowder fronted her so on this that she wondered what she had said. "I suppose I ought to be edified at what you can so beautifully give up." "Give up?" Mrs.

Translation

Lowder exclaimed. "I give up nothing. That's precisely what I was to speak to you about." And she paused. "My dear, I do rather think that one should know what one wants." "And you're sure," Susie asked, "that I don't know?" "I'm sure that you're in danger of not knowing. One is so apt to be taken by surprise."

Stringham echoed. "Why, I give up nothing—I cling." Her hostess showed impatience, turning again with some stiffness to her great brass-bound cylinder-desk and giving a push to an object or two disposed there. "I give up then.

Translation

Stringham repeated. "Why, I give up nothing—I cling." Her hostess showed impatience, turning again with some stiffness toward her large brass-bound cylinder-desk and giving a push to one or two objects arranged there. "I give up, then."

You know how little such a person as Mr. Densher was to be my idea for her. You know what I've been thinking perfectly possible." "I remember how you explained it to me later.

Translation

You know how little I envisioned someone like Mr. Densher being her type. You know what I believed was entirely possible." "I recall you explaining that to me later."

Even though it was nothing more," Susie was fair enough to admit, "than what I had felt myself." But Mrs. Lowder reacted so strongly to this that Susie wondered what she had said wrong. "I suppose I should be impressed by your ability to let things go so gracefully."

Translation

"Even though it was nothing more," Susie admitted, being fair, "than what I'd felt myself." But Mrs. Lowder reacted so strongly to this that Susie wondered what she'd said wrong. "I suppose I should be impressed by your ability to let things go so gracefully."

"Let go?" Mrs. Stringham repeated. "Why, I'm not letting go of anything—I'm holding on." Her hostess seemed impatient, turning back to her large, brass-bound desk with a touch of annoyance and rearranging a few things on it.

Translation

"Let go?" Mrs. Stringham repeated. "Why, I'm not letting go of anything—I'm holding on." Her hostess seemed impatient, turning back to her large, brass-bound desk with a touch of annoyance and rearranging a few things on it.

"Then I am the one letting go. You know how little someone like Mr. Densher fit my vision for her. You know what I'd hoped was entirely possible."

Translation

"Then I'm the one who's giving up. You know how badly someone like Mr. Densher matched my expectations for her. You know what I'd hoped could absolutely happen."

"Oh you've been great"—Susie was perfectly fair. "A duke, a duchess, a princess, a palace: you've made me believe in them too. But where we break down is that she doesn't believe in them. Luckily for her—as it seems to be turning out—she doesn't want them.

Translation

"Oh, you've been great"—Susie was perfectly fair. "A duke, a duchess, a princess, a palace: you've made me believe in them too. But where we break down is that she doesn't believe in them. Luckily for her—as it seems to be turning out—she doesn't want them."

So what's one to do? I assure you I've had many dreams. But I've only one dream now." Mrs.

So what is one to do? I assure you, I've had many dreams. But I've only one dream now. Mrs.

Stringham's tone in these last words gave so fully her meaning that Mrs. Lowder could but show herself as taking it in. They sat a moment longer confronted on it. "Her having what she does want?"

Translation

Stringham's inflection in those final words expressed her meaning so completely that Mrs. Lowder could only acknowledge it. They sat a moment longer, contemplating it. "Her getting what she wants?"

"If it will do anything for her." Mrs. Lowder seemed to think what it might do; but she spoke for the instant of something else. "It does provoke me a bit, you know—for of course I'm a brute.

Translation

Translation

Translation

"She interferes with me as it is—not that it matters now. But I saw Kate and her—really as soon as you came to me—set up side by side. Translation

Lowder, a directness she hoped would cover her hesitation. "And he's certainly very clever."

But her friend continued. "One lives for other people. You do that. If I were living for myself, I wouldn't mind him at all."

Translation

Susie's friend kept talking. "You dedicate your life to others. You always have. If I only cared about myself, I wouldn't have any issue with him."

But Mrs. Stringham was sturdier. "Ah if I find him charming it's however I'm living." Well, it broke Mrs.

Translation

Stringham's heart, though. She was already half-bent, with an awful headache, as she declared, "He must find someone else to be charming."

Lowder down. She hung fire but an instant, giving herself away with a laugh. "Of course he's all right in himself." "That's all I contend," Susie said with more reserve; and the note in question—what Merton Densher was "in himself"—closed practically, with some inconsequence, this first of their councils.

Translation

Lowder relented. She hesitated only for a moment, betraying herself with a laugh. "Of course he's all right in himself." "That's all I'm saying," Susie responded with more restraint; and the subject at hand—what Merton Densher was "in himself"—effectively concluded their first discussion with a certain degree of triviality.

Chapter 8

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
While alone in a Venetian palace arranged for her by her employee, Eugenio, a woman named Milly walks through the rooms. Eugenio has taken her companions away for the morning at her request, granting her solitude. Milly resolves to ask Eugenio if he can arrange for her to stay in the palace permanently. When she returns to the main saloon, she finds Lord Mark waiting for her. His arrival in Venice was unexpected. Lord Mark explains that he came on an impulse from Carlsbad after Mrs. Lowder and Kate Croy wrote to him about her whereabouts. He expresses no interest in joining the others, and Milly realizes he came just to see her. She offers to show him around the palace, and he accepts.

It had at least made the difference for them, they could feel, of an informed state in respect to the great doctor, whom they were now to take as watching, waiting, studying, or at any rate as proposing to himself some such process before he should make up his mind. Mrs. Stringham understood him as considering the matter meanwhile in a spirit that, on this same occasion, at Lancaster Gate, she had come back to a rough notation of before retiring. She followed the course of his reckoning.

Translation

It had, at the very least, changed things for them. They could sense a shift toward a more informed position regarding the esteemed doctor, whom they now pictured as observing, anticipating, and analyzing, or, at the very least, as being in the midst of that process before reaching a decision. Mrs. Stringham interpreted his actions as a careful contemplation, something she'd returned to noting, in a rather crude way, before going to sleep at Lancaster Gate on that same day. She was following his line of thinking.

If what they had talked of could happen—if Milly, that is, could have her thoughts taken off herself—it wouldn't do any harm and might conceivably do much good. If it couldn't happen—if, anxiously, though tactfully working, they themselves, conjoined, could do nothing to contribute to it—they would be in no worse a box than before. Only in this latter case the girl would have had her free range for the summer, for the autumn; she would have done her best in the sense enjoined on her, and, coming back at the end to her eminent man, would—besides having more to show him—find him more ready to go on with her. It was visible further to Susan Shepherd—as well as being ground for a second report to her old friend—that Milly did her part for a working view of the general case, inasmuch as she mentioned frankly and promptly that she meant to go and say good-bye to Sir Luke Strett and thank him.

Translation

If what they’d discussed could come to pass—if Milly, that is, could stop dwelling on herself—it couldn’t hurt, and might do a world of good. If it couldn’t happen—if, anxiously, though carefully, they themselves, working together, could do nothing to bring it about—they’d be in no worse a state than before. Only, in that latter case, the girl would have had her freedom for the summer, for the autumn; she would have done her best in the way that had been asked of her, and, returning at the end to her esteemed man, would—besides having more to show him—find him more willing to continue. It was also apparent to Susan Shepherd—and cause for another report to her old friend—that Milly was doing her part in service of a working understanding of the larger situation, given that she stated plainly and immediately that she intended to visit Sir Luke Strett and offer her thanks.

She even specified what she was to thank him for, his having been so easy about her behaviour. Mrs. Stringham was more resilient. "If I find him appealing, it's because that's how I live."

Translation

She went so far as to say exactly what she would thank him for: his tolerance of her conduct. Mrs. Stringham was more pragmatic. "If I find him attractive, it's because that's how I am."

That remark broke Mrs. Lowder. She hesitated briefly, then gave herself away with a laugh. "Of course, he's perfectly fine as a person."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder couldn't help but react to that. She paused for a moment, then betrayed herself with a laugh. "Of course, he's perfectly fine as a person."

"That's all I'm saying," Susie replied, more cautiously; and the discussion about Merton Densher's character concluded with some lack of focus, ending this first meeting. II At least, they felt they now understood the situation better. They saw the great doctor as someone observing, waiting, studying, or at least contemplating such a process before making his final decision.

Translation

"That's my point," Susie said, more carefully. The conversation about Merton Densher's personality then drifted off, losing its way, and that initial meeting concluded. They felt, at any rate, that they grasped the situation a bit better. They saw the great doctor as a figure of observation, of patience, of study—or at least as someone considering such a process before making his ultimate choice.

Mrs. Stringham understood him as considering the matter, a perspective she noted roughly before going to bed, in that very conversation at Lancaster Gate. She followed his reasoning. If what they had discussed could come to pass – if Milly, that is, could stop dwelling on her problems – it wouldn't hurt and might potentially help.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham understood that he was giving the matter thought. She had made a mental note of this perspective during their conversation at Lancaster Gate, just before she went to bed. She grasped his line of thinking. If what they had discussed were to happen—if Milly could only stop fixating on her problems—it wouldn't cause any harm and might even be beneficial.

If it couldn't happen – if they, working together anxiously but tactfully, couldn't contribute to it – they'd be no worse off than before. Only, in that latter scenario, the girl would have had her freedom for the summer and the autumn. She would have done her best in the way she was told, and, returning to her famous doctor at the end, would—besides having more to share with him—find him more eager to continue treating her. It was also apparent to Susan Shepherd – and something she planned to report to her old friend—that Milly was playing her part in the plan, because she said promptly and candidly that she intended to visit Sir Luke Strett and thank him.

Translation

If it didn't come to pass—if they, working together anxiously but with care, couldn't make it happen—they wouldn't be any worse off than they were. Only, in that case, the girl would have had her freedom for the summer and the fall. She would have done what she was told, and, when she went back to her well-known doctor, would—besides having more to say—find him more willing to keep treating her. It was also clear to Susan Shepherd—and something she intended to tell her old friend—that Milly was playing her part in the plan, because she immediately and honestly said that she was going to visit Sir Luke Strett and thank him.

She even specified what she was thanking him for: his acceptance of her behavior. "You see I didn't know that—for the liberty I took—I shouldn't afterwards get a stiff note from him." So much Milly had said to her, and it had made her a trifle rash. "Oh you'll never get a stiff note from him in your life."

Translation

She even explained what she was thanking him for: his tolerance of her actions. "You see, I didn't know if—for the liberty I took—I'd get a sharp note from him later." Milly had told her as much, and it made her a little reckless. "Oh, you'll never get a sharp note from him in your life."

She felt her rashness, the next moment, at her young friend's question. "Why not, as well as any one else who has played him a trick?" "Well, because he doesn't regard it as a trick. He could understand your action.

Translation

Her audacity struck her immediately, brought on by her young friend's question. "Why not? Why shouldn't he give me a hard time like anyone else who's tried to fool him?" "Well, because he doesn't see it as a trick. He could understand what you did."

It's all right, you see." "Yes—I do see. It is all right. He's easier with me than with any one else, because that's the way to let me down.

Translation

"It's alright, you see." "Yes—I do see. It is all right. He's easier with me than with anyone else, because that's the way to let me down."

He's only making believe, and I'm not worth hauling up." You know, I didn't realize that—for the freedom I took—I'd get a formal letter from him later. Milly had told her that, and it made her a bit reckless. "Oh, you'll never get a formal letter from him, ever."

Translation

"He's just pretending, and I'm not worth the effort of reeling in." You know, I hadn't realized that the liberties I took would lead to a formal letter from him later. Milly had told her that, and it made her a bit reckless. "Oh, you'll never get a formal letter from him, ever."

She recognized her recklessness, immediately, when her young friend asked, "Why not, since others have played him wrong?" "Well, because he doesn't see it as a trick. He could understand what you did. It's fine, you see."

Translation

Her recklessness was apparent the instant her young friend asked, "Why wouldn't he write a formal letter if others have wronged him?" "Because he doesn't think you were trying to deceive him. He'd understand what you did. It's okay, you see."

"Yes—I do see. It is fine. He's more relaxed with me than with anyone else, because that's the way to let me off the hook. He's only pretending, and I'm not worth the effort of confronting."

Translation

"Yes, I understand now. It's alright. He's more at ease with me than with anyone else, and that's how he lets me off the hook. He's just putting on an act, and I'm not worth the trouble of a real confrontation."

Rueful at having provoked again this ominous flare, poor Susie grasped at her only advantage. "Do you really accuse a man like Sir Luke Strett of trifling with you?" She couldn't blind herself to the look her companion gave her—a strange half-amused perception of what she made of it. "Well, so far as it's trifling with me to pity me so much."

Translation

Feeling regret for having once again stirred up this threatening anger, poor Susie clung to her only strength. "Do you truly accuse a man like Sir Luke Strett of toying with you?" She couldn't ignore the look her companion gave her—a peculiar, half-amused understanding of her perspective. "Well, if it's toying with me to feel so much pity for me, then yes."

"He doesn't pity you," Susie earnestly reasoned. "He just—the same as any one else—likes you." "He has no business then to like me. He's not the same as any one else."

Translation

"He doesn't pity you," Susie insisted. "He just—the same as anyone—is attracted to you."

"He shouldn't be attracted to me. He isn't

like anyone else."

"Why not, if he wants to work for you?" Milly gave her another look, but this time a wonderful smile. "Ah there you are!" Mrs. Stringham coloured, for there indeed she was again.

Translation

"Why not, if he wants to work for you?" Milly gave her another look, but this time a wonderful smile. "Ah, there you are!" Mrs. Stringham blushed, for there she indeed was again.

But Milly let her off. "Work for me, all the same—work for me! It's of course what I want." Then as usual she embraced her friend. "I'm not going to be as nasty as this to him."

Translation

But Milly let her off. "Work for me, all the same—work for me! That's exactly what I want." Then, as usual, she embraced her friend. "I'm not going to be as nasty as this to him."

Feeling regret at having caused another outburst, poor Susie clung to her only advantage. "Do you really think Sir Luke Strett is toying with you?" She couldn't ignore the look her companion gave her—a strange, slightly amused assessment of her interpretation. "Well, if it's considered toying to feel so much pity for me, then yes."

Translation

Susie, still regretting that she'd upset her, held tight to the only card she had left to play. "Do you truly believe Sir Luke Strett is playing games with you?" She couldn't help but notice the look her friend gave her, an odd, almost amused assessment of her perspective. "Well, if you consider it playing games to feel so much pity for me, then yes."

"He doesn't pity you," Susie insisted earnestly. "He just—like anyone else—likes you." "He shouldn't like me. He's not like anyone else."

Translation

"He doesn't pity you," Susie insisted earnestly. "He just—like anyone else—likes you." "He shouldn't like me. He's not like anyone else."

"Why not, if he wants to help you?" Milly looked at her again, but this time with a beautiful smile. "Oh, there you are!" Mrs. Stringham blushed, because indeed, she had revealed herself once more.

Translation

"Why shouldn't he, if he wants to help you?" Milly looked at her again, but this time with a beautiful smile. "Oh, there you are!" Mrs. Stringham blushed, because indeed, she had revealed herself once more.

But Milly let it go. "Help me anyway—help me! That's what I want, of course." Then, as usual, she hugged her friend. "I won't be this mean to him."

Translation

Milly didn't press the issue. "Just help me—please, help me! That's all I ask, really." As she always did, she embraced her friend. "I won't be so awful to him."

"I'm sure I hope not!"—and Mrs. Stringham laughed for the kiss. "I've no doubt, however, he'd take it from you! It's you, my dear, who are not the same as any one else."

Translation

"I certainly hope not!" Mrs. Stringham said, laughing as she was kissed. "Though I have no doubt he'd put up with it from you! It's you, my dear, who are unlike anyone else."

Milly's assent to which, after an instant, gave her the last word. "No, so that people can take anything from me." And what Mrs. Stringham did indeed resignedly take after this was the absence on her part of any account of the visit then paid. It was the beginning in fact between them of an odd independence—an independence positively of action and custom—on the subject of Milly's future.

Translation

Milly's agreement, which came after a moment, gave her the final say. "No, so people can take anything from me." What Mrs. Stringham resignedly accepted after this was the absence of any details about the visit. It was, in fact, the start of an odd independence between them—an independence in their actions and customs—regarding Milly's future.

They went their separate ways with the girl's intense assent; this being really nothing but what she had so wonderfully put in her plea for after Mrs. Stringham's first encounter with Sir Luke. She fairly favoured the idea that Susie had or was to have other encounters—private pointed personal; she favoured every idea, but most of all the idea that she herself was to go on as if nothing were the matter. Since she was to be worked for that would be her way; and though her companions learned from herself nothing of it this was in the event her way with her medical adviser.

Translation

They parted, the girl's enthusiastic agreement sealed. This was, in essence, the very thing she'd so eloquently argued for after Mrs. Stringham's initial meeting with Sir Luke. She quite approved of the notion that Susie was, or would be, having other encounters—private, focused, and personal. She approved of every notion, but most of all the notion that she herself would continue as if nothing were amiss. Since she was to be looked after, that would be her approach; and though her companions learned nothing from her of it, this, as it turned out, was her approach with her doctor.

She put her visit to him on the simplest ground; she had come just to tell him how touched she had been by his good nature. That required little explaining, for, as Mrs. Stringham had said, he quite understood he could but reply that it was all right. "I certainly hope not!" Mrs.

Translation

She framed her visit as the simplest gesture; she'd come only to tell him how touched she was by his kindness. That didn't require much explaining, because, as Mrs. Stringham had said, he understood perfectly and could only reply that it was fine. "I certainly hope not!" Mrs.

Stringham said, laughing. "I have no doubt, however, that he would accept it from you! You, my dear, are not like anyone else." Milly agreed with this, after a moment, and had the last word.

Translation

"I certainly hope not!" Mrs. Stringham said, laughing. "I have no doubt, however, that he would accept it from you! You, my dear, are not like anyone else." Milly agreed with this, after a moment, and had the last word.

Stringham’s first encounter with Sir Luke. Milly actually liked the notion that Susie would have, or was going to have, additional meetings—private, particular, personal ones. Translation

Although her friends heard nothing from her directly about this, it was, in fact, her approach with her doctor. She explained her visit to him in the simplest terms: she had come solely to express how moved she was by his kindness. This didn't require much explanation because, as Mrs. Stringham had said, he completely understood, and his only response was that it was all fine.

"I had a charming quarter of an hour with that clever lady. You've got good friends." "So each one of them thinks of all the others. But so I also think," Milly went on, "of all of them together.

Translation

"I spent a lovely fifteen minutes with that intelligent woman. You have good friends." "Yes, they all think of each other. But I also think," Milly continued, "of all of them together."

You're excellent for each other. And it's in that way, I dare say, that you're best for me." There came to her on this occasion one of the strangest of her impressions, which was at the same time one of the finest of her alarms—the glimmer of a vision that if she should go, as it were, too far, she might perhaps deprive their relation of facility if not of value. Going too far was failing to try at least to remain simple.

Translation

You complement each other perfectly. And it's in that way, I'd venture to say, that you are the best thing for me. On this occasion, one of her strangest impressions came to her, which was also one of her most delicate alarms: the dawning of an understanding that if she were to go, so to speak, too far, she might perhaps rob their relationship of its ease, if not its worth. Going too far meant failing to attempt to stay uncomplicated.

He would be quite ready to hate her if she did, by heading him off at every point, embarrass his exercise of a kindness that, no doubt, rather constituted for him a high method. Susie wouldn't hate her, since Susie positively wanted to suffer for her; Susie had a noble idea that she might somehow so do her good. Such, however, was not the way in which the greatest of London doctors was to be expected to wish to do it. He wouldn't have time even should he wish; whereby, in a word, Milly felt herself intimately warned.

Translation

He was poised to despise her if, by constantly correcting him, she undermined the exercise of his particular brand of kindness, which was undoubtedly a lofty practice for him. Susie wouldn't despise her, as Susie was eager to endure hardship for her sake, harboring the idealistic notion that she could somehow improve her. However, this was not how the foremost London doctor could be expected to behave. He wouldn't have time, even if he desired to; and with that, Milly was deeply alerted.

Face to face there with her smooth strong director, she enjoyed at a given moment quite such another lift of feeling as she had known in her crucial talk with Susie. It came round to the same thing; him too she would help to help her if that could possibly be; but if it couldn't possibly be she would assist also to make this right. I had a lovely fifteen minutes with that intelligent woman. You have good friends."

Translation

Facing her, there, with her calm, capable director, she experienced, in that moment, a feeling similar to the one she'd felt during her critical conversation with Susie. It came down to the same thing; she would help him, too, help her, if that were possible. But if it weren't, she would also help to make that right. I had a lovely fifteen minutes with that intelligent woman. You have good friends.

"Everyone thinks about the others," Milly continued. "But I also think about all of you together. You're great for each other. And it's in that way, I suppose, that you're best for me."

Translation

"Everyone considers everyone else," Milly continued. "But I also think about all of you as a group. You're wonderful together. And I guess that's how you're best for me."

On this occasion, she experienced one of her strangest, yet most profound, anxieties – the fleeting idea that if she pushed things too far, she might damage their relationship, maybe even diminish its worth. Going too far meant not trying to stay uncomplicated. He would likely come to dislike her if she hindered him, if she interfered with his way of showing kindness, which was undoubtedly important to him. Susie wouldn't hate her because Susie actually wanted to suffer for her; Susie had this noble idea that she could somehow benefit her.

Translation

This time, she felt a strange, deeply unsettling fear—the sudden thought that if she overstepped, she could hurt their relationship, maybe even cheapen it. To go too far meant not staying easy to be around. He’d probably grow to resent her if she got in his way, if she messed with how he showed kindness, which was obviously important to him. Susie wouldn't hate her because Susie actually wanted to sacrifice for her; Susie had this idealistic notion that she could help her through it somehow.

That, however, was not the way the greatest London doctor would want to help. He wouldn't have the time even if he wanted to; in other words, Milly felt an intimate warning. Confronting her capable and composed doctor, she experienced a similar surge of emotion to what she had felt during her important conversation with Susie. It came down to the same thing; she would help him help her if it was possible; but if it wasn't, she would help make that acceptable too.

Translation

However, that wasn't the kind of help the best doctor in London would offer. He wouldn’t have the opportunity, even if he wanted to. Milly sensed an unspoken caution. Facing her competent, collected doctor, she felt the same wave of emotion she’d experienced in that crucial conversation with Susie. It boiled down to the same choice: she would help him help her, if she could. If she couldn’t, she would help make that situation bearable, too.

It wouldn't have taken many minutes more, on the basis in question, almost to reverse for her their characters of patient and physician. What was he in fact but patient, what was she but physician, from the moment she embraced once for all the necessity, adopted once for all the policy, of saving him alarms about her subtlety? She would leave the subtlety to him: he would enjoy his use of it, and she herself, no doubt, would in time enjoy his enjoyment. She went so far as to imagine that the inward success of these reflexions flushed her for the minute, to his eyes, with a certain bloom, a comparative appearance of health; and what verily next occurred was that he gave colour to the presumption.

Translation

On this matter, it would have taken only a few more minutes to nearly switch their roles from patient and doctor. In fact, wasn't he the patient and wasn't she the doctor, from the moment she accepted the need, embraced the policy, of sparing him concerns about her cleverness? She would leave the cleverness to him. He would enjoy using it, and she, no doubt, would eventually enjoy his enjoyment. She went so far as to imagine that the internal success of these thoughts momentarily gave her a certain glow, a comparative appearance of health in his eyes. And what truly happened next was that he confirmed this assumption.

"Every little helps, no doubt!"—he noticed good-humouredly her harmless sally. "But, help or no help, you're looking, you know, remarkably well." In a matter of moments, the roles of patient and doctor could have easily switched, with her becoming the physician and him the patient. From the moment she accepted the need to shield him from the potential worry of her cleverness, she took on this role.

Translation

"Every little bit helps, no doubt!" he said good-naturedly, noticing her harmless joke. "But, help or no help, you're looking, you know, remarkably well." In a matter of moments, the roles of patient and doctor could have easily switched, with her becoming the physician and him the patient. From the moment she accepted the need to shield him from the potential worry of her cleverness, she took on this role.

She would let him have the intellectual freedom, allowing him to enjoy it. In time, she assumed she would enjoy his enjoyment. She even imagined that the satisfaction of these thoughts briefly gave her a healthy glow, a look of vitality. He then confirmed her suspicion.

Translation

She decided to cede him the intellectual space, letting him have his pleasure. Eventually, she supposed she would derive pleasure from his. She even felt a brief flush of health, a vibrancy, from the thought of it. He then proved her right.

"Every little bit helps, I suppose!" he commented on her harmless joke. "But, regardless, you actually look remarkably good." "Oh I thought I was," she answered; and it was as if already she saw his line. Only she wondered what he would have guessed.

Translation

"Every little bit helps, I suppose!" he commented on her harmless joke. "But, regardless, you actually look remarkably good." "Oh I thought I was," she answered; and it was as if she already saw his play. Only she wondered what he would have guessed.

If he had guessed anything at all it would be rather remarkable of him. As for what there was to guess, he couldn't—if this was present to him—have arrived at it save by his own acuteness. That acuteness was therefore immense; and if it supplied the subtlety she thought of leaving him to, his portion would be none so bad. Neither, for that matter, would hers be—which she was even actually enjoying.

Translation

If he had guessed anything at all, it would have been quite remarkable. As for what there was to guess, he couldn't have arrived at it, even if it was present to him, except through his own intelligence. Therefore, his intelligence was immense. And if it provided the subtlety she planned on leaving him with, his portion wouldn't be so bad. Neither, for that matter, would hers be—which she was, in fact, even enjoying.

She wondered if really then there mightn't be something for her. She hadn't been sure in coming to him that she was "better," and he hadn't used, he would be awfully careful not to use, that compromising term about her; in spite of all of which she would have been ready to say, for the amiable sympathy of it, "Yes, I must be," for he had this unaided sense of something that had happened to her. It was a sense unaided, because who could have told him of anything? Susie, she was certain, hadn't yet seen him again, and there were things it was impossible she could have told him the first time.

Translation

She wondered if, in reality, there might be some benefit for her. She hadn't been certain, when she came to him, that she was "improved," and he hadn't used—he would be extremely careful not to use—that dangerous term in reference to her. Despite all of this, she would have been prepared to say, for the sake of feeling agreeable and sympathetic, "Yes, I must be," because he possessed this unprompted sense of something that had occurred to her. It was a sense unprompted, since who could have informed him of anything? She was certain that Susie hadn't yet seen him again, and there were things that it was impossible she could have told him the first time.

Since such was his penetration, therefore, why shouldn't she gracefully, in recognition of it, accept the new circumstance, the one he was clearly wanting to congratulate her on, as a sufficient cause? If one nursed a cause tenderly enough it might produce an effect; and this, to begin with, would be a way of nursing. "You gave me the other day," she went on, "plenty to think over, and I've been doing that—thinking it over—quite as you'll have probably wished me. I think I must be pretty easy to treat," she smiled, "since you've already done me so much good."

Translation

Given his perceptiveness, why shouldn't she gracefully acknowledge it and accept the new situation? He clearly wanted to congratulate her, so this should be enough. If one cherished a cause long enough, it might produce an effect; and this, to begin with, would be a way to cherish it. "The other day," she continued, "you gave me plenty to think about, and I've been doing that—thinking it over—just as you probably wanted me to. I must be easy to manage," she smiled, "since you've already done me so much good."

"Oh, I thought I was," she replied, immediately imagining his perspective. She simply pondered what he might have figured out. It would be quite impressive if he'd guessed anything at all. As for what was there to guess, he couldn't have understood—if he was aware of it—unless he was incredibly perceptive.

"Oh, I believed I was," she responded, instantly considering his point of view. She merely wondered what he might have deduced. It would be quite remarkable if he'd figured anything out. So, his perceptiveness was immense. If it provided the subtlety she planned to leave him with, his situation wouldn't be so bad. And, for that matter, neither would hers be—which she was actually enjoying. She wondered if something good might come of this for her.

Therefore, he was extremely perceptive. If his acuity worked in her favor, the outcome wouldn't be so detrimental for him. And, for that matter, not for her either—which she was finding quite enjoyable. She was curious if she could benefit from all of this.

She hadn't been certain, when she turned to him, that she was "better," and he wouldn't use—he'd be exceedingly careful not to use—that loaded term to describe her. I'm hoping," Sir Luke continued, "that this is only the beginning." And the next question he ventured might have been connected to his hope. "Just you and her, traveling together?"
