Translation

"I hope," Sir Luke said, "that this is just the start." The next question he asked might have had something to do with that hope. "Just the two of you, traveling together?" "No, we're traveling with two other friends; two women we've gotten to know better here than anyone, and who are ideal companions for us." He paused for a moment.

"You'll be four women together then?" "Ah," said Milly, "we're widows and orphans. But I think," she added as if to say what she saw would reassure him, "that we shall not be unattractive, as we move, to gentlemen. When you talk of 'life' I suppose you mean mainly gentlemen."

Translation

"So there will be four women traveling together?" "Well," Milly said, "we're widows and orphans. But," she added, as if to calm him, "I don't think we'll be unattractive to men as we travel. When you talk about 'life,' I imagine you're mainly referring to gentlemen."

"When I talk of 'life,'" he made answer after a moment during which he might have been appreciating her raciness—"when I talk of life I think I mean more than anything else the beautiful show of it, in its freshness, made by young persons of your age. So go on as you are. I see more and more how you are. You can't," he went so far as to say for pleasantness, "better it."

Translation

"When I talk about 'life,'" he responded after a moment, during which he seemed to be appreciating her spirit, "when I talk about life, I think I'm referring above all to the beautiful spectacle of it, in its freshness, created by young people your age. So keep going as you are. I see more and more how you are. You couldn't," he went so far as to say, trying to be agreeable, "improve on it."

He paused, considering. "So, you'll all be women together?" "Yes," Milly replied, "We're all alone in the world. But," she added, as if to offer him comfort with the image she presented, "I don't think we'll be unappealing to men as we go about.

Translation

He hesitated, thinking it over. "So, you'll all be women together, then?"

"Yes," Milly answered. "We're all on our own in this world. But," she added, as though attempting to reassure him with the picture she painted, "I don't think we'll be unattractive to men as we go along."

When you say 'life', I assume you're mostly talking about men, aren't you?" "When I say 'life'," he responded after a moment, in which he seemed to be admiring her lively spirit, "I think I mean above all else, the captivating spectacle of it, in its prime, as presented by young people like yourselves. So, just keep doing what you're doing. I understand you more and more.

Translation

"When you say 'life', I assume you're mostly talking about men, aren't you?"

"When I say 'life'," he responded after a moment, in which he seemed to be admiring her lively spirit, "I think I mean above all else, the captivating spectacle of it, in its prime, as presented by young people like yourselves. So, just keep doing what you're doing. I understand you more and more."

There's really nothing you can do to improve it," he said playfully. She took it from him with a great show of peace. "One of our companions will be Miss Croy, who came with me here first. It's in her that life is splendid; and a part of that is even that she's devoted to me.

Translation

"There's really nothing you can do to improve it," he said playfully. She accepted the sentiment with an obvious calm. "One of our group will be Miss Croy, who first accompanied me here. Life is splendid in her; and part of that is even her devotion to me."

But she's above all magnificent in herself. So that if you'd like," she freely threw out, "to see her—" "Oh I shall like to see any one who's devoted to you, for clearly it will be jolly to be 'in' it. So that if she's to be at Venice I shall see her?"

Translation

But above all, she's magnificent in her own right. "So that, if you'd like," she offered freely, "to see her—" "Oh, I'd like to see anyone devoted to you; it'll be jolly to be 'in' it. So if she's going to be in Venice, I'll see her?"

"We must arrange it—I shan't fail. She moreover has a friend who may also be there"—Milly found herself going on to this. "He's likely to come, I believe, for he always follows her." She accepted the news calmly.

Translation

"We'll make it happen, I promise. She also has a friend who might be there"—Milly realized she was saying this. "He's probably coming, I think, because he always follows her." She reacted to the information without surprise.

"One of the people coming with us will be Miss Croy, who first came here with me. She's the one who truly lives a vibrant life, and part of that is even her devotion to me. But most of all, she's amazing in her own right. So, if you'd like," she offered readily, "to meet her—"

Translation

"Miss Croy will be joining us; she's the one who first came here with me. She's the kind of person who really knows how to live, and she's even devoted to me, which is part of it. But mostly, she's wonderful on her own. So, if you'd like," she offered easily, "to meet her—"

"Oh, I'd love to meet anyone devoted to you; it would be fun to be part of that. So, if she's going to be in Venice, I'll meet her?" "We'll make it happen—I'll make sure of it. She also has a friend who might be there"—Milly found herself adding this.

Translation

"I'd be delighted to meet anyone who cares for you; it would be enjoyable to be included in that. So, if she's going to be in Venice, I'll meet her?" "We'll arrange it—I'll see to it. She also has a friend who may be there"—Milly added this, almost without realizing.

"He's likely to come, I believe, because he always follows her." Sir Luke wondered. "You mean they're lovers?" "He is," Milly smiled; "but not she.

Translation

"I think he'll probably come, because he always does whatever she does," Sir Luke mused. "You mean, they're having an affair?" "He is," Milly said with a smile, "but she isn't."

She doesn't care for him." Sir Luke took an interest. "What's the matter with him?" "Nothing but that she doesn't like him."

Translation

"She doesn't care for him." Sir Luke became interested. "What's wrong with him?" "Nothing, except she doesn't like him."

Sir Luke kept it up. "Is he all right?" "Oh he's very nice. Indeed he's remarkably so."

Translation

Sir Luke pressed on. "Is he a good person?" "Oh, he's perfectly lovely. Actually, he's exceptionally so."

"And he's to be in Venice?" "So she tells me she fears. For if he is there he'll be constantly about with her." "And she'll be constantly about with you?"

Translation

"And he's going to Venice?" "That's what she's afraid of, she says. Because if he goes, he'll be spending all his time with her." "And she'll be spending all her time with you?"

"As we're great friends—yes." "Well then," said Sir Luke, "you won't be four women alone." "Oh no; I quite recognise the chance of gentlemen. But he won't," Milly pursued in the same wondrous way, "have come, you see, for me."

Translation

"Since we're good friends—yes." "Well then," Sir Luke said, "you won't be four women alone." "Oh no; I quite understand the possibility of gentlemen. But he won't," Milly continued in the same dreamy way, "have come, you see, for me."

Sir Luke was puzzled. "Are you saying they are having an affair?" "He is," Milly said with a smile, "but not her. She's not interested in him."

Translation

Sir Luke was perplexed. "Are you implying they're involved?" "He is," Milly replied with a smile, "but not her. She isn't interested in him."

Sir Luke's curiosity was piqued. "What's wrong with him?" "Nothing, except she doesn't like him." Sir Luke pressed further.

Translation

Sir Luke's interest was now fully engaged. "What's his problem?" "Nothing, except she doesn't like him." Sir Luke persisted.

"Is he a good person?" "Oh yes, he's very nice. In fact, he's exceptionally so." "And he'll be in Venice?"

Translation

"Is he a good man?" "Oh yes, he's a very kind person. Exceptionally so, in fact." "And he'll be in Venice?"

"That's what she's afraid of. She thinks he'll be constantly pursuing her if he's there." "And she'll be spending time with you?" "Since we're good friends—yes."

Translation

"That's her worry. She believes he'll be relentlessly chasing her if he's in Venice." "And she'll be spending time with you?" "As we're close friends—yes."

"Well then," Sir Luke said, "it won't just be the two of you women alone." "Oh no; I realize there's a chance of other men. But he," Milly continued in that same odd way, "won't have come, you see, for me." "No—I see.

Translation

"Well then," Sir Luke said, "it won't just be the two of you women alone." "Oh no; I realize there's a chance of other men. But he," Milly continued in that same strange way, "won't have come, you see, for me." "No—I see.

But can't you help him?" "Can't you?" Milly after a moment quaintly asked. Then for the joke of it she explained. "I'm putting you, you see, in relation with my entourage."

Translation

"But can't you help him?" "Can't you?" Milly asked, in a strange, antiquated way, after a moment. Then, just for the fun of it, she explained. "I'm introducing you, you see, to my circle."

It might have been for the joke of it too, by this time, that her eminent friend fell in. "But if this gentleman isn't of your 'entourage '? I mean if he's of—what do you call her?—Miss Croy's. Unless indeed you also take an interest in him."

Translation

It was likely a joke by now that her important friend got involved. "But if this gentleman isn't part of your 'group?' I mean, if he belongs to—what's her name?—Miss Croy. Unless, of course, you're also interested in him."

"Oh certainly I take an interest in him!" "You think there may be then some chance for him?" "I like him," said Milly, "enough to hope so." "Then that's all right.

Translation

"Oh, absolutely, I am interested in him!" "So you think there might be a chance for him, then?" "I like him," Milly said, "enough to hope there is." "Then that's all right."

But what, pray," Sir Luke next asked, "have I to do with him?" "I understand. But can't you assist him?" Milly inquired, almost playfully, after a short pause.

Translation

"But, pray," Sir Luke next asked, "what's any of this got to do with me?" "I understand," Milly asked, after a short pause, almost playfully, "but can't you help him?"

Then, for the amusement of it, she clarified her statement. "I'm essentially connecting you with my circle of acquaintances." Perhaps it was also for the fun of it that her distinguished friend joined in. "But if this man isn't part of your 'circle'?

Translation

Milly then, as though for sport, elaborated. "I'm basically introducing you to my social set." Perhaps enjoying the game, her elegant companion added, "But if this fellow isn't actually *in* your 'set'?"

If he's connected to—what's her name?—Miss Croy. Unless, of course, you also have an interest in him." "Oh, absolutely, I do have an interest in him!" "So you believe there might be some hope for him?"

Translation

"If he's connected to—what's her name?—Miss Croy. Unless, of course, you're also interested in him." "Oh, absolutely, I am interested in him!" "So you think there might be some hope for him?"

"I'm fond of him," Milly replied, "enough to want that to be true." "Then that's settled. But, tell me," Sir Luke then asked, "what, precisely, do I have to do with him?" "Nothing," said Milly, "except that if you're to be there, so may he be.

Translation

Translation

"And also, we won't just be four dreary women." He looked at her as if she were trying his patience a bit. "You're the least 'dreary' woman I've ever, ever seen. Ever, you know?"

There's no reason why you shouldn't have a really splendid life." "So every one tells me," she promptly returned. "The conviction—strong already when I had seen you once—is strengthened in me by having seen your friend. There's no doubt about it.

Translation

"There's no reason why you shouldn't have a truly splendid life." "That's what everyone tells me," she replied immediately. "The belief—already strong when I'd met you once—is reinforced now that I've met your friend. There's no question about it."

The world's before you." "What did my friend tell you?" Milly asked. "Nothing that wouldn't have given you pleasure. We talked about you—and freely.

"The world lies before you." "What did my friend say to you?" Milly inquired. "Nothing that would displease you. We discussed you—openly."

I don't deny that. But it shows me I don't require of you the impossible." "The only thing," Milly said, "is that if you're going to be there, he might be there, too. And also, that we won't be just a group of four boring women."

"There's no reason why you shouldn't have an absolutely wonderful life." "That's what everyone tells me," she replied immediately. "My belief—which was already strong after I met you once—has only grown stronger after meeting your friend. There's no question.

The world is yours." "What did my friend tell you?" Milly asked. "Nothing that would upset you. We talked about you—and frankly.

Translation

The world is yours." "What did my friend tell you?" Milly asked. "Nothing that would upset you. We talked about you—and frankly,

I don't deny that. But it proves that I'm not asking too much of you." She was now on her feet. "I think I know what you require of me."

Translation

I won't deny it. But it shows I'm not expecting too much from you." She stood up then. "I believe I understand what you want from me."

"Nothing, for you," he went on, "is impossible. So go on." He repeated it again—wanting her so to feel that to-day he saw it. "You're all right." "Well," she smiled—"keep me so."

Translation

"Nothing is impossible for you," he continued, "so go on." He repeated the words, wanting her to feel that he truly saw it that day. "You're all right." "Well," she smiled, "keep me that way."

"Oh you'll get away from me." "Keep me, keep me," she simply continued with her gentle eyes on him. She had given him her hand for good-bye, and he thus for a moment did keep her. Something then, while he seemed to think if there were anything more, came back to him; though something of which there wasn't too much to be made.

Translation

"Oh, you'll leave me." "Keep me, keep me," she simply repeated, her gentle eyes fixed on him. She'd offered her hand for goodbye, and for a moment he held onto her that way. Something then, as he seemed to consider if there was anything else, came back to him; though it wasn't something that amounted to much.

"Of course if there's anything I can do for your friend: I mean the gentleman you speak of—?" He gave out in short that he was ready. She stood up. "I believe I understand your expectations." "Nothing is beyond your capabilities," he continued, "so please, proceed." He emphasized the point, hoping she would recognize his belief in her that day.

Translation

"Of course, if there's anything I can do for your friend—I mean, the gentleman you mentioned—?" He cut himself off, stating plainly that he was prepared. She rose to her feet. "I believe I understand your expectations." "Nothing is beyond your capabilities," he went on, "so please, continue." He stressed the point, hoping she would acknowledge his faith in her on that day.

"You're capable." "Alright," she replied with a smile, "ensure I remain so." "You'll eventually distance yourself from me." "Preserve me, maintain me," she persisted, her kind eyes fixed on him.

Translation

"You're capable." "Very well," she responded, smiling, "see to it that I stay that way." "You'll leave me eventually." "Preserve me, keep me," she insisted, her warm gaze fixed on him.

She offered her hand for a final farewell, and for a moment, he did just that, holding her in place. Then, as he considered if anything else needed to be said, a thought resurfaced, although it wasn't particularly significant. Translation

She extended her hand for a final goodbye, and for a moment, he did nothing but hold it, keeping her there. Then, as he wondered if anything more needed to be said, a thought returned, though it wasn't especially important. Densher?" It was as if she had forgotten. "Mr. Densher—is that his name?" "Yes—but his case isn't so dreadful." She had within a minute got away from that.

Translation

"Densher?" She seemed to have forgotten. "Mr. Densher—is that his name?" "Yes—but his situation isn't that bad." She moved on from the subject within a minute.

"No doubt—if you take an interest." She had got away, but it was as if he made out in her eyes—though they also had rather got away—a reason for calling her back. "Still, if there's anything one can do—?" She looked at him while she thought, while she smiled. "I'm afraid there's really nothing one can do."

Translation

"I suppose, if you care about it." She was leaving, but he thought he saw in her eyes—though they were also drifting away—a reason to make her stay. "Even so, if there's anything I can—?" She looked at him as she considered, as she smiled. "I don't think there's really anything I can."

Chapter 9

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A silence falls upon a woman, Milly, and her visitor, Lord Mark, after twenty minutes in an elevated room. She sighs to him that she never wants to go down. He asks why not, and she explains that she no longer goes out. Lord Mark asks if she is not well. In response, Milly kneels silently at a window with her head in her arms. When she speaks again, she evades the question and says she would like to die there. He laughs and suggests she has other uses. She tells him England is too much for her, and he suggests she buy the place she is in. She says she will try. She asks if he thinks it better for her to "have it over," which makes him look worried. He then brings up a past conversation where he offered to look after her. He asks again if she is in trouble. She tells him, "I'm very badly ill." He asks what she is doing about it, and she says she is living. Lord Mark tells her she wants to be adored, proposes to be the one to do it, and asks her to believe in him. Milly laughs. To change the subject, she gives him a tour of other rooms. Downstairs, as he is about to leave, she tells him he should not have come to Venice for her, but for his best friend. He asks if she means Kate Croy. Milly says Mrs. Lowder wants them to marry and that he should pursue Kate. Lord Mark says that Kate is in love with someone else. Milly denies this, saying Kate herself gave her word that she was free and interested in no one. He questions Kate's word. As he is leaving, a servant named Pasquale enters with a visiting card. The visitor, Mr. Merton Densher, is announced and is waiting at the top of the stairs. Milly says she will see him, and Lord Mark reacts to the name.
How painful it all was! And yet, I would not have traded those hours for all the riches in the world. As I walked, I recalled the scene of our meeting, the words that we had exchanged, and the things that she had told me. I wanted to relive them. I wanted to see her again, to hear the sound of her voice. I had to see her again! I began to walk faster. It was already late, and I had a long way to go. I arrived at the entrance to the park. The iron gates were closed, but I knew the way. I climbed over them, and, taking a hidden path, I was soon inside. The park was deserted. I could only make out the dark outlines of the trees.

Not yet so much as this morning had she felt herself sink into possession; gratefully glad that the warmth of the Southern summer was still in the high florid rooms, palatial chambers where hard cool pavements took reflexions in their lifelong polish, and where the sun on the stirred sea-water, flickering up through open windows, played over the painted "subjects" in the splendid ceilings—medallions of purple and brown, of brave old melancholy colour, medals as of old reddened gold, embossed and beribboned, all toned with time and all flourished and scolloped and gilded about, set in their great moulded and figured concavity (a nest of white cherubs, friendly creatures of the air) and appreciated by the aid of that second tier of smaller lights, straight openings to the front, which did everything, even with the Baedekers and photographs of Milly's party dreadfully meeting the eye, to make of the place an apartment of state. This at last only, though she had enjoyed the palace for three weeks, seemed to count as effective occupation; perhaps because it was the first time she had been alone—really to call alone—since she had left London, it ministered to her first full and unembarrassed sense of what the great Eugenio had done for her. The great Eugenio, recommended by grand-dukes and Americans, had entered her service during the last hours of all—had crossed from Paris, after multiplied pourparlers with Mrs. Stringham, to whom she had allowed more than ever a free hand, on purpose to escort her to the Continent and encompass her there, and had dedicated to her, from the moment of their meeting, all the treasures of his experience.

Translation

Not yet so much as this morning had she felt herself sink into possession; gratefully glad that the warmth of the Southern summer was still in the high florid rooms, palatial chambers where hard cool pavements took reflections in their lifelong polish, and where the sun on the stirred sea-water, flickering up through open windows, played over the painted "subjects" in the splendid ceilings—medallions of purple and brown, of brave old melancholy color, medals as of old reddened gold, embossed and beribboned, all toned with time and all flourished and scolloped and gilded about, set in their great molded and figured concavity (a nest of white cherubs, friendly creatures of the air) and appreciated by the aid of that second tier of smaller lights, straight openings to the front, which did everything, even with the Baedekers and photographs of Milly's party dreadfully meeting the eye, to make of the place an apartment of state. This at last only, though she had enjoyed the palace for three weeks, seemed to count as effective occupation; perhaps because it was the first time she had been alone—really to call alone—since she had left London, it ministered to her first full and unembarrassed sense of what the great Eugenio had done for her. The great Eugenio, recommended by grand-dukes and Americans, had entered her service during the last hours of all—had crossed from Paris, after multiplied pourparlers with Mrs. Stringham, to whom she had allowed more than ever a free hand, on purpose to escort her to the Continent and encompass her there, and had dedicated to her, from the moment of their meeting, all the treasures of his experience.

She had judged him in advance—polyglot and universal, very dear and very deep—as probably but a swindler finished to the finger-tips; for he was forever carrying one well-kept Italian hand to his heart and plunging the other straight into her pocket, which, as she had instantly observed him to recognise, fitted it like a glove. The remarkable thing was that these elements of their common consciousness had rapidly gathered into an indestructible link, formed the ground of a happy relation; being by this time, strangely, grotesquely, delightfully, what most kept up confidence between them and what most expressed it. "Oh, Mr. Densher?" Her voice implied she had momentarily forgotten.

Translation

She had judged him in advance—polyglot and worldly, very precious and very profound—as likely a con man through and through. He was always holding one perfectly manicured Italian hand to his heart while the other plunged directly into her pocket. She had instantly observed that the pocket fit his hand like a glove. The remarkable thing was that these elements of their shared understanding had quickly bonded them, forming the basis of a happy relationship. By this time, it was strangely, grotesquely, delightfully what most maintained confidence between them and what most expressed it. "Oh, Mr. Densher?" Her voice implied she had momentarily forgotten.

"Mr. Densher—is that his name?" "Yes—but his situation isn't so terrible." She had swiftly changed the subject. "No doubt—if you're invested in it." She had changed the subject, yet it seemed as if he detected in her eyes—though her eyes also seemed to have drifted away—a reason to draw her back.

Translation

"Mr. Densher—that's his name?" "Yes—but it's not all that bad for him." She’d switched gears right away. "No question—if you're invested in it." She’d changed the subject, and yet it felt like he saw in her eyes—though they seemed to have wandered off—something that brought her back.

"Still, if there's anything I can do—?" She gazed at him as she pondered, as she smiled. "I'm afraid there's genuinely nothing to be done." III

Translation

"Even so, if there's anything I can help with—?" She regarded him while she considered the matter, while she smiled. "I'm afraid there's absolutely nothing that can be done."

She hadn't felt this sense of ownership as strongly as she did this morning; she was grateful that the warmth of the Southern summer lingered in the grand, ornate rooms, palatial chambers where polished floors reflected light, and where the sun's reflection on the sea, shimmering through open windows, danced across the painted "subjects" on the magnificent ceilings—medallions in shades of purple and brown, with a brave, aged, melancholic color, like old, reddened gold medals, embossed and ribboned, all softened by time and adorned with flourishes, scallops, and gilding, set within their great molded and figured recesses (a gathering of white cherubs, friendly aerial beings), and appreciated with the aid of a second tier of smaller lights, straight openings to the front, which contributed everything, even with the presence of Milly's party's Baedekers and photographs, making the place feel like a state apartment. This, finally, after three weeks of enjoying the palace, seemed to be an effective occupation; perhaps because it was the first time she had been alone—truly alone—since leaving London, it supported her first full and unreserved understanding of what the great Eugenio had done for her. The great Eugenio, recommended by grand dukes and Americans, had come into her service during the final moments—had crossed from Paris, after numerous negotiations with Mrs. Stringham, to whom she had given unprecedented freedom, to escort her to the Continent and look after her there, and had devoted to her, from their first meeting, all the treasures of his expertise.

Translation

This morning, her sense of possession felt especially strong. She was glad the warmth of the Southern summer lingered in the huge, decorated rooms, palatial halls where polished floors reflected light. The sun's reflection on the sea, shimmering through the open windows, danced across the painted "subjects" on the impressive ceilings. These medallions, in shades of purple and brown, had a brave, aged, melancholic color, like old, reddened gold medals, embossed and ribboned. They were softened by time and adorned with flourishes, scallops, and gilding, set within their large, molded recesses (a gathering of friendly, aerial cherubs), and made more vivid by a second tier of smaller, direct openings. Even with Milly's party's guidebooks and photos, these details contributed, making the place feel like a state apartment. Finally, after three weeks of enjoying the palace, this seemed to be a fulfilling activity, perhaps because it was the first time she’d been completely alone since leaving London. It supported her first full and unrestricted understanding of what the great Eugenio had done for her. Recommended by grand dukes and Americans, Eugenio had entered her service at the last minute. After considerable negotiations with Mrs. Stringham, to whom she'd given unprecedented freedom, he'd crossed from Paris to escort her to the Continent and look after her. From their first meeting, he had dedicated the treasures of his expertise to her.

She had judged him beforehand—polyglot and worldly, very charming and very profound—as likely nothing more than a swindler through and through; for he consistently brought one well-maintained Italian hand to his heart and plunged the other straight into her pocket, which, as she had immediately noticed him recognize, fit perfectly. The remarkable part was that these shared truths had quickly solidified into an unbreakable bond, forming the basis of a happy relationship; by this point, strangely, grotesquely, delightfully, it was what most preserved their trust and most expressed it. She had seen quickly enough what was happening—the usual thing again, yet once again. Eugenio had, in an interview of five minutes, understood her, had got hold, like all the world, of the idea not so much of the care with which she must be taken up as of the care with which she must be let down.

Translation

She had pegged him from the start—a polyglot and a man of the world, exceedingly charming and exceedingly deep—as likely a con man through and through. He always held one immaculately manicured Italian hand to his heart and the other he plunged directly into her pocket, which, as she’d noticed him recognize immediately, was a perfect fit. The remarkable thing was that these mutual understandings had quickly become an unbreakable bond, forming the foundation of a happy relationship; at this point, strangely, grotesquely, delightfully, it was what most preserved their trust and most expressed it. She had understood quickly enough what was happening—the same old story, yet again. Eugenio had, in a five-minute interview, understood her, had grasped, like everyone else, not so much the idea of how carefully she must be picked up, but how carefully she must be let down.

All the world understood her, all the world had got hold; but for nobody yet, she felt, would the idea have been so close a tie or won from herself so patient a surrender. Gracefully, respectfully, consummately enough—always with hands in position and the look, in his thick neat white hair, smooth fat face and black professional, almost theatrical eyes, as of some famous tenor grown too old to make love, but with an art still to make money—did he on occasion convey to her that she was, of all the clients of his glorious career, the one in whom his interest was most personal and paternal. The others had come in the way of business, but for her his sentiment was special. Confidence rested thus on her completely believing that: there was nothing of which she felt more sure.

Translation

Everyone else in the world understood her, everyone had understood her secret; but she felt that no one else had yet made the idea such a close connection, or taken from her such patient surrender. Gracefully, respectfully, consummately—always with hands in position and the look, in his thick, neatly combed white hair, smooth, fat face and black, professional, almost theatrical eyes, like some famous tenor grown too old to make love, but with an art still to make money—he would, from time to time, let her know that, of all the clients of his glorious career, she was the one in whom his interest was most personal and paternal. The others had come for business, but for her, his sentiment was special. Trust thus rested on her completely believing that: there was nothing she felt more sure of.

It passed between them every time they conversed; he was abysmal, but this intimacy lived on the surface. He had taken his place already for her among those who were to see her through, and meditation ranked him, in the constant perspective, for the final function, side by side with poor Susie—whom she was now pitying more than ever for having to be herself so sorry and to say so little about it. Eugenio had the general tact of a residuary legatee—which was a character that could be definitely worn; whereas she could see Susie, in the event of her death, in no character at all, Susie being insistently, exclusively concerned in her mere makeshift duration. This principle, for that matter, Milly at present, with a renewed flare of fancy, felt she should herself have liked to believe in.

Translation

It passed between them every time they spoke; he was awful, but this closeness remained on the surface. He had already become, for her, one of those who would see her through. And in her constant contemplation, he was ranked for the final role, right beside poor Susie—whom she pitied now more than ever for having to be so sorrowful and saying so little about it. Eugenio had the general tact of a residuary legatee—which was a character one could definitely play. Whereas she could picture Susie, in the event of her death, in no character at all, Susie being utterly and solely concerned with her mere makeshift existence. This principle, for that matter, Milly at present, with a renewed flare of imagination, felt she would have liked to believe in herself.

Eugenio had really done for her more than he probably knew—he didn't after all know everything—in having, for the wind-up of the autumn, on a weak word from her, so admirably, so perfectly established her. Her weak word, as a general hint, had been: "At Venice, please, if possible, no dreadful, no vulgar hotel; but, if it can be at all managed—you know what I mean—some fine old rooms, wholly independent, for a series of months. Plenty of them too, and the more interesting the better: part of a palace, historic and picturesque, but strictly inodorous, where we shall be to ourselves, with a cook, don't you know?—with servants, frescoes, tapestries, antiquities, the thorough make-believe of a settlement." She had understood immediately what was happening—the same old story, yet again.

Translation

Eugenio had truly done more for her than he likely realized—he didn’t know everything, after all—by, at the end of autumn, responding to her vague suggestion with such admirable, flawless execution. Her offhand remark had been, in essence: “In Venice, please, if possible, no awful, vulgar hotel; but, if it can be arranged—you know what I mean—some beautiful, old rooms, entirely private, for a few months. Plenty of them, too, and the more interesting the better: part of a palace, historic and picturesque, but without any unpleasant smells, where we can be alone, with a cook, you know?—with servants, frescoes, tapestries, antiques, the complete illusion of a home.” She had instantly understood what was happening—the same old story, once again.

Eugenio, in a five-minute conversation, had figured her out. Like everyone else, he grasped the idea not so much of how carefully she needed to be taken care of, but how carefully she needed to be let down. Everyone understood her, everyone had figured it out, but she felt that for no one else was this understanding so intimate a bond, or had it drawn from her such patient acceptance. Gracefully, respectfully, and with perfect skill—always with his hands in the right position, and with the look in his thick, neatly combed white hair, smooth, fleshy face, and dark, professional, almost theatrical eyes, of a famous tenor who'd grown too old for romance but still had the art of making money—he would sometimes convey to her that, of all the clients in his illustrious career, she was the one in whom his interest was most personal and paternal.

Translation

Eugenio, in a five-minute conversation, had pegged her. Like everyone, he understood not so much the extent of her needs, but how gently she needed to be disappointed. Everyone understood her, everyone knew the score, but she felt that for no one else was this understanding so intimate, or had it garnered such patient acceptance from her. With grace, respect, and perfect skill—his hands always positioned just so, and with the look in his thick, neatly combed white hair, smooth, fleshy face, and dark, professional, almost theatrical eyes, of a famous tenor who'd aged out of romance but still had the art of making money—he would sometimes let her know that, of all the clients in his illustrious career, she was the one in whom his interest was most personal and paternal.

The others were just business, but for her, his feelings were special. Confidence rested on her completely believing this: there was nothing she felt more certain of. It passed between them every time they spoke; he was an abyss, but this intimacy was superficial. He had already taken his place among those who were to see her through, and in her constant plans, she ranked him alongside poor Susie for the final role.

Translation

The others were just clients, but she believed he felt something more for her. She was utterly convinced of this: it was her unwavering conviction. It was implicit in every conversation; he was a bottomless well, yet their closeness was shallow. He had already become one of the people who would see her through, and in her endless calculations, she considered him, like poor Susie, a player in the final act.

She pitied Susie now more than ever for having to feel so sorry and say so little about it. Eugenio had the general tact of someone expecting an inheritance—a persona that could be readily adopted. Whereas, she couldn't imagine Susie in any role at all after her death, Susie being entirely and exclusively focused on her mere existence. Milly, with a renewed surge of imagination, felt she would have liked to believe in this principle herself.

Translation

She pitied Susie more than ever, knowing how much sorrow she had to bear and how little she could express. Eugenio possessed the general tact of someone anticipating an inheritance—an easily assumed demeanor. As for Susie, she couldn't picture her in any role after her death, given Susie's complete and utter focus on simply being alive. Milly, with a fresh surge of imagination, wished she could believe in that principle herself.

Eugenio had truly done more for her than he probably knew—he didn't know everything, after all—by having, at the end of autumn, based on a vague suggestion from her, so admirably and perfectly set her up. Her vague suggestion, as a general guideline, had been: "In Venice, please, if possible, no awful, no vulgar hotel; but, if it can be arranged at all—you know what I mean—some fine old rooms, entirely independent, for a series of months. Plenty of them too, and the more interesting the better: part of a palace, historic and picturesque, but strictly odorless, where we'll be to ourselves, with a cook, you know?—with servants, frescoes, tapestries, antiques, the complete pretense of settling down." The proof of how he better and better understood her was in all the place; as to his masterly acquisition of which she had from the first asked no questions.

Translation

Eugenio had truly helped her more than he probably realized—he wasn't omniscient, after all—by so expertly and perfectly arranging everything for her at the end of autumn, based on a vague suggestion from her. Her vague suggestion, as a general guideline, had been: "In Venice, please, if possible, no awful, no vulgar hotel; but, if it can be arranged at all—you know what I mean—some fine old rooms, entirely independent, for a series of months. Plenty of them too, and the more interesting the better: part of a palace, historic and picturesque, but strictly odorless, where we'll be to ourselves, with a cook, you know?—with servants, frescoes, tapestries, antiques, the complete pretense of settling down." The proof of how well he understood her lay in the place itself; she'd asked no questions about his masterful acquisition of it from the beginning.

She had shown him enough what she thought of it, and her forbearance pleased him; with the part of the transaction that mainly concerned her she would soon enough become acquainted, and his connexion with such values as she would then find noted could scarce help growing, as it were, still more residuary. Charming people, conscious Venice-lovers, evidently, had given up their house to her, and had fled to a distance, to other countries, to hide their blushes alike over what they had, however briefly, alienated, and over what they had, however durably, gained. They had preserved and consecrated, and she now—her part of it was shameless—appropriated and enjoyed. Palazzo Leporelli held its history still in its great lap, even like a painted idol, a solemn puppet hung about with decorations.

Translation

She had shown him plainly enough what she thought of it, and her patience in the matter satisfied him. She would soon enough learn the aspect of the transaction that most concerned her, and his connection to the holdings she would then find enumerated could hardly help but grow, as it were, even more foundational. Charming people, clearly lovers of Venice, had given up their house to her and fled far away, to other countries, to hide their blushes over what they had, however briefly, alienated, and over what they had, however durably, gained. They had preserved and consecrated, and she now—her part in it was unashamed—appropriated and enjoyed. Palazzo Leporelli still held its history in its great lap, even like a painted idol, a solemn puppet hung about with decorations.

Hung about with pictures and relics, the rich Venetian past, the ineffaceable character, was here the presence revered and served: which brings us back to our truth of a moment ago—the fact that, more than ever, this October morning, awkward novice though she might be, Milly moved slowly to and fro as the priestess of the worship. Certainly it came from the sweet taste of solitude, caught again and cherished for the hour; always a need of her nature, moreover, when things spoke to her with penetration. It was mostly in stillness they spoke to her best; amid voices she lost the sense. Voices had surrounded her for weeks, and she had tried to listen, had cultivated them and had answered back; these had been weeks in which there were other things they might well prevent her from hearing.

Translation

Adorned with paintings and relics, the opulent Venetian past, its indelible essence, was the presence honored and attended to here. This brings us back to what we realized a moment ago—that, more than ever this October morning, though a clumsy novice, Milly paced back and forth, the priestess of the ritual. It surely arose from the sweet savor of solitude, recaptured and treasured for an hour. This was always a necessity for her temperament, especially when things resonated with her deeply. They spoke to her best in stillness; she lost the meaning amidst voices. Voices had surrounded her for weeks; she had attempted to listen, had fostered them and responded. These were weeks in which there were other things that might well stop her from hearing.

More than the prospect had at first promised or threatened she had felt herself going on in a crowd and with a multiplied escort; the four ladies pictured by her to Sir Luke Strett as a phalanx comparatively closed and detached had in fact proved a rolling snowball, condemned from day to day to cover more ground. Susan Shepherd had compared this portion of the girl's excursion to the Empress Catherine's famous progress across the steppes of Russia; improvised settlements appeared at each turn of the road, villagers waiting with addresses drawn up in the language of London. Old friends in fine were in ambush, Mrs. Lowder's, Kate Croy's, her own; when the addresses weren't in the language of London they were in the more insistent idioms of American centres.

Translation

More than the prospect had initially promised or threatened, she had felt herself progressing within a crowd and with a growing retinue. The four women she had imagined to Sir Luke Strett as a relatively closed and separate phalanx had, in reality, become a rolling snowball, destined to expand daily. Susan Shepherd had likened this segment of the girl's journey to Empress Catherine's famous expedition across the Russian steppes; impromptu settlements materialized at every bend, with villagers poised with speeches composed in the style of London. Old acquaintances, finely dressed, were lying in wait—Mrs. Lowder's, Kate Croy's, and her own. When the speeches weren’t in London's style, they were in the more persistent dialects of American hubs.

The current was swollen even by Susie's social connexions; so that there were days, at hotels, at Dolomite picnics, on lake steamers, when she could almost repay to Aunt Maud and Kate with interest the debt contracted by the London "success" to which they had opened the door. The evidence of how well he understood her was everywhere. She had never questioned his brilliant mastery of it. She had made her opinion clear, and his appreciation of her restraint pleased him.

Translation

The current had swelled further, fueled even by Susie's social connections. There were days, at hotels, on Dolomite picnics, aboard lake steamers, when she could almost repay Aunt Maud and Kate with interest for the debt incurred by the London "success" to which they had given her access. The evidence of his understanding was everywhere. She had never doubted his brilliance in this regard. She had made her opinion clear, and his appreciation of her restraint pleased him.

She would soon learn about the part of the plan that concerned her, and his connection to the valuable things she would discover would inevitably become even more essential. Obviously, delightful people who loved Venice had given her their house and left, going far away to other countries, to hide their embarrassment over what they had, however briefly, given up, and what they had, however permanently, gained. They had preserved and consecrated, and she—shamelessly—now took possession and enjoyed it. Palazzo Leporelli still held its history in its great embrace, like a painted idol, a solemn puppet adorned with decorations.

Translation

She would soon be informed about her role in the plan, and his link to the valuable objects she would find would necessarily grow even more important. Clearly, charming people who adored Venice had handed over their home and departed, fleeing to distant lands, to conceal their shame regarding what they had, however fleetingly, relinquished, and what they had, however enduringly, acquired. They had protected and sanctified, and she—unashamedly—now occupied and reveled in it. Palazzo Leporelli still cradled its history in its vast embrace, like a painted idol, a grave puppet festooned with embellishments.

Surrounded by pictures and relics, the rich Venetian past, the unforgettable character, was honored and served here. This brings us back to our earlier point: that, more than ever, this October morning, though she might be an awkward beginner, Milly moved slowly, like a priestess in worship. Certainly, this came from the delightful taste of solitude, regained and treasured for the moment. This was always a need of her nature, especially when things spoke to her with feeling.

Translation

She was surrounded by paintings and artifacts that paid homage to Venice's opulent past, its unforgettable personality, which was revered and served here. This brought us back to our earlier point: that, more than ever, on this October morning, even though she might be an awkward beginner, Milly moved slowly, like a priestess in worship. Indeed, this stemmed from the exquisite taste of solitude, regained and treasured for the moment. This was always a necessity of her nature, particularly when things spoke to her with emotion.

They spoke best in stillness; she lost the meaning amidst voices. Voices had surrounded her for weeks, and she had tried to listen, had cultivated them, and responded. These were weeks in which other things could easily have prevented her from hearing. She had felt herself moving forward in a crowd and with a large entourage, more than the prospect had initially promised or threatened.

Translation

Stillness was their preferred language; she became lost in voices. For weeks, voices had enveloped her, and she had attempted to listen, to nurture them, and to answer. These were weeks in which other matters could easily have drowned out her hearing. She had felt herself advancing in a crowd and with a substantial following, exceeding the initial promise or threat of the prospect.

The four ladies she had described to Sir Luke Strett as a relatively closed and separate group had, in fact, turned into a rolling snowball, destined to cover more ground daily. Susan Shepherd had compared this part of the girl's journey to Empress Catherine's famous travels across the steppes of Russia. Improvised settlements appeared at every turn, villagers waiting with speeches written in the language of London. Old friends were waiting, including Mrs.

Translation

The four women she'd characterized to Sir Luke Strett as a relatively insular group had, in reality, become a growing force, expanding daily. Susan Shepherd had likened this stage of the girl's trajectory to Empress Catherine's renowned journey across the Russian steppes. Temporary communities arose at every stop, with locals ready to greet them with speeches composed in the style of London. Old acquaintances awaited them, including Mrs.

Lowder and Kate Croy, and her own. When the speeches weren't in the language of London, they were in the more persistent dialects of American cities. The current was even increased by Susie's social connections, so that there were days, at hotels, on Dolomite picnics, and on lake steamers, when she could almost repay Aunt Maud and Kate with interest for the "success" in London that they had made possible. Mrs.

Translation

Lowder and Kate Croy, and her own. When the speeches weren't in the language of London, they were in the more enduring dialects of American cities. The current was further strengthened by Susie's social network, so that there were days, at hotels, on Dolomite picnics, and on lake steamers, when she could almost repay Aunt Maud and Kate with interest for the "success" in London that they had made possible. Mrs.

Lowder's success and Kate's, amid the shock of Milly's and Mrs. Stringham's compatriots, failed but little, really, of the concert-pitch; it had gone almost as fast as the boom, over the sea, of the last great native novel. Those ladies were "so different"—different, observably enough, from the ladies so appraising them; it being throughout a case mainly of ladies, of a dozen at once sometimes, in Milly's apartment, pointing, also at once, that moral and many others. Milly's companions were acclaimed not only as perfectly fascinating in themselves, the nicest people yet known to the acclaimers, but as obvious helping hands, socially speaking, for the eccentric young woman, evident initiators and smoothers of her path, possible subduers of her eccentricity.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder's and Kate's triumph, even amidst the astonishment of Milly's and Mrs. Stringham's American friends, barely faltered, truly. It had gained momentum almost as rapidly as the splash, across the ocean, of the latest blockbuster novel. Those women were "so different"—different, clearly enough, from the women assessing them; the situation involving, for the most part, women, sometimes a dozen at once, in Milly's apartment, drawing attention, simultaneously, to that lesson and many others. Milly's friends were celebrated not only as utterly captivating, the most delightful people the admirers had ever known, but as plainly helpful figures, socially speaking, for the unconventional young woman, clear instigators and easeful guides, potential mitigators of her eccentricities.

Short intervals, to her own sense, stood now for great differences, and this renewed inhalation of her native air had somehow left her to feel that she already, that she mainly, struck the compatriot as queer and dissociated. She moved such a critic, it would appear, as to rather an odd suspicion, a benevolence induced by a want of complete trust: all of which showed her in the light of a person too plain and too ill-clothed for a thorough good time, and yet too rich and too befriended—an intuitive cunning within her managing this last—for a thorough bad one. The compatriots, in short, by what she made out, approved her friends for their expert wisdom with her; in spite of which judicial sagacity it was the compatriots who recorded themselves as the innocent parties. She saw things in these days that she had never seen before, and she couldn't have said why save on a principle too terrible to name; whereby she saw that neither Lancaster Gate was what New York took it for, nor New York what Lancaster Gate fondly fancied it in coquetting with the plan of a series of American visits.

Translation

For Milly, short periods of time now represented significant shifts, and this return to her homeland had left her feeling that, in her compatriots' eyes, she was already, and primarily, strange and out of touch. She seemed to inspire a type of critic characterized by a curious suspicion, a kindness born of a lack of complete faith. This placed her in the position of someone too ordinary and poorly dressed for a genuinely enjoyable experience, yet too wealthy and well-connected—an intuitive cleverness at work in the latter—to have a truly bad time. In essence, as far as she could tell, her fellow Americans admired her friends for their ability to advise her, and despite this perceptive judgment, they, the Americans, ultimately saw themselves as the innocent ones. She observed things during this period that she had never noticed before, and she couldn't explain why, except in terms of a principle too frightening to articulate: that neither Lancaster Gate was what New York believed it to be, nor New York what Lancaster Gate, in its flirtation with the idea of American visits, fondly imagined it to be.

The plan might have been, humorously, on Mrs. Lowder's part, for the improvement of her social position—and it had verily in that direction lights that were perhaps but half a century too prompt; at all of which Kate Croy assisted with the cool controlled facility that went so well, as the others said, with her particular kind of good looks, the kind that led you to expect the person enjoying them would dispose of disputations, speculations, aspirations, in a few very neatly and brightly uttered words, so simplified in sense, however, that they sounded, even when guiltless, like rather aggravated slang. It wasn't that Kate hadn't pretended too that she should like to go to America; it was only that with this young woman Milly had constantly proceeded, and more than ever of late, on the theory of intimate confessions, private frank ironies that made up for their public grimaces and amid which, face to face, they wearily put off the mask. Mrs.

Translation

The plan might have been, humorously, Mrs. Lowder’s attempt to advance her social standing—and it had indeed involved aspects that were perhaps only half a century ahead of their time. Kate Croy assisted with all of this, her cool, controlled ease complementing her distinctive good looks, the kind that made you expect she would dismiss arguments, ponderings, and ambitions with a few cleverly and brightly spoken words, so simplified in meaning that, even when innocent, they sounded like rather exaggerated slang. It wasn't that Kate hadn't also pretended she wanted to go to America; it was only that she and Milly had constantly operated, and especially lately, on the basis of intimate confessions, private frank ironies that compensated for their public pretenses, and amidst which, face to face, they wearily removed their masks. Mrs.

Lowder's and Kate's success, despite the surprise of Milly's and Mrs. Stringham's fellow Americans, was nearly perfect; it was almost as quick as the huge popularity, across the ocean, of the latest popular American novel. These women were "so different"—obviously different, from the women evaluating them; it was mostly a matter of women, sometimes a dozen at once in Milly's apartment, pointing out this and other points. Milly's companions were praised not only for being completely fascinating in themselves, the nicest people the praisers had ever met, but also as clear social helpers for the unusual young woman, the ones who had started her social life, smoothed her path, and maybe even subdued her strangeness.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder and Kate's success, much to the surprise of Milly and Mrs. Stringham's American friends, was nearly flawless, almost as immediate as the widespread acclaim for the latest American bestseller back home. These women were "so different"—strikingly different, from the women judging them; this was the common refrain, often voiced by a dozen women at once in Milly's apartment, as they pointed out this and that. Milly's companions were lauded not only for being utterly captivating in their own right, the most delightful people the admirers had ever encountered, but also as invaluable guides for the unconventional young woman, the ones who had launched her social life, paved the way for her, and perhaps even softened her eccentricities.

Short periods of time, in Milly's mind, now represented great changes, and somehow this return to her home country made her feel that she, especially, seemed odd and disconnected to her fellow Americans. She seemed to make these critics suspicious, their kindness caused by a lack of complete trust. All of this made her appear to be someone too plain and too poorly dressed for a truly enjoyable life, and yet too rich and too well-connected—with an instinctive cleverness that controlled the last quality—to have a truly bad life. In short, from what she understood, the fellow Americans approved of her friends because of their expert handling of her; despite this wise judgment, it was the Americans who considered themselves the innocent ones.

Translation

Brief moments, in Milly's estimation, now signified significant shifts. Somehow, returning to America made her feel particularly alien, out of sync with her compatriots. She seemed to arouse suspicion in these observers; their amiability concealed a lack of genuine faith. It all painted her as someone too unremarkable and poorly styled for a life of real pleasure, yet too wealthy and well-connected—possessing an innate intelligence that kept the latter from becoming a liability—to suffer terribly. In essence, as she grasped it, the Americans valued her friends for their skillful management of her. Despite this astute assessment, it was the Americans who viewed themselves as the uncorrupted ones.

She noticed things these days that she'd never noticed before, and she couldn't explain why except for a reason that was too frightening to acknowledge. This reason was that neither Lancaster Gate (in London) was what New York thought it was, nor was New York what Lancaster Gate imagined it to be while flirting with the idea of a series of American visits. The plan may have been, comically, on Mrs. Lowder's part, to improve her social standing—and indeed, it had benefits in that direction that were perhaps only half a century too early.

Translation

Lately, she was noticing things she’d never noticed before, and she couldn't explain it except for a reason she was too afraid to confront. This reason was that Lancaster Gate, in London, was not what New York thought it was, and New York wasn’t what Lancaster Gate imagined it to be while toying with the prospect of American trips. The plan may have been, comically, on Mrs. Lowder’s part, to elevate her social status—and in fact, it had advantages in that respect, but perhaps it was only half a century too early.

Kate Croy assisted with all of this with the calm, controlled ease that, as others said, went so well with her particular beauty, the kind that made you expect the person possessing it to settle arguments, discussions, and ambitions with a few very neat and bright words, so simple in meaning, however, that they sounded, even when innocent, like rather exaggerated slang. It wasn't that Kate hadn't also pretended that she'd like to go to America; it was only that Milly had consistently acted with this young woman, especially recently, based on the principle of intimate confessions, private, frank ironies that made up for their public pretenses, and in which they, face to face, wearily removed the mask. These puttings-off of the mask had finally quite become the form taken by their moments together, moments indeed not increasingly frequent and not prolonged, thanks to the consciousness of fatigue on Milly's side whenever, as she herself expressed it, she got out of harness. They flourished their masks, the independent pair, as they might have flourished Spanish fans; they smiled and sighed on removing them; but the gesture, the smiles, the sighs, strangely enough, might have been suspected the greatest reality in the business.

Translation

Kate Croy helped with all of this with a composed, controlled grace. Other people said it complemented her particular beauty, the kind that made you expect the person to settle arguments, discussions, and ambitions with a few neat, bright words. Those words were simple, even when innocent, sounding like exaggerated slang. It wasn’t that Kate hadn’t also pretended she wanted to go to America. It was only that Milly had consistently behaved with this young woman, especially recently, based on intimate confessions, private, frank ironies. These made up for their public pretenses, and in those moments, face to face, they wearily removed the mask. These removals of the mask had finally become the form of their moments together, moments that weren’t increasingly frequent or prolonged. This was because of Milly’s fatigue whenever, as she put it, she got out of harness. The independent pair flourished their masks like Spanish fans. They smiled and sighed on removing them. But the gesture, the smiles, and the sighs might have been the greatest reality of all.

Strangely enough, we say, for the volume of effusion in general would have been found by either on measurement to be scarce proportional to the paraphernalia of relief. It was when they called each other's attention to their ceasing to pretend, it was then that what they were keeping back was most in the air. There was a difference, no doubt, and mainly to Kate's advantage: Milly didn't quite see what her friend could keep back, was possessed of, in fine, that would be so subject to retention; whereas it was comparatively plain sailing for Kate that poor Milly had a treasure to hide. This was not the treasure of a shy, an abject affection—concealment, on that head, belonging to quite another phase of such states; it was much rather a principle of pride relatively bold and hard, a principle that played up like a fine steel spring at the lightest pressure of too near a footfall.

Translation

Oddly enough, we say, the amount of emotion poured out would, if measured, have proven hardly proportionate to the displays of sympathy. It was when they acknowledged they had stopped pretending that what they were concealing was most evident. There was a difference, certainly, mostly to Kate's benefit: Milly couldn't quite see what her friend was holding back, what she possessed that she would be so careful to retain; whereas it was relatively obvious to Kate that poor Milly had a treasure to hide. This wasn't the treasure of a timid, servile affection—concealment, in that case, belonged to a different stage of such emotions. Instead, it was a principle of pride, relatively bold and unyielding, a principle that responded like a fine steel spring at the slightest pressure of too close an approach.

Thus insuperably guarded was the truth about the girl's own conception of her validity; thus was a wondering pitying sister condemned wistfully to look at her from the far side of the moat she had dug round her tower. Certain aspects of the connexion of these young women show for us, such is the twilight that gathers about them, in the likeness of some dim scene in a Maeterlinck play; we have positively the image, in the delicate dusk, of the figures so associated and yet so opposed, so mutually watchful: that of the angular pale princess, ostrich-plumed, black-robed, hung about with amulets, reminders, relics, mainly seated, mainly still, and that of the upright restless slow-circling lady of her court who exchanges with her, across the black water streaked with evening gleams, fitful questions and answers. The upright lady, with thick dark braids down her back, drawing over the grass a more embroidered train, makes the whole circuit, and makes it again, and the broken talk, brief and sparingly allusive, seems more to cover than to free their sense. This is because, when it fairly comes to not having others to consider, they meet in an air that appears rather anxiously to wait for their words.

Translation

Thus, the truth about the girl's sense of her own worth was impregnably defended. Thus, a sister, filled with wonder and pity, was condemned to gaze at her wistfully from across the moat she had dug around her tower. Certain aspects of the connection between these young women appear to us, surrounded as they are by shadows, like a scene from a Maeterlinck play. We positively have the image, in the delicate dusk, of the figures so connected and yet so opposed, so mutually watchful: the angular, pale princess, with ostrich plumes, in a black robe, adorned with amulets, reminders, relics, mostly seated, mostly still, and the upright, restless lady of her court, slowly circling, who exchanges with her, across the black water streaked with evening gleams, questions and answers that come and go. The upright lady, with thick, dark braids down her back, trailing a more embroidered train across the grass, makes the whole circuit, and makes it again, and the broken talk, brief and sparing with its allusions, seems more to conceal than to reveal their meaning. This is because, when they finally have no one else to consider, they meet in an atmosphere that seems rather anxiously to await their words.

Such an impression as that was in fact grave, and might be tragic; so that, plainly enough, systematically at last, they settled to a care of what they said. Taking off their masks had become their standard interaction. These moments together weren't happening very often, and they weren't lasting long, because Milly felt tired whenever, as she put it, she took a break from the act. They flaunted their masks, these two independent women, like they were waving Spanish fans.

Translation

That impression was, in truth, serious, potentially tragic. Consequently, they began, plainly and systematically, to be careful with their words. Removing their masks had become their customary way of interacting. These moments, when they were together, were infrequent and brief, because Milly felt exhausted whenever she took a break from the act, as she put it. These two independent women brandished their masks as if they were waving Spanish fans.

They smiled and sighed when they took them off, but the gestures, the smiles, and the sighs were, strangely enough, probably the most genuine thing about their relationship. Surprisingly, the emotional outpouring, if you could measure it, wouldn't have matched the effort it took to feel relieved. It was when they pointed out that they weren't pretending that the things they were hiding were most noticeable. There was a difference between them, mainly to Kate's advantage.

Translation

They smiled and sighed as they removed the masks, and yet, the gestures, smiles, and sighs were, oddly enough, likely the most authentic thing about their relationship. Surprisingly, the emotional release, if it could be measured, didn’t compare to the effort it took to feel unburdened. The things they were concealing were most apparent when they insisted they weren't pretending. A disparity existed between the two of them, primarily benefiting Kate.

Milly didn't quite understand what her friend might be holding back, what she possessed that she wouldn't share. It was much easier for Kate to see that poor Milly had a secret. It wasn't about being shy or afraid of affection—that kind of secrecy was part of a different situation. Instead, it was a strong sense of pride, bold and resolute, that reacted like a finely-tuned spring at the slightest hint of someone getting too close.

Translation

Milly couldn't grasp what her friend kept hidden, the aspects of herself she wouldn't reveal. For Kate, it was simpler to see that Milly harbored a secret. It wasn't simple timidity or a fear of intimacy—that form of concealment belonged elsewhere. Instead, it was an intense pride, assertive and unwavering, that recoiled like a coiled spring at any suggestion of intimacy.

This is how well-guarded the truth was about Milly's view of herself. A curious, sympathetic friend was forced to watch from across the moat Milly had built around herself. Certain parts of their relationship, shrouded in shadows, are like a scene from a play by Maeterlinck. We see the image in the dim light of the figures, so connected and yet so different, constantly watching each other.

Translation

This is the extent of Milly's self-regard, carefully concealed. A curious, empathetic friend was left to observe from across the barrier Milly had erected. Aspects of their connection, obscured in darkness, resemble a scene from a Maeterlinck play. We glimpse the forms in the half-light, bound together and yet distinct, perpetually observing one another.

There's the angular, pale princess, wearing black, with ostrich feathers and amulets, relics, mostly sitting still, and the restless lady of her court, who walks around her, exchanging occasional questions and answers across the dark water reflecting the evening light. The lady, with thick, dark braids, drags an elaborate train over the grass, making the full circle again and again. Their fragmented conversation, brief and indirect, seems more like a way to hide their true feelings than to express them. When they were alone, they met in an atmosphere that seemed to be waiting nervously for them to speak.

Translation

There's the pale, sharp-featured princess in black, adorned with ostrich feathers and amulets, relics of some kind. She mostly sits still. Around her moves the restless lady of her court. She wanders, trading questions and answers across the dark water mirroring the evening. The lady, with thick, dark braids, trails an elaborate gown over the grass, circling endlessly. Their scattered conversation, brief and evasive, feels more like a cover than a confession. Alone together, they met in an atmosphere charged with the nervous expectation of words unspoken.

That feeling was serious and might even be tragic, so they became careful about what they said. There could be no gross phrasing to Milly, in particular, of the probability that if she wasn't so proud she might be pitied with more comfort—more to the person pitying; there could be no spoken proof, no sharper demonstration than the consistently considerate attitude, that this marvellous mixture of her weakness and of her strength, her peril, if such it were, and her option, made her, kept her, irresistibly interesting. Kate's predicament in the matter was, after all, very much Mrs. Stringham's own, and Susan Shepherd herself indeed, in our Maeterlinck picture, might well have hovered in the gloaming by the moat.

Translation

That feeling was weighty, perhaps even tragic, so they became cautious with their words. There could be no bluntness of expression to Milly, especially regarding the likelihood that, were she less proud, she might receive more compassionate pity—more so from the person offering it. There could be no verbal confirmation, no clearer illustration than the constant, solicitous behavior; this remarkable mix of her frailty and her fortitude, her potential danger if that's what it was, and her choices, made her, kept her, captivatingly interesting. Kate's situation in all of this was, in the end, very similar to Mrs. Stringham's own, and Susan Shepherd herself, in our Maeterlinck-esque tableau, could very well have been lingering in the twilight by the water.

It may be declared for Kate, at all events, that her sincerity about her friend, through this time, was deep, her compassionate imagination strong; and that these things gave her a virtue, a good conscience, a credibility for herself, so to speak, that were later to be precious to her. She grasped with her keen intelligence the logic of their common duplicity, went unassisted through the same ordeal as Milly's other hushed follower, easily saw that for the girl to be explicit was to betray divinations, gratitudes, glimpses of the felt contrast between her fortune and her fear—all of which would have contradicted her systematic bravado. That was it, Kate wonderingly saw: to recognise was to bring down the avalanche—the avalanche Milly lived so in watch for and that might be started by the lightest of breaths; though less possibly the breath of her own stifled plaint than that of the vain sympathy, the mere helpless gaping inference of others. With so many suppressions as these, therefore, between them, their withdrawal together to unmask had to fall back, as we have hinted, on a nominal motive—which was decently represented by a joy at the drop of chatter.

Translation

It can be said, in Kate's case at least, that her sincerity regarding her friend during this time was profound, her empathetic imagination powerful. These qualities gave her a sense of virtue, a clear conscience, and a self-assurance that would later become invaluable. She understood with her sharp intellect the unspoken agreement they shared. She endured the same test as Milly's other silent supporter. She saw easily that for Milly to be candid was to betray insights, expressions of gratitude, and glimpses of the felt contrast between her good fortune and her fear—all of which would have undermined her carefully constructed facade. That was the point, Kate realized with wonder: to acknowledge was to trigger the avalanche. This was the same avalanche Milly was always watching out for, an avalanche that could be set off by the slightest of sounds. It was less likely to be triggered by Milly's own suppressed complaints than by the useless sympathy, the empty, helpless assumptions of others. With so much unsaid between them, their efforts to be honest had to retreat, as we've suggested, to a superficial reason—which was adequately represented by a shared delight in the absence of idle talk.

Chatter had in truth all along attended their steps, but they took the despairing view of it on purpose to have ready, when face to face, some view or other of something. The relief of getting out of harness—that was the moral of their meetings; but the moral of this, in turn, was that they couldn't so much as ask each other why harness need be worn. Milly wore it as a general armour. It was impossible for anyone to openly suggest to Milly that if she weren't so proud, people might pity her more comfortably – that is, in a way that would be more fulfilling for the person doing the pitying.

Translation

The truth was that they had always been accompanied by a certain amount of idle talk, but they deliberately regarded it with a sense of despair in order to have something to discuss when they met. The relief of escaping constraint—that was the underlying purpose of their meetings. But the purpose of this, in turn, was that they couldn't even ask each other why such constraint was necessary. Milly wore it as a sort of general defense. It was impossible for anyone to openly suggest to Milly that if she weren't so proud, people might feel pity for her more easily—that is, in a way that would be more satisfying for the person doing the pitying.

There could be no clearer demonstration than the consistently thoughtful behavior that this remarkable combination of her fragility and her strength, her vulnerability, if that's what it was, and her choices, made her, kept her, irresistibly captivating. Kate's situation in all of this was, after all, very similar to Mrs. Stringham's. And Susan Shepherd herself, in our melancholic scene, might easily have been seen lingering in the shadows near the castle's waterway.

Translation

Nothing demonstrated it more clearly than the consistently thoughtful behavior that this remarkable combination of her fragility and her strength, her vulnerability, if that's what it was, and her choices, made her, kept her, irresistibly captivating. Kate's situation in all of this was, after all, very similar to Mrs. Stringham's. And Susan Shepherd herself, in our melancholic scene, might easily have been seen lingering in the shadows near the castle's waterway.

We can certainly say about Kate that her genuine feelings for her friend during this time were profound, and her compassionate imagination was strong. These qualities gave her a sense of virtue, a clear conscience, and a kind of self-respect that would later become very important to her. With her sharp mind, she grasped the logic of their shared deception, went through the same difficult experience as Milly's other quiet supporter, and understood that for the girl to be explicit would mean revealing insights, gratitude, and a glimpse of the contrast she felt between her good fortune and her fear. All of this would have undermined her carefully constructed façade of bravery.

Translation

Kate's affection for her friend at this time was undoubtedly genuine, and her capacity for empathy was considerable. These traits fostered a sense of goodness within her, a clear moral compass, and a form of self-regard that would prove critical to her later. Her astute mind understood the rationale behind their shared deceit. She endured the same hardship as Milly's other quiet confidante, and knew that for the girl to be open would mean exposing her perceptions, her appreciation, and a hint of the disparity she felt between her good luck and her fear. All of this would have compromised her carefully cultivated image of courage.

That was the key, Kate realized with wonder: to acknowledge the truth was to unleash the disaster—the disaster that Milly was constantly watching for and that could be triggered by the slightest word; though perhaps less by her own suppressed complaints than by the useless sympathy, the mere helpless, gaping assumptions of others. With so much unspoken between them, their joint attempt to be honest had to fall back, as we've suggested, on a superficial reason—which was suitably represented by a shared joy in escaping the endless talk. Talk had, in fact, always accompanied them, but they deliberately took a negative view of it, to have something to say to each other when they finally met. The relief of escaping obligations—that was the point of their meetings.

Translation

Kate understood, with amazement: admitting the truth meant releasing the disaster—the disaster Milly was always anticipating, which could be set off by a single word; though perhaps less by her own unspoken grievances than by the useless sympathy, the helpless, vacant assumptions of others. So much went unsaid between them that their attempt to be honest had to retreat, as we've already suggested, to a shallow rationale—which was suitably embodied by a shared pleasure in avoiding the endless chatter.
