They had always been surrounded by talk, but they deliberately took a dim view of it, so they would have something to say to each other when they finally met. The relief of escaping obligations—that was the purpose of their meetings.

But the point of this, in turn, was that they couldn't even ask each other why those obligations were necessary. Milly wore them like a constant suit of armor. She was out of it at present, for some reason, as she hadn't been for weeks; she was always out of it, that is, when alone, and her companions had never yet so much as just now affected her as dispersed and suppressed. It was as if still again, still more tacitly and wonderfully, Eugenio had understood her, taking it from her without a word and just bravely and brilliantly in the name, for instance, of the beautiful day: "Yes, get me an hour alone; take them off—I don't care where; absorb, amuse, detain them; drown them, kill them if you will: so that I may just a little, all by myself, see where I am." She was conscious of the dire impatience of it, for she gave up Susie as well as the others to him—Susie who would have drowned her very self for her; gave her up to a mercenary monster through whom she thus purchased respites.

Translation

But the point was that they couldn't even question the reasons for those obligations. Milly wore them constantly, like a suit of armor. For some reason, she wasn't wearing it now, as she hadn't been for weeks; in other words, she wasn't wearing it when alone, and her companions had never seemed so dispersed and suppressed. It was as though Eugenio, again, even more silently and wonderfully, had understood her, taking her meaning without a word and bravely, brilliantly, in the name, for instance, of the beautiful day: "Yes, get me an hour alone; take them away—I don't care where; absorb them, amuse them, detain them; drown them, kill them if you must: so that I might, just for a little while, all by myself, see where I am." She was aware of the urgency of it, because she relinquished Susie along with the others—Susie who would have sacrificed herself for her; she gave her to a mercenary monster through whom she bought these respites.

Strange were the turns of life and the moods of weakness; strange the flickers of fancy and the cheats of hope; yet lawful, all the same—weren't they?—those experiments tried with the truth that consisted, at the worst, but in practising on one's self. She was now playing with the thought that Eugenio might inclusively assist her: he had brought home to her, and always by remarks that were really quite soundless, the conception, hitherto ungrasped, of some complete use of her wealth itself, some use of it as a counter-move to fate. It had passed between them as preposterous that with so much money she should just stupidly and awkwardly want—any more want a life, a career, a consciousness, than want a house, a carriage or a cook. It was as if she had had from him a kind of expert professional measure of what he was in a position, at a stretch, to undertake for her; the thoroughness of which, for that matter, she could closely compare with a looseness on Sir Luke Strett's part that—at least in Palazzo Leporelli when mornings were fine—showed as almost amateurish.

Translation

Life's twists were bizarre, as were the moments of vulnerability, the whimsical flights of fancy, and hope's deceits. But they were all legitimate, weren't they, these experiments with truth, even if they amounted to little more than self-deception? She was now toying with the idea that Eugenio might comprehensively assist her. He had subtly communicated—and always through almost silent observations—the notion, which she hadn't previously grasped, of how she could fully utilize her wealth as a strategic response to fate. The absurdity had been discussed between them: that with so much money, she should simply, stupidly, and awkwardly desire—any more than she wanted a house, a carriage, or a cook—a life, a career, or consciousness. It was as if he had offered her a professional estimate of what he was capable of undertaking for her, pushed to his limits. For that matter, she could closely compare his approach to the laxity of Sir Luke Strett's work, which, at least at the Palazzo Leporelli when the mornings were lovely, seemed almost amateurish.

Sir Luke hadn't said to her "Pay enough money and leave the rest to me"—which was distinctly what Eugenio did say. Sir Luke had appeared indeed to speak of purchase and payment, but in reference to a different sort of cash. Those were amounts not to be named nor reckoned, and such moreover as she wasn't sure of having at her command. Eugenio—this was the difference—could name, could reckon, and prices of his kind were things she had never suffered to scare her.

Translation

Sir Luke hadn't told her, "Pay enough money and leave the rest to me"—which was precisely what Eugenio did say. Sir Luke had indeed seemed to speak of purchase and payment, but in reference to a different kind of currency. Those were sums not to be mentioned or calculated, and moreover, amounts that she wasn't certain she possessed. Eugenio—this was the difference—could name, could calculate, and prices of his kind were things she had never allowed to frighten her.

She had been willing, goodness knew, to pay enough for anything, for everything, and here was simply a new view of the sufficient quantity. She amused herself—for it came to that, since Eugenio was there to sign the receipt—with possibilities of meeting the bill. She was more prepared than ever to pay enough, and quite as much as ever to pay too much. What else—if such were points at which your most trusted servant failed—was the use of being, as the dear Susies of earth called you, a princess in a palace?

Translation

She had, heaven knows, been ready to pay whatever was necessary for anything, for everything. Now, she was simply faced with a new perspective on the idea of a sufficient amount. She amused herself—because that was what it came to, since Eugenio was there to sign the receipt—by considering how she would handle the bill. She was more ready than ever to pay enough, and equally ready to pay too much. What else—if your most trusted servant failed in these matters—was the point of being, as the dear Susies of the world called you, a princess in a palace?

She was disconnected, for some reason she hadn't felt in weeks. She was always that way when she was alone, and her companions had never seemed so distant and suppressed as they did at that moment. It was as though, again, even more silently and wonderfully, Eugenio understood her. He seemed to grasp her desires without a word, bravely and brilliantly, perhaps in the name of the beautiful day.

Translation

She felt detached, a sensation she hadn’t experienced in weeks. It was a familiar state when she was alone, and her companions had never seemed so remote and subdued as they did then. As if, once more, even more subtly and wonderfully, Eugenio understood her. He appeared to comprehend her wishes without her speaking, with boldness and brilliance, perhaps honoring the lovely day.

"Yes, get me an hour alone. Take them away—I don't care where. Occupy them, entertain them, detain them; drown them, kill them if you must, so I can just be alone for a little while, to see where I am." She was aware of the intense impatience driving her, because she sacrificed Susie, as well as the others, to him—Susie, who would have done anything for her. She gave her up to a mercenary monster through whom she purchased these respites.

Translation

"Yes, get me an hour alone. Get them out of here—I don't care where they go. Occupy them, entertain them, detain them; drown them, kill them if you have to, just so I can be alone for a little while, to figure out where I am." She knew the intense impatience that drove her, because she was sacrificing Susie, as well as the others, to him—Susie, who would have done anything for her. She gave her up to a mercenary monster through whom she purchased these respites.

Life's twists and turns were strange, as were the moods of weakness, the flickering of imagination, and the deceptions of hope. Still, they were permissible, weren't they? These experiments played with the truth, which at worst, was just about practicing on oneself. She was now toying with the idea that Eugenio could help her completely.

Translation

Life's vagaries were peculiar, as were the periods of vulnerability, the bursts of imagination, and the self-deceptions of hope. Yet, they were acceptable, weren't they? These tests were manipulations of the truth, which at its core, was nothing more than self-experimentation. She was now entertaining the notion that Eugenio could be her salvation.

He had impressed upon her, always through completely unspoken suggestions, the idea, which she hadn't grasped before, of how to fully utilize her wealth as a countermeasure against fate. It had passed between them as absurd that with so much money she should stupidly and awkwardly want anything more than a life, a career, or consciousness—anything more than a house, a carriage, or a cook. It was as though he had given her a kind of expert professional assessment of what he was capable of undertaking for her. The thoroughness of it she could closely compare with Sir Luke Strett's looseness, which, at least in the Palazzo Leporelli when the mornings were fair, seemed almost amateurish.

Translation

He had instilled in her, always without explicitly saying so, the concept, which she hadn't understood before, of how to leverage her fortune to defy her destiny. It had been understood between them, ridiculously, that with her wealth she shouldn't foolishly and clumsily desire anything beyond a life, a profession, or awareness—anything more than a home, a carriage, or a chef. It was as if he had provided her with an expert, professional evaluation of what he could do for her. She could easily compare its meticulousness to Sir Luke Strett's lack of rigor, which, at least within the Palazzo Leporelli when the mornings were pleasant, appeared almost amateurish.

Sir Luke hadn't said to her, "Pay enough money and leave the rest to me," which was exactly what Eugenio did say. Sir Luke had appeared to speak of purchase and payment, but in reference to a different type of currency. Those were amounts not to be named or calculated, and moreover, she wasn't sure she had that kind of money. Eugenio—this was the difference—could name, could reckon, and prices of his kind were things she had never been afraid of.

Translation

Sir Luke hadn’t told her, “Pay me, and I’ll handle the rest,” which was precisely what Eugenio had said. Sir Luke seemed to speak of transactions and costs, but in a different currency altogether. These were sums that couldn’t be quantified or even mentioned, and she wasn’t sure she possessed that kind of wealth, anyway. Eugenio—and this was the defining factor—could name figures, could calculate them. And she’d never been afraid of the prices he quoted.

She had been willing, goodness knows, to pay enough for anything, for everything, and here was simply a new perspective on the necessary amount. She amused herself—because it came to that since Eugenio was there to sign the receipt—with the possibilities of meeting the bill. She was more ready than ever to pay enough, and quite as much as ever to pay too much. If your most trusted servant failed in these areas, what else was the point of being, as the dear Susies of the world called you, a princess in a palace?

Translation

She'd have gladly paid anything, for anything, and now here was just another way of looking at how much that would be. She amused herself—since Eugenio was the one writing the check—by considering how she'd cover it. She was more prepared than ever to pay enough, and as eager as ever to overpay. If your most trusted servant couldn't handle this, what was the point of being, as the Susies of the world put it, a princess in a palace?

She made now, alone, the full circuit of the place, noble and peaceful while the summer sea, stirring here and there a curtain or an outer blind, breathed into its veiled spaces. She had a vision of clinging to it; that perhaps Eugenio could manage. She was in it, as in the ark of her deluge, and filled with such a tenderness for it that why shouldn't this, in common mercy, be warrant enough? She would never, never leave it—she would engage to that; would ask nothing more than to sit tight in it and float on and on.

Translation

She completed the entire tour of the place now, alone, feeling noble and serene as the summer sea, occasionally lifting a curtain or an outer blind, breathed into its hidden depths. She envisioned clinging to it, believing that perhaps Eugenio could manage. She was within it, as in the ark of her own flood, and filled with such affection for it that why shouldn't this, in simple mercy, be sufficient guarantee? She would never, never leave it—she'd commit to that; she would ask for nothing more than to remain secure within it and drift on and on.

The beauty and intensity, the real momentary relief of this conceit, reached their climax in the positive purpose to put the question to Eugenio on his return as she had not yet put it; though the design, it must be added, dropped a little when, coming back to the great saloon from which she had started on her pensive progress, she found Lord Mark, of whose arrival in Venice she had been unaware, and who had now—while a servant was following her through empty rooms—been asked, in her absence, to wait. He had waited then, Lord Mark, he was waiting—oh unmistakeably; never before had he so much struck her as the man to do that on occasion with patience, to do it indeed almost as with gratitude for the chance, though at the same time with a sort of notifying firmness. The odd thing, as she was afterwards to recall, was that her wonder for what had brought him was not immediate, but had come at the end of five minutes; and also, quite incoherently, that she felt almost as glad to see him, and almost as forgiving of his interruption of her solitude, as if he had already been in her thought or acting at her suggestion. He was some-how, at the best, the end of a respite; one might like him very much and yet feel that his presence tempered precious solitude more than any other known to one: in spite of all of which, as he was neither dear Susie, nor dear Kate, nor dear Aunt Maud, nor even, for the least, dear Eugenio in person, the sight of him did no damage to her sense of the dispersal of her friends.

Translation

The beauty and intensity, the genuine, fleeting comfort of this idea, reached its peak in her firm resolve to pose the question to Eugenio upon his return, a question she had yet to ask. Though, it must be acknowledged, the plan diminished somewhat when, returning to the grand saloon from which she had begun her thoughtful journey, she encountered Lord Mark. She hadn’t known he was in Venice, and now—while a servant followed her through the empty rooms—he had been asked, in her absence, to wait. He had waited then, Lord Mark; he was waiting—undeniably. Never before had he so struck her as the type of man to do that on occasion, with patience, to do it almost with gratitude for the opportunity, even while exhibiting a certain resolute composure. The strange thing, as she would later remember, was that her curiosity about his purpose didn't immediately arise, but rather arrived after five minutes. Also, quite illogically, she felt almost as pleased to see him, and almost as forgiving of his intrusion upon her solitude, as if he had already been in her thoughts or acting at her suggestion. Somehow, at best, he represented the end of a break; one might enjoy him immensely and still feel that his presence diluted precious solitude more than any other person known to her: despite all of which, as he was neither dear Susie, nor dear Kate, nor dear Aunt Maud, nor, not even in the slightest, dear Eugenio in person, the sight of him didn't diminish her sense of the absence of her friends.

She hadn't been so thoroughly alone with him since those moments of his showing her the great portrait at Matcham, the moments that had exactly made the high-water-mark of her security, the moments during which her tears themselves, those she had been ashamed of, were the sign of her consciously rounding her protective promontory, quitting the blue gulf of comparative ignorance and reaching her view of the troubled sea. His presence now referred itself to his presence then, reminding her how kind he had been, altogether, at Matcham, and telling her, unexpectedly, at a time when she could particularly feel it, that, for such kindness and for the beauty of what they remembered together, she hadn't lost him—quite the contrary. To receive him handsomely, to receive him there, to see him interested and charmed, as well, clearly, as delighted to have found her without some other person to spoil it—these things were so pleasant for the first minutes that they might have represented on her part some happy foreknowledge. She gave an account of her companions while he on his side failed to press her about them, even though describing his appearance, so unheralded, as the result of an impulse obeyed on the spot.

Translation

She hadn’t been this alone with him since the times he'd shown her the huge portrait at Matcham. Those moments had been the high point of her security, the moments when even her tears, the ones she'd been ashamed of, were the sign that she was consciously rounding her protective headland, leaving the blue gulf of relative ignorance and reaching her view of the troubled sea. His presence now was connected to his presence then, reminding her how kind he'd been, all things considered, at Matcham, and telling her, unexpectedly, at a time when she could really feel it, that, because of that kindness and because of the beauty of what they remembered together, she hadn't lost him—quite the opposite. To welcome him gracefully, to welcome him there, to see him interested and charmed, and obviously delighted to have found her without anyone else to ruin it—these things were so pleasant for the first few minutes that it might have seemed like she'd foreseen it somehow. She told him about her friends, while he, for his part, didn’t press her about them, even while describing his arrival, so unexpected, as the result of a sudden impulse.

He had been shivering at Carlsbad, belated there and blue, when taken by it; so that, knowing where they all were, he had simply caught the first train. He explained how he had known where they were; he had heard—what more natural?—from their friends, Milly's and his. He mentioned this betimes, but it was with his mention, singularly, that the girl became conscious of her inner question about his reason. She noticed his plural, which added to Mrs.

Translation

He had been shivering in Carlsbad, late and gloomy, when it had struck him. Knowing where they all were, he had simply taken the first train. He explained how he had known their location. He had heard—how could he not?—from their mutual friends, Milly’s and his own. He brought this up early on, but it was with this mention, strangely, that the girl became aware of her inner question about his motives. She noticed his plural, which added to Mrs.

Lowder or added to Kate; but she presently noticed also that it didn't affect her as explaining. Aunt Maud had written to him, Kate apparently—and this was interesting—had written to him; but their design presumably hadn't been that he should come and sit there as if rather relieved, so far as they were concerned, at postponements. He only said "Oh!" and again "Oh!" when she sketched their probable morning for him, under Eugenio's care and Mrs. Stringham's—sounding it quite as if any suggestion that he should overtake them at the Rialto or the Bridge of Sighs would leave him temporarily cold.

Translation

Lowder, or added to Kate; but she presently noticed also that it didn't serve as an explanation. Aunt Maud had written to him; Kate, apparently—and this was interesting—had written to him; but their intention, presumably, hadn't been that he should come and sit there as if relieved, so far as they were concerned, by delays. He only said "Oh!" and again "Oh!" when she described their likely morning for him, under Eugenio's care and Mrs. Stringham's—sounding as if any suggestion that he should catch up with them at the Rialto or the Bridge of Sighs would leave him temporarily uninterested.

This precisely it was that, after a little, operated for Milly as an obscure but still fairly direct check to confidence. He had known where they all were from the others, but it was not for the others that, in his actual dispositions, he had come. That, strange to say, was a pity; for, stranger still to say, she could have shown him more confidence if he himself had had less intention. His intention so chilled her, from the moment she found herself divining it, that, just for the pleasure of going on with him fairly, just for the pleasure of their remembrance together of Matcham and the Bronzino, the climax of her fortune, she could have fallen to pleading with him and to reasoning, to undeceiving him in time.

Translation

This, precisely, was what, after a little while, worked on Milly as an unclear but still quite direct check to her confidence. He had known where they all were from the others, but it wasn't for the others that, in his actual state of mind, he had come. That, strangely enough, was a pity; because, even stranger to say, she could have shown him more confidence if he himself had had less intention. His intention so chilled her, from the moment she found herself guessing it, that, just for the pleasure of continuing with him fairly, just for the pleasure of their shared memory of Matcham and the Bronzino, the high point of her fortune, she could have started pleading with him and reasoning, to disabuse him in time.

There had been, for ten minutes, with the directness of her welcome to him and the way this clearly pleased him, something of the grace of amends made, even though he couldn't know it—amends for her not having been originally sure, for instance at that first dinner of Aunt Maud's, that he was adequately human. That first dinner of Aunt Maud's added itself to the hour at Matcham, added itself to other things, to consolidate, for her present benevolence, the ease of their relation, making it suddenly delightful that he had thus turned up. He exclaimed, as he looked about, on the charm of the place: "What a temple to taste and an expression of the pride of life, yet, with all that, what a jolly home!"—so that, for his entertainment, she could offer to walk him about though she mentioned that she had just been, for her own purposes, in a general prowl, taking everything in more susceptibly than before. He embraced her offer without a scruple and seemed to rejoice that he was to find her susceptible.

Translation

For ten minutes, her warm welcome and the clear pleasure it gave him had possessed a kind of graceful recompense. It was a recompense he couldn't know he was receiving, a recompense for her original uncertainty, like at Aunt Maud's first dinner, where she hadn't been sure he was quite human. That first dinner at Aunt Maud's joined the hour at Matcham and other memories, solidifying the comfort of their connection and making his unexpected arrival suddenly delightful. He looked around and exclaimed at the place's charm: "What a temple to taste, an expression of life's pride, yet what a jolly home!" For his amusement, she offered to show him around, though she mentioned she'd just been on a personal prowl, absorbing everything with greater sensitivity than usual. He eagerly accepted and seemed pleased that she was so receptive.

She now took a complete walk through the place by herself, which felt both majestic and tranquil while the summer sea gently moved curtains or blinds, subtly affecting its enclosed spaces. She imagined holding onto it; perhaps Eugenio could manage things. She was in it, like in a safe haven from a storm, and felt such affection for it that this, in simple kindness, should be enough. She would never, ever leave it—she was determined; she would only want to stay put and keep floating on.

Translation

Now she explored the entire place alone, a feeling of both grandeur and peace settling in as the summer sea softly stirred the curtains or blinds, subtly influencing the interior. She pictured herself holding onto it; perhaps Eugenio could manage everything. She was within it, a sanctuary from any tempest, and felt such fondness that this, simply, should suffice. She would never, ever abandon it—she was resolved; she only wanted to remain and continue drifting.

The beauty and emotional intensity, the genuine, temporary relief of this idea reached its peak in the firm intention to ask Eugenio about it when he returned, as she hadn't yet. However, this plan faded a little when, returning to the large room where she had started her thoughtful walk, she found Lord Mark. She hadn't realized he was in Venice, and he had been asked to wait while a servant led her through the empty rooms. He had waited, Lord Mark, he was waiting—clearly; never before had he seemed so much the type to do that patiently, to do it almost with gratitude for the opportunity, while also displaying a kind of noticeable firmness.

Translation

The appeal of this thought, its beauty and emotional charge, the true, passing solace it offered, reached its height in her firm resolve to discuss it with Eugenio upon his return, a conversation she hadn't yet initiated. Yet, this conviction softened somewhat when she returned to the expansive room where her musings had begun, and found Lord Mark. She hadn’t known he was in Venice, and he’d been asked to wait while a servant guided her through the empty space. He had waited, Lord Mark, he was waiting—undeniably; never before had he seemed so perfectly suited to wait patiently, to do it almost gratefully, while also radiating a palpable sense of resolve.

The odd thing, as she would later recall, was that she didn't immediately wonder why he was there, but it came to her after five minutes. Also, quite strangely, she felt almost as happy to see him, and almost as forgiving of his interruption of her solitude, as if he had already been on her mind or acting according to her wishes. At best, he was like the end of a break; one might like him very much and still feel that his presence spoiled precious solitude more than anyone else's: despite all this, since he wasn't dear Susie, or dear Kate, or dear Aunt Maud, or even, in the slightest, dear Eugenio in person, seeing him didn't bother her sense of her friends being away. She hadn't been so completely alone with him since those moments when he showed her the great portrait at Matcham, moments that were the high point of her sense of security, the moments when even her tears, which she had been ashamed of, showed that she was consciously rounding her protective headland, leaving the blue gulf of relative ignorance and seeing the troubled sea.

Translation

The strange thing, as she would later remember it, was that she didn’t immediately wonder why he was there, but it occurred to her after five minutes. And, rather oddly, she felt almost as happy to see him, and almost as understanding of his disrupting her solitude, as though he’d already been on her mind or acting in accordance with her desires. At best, he was like the end of a vacation; one could like him very much and still feel that his presence spoiled precious solitude more than anyone else's: despite all that, since he wasn’t dear Susie, or dear Kate, or dear Aunt Maud, or even, not in the slightest, dear Eugenio in person, seeing him didn't make her feel the absence of her friends. She hadn’t been so completely alone with him since those times when he showed her the grand portrait at Matcham, moments that were the high point of her sense of security, the times when even her tears, which she had been ashamed of, showed that she was consciously turning the corner of her protective headland, leaving behind the blue gulf of relative ignorance and seeing the troubled sea.

His presence now reminded her of his presence then, reminding her of how kind he had been, overall, at Matcham, and telling her unexpectedly, at a time when she could particularly feel it, that, because of that kindness and the beauty of what they remembered together, she hadn't lost him—quite the opposite. To welcome him gracefully, to welcome him there, to see him interested and charmed, and clearly delighted to have found her without anyone else to bother it—these things were so pleasant for the first few minutes that they could have seemed like a happy prediction on her part. She described her companions while he, in turn, didn't press her about them, even though he said his unannounced arrival was the result of a sudden impulse. He had been shivering in Carlsbad, late and feeling down, when he decided to come; so, knowing where they all were, he had simply taken the first train.

Translation

His presence now reminded her of his presence then, reminding her of how kind he had been, overall, at Matcham. It unexpectedly told her, at a time when she could particularly feel it, that because of that kindness and the beauty of what they remembered together, she hadn't lost him—quite the opposite. To welcome him gracefully, to welcome him there, to see him interested and charmed, and clearly delighted to have found her without anyone else to bother it—these things were so pleasant for the first few minutes that they could have seemed like a happy prediction on her part. She described her companions while he, in turn, didn't press her about them, even though he said his unannounced arrival was the result of a sudden impulse. He had been shivering in Carlsbad, late and feeling down, when he decided to come; so, knowing where they all were, he had simply taken the first train.

He explained how he knew where they were; he had heard—what could be more natural?—from their friends, Milly's and his. He mentioned this early on, but it was with his words that the girl became aware of her inner question about his reason. She noticed his use of the plural, which included Mrs. Lowder or Kate; but she also noticed that it didn't explain anything to her.

Translation

He explained how he knew their location; it was, naturally, through their mutual friends, his and Milly's. He brought this up early on, but it was with his words that the girl became aware of her inner question about his reason for being there. She noted his use of the plural, which included Mrs. Lowder and Kate; however, she realized it didn’t clarify anything for her.

Aunt Maud had written to him, Kate apparently—and this was interesting—had written to him; but they probably didn't intend for him to come and sit there as if somewhat relieved, so far as they were concerned, by delays. He only said "Oh!" and again "Oh!" when she described their likely morning, under Eugenio's care and Mrs. Stringham's—saying it as if any suggestion that he should join them at the Rialto or the Bridge of Sighs would leave him temporarily uninterested. This, after a little while, was what subtly but clearly undermined her confidence.

Translation

Aunt Maud had written to him, and apparently Kate had written to him as well. This was interesting. But they probably didn't want him to just show up and sit there, as if somewhat relieved, as far as they were concerned, by delays. He only said "Oh!" and again "Oh!" when she described their probable morning, under Eugenio's care and Mrs. Stringham's. He said it as if any suggestion that he should join them at the Rialto or the Bridge of Sighs would leave him temporarily uninterested. After a little while, this was what subtly but clearly undermined her confidence.

He had known where they all were from the others, but it wasn't for the others that he had actually come. That, strangely, was a pity; because, even stranger to say, she could have shown him more trust if he himself hadn't had so much intention. His intention chilled her from the moment she began to guess it, that, just for the pleasure of keeping things friendly with him, just for the pleasure of remembering Matcham and the Bronzino together, the peak of her good fortune, she could have started pleading with him and reasoning, to correct his wrong ideas in time. For ten minutes, with her warm welcome to him and the way he clearly liked it, there was a feeling of making amends, even though he couldn't know it—amends for her not having been sure of him, for instance at Aunt Maud's first dinner, that he was truly a human being.

Translation

He'd learned their locations from the others, but his actual reason for coming wasn't because of them. Oddly, that was a shame. Even stranger to say, she would have felt more trust if he hadn't been so intent on something. His intention had chilled her from the moment she began to suspect it: that, just to maintain a friendly atmosphere, just to enjoy the memory of Matcham and the Bronzino together, the high point of her life, she could have begun to plead with him and reason with him, to correct his mistaken assumptions. For ten minutes, with her warm welcome and his obvious enjoyment of it, there was a sense of reconciliation, even though he couldn't know it—reconciliation for her uncertainty about him, such as at Aunt Maud's first dinner, about whether he was truly human.

That first dinner at Aunt Maud's added itself to the time at Matcham, added itself to other things, to reinforce, with her present goodwill, the ease of their relationship, making it suddenly wonderful that he had shown up. He exclaimed as he looked around, about the charm of the place: "What a temple to good taste and an expression of the pride of life, and yet, with all that, what a wonderful home!"—so that, for his entertainment, she could offer to walk him around, even though she mentioned that she had just been, for her own purposes, on a general exploration, taking everything in more sensitively than before. He accepted her offer without hesitation and seemed pleased that he would find her receptive.

Translation

That first dinner at Aunt Maud's was added to Matcham, and to other things, bolstering the ease of their relationship with her current good feelings, making it suddenly wonderful that he'd appeared. Looking around, he exclaimed about the place's charm: "What a temple to good taste, an expression of the pride of life, and yet, with all that, what a wonderful home!"—so that, for his amusement, she could offer to walk him around, even though she mentioned she'd just been, for her own purposes, on a general exploration, taking everything in more sensitively than before. He accepted her offer without hesitation and seemed pleased that she would be receptive.

Chapter 10

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Densher, disliking his hotel in Venice, takes his first walk alone after having spent the previous two days at Palazzo Leporelli, mostly indoors due to bad weather. During his walk, he emerges onto a traghetto (a ferry stop) and sees a "for rent" sign on the green shutters of a small apartment he once occupied. He recalls recently being out with Mrs. Lowder, Mrs. Stringham, and Kate, when Mrs. Lowder publicly instructed him to leave them and return to Milly Theale at the palace. He obeyed and sat with Milly alone until the others returned for tea. After leaving the palace, feeling irritated, he stands at the traghetto for fifteen minutes looking at his old apartment across the canal. Deciding to rent the rooms as a test of his will, he ignores a ferryman and instead walks a longer route, crossing the Rialto bridge. He finds the rooms are unoccupied, speaks with the landlady, and arranges to move in the next day. That evening at dinner at the palace, he tells the group about his new rooms. His hostess, Milly Theale, asks him to invite her over for tea. He agrees to her request, but internally resolves that he will not actually host her there. He also recalls that he came to Venice because Mrs. Lowder had written to invite him. He continues to spend time with the group at the palace, having occasional private moments with Kate.

She couldn't have said what it was, in the conditions, that renewed the whole solemnity, but by the end of twenty minutes a kind of wistful hush had fallen upon them, as before something poignant in which her visitor also participated. That was nothing verily but the perfection of the charm—or nothing rather but their excluded disinherited state in the presence of it. The charm turned on them a face that was cold in its beauty, that was full of a poetry never to be theirs, that spoke with an ironic smile of a possible but forbidden life. It all rolled afresh over Milly: "Oh the impossible romance—!" The romance for her, yet once more, would be to sit there for ever, through all her time, as in a fortress; and the idea became an image of never going down, of remaining aloft in the divine dustless air, where she would hear but the plash of the water against stone.

Translation

She couldn’t say what it was, given the circumstances, that revived the feeling of solemnity. But after about twenty minutes, a kind of wistful silence fell upon them, as though they were observing something poignant, and her visitor was also participating. It was nothing but the charm's perfection, or rather their exclusion, their disinheritance in its presence. The charm presented them with a face cold in its beauty, brimming with a poetry they would never know, and speaking with an ironic smile of a possible but forbidden life. It all resurfaced for Milly: "Oh, the impossible romance!" The romance, for her, would be to sit there forever, through all her days, as if in a fortress. The idea transformed into an image of never going down, of remaining aloft in the divine, dustless air, where she could only hear the water lapping against the stone.

The great floor on which they moved was at an altitude, and this prompted the rueful fancy. "Ah not to go down—never, never to go down!" she strangely sighed to her friend. IV She wasn't sure what it was about the circumstances

...cold beauty, a beauty brimming with poetry they could never possess, and her ironic smile suggested a possible, yet forbidden life. It all washed over Milly again: "Oh, the impossible...

romance—!" The romance for her, once more, was to sit there forever, through all her days, as if in a fortress. The idea became an image of never descending, of remaining aloft in the pristine, dust-free air, where she

Translation

...could contemplate, and condemn, and never be touched. She could feel herself turning to ice, a flawless, glacial statue, an object of wonder, an enigma. The world, the world below, a teeming, messy, passionate place, would be always and forever beyond her grasp.

would hear only the lapping of water against stone. The vast floor they walked upon was at such a height, and this spurred the wistful thought.

Translation

She would hear only the gentle sounds of water against the unyielding stone. The immense expanse they walked upon was elevated to such a degree, and this prompted a melancholy reflection.

"Ah, not to go down—never, never to go down!" she strangely sighed to her friend. "But why shouldn't you," he asked, "with that tremendous old staircase in your court?

Translation

"Oh, never, never to descend!" she strangely sighed to her friend. "But why shouldn't you," he asked, "with that enormous old staircase in your court?"

There ought of course always to be people at top and bottom, in Veronese costumes, to watch you do it." She shook her head both lightly and mournfully enough at his not understanding. "Not even for people in Veronese costumes. I mean that the positive beauty is that one needn't go down.

Translation

"There should always be people, of course, at the top and the bottom, in Veronese costumes, to watch you do it." She shook her head, lightly and mournfully, at his lack of understanding. "Not even for people in Veronese costumes. I mean, the true beauty of it is that one doesn't have to go down."

I don't move in fact," she added—"now. I've not been out, you know. I stay up. That's how you happily found me."

Translation

I don't actually move," she added, "anymore. I haven't been out, you know. I stay up here. That's how you happily found me."

Lord Mark wondered—he was, oh yes, adequately human. "You don't go about?" She looked over the place, the storey above the apartments in which she had received him, the sala corresponding to the sala below and fronting the great canal with its gothic arches. The casements between the arches were open, the ledge of the balcony broad, the sweep of the canal, so overhung, admirable, and the flutter toward them of the loose white curtain an invitation to she scarce could have said what.

Translation

Lord Mark wondered—he was, yes, reasonably human. "You don't go out?" She surveyed the space, the floor above the apartments where she'd received him, the grand room mirroring the one beneath, facing the wide canal with its gothic arches. The windows set within the arches were open, the balcony ledge spacious, the expanse of the canal, so overhanging, striking, and the flutter of the loose white curtain towards them an invitation to she could barely define what.

But there was no mystery after a moment; she had never felt so invited to anything as to make that, and that only, just where she was, her adventure. It would be—to this it kept coming back—the adventure of not stirring. "I go about just here." "But why not," he inquired, "with that extraordinary old staircase in your building?

Translation

But after a moment, the mystery vanished. She'd never felt so drawn to anything as she did to making this, and only this, her adventure, right where she was. It would be—she kept returning to this thought—the adventure of not moving. "I just stay here." "But why not," he asked, "explore that extraordinary old staircase in your building?"

Ideally, there should always be people at the top and bottom, in the style of Veronese paintings, to observe you descend." She gently shook her head, a hint of sadness in her expression, at his lack of comprehension. "Not even for people in Veronese costumes. The true beauty lies in the fact that one doesn't have to go down.

Translation

"Ideally, there should always be people at the top and bottom, like in Veronese paintings, watching you go down." She shook her head softly, a flicker of sadness in her eyes, at his not understanding. "Not even for people in Veronese costumes. The real beauty is that you don't have to go down."

The truth is, I don't move," she added, "not anymore. I haven't been outside, you see. I remain upstairs. That's how you found me."

Translation

The truth is, I don't move," she added, "not anymore. I haven't been outside, you see. I remain upstairs. That's how you found me."

Lord Mark considered this - yes, he was, in fact, a reasonably perceptive person. "You don't go anywhere?" She surveyed the space, the floor above the rooms where she had received him, the grand hall echoing the one below, overlooking the large canal with its Gothic arches. The windows between the arches were open, the balcony ledge wide, the curve of the canal, so dramatically framed, beautiful, and the way the loose, white curtain moved toward them was an invitation to she barely knew what.

Translation

Lord Mark pondered her words, acknowledging his own capacity for observation. "You never leave?" She looked around, at the level above the rooms where they had met, at the magnificent hall mirroring the one below, overlooking the broad canal with its Gothic arches. The windows set within the arches were open, the balcony ledge expansive, the curve of the canal, so exquisitely framed, beautiful, and the way the airy, white curtain drifted toward them was an enticement to something she couldn't quite define.

But there was no mystery after a moment; she had never felt so drawn to anything as to make that, and that alone, right where she was, her adventure. It would be - this was the core of it - the adventure of remaining still. "I go about only here." "Do you mean," Lord Mark presently asked, "that you're really not well?"

Translation

But the mystery evaporated quickly. She’d never felt so compelled to anything as to make that, right there, her adventure. It would be—this was the heart of it—the adventure of staying still. “I only move around here.”

“Do you mean,” Lord Mark asked shortly, “that you’re actually unwell?”

They were at the window, pausing, lingering, with the fine old faded palaces opposite and the slow Adriatic tide beneath; but after a minute, and before she answered, she had closed her eyes to what she saw and unresistingly dropped her face into her arms, which rested on the coping. She had fallen to her knees on the cushion of the window-place, and she leaned there, in a long silence, with her forehead down. She knew that her silence was itself too straight an answer, but it was beyond her now to say that she saw her way. She would have made the question itself impossible to others—impossible for example to such a man as Merton Densher; and she could wonder even on the spot what it was a sign of in her feeling for Lord Mark that from his lips it almost tempted her to break down.

Translation

They stood at the window, lingering, the old faded palaces across the way, the slow Adriatic tide below. But after a minute, before she could answer, she closed her eyes to what she saw, dropping her face into her arms, which rested on the ledge. She’d sunk to her knees on the window seat, leaning there in a long silence, her forehead down. She knew her silence was too direct an answer, but she couldn’t see her way now. She would have made the question itself impossible for others—impossible for a man like Merton Densher, for instance; and she could even wonder there, what it meant in her feelings for Lord Mark that from his lips it almost tempted her to break down.

This was doubtless really because she cared for him so little; to let herself go with him thus, suffer his touch to make her cup overflow, would be the relief—since it was actually, for her nerves, a question of relief—that would cost her least. If he had come to her moreover with the intention she believed, or even if this intention had but been determined in him by the spell of their situation, he mustn't be mistaken about her value—for what value did she now have? It throbbed within her as she knelt there that she had none at all; though, holding herself, not yet speaking, she tried, even in the act, to recover what might be possible of it. With that there came to her a light: wouldn't her value, for the man who should marry her, be precisely in the ravage of her disease?

Translation

This was likely because she cared for him so little. To allow herself to go with him like this, to let his touch make her cup overflow, would be the easiest thing. It would be a relief—since it was, for her nerves, a question of relief—and it would cost her the least. If he had come to her with the intention she believed, or even if this intention had only been determined in him by the spell of their situation, he mustn't be mistaken about her value—because what value did she have now? It throbbed within her as she knelt there that she had none at all; though, holding herself, not yet speaking, she tried, even in the act, to recover what might be possible of it. With that, a light came to her: wouldn't her value, for the man who should marry her, be precisely in the ravage of her disease?

She mightn't last, but her money would. For a man in whom the vision of her money should be intense, in whom it should be most of the ground for "making up" to her, any prospective failure on her part to be long for this world might easily count as a positive attraction. Such a man, proposing to please, persuade, secure her, appropriate her for such a time, shorter or longer, as nature and the doctors should allow, would make the best of her, ill, damaged, disagreeable though she might be, for the sake of eventual benefits: she being clearly a person of the sort esteemed likely to do the handsome thing by a stricken and sorrowing husband. "Are you saying," Lord Mark finally asked, "that you're actually sick?"

Translation

She might not live long, but her money would. For a man who was fixated on her money, for whom it would be the primary reason for pursuing her, any chance of her not being around for long might easily be seen as an advantage. Such a man, trying to please her, persuade her, secure her, and possess her for whatever time, short or long, nature and the doctors would permit, would take what he could from her, sick, damaged, and unpleasant as she might be, for the sake of the eventual payoff: she was clearly the type of person who would be expected to take care of a grieving and sorrowful husband. "Are you saying," Lord Mark finally asked, "that you're actually sick?"

They were at the window, lingering there, looking out at the beautiful, old, decaying palaces across the way and the slow Adriatic waters below. After a moment, before she could respond, she closed her eyes, shutting out the view, and lowered her face into her arms, which were resting on the windowsill. She had knelt on the window seat's cushion, leaning there in silence, her forehead against her arms. She knew that her silence was an answer in itself, too direct, but she couldn't see how to respond now.

Translation

They stood at the window, still there, gazing at the beautiful, ancient, crumbling palaces opposite and the sluggish Adriatic Sea beneath. After a moment, before she could reply, she closed her eyes, blocking out the view, and lowered her face into her arms, which were resting on the windowsill. She had knelt on the window seat's cushion, leaning there silently, her forehead against her arms. She knew her silence was an answer in itself, too straightforward, but she couldn't figure out how to respond just then.

She would have preferred to make the question itself impossible for anyone, especially for someone like Merton Densher. She even wondered right then what it meant about her feelings for Lord Mark that his question almost made her want to break down. It was probably because she cared for him so little; letting herself go with him, letting his presence overwhelm her, would be the easiest way to find some relief—and she desperately needed relief for her frayed nerves. Furthermore, if he had come to her with the intention she believed, or even if the situation had only inspired his intentions, he must not misunderstand her value—because what value did she have now?

Translation

She would have preferred to make the question itself unaskable for anyone, and especially for someone like Merton Densher. She wondered, even in that moment, what it said about her feelings for Lord Mark that his question nearly made her want to fall apart. It was likely because she cared so little for him; giving in, letting herself be consumed by his presence, would be the easiest way to find some respite—and she desperately needed to soothe her frazzled nerves. Besides, if he had come to her with the intentions she believed, or even if the circumstances had merely prompted such intentions, he mustn't misunderstand her worth—because what worth did she have now?

It struck her as she knelt there that she had none at all; though, holding herself together and not speaking, she tried, even while kneeling, to salvage some sense of her value. Then she realized something: wouldn't her value, for the man who would marry her, be precisely in the damage of her illness? She might not live long, but her money would. For a man who was most intensely focused on her money, for whom that was the primary reason to court her, the prospect of her dying soon could easily be seen as an advantage.

Translation

It hit her, kneeling, that she had no value whatsoever. Even as she remained composed and silent, she tried, still on her knees, to recover some sense of her worth. Then she understood something: wouldn't her value, to the man who would marry her, lie exactly in the damage her illness had caused? She might not live long, but her money would. For a man who was most intensely focused on her money, for whom that was the only reason to court her, the possibility of her dying soon might easily be seen as an advantage.

Such a man, trying to please her, persuade her, secure her, and possess her for whatever time she had left, however long or short, would make the most of her, even if she were sick, damaged, and unpleasant, for the sake of the eventual financial gain. She was, after all, clearly the type of woman expected to be generous to a grieving husband. She had said to herself betimes, in a general way, that whatever habits her youth might form, that of seeing an interested suitor in every bush should certainly never grow to be one of them—an attitude she had early judged as ignoble, as poisonous. She had had accordingly in fact as little to do with it as possible and she scarce knew why at the present moment she should have had to catch herself in the act of imputing an ugly motive.

Translation

Such a man, in the effort to please her, to convince her, to secure her affections, and to possess her for whatever time she had remaining—whether a long or short period—would make the most of her, even if she were ill, damaged, and difficult. He would do this all for the eventual financial gain. After all, she was clearly the type of woman who would be expected to be generous to a grieving husband. She had often told herself, in a general way, that no matter what habits her youth might form, the habit of seeing an interested suitor in every bush was one she would never allow to develop. She had always considered such an attitude ignoble and poisonous. Accordingly, she had avoided such thinking as much as possible, and she scarcely knew why she had caught herself at this moment, assigning an ugly motive.

It didn't sit, the ugly motive, in Lord Mark's cool English eyes; the darker side of it at any rate showed, to her imagination, but briefly. Suspicion moreover, with this, simplified itself: there was a beautiful reason—indeed there were two—why her companion's motive shouldn't matter. One was that even should he desire her without a penny she wouldn't marry him for the world; the other was that she felt him, after all, perceptively, kindly, very pleasantly and humanly, concerned for her. They were also two things, his wishing to be well, to be very well, with her, and his beginning to feel her as threatened, haunted, blighted; but they were melting together for him, making him, by their combination, only the more sure that, as he probably called it to himself, he liked her.

Translation

That ugly motive didn't fit, not in Lord Mark's cool English eyes. Its darker side flickered, in her imagination, but only briefly. Furthermore, suspicion simplified itself: there was a good reason—in fact, two—why her companion's motive shouldn't matter. One was that even if he wanted her without any money, she wouldn't marry him for anything; the other was that she felt him, despite everything, to be perceptive, kind, very pleasant, and humanly concerned for her. His desire to be on good terms with her, to be very much on good terms with her, was also present, as was his growing sense of her being threatened, haunted, blighted. But these two things were merging for him, and their combination only made him more certain that, as he probably put it to himself, he liked her.

That was presently what remained with her—his really doing it; and with the natural and proper incident of being conciliated by her weakness. Would she really have had him—she could ask herself that—disconcerted or disgusted by it? If he could only be touched enough to do what she preferred, not to raise, not to press any question, he might render her a much better service than by merely enabling her to refuse him. Again, again it was strange, but he figured to her for the moment as the one safe sympathiser.

Translation

That was what she took away from the moment—the fact that he had actually done it; and the appropriate consequence of his being won over by her vulnerability. Could she really ask herself if she would have preferred him—disconcerted or disgusted by it? If he could be moved enough to do what she wanted, to avoid questions or pressure, he might serve her better than by simply allowing her to refuse him. Again, it was strange, but for the moment, he seemed to her the only safe person to confide in.

It would have made her worse to talk to others, but she wasn't afraid with him of how he might wince and look pale. She would keep him, that is, her one easy relation—in the sense of easy for himself. Their actual outlook had meanwhile such charm, what surrounded them within and without did so much toward making appreciative stillness as natural as at the opera, that she could consider she hadn't made him hang on her lips when at last, instead of saying if she were well or ill, she repeated: "I go about here. I don't get tired of it.

Translation

Talking to anyone else would have been detrimental, but with him, she wasn't worried about him flinching or turning pale. She would keep him, her only easy relationship—easy for him, that is. Their shared perspective had so much appeal, and their environment, both internal and external, contributed so much to an atmosphere of appreciative stillness, like at the opera. She could consider she hadn't made him wait on her words when, instead of asking if she felt well or unwell, she finally repeated: "I just walk around here. I don't get tired of it."

I never should—it suits me so. I adore the place," she went on, "and I don't want in the least to give it up." She had told herself, from time to time, that whatever habits her youth might foster, she would never become the type who sees a potential lover lurking behind every corner. She had always considered that attitude to be contemptible and toxic.

Translation

"I never should—it suits me so. I adore the place," she continued, "and I don't want in the least to give it up." She had told herself, from time to time, that whatever habits her youth might foster, she would never become the type who sees a potential lover lurking behind every corner. She had always considered that attitude to be contemptible and toxic.

As a result, she had avoided it as much as possible. Now, she didn't understand why she found herself attributing a negative motive to him. That dark motive didn't fit with Lord Mark's calm, composed demeanor. In her imagination, at least, the uglier side of it was only briefly visible.

Translation

Consequently, she'd done her best to steer clear. Now, she was baffled by her instinct to suspect him of ill intent. This dark impulse didn't align with Lord Mark's placid, collected manner. In her mind, the uglier side of it was only fleetingly apparent.

Furthermore, her suspicion was simplified by this: there was a beautiful reason—in fact, two reasons—why his motives shouldn't matter. One was that even if he desired her without any money, she wouldn't marry him for anything. The other was that she felt he was, in fact, perceptively, kindly, and very pleasantly and humanly, concerned for her. There were also two things at play: his desire to be friendly with her, and his perception of her as threatened, haunted, and damaged.

Translation

In addition, her suspicions were straightforward because there were two obvious reasons his motives were irrelevant. The first was that even if he wanted her without her fortune, she wouldn’t marry him no matter what. The second was that she felt he was genuinely, kindly, and in a pleasant, human way, concerned for her. There were also two dynamics at play: his desire to be friendly, and his perception of her as someone who was threatened, haunted, and wounded.

However, these things were merging for him, making him even more certain—as he probably told himself—that he liked her. That was what remained with her: his genuine affection for her, along with the natural inclination to be sympathetic because of her vulnerability. Would she have preferred him to be uncomfortable or disgusted by her? If he could be moved enough to do what she wanted, not to ask questions or press the issue, he could be of much more help than simply allowing her to reject him.

Translation

Yet these factors were converging, reinforcing his conviction—as he likely rationalized—that he was fond of her. What resonated with her was his authentic fondness, intertwined with a natural tendency to be empathetic due to her fragility. Would she have preferred him to be repulsed or unsettled by her? If he could be swayed to act in accordance with her wishes, refraining from interrogation or persistence, he could be far more useful than if he simply allowed her to rebuff him.

Again, it was strange, but he appeared to her at that moment as the only safe person to confide in. Talking to others would have made things worse, but she wasn't afraid of his reaction—how he might wince or turn pale. She would keep him, that is, her only easy relationship—easy for him. Their surroundings had so much charm, both inside and out, making appreciative silence as natural as it would be at the opera.

Translation

Once more, it was peculiar, but he seemed, at that instant, the sole individual with whom she could safely share her thoughts. Speaking with anyone else would only complicate matters. Yet, she didn't fear his response, the possibility of a flinch or a blanch. She would maintain him, that is, the sole uncomplicated connection she had—uncomplicated for him. The environment they shared was so pleasant, both indoors and out, rendering a shared, appreciative silence as effortless as it would be at a performance.

She thought she hadn't made him wait for her words when, instead of asking if she was well, she said, "I walk around here. I don't get tired of it. I never would—it suits me so. I adore this place," she continued, "and I don't want to give it up at all."

Translation

She believed she hadn't left him hanging when, rather than asking about her health, she simply said, "I wander around here. I never get tired of it. Never will—it's perfect for me. I love this place," she continued, "and I don't want to leave it behind at all."

"Neither should I if I had your luck. Still, with that luck, for one's all—! Should you positively like to live here?" "I think I should like," said poor Milly after an instant, "to die here."

Translation

"I wouldn't either, if I had your fortune. But even with all that, all of it—! Would you really want to live here?" "I think," poor Milly replied after a beat, "I'd like to die here."

Which made him, precisely, laugh. That was what she wanted—when a person did care: it was the pleasant human way, without depths of darkness. "Oh it's not good enough for that! That requires picking.

Translation

Which, of course, made him laugh. That was exactly what she wanted – when someone actually cared: it was the nice, normal way, with no hidden despair. "Oh, it's not good enough for that! That requires selection."

But can't you keep it? It is, you know, the sort of place to see you in; you carry out the note, fill it, people it, quite by yourself, and you might do much worse—I mean for your friends—than show yourself here a while, three or four months, every year. But it's not my notion for the rest of the time. One has quite other uses for you."

Translation

"But can't you just stay there?" she asked. "It's the kind of place that suits you, you know? You'd take care of it, make it lively, fill it up all on your own, and you could do much worse—I mean, for your friends—than staying here for a while, three or four months every year. But that's not what I envision for the rest of your time. I have other plans for you."

"I wouldn't want to live here either, if I had your good fortune. Even with that good fortune, it's everything, isn't it? Would you actually want to live here?" "I think I'd like," Milly said after a moment, "to die here."

Translation

"I wouldn't want to live here either, if I were you. Even with all the advantages, it's just everything, isn't it? Would you actually want to live here?" "I think I'd like," Milly said after a pause, "to die here."

Which made him laugh, exactly. That was what she wanted when a person did care: it was the friendly, human way, without any hints of sadness. "Oh, it's not the right place for that! That requires a specific kind of setting.

Translation

Which made him laugh, precisely. That was the point of it, when a person did care: it was the kind, human approach, free of any mournfulness. "Oh, this isn't the location for that! That needs a particular sort of scene."

But can't you keep it? You know, it's the kind of place that suits you; you embody it, complete it, and make it your own. You could do much worse—I mean for your friends—than to spend some time here, three or four months every year. But it's not my idea for the rest of your life.

Translation

But couldn't you stay here? It's the right kind of place for you, you fit in, you make it whole, you own it. You could do far worse for your friends than spend some time here, three or four months a year. But I don't see you spending the rest of your life here.

I have other things I want you to do." "What sort of a use for me is it," she smilingly enquired, "to kill me?" "Do you mean we should kill you in England?" "Well, I've seen you and I'm afraid.

Translation

"I have other plans for you." She asked with a smile, "What good will it do you to kill me?" "Do you mean we'd kill you in England?" "Well, I've seen you, and I'm afraid."

You're too much for me—too many. England bristles with questions. This is more, as you say there, my form." "Oho, oho!"—he laughed again as if to humour her.

Translation

You're too much for me, too many things. England is bristling with questions. This is more, as you put it, my true nature." "Oho, oho!" he laughed again as if to appease her.

"Can't you then buy it—for a price? Depend upon it they'll treat for money. That is for money enough." "I've exactly," she said, "been wondering if they won't.

Translation

"Couldn't you just buy it—if the price is right? I'm sure they'd negotiate. Everything has a price, as long as it's high enough." "Exactly," she said, "I was just considering the same thing."

I think I shall try. But if I get it I shall cling to it." They were talking sincerely. "It will be my life—paid for as that. It will become my great gilded shell; so that those who wish to find me must come and hunt me up."

Translation

I think I will try. But if I get it, I will cling to it." They were speaking sincerely. "It will be my life, paid for in that way. It will become my great, gilded shell, so that those who wish to find me will have to come and hunt me out."

"What good am I to you," she asked with a smile, "if you kill me?" "Do you mean we would kill you in England?" "Well, I've seen you, and I'm frightened. You're too much for me—too many.

Translation

"What use would I be to you," she asked, smiling, "if you killed me?" "Are you suggesting we'd kill you in England?" "Well, I've seen you, and I'm frightened. You're too much for me—too many of you."

England is full of questions. This is more...my true form, as you put it." "Oh, ho!" he laughed, as if to indulge her. "Can't you then purchase it—for a price?

Translation

England is rife with inquiries. This is more like…my authentic self, the way you phrased it." "Oh, ho!" he chuckled, as if to humor her. "Can’t you buy it—at a cost?"

You can be certain they'll negotiate for money. That is, for enough money." "I've been wondering, exactly," she said, "if they won't. I believe I will try.

Translation

They'll definitely haggle over the price. That is, if the price is high enough." "That's precisely what I've been considering," she replied, "whether they will refuse. I think I'll give it a shot."

But if I get it, I'll hold onto it." They were speaking earnestly. "It will be my life—bought in that way. It will become my grand, extravagant shell; so that anyone who wants to find me will have to search me out." "Ah then you will be alive," said Lord Mark.

Translation

"But if I get it, I'll keep it." They spoke with conviction. "It will be my life—purchased that way. It will become my grand, extravagant facade; anyone who wants to find me will have to look through it." "Ah, then you will truly be alive," said Lord Mark.

"Well, not quite extinct perhaps, but shrunken, wasted, wizened; rattling about here like the dried kernel of a nut." "Oh," Lord Mark returned, "we, much as you mistrust us, can do better for you than that." "In the sense that you'll feel it better for me really to have it over?" He let her see now that she worried him, and after a look at her, of some duration, without his glasses—which always altered the expression of his eyes—he re-settled the nippers on his nose and went back to the view.

Translation

"Well, maybe not completely extinct, but diminished, shriveled, withered; rattling around here like a dried-up nut." "Oh," Lord Mark replied, "We can do better for you than that, even though you don't trust us."

Translation

"Yes, you could be very helpful to me. I understood that completely." "The thing is," he continued, despite what she'd said, "I wanted to gain your trust. You know, to have it where it matters."

"Well, Lord Mark, you did—my trust is exactly where you placed it then. The only difference," said Milly, "is that it seems I have no use for it now. Besides," she then added, "I have the sense that you might be inclined to act in a way that would weaken it a little." He took no more notice of these last words than if she hadn't said them, only watching her at present as with a gradual new light.

"Well, Lord Mark, you did—my trust is exactly where you put it then. The only difference," said Milly, "is that it seems I don't need it now. Besides," she then added, "I have the feeling that you might be inclined to do something that would undermine it a bit." "Are you really in any trouble?" To this, on her side, she gave no heed. Making out his light was a little a light for herself. "Don't say, don't try to say, anything that's impossible.

He told her not to say anything impossible, or even try. He seemed to disregard her words, looking away. "It's infuriating that I can't even ask you, as a friend, what I'm desperate to know."

"What is it that you want to know?" She asked, suddenly changing her tone, a slight edge in her voice. "Do you want to know if I'm seriously ill?" The sound of it in truth, though from no raising of her voice, invested the idea with a kind of terror, but a terror all for others. Lord Mark winced and flushed—clearly couldn't help it; but he kept his attitude together and spoke even with unwonted vivacity.

Translation

"What do you want to know?" she asked, her voice shifting, a subtle sharpness to it. "Do you want to know if I'm dying?" Translation

"I do everything. Everything is this," she said with a smile. "I'm doing it now. You can't do more than simply live."

"Ah, except live the right way, I suppose. But is that what you do? Why don't you offer some advice?" He surveyed the ornate surroundings, as though they deprived her of countless things, and he pointed out the most obvious lack.

Translation

"Unless, I guess, you live correctly. But is that what you do? Why won't you give some guidance?" He examined the elaborate decorations, as if they were denying her many opportunities, and indicated the most glaring omission.

But she dismissed his remedy with a smile. "I have the best advice in the world. I'm following it now. I'm acting on it by receiving you, by talking with you like this.

Translation

But she brushed aside his solution with a smile. "I have the best advice there is. I'm following it right now. I'm putting it into practice by welcoming you, by having this conversation with you."

As I said, you can't do more than simply live." "Oh, just live!" Lord Mark exclaimed. "Well, it's a huge undertaking, for me." There she was; but it was as if she would never speak again.

Translation

"As I said, all you can do is live." "Oh, just live!" Lord Mark exclaimed. "Well, that's a big deal, for me." "I won't," she added, "have missed everything." "Why should you have missed anything?" She felt, as he sounded this, to what, within the minute, he had made up his mind. Since you believe in advice, for God's sake take mine.

Translation

"I won't," she added, "have missed everything." "Why should you have missed anything?" She sensed, as he said this, what he had decided in the last minute. "You're the last person in the world who needs to worry about that. In fact, it's impossible. For you to 'miss' anything would require a truly remarkable amount of misplaced goodwill. I know what you want." Oh she knew he would know it. But she had brought it on herself—or almost. Yet she spoke with kindness.

Translation

Translation

It is so"—he firmly kept it up. "You're not loved enough." "Why would you miss anything?" She realized in that instant what he had decided. "You are the last person who needs to miss out; in fact, it's impossible for you.
