But she had brought this upon herself—or nearly. Yet she spoke gently. "I think I want to avoid being overly troubled." "You want to be adored." It came at last, directly.

Translation

However, she had mostly done this to herself. Still, she softened her tone. "I think I'd prefer not to be overly upset." "You want to be worshipped." It was out now, blunt and unavoidable.

"Nothing would bother you less. And I intend to do it. It's true"—he insisted. "You're not loved enough."

Translation

"Nothing would trouble you less," he said. "And I intend to do it. It's true," he pressed, "you're not loved enough."

"Enough for what, Lord Mark?" "Why to get the full good of it." Well, she didn't after all mock at him. "I see what you mean.

Translation

"Enough for what, Lord Mark?" "Why, to get all the good out of it." Well, she didn't mock him, after all. "I understand what you mean."

That full good of it which consists in finding one's self forced to love in return." She had grasped it, but she hesitated. "Your idea is that I might find myself forced to love you?" "Oh 'forced'—!" He was so fine and so expert, so awake to anything the least ridiculous, and of a type with which the preaching of passion somehow so ill consorted—he was so much all these things that he had absolutely to take account of them himself. And he did so, in a single intonation, beautifully.

Translation

That complete good of it which consists in finding oneself compelled to love in return." She understood, but she hesitated. "Your idea is that I might find myself compelled to love you?" "Oh, 'compelled'—!" He was so refined and so skilled, so aware of anything the slightest bit absurd, and of a type with which the proclamation of passion somehow so poorly agreed—he was so much all these things that he absolutely had to take them into account himself. And he did so, in a single inflection, beautifully.

Milly liked him again, liked him for such shades as that, liked him so that it was woeful to see him spoiling it, and still more woeful to have to rank him among those minor charms of existence that she gasped at moments to remember she must give up. "Is it inconceivable to you that you might try?" "Enough for what, Lord Mark?" "To fully enjoy it."

Translation

Milly liked him again, liked him for the subtle nuances he possessed, liked him so much it was painful to see him ruin it. It was even more painful to have to consider him one of the minor joys of life, the kind she suddenly remembered she would have to relinquish. "Is it impossible for you to even try?" "Try to do what, Lord Mark?" "To fully enjoy it."

Well, she didn't make fun of him, after all. "I understand what you're saying. The 'full good' being when you're forced to love someone back." She got it, but she was hesitant. "Your idea is that I might be forced to love you?"

Translation

Well, she didn't mock him, at least. "I see what you mean. The 'full good' comes when you're compelled to reciprocate the love." She understood, but she was wary. "Are you suggesting I might be forced to love you?"

"Oh, 'forced'—!" He was so refined, so skilled, so aware of anything even slightly ridiculous. And being the type that passion didn't exactly fit with, he was all of those things, so much so that he had to consider it himself. And he did, with a single, beautiful tone. Milly liked him again, liked him for those subtle qualities, liked him so much it was painful to see him ruin it, and even more painful to have to consider him among the minor joys of life that she was shocked to realize she would have to give up.

Translation

"Oh, 'forced'—!" He was so sophisticated, so gifted, so attuned to anything remotely absurd. And as someone for whom passion seemed a poor fit, he was all those things to the point that he had to acknowledge it himself. And he did, with a single, elegant intonation. Milly liked him again, liked him for those delicate traits, liked him so much it hurt to watch him spoil them, and it was even more painful to have to count him among the small pleasures of life that she was surprised to find she would have to forgo.

"Is it impossible for you to try?" "To be so favourably affected by you—?" "To believe in me. To believe in me," Lord Mark repeated.

Translation

"Can't you even try?"

"To feel this way about you—?"

"To have faith in me. To have faith in me," Lord Mark repeated.

Again she hesitated. "To 'try' in return for your trying?" "Oh I shouldn't have to!" he quickly declared. The prompt neat accent, however, his manner of disposing of her question, failed of real expression, as he himself the next moment intelligently, helplessly, almost comically saw—a failure pointed moreover by the laugh into which Milly was immediately startled.

Translation

She hesitated once more. "To 'try' in exchange for your trying?"

"Oh, I shouldn't have to!" he declared quickly. The crisp, precise accent, however, and his dismissal of her question, lacked genuine conviction, as he himself realized the next moment, intelligently, helplessly, almost comically—a failure highlighted by the laugh that immediately startled Milly.

As a suggestion to her of a healing and uplifting passion it was in truth deficient; it wouldn't do as the communication of a force that should sweep them both away. And the beauty of him was that he too, even in the act of persuasion, of self-persuasion, could understand that, and could thereby show but the better as fitting into the pleasant commerce of prosperity. The way she let him see that she looked at him was a thing to shut him out, of itself, from services of danger, a thing that made a discrimination against him never yet made—made at least to any consciousness of his own. Born to float in a sustaining air, this would be his first encounter with a judgement formed in the sinister light of tragedy.

Translation

It was, in truth, an inadequate suggestion of a healing, uplifting passion. It wouldn’t serve as the conveyance of a force that should carry them both away. The beautiful thing about him was that even in the act of persuasion, of self-persuasion, he could understand that. He could thereby present himself as fitting into the agreeable trade of prosperity. The way she let him see her looking at him was enough to exclude him from any dangerous undertakings, a thing that made a distinction against him that had never been made before—at least, not to his own knowledge. Born to float in a sustaining air, this would be his first experience with a judgement formed in the sinister light of tragedy.

The gathering dusk of her personal world presented itself to him, in her eyes, as an element in which it was vain for him to pretend he could find himself at home, since it was charged with depressions and with dooms, with the chill of the losing game. Almost without her needing to speak, and simply by the fact that there could be, in such a case, no decent substitute for a felt intensity, he had to take it from her that practically he was afraid—whether afraid to protest falsely enough, or only afraid of what might be eventually disagreeable in a compromised alliance, being a minor question. She believed she made out besides, wonderful girl, that he had never quite expected to have to protest about anything beyond his natural convenience—more, in fine, than his disposition and habits, his education as well, his personal moyens, in short, permitted. His predicament was therefore one he couldn't like, and also one she willingly would have spared him hadn't he brought it on himself.

Translation

The gathering dusk of her private world appeared to him in her eyes as an environment in which it was pointless for him to pretend he could feel at ease, since it was filled with sorrows and portents of disaster, with the coldness of a losing battle. Almost without her having to say anything, simply by the fact that there could be no proper substitute for genuine feeling in such a situation, he understood that he was, in effect, afraid—whether afraid of protesting unconvincingly, or only afraid of what might eventually become unpleasant in a compromised relationship, was a secondary concern. She also believed, the wonderful girl, that he had never truly expected to have to object to anything beyond his own convenience—more, essentially, than his temperament and routines, as well as his education, his personal resources, in short, allowed. His situation was therefore one he didn’t like, and also one she would gladly have saved him from if he hadn’t caused it himself.

No man, she was quite aware, could enjoy thus having it from her that he wasn't good for what she would have called her reality. It wouldn't have taken much more to enable her positively to make out in him that he was virtually capable of hinting—had his innermost feeling spoken—at the propriety rather, in his interest, of some cutting down, some dressing up, of the offensive real. He would meet that halfway, but the real must also meet him. Milly's sense of it for herself, which was so conspicuously, so financially supported, couldn't, or wouldn't, so accommodate him, and the perception of that fairly showed in his face after a moment like the smart of a blow.

Translation

She knew well that no man could enjoy hearing from her that he wasn't suited to what she would call her reality. It wouldn't have taken much more for her to see in him that he was almost able to suggest—had his deepest feelings surfaced—that it would be more appropriate, for his own sake, to make some cuts, some adjustments, to the offensive real. He would meet that halfway, but the real must also meet him. Milly's own sense of it, so conspicuously and so financially supported, couldn't, or wouldn't, accommodate him, and the awareness of that showed plainly on his face after a moment, like the sting of a slap.

It had marked the one minute during which he could again be touching to her. By the time he had tried once more, after all, to insist, he had quite ceased to be so. "To have you like me so much—?" "To trust me.

Translation

That single minute was the only time he could still be endearing to her. By the time he tried to press the issue again, he had completely lost that quality. "To have you like me so much—?" "To trust me."

To trust me," Lord Mark repeated. She paused again. "To 'try' in return for your trying?" "Oh, I wouldn't have to!" he quickly declared.

Translation

"To trust me," Lord Mark repeated. She paused again. "To 'try' in return for your trying?" "Oh, I wouldn't have to!" he quickly declared.

His prompt, polished way of answering her question didn't convey genuine feeling, as he himself realized a moment later—intelligently, helplessly, almost comically—a failure that was emphasized by the laughter that Milly immediately couldn't help but let out. As a suggestion of a healing and uplifting passion, it truly fell short; it wouldn't work as the expression of a force that would sweep them both away. The remarkable thing about him was that even in the act of persuasion, of trying to persuade himself, he understood this and could thereby fit himself all the more seamlessly into the pleasant world of wealth and success. The way she looked at him was enough to shut him out, to prevent him from taking on any risky endeavors, an action that discriminated against him in a way he had never experienced—at least, not consciously.

Translation

The speed and finesse with which he responded to her question lacked sincerity, a fact he himself recognized a moment later—with his usual intelligence, his inability to do otherwise, and a touch of the absurd—a failing that was underscored by the laughter that Milly immediately, involuntarily, produced. It was hardly the mark of a healing, transformative passion; it wasn’t the sort of force that would carry them both away. The thing about him was that even when he was attempting to persuade, even when he was trying to persuade himself, he understood this, and that understanding allowed him to fit all the more easily into the agreeable world of money and achievement. The way she regarded him was enough to exclude him, to discourage him from taking any chances, an experience of exclusion he had never encountered before—at least, not consciously.

He was accustomed to a life of ease, and this would be his first confrontation with a judgment made in the somber light of tragedy. The growing darkness of her personal world revealed itself to him in her eyes, an environment in which it was useless for him to pretend he belonged, since it was filled with despair and doom, with the coldness of a losing game. Almost without her needing to speak, and simply because there was no acceptable substitute for a deeply felt intensity in this situation, he had to accept that he was essentially afraid—whether afraid to lie convincingly or merely afraid of the potential unpleasantness of a compromised relationship was a secondary concern. She also believed, remarkably, that he had never expected to have to argue about anything beyond his own convenience—that is, beyond his temperament and habits, as well as his education and personal resources, in short, beyond anything he could readily offer.

Translation

He was used to a comfortable life, and this was his first encounter with a judgment born of tragedy’s gravity. The encroaching darkness of her inner world was visible in her eyes, a realm where it was pointless for him to feign belonging, as it was populated by despair and the shadow of death, the coldness of a losing battle. Without her even needing to say anything, simply because there was no acceptable replacement for genuine depth of feeling in this moment, he had to admit he was fundamentally afraid—whether of lying poorly or simply of the potential discomfort of an imperfect relationship was of secondary importance. She, too, believed, and astonishingly so, that he had never anticipated having to contend with anything beyond his own convenience—that is, beyond his personality and routines, as well as his education and personal assets; in brief, beyond anything he could easily provide.

His predicament was therefore something he couldn't like, and also something she would gladly have spared him had he not brought it upon himself. No man, she knew very well, could enjoy hearing from her that he wasn't up to her standards for reality. It wouldn't have taken much more for her to make out that he was almost hinting—if his true feelings were revealed—at the appropriateness, in his own interest, of some diminishing, some alteration of the offensive real. He would meet it halfway, but the real must also meet him.

Translation

His situation was therefore one he found disagreeable, and which she would have gladly prevented if he hadn't created it. She knew well that no man enjoyed being told he failed to meet her standards for reality. It wouldn't have taken much more for her to realize he was nearly suggesting—if his true feelings were revealed—the desirability, for his own benefit, of some lessening, some manipulation of the offensive reality. He would compromise, but reality had to meet him, too.

Milly's understanding of it for herself, which was so obviously and financially supported, couldn't or wouldn't accommodate him, and the awareness of that showed plainly on his face after a moment, like the sting of a slap. It had marked the one minute during which he could once again be touching to her. By the time he had tried again to insist, he had entirely lost that quality. By this time she had turned from their window to make a diversion, had walked him through other rooms, appealing again to the inner charm of the place, going even so far for that purpose as to point afresh her independent moral, to repeat that if one only had such a house for one's own and loved it and cherished it enough, it would pay one back in kind, would close one in from harm.

Translation

Milly’s own understanding, so openly and financially secure, couldn’t or wouldn’t include him. The realization of that was visible on his face after a moment, like the burning sensation of a slap. It had defined the single minute when he might have again been endearing to her. By the time he tried to reassert himself, he had completely lost that appeal. By then, she had turned away from their window to distract, led him through other rooms, once more appealing to the inner charm of the house. She went so far as to emphasize her independent moral code, repeating that if one owned such a house and loved and cherished it enough, it would reciprocate, protecting one from harm.

He quite grasped for the quarter of an hour the perch she held out to him—grasped it with one hand, that is, while she felt him attached to his own clue with the other; he was by no means either so sore or so stupid, to do him all justice, as not to be able to behave more or less as if nothing had happened. It was one of his merits, to which she did justice too, that both his native and his acquired notion of behaviour rested on the general assumption that nothing—nothing to make a deadly difference for him—ever could happen. It was, socially, a working view like another, and it saw them easily enough through the greater part of the rest of their adventure. Downstairs again, however, with the limit of his stay in sight, the sign of his smarting, when all was said, reappeared for her—breaking out moreover, with an effect of strangeness, in another quite possibly sincere allusion to her state of health.

Translation

For the fifteen minutes that she offered him a reprieve, he accepted it—with one hand, that is, while she sensed he was still clinging to his own perspective with the other. To be fair, he wasn't so hurt or foolish that he couldn't act as though nothing had happened. It was one of his strengths, and she acknowledged it, that his inherent and learned understanding of how to behave was founded on the belief that nothing—nothing that could truly affect him—ever would. Socially, it was a practical outlook, and it saw them through most of their time together. But back downstairs, with his departure imminent, the sign of his pain returned for her—emerging with an air of oddity, in another, possibly genuine, reference to her health.

He might for that matter have been seeing what he could do in the way of making it a grievance that she should snub him for a charity, on his own part, exquisitely roused. "It's true, you know, all the same, and I don't care a straw for your trying to freeze one up." He seemed to show her, poor man, bravely, how little he cared. "Everybody knows affection often makes things out when indifference doesn't notice. And that's why I know that I notice."

Translation

He could have, for all she knew, been attempting to turn her behavior into a grievance, that she would snub him for a charitable act he'd undertaken with exquisite enthusiasm. “It’s still true, though, you know, and I don’t care at all that you’re trying to shut me out.” He seemed to be showing her, the poor man, bravely, how little he was affected. “Everyone knows affection often exaggerates when indifference overlooks something. And that's why I know that I do notice.”

By this point, she had turned away from the window to change the subject, leading him through other rooms, again highlighting the appealing qualities of the house. She even went so far as to re-emphasize her own belief, reiterating that if someone owned such a house and loved and cared for it enough, it would reciprocate, protecting them from trouble. For about fifteen minutes, he accepted her perspective, or at least pretended to, while she sensed he remained focused on his own thoughts. To be fair to him, he wasn't so hurt or foolish that he couldn't act as if nothing had occurred.

Translation

At this juncture, she pivoted from the window, seeking to alter the course of their conversation. She guided him through various rooms, once more accentuating the house's most charming features. She even went so far as to restate her conviction, underlining her belief that a house of this caliber, if properly cherished and attended to, would offer a form of protection from hardship. For a quarter of an hour or so, he entertained her point of view, or at least gave the impression that he did, while she felt his thoughts remained elsewhere. To his credit, he wasn't so wounded or obtuse that he couldn't behave as though nothing was amiss.

It was one of his strengths, as she acknowledged, that both his inherent and learned understanding of social conduct was based on the idea that nothing, nothing that would significantly affect him, could ever happen. This was a functional approach to life, and it allowed them to navigate most of the remainder of their interaction without incident. But back downstairs, with the end of his visit approaching, his emotional pain resurfaced for her, and it manifested, surprisingly, in a possibly genuine concern for her health. He might as well have been trying to make it seem as though she was mistreating him by accepting his charity when he felt, on his end, extraordinarily hurt.

Translation

She knew it was one of his strengths: his natural and cultivated understanding of social graces, rooted in the belief that nothing, nothing that truly mattered, would ever actually happen to him. It was a practical way of moving through life, and it allowed them to get through most of the rest of their time together without any problems. But when they were back downstairs, with his visit nearing its end, his emotional pain returned to her, and it surprisingly manifested as possibly genuine concern for her well-being. It was almost as though he was trying to make her the bad guy, the one who was somehow mistreating him by accepting his generosity while he was, in fact, incredibly hurt.

"It's still true, you know, despite everything, and I don't care at all if you try to shut me out." He seemed to bravely demonstrate how little he was affected. "Everyone knows that care often exaggerates issues that indifference overlooks. And that's why I know I'm noticing things." "Are you sure you've got it right?" the girl smiled.

Translation

"It's still the truth, you know, no matter what, and I don't care if you try to shut me out." He seemed to bravely prove how little he was affected. "Everyone knows that care often blows things out of proportion, while indifference just overlooks them. And that's why I know I'm seeing things clearly." "Are you sure you've got it right?" the girl smiled.

"I thought rather that affection was supposed to be blind." "Blind to faults, not to beauties," Lord Mark promptly returned. "And are my extremely private worries, my entirely domestic complications, which I'm ashamed to have given you a glimpse of—are they beauties?" "Yes, for those who care for you—as every one does.

Translation

"I'd always thought affection was supposed to be blind," I said. "Blind to flaws, not to what is lovely," Lord Mark responded without hesitation. "And are my very personal anxieties, my entirely domestic troubles, which I'm ashamed to have let you see—are those lovely?" "Yes, to those who care for you—as everyone does."

Everything about you is a beauty. Besides which I don't believe," he declared, "in the seriousness of what you tell me. It's too absurd you should have any trouble about which something can't be done. If you can't get the right thing, who can, in all the world, I should like to know?

Translation

Everything about you is beautiful. Besides, I don't believe, he declared, that your problems are serious. It's absurd that you should have trouble with anything that can't be solved. If you can't get what you need, I'd like to know, who can, in the entire world?

You're the first young woman of your time. I mean what I say." He looked, to do him justice, quite as if he did; not ardent, but clear—simply so competent, in such a position, to compare, that his quiet assertion had the force not so much perhaps of a tribute as of a warrant. "We're all in love with you. I'll put it that way, dropping any claim of my own, if you can bear it better.

Translation

You are the foremost young woman of your era. I mean that sincerely."

To be fair to him, he appeared to believe what he was saying. Not passionately, but with a clarity—he was simply so capable, in a position to judge, that his calm pronouncement carried the weight not necessarily of praise but of assurance. "We are all in love with you. I'll phrase it that way, omitting any personal claim, if it's more palatable to you."

I speak as one of the lot. You weren't born simply to torment us—you were born to make us happy. Therefore you must listen to us." "Are you sure you understand the situation correctly?" the young woman asked, smiling.

Translation

I speak for all of us. You weren't brought into this world just to make us miserable; you were brought into this world to make us happy. So you have to listen to us.”

“Are you certain you understand the situation?” the young woman asked, smiling.

"I always thought love was supposed to be blind." "Blind to imperfections, not to the good qualities," Lord Mark replied without hesitation. "And are my personal anxieties, my private domestic issues—which I regret even mentioning—are those supposed to be good qualities?" "Yes, for those who care about you—as everyone does.

Translation

"I always thought love was blind." "Blind to flaws, not to what's good," Lord Mark replied instantly. "And are my anxieties, my private problems at home—which I regret bringing up—are those supposed to be good qualities?" "Yes, for those who care about you—as everyone does."

Everything about you is a good quality. Besides, I don't believe what you're telling me is that serious," he stated. "It's ridiculous that you'd have any problems that can't be resolved. If you can't find a solution, then who can, in the world?

Translation

Everything about you is a good quality. Besides, I don't think what you're saying is that serious. It's ridiculous that you'd have problems that can't be fixed. If you can't find a solution, then who can, in this world?

You're the most exceptional young woman of our time. I mean it." To be fair to him, he looked like he meant it; not passionate, but assured—exceedingly competent in this kind of situation. His calm declaration felt less like praise and more like a guarantee.

Translation

You are the most remarkable young woman of our era. I am serious." To his credit, he seemed to believe it; not intensely, but with certainty—completely at ease in this kind of scenario. His composed statement resembled less a compliment and more a promise.

"We all adore you. Let me put it that way, without making any claims for myself, if that's easier for you. I speak as one of many. You weren't born just to make us miserable; you were born to bring us joy.

Translation

"Everyone loves you. I'll just say that, and leave myself out of it if that's easier. I'm speaking for a lot of people. You weren't put here just to make us unhappy; you were put here to make us happy."

Therefore, you must listen to us." She shook her head with her slowness, but this time with all her mildness. "No, I mustn't listen to you—that's just what I mustn't do. The reason is, please, that it simply kills me.

Translation

"So, you have to listen to us." She slowly shook her head, but this time with complete gentleness. "No, I can't listen to you—that's the very thing I mustn't do. Because, you see, it will simply destroy me."

I must be as attached to you as you will, since you give that lovely account of yourselves. I give you in return the fullest possible belief of what it would be—" And she pulled up a little. "I give and give and give—there you are; stick to me as close as you like and see if I don't. Only I can't listen or receive or accept—I can't agree.

Translation

I have to be as devoted to you as you wish, because you offer such a beautiful story about yourselves. In return, I offer the fullest possible belief in what it could be—" She paused briefly. "I give and give and give—there you are; cling to me as closely as you like and see if I don't. But I cannot listen or receive or accept—I cannot agree.

I can't make a bargain. I can't really. You must believe that from me. It's all I've wanted to say to you, and why should it spoil anything?"

Translation

I can't make a deal. Truly, I can't. You need to believe that. It's the only thing I've wanted to tell you, and why would it ruin anything?

She slowly shook her head, but this time, she was completely gentle. "No, I can't listen to you – that's the one thing I absolutely can't do. The reason is, frankly, it's devastating to me. I'll be as devoted to you as you want, since you describe yourselves so beautifully.

Translation

She shook her head slowly, but this time, there was no harshness in the gesture. "No, I can't listen to you. That's the single thing I cannot do. The truth is, it destroys me. I'll be as devoted to you as you like, since you speak so eloquently of yourselves."

I offer you in return my complete and utter conviction of what it would be—" She paused slightly. "I offer and offer and offer—there you have it; stay close to me, and see if I don't. But I can't listen, or receive, or accept—I can't agree. I can't make a deal.

Translation

I can give you in return my absolute belief in what it would be—" She hesitated a moment. "I offer and offer and offer—there, that’s it; stay close to me, and see if I don’t. But I can't listen, or take, or receive—I can’t agree. I can't compromise."

I really can't. You have to believe me. That's all I've wanted to tell you, so why should it ruin anything?" He let her question fall—though clearly, it might have seemed, because, for reasons or for none, there was so much that was spoiled.

Translation

I truly can't. You need to believe me. That's the only thing I've wanted to say to you, so why would it destroy anything?" He allowed her question to dissipate—though it seemed, plainly, as if, for various causes or none at all, so much was already ruined.

"You want somebody of your own." He came back, whether in good faith or in bad, to that; and it made her repeat her headshake. He kept it up as if his faith were of the best. "You want somebody, you want somebody." She was to wonder afterwards if she hadn't been at this juncture on the point of saying something emphatic and vulgar—"Well, I don't at all events want you!" What somehow happened, nevertheless, the pity of it being greater than the irritation—the sadness, to her vivid sense, of his being so painfully astray, wandering in a desert in which there was nothing to nourish him—was that his error amounted to positive wrongdoing.

Translation

"You want someone of your own." He returned to the point, whether sincerely or not, and she shook her head again. He persisted as if his intentions were pure. "You want someone, you want someone." Afterward, she would wonder if she hadn't been on the verge of saying something blunt and rude—"Well, I certainly don't want you!" But what occurred, the pity of it exceeding her irritation—the sadness, to her mind, of his being so painfully lost, wandering in a desert that offered him nothing—was that his mistake became a genuine wrong.

She was moreover so acquainted with quite another sphere of usefulness for him that her having suffered him to insist almost convicted her of indelicacy. Why hadn't she stopped him off with her first impression of his purpose? She could do so now only by the allusion she had been wishing not to make. "Do you know I don't think you're doing very right?—and as a thing quite apart, I mean, from my listening to you.

Translation

Furthermore, she knew of a different, more fitting role for him. Allowing him to continue, she felt, almost accused her of a lack of discretion. Why hadn't she halted him at the first hint of his intentions? She could only do so now by bringing up the very thing she'd been avoiding. "Do you realize you're not behaving properly?—and I mean, apart from the fact that I'm listening to you."

That's not right either—except that I'm not listening. You oughtn't to have come to Venice to see me—and in fact you've not come, and you mustn't behave as if you had. You've much older friends than I, and ever so much better. Really, if you've come at all, you can only have come—properly, and if I may say so honourably—for the best friend, as I believe her to be, that you have in the world."

Translation

That's not right, either—except that I'm not listening. You shouldn't have come to Venice to see me—and in fact, you haven't come, and you mustn't behave as if you had. You've much older friends than I am, and far better ones. Really, if you've come at all, you can only have come—properly, and if I may say so honorably—for the best friend, as I believe her to be, that you have in the world.

He ignored her question, though it was obvious, it seemed, because a lot was ruined, for no apparent reason. "You want someone of your own." He returned to this idea, whether sincerely or not, and she shook her head again. He persisted as if he truly believed it. "You want someone, you want someone."

Translation

He didn't respond to her question, even though it was clear, it appeared, because a lot of things were destroyed, for no discernible cause. "You want someone for yourself." He went back to that thought, whether he meant it or not, and she shook her head once more. He continued to insist, as if he genuinely thought it was true. "You want someone, you want someone."

Later, she would wonder if she had almost blurted out something blunt and rude—"Well, I certainly don't want you!" But somehow, the pity of it, the sadness that he was so painfully lost, wandering in a desolate place without sustenance, overshadowed her irritation. His mistake amounted to a real offense. She knew of another, better way for him to spend his time, so letting him continue almost made her feel ashamed. Why hadn't she stopped him earlier, with her first thoughts about his intentions?

Translation

Later, she would wonder if she had nearly snapped something harsh and impolite—"Well, I definitely don't want you!" But somehow, the sorrow of it, the sadness that he was so agonizingly lost, wandering in a desolate place, eclipsed her annoyance. His misstep was actually an offense. She knew a better way for him to spend his time, so letting him continue almost made her feel ashamed. Why hadn't she stopped him earlier, with her first suspicions about his intentions?

Now, she could only do so by mentioning something she didn't want to. "I don't think you're doing the right thing, and this is completely separate from my listening to you. That's not right either, except that I'm not listening. You shouldn't have come to Venice to see me—in reality, you haven't, and you shouldn't act like you have.

Translation

The only way forward was to say something she didn't want to say. "I don't believe you're on the right track, and it has nothing to do with my hearing you out. That's wrong too, though I'm not listening. You shouldn't have come to Venice to see me—in truth, you haven't, and you shouldn't pretend you have."

You have much older and better friends than me. Really, if you've come at all, it can only be—properly, and if I may say so honourably—for the best friend, who I believe you have in the world." When once she had said it he took it, oddly enough, as if he had been more or less expecting it. Still, he looked at her very hard, and they had a moment of this during which neither pronounced a name, each apparently determined that the other should.

Translation

"You have friends who are much older and better than I am. Truly, if you've come at all, the only reason could be—fittingly, and if I may be so bold—for the best friend you have in the world." When she'd finished speaking, he took it, strangely enough, as if he'd been anticipating it to a certain extent. Nevertheless, he stared at her intently, and they shared a moment in which neither of them uttered a name, each seemingly resolved to wait for the other to do so.

It was Milly's fine coercion, in the event, that was the stronger. "Miss Croy?" Lord Mark asked. It might have been difficult to make out that she smiled. "Mrs.

Translation

It was ultimately Milly's subtle pressure that proved more effective. "Miss Croy?" Lord Mark inquired. It was almost imperceptible, but she might have smiled. "Mrs.

Lowder." He did make out something, and then fairly coloured for its attestation of his comparative simplicity. "I call her on the whole the best. I can't imagine a man's having a better." Still with his eyes on her he turned it over.

Translation

Lowder." He did make out something, and then fairly blushed for its confirmation of his comparative naiveté. "I consider her, on the whole, the best. I can't imagine a man having a better woman." Still staring at her, he considered the statement.

"Do you want me to marry Mrs. Lowder?" Once she spoke, he received the information as though he'd been anticipating it. He stared at her intently, and there was a pause where neither of them spoke a name, each seeming to wait for the other to do so.

Translation

"Do you want me to marry Mrs. Lowder?" The moment she spoke, he reacted as though he'd been expecting the question. He looked at her closely, and a silence fell between them, as if each was waiting for the other to mention a name.

In the end, Milly's subtle pressure prevailed. "Miss Croy?" Lord Mark inquired. It was hard to tell if she smiled. "Mrs.

Translation

Lowder's companion." "Ah," he said, and the way he said it suggested he'd finally understood.

Lowder." He did perceive something, and then he blushed, acknowledging his own naiveté. "I consider her the best, all things considered. I can't imagine a man could find someone better." Still looking at her, he considered the idea.

Translation

Lowder. He did realize something then, and blushed, admitting his own innocence. "I think she's the best, all things considered. I can't imagine a man could find someone better." He kept looking at her, considering the thought.

"Do you want me to marry Mrs. Lowder?" At which it seemed to her that it was he who was almost vulgar! But she wouldn't in any way have that.

Translation

"Do you want me to marry Mrs. Lowder?" To her, the question revealed a crudeness, almost. But she refused to accept it in any way.

"You know, Lord Mark, what I mean. One isn't in the least turning you out into the cold world. There's no cold world for you at all, I think," she went on; "nothing but a very warm and watchful and expectant world that's waiting for you at any moment you choose to take it up." He never budged, but they were standing on the polished concrete and he had within a few minutes possessed himself again of his hat.

Translation

"You understand, Lord Mark, what I'm saying. No one is casting you out into the world to fend for yourself. There is no such cold world for you, I think," she continued. "Only a very warm and attentive, expectant world, waiting for you whenever you decide to embrace it." He didn't move, but they were standing on the polished concrete, and within a few minutes, he'd taken hold of his hat again.

"Do you want me to marry Kate Croy?" "Mrs. Lowder wants it—I do no wrong, I think, in saying that; and she understands moreover that you know she does." It struck her then that he was behaving in a way that was almost vulgar!

Translation

"Do you want me to marry Kate Croy?" "Mrs. Lowder wants it—I don't think I'm wrong in saying that; and she also understands that you know she does." It occurred to her then that his behavior was almost vulgar!

But she refused to accept that notion. "You understand, Lord Mark, what I'm saying. I'm not in the least trying to cast you aside. There's no such thing as a cold world for you, I believe," she continued; "only a very welcoming, observant, and eager world that will welcome you the moment you decide to engage with it."

Translation

However, she refused to entertain the idea. "You understand, Lord Mark, what I'm saying. I'm not attempting to dismiss you. I believe a cold world doesn't exist for you," she continued. "Only a world that's very welcoming, observant, and eager, ready to embrace you the moment you choose to participate."

He didn't move, though they were standing on the smooth concrete, and he had reclaimed his hat within a few minutes. "Do you want me to marry Kate Croy?" "Mrs. Lowder desires it—I don't believe I'm being dishonest by saying that; and she also realizes that you know she wants it."

Translation

He remained still, even though they were on the polished concrete, and he’d retrieved his hat a few minutes prior. "Do you want me to marry Kate Croy?" "Mrs. Lowder wants it—I don't think I'm being untruthful in saying that; and she also knows you know she wants it."

Well, he showed how beautifully he could take it; and it wasn't obscure to her, on her side, that it was a comfort to deal with a gentleman. "It's ever so kind of you to see such opportunities for me. But what's the use of my tackling Miss Croy?" Milly rejoiced on the spot to be so able to point out.

Translation

He demonstrated how gracefully he could handle the situation. And from her perspective, it was clear that it was reassuring to interact with a gentleman. "It's exceedingly generous of you to identify these opportunities for me. But why would I even bother pursuing Miss Croy?" Milly was delighted in that moment to be able to make that point.

"Because she's the handsomest and cleverest and most charming creature I ever saw, and because if I were a man I should simply adore her. In fact I do as it is." It was a luxury of response. "Oh, my dear lady, plenty of people adore her. But that can't further the case of all."

Translation

"Because she's the most beautiful, intelligent, and charming woman I've ever met, and if I were a man, I'd simply adore her. As it is, I already do." It was a lavish, almost reckless, response. "Oh, my dear, many people adore her. But that doesn't advance your cause at all."

"Ah," she went on, "I know about 'people.' If the case of one's bad, the case of another's good. I don't see what you have to fear from any one else," she said, "save through your being foolish, this way, about me." He demonstrated how gracefully he could handle the situation. And from her perspective, it was clear that it was pleasant to be dealing with a man of refinement.

Translation

"Ah," she continued, "I know about 'people.' If one person is bad, another is good. I don't see what you have to fear from anyone else," she said, "unless you're foolish about me." He demonstrated how gracefully he could manage the situation. And from her perspective, it was clear that it was pleasant to be dealing with a man of refinement.

"It's extremely generous of you to identify these possibilities for me. But what's the point of my approaching Miss Croy?" Milly was immediately delighted to make her point. "Because she's the most beautiful, intelligent, and captivating person I've ever encountered, and if I were a man, I would absolutely adore her.

Translation

"You're very kind to lay this out for me. But what's the use of my going to see Miss Croy?" Milly was pleased to be able to ask. "Because she's the most beautiful, intelligent, and enchanting woman I've ever met, and if I were a man, I would be utterly devoted to her."

In fact, I already do." It was a moment of pure enjoyment. "Oh, my dear, many people adore her. But that doesn't necessarily help matters." "Yes," she continued, "I understand 'people.' If one person's prospects are poor, another's might be good.

Translation

"Actually, I already am." It was a moment of sheer bliss. "Oh, darling, she has many admirers. But that doesn't always solve anything." "Yes," she continued, "I get 'people.' If one person's chances are bad, another's might be good.

I don't see what you have to worry about from anyone else," she said, "unless you're being foolish with me." So she said, but she was aware the next moment of what he was making of what she didn't see. "Is it your idea—since we're talking of these things in these ways—that the young lady you describe in such superlative terms is to be had for the asking?" "Well, Lord Mark, try.

Translation

"I don't think you need to worry about anyone else," she said, "unless you're being a fool with me." She said that, but she realized instantly what he was thinking about what she didn't see. "Is it your idea—since we're discussing these matters this way—that the young woman you're describing so highly is easily attainable?" "Well, Lord Mark, go ahead and try."

She is a great person. But don't be humble." She was almost gay. It was this apparently, at last, that was too much for him. "But don't you really know?"

Translation

"She's wonderful. But don't be coy." She was practically giddy. Apparently, this was the last straw for him. "Don't you actually know?"

As a challenge, practically, to the commonest intelligence she could pretend to, it made her of course wish to be fair. "I 'know' yes, that a particular person's very much in love with her." "Then you must know by the same token that she's very much in love with a particular person." She spoke, but immediately understood his interpretation of her words.

Translation

It was almost as if she were daring the simplest mind to understand. Of course, that made her want to be fair. "I 'know,' yes, that someone is very much in love with her." "Then you must know that she, in turn, is very much in love with someone." She spoke, but at once understood his interpretation of her words.

"Do you think—since we're being so open—that this amazing young woman you're describing is easily won?" "Well, Lord Mark, go for it. She's extraordinary. But don't be shy." She seemed almost amused.

Translation

"Do you believe—since we're speaking frankly—that this remarkable young woman you're talking about is easy to win over?" "Well, Lord Mark, go for it. She's exceptional. But don't hesitate." She appeared almost amused.

It was this, it seemed, that finally pushed him over the edge. "But don't you actually know?" As a direct challenge to even the most basic understanding, it made her want to be honest. "I 'know,' yes, that someone is deeply in love with her."

Translation

That seemed to be the thing that did it. "But don't you actually know?" As if she were being dared to tell the truth, it made her want to be forthright. "I 'know,' yes, that someone is in love with her."

"Then you must also know that she's deeply in love with someone." "Ah I beg your pardon!"—and Milly quite flushed at having so crude a blunder imputed to her. "You're wholly mistaken." "It's not true?"

Translation

"Then you must also know she's deeply in love with someone."

"Oh, I beg your pardon!" Milly flushed, mortified that such a crude error had been attributed to her. "You are completely mistaken."

"It isn't true?"

"It's not true." His stare became a smile. "Are you very, very sure?" "As sure as one can be"—and Milly's manner could match it—"when one has every assurance.

Translation

"It's not true." His gaze shifted, forming a smile. "Are you absolutely, positively certain?" "As certain as I can be"—Milly's demeanor mirroring her conviction—"when all the evidence supports it."

I speak on the best authority." He hesitated. "Mrs. Lowder's?"

Translation

"I have the best source." He paused. "Mrs. Lowder?"

"No. I don't call Mrs. Lowder's the best." "Oh I thought you were just now saying," he laughed, "that everything about her's so good."

Translation

"No. I wouldn't say Mrs. Lowder's is the best." He chuckled. "I figured you were just saying everything about her is so wonderful."

"Good for you"—she was perfectly clear. "For you," she went on, "let her authority be the best. She doesn't believe what you mention, and you must know yourself how little she makes of it. So you can take it from her.

Translation

"Good for you," she said, crystal clear. "For you," she continued, "let her word be the best. She doesn't believe what you're talking about, and you must know yourself how little she values it. So you can take it from her."

I take it—" But Milly, with the positive tremor of her emphasis, pulled up. "Oh, I'm sorry!" Milly said, blushing from being accused of making such a clumsy mistake. "You're completely wrong." "It's not true then?"

Translation

"I assume—" But Milly, with the emphatic tremor in her voice, stopped short. "Oh, I'm sorry!" Milly said, blushing from being accused of such a clumsy mistake. "You're completely wrong." "So it's not true?"

"It's not true." He smiled, staring at her. "Are you absolutely, positively certain?" "As certain as anyone can be," Milly replied, her tone matching his.

Translation

"It's not true." He smiled, looking at her. "Are you absolutely, positively certain?" "As certain as anyone can be," Milly replied, her tone matching his.

"When you have all the facts. I'm getting my information from the most reliable source." He paused. "Mrs. Beringer."

Lowder?" "No. I wouldn't call Mrs. Lowder the most reliable."

"Lowder?"

Translation

"Oh, but I thought you were just saying," he said, laughing, "that everything about her is so wonderful." "Wonderful for you," she clarified. "You should consider her information the best. She doesn't believe what you mentioned, and you probably know how little she thinks of it."

So you can get it from her. I'm getting it—" Milly stopped abruptly, the emphasis in her voice giving her words a slight tremor. "You take it from Kate?" "From Kate herself."

Translation

"So you can get it from her. I'm getting it—" Milly stopped short, the emphasis in her voice making her words waver slightly. "You're getting it from Kate?" "From Kate herself."

"That she's thinking of no one at all?" "Of no one at all." Then, with her intensity, she went on. "She has given me her word for it." "Oh!" said Lord Mark.

Translation

"That she's not thinking of anyone?" "Of no one at all." Then, with a strong feeling, she continued. "She promised me." "Oh!" said Lord Mark.

To which he next added: "And what do you call her word?" It made Milly, on her side, stare—though perhaps partly but with the instinct of gaining time for the consciousness that she was already a little further "in" than she had designed. "Why, Lord Mark, what should you call her word?" "Ah I'm not obliged to say.

Translation

To which he next added:

"And what do you call her word?" It made Milly, on her side, stare—though perhaps partly only to buy time while realizing that she'd already gotten a little "in" deeper than she'd meant to. "Why, Lord Mark, what should you call her word?" "Ah, I'm not obliged to say."

I've not asked her. You apparently have." Well, it threw her on her defence—a defence that she felt, however, especially as of Kate. "We're very intimate," she said in a moment; "so that, without prying into each other's affairs, she naturally tells me things."

Translation

"I haven't asked her. Apparently you have." Well, this forced her to defend herself—a defense she felt, particularly on Kate's behalf. "We're very close," she said after a moment, "so that, without being nosy, she tells me things naturally."

"You're sure Kate said this?" "I heard it directly from her." "That she isn't interested in anyone?" "That's right, no one." She continued, her voice emphatic, "She promised me."

Translation

"Are you certain Kate said this?" "I heard it straight from her." "That she's not interested in anyone?" "Exactly, no one." She continued, her voice gaining intensity, "She promised me."

"Oh," Lord Mark replied. He added, "And what do you think of her word?" Milly stared at this, possibly just to buy herself time as she realized she'd already revealed more than she'd intended. "Well, Lord Mark, what would you think of her word?"

Translation

"Oh," Lord Mark replied. He added, "And what do you think of her word?" Milly stared at him, perhaps just stalling as she recognized she'd already said too much. "Well, Lord Mark, what do you think of her word?"

"I don't have to say. I didn't ask her. You did, apparently." This put her on the defensive, especially in Kate's defense.

Translation

"I don't need to answer that. I wasn't the one who asked her. You were, it seems." Her tone became sharp, especially as she defended Kate.

"We're very close," she said after a moment. "So, without being nosy, she just tells me things naturally." Lord Mark smiled as at a lame conclusion. "You mean then she made you of her own movement the declaration you quote?"

Translation

"We're very close," she said after a moment. "So, without me prying, she just tells me things naturally." Lord Mark smiled as if at a weak argument. "You mean then she just, of her own accord, made the declaration you're quoting?"

Milly thought again, though with hindrance rather than help in her sense of the way their eyes now met—met as for their each seeing in the other more than either said. What she most felt that she herself saw was the strange disposition on her companion's part to disparage Kate's veracity. She could be only concerned to "stand up" for that. "I mean what I say: that when she spoke of her having no private interest—"

Translation

Milly thought again, though her sense of how their eyes now met was more of a hindrance than a help – they met as though each saw in the other more than either spoke aloud. What she most felt that she herself saw was her companion's strange inclination to discredit Kate's truthfulness. She could only be concerned with "standing up" for that. "I mean what I say: that when she spoke of her having no private interest—"

"She took her oath to you?" Lord Mark interrupted. Milly didn't quite see why he should so catechise her; but she met it again for Kate. "She left me in no doubt whatever of her being free." Lord Mark's smile suggested he found the idea unconvincing.

Translation

"Did she swear it to you?" Lord Mark cut in. Milly wasn't sure why he was questioning her like this, but she stood up for Kate again. "She made it perfectly clear to me that she was unattached." Lord Mark's smile implied he didn't believe it.

"So, you're saying she volunteered the statement you mentioned?" Milly considered, though the way their eyes met, each seeming to understand something unspoken by the other, made it difficult. What she primarily perceived was her companion's peculiar tendency to undermine Kate's truthfulness. She felt compelled to defend Kate.

Translation

"So, you're saying she just offered that information, unprompted?" Milly thought about it, but their eyes locked, communicating something neither of them voiced, making it hard to think clearly. What she really noticed was his strange habit of trying to discredit Kate. She felt a need to stand up for Kate.

"I mean exactly what I said: that when she mentioned not having any personal motives—" "Did she swear it to you?" Lord Mark interrupted. Milly wasn't sure why he was questioning her so closely, but she answered him again for Kate's sake. "She left me with no uncertainty about her freedom."

Translation

"I'm saying precisely what I said: when she stated she had no personal reasons—" Lord Mark cut in, "Did she swear it to you?" Milly didn't understand why he was scrutinizing her so intensely, but she answered him again, defending Kate. "She made it completely clear that she was unbiased."

At this Lord Mark did look at her, though he continued to smile. "And thereby in no doubt of your being too?" It was as if as soon as he had said it, however, he felt it as something of a mistake, and she couldn't herself have told by what queer glare at him she had instantly signified that. He at any rate gave her glare no time to act further; he fell back on the spot, and with a light enough movement, within his rights. "That's all very well, but why in the world, dear lady, should she be swearing to you?"

Translation

At this, Lord Mark did look at her, though he kept smiling. "And thus, you're not in doubt either?" It was as if, as soon as he'd said it, he realized he'd made a mistake, and she couldn't have explained what strange expression she'd used to instantly convey that. At any rate, he didn't give her expression a chance to develop. He retreated, lightly enough, and within his rights. "That's all well and good, but why, dear lady, would she be swearing to you?"

She had to take this "dear lady" as applying to herself; which disconcerted her when he might now so gracefully have used it for the aspersed Kate. Once more it came to her that she must claim her own part of the aspersion. "Because, as I've told you, we're such tremendous friends." Lord Mark glanced at her, though he kept smiling.

Translation

She had to understand that "dear lady" was directed at her, which unsettled her because he could have so easily used it to refer to Kate, who was the subject of the accusation. Once again, it occurred to her that she had to accept her own share of the blame. "Because, as I've told you, we're such tremendous friends." Lord Mark glanced at her, but he continued to smile.

"And thereby, you're also in no doubt, are you?" It was as if he regretted saying it, and she couldn't tell by what strange look she showed him immediately. At least he didn't give her look time to affect him further; he retreated slightly, a casual action, completely within his rights. "That's all well and good, but why, for heaven's sake, should she be vouching for you?" She had to understand "dear lady" as applying to her; this confused her, as he could have gracefully used it for the maligned Kate.

Translation

"And therefore, you understand, don't you?" It was as though he regretted the words, and she couldn't interpret the strange expression that immediately crossed her face. At least he didn't allow her expression to affect him further; he subtly retreated, a casual movement, perfectly acceptable. "That's all fine, but why, for the love of God, would she vouch for you?" She needed to understand that "dear lady" referred to her; this confused her, since he could have easily used it for the accused Kate.

Once again, she realized she had to accept her own share of the accusation. "Because, as I've told you, we're such close friends." "Oh," said Lord Mark, who for the moment looked as if that might have stood rather for an absence of such rigours. He was going, however, as if he had in a manner, at the last, got more or less what he wanted.

Translation

Once more, she understood she was implicated in the accusation. "Because, as I said, we're very close friends." "Oh," said Lord Mark, appearing for a moment as if that explanation might excuse him from any further scrutiny. However, he was leaving, as if he had, in the end, gotten what he wanted.

Milly felt, while he addressed his next few words to leave-taking, that she had given rather more than she intended or than she should be able, when once more getting herself into hand, theoretically to defend. Strange enough in fact that he had had from her, about herself—and, under the searching spell of the place, infinitely straight—what no one else had had: neither Kate, nor Aunt Maud, nor Merton Densher, nor Susan Shepherd. He had made her within a minute, in particular, she was aware, lose her presence of mind, and she now wished he would take himself off, so that she might either recover it or bear the loss better in solitude. If he paused, however, she almost at the same time saw, it was because of his watching the approach, from the end of the sala, of one of the gondoliers, who, whatever excursions were appointed for the party with the attendance of the others, always, as the most decorative, most sashed and starched, remained at the palace on the theory that she might whimsically want him—which she never, in her caged freedom, had yet done.

Translation

Milly felt, as he spoke his farewells, that she'd revealed more than she'd meant to, more than she'd be able to defend once she regained her composure. It was odd that he, of all people, had heard from her, in that intensely revealing atmosphere, things no one else had: not Kate, not Aunt Maud, not Merton Densher, not Susan Shepherd. In a matter of minutes, she realized, he'd made her lose her composure, and now she wished he would just leave so she could either get it back or handle the loss better on her own. But if he paused, she saw at the same time, it was because he was watching the approach, from the end of the hall, of one of the gondoliers. He, along with the others, attended the party on excursions. However, he always stayed at the palace, the most decorative, the most formally dressed, on the off-chance that she might whimsically want him, which she never had, in her confined freedom.

Brown Pasquale, slipping in white shoes over the marble and suggesting to her perpetually charmed vision she could scarce say what, either a mild Hindoo, too noiseless almost for her nerves, or simply a barefooted seaman on the deck of a ship—Pasquale offered to sight a small salver, which he obsequiously held out to her with its burden of a visiting-card. Lord Mark—and as if also for admiration of him—delayed his departure to let her receive it; on which she read it with the instant effect of another blow to her presence of mind. This precarious quantity was indeed now so gone that even for dealing with Pasquale she had to do her best to conceal its disappearance. The effort was made, none the less, by the time she had asked if the gentleman were below and had taken in the fact that he had come up.

Translation

Brown.

Pasquale, moving smoothly in white shoes across the marble, conjured for her a vision so enchanting she could barely define it—either a gentle Indian, nearly too quiet for her nerves, or just a barefoot sailor on a ship’s deck. Pasquale offered a small silver tray, presenting it with a visiting card. Lord Mark—seeming also to admire him—paused his exit to let her receive it. She read it with the immediate effect of another blow to her composure. This fragile quality was now so depleted that even to manage Pasquale, she had to work to hide its absence. She made the effort, nonetheless, by the time she’d asked if the gentleman was downstairs and absorbed the fact that he’d come up.

He had followed the gondolier and was waiting at the top of the staircase. "Oh," said Lord Mark, who for the moment seemed to suggest he wasn't burdened by such formality. He was leaving, though, as if he had, in a way, gotten what he wanted. Milly felt, as he addressed his parting words, that she had revealed more than she intended, and more than she would be able to justify to herself once she regained control.

Translation

He had pursued the gondolier and was waiting at the top of the staircase. "Oh," Lord Mark said, seeming for a moment unconcerned with such things as proper etiquette. He was leaving, though, as if he had, in a way, achieved his aim. Milly felt, as he spoke his farewells, that she had shown more than she intended, and more than she would be able to account for once she was back in control.

It was odd that he, of all people, had gotten from her, about herself—and, under the powerful influence of the setting, with absolute directness—what no one else had: neither Kate, nor Aunt Maud, nor Merton Densher, nor Susan Shepherd. He had, in a matter of seconds, she realized, made her lose her composure, and she now wished he would leave so she could either regain it or bear the loss more privately. If he hesitated, however, she noticed simultaneously, it was because he was watching the approach, from the far end of the hall, of one of the gondoliers, who, even when the rest of the crew went on outings with the group, always, being the most decorative, most formally dressed, stayed at the palace, under the assumption that she might whimsically want him—which she, in her restricted freedom, never had. Brown Pasquale, gliding in white shoes over the marble and presenting to her perpetually fascinated gaze—she could hardly say what, either a gentle Indian, too quiet for her, or simply a barefoot sailor on a ship—Pasquale presented a small tray, which he deferentially offered to her, bearing a visiting card.

Translation

It was strange that he, of all people, had gotten something from her, something about herself. And, under the potent influence of the environment, with absolute candor, he had learned what no one else had: not Kate, not Aunt Maud, not Merton Densher, not Susan Shepherd. In a matter of seconds, she realized, he'd made her lose her composure, and she now wished he would leave so she could either get it back or endure its loss more privately. If he hesitated, however, she noticed at the same time, it was because he was watching the approach, from the far end of the hall, of one of the gondoliers. Even when the rest of the crew went on outings with the group, he always, being the most decorative, most formally dressed, stayed at the palace, under the assumption that she might whimsically want him—which she, in her restricted freedom, never had. Brown Pasquale, gliding in white shoes over the marble and presenting to her perpetually fascinated gaze—she could hardly say what, either a gentle Indian, too quiet for her, or simply a barefoot sailor on a ship—Pasquale presented a small tray, which he deferentially offered to her, bearing a visiting card.

Lord Mark—and as if to also admire the gesture—delayed his exit to allow her to receive it; upon which she read it, which immediately caused her to lose what little composure she had left. This fragile quality was indeed now so gone that even when dealing with Pasquale, she had to struggle to hide its absence. She made the effort, nonetheless, by the time she had asked if the gentleman was downstairs and taken in the fact that he had come up. He had followed the gondolier and was waiting at the top of the staircase.

Translation

Lord Mark—as if wanting to appreciate the moment—postponed his departure to allow her to take the card. She read it, and what little control she had left evaporated. This fragile composure was now so completely gone that she had to work to conceal its absence, even with Pasquale. Nevertheless, she managed an effort, just as she asked if the gentleman was downstairs and absorbed the fact that he'd come up. He had followed the gondolier and was waiting at the top of the stairs.

"I'll see him with pleasure." To which she added for her companion, while Pasquale went off: "Mr. Merton Densher." "Oh!" said Lord Mark—in a manner that, making it resound through the great cool hall, might have carried it even to Densher's ear as a judgement of his identity heard and noted once before

Translation

"I'd be glad to." Then, to her companion as Pasquale departed: "Mr. Merton Densher." "Oh!" said Lord Mark, the sound echoing through the vast, cool hall, perhaps even reaching Densher's ear as an assessment of his identity, heard and noted previously.

Chapter 11

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A man, Densher, asks Kate about Mrs. Lowder's (Aunt Maud's) opinion of their frequent meetings. Kate dismisses his concern, causing him to blush. Her tone softens, and she questions the value of their meetings. He replies that they are not enough, but more than Mrs. Lowder gets. Kate explains that Mrs. Lowder believes what she wants to be true and assumes her plans for them are succeeding. Densher asks if Mrs. Lowder believes Kate now dislikes him. Kate says he could make her believe it. When he asks how, she tells him not by lying, but by praising Milly, another woman in their party. The conversation shifts, and Densher asks about Lord Mark's recent brief visit. Kate explains that Lord Mark came to Venice, proposed marriage to Milly, was rejected, and left immediately. The discussion returns to their own arrangement. Densher complains that Kate expects a great deal from him but gives him no "proof" in return. He challenges her claim that she is risking anything in their plan. She grows impatient and asks what he wants her to risk. He replies that he wants to be loved and cannot continue without "help." He suggests they end the deception and "face the music." Kate refuses, saying they have gone too far and asks if he wants to kill Milly. She says they have told too many lies. Densher denies having told any lies and threatens to leave that night. Kate tells him, "Then go." As they walk on in silence, Densher suddenly grabs her arm, stopping her. He says he will tell any lie she requires if she will come to his rooms. She asks how and where. He explains that it can be arranged. Before she answers, she sees their companions—Mrs. Lowder and Mrs. Stringham—emerging from a lace shop. She tells Densher to take his hand from her arm. They walk side-by-side to rejoin the waiting group.

Densher became aware, afresh, that he disliked his hotel—and all the more promptly that he had had occasion of old to make the same discrimination. The establishment, choked at that season with the polyglot herd, cockneys of all climes, mainly German, mainly American, mainly English, it appeared as the corresponding sensitive nerve was touched, sounded loud and not sweet, sounded anything and everything but Italian, but Venetian. The Venetian was all a dialect, he knew; yet it was pure Attic beside some of the dialects at the bustling inn. It made, "abroad," both for his pleasure and his pain that he had to feel at almost any point how he had been through every thing before.

Translation

Densher realized again that he disliked his hotel—and this was even more immediate since he’d already felt this way before. The place, crammed at that time of year with a cacophony of languages, Londoners from every corner of the world, mostly German, mostly American, mostly English, seemed, when the appropriate sensitive nerve was struck, to sound loud and unpleasant. It sounded like anything and everything but Italian, but Venetian. He knew Venetian was just a dialect, but it was like pure Attic Greek compared to some of the other dialects in the busy hotel. Abroad, it was both a pleasure and a burden that he had to sense, at nearly every moment, how he had experienced it all before.

He had been three or four times, in Venice, during other visits, through this pleasant irritation of paddling away—away from the concert of false notes in the vulgarised hall, away from the amiable American families and overfed German porters. He had in each case made terms for a lodging more private and not more costly, and he recalled with tenderness these shabby but friendly asylums, the windows of which he should easily know again in passing on canal or through campo. The shabbiest now failed of an appeal to him, but he found himself at the end of forty-eight hours forming views in respect to a small independent quartiere, far down the Grand Canal, which he had once occupied for a month with a sense of pomp and circumstance and yet also with a growth of initiation into the homelier Venetian mysteries. The humour of those days came back to him for an hour, and what further befell in this interval, to be brief, was that, emerging on a traghetto in sight of the recognised house, he made out on the green shutters of his old, of his young windows the strips of white pasted paper that figure in Venice as an invitation to tenants.

Translation

He had, during previous trips to Venice, three or four times enjoyed this pleasant sensation of drifting away—away from the concert of discordant sounds in the hall, away from the friendly American families and the overfed German porters. Each time, he’d secured a more private, though not more expensive, lodging, and he remembered these humble but welcoming refuges with affection. He knew he would recognize their windows again as he passed by on the canal or through the campo. The shabbiest of them held no appeal for him now, but after forty-eight hours, he found himself considering a small, independent neighborhood, far down the Grand Canal, where he had once lived for a month, experiencing a sense of grandeur and also gaining insight into the more intimate Venetian secrets. The humor of those days returned to him for an hour, and what happened next, in short, was this: emerging onto a traghetto in view of the familiar house, he noticed on the green shutters of his old, young windows the strips of white paper that Venetians use to advertise a rental.

This was in the course of his very first walk apart, a walk replete with impressions to which he responded with force. He had been almost without cessation, since his arrival, at Palazzo Leporelli, where, as happened, a turn of bad weather on the second day had kept the whole party continuously at home. The episode had passed for him like a series of hours in a museum, though without the fatigue of that; and it had also resembled something that he was still, with a stirred imagination, to find a name for. He might have been looking for the name while he gave himself up, subsequently, to the ramble—he saw that even after years he couldn't lose his way—crowned with his stare across the water at the little white papers.

Translation

This happened during his very first walk alone, a walk full of impressions that strongly affected him. Since his arrival, he had been almost constantly at Palazzo Leporelli, where, as luck would have it, a spell of bad weather on the second day had kept everyone inside. This period had felt to him like a series of hours spent in a museum, though without the exhaustion; it also resembled something he hadn't yet named, though his imagination was already at work. He might have been searching for that name as he surrendered to the walk—he saw that even after all these years, he couldn't get lost—and he concluded his thoughts by staring across the water at the little white papers.

"I'll be glad to see him." She then added for her companion, as Pasquale left, "Mr. Merton Densher." "Oh!" said Lord Mark—his tone echoing through the vast, cool hall, perhaps even reaching Densher's ears as a judgment of his identity, heard and noted before. BOOK EIGHTH

Translation

"I'm looking forward to seeing him." Then, as Pasquale departed, she said to the person with her, "Mr. Merton Densher." "Oh!" Lord Mark said, his voice echoing through the enormous, cool hall, possibly even reaching Densher's ears as an assessment of who he was, heard and registered in advance. BOOK EIGHTH

I Densher was again aware that he disliked his hotel—and all the more quickly because he'd felt the same way before. The place, crowded that time of year with a cacophony of languages, people from everywhere, mostly German, American, and English, sounded loud and unpleasant, anything but Italian, anything but Venetian, as that sensitive part of him was triggered. He knew the Venetian dialect was different, but it was pure compared to some of the dialects at the busy hotel.

Translation

Densher once again realized how much he disliked his hotel, and all the more quickly because he’d felt this way before. The place, crowded at that time of year with a cacophony of languages, the voices of people from everywhere, mostly German, American, and English, sounded loud and unpleasant, anything but Italian, anything but Venetian, as that sensitive part of him was triggered. He knew the Venetian dialect was different, but it was pure compared to some of the dialects at the busy hotel.

"Abroad" made him both happy and annoyed that he had to realize at almost every turn that he'd experienced everything already. He'd been to Venice several times before, and during those visits, he'd gone through this familiar irritation of escaping—escaping the discordant sounds of the vulgar hall, escaping the friendly American families and the overfed German porters. Each time, he'd found a cheaper, more private place to stay, and he remembered with fondness those run-down but welcoming havens, whose windows he'd easily recognize while passing on the canal or through the campo. The shabbiest now didn't appeal to him, but after two days, he found himself thinking about a small, independent neighborhood far down the Grand Canal, where he'd once stayed for a month with a sense of importance and also a growing understanding of the more intimate Venetian secrets.

Translation

Being "abroad" made him simultaneously pleased and exasperated by the persistent awareness that he'd already done it all. He'd been to Venice before, numerous times, and each trip had involved the now-familiar annoyance of getting away—escaping the jarring noise of the vulgar hotel lobby, escaping the amiable American families and the overfed German bellhops. Every time, he'd sought out a more affordable, more private accommodation, and he recalled with affection those shabby but inviting sanctuaries, whose windows he would easily spot while traveling on the canal or through the campo. The most run-down options held no appeal for him now, but after two days, he found himself thinking about a small, independent neighborhood, far down the Grand Canal, where he'd once resided for a month, experiencing a sense of significance, and also cultivating an evolving comprehension of the more private Venetian mysteries.

The humor of those days returned to him for an hour, and briefly, what happened next was that, emerging on a traghetto with his old home in sight, he noticed on the green shutters of his old windows the white paper strips that indicated a place was available to rent. This was during his first real walk alone, a walk full of impressions to which he strongly reacted. He'd been almost constantly at Palazzo Leporelli since he arrived, where, as it happened, a spell of bad weather on the second day had kept everyone inside. The experience had seemed like a series of hours in a museum, though without the fatigue; it had also resembled something he was still, with a stirred imagination, trying to define.

Translation

The humor of those days resurfaced, and for a short time, this is what happened: exiting a traghetto with his former residence in view, he saw white rental notices affixed to the green shutters of his old windows. This occurred during his first genuine solitary walk, a walk abundant with sensations to which he responded with intensity. He’d spent almost all his time at Palazzo Leporelli since arriving, where, as luck would have it, a stretch of inclement weather on the second day had confined everyone indoors. The experience felt like an extended museum visit, albeit without the exhaustion; it was also similar to something he was still, with a stimulated imagination, trying to articulate.

He might have been looking for the name as he gave himself over to the stroll—he realized even after all this time, he couldn't get lost—culminating with his gaze across the water at the little white papers. He was to dine at the palace in an hour or two, and he had lunched there, at an early luncheon, that morning. He had then been out with the three ladies, the three being Mrs. Lowder, Mrs.

Translation

He might have been searching for the name as he let himself wander—he realized, even after all this time, he couldn't get lost—until his eyes landed on the small white papers across the water. He was scheduled to dine at the palace in an hour or two, and he'd had lunch there that very morning, an early luncheon. He'd then gone out with the three ladies, namely Mrs. Lowder, Mrs.
