Stringham and Kate, and had kept afloat with them, under a sufficient Venetian spell, until Aunt Maud had directed him to leave them and return to Miss Theale. Of two circumstances connected with this disposition of his person he was even now not unmindful; the first being that the lady of Lancaster Gate had addressed him with high publicity and as if expressing equally the sense of her companions, who had not spoken, but who might have been taken—yes, Susan Shepherd quite equally with Kate—for inscrutable parties to her plan. What he could as little contrive to forget was that he had, before the two others, as it struck him—that was to say especially before Kate—done exactly as he was bidden; gathered himself up without a protest and retraced his way to the palace. Present with him still was the question of whether he looked a fool for it, of whether the awkwardness he felt as the gondola rocked with the business of his leaving it—they could but make, in submission, for a landing-place that was none of the best—had furnished his friends with such entertainment as was to cause them, behind his back, to exchange intelligent smiles.

Translation

Stringham and Kate, and he'd kept afloat with them, under a sufficient Venetian spell, until Aunt Maud had told him to leave them and go back to Miss Theale. He was still mindful of two things related to how he'd been told to do this. The first was that the woman from Lancaster Gate had spoken to him publicly, as if she were also expressing what the others thought, even though they hadn't said anything. He thought they could have been, yes, Susan Shepherd as easily as Kate, that they were equally in on her plan. What he also couldn't forget was that he had, in front of the other two, especially before Kate, done exactly as he was told. He'd gathered himself together without protesting and gone back to the palace. He was still wondering if he'd looked like a fool, if the awkwardness he'd felt as the gondola swayed when he left—they could only go to a landing spot that wasn't very good—had entertained his friends enough to make them exchange knowing smiles behind his back.

He had found Milly Theale twenty minutes later alone, and he had sat with her till the others returned to tea. The strange part of this was that it had been very easy, extraordinarily easy. He knew it for strange only when he was away from her, because when he was away from her he was in contact with particular things that made it so. At the time, in her presence, it was as simple as sitting with his sister might have been, and not, if the point were urged, very much more thrilling.

Translation

He'd found Milly Theale alone twenty minutes later, and he'd stayed with her until the others came back for tea. The odd thing was that it had been very easy, extraordinarily easy. He only knew it was strange when he was away from her, because when he was away from her he was in contact with specific things that made it so. At the time, with her, it was as simple as sitting with his sister might have been, and not, if the matter were pushed, much more exciting.

He continued to see her as he had first seen her—that remained ineffaceably behind. Mrs. Lowder, Susan Shepherd, his own Kate, might, each in proportion, see her as a princess, as an angel, as a star, but for himself, luckily, she hadn't as yet complications to any point of discomfort: the princess, the angel, the star, were muffled over, ever so lightly and brightly, with the little American girl who had been kind to him in New York and to whom certainly—though without making too much of it for either of them—he was perfectly willing to be kind in return. She appreciated his coming in on purpose, but there was nothing in that—from the moment she was always at home—that they couldn't easily keep up.

Translation

He continued to see her as he had first seen her—that image remained indelible. Mrs. Lowder, Susan Shepherd, his own Kate, might each, in their own way, see her as a princess, an angel, a star, but for him, fortunately, she didn't yet have complexities that caused any unease. The princess, the angel, the star, were gently and brightly veiled by the little American girl who had been kind to him in New York, and to whom—though without making a big deal of it for either of them—he was perfectly happy to be kind in return. She appreciated his coming on purpose, but there was nothing in that—since she was always available—that they couldn't easily maintain.

The only note the least bit high that had even yet sounded between them was this admission on her part that she found it best to remain within. She wouldn't let him call it keeping quiet, for she insisted that her palace—with all its romance and art and history—had set up round her a whirlwind of suggestion that never dropped for an hour. It wasn't therefore, within such walls, confinement, it was the freedom of all the centuries: in respect to which Densher granted good-humouredly that they were then blown together, she and he, as much as she liked, through space. He was scheduled to dine at the palace in an hour or two, and he'd had lunch there earlier that morning.

Translation

The only hint of tension between them thus far had been her admission that she preferred to stay indoors. She didn't want him to call it keeping quiet, because she insisted her palace—with all its romance, art, and history—had conjured a constant whirlwind of suggestion that never faded. So within those walls, it wasn't confinement; it was the freedom of all the centuries. Densher good-naturedly conceded that they were then swept together, she and he, through space, as much as she wished. He was expected to dine at the palace in an hour or two, and he'd had lunch there earlier that morning.

He'd been out with the three women—Mrs. Lowder, Mrs. Stringham, and Kate—and had remained with them, under the enchantment of Venice, until Aunt Maud told him to leave them and go back to Miss Theale. He still remembered two things about this arrangement.

Translation

He had spent time with the three women—Mrs. Lowder, Mrs. Stringham, and Kate—and stayed with them, captivated by Venice, until Aunt Maud told him to go, back to Miss Theale. He still recalled two things about this arrangement.

First, the woman from Lancaster Gate had spoken to him publicly, as if she were also expressing the feelings of her companions, who hadn't said anything but might have been considered—yes, Susan Shepherd just as much as Kate—complicit in her plan. He also couldn't forget that he'd done exactly as he was told, in front of the other two, particularly Kate. He'd gathered himself together without protesting and gone back to the palace. The question of whether he'd looked like a fool for doing so was still on his mind.

Translation

First, the woman from Lancaster Gate had addressed him openly, as though she spoke for them all, even though they’d remained silent, possibly implicating them—Susan Shepherd as much as Kate—in her intentions. He also remembered he had complied without a word, in front of the other two, and especially Kate. He’d straightened himself up, made no objections, and returned to the palace. The question of whether he’d appeared foolish by doing so continued to trouble him.

He wondered if the awkwardness he'd felt as the gondola swayed while he was leaving—they could only find a mediocre landing spot—had entertained his friends enough to make them exchange knowing smiles behind his back. He'd found Milly Theale alone twenty minutes later, and he'd stayed with her until the others returned for tea. The strange thing was that it had been easy, remarkably easy. He only recognized this strangeness when he was away from her, because when he was away from her, he was in contact with specific things that made it so.

Translation

He wondered if the instability of the gondola as he disembarked—they'd had to settle for a second-rate dock—had provided his companions with sufficient amusement to cause them to exchange knowing glances behind his back. Twenty minutes later, he had found Milly Theale alone, and remained with her until the others returned for tea. The curious part was how simple it had been, unexpectedly simple. He only understood this peculiarity when he was away from her, because when he was away from her, he interacted with particular things that made it so.

At the time, with her, it was as simple as sitting with his sister might have been, and not, if you pushed the issue, much more exciting. He still saw her as he had first seen her—that memory remained clear. Mrs. Lowder, Susan Shepherd, and his own Kate might each see her as a princess, an angel, a star, but fortunately for him, she didn't yet have qualities that caused him any discomfort.

Translation

With her then, it was as easy as sitting with a sister, and if you pressed it, not much more thrilling. He still saw her as he first saw her—that memory stuck. Mrs. Lowder, Susan Shepherd, and his own Kate might each see her as a princess, an angel, a star, but luckily for him, she didn’t have qualities that bothered him yet.

The princess, the angel, and the star were veiled, lightly and brightly, with the little American girl who had been kind to him in New York and to whom, certainly—though without making too much of it for either of them—he was happy to return the kindness. She was glad he'd come on purpose, but there was nothing in that—since she was always available—that they couldn't easily maintain. The only slightly unusual thing that had happened between them was her admitting that she preferred to stay inside. She wouldn't let him call it staying quiet because she insisted that her palace—with all its romance, art, and history—had created a whirlwind of inspiration around her that never stopped for a moment.

Translation

The princess, the angel, and the star were all lightly and brightly overshadowed by the young American girl who had been friendly to him in New York. He felt genuinely pleased to reciprocate her kindness, although neither of them made a big deal out of it. She was glad he had come specifically to see her, but their relationship, with her perpetual availability, was easily sustained. The only slightly out-of-the-ordinary thing between them was her admission that she preferred to stay indoors. She didn't like him calling it "quiet," because she insisted that her palace, with all its romance, art, and history, had created a constant whirlwind of inspiration around her.

So, within those walls, it wasn't confinement; it was the freedom of all the centuries. Regarding this, Densher agreed good-naturedly that they were, then, blown together, she and he, as much as she liked, through space. Kate had found on the present occasion a moment to say to him that he suggested a clever cousin calling on a cousin afflicted, and bored for his pains; and though he denied on the spot the "bored" he could so far see it as an impression he might make that he wondered if the same image wouldn't have occurred to Milly. As soon as Kate appeared again the difference came up—the oddity, as he then instantly felt it, of his having sunk so deep.

Translation

Within those walls, it wasn't confinement; it was the freedom of centuries. Densher good-naturedly agreed that they were, then, blown together, she and he, as much as she liked, through space. Kate had found a moment to tell him that he reminded her of a clever cousin visiting a cousin who was suffering and bored as a result. Although he immediately denied being "bored," he could see that as an impression he might be giving, and he wondered if the same idea had occurred to Milly. As soon as Kate reappeared, the difference came up—the oddness, as he immediately felt it, of his having sunk so deep.

It was sinking because it was all doing what Kate had conceived for him; it wasn't in the least doing—and that had been his notion of his life—anything he himself had conceived. The difference, accordingly, renewed, sharp, sore, was the irritant under which he had quitted the palace and under which he was to make the best of the business of again dining there. He said to himself that he must make the best of everything; that was in his mind, at the traghetto, even while, with his preoccupation about changing quarters, he studied, across the canal, the look of his former abode. It had done for the past, would it do for the present?

Translation

It was sinking because it was all playing out according to Kate's plan for him. It wasn't doing—and that had been his idea of his life—anything he himself had envisioned. The difference, therefore, reemerged, sharp, painful, a source of irritation that had driven him from the palace and under which he was now supposed to make the best of the situation by dining there again. He told himself he had to make the best of everything; that was on his mind at the gondola stop, even while he was distracted by the prospect of changing locations, and he studied the look of his former residence across the canal. It had served for the past; would it serve for the present?

would it play in any manner into the general necessity of which he was conscious? That necessity of making the best was the instinct—as he indeed himself knew—of a man somehow aware that if he let go at one place he should let go everywhere. If he took off his hand, the hand that at least helped to hold it together, the whole queer fabric that built him in would fall away in a minute and admit the light. It was really a matter of nerves; it was exactly because he was nervous that he could go straight; yet if that condition should increase he must surely go wild.

Translation

Would it contribute in any way to the overarching obligation of which he was aware? This obligation to make the best of it was an instinct—as he, in fact, knew—of a man somehow conscious that if he faltered in one place, he would falter everywhere. If he removed his hand, the hand that at least helped keep it all together, the strange construction that defined him would collapse in an instant and expose everything. It was really a matter of nerves; it was precisely because he was nervous that he could remain composed; yet if that state were to worsen, he would certainly unravel.

He was walking in short on a high ridge, steep down on either side, where the proprieties—once he could face at all remaining there—reduced themselves to his keeping his head. It was Kate who had so perched him, and there came up for him at moments, as he found himself planting one foot exactly before another, a sensible sharpness of irony as to her management of him. It wasn't that she had put him in danger—to be in real danger with her would have had another quality. There glowed for him in fact a kind of rage at what he wasn't having; an exasperation, a resentment, begotten truly by the very impatience of desire, in respect to his postponed and relegated, his so extremely manipulated state.

Translation

He was walking, in short, on a high ridge, steep on both sides, where the proprieties—once he could face remaining there at all—came down to just keeping his head. It was Kate who had perched him there, and moments would find him, as he placed one foot precisely in front of the other, seized by a sharp, sensible irony concerning her management of him. It wasn't that she had put him in danger—to be in real danger with her would have been a different thing altogether. In fact, a kind of rage glowed within him at what he wasn't having: an exasperation, a resentment born truly of the very impatience of desire, with regard to his postponed, relegated, and extremely manipulated state.

It was beautifully done of her, but what was the real meaning of it unless that he was perpetually bent to her will? His idea from the first, from the very first of his knowing her, had been to be, as the French called it, bon prince with her, mindful of the good humour and generosity, the contempt, in the matter of confidence, for small outlays and small savings, that belonged to the man who wasn't generally afraid. There were things enough, goodness knew—for it was the moral of his plight—that he couldn't afford; but what had had a charm for him if not the notion of living handsomely, to make up for it, in another way? of not at all events reading the romance of his existence in a cheap edition.

Translation

It was a masterful performance on her part, but what did it truly signify if not that he was constantly subject to her will? His intention from the very beginning, from the first moment he knew her, had been to treat her with generosity and good grace, to be mindful of good humor and a refusal to be stingy with either confidences or expenditures, qualities that defined a man unafraid to live fully. There were, God knows—and this was the moral of his situation—things he simply couldn't afford. But what had drawn him to her if not the idea of living handsomely to compensate? Of, in any case, avoiding a cheap, tawdry version of his own existence.

All he had originally felt in her came back to him, was indeed actually as present as ever—how he had admired and envied what he called to himself her pure talent for life, as distinguished from his own, a poor weak thing of the occasion, amateurishly patched up; only it irritated him the more that this was exactly what was now, ever so characteristically, standing out in her. Kate had found a moment to tell him that he reminded her of a clever cousin visiting a cousin who was suffering and bored; although he immediately denied being "bored," he could see how he might give that impression, and he wondered if Milly would have thought the same thing. As soon as Kate reappeared, the difference became clear—the strange fact, as he then immediately felt it, of how deeply he'd sunk. It was sinking because everything he was doing was what Kate had planned for him; it wasn't at all doing—and that had been his idea of his life—anything he himself had conceived.

Translation

Everything he'd initially felt for her resurfaced, was in fact as present as ever—how he'd admired and envied what he privately called her innate talent for life, unlike his own, a weak and pathetic thing, amateurishly put together; it only irritated him more that this was precisely what now, so characteristically, was most prominent in her. Kate had taken the opportunity to tell him that he reminded her of a clever cousin visiting a cousin who was suffering and bored; though he immediately denied being "bored," he could see how he might give that impression, and he wondered if Milly would have thought the same thing. As soon as Kate reappeared, the difference became clear—the strange fact, as he then immediately felt it, of how deeply he'd sunk. He was sinking because everything he was doing was what Kate had planned for him; it wasn't at all doing—and that had been his idea of his life—anything he himself had conceived.

The difference, therefore, reemerged, sharp and painful, as the irritant that had made him leave the palace and that would force him to make the best of again dining there. He told himself that he must make the best of everything; that was on his mind, at the ferry, even as he studied the look of his former home across the canal, preoccupied with changing his residence. It had worked for the past; would it work for the present? Would it in any way fit into the overall necessity he was conscious of?

Translation

The difference, sharp and painful, returned, the same irritant that had driven him from the palace and now compelled him to make the most of dining there again. He repeated to himself that he must make the best of everything; the thought was with him on the ferry, even as he considered the appearance of his former home across the canal, preoccupied as he was with changing his address. It had worked in the past; would it work now? Would it contribute in any way to the larger necessities he felt?

That necessity of making the best of things was the instinct—as he himself knew—of a man somehow aware that if he gave up in one place, he would give up everywhere. If he removed his hand, the hand that at least helped hold things together, the whole strange structure that defined him would collapse in a minute and let in the light. It was really a matter of nerves; it was exactly because he was nervous that he could stay on track; yet if that condition increased, he would surely go crazy. In short, he was walking on a high ridge, with a steep drop on either side, where the expected behavior—once he could face remaining there at all—was reduced to keeping his head.

Translation

This instinct to make the best of things was, as he understood it, the driving force of a man who knew that if he surrendered in one instance, he would surrender entirely. If he withdrew his hand, the hand that, at a minimum, kept things from falling apart, the peculiar construct that defined him would crumble instantly, exposing everything. It was, truly, a matter of nerves; it was precisely his anxiety that allowed him to stay the course, and yet, if that anxiety intensified, it would inevitably drive him mad. In essence, he was traversing a high ridge, with a precipitous descent on either side, where his expected behavior—once he could accept remaining there at all—was simply to remain composed.

It was Kate who had put him there, and at moments, as he found himself carefully placing one foot in front of the other, a sensible sharpness of irony regarding her control of him came over him. It wasn't that she had put him in danger—being in real danger with her would have been a different experience. In fact, he felt a kind of rage at what he wasn't experiencing; an exasperation and resentment, born truly of the very impatience of desire, in regard to his postponed and relegated, his so extremely manipulated state. It was beautifully done by her, but what was the real meaning of it unless that he was perpetually subject to her will?

Translation

Kate had put him in this position, and as he focused on the deliberate placement of each step, a clear and reasonable irony regarding her influence over him surfaced. It wasn't that she had put him in harm's way—actual danger with her would have been a different matter altogether. He was, in truth, angered by what he was not experiencing; an exasperation and resentment that stemmed from the very restlessness of desire itself, concerning his delayed and restricted, his thoroughly manipulated situation. Her actions were artful, but what did they signify other than his perpetual subjugation to her will?

His idea from the start, from the very beginning of knowing her, had been to be, as the French would say, a good sport with her, mindful of the good humor and generosity, the lack of concern for small details and careful economies, that belonged to the man who wasn't generally afraid. There were enough things, goodness knows—for it was the lesson of his predicament—that he couldn't afford; but what had charmed him if not the idea of living handsomely, to make up for it, in another way? Of not at all events reading the romance of his existence in a cheap edition. All he had originally felt for her came back to him, was indeed actually as present as ever—how he had admired and envied what he called her pure talent for life, as distinct from his own, a poor weak thing of the moment, amateurishly put together; only it irritated him all the more that this was exactly what was now, so characteristically, standing out in her.

Translation

His intention from the start, from the moment he knew her, had been to, as the French say, be a good sport with her. He wanted to be mindful of her good humor and generosity, the lack of concern for small details and careful economies that characterized a man without fear. There were plenty of things he couldn't afford—that was the lesson of his situation—but what had attracted him to her if not the idea of living handsomely, making up for it in another way? Not reading the romance of his existence in a cheap edition. Everything he'd felt for her initially came back to him, as present as ever—how he'd admired and envied what he called her pure talent for life, in contrast to his own, a weak thing of the moment, amateurishly put together. It only irritated him more that this was exactly what now, so characteristically, stood out in her.

It was thanks to her pure talent for life, verily, that he was just where he was and that he was above all just how he was. The proof of a decent reaction in him against so much passivity was, with no great richness, that he at least knew—knew, that is, how he was, and how little he liked it as a thing accepted in mere helplessness. He was, for the moment, wistful—that above all described it; that was so large a part of the force that, as the autumn afternoon closed in, kept him, on his traghetto, positively throbbing with his question. His question connected itself, even while he stood, with his special smothered soreness, his sense almost of shame; and the soreness and the shame were less as he let himself, with the help of the conditions about him, regard it as serious.

Translation

It was, in fact, because of her pure talent for life that he found himself precisely where he was, and, more importantly, exactly as he was. The evidence of a healthy reaction within him, a response to so much passivity, amounted to this: though he possessed little in the way of wealth, he at least understood—that is, he knew—how he was, and how little he enjoyed it as something passively accepted. He felt wistful, for the time being—that word captured it best; it comprised so much of the power that kept him, as the autumn afternoon drew to a close, positively vibrating with his question, there on his gondola-ferry. His question, even as he stood there, became connected to his particular, suppressed anguish, his feeling bordering on shame; and that anguish and shame diminished as he allowed himself, aided by his surroundings, to consider them significant.

It was born, for that matter, partly of the conditions, those conditions that Kate had so almost insolently braved, had been willing, without a pang, to see him ridiculously—ridiculously so far as just complacently—exposed to. How little it could be complacently he was to feel with the last thoroughness before he had moved from his point of vantage. His question, as we have called it, was the interesting question of whether he had really no will left. How could he know—that was the point—without putting the matter to the test?

Translation

It came about, in a way, because of the circumstances, the very circumstances that Kate had almost insolently defied, had been willing to see him, without a second thought, looking ridiculous—ridiculous in a way that was simply complacent. He was to experience how little of that complacency there was to feel before he moved from his vantage point, and with the utmost thoroughness. His question, as we've called it, was the interesting question of whether he truly had no will left. How could he know—that was the key—without putting it to the test?

It had been right to be bon prince, and the joy, something of the pride, of having lived, in spirit, handsomely, was even now compatible with the impulse to look into their account; but he held his breath a little as it came home to him with supreme sharpness that, whereas he had done absolutely everything that Kate had wanted, she had done nothing whatever that he had. So it was in fine that his idea of the test by which he must try that possibility kept referring itself, in the warm early dusk, the approach of the Southern night—"conditions" these, such as we just spoke of—to the glimmer, more and more ghostly as the light failed, of the little white papers on his old green shutters. By the time he looked at his watch he had been for a quarter of an hour at this post of observation and reflexion; but by the time he walked away again he had found his answer to the idea that had grown so importunate. Since a proof of his will was wanted it was indeed very exactly in wait for him—it lurked there on the other side of the Canal.

Translation

It had been correct to be gracious, and the joy, some of the pride, of having lived, in spirit, handsomely, was even now compatible with the impulse to examine their account; but he held his breath a little as it came home to him with supreme sharpness that, whereas he had done absolutely everything that Kate had wanted, she had done nothing whatever that he had. So it was in the end that his idea of the test by which he must try that possibility kept referring itself, in the warm early dusk, the approach of the Southern night—"conditions" these, such as we just spoke of—to the glimmer, more and more ghostly as the light failed, of the little white papers on his old green shutters. By the time he looked at his watch he had been for a quarter of an hour at this post of observation and reflection; but by the time he walked away again he had found his answer to the idea that had grown so importunate. Since a proof of his will was wanted it was indeed very exactly in wait for him—it lurked there on the other side of the Canal.

A ferryman at the little pier had from time to time accosted him; but it was a part of the play of his nervousness to turn his back on that facility. He would go over, but he walked, very quickly, round and round, crossing finally by the Rialto. The rooms, in the event, were unoccupied; the ancient padrona was there with her smile all a radiance but her recognition all a fable; the ancient rickety objects too, refined in their shabbiness, amiable in their decay, as to which, on his side, demonstrations were tenderly veracious; so that before he took his way again he had arranged to come in on the morrow. It was truly because of her innate zest for life that he was in his current situation and, above all, was exactly the way he was.

Translation

A ferryman at the small pier had occasionally approached him, but it was part of his anxious performance to refuse the offer. He would go over, but instead, he walked, quickly, in circles, eventually crossing by the Rialto. The rooms, as it happened, were empty; the old landlady was there, radiating a smile that was completely deceptive; the old, ramshackle furnishings, too, refined in their shabbiness, agreeable in their decay, and his displays of affection for them were genuinely heartfelt. Thus, before leaving, he made arrangements to return the next day. It was truly because of her inherent love of life that he was in his present state, and above all, exactly the way he was.

The evidence of his decent reaction to so much passivity, though not abundant, was that he, at the very least, understood—understood how he was, and how little he liked being that way, accepting it out of mere helplessness. He felt wistful, above all else; that described it perfectly. It was a significant part of the feeling that, as the autumn afternoon drew to a close, kept him on his traghetto, positively consumed by his question. His question was connected to his specific, concealed bitterness, his almost shameful feeling.

Translation

His decent response to all this inaction, though not overt, was that he understood—at the very least, he understood how he was and how much he disliked being that way, resigned to it out of sheer powerlessness. Above all, he felt a profound melancholy; that captured it perfectly. It was a core component of the sensation that, as the autumn afternoon waned, kept him on his traghetto, completely absorbed by his question. His question was bound up with his specific, hidden resentment, his almost shameful feeling.

That soreness and shame lessened as he allowed himself, aided by his surroundings, to consider it as a serious matter. It originated, in fact, partially from those conditions—the conditions that Kate had so brazenly defied, and was willing to see him exposed to, in a ridiculous, even complacent manner. How little he could feel complacent about it was something he would fully experience before leaving his vantage point. The question, as we’ve called it, was the intriguing question of whether he truly had no will left.

Translation

The ache and the shame diminished as he, with the help of his environment, began to treat his plight with the gravity it deserved. In truth, it stemmed partly from those circumstances—the circumstances Kate had so flagrantly disregarded and was prepared to let him suffer through, in a way that was absurd, even self-satisfied. He would come to understand just how little cause he had for complacency before he abandoned his post. The question, as we’ve termed it, was the compelling question of whether he possessed any will at all.

How could he know—that was the key—without putting the matter to the test? He’d done the right thing by being gracious, and the pleasure, some of the pride, of having lived honorably in spirit, was still compatible with the desire to examine it more closely. But he held his breath a little as it dawned on him with absolute clarity that, while he had done everything Kate wanted, she had done absolutely nothing that he wanted. And so, his idea of the test by which he must assess that possibility kept returning, in the warm early dusk, with the approach of the Southern night—"conditions" like the ones we just mentioned—to the increasingly ghostly glimmer of the little white papers on his old green shutters.

Translation

How could he possibly know—that was the crucial point—without actually testing the situation? He’d behaved well by being magnanimous, and the satisfaction, some of the pride, from having acted with integrity was still compatible with his need to investigate this more thoroughly. But he found himself holding his breath slightly as it became absolutely clear to him that, while he had done everything Kate wanted, she hadn't done anything he wanted. And so, the concept of the test by which he must evaluate that likelihood kept returning, in the warm light of the early evening, as the Southern night drew near—"conditions" like those we described earlier—to the increasingly eerie glow of the small white papers on his old green shutters.

By the time he looked at his watch, he’d been at this place for observation and reflection for a quarter of an hour; but by the time he walked away again, he’d found his answer to the idea that had become so pressing. Since he needed proof of his will, it was indeed waiting for him—it was concealed on the other side of the Canal. The ferryman at the little pier had occasionally approached him; but it was part of his nervousness to ignore that opportunity. He would go over there, but instead, he walked rapidly around, finally crossing by the Rialto.

Translation

By the time he checked his watch, he’d been stationed there, observing and considering, for fifteen minutes. But when he finally left, he’d come to a conclusion about the question that had become so urgent. He needed proof of his own determination, and it was indeed there, waiting for him, hidden on the other side of the Canal. The ferryman at the small pier had sometimes approached him, but he was too anxious to take advantage of that option. He would go there eventually, but instead, he quickly circled around, ultimately crossing the Rialto Bridge.

The rooms, as it happened, were empty; the old landlady was there, her smile beaming, her recognition a complete fabrication. The old, rickety objects were there too, refined in their shabbiness, charming in their decay. He, for his part, made tenderly truthful declarations. Before he departed, he arranged to return the next day.

Translation

The rooms were, as luck would have it, vacant. The aging landlady was present, her smile radiant, her acknowledgment entirely feigned. The antique, unstable furnishings were also there, elegant in their dilapidation, endearing in their decrepitude. As for him, he uttered heartfelt, sincere statements. Before leaving, he made arrangements to come back the following day.

He was amusing about it that evening at dinner—in spite of an odd first impulse, which at the palace quite melted away, to treat it merely as matter for his own satisfaction. This need, this propriety, he had taken for granted even up to the moment of suddenly perceiving, in the course of talk, that the incident would minister to innocent gaiety. Such was quite its effect, with the aid of his picture—an evocation of the quaint, of the humblest rococo, of a Venetian interior in the true old note. He made the point for his hostess that her own high chambers, though they were a thousand grand things, weren't really this; made it in fact with such success that she presently declared it his plain duty to invite her on some near day to tea.

Translation

That evening, at dinner, he found the whole thing quite amusing. Despite an initial, strange inclination—which dissipated entirely at the palace—to simply use the situation to his own advantage. This sense of obligation, of what was proper, had been a given until he suddenly realized during the conversation that the incident could provide some innocent amusement. And that was precisely its effect, aided by his painting—an evocation of the quaint, of the most humble rococo, a Venetian interior in the authentic old style. He made the point to his hostess that her own grand chambers, though they had many virtues, weren't truly this. He made the point so successfully, in fact, that she soon declared it was his clear duty to invite her to tea very soon.

She had expressed as yet—he could feel it as felt among them all—no such clear wish to go anywhere, not even to make an effort for a parish feast, or an autumn sunset, nor to descend her staircase for Titian or Gianbellini. It was constantly Densher's view that, as between himself and Kate, things were understood without saying, so that he could catch in her, as she but too freely could in him, innumerable signs of it, the whole soft breath of consciousness meeting and promoting consciousness. This view was so far justified to-night as that Milly's offer to him of her company was to his sense taken up by Kate in spite of her doing nothing to show it. It fell in so perfectly with what she had desired and foretold that she was—and this was what most struck him—sufficiently gratified and blinded by it not to know, from the false quality of his response, from his tone and his very look, which for an instant instinctively sought her own, that he had answered inevitably, almost shamelessly, in a mere time-gaining sense.

Translation

She had not yet expressed—and he could sense it among them all—any clear desire to go anywhere, not even to make the effort for a parish feast, or an autumn sunset, nor to descend her staircase for Titian or Gianbellini. Densher constantly believed that, between himself and Kate, things were understood without being spoken, such that he could perceive in her, as she could freely in him, countless signs of this understanding. It was the whole soft breath of consciousness meeting and promoting consciousness. This view was supported tonight, as Milly's offer of her company to him was, in his estimation, accepted by Kate, even though she did nothing to indicate it. It coincided so perfectly with what she had wanted and predicted that she was—and this was what struck him most—sufficiently gratified and blinded by it not to recognize, from the falseness of his response, from his tone and his very look, which for an instant instinctively sought her own, that he had answered inevitably, almost shamelessly, in a simple delaying tactic.

It gave him on the spot, her failure of perception, almost a beginning of the advantage he had been planning for—that is at least if she too were not darkly dishonest. She might, he was not unaware, have made out, from some deep part of her, the bearing, in respect to herself, of the little fact he had announced; for she was after all capable of that, capable of guessing and yet of simultaneously hiding her guess. It wound him up a turn or two further, none the less, to impute to her now a weakness of vision by which he could himself feel the stronger. Whatever apprehension of his motive in shifting his abode might have brushed her with its wings, she at all events certainly didn't guess that he was giving their friend a hollow promise.

Translation

Her lack of perception gave him an immediate advantage—or at least a starting point for the advantage he'd been planning—assuming she wasn't being deliberately deceitful. He knew she might have understood, from some hidden place within herself, the significance of his announcement. After all, she was capable of guessing and, at the same time, concealing that guess. Nonetheless, it pleased him to believe her vision was clouded, allowing him to feel more powerful. Whatever suspicion of his intentions might have momentarily crossed her mind, she certainly didn't realize he was making a false promise to their friend.

That was what she had herself imposed on him; there had been in the prospect from the first a definite particular point at which hollowness, to call it by its least compromising name, would have to begin. Therefore its hour had now charmingly sounded. Whatever in life he had recovered his old rooms for, he had not recovered them to receive Milly Theale: which made no more difference in his expression of happy readiness than if he had been—just what he was trying not to be—fully hardened and fully base. So rapid in fact was the rhythm of his inward drama that the quick vision of impossibility produced in him by his hostess's direct and unexpected appeal had the effect, slightly sinister, of positively scaring him.

Translation

That was the condition she'd set. From the start, there had been a specific moment when emptiness—to put it kindly—would inevitably take hold. Now, that moment had delightfully arrived. Whatever his reasons for reclaiming his old rooms, they weren't to accommodate Milly Theale. This made no visible impact on his cheerful demeanor, just as if he were entirely callous and morally bankrupt—precisely what he was striving not to be. The tempo of his internal conflict was so frenetic that the sudden realization of impossibility, triggered by his hostess's direct and unforeseen request, had a slightly unsettling effect, actually frightening him.

It gave him a measure of the intensity, the reality of his now mature motive. It prompted in him certainly no quarrel with these things, but it made them as vivid as if they already flushed with success. It was before the flush of success that his heart beat almost to dread. The dread was but the dread of the happiness to be compassed; only that was in itself a symptom.

Translation

It provided him with a sense of the depth, the truth of his now fully developed intention. This didn't cause him to resent these things, but it made them as vibrant as if they were already glowing with triumph. It was before the flush of success that his heart raced with something close to fear. This fear was simply the fear of the happiness he was about to achieve; but that in itself was a sign.

That a visit from Milly should, in this projection of necessities, strike him as of the last incongruity, quite as a hateful idea, and above all as spoiling, should one put it grossly, his game—the adoption of such a view might of course have an identity with one of those numerous ways of being a fool that seemed so to abound for him. It would remain none the less the way to which he should be in advance most reconciled. His mature motive, as to which he allowed himself no grain of illusion, had thus in an hour taken imaginative possession of the place: that precisely was how he saw it seated there, already unpacked and settled, for Milly's innocence, for Milly's beauty, no matter how short a time, to be housed with. There were things she would never recognise, never feel, never catch in the air; but this made no difference in the fact that her brushing against them would do nobody any good.

Translation

That a visit from Milly, given the circumstances he had created, should appear to him as the most inappropriate thing possible, a hateful idea, and, above all, as something that would ruin his plan—taking such a view might be just another way of being a fool, a condition he knew well. It would still be the view he was most ready to accept. His true motive, which he refused to romanticize, had, in a single hour, seized the place in his imagination: that was precisely how he saw it, already unpacked and settled, ready for Milly's innocence, for Milly's beauty, no matter how brief their time together, to coexist with. There were things she would never understand, never feel, never sense; but this didn't change the fact that her presence would be harmful to everyone involved.

The discrimination and the scruple were for him. So he felt all the parts of the case together, while Kate showed admirably as feeling none of them. Of course, however—when hadn't it to be his last word?—Kate was always sublime. He was being entertaining about it that evening at dinner—despite an initial impulse, which vanished at the palace, to treat the situation solely for his own benefit.

Translation

The burden of judgment and caution fell on him. He considered the whole matter, while Kate appeared to be completely unaware. Naturally—when had it ever been otherwise?—Kate was always perfect. He was amusing about it that night at dinner—after an initial urge, which he abandoned at the palace, to focus only on himself.

This sense of obligation, this expectation, he had accepted as the norm until he suddenly realized during the conversation that the incident could provide some innocent amusement. And that was precisely the effect it had, with the help of his description—a recreation of the quaint, the humble rococo, of a Venetian interior in its true, old style. He pointed out to his hostess that her own grand rooms, while they were wonderful in a thousand ways, weren't really like this; he did so with such success that she immediately declared it was his duty to invite her to tea soon. She had yet—he could feel this among them all—to express a strong desire to go anywhere, not even to attend a church gathering, or an autumn sunset, or to descend her staircase to see a Titian or a Gianbellini painting.

Translation

He had always accepted this feeling of duty, this expectation, as normal. Then, during the conversation, he suddenly realized that the incident could be a source of harmless amusement. And that was exactly the effect it had, thanks to his description. He recreated the charming, humble rococo of a Venetian interior, in its authentic, old style. He told his hostess that her own magnificent rooms, though wonderful in countless ways, weren't truly like that. He was so convincing that she immediately said it was his duty to invite her for tea soon. He could sense that she had yet to express a real desire to go anywhere, not even to a church gathering, an autumn sunset, or to go downstairs to see a Titian or a Gianbellini painting.

Densher often believed that things between himself and Kate were understood without having to be said, so he could see in her, as she could see in him, countless signs of their understanding, a shared awareness that reinforced itself. This was proven tonight when Milly offered to keep him company, which Kate, though she didn't show it, seemed to accept. It aligned so perfectly with what she had wanted and predicted that she was—and this was what struck him the most—pleased and distracted enough not to notice, from the false quality of his response, his tone, and his very look, which instinctively sought hers for a moment, that he had answered automatically, almost shamelessly, to gain time. This failure of hers to perceive gave him, almost immediately, the advantage he had been planning for—at least if she wasn't also being secretly dishonest.

Translation

Densher often felt that he and Kate needed no words, that they found in each other a thousand confirmations of their bond, a mutual recognition that fed on itself. This was confirmed tonight, when Milly offered to stay with him, an offer that Kate, though she didn't reveal it, seemed to approve. It fit so well with what she’d wanted and anticipated that she was—and this was what most surprised him—pleased and preoccupied enough not to notice that his reply had a hollow ring. He could tell, from his tone, from his very gaze, which instinctively flickered towards hers for an instant, that he’d answered mechanically, almost brazenly, simply to gain time. Her failure to perceive this gave him, almost at once, the upper hand he’d been angling for—at least, if she wasn’t also playing a secret game.

He was aware that, deep down, she might have figured out the implications of the news he had announced for her, because she was, after all, capable of guessing and also hiding her guess. Nevertheless, it gave him a small boost to now assume that she was lacking insight, which allowed him to feel stronger. Whatever suspicion of his plan to move his residence might have crossed her mind, she certainly didn't suspect that he was giving their friend a meaningless promise. That was what she herself had required of him; there had been a specific point from the beginning where the pretense, to put it mildly, would have to begin.

Translation

He knew, on some level, that she might have understood the ramifications of what he’d told her, because she was, after all, perceptive and good at keeping her cards close. Still, it made him feel a little better to think she was in the dark, and that in turn made him feel more confident. Whatever she might have suspected about his plans to change residences, she certainly didn’t suspect that he was making their friend a meaningless promise. That was exactly what she’d wanted from him; there had been a particular moment from the start when the charade, to put it politely, would have to begin.

Therefore, the moment had now arrived beautifully. Whatever purpose he had in reclaiming his old rooms, it wasn't to receive Milly Theale: which made no more difference in his expression of happy readiness than if he had been—exactly what he was trying not to be—completely callous and morally bankrupt. In fact, the rhythm of his internal drama was so rapid that the sudden realization of impossibility caused by his hostess's direct and unexpected invitation had the effect, somewhat unsettling, of actually scaring him. It gave him an understanding of the intensity, the reality of his now developed motive.

Translation

The moment had, therefore, arrived perfectly. Whatever his reason for wanting his old rooms back, it wasn't to receive Milly Theale: which didn't change his expression of happy readiness any more than if he had been—exactly what he was trying not to be—utterly cold and morally compromised. In truth, the rhythm of his inner drama was so fast that the sudden realization of impossibility, brought on by his hostess’s direct and unanticipated invitation, had the effect, a bit unnerving, of actually frightening him. It gave him an understanding of the intensity, the reality, of his now-developed motive.

It certainly didn't lead him to resent these things, but it made them as vivid as if they were already successful. It was before the appearance of success that his heart beat with near dread. The dread was just the fear of the happiness he would achieve; only that was a symptom in itself. That a visit from Milly should, given these circumstances, seem incredibly inappropriate to him, a hateful idea, and, above all, be detrimental, to his plans—adopting such a view might be one of those many ways of being a fool that seemed to plague him.

Translation

This didn't, to be sure, make him feel resentful, but it did make those things feel as real as if they were already accomplished. His heart raced with something close to dread before he'd even tasted success. The dread was simply a fear of the happiness he stood to gain; though even that was a symptom in itself. Considering the circumstances, it seemed incredibly wrong for Milly to visit, a hateful thought, and, worse still, a threat to his plans—and yet, believing that might just be one of the countless ways he seemed destined to make a fool of himself.

Nevertheless, it would be the path he would be most likely to accept beforehand. His well-formed motive, about which he had no illusions, had in an hour taken imaginative control of the place: that was how he saw it, already established there, unpacked and settled, for Milly's innocence, for Milly's beauty, no matter for how short a time, to reside with. There were things she would never recognize, never feel, never sense; but this didn't change the fact that her exposure to them wouldn't benefit anyone. The discernment and the ethical considerations were for him.

Translation

Still, this was the path he would most readily choose. His carefully constructed plan, which he fully understood, had, in a matter of an hour, seized imaginative control: he envisioned himself there already, set up, settled, ready for Milly's innocence, for Milly's beauty, however briefly, to take root. There were things she would never understand, never experience, never perceive; but this didn't change the fact that her encounter with them would serve no one. The judgment and moral considerations were his alone.

He understood all the facets of the situation together, while Kate acted as though she felt none of them. Of course, however—when hadn't it been his final word?—Kate was always superb. That came up in all connexions during the rest of these first days; came up in especial under pressure of the fact that each time our plighted pair snatched, in its passage, at the good fortune of half an hour together, they were doomed—though Densher felt it as all by his act—to spend a part of the rare occasion in wonder at their luck and in study of its queer character. This was the case after he might be supposed to have got, in a manner, used to it; it was the case after the girl—ready always, as we say, with the last word—had given him the benefit of her righting of every wrong appearance, a support familiar to him now in reference to other phases.

Translation

He took in every aspect of the situation simultaneously, while Kate behaved as though she wasn't affected by any of them. Of course, though—when had his word not been the final one?—Kate was consistently brilliant. This became apparent in every interaction during the following few days; it was especially clear given that each time the betrothed couple managed to steal a half-hour together, they were destined—though Densher felt this was entirely his doing—to spend a portion of this limited time marveling at their good fortune and contemplating its strange nature. This continued even after he should have become accustomed to it; it continued even after the girl—ever ready to have the last word—had offered him the advantage of her rectifying any misinterpretations, a support he was now familiar with in relation to other issues.

It was still the case after he possibly might, with a little imagination, as she freely insisted, have made out, by the visible working of the crisis, what idea on Mrs. Lowder's part had determined it. Such as the idea was—and that it suited Kate's own book she openly professed—he had only to see how things were turning out to feel it strikingly justified. Densher's reply to all this vividness was that of course Aunt Maud's intervention hadn't been occult, even for his vividness, from the moment she had written him, with characteristic concentration, that if he should see his way to come to Venice for a fortnight she should engage he would find it no blunder.

Translation

That was still the case even after he possibly could have discerned, with a little imagination—as she readily insisted—the idea Mrs. Lowder had, based on how the crisis visibly unfolded. The idea, whatever it was—and Kate openly admitted it served her purposes—was something he only needed to see how things were turning out to feel was remarkably justified. Densher's response to all this vividness was that Aunt Maud's intervention, even for him, hadn't been a secret, from the moment she'd written him, with her characteristic focus, that if he could see his way to spend a fortnight in Venice, she guaranteed he wouldn't regret it.

It took Aunt Maud really to do such things in such ways; just as it took him, he was ready to confess, to do such others as he must now strike them all—didn't he?—as committed to. Mrs. Lowder's admonition had been of course a direct reference to what she had said to him at Lancaster Gate before his departure the night Milly had failed them through illness; only it had at least matched that remarkable outbreak in respect to the quantity of good nature it attributed to him. The young man's discussions of his situation—which were confined to Kate; he had none with Aunt Maud herself—suffered a little, it may be divined, by the sense that he couldn't put everything off, as he privately expressed it, on other people.

Translation

It took Aunt Maud to really do such things in such ways; just as it took him, he was ready to confess, to do such others as he must now—didn't he?—strike them all as committed to. Mrs. Lowder’s admonition had been, of course, a direct reference to what she had said to him at Lancaster Gate before his departure the night Milly had failed them through illness; only it had at least matched that remarkable outbreak in respect to the quantity of good nature it attributed to him. The young man's discussions of his situation—which were confined to Kate; he had none with Aunt Maud herself—suffered a little, it may be divined, by the sense that he couldn't put everything off, as he privately expressed it, on other people.

His ears, in solitude, were apt to burn with the reflexion that Mrs. Lowder had simply tested him, seen him as he was and made out what could be done with him. She had had but to whistle for him and he had come. If she had taken for granted his good nature she was as justified as Kate declared.

Translation

Alone, he was likely to feel his ears burn with the realization that Mrs. Lowder had simply assessed him, seen him for who he was, and figured out how to use him. All she had to do was call for him, and he’d come running. If she took his good nature for granted, she was as justified as Kate claimed.

This awkwardness of his conscience, both in respect to his general plasticity, the fruit of his feeling plasticity, within limits, to be a mode of life like another—certainly better than some, and particularly in respect to such confusion as might reign about what he had really come for—this inward ache was not wholly dispelled by the style, charming as that was, of Kate's poetic versions. Even the high wonder and delight of Kate couldn't set him right with himself when there was something quite distinct from these things that kept him wrong. This issue kept coming up throughout those first few days. It arose specifically because each time the engaged couple managed to steal a half-hour together, they were fated—though Densher felt this was his fault—to spend part of the precious time marveling at their good fortune and examining its strange nature.

Translation

This discomfort of his conscience, both regarding his general malleability—the result of his capacity to adapt, within certain boundaries, as a way of life, just like any other, and arguably a better one than some—and especially concerning the confusion about his true purpose, this internal pain was not entirely relieved by Kate’s poetic, albeit charming, manner of expressing things. Even her profound amazement and joy couldn't reconcile him with himself when something separate from those things made him feel off. This issue persisted throughout those initial days. It surfaced precisely because each time the engaged couple managed to find a half-hour alone, they were destined—though Densher felt this was his fault—to use part of the precious time marveling at their good luck and dissecting its peculiar character.

This happened even after he might have been expected to get used to it. It happened after the girl—always ready with the last word—had explained everything to him, correcting any misunderstandings. He was now familiar with her explanations from other situations. And it still happened even after he could have, with a little imagination, as she readily insisted, figured out, by observing the situation, what Mrs.

Translation

This continued even when he should have grown accustomed to it. It continued even after the girl—never short on words—had explained everything to him, clearing up any confusion. He knew these explanations from other situations. And it continued even after he could have, with a little effort, as she repeatedly insisted, understood, by observing the circumstances, what Mrs.

Lowder's motives were. Whatever the motive was—and Kate openly admitted it suited her—he only needed to see how things were unfolding to feel it was clearly justified. Densher's response to all this energy was that, of course, Aunt Maud's involvement hadn't been hidden from him, not even by his own energy, since the moment she had written to him, with her typical directness, that if he could come to Venice for two weeks, she guaranteed he wouldn't regret it. It really took Aunt Maud to do things like that, just as it took him, he was ready to admit, to do the things he was now clearly committed to.

Translation

This persisted even when he should have grown used to it. It continued even after the girl—never at a loss for words—had explained everything, clarifying any confusion. He recognized these explanations from other situations. And it continued even after he could have, with a little effort, as she repeatedly insisted, understood, through observing the circumstances, what Mrs. Lowder’s motives were. Whatever the motive—and Kate readily admitted it suited her—he only needed to see how things were playing out to feel it was clearly justified. Densher's reaction to all this energy was that, of course, Aunt Maud's involvement hadn't been hidden from him, not even by his own energy, since the moment she had written to him, with her typical directness, that if he could come to Venice for two weeks, she guaranteed he wouldn't regret it. It really took Aunt Maud to do things like that, just as it took him, he was willing to admit, to do the things he was now clearly committed to.

Mrs. Lowder's instruction had, of course, been a direct reference to what she had said to him at Lancaster Gate before he left, the night Milly was unable to join them because she was sick. It at least matched that remarkable outburst in terms of the amount of generosity it attributed to him. The young man's discussions of his situation—which were only with Kate; he had none with Aunt Maud herself—were somewhat troubled, it might be guessed, by the feeling that he couldn't blame everything on other people, as he put it privately.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder’s direction, naturally, recalled what she had told him at Lancaster Gate before he left, on the night Milly couldn’t come because she was unwell. It at least equaled that astonishing outburst in the degree of generosity it assumed he possessed. The young man’s considerations of his circumstances—which were solely with Kate; he didn’t discuss them with Aunt Maud herself—were, it could be assumed, somewhat complicated by the feeling that, as he privately phrased it, he couldn’t place the blame entirely on others.

In solitude, his ears often burned with the thought that Mrs. Lowder had simply tested him, seen him for who he was, and figured out what could be done with him. She had just needed to beckon him, and he had come. If she had assumed he was agreeable, Kate said she was justified.

Translation

Alone, he often felt a burning sensation in his ears, brought on by the thought that Mrs. Lowder had only been testing him, sizing him up, and calculating how to use him. She had just needed to call him, and he had appeared. If she’d thought he was pliable, Kate said she was right.

This discomfort of his conscience, both regarding his general flexibility, the result of his feeling it was a way of life like any other—certainly better than some, and especially in regard to the confusion about what he had really come for—this inner struggle wasn't entirely resolved by Kate's charming poetic interpretations. Even Kate's intense amazement and happiness couldn't make him feel right with himself when something separate from these things kept him feeling wrong. In default of being right with himself he had meanwhile, for one thing, the interest of seeing—and quite for the first time in his life—whether, on a given occasion, that might be quite so necessary to happiness as was commonly assumed and as he had up to this moment never doubted. He was engaged distinctly in an adventure—he who had never thought himself cut out for them, and it fairly helped him that he was able at moments to say to himself that he mustn't fall below it.

Translation

This unease in his conscience, both concerning his general adaptability—a result of his believing it was a valid way to live, certainly better than some, especially regarding the confusion about his true purpose—this inner conflict wasn't entirely eased by Kate's charming, poetic explanations. Even Kate's intense amazement and happiness couldn't reconcile him when something separate from those things made him feel wrong. Since he couldn't be at peace with himself, he had, for one thing, the interest of seeing—and for the first time in his life—whether, on a specific occasion, the usual assumptions about happiness were correct. He had never questioned them up to this moment. He was engaged in an adventure—he who had never considered himself the adventurous type—and it helped that he could tell himself he mustn't fail.

At his hotel, alone, by night, or in the course of the few late strolls he was finding time to take through dusky labyrinthine alleys and empty campi, overhung with mouldering palaces, where he paused in disgust at his want of ease and where the sound of a rare footstep on the enclosed pavement was like that of a retarded dancer in a banquet-hall deserted—during these interludes he entertained cold views, even to the point, at moments, on the principle that the shortest follies are the best, of thinking of immediate departure as not only possible but as indicated. He had however only to cross again the threshold of Palazzo Leporelli to see all the elements of the business compose, as painters called it, differently. It began to strike him then that departure wouldn't curtail, but would signally coarsen his folly, and that above all, as he hadn't really "begun" anything, had only submitted, consented, but too generously indulged and condoned the beginnings of others, he had no call to treat himself with superstitious rigour. The single thing that was clear in complications was that, whatever happened, one was to behave as a gentleman—to which was added indeed the perhaps slightly less shining truth that complications might sometimes have their tedium beguiled by a study of the question of how a gentleman would behave.

Translation

Alone in his hotel at night, or during the few late walks he managed to take through dimly lit, winding alleys and deserted squares, shadowed by crumbling palaces where he paused, disgusted by his own discomfort, and where the sound of a rare footstep on the enclosed pavement echoed like a slow dancer in an abandoned banquet hall—during these quiet times, he harbored pessimistic thoughts. At times, believing that the quickest route was best, he considered immediate departure, not just a possibility, but the most sensible option.

However, once he crossed the threshold of Palazzo Leporelli, the elements of the situation rearranged themselves, as painters would say. It then occurred to him that leaving wouldn't lessen his foolishness, but would actually make it worse. He hadn't truly "begun" anything; he had merely submitted, agreed, indulged too freely, and excused the beginnings of others. Therefore, he had no reason to treat himself with such harshness.

The only thing clear in this confusing situation was that, regardless of the outcome, he was to behave as a gentleman. To this was added the perhaps less inspiring truth that the tedium of complications could sometimes be relieved by considering how a gentleman would act.

This question, I hasten to add, was not in the last resort Densher's greatest worry. Three women were looking to him at once, and, though such a predicament could never be, from the point of view of facility, quite the ideal, it yet had, thank goodness, its immediate workable law. The law was not to be a brute—in return for amiabilities. He hadn't come all the way out from England to be a brute.

Translation

This question, I should add quickly, wasn't Densher's biggest concern in the end. Three women were looking to him simultaneously, and while such a predicament could hardly be considered ideal from a practical perspective, it fortunately had its own basic, functional rule. The rule was to not be a cad—in exchange for kindness. He hadn't traveled all the way from England to be a cad.

He hadn't thought of what it might give him to have a fortnight, however handicapped, with Kate in Venice, to be a brute. He hadn't treated Mrs. Lowder as if in responding to her suggestion he had understood her—he hadn't done that either to be a brute. And what he had prepared least of all for such an anti-climax was the prompt and inevitable, the achieved surrender—as a gentleman, oh that indubitably!—to the unexpected impression made by poor pale exquisite Milly as the mistress of a grand old palace and the dispenser of an hospitality more irresistible, thanks to all the conditions, than any ever known to him.

Translation

He hadn't considered what he might gain from having two weeks, however constrained, with Kate in Venice, just to be cruel. He hadn't treated Mrs. Lowder as if he understood her in agreeing to her suggestion—he hadn't done that to be cruel, either. And what he'd prepared for least of all, as a kind of letdown, was the immediate, unavoidable, the realized surrender—as a gentleman, oh, undoubtedly!—to the unforeseen impression made by poor, pale, exquisite Milly, as the mistress of a grand old palace and the bestower of a hospitality more irresistible, because of all the circumstances, than any he'd ever experienced.

Because he wasn't at peace with himself, he was, for one thing, interested in seeing—for the first time in his life—whether being right with himself was as crucial to happiness as everyone assumed, and as he had always believed until now. He was clearly involved in an adventure—he who never thought of himself as someone who had adventures, and it helped him to tell himself he couldn't fail. At his hotel, alone at night, or during the few late walks he took through dark, winding alleys and empty squares, overshadowed by decaying palaces, where he paused, disgusted by his lack of ease and where the sound of a rare footstep on the enclosed pavement was like a slow dancer in a deserted ballroom—during these pauses, he considered things coldly, even to the point of thinking, sometimes, that the quickest way to end a foolish situation was the best, and that leaving immediately was not only possible but the right thing to do. However, as soon as he crossed the threshold of Palazzo Leporelli, all the elements of the situation changed, as artists would say.

Translation

Because he wasn't at peace with himself, he was, for one thing, interested in seeing—for the first time in his life—whether inner peace was as crucial to happiness as everyone assumed, and as he had always believed until now. He was clearly involved in an adventure—he who never thought of himself as someone who had adventures, and it helped him to tell himself he couldn't fail. At his hotel, alone at night, or during the few late walks he took through dark, winding alleys and empty squares, overshadowed by decaying palaces, where he paused, disgusted by his lack of ease and where the sound of a rare footstep on the enclosed pavement was like a slow dancer in a deserted ballroom—during these pauses, he considered things coldly, even to the point of thinking, sometimes, that the quickest way to end a foolish situation was the best, and that leaving immediately was not only possible but the right thing to do. However, as soon as he crossed the threshold of Palazzo Leporelli, all the elements of the situation changed, as artists would say.

It then occurred to him that leaving wouldn't lessen his foolishness, but would actually make it worse, and that, above all, since he hadn't really "started" anything, but had only yielded and agreed, had been too generous in accepting and forgiving the starts of others, he had no reason to be too strict with himself. The only clear thing in this complicated situation was that, whatever happened, he had to behave like a gentleman—which led to the, perhaps, less impressive truth that complications could sometimes be made less boring by considering how a gentleman would behave. I must add that this question wasn't Densher's biggest worry. Three women were looking to him, and, although such a situation could never be ideal, it did, thankfully, have an immediately workable rule.

Translation

He realized that leaving wouldn't alleviate his folly, but would only compound it. More importantly, he hadn't truly "begun" anything. He'd merely conceded and assented, having been overly magnanimous in embracing and overlooking the initiatives of others. Therefore, he had no justification for being overly critical of himself. The sole certainty in this convoluted scenario was that, regardless of the outcome, he was obligated to conduct himself as a gentleman. This, perhaps, less profound observation, hinted that complexities could occasionally be rendered less tedious by considering how a gentleman would act. It should be noted that this concern didn't occupy the forefront of Densher's mind. Three women were observing him, and while the circumstances were hardly ideal, they did, thankfully, present a readily applicable guideline.

The rule was not to be a jerk—in return for kindness. He hadn't come all the way from England to be a jerk. He hadn't thought about what it might give him to have two weeks, however difficult, with Kate in Venice, to be a jerk. He hadn't treated Mrs.

Translation

The directive was to reciprocate kindness. He hadn't crossed the ocean from England to act poorly. He hadn't considered the potential benefits of two weeks, however challenging, with Kate in Venice, to be a jerk. He hadn't treated Mrs.

Lowder as if he understood her suggestion—he hadn't done that either to be a jerk. And what he least expected, as the anti-climax, was the prompt, inevitable, surrender—as a gentleman, yes, definitely!—to the unexpected impression made by the frail, elegant Milly as the mistress of a grand, old palace and the host of an irresistible hospitality, thanks to all the circumstances, greater than any he had ever known. This spectacle had for him an eloquence, an authority, a felicity—he scarce knew by what strange name to call it—for which he said to himself that he had not consciously bargained. Her welcome, her frankness, sweetness, sadness, brightness, her disconcerting poetry, as he made shift at moments to call it, helped as it was by the beauty of her whole setting and by the perception at the same time, on the observer's part, that this element gained from her, in a manner, for effect and harmony, as much as it gave—her whole attitude had, to his imagination, meanings that hung about it, waiting upon her, hovering, dropping and quavering forth again, like vague faint snatches, mere ghosts of sound, of old-fashioned melancholy music.

Translation

Lowder as if he understood her suggestion—he hadn't done that either to be a jerk. And what he least expected, as the anti-climax, was the prompt, inevitable surrender—as a gentleman, yes, definitely!—to the unexpected impression made by the frail, elegant Milly as the mistress of a grand, old palace and the host of an irresistible hospitality, thanks to all the circumstances, greater than any he had ever known. This display had for him an eloquence, an authority, a joy—he hardly knew what to call it—that he told himself he hadn't bargained for. Her welcome, her openness, sweetness, sadness, radiance, her unsettling poetry, as he sometimes termed it, enhanced as it was by the beauty of her surroundings and by the simultaneous understanding on the part of the observer that the setting gained from her, in a way, as much as she gained from it—her entire demeanor had, to his imagination, implications that clung to her, waited on her, hovered, dropped and quavered forth again, like vague, faint snatches, mere echoes of sound, of old-fashioned melancholy music.

It was positively well for him, he had his times of reflecting, that he couldn't put it off on Kate and Mrs. Lowder, as a gentleman so conspicuously wouldn't, that—well, that he had been rather taken in by not having known in advance! There had been now five days of it all without his risking even to Kate alone any hint of what he ought to have known and of what in particular therefore had taken him in. The truth was doubtless that really, when it came to any free handling and naming of things, they were living together, the five of them, in an air in which an ugly effect of "blurting out" might easily be produced.

Translation

It was fortunate for him, he thought at times, that he couldn't simply disclose it to Kate and Mrs. Lowder, as a gentleman, of course, wouldn't do—that he'd been rather captivated by not knowing in advance! It had been going on for five days now, and he hadn't even dared to give Kate any hint of what he should have understood, and therefore, what had particularly charmed him. The reality was that, when it came to speaking freely and naming things, the five of them were living in an atmosphere where an awkward effect of "blurting out" might easily occur.

He came back with his friend on each occasion to the blest miracle of renewed propinquity, which had a double virtue in that favouring air. He breathed on it as if he could scarcely believe it, yet the time had passed, in spite of this privilege, without his quite committing himself, for her ear, to any such comment on Milly's high style and state as would have corresponded with the amount of recognition it had produced in him. Behind everything for him was his renewed remembrance, which had fairly become a habit, that he had been the first to know her. This was what they had all insisted on, in her absence, that day at Mrs.

Translation

He returned with his friend each time to the blessed miracle of renewed closeness, which had a double benefit in that welcoming atmosphere. He breathed it in as if he could scarcely believe it, yet time had passed, despite this privilege, without his quite committing himself, for her ear, to any comment on Milly's high style and status that would have matched the amount of recognition it had brought him.
