Behind everything for him was his renewed memory, which had truly become a habit, that he had been the first to know her. This was what they had all insisted on, in her absence, that day at Mrs.

Lowder's; and this was in especial what had made him feel its influence on his immediately paying her a second visit. Its influence had been all there, been in the high-hung, rumbling carriage with them, from the moment she took him to drive, covering them in together as if it had been a rug of softest silk. It had worked as a clear connexion with something lodged in the past, something already their own. He had more than once recalled how he had said to himself even at that moment, at some point in the drive, that he was not there, not just as he was in so doing it, through Kate and Kate's idea, but through Milly and Milly's own, and through himself and his own, unmistakeably—as well as through the little facts, whatever they had amounted to, of his time in New York.

Translation

Lowder's; and this was especially what made him feel its influence, causing him to immediately pay her a second visit. Its influence had been there the whole time, in the high-riding, rumbling carriage with them, from the moment she took him for a drive, enveloping them as if it were a rug of the softest silk. It had served as a clear connection to something in the past, something they already shared. He had, more than once, recalled how he had told himself, even at that moment, at some point during the drive, that he wasn’t there just as he was, in the act of being there, through Kate and Kate’s idea, but through Milly and Milly’s own, and through himself and his own, unmistakably—as well as through the little facts, whatever they amounted to, of his time in New York.

This spectacle had a power and beauty to it—he struggled to find the right words—that he hadn't deliberately sought. Her welcome, her openness, sweetness, sadness, and radiance, her unsettling poetry, as he sometimes called it, along with the beauty of her surroundings and the sense that she enhanced her environment as much as it enhanced her—her entire demeanor held meanings for him, waiting for her, lingering, occasionally expressing themselves like fragments of old, melancholy music. He realized it was fortunate that he couldn't simply share this with Kate and Mrs. Lowder, as a gentleman wouldn't—that he had been somewhat misled by his lack of prior knowledge!

Translation

This display possessed a power and beauty that he found difficult to articulate, qualities he hadn't actively pursued. Her graciousness, her frankness, her gentleness, her sorrow, and her vibrancy, her disquieting lyricism, as he sometimes termed it, combined with the loveliness of her home and the impression that she elevated her surroundings as much as they elevated her—her entire presentation conveyed meanings to him, anticipating her, remaining present, sometimes emerging like strains of an old, mournful melody. He understood it was just as well he couldn't simply disclose this to Kate and Mrs. Lowder, as a gentleman wouldn't—that his ignorance had somewhat misled him!

Five days had passed without him even hinting to Kate about what he should have known and what, therefore, had deceived him. The truth was that when it came to speaking openly, the five of them existed in an atmosphere where an awkward "blurting out" might easily occur. He returned with his friend each time to the wonderful miracle of their renewed closeness, which thrived in that favorable atmosphere. He found it hard to believe, yet despite this advantage, he hadn't dared to share with her any observations about Milly's elevated manner that would accurately reflect how much he had noticed it.

Translation

Five days went by, and he hadn't even given Kate a clue about the things he should have known, and therefore, had been fooled by. The truth was, when it came to speaking freely, the five of them existed in an environment where a clumsy, unguarded statement could easily happen. He went back with his friend each time to the astonishing miracle of their revived intimacy, which flourished in that positive setting. It was difficult for him to believe, but even with that advantage, he hadn't dared to share with her any of his insights about Milly's refined demeanor that would truly convey how much he'd taken notice of it.

He kept remembering, almost compulsively, that he had been the first to know her. This was what everyone had emphasized in her absence that day at Mrs. Lowder's. This, specifically, had made him feel compelled to visit her again immediately.

Translation

He couldn't stop remembering, almost against his will, that he'd been the first to know her. Everyone had made that clear in her absence at Mrs. Lowder's that day. That fact, specifically, had driven him to go see her again right away.

That influence was present the whole time, in the grand, rumbling carriage, covering them together as though it were the softest silk. It created a clear link to something in the past, something they already shared. He recalled how he'd told himself during that drive that he wasn't there only through Kate and her ideas, but through Milly and Milly's own, and through himself and his own, undoubtedly—as well as through the insignificant details of his time in New York.

Translation

The influence was with them constantly, within the large, rumbling carriage, enveloping them as if it were the softest silk. It established a distinct connection to something in their past, something they already had in common. He remembered how he had told himself during the carriage ride that he wasn't there only because of Kate and her beliefs, but because of Milly and Milly's own, and because of himself and his own, without question—as well as because of the small details of his time in New York.

Chapter 12

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A man, Densher, arrives at a palace at the end of the day. He learns from Mrs. Stringham that Milly will miss dinner but will join them later for a party. He and Mrs. Stringham talk alone for five minutes before Kate and Mrs. Lowder appear. He asks about Milly's health, and Mrs. Stringham tells him Milly is better and is saving her strength for the party, where a doctor, Sir Luke Strett, will be a guest. She encourages Densher to speak with Sir Luke. After dinner, Milly comes down to the party, which is attended by several other guests. She is wearing a white dress and a long pearl necklace. As the party continues with music, Kate approaches Densher. He tells her that Mrs. Stringham said Milly is better. Kate contradicts him, stating that Milly is actually worse. She explains their plan is to make Milly want to live. Densher questions how the plan can work if Milly is dying. Kate tells him he must propose marriage to Milly. He asks if the purpose is for him to inherit her money upon her death, and Kate confirms it, saying they will then be free. She then informs him that she and her aunt, Mrs. Lowder, are leaving for London in three days, and that he is to stay behind with Milly. As they speak, Milly notices them from across the room and smiles. Densher tells Kate he will only stay if she agrees to come to him first. When she hesitates, he threatens to leave the next day. Seeing he is serious, Kate agrees to his condition.

There was at last, with everything that made for it, an occasion when he got from Kate, on what she now spoke of as his eternal refrain, an answer of which he was to measure afterwards the precipitating effect. His eternal refrain was the way he came back to the riddle of Mrs. Lowder's view of her profit—a view so hard to reconcile with the chances she gave them to meet. Impatiently, at this, the girl denied the chances, wanting to know from him, with a fine irony that smote him rather straight, whether he felt their opportunities as anything so grand.

Translation

Finally, there came a time, everything considered, when he received from Kate, concerning what she now called his eternal refrain, a response whose decisive impact he would later assess. His eternal refrain was his repeated question regarding Mrs. Lowder's financial perspective—a view so difficult to understand given the opportunities she provided for them to be together. Kate, in response, dismissed these opportunities impatiently, wanting to know from him, with an irony that struck him directly, if he considered their chances as being all that significant.

He looked at her deep in the eyes when she had sounded this note; it was the least he could let her off with for having made him visibly flush. For some reason then, with it, the sharpness dropped out of her tone, which became sweet and sincere. "'Meet,' my dear man," she expressively echoed; "does it strike you that we get, after all, so very much out of our meetings?" II

Translation

He looked into her eyes when she said that; it was the least he could do, considering she’d made him visibly blush. For some reason, her sharpness faded then, and her tone became sweet and sincere. “Meet, my dear man,” she echoed expressively. “Does it strike you that we get, after all, so very much out of our meetings?”

Finally, there was an instance, along with everything that contributed to it, when he received a response from Kate regarding what she now referred to as his constant questioning. He would later realize the profound impact of this answer. His constant questioning concerned Mrs. Lowder's perspective on their situation—a perspective that was difficult to understand considering the opportunities she provided for them to spend time together.

Translation

At long last, a moment arrived, compounded by other factors, when he received a reply from Kate about his incessant inquiries. He would come to understand the significance of the answer. His constant questions focused on Mrs. Lowder’s view of their circumstances—a view that seemed perplexing, given the opportunities she offered them to spend time together.

Kate, growing impatient with this, dismissed these opportunities. With a subtle irony that stung him directly, she wanted to know if he truly considered their meetings to be such significant events. He looked deeply into her eyes after she made this statement; it was the least he could do since she had caused him to visibly blush. For some reason, the sharpness in her voice then softened, becoming sweet and genuine.

Translation

Kate, losing patience, dispensed with these opportunities. With a delicate irony that cut him to the quick, she asked if he really thought their encounters were that important. He stared into her eyes after she said this, the least he could do since she’d made him visibly blush. For some reason, the sharpness of her voice then softened, becoming sweet and sincere.

"'Meetings,' my dear man," she repeated, emphasizing the word. "Do you truly feel that we gain so much from our time together?" "On the contrary—they're starvation diet. All I mean is—and it's all I've meant from the day I came—that we at least get more than Aunt Maud."

Translation

“‘Meetings,’ my dear man,” she repeated, stressing the word. “Do you honestly think we benefit so much from seeing each other?”

“On the contrary—they’re a starvation diet. All I mean—and it’s all I’ve meant from the moment I arrived—is that we get more than Aunt Maud, at least.”

"Ah but you see," Kate replied, "you don't understand what Aunt Maud gets." "Exactly so—and it's what I don't understand that keeps me so fascinated with the question. She gives me no light; she's prodigious. She takes everything as of a natural—!"

Translation

"You don't understand, though," Kate replied, "what Aunt Maud gets." "Precisely—and what I don't understand is what fascinates me about it. She offers no illumination; she's a marvel. She accepts everything as natural—!"

"She takes it as 'of a natural' that at this rate I shall be making my reflexions about you. There's every appearance for her," Kate went on, "that what she had made her mind up to as possible is possible; that what she had thought more likely than not to happen is happening. The very essence of her, as you surely by this time have made out for yourself, is that when she adopts a view she—well, to her own sense, really brings the thing about, fairly terrorizes with her view any other, any opposite view, and those, not less, who represent that. I've often thought success comes to her"—Kate continued to study the phenomenon—"by the spirit in her that dares and defies her idea not to prove the right one.

Translation

"She simply assumes, as a matter of course, that at this rate I'll be forming my opinions of you. Everything suggests to her," Kate continued, "that what she's decided is possible, is, in fact, possible; that what she considered probable is actually happening. The very core of her being, as you've surely realized by now, is that when she adopts a perspective, she—well, in her own mind, she essentially brings the thing about, she intimidates with her perspective any other, any opposing view, and the people who represent that view. I've often thought her success comes,"—Kate continued to observe the phenomenon—"from the force within her that dares and defies her own idea not to be proven correct."

One has seen it so again and again, in the face of everything, become the right one." "On the contrary, they're starving. All I'm saying—and I've been saying it since I arrived—is that we get more than Aunt Maud, at least." "Oh, but you see," Kate replied, "you don't understand what Aunt Maud gets."

Translation

It's been observed, time and again, that against all odds, her way prevails. "On the contrary, they're suffering. All I'm saying—and I've said it since I arrived—is that we get more than Aunt Maud, at the very least." "Oh, but you see," Kate responded, "you don't grasp what Aunt Maud receives."

"Precisely—and what I don't understand is what keeps me so interested. She gives me no clarity; she's extraordinary. She treats everything as normal—!" "She treats it as normal that, at this rate, I'll be forming my opinions about you.

Translation

"Exactly—and what I can't figure out is why I'm still so fascinated. She doesn't explain anything; she's remarkable. She acts like it's normal—!" "She acts like it's normal that, at this pace, I'll be developing my opinions about you."

Everything suggests to her," Kate continued, "that what she decided was possible is, in fact, possible; that what she thought likely to happen is happening. The very core of who she is, as you must have realized by now, is that when she forms an opinion, she—well, in her own mind, actually causes the thing to happen. She completely overwhelms any other view, any opposing viewpoint, and those who support that view. I've often thought that her success comes"—Kate continued to observe the phenomenon—"from her spirit, which dares to challenge her idea not to be proven correct.

Translation

Everything indicates to her," Kate continued, "that what she deemed achievable is, in fact, achievable; that what she anticipated would happen is happening. The very essence of her being, as you must have understood by now, is that when she forms a belief, she—well, in her own mind, essentially makes the thing happen. She completely dominates any other perspective, any opposing argument, and those who hold that argument. I've often thought that her success comes"—Kate continued to observe the phenomenon—"from her spirit, which dares to challenge the idea that she won't be proven right.

One has repeatedly witnessed it, against all odds, becoming the correct one." Densher had for this, as he listened, a smile of the largest response. "Ah my dear child, if you can explain I of course needn't not 'understand.' I'm condemned to that," he on his side presently explained, "only when understanding fails." He took a moment; then he pursued: "Does she think she terrorises us?" To which he added while, without immediate speech, Kate but looked over the place: "Does she believe anything so stiff as that you've really changed about me?" He knew now that he was probing the girl deep—something told him so; but that was a reason the more. "Has she got it into her head that you dislike me?"

Translation

"One has repeatedly witnessed it, against all odds, becoming the correct one." Densher responded with a broad smile as he listened. "Ah, my dear, if you can explain, I of course needn't 'understand.' I'm condemned to that," he explained in turn, "only when understanding fails." He paused, and then continued, "Does she think she terrorizes us?" To this, he added as Kate glanced around without immediately speaking, "Does she believe anything so rigid as that you've really changed about me?" He knew then that he was probing the girl deeply—something told him so; but that was all the more reason to do it. "Has she gotten it into her head that you dislike me?"

To this, of a sudden, Kate's answer was strong. "You could yourself easily put it there!" Densher responded with a broad smile. "My dear, if you can explain, I certainly don't need to understand.

Translation

Kate's answer was suddenly emphatic. "You could easily be the one to plant that idea!" Densher responded with a broad smile. "My dear, if you can explain it to me, then I certainly don't need to understand."

I'm stuck with that," he clarified, "only when understanding doesn't work." He paused, then continued, "Does she think she's intimidating us?" He added, while Kate simply surveyed the room without speaking immediately, "Does she believe something so ridiculous, that you've truly changed your feelings about me?" He felt he was digging deep into Kate—something told him so, and that was all the more reason to continue. "Has she convinced herself that you dislike me?" Kate answered with sudden, forceful conviction. "You could easily be the one to plant that idea!"

Translation

"I'm stuck with that," he clarified, "only when understanding fails." He paused, then continued, "Does she think she's trying to scare us?" He added, while Kate simply surveyed the room without immediately speaking, "Does she believe something so ridiculous, that you've truly stopped caring about me?" He felt he was getting to Kate—something told him so, and that was all the more reason to continue. "Has she convinced herself that you hate me?" Kate answered with sudden, forceful conviction. "You could easily be the one to plant that idea!"

He wondered. "By telling her so?" "No," said Kate as with amusement at his simplicity; "I don't ask that of you." "Oh my dear," Densher laughed, "when you ask, you know, so little—!"

Translation

He was curious. "By saying that to her?" "No," Kate replied, a hint of amusement in her voice, as if his question was naive. "I wouldn't ask you to do that." "Oh, my dear," Densher chuckled, "when you ask, you know, so little—!"

There was a full irony in this, on his own part, that he saw her resist the impulse to take up. "I'm perfectly justified in what I've asked," she quietly returned. "It's doing beautifully for you." Their eyes again intimately met, and the effect was to make her proceed. "You're not a bit unhappy."

Translation

He found the whole situation ironic, given his own part in it. He saw her fight the urge to challenge him. "I'm completely justified in what I've asked," she replied softly. "It's working out beautifully for you." Their eyes met again, in an intimate way, and it spurred her to continue. "You're not at all unhappy."

"Oh ain't I?" he brought out very roundly. "It doesn't practically show—which is enough for Aunt Maud. You're wonderful, you're beautiful," Kate said; "and if you really want to know whether I believe you're doing it you may take from me perfectly that I see it coming." With which, by a quick transition, as if she had settled the case, she asked him the hour. He was curious.

Translation

"Oh, am I not?" he stated, emphasizing each word. "It's not exactly obvious—which is good enough for Aunt Maud. You're wonderful, you're beautiful," Kate said. "And if you really want to know whether I think you're going along with it, I can tell you plainly that I see it coming." With that, abruptly changing the subject, as if she'd resolved the issue, she asked him the time. He was intrigued.

"By telling her?" "No," Kate replied, amused by his naiveté. "I'm not asking you to do that." "Oh, darling," Densher laughed, "you're always so undemanding!"

Translation

"By telling her?"

"No," Kate replied, amused by his naiveté. "I'm not asking you to do that."

"Oh, darling," Densher laughed, "you're always so undemanding!"

He was fully aware of the irony in that statement, and he noticed she almost reacted to it. "I'm entirely justified in what I've asked," she calmly responded. "It's working out wonderfully for you." Their eyes met in a familiar way, and she continued. "You're not unhappy at all."

Translation

Densher was well aware of the irony in what he'd said, and he saw that she nearly responded to it. "I'm completely justified in what I've asked," she said calmly. "It's working out perfectly for you." Their eyes met in a way they both knew, and she went on. "You're not unhappy in the least."

"Oh, really?" he countered bluntly. "It doesn't show, which is all that matters to Aunt Maud. You're amazing, you're charming," Kate said. "And if you truly want to know if I believe you're faking it, I can tell you that I see it completely." Then, in a quick change of subject, as if the matter was settled, she asked him the time.

Translation

"Oh, really?" he countered bluntly. "It doesn't show, which is all that matters to Aunt Maud. You're amazing, you're charming," Kate said. "And if you truly want to know if I believe you're faking it, I can tell you that I see it completely." Then, in a quick change of subject, as if the matter was settled, she asked him the time.

"Oh only twelve-ten"—he had looked at his watch. "We've taken but thirteen minutes; we've time yet." "Then we must walk. We must go toward them."

Translation

"Oh, it's only twelve-ten," he said, glancing at his watch. "We've only been at it for thirteen minutes; we have time." "Then we have to walk. We have to go toward them."

Densher, from where they had been standing, measured the long reach of the Square. "They're still in their shop. They're safe for half an hour." "That shows then, that shows!" said Kate.

Translation

Densher, from where they had been standing, gauged the long expanse of the Square. "They're still in their shop. They're safe for half an hour." "That shows then, that shows!" said Kate.

This colloquy had taken place in the middle of Piazza San Marco, always, as a great social saloon, a smooth-floored, blue-roofed chamber of amenity, favourable to talk; or rather, to be exact, not in the middle, but at the point where our pair had paused by a common impulse after leaving the great mosque-like church. It rose now, domed and pinnacled, but a little way behind them, and they had in front the vast empty space, enclosed by its arcades, to which at that hour movement and traffic were mostly confined. Venice was at breakfast, the Venice of the visitor and the possible acquaintance, and, except for the parties of importunate pigeons picking up the crumbs of perpetual feasts, their prospect was clear and they could see their companions hadn't yet been, and weren't for a while longer likely to be, disgorged by the lace-shop, in one of the loggie, where, shortly before, they had left them for a look-in—the expression was artfully Densher's—at Saint Mark's. Their morning had happened to take such a turn as brought this chance to the surface; yet his allusion, just made to Kate, hadn't been an overstatement of their general opportunity.

Translation

This exchange had occurred in the heart of Piazza San Marco, a vast public gathering space, a smooth-paved, sky-domed chamber of pleasantries, conducive to conversation. Or rather, to be precise, not in the center, but at the spot where our two figures had stopped, drawn there by a shared instinct after exiting the grand, mosque-like church. It loomed now, crowned with domes and spires, though set a little distance behind them, and they had before them the expansive, empty space, bordered by its arcades, where, at that hour, activity and movement were mostly concentrated. Venice was at breakfast, the Venice of the tourist and the potential acquaintance, and, save for the flocks of persistent pigeons pecking at the remains of constant meals, their view was unobstructed and they could see their companions hadn't yet emerged, and wouldn't for some time be likely to emerge, from the lace shop in one of the loggias, where, moments before, they'd left them for a peek—the phrase was Densher's crafty way of putting it—at Saint Mark's. Their morning had unfolded in such a way as to bring this opportunity to the fore; still, his reference, just made to Kate, hadn't been an exaggeration of their overall situation.

The worst that could be said of their general opportunity was that it was essentially in presence—in presence of every one; every one consisting at this juncture, in a peopled world, of Susan Shepherd, Aunt Maud and Milly. But the proof how, even in presence, the opportunity could become special was furnished precisely by this view of the compatibility of their comfort with a certain amount of lingering. The others had assented to their not waiting in the shop; it was of course the least the others could do. What had really helped them this morning was the fact that, on his turning up, as he always called it, at the palace, Milly had not, as before, been able to present herself.

Translation

The worst criticism of their situation was that it was, at its heart, a public affair—a public affair involving Susan Shepherd, Aunt Maud, and Milly, who, at that moment, constituted the whole world, insofar as it concerned them. But the evidence of how, even in plain sight, the situation could become unique was provided by the way their comfort meshed with a certain amount of delay. The others had agreed they wouldn't wait in the shop; it was, of course, the least they could have done. What had genuinely benefited them that morning was that, when he’d shown up, as he always phrased it, at the palace, Milly hadn’t been able to make an appearance, as she had done before.

Custom and use had hitherto seemed fairly established; on his coming round, day after day—eight days had been now so conveniently marked—their friends, Milly's and his, conveniently dispersed and left him to sit with her till luncheon. Such was the perfect operation of the scheme on which he had been, as he phrased it to himself, had out; so that certainly there was that amount of justification for Kate's vision of success. He had, for Mrs. Lowder—he couldn't help it while sitting there—the air, which was the thing to be desired, of no absorption in Kate sufficiently deep to be alarming.

Translation

Habit and precedent had seemed fairly settled up to this point. He visited them daily—eight days had now passed in this convenient way—and their friends, Milly's and his, would conveniently leave, allowing him to sit with her until lunch. This was the flawless execution of the plan he had, as he put it to himself, brought about. It provided justification for Kate's vision of success. He projected, to Mrs. Lowder—he couldn't help it while sitting there—the desirable impression of not being overly absorbed in Kate, and therefore, not being alarming.

He had failed their young hostess each morning as little as she had failed him; it was only to-day that she hadn't been well enough to see him. "Oh, it's only twelve-ten," he said, glancing at his watch. "We've only been talking for thirteen minutes; we still have time." "Then we must walk.

Translation

He had disappointed their young hostess each morning to the same extent she had disappointed him. It was only today that she had been too unwell to see him. "Oh, it's only twelve-ten," he said, glancing at his watch. "We've only been talking for thirteen minutes; we still have time." "Then we must walk."

We have to go towards them." Densher looked across the expanse of the Square from where they were standing. "They're still in the shop. They're safe for another half hour."

Translation

"We have to go over there." Densher looked across the Square from where they stood. "They're still in the shop. They'll be fine for another thirty minutes."

"That proves it, doesn't it?" Kate said. This exchange had taken place in the middle of Saint Mark's Square, which always felt like a grand social gathering place, a smooth, open space under the sky, conducive to conversation. Or rather, to be precise, not in the middle, but at the spot where they had stopped together after leaving the large church. The church now rose behind them, with its domes and spires, and they faced the vast, empty square enclosed by its arcades, where movement and activity were minimal at that hour.

Translation

"That settles it, doesn't it?" Kate said. The discussion had happened in Saint Mark's Square, which always felt like a grand party, a flat, open area under the sky, perfect for talking. Or rather, to be exact, not in the middle of the square, but where they'd paused after leaving the big church. The church now loomed behind them, its domes and spires reaching up, and they faced the huge, empty square ringed by arcades, where there wasn't much going on at that time of day.

Venice was at breakfast, the Venice of tourists and potential acquaintances, and apart from the persistent pigeons scavenging for scraps, their view was clear, and they could see that their companions hadn't yet emerged from the lace shop, in one of the covered walkways, where they had left them earlier to take a quick look inside Saint Mark's—a phrase Densher had carefully chosen. Their morning had taken a turn that brought this opportunity to the surface; yet his remark to Kate hadn't exaggerated their general situation. The worst thing about their opportunity was that it existed in the presence of others—specifically, Susan Shepherd, Aunt Maud, and Milly. But the proof of how, even in their presence, the opportunity could be made special was provided by their ability to relax and linger.

Translation

Venice was eating breakfast, the Venice of tourists and people who might become friends. Their view was unobstructed, save for the ever-present pigeons hunting for leftovers. They could see that their friends hadn't yet come out of the lace shop, one of the stores in the covered walkways where they'd left them earlier to quickly look inside Saint Mark's—a phrase Densher had chosen carefully. Their morning had taken a turn that presented this opening; still, his comment to Kate hadn't overstated their general circumstances. The most troubling part of their opportunity was that it existed while others were present—specifically, Susan Shepherd, Aunt Maud, and Milly. But the fact that they could unwind and take their time proved how, even with others around, the opportunity could be made something special.

The others had agreed they wouldn't wait in the shop; it was the least they could have done. What had truly helped them this morning was that Milly hadn't been able to join him when he arrived at the palace, as he always called it. Previously, this had been their routine: he would visit, day after day—eight days had now passed in this way—and their friends, Milly's and his, would conveniently leave him alone with her until lunchtime. This was the perfect operation of the plan he had been working on.

Translation

The others had decided not to linger in the shop; it was the least they could have done. What had really made this morning easier was that Milly hadn't been able to be with him when he arrived at the palazzo, as he always called it. Before, this had been their pattern: he would visit, day after day—eight days now, in fact—and their friends, hers and his, would conveniently leave him alone with her until lunchtime. This was the perfect execution of the plan he'd been working on.

There was certainly some basis for Kate's hope of success. For Mrs. Lowder, while he was sitting there, he had to give the impression of not being overly focused on Kate, which was what she wanted. He hadn't let their young hostess down each morning, and she hadn't let him down either; it was just today that she hadn't been well enough to see him.

Translation

Kate's hope for success wasn't entirely unfounded. While he was there with Mrs. Lowder, he needed to appear as though Kate wasn't his primary concern, which was what Mrs. Lowder expected. He hadn't disappointed their young hostess each morning, and she hadn't disappointed him, either; it was only today that she was too unwell to receive him.

That had made a mark, all round; the mark was in the way in which, gathered in the room of state, with the place, from the right time, all bright and cool and beflowered, as always, to receive her descent, they—the rest of them—simply looked at each other. It was lurid—lurid, in all probability, for each of them privately—that they had uttered no common regrets. It was strange for our young man above all that, if the poor girl was indisposed to that degree, the hush of gravity, of apprehension, of significance of some sort, should be the most the case—that of the guests—could permit itself. The hush, for that matter, continued after the party of four had gone down to the gondola and taken their places in it.

Translation

That had made an impression, all around; the impression was evident in the way that, assembled in the formal room, the space, at the proper time, all bright and cool and decorated with flowers, as always, to welcome her arrival, they—the others—simply looked at each other. It was unsettling—unsettling, most likely, for each of them privately—that they had expressed no shared sadness. It was strange, above all, for our young man, that if the poor girl was so unwell, the silence of seriousness, of worry, of significance of some kind, should be the most that those present—the guests—could allow themselves. The silence, for that matter, persisted even after the party of four had gone down to the gondola and taken their seats.

Milly had sent them word that she hoped they would go out and enjoy themselves, and this indeed had produced a second remarkable look, a look as of their knowing, one quite as well as the other, what such a message meant as provision for the alternative beguilement of Densher. She wished not to have spoiled his morning, and he had therefore, in civility, to take it as pleasantly patched up. Mrs. Stringham had helped the affair out, Mrs.

Translation

Milly had sent them word that she hoped they would go out and enjoy themselves, and this had, in fact, produced a second remarkable look. It was a look of shared understanding, as if each of them knew the meaning of such a message, which was a way of making space for Densher’s alternative amusement. She hadn’t wanted to ruin his morning, and so, out of courtesy, he had to accept it as a pleasant solution. Mrs. Stringham had facilitated the whole affair, Mrs.

Stringham who, when it came to that, knew their friend better than any of them. She knew her so well that she knew herself as acting in exquisite compliance with conditions comparatively obscure, approximately awful to them, by not thinking it necessary to stay at home. She had corrected that element of the perfunctory which was the slight fault, for all of them, of the occasion; she had invented a preference for Mrs. Lowder and herself; she had remembered the fond dreams of the visitation of lace that had hitherto always been brushed away by accidents, and it had come up as well for her that Kate had, the day before, spoken of the part played by fatality in her own failure of real acquaintance with the inside of Saint Mark's.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham, who, when it came to it, understood their friend better than anyone. She knew her so well that she seemed to be acting in perfect accordance with conditions that were relatively unclear, and almost terrifying to them, by not feeling the need to stay put. She had fixed the perfunctory aspect, a small flaw in the situation for everyone involved; she had conjured a preference for herself and Mrs. Lowder; she recalled the cherished hopes of the lace, which had always been sidelined by circumstance, and it occurred to her that Kate had, the previous day, mentioned the role of fate in her own inability to truly get to know the inside of Saint Mark's.

Densher's sense of Susan Shepherd's conscious intervention had by this time a corner of his mind all to itself; something that had begun for them at Lancaster Gate was now a sentiment clothed in a shape; her action, ineffably discreet, had at all events a way of affecting him as for the most part subtly, even when not superficially, in his own interest. They were not, as a pair, as a "team," really united; there were too many persons, at least three, and too many things, between them; but meanwhile something was preparing that would draw them closer. He scarce knew what: probably nothing but his finding, at some hour when it would be a service to do so, that she had all the while understood him. He even had a presentiment of a juncture at which the understanding of every one else would fail and this deep little person's alone survive.

Translation

Densher's feeling that Susan Shepherd was consciously involved had, by this point, taken up a portion of his mind entirely. Something that had begun for them at Lancaster Gate was now an emotion with a defined form. Her actions, indescribably subtle, had the effect of influencing him, mostly in ways that were delicate, even when not immediately obvious, and to his benefit. They weren't, as a pair, as a "team," truly united; there were too many people, at least three, and too many things between them. But in the meantime, something was developing that would bring them closer. He barely knew what: probably nothing more than his eventual realization, at some opportune moment, that she had understood him all along. He even had a premonition of a moment when everyone else's understanding would fail, and only this small, perceptive woman's would endure.

The situation left its mark on everyone. The way they reacted, gathered in the opulent room, pristine and beautifully decorated as always for her arrival, was telling. They—the others—simply stared at each other. It was unsettling, likely disturbing for each of them individually, that they didn’t express any shared sadness.

Translation

The situation left its imprint on everyone. How they reacted, gathered in the luxurious room, immaculate and perfectly prepared for her arrival, was revealing. They—the others—just looked at one another. It was unsettling, probably disturbing to each of them individually, that they didn't demonstrate any shared sorrow.

It was particularly strange for our young man that, if the poor girl was truly unwell, the quiet seriousness, the sense of worry, of underlying meaning, was all the guests could muster. In fact, the silence continued even after the group of four descended to the gondola and settled in. Milly had sent word that she hoped they would enjoy themselves, which produced another remarkable look, a look as if they all knew exactly what such a message meant: a way to occupy Densher. She didn’t want to ruin his morning, and so, out of politeness, he had to pretend everything was fine.

Translation

This was especially odd for our young man. If the poor girl was genuinely sick, all the guests could manage was a quiet solemnity, a vague air of concern, an unspoken significance. The silence persisted even as the four of them went down to the gondola and took their seats. Milly had sent word that she hoped they would have a good time. This prompted another peculiar look, as if they all knew precisely what that message implied: a way to keep Densher occupied. She didn't want to spoil his morning, and so, out of courtesy, he had to act as though everything was normal.

Mrs. Stringham had helped smooth things over, Mrs. Stringham, who, when it came down to it, understood their friend better than any of them. She knew her so well that she knew herself to be acting in delicate accordance with circumstances that were somewhat mysterious and deeply concerning to them, by not feeling it was necessary to stay behind.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham had been the one to ease the situation, Mrs. Stringham, who, in the end, understood their friend better than anyone. She knew her so well that she knew she was acting in a way that was sensitive to the circumstances, which were, to them, somewhat mysterious and deeply worrying, by not feeling the need to remain behind.

She had corrected the perfunctory feeling, which was a minor flaw of the occasion for all of them; she had invented a preference for Mrs. Lowder and herself; she had remembered the cherished dream of seeing lace that had always been thwarted by unfortunate events, and it also occurred to her that Kate had, the previous day, mentioned the role of fate in her own lack of experience with the inside of Saint Mark's. Densher had by this time dedicated a corner of his mind to Susan Shepherd's deliberate interference; something that had begun for them at Lancaster Gate was now a feeling that had taken shape; her actions, exquisitely subtle, had a way of affecting him, mostly subtly, even when not obviously, in his own favor. They weren't truly united as a couple, as a "team"; there were too many people, at least three, and too many complications between them; but in the meantime, something was developing that would draw them closer.

Translation

She had smoothed over the superficiality, a small imperfection in the situation for everyone present. She had manufactured a fondness for Mrs. Lowder and herself. She had recalled a long-held desire to see lace, a wish repeatedly frustrated by bad luck. It also occurred to her that Kate had, the day before, spoken about fate's influence on her inexperience with Saint Mark's interior. Densher had, by this point, devoted a portion of his thoughts to Susan Shepherd's intentional meddling. A vague unease that had started at Lancaster Gate had crystallized into something more substantial. Her exquisitely delicate maneuvers had a way of influencing him, often subtly, even when it wasn't immediately apparent, and usually to his benefit. They weren't a true couple, not a cohesive unit. Too many other people, at least three, and too many complexities stood between them. But in the meantime, a connection was forming that would pull them nearer.

He barely knew what: probably nothing but his discovery, at some point when it would be helpful, that she had understood him all along. He even had a premonition of a moment when everyone else's understanding would fail, and only this insightful little person’s would remain. Such was to-day, in its freshness, the moral air, as we may say, that hung about our young friends; these had been the small accidents and quiet forces to which they owed the advantage we have seen them in some sort enjoying. It seemed in fact fairly to deepen for them as they stayed their course again; the splendid Square, which had so notoriously, in all the years, witnessed more of the joy of life than any equal area in Europe, furnished them, in their remoteness from earshot, with solitude and security.

Translation

He barely knew what: probably nothing beyond realizing, whenever it became relevant, that she had understood him all along. He even foresaw a moment when everyone else would fail to grasp things, and only this perceptive little person would still get it. Such was the freshness of the moral atmosphere that surrounded our young friends today, we might say. They owed their current advantage to these small occurrences and quiet forces. It seemed to deepen for them as they continued their journey; the magnificent Square, which had, over the years, notoriously witnessed more joy than any other comparable space in Europe, provided them with solitude and safety, far from any listening ears.

It was as if, being in possession, they could say what they liked; and it was also as if, in consequence of that, each had an apprehension of what the other wanted to say. It was most of all for them, moreover, as if this very quantity, seated on their lips in the bright historic air, where the only sign for their ears was the flutter of the doves, begot in the heart of each a fear. There might have been a betrayal of that in the way Densher broke the silence resting on her last words. "What did you mean just now that I can do to make Mrs.

Translation

It was as though, in this state of possession, they could say whatever they pleased. Furthermore, because of this, each had a sense of what the other intended to say. Above all, it felt as though this very thing, hovering on their lips in the bright, historic air, where the only sound was the flutter of doves, instilled a fear in each of their hearts. Perhaps there was a hint of this fear in the way Densher broke the silence that followed her last words. "What did you mean just now, about what I can do to make Mrs.

Lowder believe? For myself, stupidly, if you will, I don't see, from the moment I can't lie to her, what else there is but lying." The moral atmosphere surrounding our young friends was fresh today. These were the small incidents and subtle influences that had given them the advantage we've seen them experience.

Translation

"What did you mean just now, about what I can do to make Mrs. Lowder believe? Because, for myself, stupidly, if you will, I don't see, since I can't lie to her, what else there is but lying." The moral atmosphere surrounding our young friends was fresh today. These were the small incidents and subtle influences that had given them the advantage we've seen them experience.

As they continued their journey, this feeling seemed to deepen. The magnificent Square, which had seen more joy than any other place in Europe over the years, provided them with solitude and security, as they were far from any noise. It was as if, now that they were in control, they could say whatever they wanted. Also, each seemed to understand what the other wished to express.

Translation

That sensation only intensified as they went on. The grand Square, a place that had witnessed more happiness than perhaps anywhere else in Europe, offered them isolation and safety, removed as they were from any disturbances. It was as though, with their current leverage, they could speak with complete freedom. Furthermore, they each seemed to grasp the other’s unspoken intentions.

Most of all, this sense of possibility, present in the bright, historic air where the only sound was the cooing of doves, created fear within them. Densher's response to her final words revealed this fear. "What did you mean when you said I could do something to make Mrs. Lowder believe?

Translation

Above all, this feeling of potential, palpable in the vibrant, historic air, the only sound the soft cooing of doves, provoked dread in them. Densher's reaction to her last words betrayed this fear. "What did you mean when you said I could make Mrs. Lowder believe?"

I don't see, since I can't lie to her, what else there is to do besides lying, even though it's foolish." Well, she could tell him. "You can say something both handsome and sincere to her about Milly—whom you honestly like so much. That wouldn't be lying; and, coming from you, it would have an effect.

Translation

"I don't understand, since I can't lie to her, what else I could do besides lying, even if it's pointless." Well, she had an idea. "You could say something both gracious and genuine to her about Milly—whom you honestly like so much. That wouldn't be a lie; and, coming from you, it would have an impact."

You don't, you know, say much about her." And Kate put before him the fruit of observation. "You don't, you know, speak of her at all." "And has Aunt Maud," Densher asked, "told you so?" Then as the girl, for answer, only seemed to bethink herself, "You must have extraordinary conversations!" he exclaimed.

Translation

"You don't talk about her much, you know." Kate presented him with the fruit of her observations. "You don't, you know, mention her at all."

"And has Aunt Maud," Densher asked, "told you that?" Then, as the girl only seemed to consider this as an answer, he exclaimed, "You must have some fascinating conversations!"

Yes, she had bethought herself. "We have extraordinary conversations." His look, while their eyes met, marked him as disposed to hear more about them; but there was something in her own, apparently, that defeated the opportunity. He questioned her in a moment on a different matter, which had been in his mind a week, yet in respect to which he had had no chance so good as this.

Translation

Yes, she had thought about it. "We have extraordinary conversations." His expression, as their eyes met, signaled that he wanted to hear more; but something about her own expression seemed to squelch the possibility. In an instant, he shifted the topic to something else, a matter he'd been pondering for a week, and for which he hadn't had such a good opportunity to discuss.

"Do you happen to know then, as such wonderful things pass between you, what she makes of the incident, the other day, of Lord Mark's so very superficial visit?—his having spent here, as I gather, but the two or three hours necessary for seeing our friend and yet taken no time at all, since he went off by the same night's train, for seeing any one else. What can she make of his not having waited to see you, or to see herself—with all he owes her?" She could advise him. "You can tell her something nice and truthful about Milly, whom you genuinely like so much.

Translation

"Do you happen to know, since you two have such remarkable discussions, what she thinks of Lord Mark's rather shallow visit the other day? I understand he spent only two or three hours here, enough time to see our friend, and then left on the same night's train without seeing anyone else. What do you suppose she thinks of his not waiting to see you, or to see her, considering everything he owes her?" She could give him advice. "You could tell her something kind and truthful about Milly, whom you genuinely like."

That wouldn't be a lie, and it would have an impact coming from you. You don't often talk about her." Kate offered the results of her observations. "You hardly ever mention her."

Translation

That wouldn't be a deception, and it would be significant coming from you. You rarely speak about her." Kate offered her assessment. "You almost never mention her."

"Has Aunt Maud," Densher inquired, "told you this?" When the girl seemed to be thinking about it instead of answering, he exclaimed, "You must have some fascinating conversations!" Yes, she had been thinking. "We do have fascinating conversations." His expression, as their eyes met, suggested he wanted to hear more, but something in her expression seemed to prevent it.

Translation

"Has Aunt Maud mentioned this to you?" Densher asked. When the girl didn't immediately reply, seeming to consider the question, he exclaimed, "You must have some captivating conversations!" Yes, she had been thinking. "We do have captivating conversations." His expression, as their eyes met, indicated that he wanted to know more, but something in her demeanor seemed to discourage him.

He switched the subject to something else that had been on his mind for a week, but he hadn't had a good chance to ask about it. "Since such amazing things are discussed between you, do you happen to know what she thinks about Lord Mark's very brief visit the other day? He spent just a few hours here, just enough time to see our friend, and then left on the same night's train without seeing anyone else. What could she possibly think about him not waiting to see you or even herself, considering everything he owes her?"

Translation

He changed the topic to something else that had been on his mind for a week but he hadn't had a chance to ask about. "Since you two have such amazing discussions, do you know what she thinks about Lord Mark's very short visit the other day? He was here only a few hours, long enough to see our friend, and then left on the same night's train without seeing anyone else. What could she possibly think about him not waiting to see you or even herself, considering everything he owes her?"

"Oh of course," said Kate, "she understands. He came to make Milly his offer of marriage—he came for nothing but that. As Milly wholly declined it his business was for the time at an end. He couldn't quite on the spot turn round to make up to us."

Translation

"Oh, certainly," Kate replied, "she understands. He came to propose to Milly—that was his only reason for being here. Since Milly turned him down completely, his purpose was finished. He couldn't just immediately switch gears and visit us."

Kate had looked surprised that, as a matter of taste on such an adventurer's part, Densher shouldn't see it. But Densher was lost in another thought. "Do you mean that when, turning up myself, I found him leaving her, that was what had been taking place between them?" "Didn't you make it out, my dear?" Kate enquired.

Translation

Kate had been surprised that Densher, who seemed so worldly, didn't understand the situation as a matter of principle. But Densher was preoccupied. "Are you saying that when I arrived and found him leaving her, that was the situation between them?" "Didn't you realize, dear?" Kate asked.

"What sort of a blundering weathercock then is he?" the young man went on in his wonder. "Oh, obviously," Kate said, "she understands. He came to propose to Milly—he came solely for that purpose. Since Milly rejected him, his business was finished.

Translation

"What kind of a confused simpleton is he, then?" the young man continued, clearly amazed. "Oh, it's obvious," Kate replied. "She understands. He came to propose to Milly—that was his only goal. Since Milly turned him down, his task was done."

He couldn't simply turn around and court us right away." Kate had been surprised that Densher, being the kind of person he was, couldn't see it. But Densher was preoccupied with something else. "Are you saying that when I arrived and found him leaving her, that's what had just happened?"

Translation

"He couldn't just pivot and start pursuing us immediately." Kate was astonished that Densher, given his nature, didn't grasp this. However, Densher was focused on another point. "Are you implying that when I got here and saw him leaving her, that's what had just occurred?"

"Didn't you realize, dear?" Kate asked. "What a clueless opportunist he is then?" the young man exclaimed in amazement. "Oh don't make too little of him!" Kate smiled. "Do you pretend that Milly didn't tell you?"

Translation

"Didn't you understand, darling?" Kate asked. "So he's nothing but a clueless opportunist?" The young man expressed his astonishment. "Oh, don't underestimate him," Kate replied with a smile. "Are you pretending Milly didn't tell you?"

"How great an ass he had made of himself?" Kate continued to smile. "You are in love with her, you know." He gave her another long look.

Translation

"What a fool he'd made of himself?" Kate kept smiling. "You're in love with her, you know." He gave her another long look.

"Why, since she has refused him, should my opinion of Lord Mark show it? I'm not obliged, however, to think well of him for such treatment of the other persons I've mentioned, and I feel I don't understand from you why Mrs. Lowder should." "She doesn't—but she doesn't care," Kate explained.

Translation

"Why should my opinion of Lord Mark change just because she rejected him? I'm not required to think highly of him because of how he's treated the other people I mentioned. And I don't understand why Mrs. Lowder would," he said.

"She doesn't—but she doesn't care," Kate replied.

"You know perfectly the terms on which lots of London people live together even when they're supposed to live very well. He's not committed to us—he was having his try. Mayn't an unsatisfied man," she asked, "always have his try?" "Oh, don't dismiss him so quickly!" Kate said with a smile.

Translation

"You're fully aware of how many Londoners operate, even those with substantial means. He's not devoted to us—he was testing the waters. Isn't a man who's been denied allowed to try again?" she asked.

Lowder doesn't care either. "She doesn't," Kate clarified. "You know how many Londoners struggle, even those with money. He wasn't dedicated to us; he was just giving it a shot."

Can't a man who hasn't succeeded," she asked, "always try again?" "And come back afterwards, with confidence in a welcome, to the victim of his inconstancy?" Kate consented, as for argument, to be thought of as a victim. "Oh but he has had his try at me.

Translation

"Can't a man who hasn't succeeded," she asked, "always try again?" "And then come back, expecting a welcome, to the person he was inconsistent with?" Kate, for the sake of the argument, allowed herself to be considered a victim. "He has already tried his luck with me."

So it's all right." "Through your also having, you mean, refused him?" She balanced an instant during which Densher might have just wondered if pure historic truth were to suffer a slight strain. But she dropped on the right side.

Translation

"So it's okay." "Because you also refused him, you mean?" She paused for a moment, during which Densher might have wondered if the pure historical truth would be slightly bent. But she landed on the right side of things.

"I haven't let it come to that. I've been too discouraging. Aunt Maud," she went on—now as lucid as ever—"considers, no doubt, that she has a pledge from him in respect to me; a pledge that would have been broken if Milly had accepted him. As the case stands that makes no difference."

Translation

"I haven't let things get that far. I've been too discouraging. Aunt Maud," she continued—now perfectly clear again—"probably thinks she has a promise from him regarding me; a promise that would have been void if Milly had accepted him. As things are, it doesn't matter."

"Because you, in turn, refused him?" She paused, and Densher might have wondered if she was slightly misrepresenting the truth. But she chose the correct answer. "I never let it get to that point.

Translation

"Because you turned him down?" She hesitated, and Densher might have questioned the accuracy of her statement. But she gave the right reply. "I never gave him the chance."

"I was too intimidating. Aunt Maud," she continued, now utterly convinced, "probably thinks he made her a promise about me—a promise he would have broken had Milly agreed to marry him. But it's irrelevant now." Densher laughed out loud.

"It isn't his merit that he has failed." "It's still his merit, my dear, that he's Lord Mark. He's just what he was, and what he knew he was. It's not for me either to reflect on him after I've so treated him."

Translation

"His failure isn't a reflection of his worth." "He's still worthy, my dear, because he's Lord Mark. He's exactly as he was, and as he always knew himself to be. It's not my place to judge him after I've treated him so poorly."

Translation

"Oh," Densher said impatiently, "you've treated him beautifully."

Such a recognition as that can't but seem to her to involve in some degree your own recognition. Out of which she therefore gets it that the more you have for Milly the less you have for me." Densher chuckled. "It's not his fault he failed."

Translation

That kind of understanding, she must feel, has to include your own. And from that, she figures that the more you feel for Milly, the less you feel for me.” Densher chuckled. “It’s not his fault he failed.”

"It's still his asset, darling, that he's Lord Mark. He's exactly who he always was, and he knew it. It's not my place to criticize him after the way I've behaved towards him." "Oh," Densher said impatiently, "you've treated him wonderfully."

"But it's still his advantage, dear, that he's Lord Mark. He's exactly who he's always been, and he knew it. It's not my place to criticize him after the way I've behaved towards him." "Oh," Densher said impatiently, "you've treated him wonderfully."
