Translation

"I'm glad," she said, smiling, "that you're still capable of jealousy." Before he could say anything, she went on. "I don't know why it should shock you that Milly's certainty delights Aunt Maud more than anything else upsets her. What does she see but that Milly believes her relationship with you is too precious to jeopardize? That kind of certainty must seem to include your own."

As a result, she concludes that the more you give to Milly, the less you have for me." There were moments again—we know that from the first they had been numerous—when he felt with a strange mixed passion the mastery of her mere way of putting things. There was something in it that bent him at once to conviction and to reaction. And this effect, however it be named, now broke into his tone.

Translation

"Consequently, she figures the more you devote to Milly, the less you have left over for me." Moments returned—we know they'd been frequent from the start—when he felt, with a peculiar and complex fervor, the power of her phrasing. There was something in it that immediately compelled him toward both agreement and opposition. And this effect, by whatever name, now colored his voice.

"Oh if she began to know what I have for you—!" It wasn't ambiguous, but Kate stood up to it. "Luckily for us we may really consider she doesn't. So successful have we been."

Translation

"Oh, if she started to understand how I feel about you—!" It wasn't vague, but Kate stood firm against it. "Luckily for us, we can genuinely believe she doesn't. We've been so successful."

"Well," he presently said, "I take from you what you give me, and I suppose that, to be consistent—to stand on my feet where I do stand at all—I ought to thank you. Only, you know, what you give me seems to me, more than anything else, the larger and larger size of my job. It seems to me more than anything else what you expect of me. It never seems to me somehow what I may expect of you.

Translation

"Well," he said after a moment, "I accept what you offer, and I suppose, to be consistent—to maintain my position—I should thank you. Only, what you give me feels, above all else, like an ever-increasing workload. It feels, more than anything else, like what you expect from me. Somehow, it never feels like what I can expect from you."

There's so much you don't give me." There were times—and we know there were many from the start—when he found himself strangely captivated by the way she expressed herself. Her words had a peculiar power over him, simultaneously convincing and provoking him. This effect, whatever it was, now crept into his voice.

Translation

"You withhold so much," he said. He had often been drawn to her way of speaking, and they both knew it had been that way from the start. Her words had a strange hold over him, both persuading and challenging him at once. That effect, whatever it was, was now present in his tone.

"Oh, if she only knew how I feel about you!" It was a clear statement, and Kate met it head-on. "Fortunately for us, we can safely assume she doesn't. We've been very successful."

Translation

"Oh, if only she knew how I feel about you!" The statement was straightforward, and Kate responded without hesitation. "Fortunately for us, we can safely assume she doesn't. We've been very successful."

"Well," he said after a moment, "I accept what you offer, and I suppose, to be consistent—to maintain my position—I should thank you. But what you give me feels, more than anything else, like an ever-increasing burden. It seems to me, above all, what you demand of me. Somehow, it never feels like what I can expect from you.

Translation

"Alright," he said after a pause, "I'll take what you're giving me, and I guess, to stay the course—to keep my place—I should be grateful. But what you're offering feels, more than anything else, like a weight that keeps growing. It strikes me, more than anything else, as what you require of me. Somehow, it never feels like what I can get from you."

You withhold so much." She appeared to wonder. "And pray what is it I don't—?" "I give you proof," said Densher.

Translation

You hold back so much." She seemed to be thinking. "And may I ask what exactly I don't—?" "I offer you proof," Densher said.

"You give me none." "What then do you call proof?" she after a moment ventured to ask. "Your doing something for me." She considered with surprise.

Translation

"You give me none." "What then do you call proof?" she ventured to ask after a moment. "Your doing something for me." She considered with surprise.

"Am I not doing this for you? Do you call this nothing?" "Nothing at all." "Ah I risk, my dear, everything for it."

Translation

"Am I not doing this for you? Do you call this nothing?" "Nothing at all." "Ah, I risk everything for this, my dear."

They had strolled slowly further, but he was brought up short. "I thought you exactly contend that, with your aunt so bamboozled, you risk nothing!" It was the first time since the launching of her wonderful idea that he had seen her at a loss. He judged the next instant moreover that she didn't like it—either the being so or the being seen, for she soon spoke with an impatience that showed her as wounded; an appearance that produced in himself, he no less quickly felt, a sharp pang of indulgence.

Translation

They had drifted onward at a leisurely pace, but he abruptly stopped. "I understood you to argue precisely the opposite: that with your aunt completely fooled, you risk nothing!" It was the first time since she'd conceived her brilliant plan that he had seen her uncertain. He also perceived in the next moment that she disliked it—either being so, or being seen that way, because she soon spoke with an impatience that revealed her distress; an appearance that, he felt immediately, sparked within him a sharp twinge of compassion.

"What then do you wish me to risk?" She looked puzzled. "And what exactly am I not—?" "I'm giving you evidence," Densher said.

Translation

"Then what do you want me to risk?" She looked confused. "And what exactly am I not—?" "I'm giving you evidence," Densher said.

"You're giving me none." "So what do you consider evidence?" she finally asked after a pause. "You doing something for me." She looked thoughtful, surprised.

Translation

"You're giving me nothing." "So what counts as evidence, then?" she finally asked after a pause. "You doing something for me." She looked thoughtful, surprised.

"Am I not doing this for you? You think this is nothing?" "Nothing at all." "Oh, but I am risking everything for this, my dear."

Translation

"Aren't I doing this for you? You think this is nothing?" "Nothing at all." "Oh, but I'm risking everything for this, my dear."

They had walked a little further, and he stopped. "I thought you claimed that, with your aunt so fooled, you weren't risking anything!" It was the first time since she'd presented her brilliant plan that she seemed at a loss. He realized in the next moment that she disliked it—both being in that state and being seen that way.

Translation

They walked on a bit, and then he stopped. "I thought you said you weren't risking anything, since your aunt was completely fooled!" It was the first time since she'd laid out her brilliant plan that she seemed at a loss. He realized in the next instant that she hated it—both being in that state and being seen that way.

She soon spoke with a wounded impatience, an expression that immediately caused him to feel a sharp pang of sympathy. "So, what do you want me to risk?" The appeal from danger touched him, but all to make him, as he would have said, worse. "What I wish is to be loved.

Translation

Her voice, now wounded and impatient, immediately pricked him with a sharp stab of sympathy. "So, what exactly do you want me to risk?" The plea against danger moved him, though ultimately for his own detriment. "What I want is to be loved."

How can I feel at this rate that I am?" Oh she understood him, for all she might so bravely disguise it, and that made him feel straighter than if she hadn't. Deep, always, was his sense of life with her—deep as it had been from the moment of those signs of life that in the dusky London of two winters ago they had originally exchanged. He had never taken her for unguarded, ignorant, weak; and if he put to her a claim for some intenser faith between them this was because he believed it could reach her and she could meet it. "I can go on perhaps," he said, "with help.

Translation

"At this rate, how can I feel that I exist?" Oh, she understood him, despite all her brave attempts to hide it, and that made him feel more grounded than if she hadn't understood at all. His sense of life with her was always profound—as deep as it had been from the moment they first exchanged those signs of life in the dim London of two winters prior. He had never considered her unguarded, ignorant, or weak. If he pressed her for a stronger faith between them, it was because he believed it was within her reach and that she could reciprocate. "I can go on, perhaps," he said, "with some assistance."

But I can't go on without." The threat of danger excited him, but it only served to make him, as he would put it, more troubled. "What I want is to be loved. How can I believe I am, with things as they are?" Oh, she understood him, even though she tried so hard to hide it, and that made him feel more honest than if she hadn't.

Translation

But I can't go on without it." The threat of danger excited him, but it only served to make him, in his words, more troubled. "What I want is to be loved. How can I believe I am, with things as they are?" Oh, she understood him, even though she tried so hard to hide it, and that made him feel more honest than if she hadn't.

Their shared life was always profound – as profound as it had been from the first indications of connection they had shown each other in the dim London of two winters past. He had never considered her careless, naive, or weak; and if he demanded a stronger trust between them, it was because he thought she was capable of it, that she could respond. "I might be able to manage," he said, "with support. But I can't manage without it."

Translation

Their life together had always been intense, as deep as it had been from the first glimpses of a connection they'd shared in the shadowy London of two winters before. He'd never seen her as thoughtless, innocent, or fragile. If he pushed for a greater level of trust between them, it was because he believed she was up to it, that she could meet him there. "I could probably handle this," he said, "if I had some backing. But I can't do it alone."

She looked away from him now, and it showed him how she understood. "We ought to be there—I mean when they come out." "They won't come out—not yet. And I don't care if they do." To which he straightway added, as if to deal with the charge of selfishness that his words, sounding for himself, struck him as enabling her to make: "Why not have done with it all and face the music as we are?" It broke from him in perfect sincerity.

Translation

She looked away, and it revealed her understanding. "We should be there—when they come out."

"They won't come out—not yet. And I don't care if they do."

Then he immediately added, as if to counter the accusation of selfishness that his own words seemed to allow her to make: "Why not just finish it all and face the consequences as we are?" It came from him with complete sincerity.

"Good God, if you'd only take me!" It brought her eyes round to him again, and he could see how, after all, somewhere deep within, she felt his rebellion more sweet than bitter. Its effect on her spirit and her sense was visibly to hold her an instant. "We've gone too far," she none the less pulled herself together to reply.

Translation

"Good God, if you'd only take me!" Her eyes snapped back to him, and he could see that, despite everything, deep down, she found his defiance more appealing than painful. The effect on her emotions and her reason visibly gave her pause. "We've gone too far," she nevertheless forced herself to say.

"Do you want to kill her?" She averted her gaze, and he saw that she comprehended. "We should be present—when they leave." "They won't leave—not yet.

Translation

"Do you want to kill her?" She looked away, and he could tell she understood. "We should be there—when they go." "They won't go—not yet."

And I don't care if they do." He immediately added, as if to counter the selfishness that his words, only meant for himself, seemed to allow her to accuse him of: "Why not end this and accept the consequences right now?" It escaped him with complete honesty. "For God's sake, if only you'd accept me!" Her eyes returned to him, and he could see that, despite everything, deep down, she found his defiance more appealing than repugnant. Its impact on her emotions and understanding visibly caused her to pause for a moment.

Translation

"I don't care if they do." He quickly added the words, as if to defend against the selfishness he knew his statement—intended for his own ears—might suggest to her: "Why not just end it all and face the music?" The question was utterly sincere. "For the love of God, just accept me!" Her eyes found his, and he understood that, despite everything, at her core, she found his refusal to surrender more attractive than repulsive. The effect on her feelings and comprehension made her visibly pause.

"We've gone too far," she nonetheless composed herself to reply. "Do you want to destroy her?" He had an hesitation that wasn't all candid. "Kill, you mean, Aunt Maud?"

Translation

"We've crossed a line," she gathered herself to respond. "Do you want to ruin her?" He hesitated, not entirely honestly. "Kill, you mean, Aunt Maud?"

"You know whom I mean. We've told too many lies." Oh at this his head went up. "I, my dear, have told none!"

Translation

"You know who I'm talking about. We've told far too many lies." At this, his head shot up. "I, my dear, haven't told any!"

He had brought it out with a sharpness that did him good, but he had naturally, none the less, to take the look it made her give him. "Thank you very much." Her expression, however, failed to check the words that had already risen to his lips. "Rather than lay myself open to the least appearance of it I'll go this very night."

Translation

The vehemence of his statement felt satisfying, but he still had to endure the expression it brought to her face. "Thank you very much." Her reaction, however, did not stop the words that had already formed on his tongue. "Rather than allow myself to appear even slightly susceptible, I will leave tonight."

"Then go," said Kate Croy. He knew after a little, while they walked on again together, that what was in the air for him, and disconcertingly, was not the violence, but much rather the cold quietness, of the way this had come from her. They walked on together, and it was for a minute as if their difference had become of a sudden, in all truth, a split—as if the basis of his departure had been settled. Then, incoherently and still more suddenly, recklessly moreover, since they now might easily, from under the arcades, be observed, he passed his hand into her arm with a force that produced for them another pause.

Translation

"Then go," said Kate Croy. He knew, after a moment, as they walked on again together, that what unsettled him wasn't the heat of it all, but the cold quietness of her response. They walked on, and for a moment it was as if their disagreement had suddenly become an actual divide—as if his leaving had already been decided. Then, incoherently and even more suddenly, recklessly in fact, since they were now exposed under the arcades, he took her arm with such force that it caused them to pause again.

"I'll tell any lie you want, any your idea requires, if you'll only come to me." He seemed a bit evasive. "Kill, you mean, Aunt Maud?" "You know who I mean.

Translation

"I'll say whatever you need me to, whatever you think is necessary, if you'll just come to me." He seemed to be avoiding something. "You mean, do something violent, Aunt Maud?" "You know who I'm talking about."

We've lied too much." His head shot up at that. "I, my dear, have told no lies!" He said it with a sharpness that satisfied him, but he still had to endure the look she gave him.

Translation

"We've lied too much." His head snapped up at her words. "I, my dear, have told no lies!" He spoke with a sharpness that pleased him, but he still had to bear her gaze.

"Thanks a lot." Her expression, however, didn't stop the words that were already forming. "Rather than risk even the slightest suggestion of it, I'll leave tonight." "Then go," said Kate Croy.

Translation

"Thanks a lot." Her expression, however, didn't stop the words that were already forming. "Rather than risk even the slightest suggestion of it, I'll leave tonight." "Then go," said Kate Croy.

After a moment, as they continued walking, he realized what was unsettling him wasn't the intensity of the situation, but the cold composure of her response. They walked on, and for a moment it was as if their disagreement had suddenly become a real separation—as if the reason for his departure had been decided. Then, incoherently and even more suddenly, recklessly since they could easily be seen under the arcades, he took her arm with such force that they stopped again. "I'll tell any lie you want, whatever your plan needs, if only you'll come to me."

Translation

He paused for a moment. As they kept walking, he understood that what was disturbing him wasn't the heat of the moment, but rather, the icy control she displayed in response. They continued their walk, and for a moment, it felt as though their disagreement had become a genuine parting of ways—as if his leaving had already been decided. Then, irrationally and with more suddenness, reckless given the open arcades, he grabbed her arm with such force that they stopped again. "I will tell any lie you want, whatever your plan requires, if only you'll come to me."

"Come to you?" "Come to me." "How? Where?"

Translation

"Come to you?" "Come to me." "How? Where?"

She spoke low, but there was somehow, for his uncertainty, a wonder in her being so equal to him. "To my rooms, which are perfectly possible, and in taking which, the other day, I had you, as you must have felt, in view. We can arrange it—with two grains of courage. People in our case always arrange it." She listened as for the good information, and there was support for him—since it was a question of his going step by step—in the way she took no refuge in showing herself shocked.

Translation

She lowered her voice, but for all his hesitation, there was a marvel in how she matched him. "To my rooms, which are perfectly available, and in taking which, the other day, I had you, as you must have sensed, in mind. We can manage it—with a little courage. People in our position always manage it." She listened as though for encouragement, and there was support for him—because it was a matter of his proceeding carefully—in the way she didn't feign any shock.

He had in truth not expected of her that particular vulgarity, but the absence of it only added the thrill of a deeper reason to his sense of possibilities. For the knowledge of what she was he had absolutely to see her now, incapable of refuge, stand there for him in all the light of the day and of his admirable merciless meaning. Her mere listening in fact made him even understand himself as he hadn't yet done. Idea for idea, his own was thus already, and in the germ, beautiful.

Translation

He hadn't anticipated that level of vulgarity from her, but its absence only intensified the excitement, hinting at a more profound motivation behind her proposition. Now, he absolutely needed to see her, to know exactly what she was. He needed to see her, defenseless, illuminated by the day and by his own admirable, ruthless intention. Her attentive silence even allowed him to understand himself in a way he hadn't before. His own idea, at least in its embryonic form, was already, beautifully formed.

"There's nothing for me possible but to feel that I'm not a fool. It's all I have to say, but you must know what it means. With you I can do it—I'll go as far as you demand or as you will yourself. Without you—I'll be hanged!

Translation

"The only thing I can do is feel like I'm not a fool. That's all I have to say, but you have to understand what it implies. With you, I can do it—I'll go as far as you want, as far as you'll let me. Without you—I'm finished!"

And I must be sure." "Come to you?" "Come to me." "How?

Translation

And I must be certain." "Come to you?" "Come to me." "How?"

Where?" She spoke quietly, but despite his hesitation, there was something astonishing in her composure. "To my apartment. It's perfectly feasible.

Translation

"Where?" Her voice was soft, but even though he paused, her calm was remarkable. "To my apartment. It's entirely possible."

When I took it the other day, I was thinking of you, as you must have realized. We can make it happen, if we're brave. People in our situation always manage." She seemed to be waiting for his agreement, and it was reassuring—as he was proceeding cautiously—that she didn't feign shock. He hadn't expected that particular reaction from her, but its absence only amplified the excitement of his growing sense of what was possible.

Translation

"When I took it the other day, I was thinking of you, as you must have realized." We can make it happen, if we're brave. People in our situation always manage." She seemed to be waiting for his agreement, and it was reassuring—as he was proceeding cautiously—that she didn't feign shock. He hadn't expected that particular reaction from her, but its absence only amplified the excitement of his growing sense of what was possible.

He needed to see her now, exposed and vulnerable, standing there in the full light of day, reflecting his own clear, determined intentions, if he were to truly know her. Her mere willingness to listen helped him understand his own desires more fully than he had yet. Idea for idea, his own was beautiful, even in its conception. "The only thing I can do is to avoid feeling like an idiot.

Translation

He needed to see her now, laid bare, defenseless, standing in the bright sunlight, mirroring his own clear, resolute intent, if he was ever going to truly understand her. Her simple willingness to hear him out helped him grasp his own ambitions more completely than he had yet. Concept for concept, his idea was beautiful, even in its planning. "The only thing I can do is avoid feeling like a fool."

That's all I have to say, but you must know what that implies. With you, I can do this. I'll go as far as you want, as far as you'll go. Without you, I'm finished!

Translation

That's all I'm saying, though you should understand the implications. With you, I can pull this off. I'll go as far as you want to, as far as you're willing to go. Without you, I'm done for!

And I must be certain." She listened so well that she was really listening after he had ceased to speak. He had kept his grasp of her, drawing her close, and though they had again, for the time, stopped walking, his talk—for others at a distance—might have been, in the matchless place, that of any impressed tourist to any slightly more detached companion. On possessing himself of her arm he had made her turn, so that they faced afresh to Saint Mark's, over the great presence of which his eyes moved while she twiddled her parasol.

Translation

"And I must be certain." She was so attentive that she truly heard him even after he'd finished speaking. He held her, pulling her close, and though they'd stopped walking again, for the moment, his words—to anyone watching from afar—could have been those of a tourist, amazed in a remarkable place, speaking to a slightly more reserved companion. After taking her arm, he'd made her turn to face Saint Mark's again; his eyes traveled across its grand facade while she toyed with her parasol.

She now, however, made a motion that confronted them finally with the opposite end. Then only she spoke—"Please take your hand out of my arm." He understood at once: she had made out in the shade of the gallery the issue of the others from their place of purchase. So they went to them side by side, and it was all right. The others had seen them as well and waited for them, complacent enough, under one of the arches.

Translation

She now, however, gestured, leading them to the other end. Only then did she speak—"Please take your hand off my arm." He understood immediately: she had seen the others emerging from the shops in the shade of the gallery. So they went to them, side by side, and everything was fine. The others had seen them and were waiting, contentedly, under one of the arches.

They themselves too—he argued that Kate would argue—looked perfectly ready, decently patient, properly accommodating. They themselves suggested nothing worse—always by Kate's system—than a pair of the children of a supercivilised age making the best of an awkwardness. They didn't nevertheless hurry—that would overdo it; so he had time to feel, as it were, what he felt. He felt, ever so distinctly—it was with this he faced Mrs.

Translation

They, too—he figured Kate would agree—looked entirely prepared, respectably patient, and properly agreeable. They, adhering always to Kate’s method, did not imply anything more untoward than a couple of children from a hyper-civilized era managing an uncomfortable situation as best they could. They did not, however, rush—that would be too much; thus, he had time to consider his feelings. He felt, very distinctly—and it was with this he confronted Mrs.

Lowder—that he was already in a sense possessed of what he wanted. There was more to come—everything; he had by no means, with his companion, had it all out. Yet what he was possessed of was real—the fact that she hadn't thrown over his lucidity the horrid shadow of cheap reprobation. Of this he had had so sore a fear that its being dispelled was in itself of the nature of bliss.

Translation

Lowder—that he already, in a way, had what he desired. More was to come—everything; he and his friend hadn't yet said it all. But what he did have was real—the fact that she hadn't cast the awful pall of easy condemnation over his clear thinking. He had been so afraid of this that its absence was in itself a kind of happiness.

The danger had dropped—it was behind him there in the great sunny space. So far she was good for what he wanted. She was such a good listener, that she was still listening even after he'd stopped speaking. He'd kept hold of her, pulling her close.

Translation

The peril had receded; it was now behind him, out in the expansive, sunlit space. So far, she was proving useful in the ways he wanted. She was such a good listener, that she continued to listen even after he had fallen silent. He had held onto her, drawing her closer.

Though they weren't walking anymore, his words—if heard by others nearby—might have sounded like those of any tourist admiring a place, talking to a slightly less engaged companion. He'd taken her arm and turned her, so they were facing Saint Mark's again. His eyes scanned the great cathedral as she absentmindedly played with her parasol. Now, however, she made a gesture, turning them finally toward the opposite end of the space.

Translation

Even though they were no longer moving, if anyone close by had been listening, his words would have sounded like those of any tourist admiring a landmark and speaking to a somewhat disinterested partner. He had taken her arm and turned her, so they were facing Saint Mark's once more. His eyes swept across the grand cathedral while she fiddled with her parasol, seemingly lost in thought. But then, she gestured, finally turning them toward the other side of the square.

Only then did she speak: "Please take your hand off my arm." He understood immediately. She had seen, in the shadow of the gallery, the others emerging from where they had been shopping. So they went towards them side by side, and everything was fine. The others had seen them too and waited for them, pleased enough, under one of the arches.

Translation

"Please take your hand off my arm," she said then. He understood at once. She had seen the others, coming out from where they'd been shopping, in the shadow of the gallery. They walked toward them, side by side, and everything was fine. The others had seen them and were waiting, pleased enough, under one of the arches.

He believed that he and Kate—by Kate’s standards—looked perfectly ready, reasonably patient, and properly agreeable. They themselves didn’t suggest anything worse than a couple of children from a hyper-civilized era, making the best of an awkward situation. However, they didn’t hurry—that would have been too much. So he had time to assess how he felt.

Translation

He thought that he and Kate—judging by Kate’s expectations—appeared completely prepared, tolerably composed, and suitably amenable. They, in their own eyes, seemed like nothing more alarming than two kids from an over-refined age, making the best of a difficult circumstance. Still, they didn’t rush—that would have been excessive. So, he had time to consider his feelings.

He felt, very clearly—this was how he faced Mrs. Lowder—that he already possessed, in a sense, what he wanted. There was more to come—everything; he and his companion had not yet settled all the details. Yet what he did possess was real—the fact that she hadn't cast over his understanding the awful shadow of cheap condemnation.

Translation

He felt it very keenly—this was the feeling he had when he was with Mrs. Lowder—that he already had what he wanted, in a way. More was coming—everything; he and his companion hadn’t yet finalized all the arrangements. But what he did have was real—the fact that she hadn’t cast the terrible shadow of cheap disapproval over his judgment.

He'd been so afraid of that, that its absence was, in itself, a kind of joy. The danger had passed—it was behind him there in the bright sunlight. So far, she was good for what he wanted.

Translation

He had been terrified of it, so its absence was a distinct pleasure. The danger was over, left behind in the bright sunlight. As of now, she was beneficial to his aims.

Chapter 13

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
After some people have left, a man remains in his rooms, which are filled with the memory of a woman named Kate, who visited him there once. His plan, which she had accepted, has succeeded. He avoids all visitors but leaves his rooms to go to a palace, where he spends time with another woman, Milly, each day. Kate had required him to remain near Milly. One evening, Milly asks him why he is staying. He does not answer immediately and leaves an hour later. He considers the explanation Kate would have given Milly: that he is staying to show her aunt, Mrs. Lowder, that he can live away from London and Kate. During a later conversation, to explain why he is staying, he tells Milly that he wants to write a book. Milly becomes interested and says he will need his days free for writing. She then reminds him that she and another woman, "Susie," plan to visit him for tea. The man decides he will not allow the visit and asks Milly if it is safe for her to leave her house. Milly reacts negatively to his question, and he realizes he has made a mistake she had previously warned him against. Milly tells him she wants to live and asks why she cannot visit him if doing so will help. He agrees she can come whenever she likes. Milly misinterprets his subsequent change in manner, believing he wants to leave to get away from her. The man says he will not go, and Milly responds that she will not go either, thereby cancelling her visit to his rooms. She brings up his book again, and he says he is not writing one. She asks why he is staying, then answers her own question by stating he has to stay. He agrees. He understands that she believes he is waiting for permission from Kate's aunt. To counter this, he asks if staying for Milly herself isn't reason enough. He then stands up to leave and tells her that as long as he stays, she must think of him as "judging."

She was good enough, as it proved, for him to put to her that evening, and with further ground for it, the next sharpest question that had been on his lips in the morning—which his other preoccupation had then, to his consciousness, crowded out. His opportunity was again made, as befell, by his learning from Mrs. Stringham, on arriving, as usual, with the close of day, at the palace, that Milly must fail them again at dinner, but would to all appearance be able to come down later. He had found Susan Shepherd alone in the great saloon, where even more candles than their friend's large common allowance—she grew daily more splendid; they were all struck with it and chaffed her about it—lighted up the pervasive mystery of Style.

Translation

She was, as it turned out, the right person for him to ask that evening. He had even more reason to do so, because the most pressing question he'd had that morning, which his other concerns had pushed aside, was still on his mind. As it happened, he had another opportunity to ask. He'd learned from Mrs. Stringham, when he arrived at the palace as the day ended, as he usually did, that Milly couldn't make it to dinner again but would apparently be able to join them later. He found Susan Shepherd alone in the grand saloon, where even more candles than usual—she was becoming more radiant every day; they were all amazed by it and teased her about it—illuminated the pervasive mystery of Style.

He had thus five minutes with the good lady before Mrs. Lowder and Kate appeared—minutes illumined indeed to a longer reach than by the number of Milly's candles. It turned out that she was someone he felt comfortable enough with to ask her that evening. And, the next day, he had even more reason to ask the most pressing question he'd been wanting to ask since that morning.

Translation

He thus had five minutes with the woman before Mrs. Lowder and Kate arrived—minutes that shone with a light that exceeded the reach of Milly's many candles. It turned out that she was someone he felt comfortable enough with to ask that evening. And, the next day, he had even more reason to ask the most pressing question he'd been wanting to ask since that morning.

He had been distracted then, which made him forget. Once again, the chance arose when he learned from Mrs. Stringham, upon his usual late-day arrival at the hotel, that Milly couldn't make dinner. However, she was expected to join them later.

Translation

He'd been preoccupied, which made him forget. The opportunity presented itself again when he learned from Mrs. Stringham, upon his customary late-day arrival at the hotel, that Milly couldn't make dinner. Nevertheless, she was expected to join them later.

He found Susan Shepherd alone in the grand salon. More candles than usual—she was becoming increasingly radiant, they all noticed it and teased her about it—lit up the mysterious nature of Style. He had five minutes with the woman before Mrs. Lowder and Kate arrived.

Translation

He found Susan Shepherd alone in the grand salon. More candles than usual—her beauty was intensifying, everyone saw it and joked about it—illuminated the mystique of Style. He had five minutes with her before Mrs. Lowder and Kate showed up.

These were minutes illuminated in a way that the sheer number of Milly's candles couldn't match. "May she come down—ought she if she isn't really up to it?" He had asked that in the wonderment always stirred in him by glimpses—rare as were these—of the inner truth about the girl. There was of course a question of health—it was in the air, it was in the ground he trod, in the food he tasted, in the sounds he heard, it was everywhere.

Translation

These were moments lit in a way that Milly’s multitude of candles couldn’t replicate. "Should she come down—should she even if she's not up to it?" He'd asked that, in the wonder always stirred in him by these glimpses, rare as they were, of the girl's inner reality. Of course, there was the question of her health—it hung in the air, in the earth he walked on, in the food he ate, in the sounds he heard, it was everywhere.

But it was everywhere with the effect of a request to him—to his very delicacy, to the common discretion of others as well as his own—that no allusion to it should be made. There had practically been none, that morning, on her explained non-appearance—the absence of it, as we know, quite monstrous and awkward; and this passage with Mrs. Stringham offered him his first licence to open his eyes. He had gladly enough held them closed; all the more that his doing so performed for his own spirit a useful function.

Translation

But its omnipresence felt like a request addressed to him—to his innate sensitivity, to the general discretion of others as well as his own—that there be no mention of it. There had been virtually none that morning, concerning her explanation for not appearing—the absence of the topic, as we know, being quite monstrous and awkward; and this interaction with Mrs. Stringham gave him his first opportunity to open his eyes. He'd been happy enough to keep them closed; all the more so because doing so served a useful purpose for his own well-being.

If he positively wanted not to be brought up with his nose against Milly's facts, what better proof could he have that his conduct was marked by straightness? It was perhaps pathetic for her, and for himself was perhaps even ridiculous; but he hadn't even the amount of curiosity that he would have had about an ordinary friend. He might have shaken himself at moments to try, for a sort of dry decency, to have it; but that too, it appeared, wouldn't come. In what therefore was the duplicity?

Translation

If he truly didn't want to confront Milly's circumstances head-on, what better evidence could there be that he was acting with integrity? It was possibly sad for her, and perhaps even laughable for him; but he didn't possess the level of curiosity he'd have for an ordinary friend. He might, at times, have made an effort, out of a sense of dry propriety, to feel it; but that, too, seemed impossible. So, where was the deceit?

He was at least sure about his feelings—it being so established that he had none at all. They were all for Kate, without a feather's weight to spare. He was acting for Kate—not, by the deviation of an inch, for her friend. He was accordingly not interested, for had he been interested he would have cared, and had he cared he would have wanted to know.

Translation

He was, at the very least, certain of his emotions—as it had become so clear that he felt none at all. They all belonged to Kate, without a single one to spare. He was acting for Kate—not, by any measure, for her friend. Accordingly, he wasn't interested, because if he had been, he would have cared, and had he cared, he would have wanted to know.

Had he wanted to know he wouldn't have been purely passive, and it was his pure passivity that had to represent his dignity and his honour. His dignity and his honour, at the same time, let us add, fortunately fell short to-night of spoiling his little talk with Susan Shepherd. One glimpse—it was as if she had wished to give him that; and it was as if, for himself, on current terms, he could oblige her by accepting it. She not only permitted, she fairly invited him to open his eyes.

Translation

Had he wanted to know, he wouldn't have remained purely passive, and it was this complete passivity that had to represent his dignity and his honor. His dignity and his honor, let us add, fortunately, fell short tonight of ruining his little conversation with Susan Shepherd. One glimpse—it was as if she had wished to give him that; and it was as if, for his part, he could, on the current terms, oblige her by accepting it. She not only permitted, she practically invited him to open his eyes.

"I'm so glad you're here." It was no answer to his question, but it had for the moment to serve. And the rest was fully to come. "Should she come down—should she if she's not really up to it?" He'd asked that, always surprised by the rare glimpses he got of the girl's inner truth.

Translation

"I'm so glad you're here." It didn't address his question, but it would have to do for now. And the rest was yet to unfold. "Should she come down—should she if she's not really up to it?" He'd asked that, always surprised by the rare glimpses he got of the girl's inner truth.

Of course, there was a question of her health—it hung in the air, it was the ground he walked on, the food he ate, the sounds he heard; it was everywhere. But it was everywhere like a request to him—to his very sensitivity, to everyone's discretion, including his own—that it not be mentioned. There'd been practically nothing said about it that morning, when she didn't appear—a lack of discussion that, as we know, was quite strange and awkward. This conversation with Mrs.

Translation

Her health was a given, an inescapable reality that permeated everything: the air, the ground, his meals, the sounds around him. It was a constant presence, yet it was also a plea—a plea to his own sensitivity, to everyone's tact, including his. That morning, when she didn't come down, there was practically no discussion about it, a glaring, uncomfortable silence. This conversation with Mrs.

Stringham was the first time he'd been allowed to really consider it. He'd been happy to keep his eyes closed; all the more because doing so served a useful purpose for him. If he truly didn't want to be confronted with Milly's situation, what better proof could he have that he was being honest? It might have been sad for her, and perhaps even ridiculous for him, but he didn't even have the curiosity he might have had about a regular friend.

Translation

His conversation with Mrs. Stringham marked the first time he'd been given leave to really think about it. He'd been content to keep his eyes shut; more so because this served him well. If he really didn't want to confront Milly's circumstances, what better evidence could he offer that he was sincere? It might be sad for her, and even silly for him, but he didn't even have the curiosity he might have had toward an ordinary friend.

He may have tried, at times, out of a sense of propriety, to feel something; but that didn't work either. So where was the deception? At least he was sure of his feelings—it being established that he had none at all. All of his feelings were for Kate, and he had nothing left over.

Translation

Perhaps, out of a sense of obligation, he’d attempted to feign emotion from time to time; but that effort yielded nothing. So where was the lie? At least he was certain of his emotional state—which was, in essence, nonexistent. All his capacity for feeling was directed towards Kate, leaving him emotionally depleted.

He was acting for Kate—not, in the slightest, for her friend. So he wasn't interested, because if he had been, he would have cared, and if he'd cared, he would have wanted to know. Had he wanted to know, he wouldn't have been completely passive, and his pure passivity had to represent his dignity and his honor. His dignity and his honor, let's add, thankfully didn't prevent him from enjoying his little chat with Susan Shepherd that night.

Translation

He was putting on an act for Kate, and Kate alone. He had zero interest in her friend. And so, he didn’t care. Because if he’d cared, he would have wanted to know more. If he had wanted to know more, he wouldn't have been completely hands-off. That total detachment, he told himself, was a display of his dignity and honor. And, thankfully, his dignity and honor didn’t keep him from enjoying his little conversation with Susan Shepherd that night.

One glimpse—it was as if she'd wanted to give him that, and as if, for his part, he could agree to it. She not only permitted him to open his eyes, she practically invited it. "I'm so glad you're here." It wasn't an answer to his question, but it had to do. And the rest would come later.

Translation

One look—it was as if she'd intended to offer that to him, and as if he could accept it. She didn't just allow him to look; she practically asked him to. "I'm so glad you're here." It wasn't an answer to what he'd asked, but it would have to do. The rest would come later.

He smiled at her and presently found himself, as a kind of consequence of communion with her, talking her own language. "It's a very wonderful experience." "Well"—and her raised face shone up at him—"that's all I want you to feel about it. If I weren't afraid," she added, "there are things I should like to say to you."

Translation

He smiled at her and soon found himself, as a result of being with her, speaking her language. "It's a very wonderful experience." "Well"—and her face, turned up towards him, glowed—"that's all I want you to feel about it. If I weren't afraid," she added, "there are things I'd like to say to you."

"And what are you afraid of, please?" he encouragingly asked. "Of other things that I may possibly spoil. Besides, I don't, you know, seem to have the chance. You're always, you know, with her."

Translation

"And what are you afraid of, if you don't mind me asking?" he inquired, trying to be encouraging. "Of other things that I might ruin. Besides, I don't seem to get the opportunity, you know. You're always with her."

He was strangely supported, it struck him, in his fixed smile; which was the more fixed as he felt in these last words an exact description of his course. It was an odd thing to have come to, but he was always with her. "Ah," he none the less smiled, "I'm not with her now." He smiled at her and soon found himself, as a result of being with her, speaking like she did.

Translation

He found himself strangely buoyed by his steady smile. It was more steady because he recognized in those last words a perfect summary of his routine. It was odd, but he was always with her. "Ah," he smiled, even so, "I'm not with her now." He smiled at her, and then, because he was with her, he found himself speaking in her manner.

"It's a really amazing experience." "Well"—and her face, looking up at him, glowed—"that's all I want you to think about it. If I weren't worried," she added, "there are things I'd like to tell you." "And what are you worried about, exactly?" he asked, encouragingly.

Translation

"It's a truly amazing experience." "Well"—and her face, looking up at him, glowed—"that's the only thing I want you to think about. If I weren't worried," she added, "there are things I'd like to tell you." "And what exactly are you worried about?" he asked, encouragingly.

"Other things that I might ruin, possibly. Also, I don't seem to get the opportunity, you know. You're always with her." He was oddly comforted, he realized, by his unchanging smile.

Translation

"Other things I could mess up, maybe. Plus, I never get the chance, you know? You're always with her." He found comfort, strangely, in the fact that his smile never changed.

The smile was more fixed because he felt those last words described his situation perfectly. It was strange that things had come to this, but he was always with her. "Ah," he still smiled, "I'm not with her now." "No—and I'm so glad, since I get this from it.

Translation

The smile felt more rigid, because he knew those last words described his life exactly. It was odd that things had ended up like this, but he was always with her. "Ah," he said, still smiling, "I'm not with her now." "No—and I'm so glad, because I get this out of it."

She's ever so much better." "Better? Then she has been worse?" Mrs.

Translation

"She's much better." "Better? So she was sick?" Mrs.

Stringham waited. "She has been marvellous—that's what she has been. She is marvellous. But she's really better."

Translation

Stringham paused. "She has been wonderful—that's what she's been. She is wonderful. But she is truly better now."

"Oh then if she's really better—!" But he checked himself, wanting only to be easy about it and above all not to appear engaged to the point of mystification. "We shall miss her the more at dinner." Susan Shepherd, however, was all there for him. "She's keeping herself.

Translation

You'll see. You'll not really need to miss anything. There's to be a little party." "Ah I do see—by this aggravated grandeur."
