"You'll see. You won't

really have to miss a thing. There's a small

party planned." "Ah, I understand—through this exaggerated show."

"Well, it is lovely, isn't it? I want the whole thing. She's lodged for the first time as she ought, from her type, to be; and doing it—I mean bringing out all the glory of the place—makes her really happy. It's a Veronese picture, as near as can be—with me as the inevitable dwarf, the small blackamoor, put into a corner of the foreground for effect.

Translation

"Yes, it is wonderful, isn't it? I want everything about it. She's settled in, finally, the way she was always meant to, given who she is. And doing this—I mean, bringing out all the best parts of the place—makes her truly happy. It's a Veronese painting, as close as you can get—with me as the inevitable dwarf, the small black figure, relegated to the corner of the foreground for show."

If I only had a hawk or a hound or something of that sort I should do the scene more honour. The old housekeeper, the woman in charge here, has a big red cockatoo that I might borrow and perch on my thumb for the evening." These explanations and sundry others Mrs. Stringham gave, though not all with the result of making him feel that the picture closed him in. What part was there for him, with his attitude that lacked the highest style, in a composition in which everything else would have it?

Translation

"If only I had a hawk, or a hound, or something like that, I could do this scene justice. The old housekeeper, the one who runs the place, has a big red cockatoo I could borrow and perch on my thumb for the evening." Mrs. Stringham offered these explanations and a few others, though they didn't entirely make him feel included in the painting. What role could he possibly play, with his decidedly un-stylish attitude, in a composition where everything else was just so?

"They won't, however, be at dinner, the few people she expects—they come round afterwards from their respective hotels; and Sir Luke Strett and his niece, the principal ones, will have arrived from London but an hour or two ago. It's for him she has wanted to do something—to let it begin at once. We shall see more of him, because she likes him; and I'm so glad—she'll be glad too—that you're to see him." The good lady, in connexion with it, was urgent, was almost unnaturally bright. "So I greatly hope—!" But her hope fairly lost itself in the wide light of her cheer.

Translation

However, the few guests she's expecting won't be joining them for dinner. They'll arrive later, straight from their hotels. Sir Luke Strett and his niece, the most important guests, will have just arrived from London an hour or two earlier. She's been eager to do this, to get it started, for his sake. We'll see more of him because she likes him, and I'm so glad—and she'll be too—that you'll get to meet him. The kind woman was animated, almost unnaturally cheerful as she spoke. "I really hope—!" But her hope was swallowed up in her bright smile.

"No—and I'm very glad, because I get a benefit from it. She's much better." "Better? Then she was worse before?"

Translation

"No—and I'm very glad, because it works to my advantage. She's doing much better." "Better? So she was worse before?"

Mrs. Stringham paused. "She was amazing—that's what she was. She is amazing.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham hesitated. "She was astonishing—that's what she was. She is astonishing."

But she really is better." "Oh, if she's really better—!" But he stopped himself, wanting only to be relaxed about it and above all, not to seem overly interested and confused. "We'll miss her at dinner." However, Susan Shepherd was entirely focused on him.

Translation

"But she's truly doing better." "Oh, if she's really better—!" But he cut himself off, wanting to be casual about it and, above all, not appear too intrigued or bewildered. "We'll miss her at dinner." However, Susan Shepherd's attention was completely fixed on him.

"She's taking care of herself. You'll see. You won't miss anything, really. There's going to be a small party."

Translation

"She's looking after herself. You'll see. You really won't miss out on anything. There's going to be a little party."

"Oh, I see—because of this over-the-top grandeur." "Well, it's lovely, isn't it? I want the whole thing. For the first time, she's staying somewhere that suits her personality; and doing this—meaning, bringing out all the glory of the place—makes her truly happy.

Translation

"Ah, I understand—it's this excessive opulence, then." "Well, it's beautiful, don't you think? I want it all. For once, she's in a place that fits her; and by doing this—that is, showcasing all the splendor of the place—she's genuinely happy."

It's like a Veronese painting, as close as can be—with me as the inevitable dwarf, the small black servant, placed in a corner of the foreground for effect. If I only had a hawk or a hound or something like that, I'd fit the scene better. The old housekeeper, the woman in charge here, has a big red cockatoo that I could borrow and perch on my thumb for the evening." Mrs. Stringham gave these and other explanations, though not all of them made him feel included in the picture.

Translation

It’s like a Veronese painting, almost exactly—with me as the unavoidable dwarf, the small black servant, positioned in the front corner for effect. If I just had a hawk or a hound or something, I’d fit in better. The old housekeeper, the woman who runs things here, has a big red cockatoo I could borrow and perch on my thumb for the evening.” Mrs. Stringham gave these and other explanations, though not all of them made him feel part of the picture.

What part was there for him, with his attitude that lacked the necessary elegance, in a composition where everything else possessed it? "They won't be at dinner, though, the few people she's expecting—they're coming later from their hotels; and Sir Luke Strett and his niece, the most important ones, will have arrived from London only an hour or two ago. She wanted to do something for him—to start things right away. We'll see more of him, because she likes him; and I'm so glad—she'll be glad too—that you'll get to see him." The kind lady, talking about it, was very enthusiastic, almost unnaturally cheerful.

Translation

What role was there for him, given his own lack of the required sophistication, in a scene where everything else was so refined? “They won’t be at dinner, though, the few guests she’s expecting—they’re coming later from their hotels; and Sir Luke Strett and his niece, the most important ones, will have just arrived from London an hour or two ago. She wanted to do something for him—to get things started right away. We'll see more of him, because she likes him; and I'm so glad—she’ll be glad too—that you’ll get to see him.” The kind lady was very enthusiastic while talking about it, almost unnaturally cheerful.

"So I really hope—!" But her hope was simply expressed in the radiant light of her smile. He considered a little this appearance, while she let him, he thought, into still more knowledge than she uttered. "What is it you hope?" "Well, that you'll stay on."

Translation

"So I really hope—!" But her hope was simply expressed in the radiant light of her smile. He considered this appearance for a moment, while she, he thought, allowed him to gain even more knowledge than she spoke aloud. "What is it you hope?" "Well, that you'll stay on."

"Do you mean after dinner?" She meant, he seemed to feel, so much that he could scarce tell where it ended or began. "Oh that, of course. Why we're to have music—beautiful instruments and songs; and not Tasso declaimed as in the guide-books either. She has arranged it—or at least I have.

Translation

"Are you asking if I'll stay after dinner?" Her implication, he surmised, was so vast that he struggled to identify its boundaries. "Of course, regarding that. We'll have music—gorgeous instruments and songs; and not just Tasso recited, as the guidebooks would have it. She's arranged it—or at least, I have."

That is Eugenio has. Besides, you're in the picture." "Oh—I!" said Densher almost with the gravity of a real protest. "You'll be the grand young man who surpasses the others and holds up his head and the wine-cup.

Translation

That is, Eugenio arranged it. Besides, you're involved." "Oh—me!" said Densher, almost with the severity of a genuine objection. "You'll be the distinguished young man who outshines everyone else, holding his head high and raising his glass."

What we hope," Mrs. Stringham pursued, "is that you'll be faithful to us—that you've not come for a mere foolish few days." He contemplated her expression for a moment, and she, he felt, communicated even more than she was saying. "What are you hoping for?"

Translation

"What we hope," Mrs. Stringham continued, "is that you'll remain loyal to us—that you haven't arrived for just a fleeting, silly visit." He considered her face for a moment, and he sensed she was conveying more than her words. "What, precisely, are you hoping for?"

"Well, that you'll stay." "Do you mean after dinner?" He felt that she implied so much he could hardly grasp its scope. "Of course, that. We'll have music—beautiful instruments and songs; and not just Tasso recited, as in the guidebooks.

Translation

"Well, that you'll stay." "Do you mean after dinner?" He felt that her implication was so dense, he could barely fathom its extent. "Of course, that. We'll have music—beautiful instruments and songs; and not just Tasso recited, as in the guidebooks.

She arranged it—or at least I did. Or, rather, Eugenio did. And you’re part of it." "Me!" Densher said, almost with genuine disbelief.

Translation

"She arranged it—or at least I did. Or, rather, Eugenio did. And you're part of it." "Me!" Densher said, almost with genuine disbelief.

"You'll be the distinguished young man who outshines everyone else, holding his head high with his wine glass. What we're hoping," Mrs. Stringham continued, "is that you'll stay with us—that you haven’t just come for a short, silly visit." Densher's more private and particular shabby realities turned, without comfort, he was conscious, at this touch, in the artificial repose he had in his anxiety about them but half-managed to induce.

Translation

"You'll be the distinguished young man who outshines everyone else, holding his head high with his wine glass. What we're hoping," Mrs. Stringham continued, "is that you'll stay with us—that you haven’t just come for a short, silly visit." Densher's more private and particular shabby realities turned, without comfort, he was conscious, at this touch, in the artificial repose he had in his anxiety about them but half-managed to induce.

The way smooth ladies, travelling for their pleasure and housed in Veronese pictures, talked to plain embarrassed working-men, engaged in an unprecedented sacrifice of time and of the opportunity for modest acquisition! The things they took for granted and the general misery of explaining! He couldn't tell them how he had tried to work, how it was partly what he had moved into rooms for, only to find himself, almost for the first time in his life, stricken and sterile; because that would give them a false view of the source of his restlessness, if not of the degree of it. It would operate, indirectly perhaps, but infallibly, to add to that weight as of expected performance which these very moments with Mrs.

Translation

The way these polished women, traveling for leisure and living in settings that could have been painted by Veronese, spoke to the awkward, ordinary working-class men, who were making an unprecedented sacrifice of their time and the chance to earn a decent living! The things they assumed and the sheer misery of having to explain himself! He couldn’t tell them how he had tried to work, how that was partly why he had moved into those rooms, only to find himself, nearly for the first time in his life, listless and unproductive; because that would give them a mistaken idea of the source of his agitation, if not the extent of it. It would work, perhaps indirectly, but surely, to add to that pressure, that expectation of success, that these very moments with Mrs.

Stringham caused more and more to settle on his heart. He had incurred it, the expectation of performance; the thing was done, and there was no use talking; again, again the cold breath of it was in the air. So there he was. And at best he floundered.

Translation

Stringham’s presence only added to the weight on his heart. He’d brought it on himself, the expectation that he would deliver; it was a done deal, and there was no use dwelling on it; once more, the chilling dread of it hung in the air. So there he was, stuck. And at the very best, he was flailing.

"I'm afraid you won't understand when I say I've very tiresome things to consider. Botherations, necessities at home. The pinch, the pressure in London." Densher's personal, less glamorous problems resurfaced, and he realized he found no solace in them.

Translation

"I'm afraid you won't understand," he said, "when I tell you I'm dealing with some tedious matters. Annoyances, obligations at home. The financial strain, the stress of things in London." Densher's own, less appealing problems came back to him, and he realized he took no comfort in them.

His anxiety over them had only partially allowed him to relax. He was aware of this. He thought about the situation: these sophisticated women, vacationing and surrounded by beauty, spoke to ordinary, uncomfortable working-class men who were making an extraordinary sacrifice of their time and the chance to earn a modest living. The assumptions they made, and the endless difficulties of explaining things!

Translation

The tension they caused had only somewhat eased his mind. He knew this to be true. He considered the scenario: these elegant women on holiday, surrounded by beauty, addressed plain, uneasy working-class men making a remarkable sacrifice of their time and the possibility of earning a small income. The presumptions they held, and the persistent problems of making them understand!

He couldn't tell them how he'd tried to work, how he'd moved into rooms specifically for that purpose, only to find himself, for the first time in his life, feeling blocked and unproductive. That would give them a mistaken idea about the reason for his restlessness, if not the intensity of it. It would, indirectly but surely, add to the feeling of needing to perform, which his conversations with Mrs. Stringham made more and more pressing.

Translation

He couldn't reveal his attempts at labor, his relocation to spaces explicitly designed for work, only to encounter a novel sensation: an inability to produce. Such information would misrepresent the source of his agitation, if not its severity. It would, subtly but definitely, exacerbate the pressure to achieve, a pressure that his discussions with Mrs. Stringham were increasingly amplifying.

He had created this need to perform; it was a done deal, and there was no point in discussing it. Again, he felt the chilling impact of it. And so, here he was. He was struggling.

Translation

He'd brought this on himself; it was settled, and further discussion was pointless. Again, he felt the cold grip of it. And so, here he was. He was failing.

"I'm afraid you won't understand when I say I have annoying things to worry about. Troubles, necessities at home. The financial strain, the pressures in London." But she understood in perfection; she rose to the pinch and the pressure and showed how they had been her own very element.

Translation

"I'm afraid you won't understand when I tell you I have irritating things to worry about. Troubles, obligations at home. The financial stress, the pressures of London." But she understood perfectly; she rose to the challenge and the pressure, and showed how they had been her very essence.

"Oh the daily task and the daily wage, the golden guerdon or reward? No one knows better than I how they haunt one in the flight of the precious deceiving days. Aren't they just what I myself have given up? I've given up all to follow her.

Translation

"The daily grind, the daily paycheck, the golden prize or reward? No one understands better than I how they torment you as precious, fleeting days slip by. Aren't those the very things I've already abandoned? I've given up everything to follow her."

I wish you could feel as I do. And can't you," she asked, "write about Venice?" He very nearly wished, for the minute, that he could feel as she did; and he smiled for her kindly. "Do you write about Venice?"

Translation

I wish you could feel this way too. And, can't you," she asked, "write about Venice?" He almost wished, at that moment, that he could feel as she did; and he smiled at her warmly. "Do you write about Venice?"

"No; but I would—oh wouldn't I?—if I hadn't so completely given up. She's, you know, my princess, and to one's princess—" She fully understood. She rose to the challenge and revealed how it was something she thrived in.

Translation

"No, but I wish I could—oh, how I wish I could—if I hadn't given up completely. She's, you know, my princess, and to one's princess—" She understood perfectly. She rose to the challenge and showed how it was something she excelled at.

"Oh, the everyday work and the daily pay, the reward? No one knows better than me how they occupy your thoughts as the precious days slip by. Aren't those things what I've given up? I gave up everything to follow her.

Translation

"The grind, the paycheck, the prize... I know better than anyone how those things consume your mind while the good times vanish. Aren't those the very things I abandoned? I sacrificed everything to be with her."

I wish you could feel the same way. And can't you write about Venice?" He almost wished he could feel the same way for a moment, and he smiled at her kindly. "Do you write about Venice?"

Translation

I wish you felt the same. And couldn't you write about Venice?" He almost wanted to feel the same for a moment, and he smiled at her kindly. "Do you write about Venice?"

"No, but I would—oh, wouldn't I?—if I hadn't completely given up everything. She's, you know, my princess, and for one's princess—" "One makes the whole sacrifice?" "Precisely.

Translation

"No, but I would—oh, wouldn't I?—if I hadn't given everything up. She's, you know, my princess, and for one's princess—" "One makes the whole sacrifice?" "Precisely."

There you are!" It pressed on him with this that never had a man been in so many places at once. "I quite understand that she's yours. Only you see she's not mine." He felt he could somehow, for honesty, risk that, as he had the moral certainty she wouldn't repeat it and least of all to Mrs.

Translation

"There you are!" The idea seized him, the idea that no man had ever been in so many places at the same time. "I fully understand that she belongs to you. Only, you see, she isn't mine." He felt he could, for the sake of honesty, risk saying that, since he was morally certain she wouldn't repeat it, especially not to Mrs.

Lowder, who would find in it a disturbing implication. This was part of what he liked in the good lady, that she didn't repeat, and also that she gave him a delicate sense of her shyly wishing him to know it. That was in itself a hint of possibilities between them, of a relation, beneficent and elastic for him, which wouldn't engage him further than he could see. Yet even as he afresh made this out he felt how strange it all was.

Translation

Lowder, who would find a disturbing implication in it. This was part of what he appreciated about the good lady: that she didn't repeat things, and also that she gave him a delicate sense of her shyly wanting him to know it. That was in itself a hint of possibilities between them, of a relationship, beneficial and flexible for him, which wouldn't commit him further than he could see. Yet even as he considered this again, he felt how strange it all was.

She wanted, Susan Shepherd then, as appeared, the same thing Kate wanted, only wanted it, as still further appeared, in so different a way and from a motive so different, even though scarce less deep. Then Mrs. Lowder wanted, by so odd an evolution of her exuberance, exactly what each of the others did; and he was between them all, he was in the midst. Such perceptions made occasions—well, occasions for fairly wondering if it mightn't be best just to consent, luxuriously, to be the ass the whole thing involved.

Translation

Susan Shepherd, it seemed, wanted the same thing Kate did. However, she wanted it in a way so different, and for a motive so different, despite its near equal depth. Then Mrs. Lowder, through her odd, exuberant behavior, wanted precisely what the others wanted. He was caught between them all, in the middle. Such realizations provided opportunities—well, opportunities to wonder if it might be best to simply consent, luxuriously, to be the fool in the whole affair.

Trying not to be and yet keeping in it was of the two things the more asinine. He was glad there was no male witness; it was a circle of petticoats; he shouldn't have liked a man to see him. He only had for a moment a sharp thought of Sir Luke Strett, the great master of the knife whom Kate in London had spoken of Milly as in commerce with, and whose renewed intervention at such a distance, just announced to him, required some accounting for. He had a vision of great London surgeons—if this one was a surgeon—as incisive all round; so that he should perhaps after all not wholly escape the ironic attention of his own sex.

Translation

To try not to be, while still remaining involved, was the more idiotic of the two options. He was relieved there were no male witnesses. The situation was contained within a circle of women, and he wouldn't have wanted a man to see him. He briefly thought of Sir Luke Strett, the renowned surgeon whom Kate had mentioned in London, the one she'd said was in contact with Milly. Strett's renewed involvement, announced to him from a distance, needed explanation. He imagined those London surgeons—if this one was indeed a surgeon—as being relentlessly critical, so that he might not, in the end, entirely avoid the mocking judgment of his own gender.

The most he might be able to do was not to care; while he was trying not to he could take that in. It was a train, however, that brought up the vision of Lord Mark as well. Lord Mark had caught him twice in the fact—the fact of his absurd posture; and that made a second male. But it was comparatively easy not to mind Lord Mark.

Translation

The most he could manage was not to care. While he was trying not to care, he could accept that. However, that line of thought brought up the image of Lord Mark as well. Lord Mark had caught him in the act twice—the act of his absurd posture—which made a second man. But it was comparatively easy not to mind Lord Mark.

"So, the complete sacrifice?" "Exactly. That's the situation!" It hit him that he, of all people, was somehow in multiple places at once.

Translation

"So, a total loss?" "Precisely. That's the deal!" It struck him that he, of all people, was somehow in multiple places simultaneously.

"I completely understand that she belongs to you. But you see, she doesn't belong to me." He felt he could, for the sake of honesty, take that risk, because he was sure she wouldn't repeat it, especially not to Mrs. Lowder, who might find it problematic. This was part of what he liked about the woman—that she kept things to herself and also subtly let him know that she wished him to know that.

Translation

"I know she's yours. But, she's not mine." He figured he could be open about it, since he knew she wouldn't blab, especially not to Mrs. Lowder, who'd probably make a fuss. That was one of the things he liked about her: she kept secrets and subtly let him know she wanted him to know she was doing that.

That was, in itself, a suggestion of possibilities between them, a relationship, beneficial and flexible for him, that wouldn't commit him beyond what he could handle. Yet even as he considered this again, he realized how odd it all was. Susan Shepherd wanted, it seemed, the same thing Kate wanted, only she wanted it in a different way and for a different reason, although the reason was almost as significant. And then Mrs.

Translation

That alone hinted at the potential between them, a relationship, convenient and adaptable for him, that wouldn't require more than he could offer. But even as he considered this again, he understood how strange it all was. Susan Shepherd appeared to want the same thing Kate wanted, only she wanted it in a different manner and for a different purpose, though the purpose was almost as important. And then Mrs.

Lowder, through such a peculiar display of her enthusiasm, wanted the exact same thing as the others. He was caught in the middle. These realizations made him wonder if it might be best to just give in, to luxuriously embrace being the fool in all of this. Trying not to be the fool while still participating was, between the two, the more foolish option.

Translation

Lowder, with her strange exuberance, desired the exact same outcome. He was trapped. These thoughts made him consider surrendering, to indulge in the role of the fool. Trying to avoid being the fool while still involved was, of the two, the more foolish approach.

He was glad there wasn't a man around; it was a gathering of women. He wouldn't have wanted a man to see him. He briefly thought of Sir Luke Strett, the expert surgeon Kate had mentioned to Milly in London, whose renewed involvement at this distance, just announced to him, needed an explanation. He imagined these great London surgeons—if this one was a surgeon—as being sharp and observant, so that he might not escape the ironic scrutiny of his own gender.

Translation

He was relieved there were only women present. He wouldn't have wanted a man to witness this. He briefly considered Sir Luke Strett, the celebrated surgeon Kate had mentioned to Milly in London, whose renewed presence, communicated to him from afar, required an explanation. He pictured these prominent London surgeons—assuming this one was indeed a surgeon—as being astute and perceptive, so he wouldn't escape the mocking examination of his own sex.

The most he could do might be not to care; and while he was trying not to care, he could at least accept that. However, that thought also brought up the image of Lord Mark. Lord Mark had caught him twice in the act—the act of his absurd situation; and that made a second man. But it was relatively easy not to care about Lord Mark.

Translation

The best he could manage was indifference; and while he was striving for indifference, he could at least acknowledge it. But that line of thinking conjured the specter of Lord Mark. Lord Mark had twice caught him in the midst of it—the absurdity of his predicament; and that made a second man. Still, it was relatively easy not to care about Lord Mark.

His companion had before this taken him up, and in a tone to confirm her discretion, on the matter of Milly's not being his princess. "Of course she's not. You must do something first." Densher gave it his thought.

Translation

His companion had previously addressed him on this, in a manner that seemed to endorse her good sense, regarding Milly's not being his princess. "Of course she isn't. You have to do something first." Densher considered this.

"Wouldn't it be rather she who must?" It had more than he intended the effect of bringing her to a stand. "I see. No doubt, if one takes it so." Her cheer was for the time in eclipse, and she looked over the place, avoiding his eyes, as in the wonder of what Milly could do.

Translation

"Wouldn't it be rather she who must?" The remark had a greater impact than he intended, causing her to stop. "I see. No doubt, if one looks at it that way."

Her good spirits dimmed, and she surveyed the scene, avoiding his gaze, as if considering what Milly might accomplish.

"And yet she has wanted to be kind." It made him on the spot feel a brute. "Of course she has. No one could be more charming.

Translation

"And yet she's wanted to be kind." He felt like a brute the instant he said it. "Of course she has. No one could be more charming."

She has treated me as if I were somebody. Call her my hostess as I've never had nor imagined a hostess, and I'm with you altogether. Of course," he added in the right spirit for her, "I do see that it's quite court life." Before this conversation, his companion had already addressed him, in a way that signaled her good judgment, about the idea of Milly not being his true love.

Translation

She's treated me like I matter. She's been a hostess to me, the best I've ever known or even dreamed of. And I completely agree with you. Of course," he added, trying to sound like her, "I realize this is like living at court." Before this conversation, his companion had already, in a way that showed her good sense, brought up the possibility of Milly not being his true love.

“Of course she isn’t. You have to achieve something first.” Densher considered this. “Wouldn’t it be more accurate to say that she has to do something?”

Translation

"Of course not. You have to accomplish something first." Densher thought about it. "Wouldn't it be more precise to say that she has to act?"

His words caused her to pause more than he intended. "I see. I suppose that's true, if you look at it that way." Her enthusiasm seemed to wane for the moment, and she looked around, avoiding his gaze, as if considering what Milly was capable of. “Even so, she’s wanted to be kind.”

Translation

His words made her hesitate longer than he'd expected. "I understand. I guess that's accurate, when you think about it." Her excitement seemed to dim for a moment. She looked around, avoiding his eyes, as if evaluating Milly's abilities. "Nevertheless, she has wanted to be kind."

He immediately felt awful. "Absolutely. No one could be more delightful. She’s treated me as if I actually matter.

Translation

He felt terrible at once. "Completely. No one could be more charming. She's treated me like I actually matter."

She’s been the most gracious hostess I could have ever hoped for. And yes," he added, trying to reassure her, "I understand that this is all like a royal court." She promptly showed how this was almost all she wanted of him. "That's all I mean, if you understand it of such a court as never was: one of the courts of heaven, the court of a reigning seraph, a sort of a vice-queen of an angel.

Translation

She's been the most wonderful host. And yes," he added, attempting to console her, "I understand this is all very formal." She immediately showed him that was almost all she wanted from him. "That is what I mean, if you understand, of such a court as never existed: a court of heaven, a court of a ruling angel, a kind of vice-queen of an angel.

That will do perfectly." "Oh well then I grant it. Only court life as a general thing, you know," he observed, "isn't supposed to pay." "Yes, one has read; but this is beyond any book.

Translation

"That will be perfect." "Oh, alright then, I concede. Though court life in general, you know," he observed, "isn't exactly known for being lucrative." "Yes, one has read as much; but this exceeds anything in books."

That's just the beauty here; it's why she's the great and only princess. With her, at her court," said Mrs. Stringham, "it does pay." Then as if she had quite settled it for him: "You'll see for yourself." She immediately demonstrated that this was practically everything she desired from him.

Translation

That's precisely the advantage here; it's the reason she's the one, the only princess. With her, at her court," Mrs. Stringham said, "it is rewarding." Then, as if she'd completely resolved the matter for him: "You'll see for yourself." She proceeded to show that this was virtually all she expected from him.

"That's precisely what I mean, assuming you can grasp it: a court unlike any other, like the courts of heaven, the court of a ruling angel, a kind of deputy to an angel. That will work perfectly." "Right, I understand. But generally speaking, you know," he remarked, "court life isn't expected to be rewarding."

Translation

"That's exactly my point, if you follow me: a court unlike anything else, like the courts of heaven, the court of a governing angel, an angel's representative. It'll be perfect." "Yes, I see. But usually," he noted, "court life isn't supposed to be so fulfilling."

"Indeed, one reads about that; but this surpasses any book. That's the extraordinary part; it's why she's the ultimate princess. With her, at her court," Mrs. Stringham said, "it *is* rewarding." Then, as if she had completely convinced him, "You'll witness it firsthand."

Translation

"That's true, you read about it in stories, but this is beyond anything you can imagine. That's the amazing thing about it; that's what makes her the best kind of princess. With her, at her court," Mrs. Stringham said, "it actually *is* fulfilling." Then, as though she'd successfully changed his mind, "You'll see it for yourself."

He waited a moment, but said nothing to discourage her. "I think you were right just now. One must do something first." "Well, you've done something."

Translation

He paused, but didn't interrupt her. "I think you're right. You have to do something first." "Well, you have."

"No—I don't see that. I can do more." Oh well, she seemed to say, if he would have it so! "You can do everything, you know."

Translation

"No—I don't agree. I can do more." Oh well, she seemed to concede, if that's what he wanted! "You can do absolutely anything, you know."

"Everything" was rather too much for him to take up gravely, and he modestly let it alone, speaking the next moment, to avert fatuity, of a different but a related matter. "Why has she sent for Sir Luke Strett if, as you tell me, she's so much better?" "She hasn't sent. He has come of himself," Mrs.

Translation

"Everything" was too grand for him to accept with seriousness, so he humbly ignored it, and then, to avoid sounding foolish, shifted to a different but connected topic. "Why did she call for Sir Luke Strett if, as you say, she's improved so much?" "She didn't call him. He came on his own," Mrs.

Stringham explained. "He has wanted to come." "Isn't that rather worse then—if it means he mayn't be easy?" He paused, but didn't say anything to dissuade her.

Translation

Stringham clarified. "He's been wanting to visit." "Isn't that actually a worse situation—if it implies he's not feeling well?" He hesitated, but offered no objection.

"I believe you were right earlier. One has to initiate some action." "Well, you've done something." "No—I don't agree.

Translation

"I think you were correct earlier. You have to take some kind of initiative." "Well, you have." "No—I don't think so."

I can do more." Oh, fine, she seemed to indicate, if he insisted! "You could accomplish anything, you know." "Anything" was too much for him to respond to seriously, so he avoided the topic.

Translation

"I can do more." Oh, great, she seemed to imply, if he was going to be that way! "You could achieve anything, you know." "Anything" was too grand for him to take seriously, so he steered clear of the idea.

To avoid sounding conceited, he changed the subject to a similar one. "Why has she summoned Sir Luke Strett if, as you mentioned, she's improving?" "She didn't summon him. He came on his own," Mrs.

Translation

To sidestep vanity, he shifted the topic slightly. "Why did she call for Sir Luke Strett, if she's getting better, as you said?" "She didn't. He arrived on his own," Mrs.

Stringham clarified. "He wanted to come." "Isn't that even more troubling then—if it implies he's still worried?" "He was coming, from the first, for his holiday.

Translation

Stringham explained. "He wanted to be here." "Isn't that even more disturbing then—if it means he's still concerned?" "He was planning to come, from the start, for his vacation.

She has known that these several weeks." After which Mrs. Stringham added: "You can make him easy." "I can?" he candidly wondered. It was truly the circle of petticoats.

Translation

"She's been aware of it for weeks." After this, Mrs. Stringham added, "You can make him feel better." "I can?" he wondered honestly. It was truly a whirlwind of women.

"What have I to do with it for a man like that?" "How do you know," said his friend, "what he's like? He's not like any one you've ever seen. He's a great beneficent being."

Translation

"What do I have to do with it, me and a guy like that?"

"How do you know what he's like?" his friend asked. "He's not like anyone you've ever met. He's a great, benevolent person."

"Ah then he can do without me. I've no call, as an outsider, to meddle." "Tell him, all the same," Mrs. Stringham urged, "what you think."

Translation

"Well, he can manage without my help. It's not my place to interfere." "Still, tell him what you think," Mrs. Stringham urged.

"What I think of Miss Theale?" Densher stared. It was, as they said, a large order. But he found the right note. "It's none of his business."

Translation

"What do I think of Miss Theale?" Densher asked, his expression blank. It was, as they put it, a tall order. But he managed to find the right tone. "It's none of his concern."

He was expected; he was coming for his vacation. She had known that for weeks. After that, Mrs. Stringham said, "You can put his mind at ease."

Translation

He was expected; he was coming for his holiday. She'd known that for weeks. Then, Mrs. Stringham said, "You can reassure him."

"I can?" he asked, surprised. The circle of women's skirts surrounded him. "What possible relevance could I have for a man like that?" "How do you know," his friend said, "what he's like?

Translation

"I can?" he asked, surprised. The circle of women's skirts surrounded him. "What possible relevance could I have for a man like that?" "How do you know," his friend said, "what he's like?"

He's not like anyone you've ever met. He's a great, benevolent person." "Well then, he can manage without me. I have no reason, as an outsider, to interfere."

Translation

"He's not like anyone you've ever met. He's a great, benevolent person." "Well then, he can manage without me. I have no reason, as an outsider, to interfere."

"Tell him, regardless," Mrs. Stringham insisted, "what you think." "What I think of Miss Theale?" Densher was taken aback. It was, as they said, a lot to ask.

Translation

"Tell him anyway," Mrs. Stringham insisted, "what you believe." Densher was surprised. "What I believe about Miss Theale?" It was, as the saying went, a heavy request.

But he found the right tone. "It's none of his concern." It did seem a moment for Mrs. Stringham too the right note.

Translation

But he found the right tone. "It's none of his business." It did seem a moment for Mrs. Stringham to find the right note too.

She fixed him at least with an expression still bright, but searching, that showed almost to excess what she saw in it; though what this might be he was not to make out till afterwards. "Say that to him then. Anything will do for him as a means of getting at you." "And why should he get at me?"

Translation

She held him with an expression that was still bright, but also searching. It revealed almost too much of what she was seeing, though he wouldn't understand what that was until later. "Tell him that then. Anything will work for him, as a way to get to you." "And why should he get to me?"

"Give him a chance to. Let him talk to you. Then you'll see." All of which, on Mrs.

Translation

Pebmarsh's part, was said without any noticeable change in the quality of her voice. It was soft, but not necessarily gentle. Firm, but not unkind. It simply was, and that was that. "Now, is there anything else I can do for you, or is that all?"

Stringham's part, sharpened his sense of immersion in an element rather more strangely than agreeably warm—a sense that was moreover, during the next two or three hours, to be fed to satiety by several other impressions. Milly came down after dinner, half a dozen friends—objects of interest mainly, it appeared, to the ladies of Lancaster Gate—having by that time arrived; and with this call on her attention, the further call of her musicians ushered by Eugenio, but personally and separately welcomed, and the supreme opportunity offered in the arrival of the great doctor, who came last of all, he felt her diffuse in wide warm waves the spell of a general, a beatific mildness. There was a deeper depth of it, doubtless, for some than for others; what he in particular knew of it was that he seemed to stand in it up to his neck. He moved about in it and it made no plash; he floated, he noiselessly swam in it, and they were all together, for that matter, like fishes in a crystal pool.

Translation

Stringham's experience of this, rather oddly, intensified his feeling of being enveloped in something that was more strange than pleasantly warm—a feeling that, over the next few hours, several other impressions would fully satisfy. Milly joined them after dinner, and by then, half a dozen friends had arrived, primarily of interest, it seemed, to the women from Lancaster Gate. With her attention claimed by them, and then by the musicians summoned by Eugenio, individually and privately welcomed, and the ultimate opportunity presented by the arrival of the great doctor, who came last of all, Stringham felt Milly spread the magic of a general, beatific gentleness in broad, warm waves. Undoubtedly, it held a deeper significance for some than for others. What he knew of it, specifically, was that he seemed to be submerged up to his neck. He moved within it, and it made no splash; he floated, he swam silently in it, and they were all together, like fish in a crystal pool.

The effect of the place, the beauty of the scene, had probably much to do with it; the golden grace of the high rooms, chambers of art in themselves, took care, as an influence, of the general manner, and made people bland without making them solemn. They were only people, as Mrs. Stringham had said, staying for the week or two at the inns, people who during the day had fingered their Baedekers, gaped at their frescoes and differed, over fractions of francs, with their gondoliers. But Milly, let loose among them in a wonderful white dress, brought them somehow into relation with something that made them more finely genial; so that if the Veronese picture of which he had talked with Mrs.

Translation

The ambiance of the place and the beauty of the scene likely played a significant role. The golden elegance of the high-ceilinged rooms, themselves works of art, exerted an influence that fostered a general air of affability, without becoming overly serious. These were simply people, as Mrs. Stringham had observed, staying for a week or two at the inns. People who, during the day, had pored over their guidebooks, marveled at the frescoes, and haggled with their gondoliers over a few francs. But Milly, appearing amongst them in a striking white dress, connected them to something that made them more finely amiable. So that if the Veronese painting, which he had discussed with Mrs.

Stringham was not quite constituted, the comparative prose of the previous hours, the traces of insensibility qualified by "beating down," were at last almost nobly disowned. There was perhaps something for him in the accident of his seeing her for the first time in white, but she hadn't yet had occasion—circulating with a clearness intensified—to strike him as so happily pervasive. She was different, younger, fairer, with the colour of her braided hair more than ever a not altogether lucky challenge to attention; yet he was loth wholly to explain it by her having quitted this once, for some obscure yet doubtless charming reason, her almost monastic, her hitherto inveterate black. Much as the change did for the value of her presence, she had never yet, when all was said, made it for him; and he was not to fail of the further amusement of judging her determined in the matter by Sir Luke Strett's visit.

Translation

Stringham was not quite in place. The earlier, mundane talk and the signs of a lack of feeling, tempered by a sense of being "worn down," were ultimately dismissed in a noble way. The fact that he saw her for the first time in white may have been significant, but her impact, as she moved with a newly enhanced clarity, hadn't yet struck him as so effortlessly pervasive. She was different, younger, fairer, with the color of her braided hair more boldly attracting attention, yet he was reluctant to fully attribute it to her having, for some unclear but likely captivating reason, abandoned her previously unwavering black attire. Though this change amplified the value of her presence, she hadn't, considering everything, achieved this effect on him. He was not to be deprived of the further pleasure of assessing her resolve in this matter by Sir Luke Strett's visit.

If he could in this connexion have felt jealous of Sir Luke Strett, whose strong face and type, less assimilated by the scene perhaps than any others, he was anon to study from the other side of the saloon, that would doubtless have been most amusing of all. But he couldn't be invidious, even to profit by so high a tide; he felt himself too much "in" it, as he might have said: a moment's reflexion put him more in than any one. The way Milly neglected him for other cares while Kate and Mrs. Lowder, without so much as the attenuation of a joke, introduced him to English ladies—that was itself a proof; for nothing really of so close a communion had up to this time passed between them as the single bright look and the three gay words (all ostensibly of the last lightness) with which her confessed consciousness brushed by him.

Translation

If, in this context, he could have been jealous of Sir Luke Strett—whose strong face and presence, perhaps less integrated with the setting than anyone else—whom he was about to study from across the room, it would have been, without question, the most amusing development. But he couldn't feel animosity, even to take advantage of such an opportune moment; he felt too much "a part of it," as he might have put it: a moment's reflection placed him more centrally than anyone else. The fact that Milly ignored him for other concerns while Kate and Mrs. Lowder, without even the slightest pretense of a joke, introduced him to English ladies—that was, in itself, proof enough. Because, up until then, nothing of such genuine closeness had passed between them as that single, bright glance and the three carefree words (all seemingly of the utmost triviality) with which her acknowledged awareness passed him by.

Mrs. Stringham also seemed to think it was the right thing to say. She looked at him with an expression that was still cheerful, but also searching, which showed how much she understood. He wouldn't figure out what she meant until later.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham also appeared to endorse the remark. She regarded him with a gaze that remained pleasant, yet probing, betraying the depth of her comprehension. He wouldn't grasp her implication until a later time.

"Tell him that then. Anything will work for him as a way to get to you." "And why would he want to get to me?" "Give him the chance.

Translation

"Tell him that, then. Anything will do for him if it gets him closer to you." "And why would he want to get to me?" "Give him a chance."

Let him talk to you. Then you'll see." All of this from Mrs. Stringham made him feel even more deeply immersed in something that was strange rather than pleasant.

Translation

"Let him speak with you. Then you'll understand." Everything Mrs. Stringham said further plunged him into something more unsettling than enjoyable.

That feeling was going to be completely satisfied by several other experiences over the next few hours. Milly came down after dinner. Half a dozen friends arrived around that time, who seemed to mainly interest the women of Lancaster Gate. Then, she had to pay attention to her musicians, who Eugenio introduced.

Translation

That sensation was about to be utterly fulfilled by a series of other occurrences during the hours that followed. Milly came downstairs after dinner. About six friends showed up around the same time, and they appeared to mostly capture the attention of the women at Lancaster Gate. Following that, she had to focus on her musicians, whom Eugenio presented.

And the best opportunity came with the arrival of the great doctor, who came last. He felt her spread out the charm of a general, pleasant kindness in wide, warm waves. Some people certainly experienced it more deeply than others. What he knew was that he seemed to be up to his neck in it.

Translation

And the prime chance presented itself with the entry of the esteemed doctor, who was the last to arrive. He sensed her unfurling the allure of an inclusive, agreeable warmth in broad, inviting currents. For some, it undoubtedly resonated more profoundly. He understood, however, that he was utterly immersed.

He moved around in it without making a splash. He floated and swam silently in it. They were all together, like fish in a crystal pool. The effect of the place, the beauty of the scene, probably had a lot to do with it.

Translation

He navigated the space without causing a ripple. He drifted and swam through it in absolute silence. They were all united, like fish in a pristine, transparent pool. The ambiance of the location, the inherent beauty of the setting, was likely a significant factor.

The golden beauty of the high rooms, which were works of art themselves, set a tone of influence, and made people gentle without being solemn. They were just people, as Mrs. Stringham had said, staying at the hotels for a week or two. During the day, they had looked through their guidebooks, stared at the frescoes, and argued with their gondoliers over small change.

Translation

The gilded splendor of the grand rooms, each a masterpiece in its own right, exuded an air of authority that fostered a sense of calm, not severity. They were simply people, as Mrs. Stringham had observed, occupying hotel rooms for a week or two. Throughout the day, they'd consulted their travel guides, gazed upon the frescoes, and bickered with their gondoliers about trivial sums of money.

But Milly, appearing among them in a wonderful white dress, brought them somehow into connection with something that made them more genuinely friendly. So that even though the Veronese painting he had talked about with Mrs. Stringham wasn't exactly realized, the ordinary reality of the previous hours, the signs of coldness softened by "negotiation," were finally almost nobly dismissed. Perhaps there was something for him in the fact that he was seeing her in white for the first time, but she hadn't yet had the chance to impress him as so happily pervasive as she was now.

Translation

But Milly, appearing amongst them in a beautiful white dress, somehow connected them to something that made them more truly amiable. So that even if the Veronese painting he’d discussed with Mrs. Stringham wasn’t quite coming to life, the everyday reality of the hours before, the coldness softened by haggling, was finally almost nobly pushed aside. Perhaps there was something for him in the fact that he was seeing her in white for the first time, but she hadn’t yet had a chance to make such a joyful, pervasive impression as she was now.

She was different, younger, more beautiful, with the color of her braided hair more noticeable than ever. Yet, he was hesitant to explain it completely by her having given up her almost monastic, her formerly stubborn black dress for some mysterious, but no doubt delightful, reason. Though the change greatly improved the value of her presence, she had never before, when all was said and done, made that impression on him. And he wasn't going to miss out on the further pleasure of understanding her decision in this matter by Sir Luke Strett's visit.

Translation

She was changed: younger, more beautiful, her braided hair a vivid contrast. Still, he couldn't simply attribute it to her having abandoned the almost monastic, once stubbornly black dress for some unknown, yet undoubtedly pleasing, reason. While the alteration amplified her appeal, she had never, in the final analysis, affected him in this way before. And he wouldn’t forgo the added satisfaction of understanding her choice, courtesy of Sir Luke Strett’s arrival.

If he could have felt jealous of Sir Luke Strett, whose strong face and general appearance, perhaps less integrated into the scene than anyone else's, he was soon going to study from the other side of the room, that would certainly have been the most amusing part of all. But he couldn't be spiteful, even to take advantage of such a high point. He felt too much "in" it, as he might have said. A moment's thought placed him more "in" it than anyone else.

Translation

If he could have felt jealous of Sir Luke Strett—whose rugged features and overall demeanor seemed oddly out of place—he was about to observe from across the room. That would have been the most entertaining element of all. But he couldn't be malicious, not even to capitalize on such a dramatic moment. He was too invested, as he might have put it. A moment's reflection confirmed that he was more invested than anyone else.

The way Milly ignored him for other concerns while Kate and Mrs. Lowder, without even a hint of a joke, introduced him to English ladies—that was proof in itself. Because nothing so intimately connected had ever passed between them before, except for the single bright glance and the three cheerful words (all seeming to be casual) with which her acknowledged awareness brushed past him. She was acquitting herself to-night as hostess, he could see, under some supreme idea, an inspiration which was half her nerves and half an inevitable harmony; but what he especially recognised was the character that had already several times broken out in her and that she so oddly appeared able, by choice or by instinctive affinity, to keep down or to display.

Translation

The fact that Milly ignored him for other things while Kate and Mrs. Lowder, without a single hint of humor, presented him to English ladies—that was proof enough. Because they had never shared anything so intimate before, save for that single brilliant look and the three friendly words (all seeming offhand) with which she acknowledged his presence. He could see that she was carrying out her duties as a hostess tonight, governed by some overriding concept, an inspiration born partly of her nerves and partly of an inescapable harmony. But what he especially recognized was the trait that had already surfaced several times in her and that she seemed so strangely capable of concealing or revealing, whether by conscious choice or instinctive connection.

She was the American girl as he had originally found her—found her at certain moments, it was true, in New York, more than at certain others; she was the American girl as, still more than then, he had seen her on the day of her meeting him in London and in Kate's company. It affected him as a large though queer social resource in her—such as a man, for instance, to his diminution, would never in the world be able to command; and he wouldn't have known whether to see it in an extension or a contraction of "personality," taking it as he did most directly for a confounding extension of surface. Clearly too it was the right thing this evening all round: that came out for him in a word from Kate as she approached him to wreak on him a second introduction. He had under cover of the music melted away from the lady toward whom she had first pushed him; and there was something in her to affect him as telling evasively a tale of their talk in the Piazza.

Translation

She was the American girl, the way he had first encountered her—found her at certain moments, it was true, in New York, more than at certain other times. She was the American girl as he had seen her, even more so than then, on the day she first met him in London, in Kate's company. He felt it as a significant, though strange, social asset she possessed—something a man, to his detriment, would never be able to utilize. He wasn’t sure whether to interpret it as an expansion or a contraction of "personality," perceiving it most directly as a confusing expansion of her outward appearance. Clearly, it was also the appropriate thing this evening: that became apparent to him in a word from Kate as she came over to subject him to a second introduction. Under cover of the music, he had slipped away from the woman to whom she had initially directed him. There was something in her that affected him as if she were evasively recounting the conversation they’d had in the Piazza.

To what did she want to coerce him as a form of penalty for what he had done to her there? It was thus in contact uppermost for him that he had done something; not only caused her perfect intelligence to act in his interest, but left her unable to get away, by any mere private effort, from his inattackable logic. With him thus in presence, and near him—and it had been as unmistakeable through dinner—there was no getting away for her at all, there was less of it than ever: so she could only either deal with the question straight, either frankly yield or ineffectually struggle or insincerely argue, or else merely express herself by following up the advantage she did possess. It was part of that advantage for the hour—a brief fallacious makeweight to his pressure—that there were plenty of things left in which he must feel her will.

Translation

What did she want to force him to do, as punishment for what he’d done to her? It was foremost in his mind that he had done something, not only causing her perfect understanding to work in his favor, but also leaving her unable to escape his unassailable logic through any private means. With him present, near her—and that had been clear throughout dinner—she had no escape at all, less than ever: so she could only address the matter directly, either give in frankly, struggle ineffectively, or argue insincerely, or else simply express herself by exploiting the advantage she held. Part of that advantage for the moment—a short, misleading counterbalance to his pressure—was that there were many things where she could make him feel her will.

They only told him, these indications, how much she was, in such close quarters, feeling his; and it was enough for him again that her very aspect, as great a variation in its way as Milly's own, gave him back the sense of his action. It had never yet in life been granted him to know, almost materially to taste, as he could do in these minutes, the state of what was vulgarly called conquest. He had lived long enough to have been on occasion "liked," but it had never begun to be allowed him to be liked to any such tune in any such quarter. It was a liking greater than Milly's—or it would be: he felt it in him to answer for that.

Translation

These signs alone told him how much she, in such close proximity, was experiencing him. That was enough for him, again, for her very appearance, as drastically changed as Milly's, gave him back the feeling of his act. He had never before known, or almost materially tasted, as he could in these moments, the state of what was crudely called conquest. He had lived long enough to have been "liked" on occasion, but he had never begun to be liked to this extent, in this way, by anyone. It was a liking greater than Milly's—or it would be: he felt certain he could guarantee that.

So at all events he read the case while he noted that Kate was somehow—for Kate—wanting in lustre. As a striking young presence she was practically superseded; of the mildness that Milly diffused she had assimilated all her share; she might fairly have been dressed to-night in the little black frock, superficially indistinguishable, that Milly had laid aside. This represented, he perceived, the opposite pole from such an effect as that of her wonderful entrance, under her aunt's eyes—he had never forgotten it—the day of their younger friend's failure at Lancaster Gate. She was, in her accepted effacement—it was actually her acceptance that made the beauty and repaired the damage—under her aunt's eyes now; but whose eyes were not effectually preoccupied?

Translation

So, at any rate, he understood the situation while he noticed that Kate was somehow—for Kate—lacking brilliance. As a striking young presence, she was practically superseded. Of the gentleness that Milly exuded, Kate had absorbed her share. She might well have been dressed tonight in the little black frock, superficially indistinguishable, that Milly had put aside. This represented, he realized, the opposite extreme from the effect of her wonderful entrance under her aunt's eyes—he had never forgotten it—the day of their younger friend's failure at Lancaster Gate. She was, in her accepted self-effacement—it was actually her acceptance that made the beauty and repaired the damage—under her aunt's eyes now; but whose eyes were not effectually preoccupied?

It struck him none the less certainly that almost the first thing she said to him showed an exquisite attempt to appear if not unconvinced at least self-possessed. He could see that she was performing her duties as a hostess tonight with a specific goal in mind, a vision fueled by both her nerves and an innate sense of harmony. He especially noticed a characteristic of hers that had previously emerged, one that she seemed able to control or unleash at will, whether by conscious choice or instinct. She was the American girl he had first encountered—in certain moments, particularly in New York, and even more so on the day he met her in London with Kate.

Translation

It struck him, all the same, that almost the first thing she said to him displayed an exquisite effort to seem, if not unconvinced, then at least self-possessed. He could see that she was performing her duties as hostess tonight with a specific goal in mind, a vision fueled both by her nerves and an innate sense of harmony. He particularly noticed a characteristic of hers that had previously emerged, one that she seemed capable of controlling or unleashing at will, whether by conscious choice or instinct. She was the American girl he had first encountered—in certain moments, particularly in New York, and even more so the day he met her in London with Kate.

He saw this as a significant, though peculiar, social skill, something a man like him could never possess. He wasn't sure if it stemmed from an expansion or a contraction of her "personality," though he saw it as an overwhelming display of outward appearance. Tonight, this quality was clearly the appropriate choice, as Kate's words confirmed when she approached him to offer a second introduction. He had retreated from the woman she'd initially pushed him towards, under the cover of the music; and there was something in her demeanor that subtly alluded to their conversation in the Piazza.

Translation

He considered this a remarkable, if odd, social talent, a skill that would always be beyond him. He couldn’t tell if it came from her personality growing or shrinking, but it was a potent projection of self. It was the right move tonight, a fact Kate verified when she came over to introduce him again. He had slipped away from the woman Kate had steered him toward earlier, hidden by the music; and something in her manner suggested their talk in the Piazza.

What was she trying to force him to do as a result of what he'd done to her there? He was primarily aware that he had influenced her, not only causing her keen intellect to work in his favor but also preventing her from escaping his undeniable logic. With him present and nearby—as it had been throughout dinner—she was trapped, more so than ever; she could either confront the issue directly, surrender frankly, struggle in vain, argue dishonestly, or simply utilize the advantage she still possessed. Part of her advantage at this moment—a temporary and misleading counterweight to his influence—was that there were areas in which she could still exert her will.

Translation

What was she trying to make him do, now, as a result of whatever he'd done to her? He knew that he had exerted some kind of influence on her, that he had not only made her sharp mind work on his behalf, but also had stopped her from getting away from his irrefutable logic. With him there, near her—as he had been all through dinner—she was more trapped than ever; she could either confront it head on, give in completely, struggle uselessly, argue dishonestly, or just use what advantage she still had. Part of her advantage at the moment—a temporary and misleading check to his influence—was that there were some things she could still control.

These indications only showed him how much she was feeling his presence in close proximity; and it was enough for him that her very appearance, as distinctive as Milly's, reminded him of his impact. He had never before experienced, almost tangibly, the feeling of what was commonly called "conquest." He'd lived long enough to be "liked" on occasion, but he'd never been favored to this extent, and in this specific situation. It was a fondness greater than Milly's—or it would be: he was certain of that. He interpreted the situation this way while observing that Kate seemed somewhat—for her—lacking in vibrancy.

Translation

These signs simply revealed to him how acutely she was aware of his closeness; and it was gratifying that her very demeanor, as unique as Milly's, served as a reminder of his effect. He'd never before experienced, almost physically, the sensation of what was commonly termed "conquest." He had lived long enough to be "liked" from time to time, but he'd never been so favored, in this particular set of circumstances. It was an affection surpassing Milly's—or it would be: he was certain of it. He understood the situation this way, noting that Kate appeared somewhat—for her—lacking in vitality.

As a striking young presence, she was practically overshadowed; she had absorbed all of Milly's gentleness; she could have easily worn the simple black dress that Milly had set aside. This represented the opposite of her dramatic entrance, under her aunt's watchful gaze—he'd never forgotten it—the day their younger friend failed at Lancaster Gate. She was, in her current state of self-effacement—which, in reality, was the source of her beauty and a way to mitigate her challenges—under her aunt's observation now; but whose attention wasn't fully captivated? He was nonetheless struck by the fact that almost the first thing she said to him displayed a delicate effort to seem, if not unconvinced, then at least composed.

Translation

Despite her striking youth, she was almost invisible, having taken on all of Milly’s softness; she could have easily worn the plain black dress that Milly had put away. This was the antithesis of her grand entrance, under her aunt’s watchful eye—he’d never forgotten it—the day their younger friend failed at Lancaster Gate. In her current self-effacing state—which, in truth, was the source of her beauty and a way of coping with her difficulties—she was now under her aunt’s scrutiny; but whose attention wasn’t fully held? He was still struck by the fact that the first thing she said to him seemed a gentle attempt to appear, if not unconvinced, then at least collected.

"Don't you think her good enough now?" Almost heedless of the danger of overt freedoms, she eyed Milly from where they stood, noted her in renewed talk, over her further wishes, with the members of her little orchestra, who had approached her with demonstrations of deference enlivened by native humours—things quite in the line of old Venetian comedy. The girl's idea of music had been happy—a real solvent of shyness, yet not drastic; thanks to the intermissions, discretions, a general habit of mercy to gathered barbarians, that reflected the good manners of its interpreters, representatives though these might be but of the order in which taste was natural and melody rank. It was easy at all events to answer Kate. "Ah my dear, you know how good I think her!"

Translation

"Don't you think she's good enough now?"

Almost oblivious to the risks of such openness, she observed Milly from where they were standing. She watched Milly in a renewed conversation, discussing her further desires with the members of her small orchestra. These musicians had approached her with displays of deference, spiced with a native wit, reminiscent of classic Venetian comedy. The girl's concept of music had been joyful—a true antidote to shyness, though not overly forceful. This was thanks to the breaks, the moments of discretion, and a general leniency toward the gathered, somewhat unrefined audience. All of this reflected the good manners of the performers, even though they represented an order where taste came naturally and melody was commonplace. It was easy, at any rate, to reply to Kate, "Oh, my dear, you know how highly I think of her!"

"Don't you believe she's good enough now?" Ignoring the risk of being too forward, she observed Milly from across the room. She watched her engaging in renewed conversation, catering to her latest desires, with the musicians. They had approached her with respectful gestures, playfully infused with local charm—much like something from a classic Venetian comedy.

Translation

"Don't you believe she's good enough now?" Completely disregarding the potential for impropriety, she observed Milly from across the room. She watched as Milly once again engaged in conversation, discussing her latest requests with the musicians. They had approached her with respectful gestures, playfully infused with local charm, like something straight out of a classic Venetian comedy.

The music she requested was a good choice—it broke down her shyness without being overwhelming. This was because of breaks and pauses, tact, and a general consideration for the diverse audience, all reflecting the musicians' good manners, even though they represented a world where good taste came naturally and music flowed freely. It was easy to respond to Kate. "Oh, darling, you know how highly I think of her!"

Translation

The music Milly chose was perfect; it eased her self-consciousness without being too demanding. The musicians' sensitivity—their use of rests, pauses, and an overall awareness of their varied audience—was a testament to their refinement, a quality that seemed innate in their world of effortless artistry. Kate replied easily, "Oh, darling, you know how much I admire her!"

"But she's too nice," Kate returned with appreciation. "Everything suits her so—especially her pearls. They go so with her old lace. I'll trouble you really to look at them." Densher, though aware he had seen them before, had perhaps not "really" looked at them, and had thus not done justice to the embodied poetry—his mind, for Milly's aspects, kept coming back to that—which owed them part of its style.

Translation

"But she's too nice," Kate said admiringly. "Everything looks so good on her—especially her pearls. They go so well with her old lace. I want you to really look at them." Densher, although he knew he'd seen them before, probably hadn't "really" looked at them, and hadn't appreciated the poetry they embodied—his mind, when it came to Milly's appearance, kept returning to that—which owed them part of its style.

Kate's face, as she considered them, struck him: the long, priceless chain, wound twice round the neck, hung, heavy and pure, down the front of the wearer's breast—so far down that Milly's trick, evidently unconscious, of holding and vaguely fingering and entwining a part of it, conduced presumably to convenience. "She's a dove," Kate went on, "and one somehow doesn't think of doves as bejewelled. Yet they suit her down to the ground." "But she's too good," Kate said, appreciating the woman.

Translation

Kate's face, as she looked at the pearls, captivated him. The long, invaluable chain, wrapped twice around the neck, fell, heavy and pure, down the front of the woman's chest—so far down that Milly's habit, clearly unconscious, of holding and vaguely touching and twisting a portion of it, likely served her. "She's gentle," Kate continued, "and one doesn't instinctively picture doves adorned with jewels. Yet they're perfect for her." "But she's too good," Kate said, admiring the woman.

"Everything looks perfect on her—especially her pearls. They complement her antique lace so well. Could you please actually look at them?" Densher, despite knowing he'd seen them before, hadn't truly examined them, and so hadn't recognized the inherent beauty—his thoughts, when considering Milly's appearance, always returned to that—that the pearls contributed to. "Everything looks perfect on her—especially the pearls. They're wonderful with her antique lace. Would you actually look at them?" Translation

"She's angelic," Kate went on, "and you don't usually imagine angels wearing jewelry. But they look absolutely right on her." "Yes—absolutely," Densher agreed. He now saw how well they suited her, but was maybe even more aware of the intensity of his companion's feelings about them. Milly was, in fact, a dove; this was the image, though it mostly applied to her spirit.

Yet he knew in a moment that Kate was just now, for reasons hidden from him, exceptionally under the impression of that element of wealth in her which was a power, which was a great power, and which was dove-like only so far as one remembered that doves have wings and wondrous flights, have them as well as tender tints and soft sounds. It even came to him dimly that such wings could in a given case—had, truly, in the case with which he was concerned—spread themselves for protection. Hadn't they, for that matter, lately taken an inordinate reach, and weren't Kate and Mrs. Lowder, weren't Susan Shepherd and he, wasn't he in particular, nestling under them to a great increase of immediate ease?

Translation

But he understood instantly that Kate was at this moment, for reasons he didn't grasp, deeply affected by the wealth she possessed. It was a source of power, significant power, and it resembled a dove only in the sense that doves have wings and undertake amazing flights, along with their soft colors and gentle cooing. It even dawned on him that these wings, in certain circumstances—indeed, in this very situation—could be unfurled to provide protection. Hadn't they, as a matter of fact, recently extended themselves immoderately, and weren't Kate and Mrs. Lowder, weren't Susan Shepherd and he, wasn't he especially, finding shelter beneath them, experiencing a greater sense of comfort?

All this was a brighter blur in the general light, out of which he heard Kate presently going on. "Yes, they're perfect, absolutely." Densher now understood how well the clothes looked on her, but he was probably even more struck by the intensity of his companion's feelings about them. Milly was like a dove; that image suited her, especially when considering her spirit. However, Densher realized instantly that Kate, for reasons he didn't understand, was unusually aware of the wealth she possessed.

Translation

The whole scene seemed to shimmer, and through it, he heard Kate continue. "Yes, they're perfect, absolutely." Densher now understood how well the clothes looked on her, though he was probably even more struck by the force of his companion's feelings about them. Milly was like a dove; that image suited her, especially given her nature. But Densher realized at once that Kate, for reasons he didn't grasp, was unusually attuned to the wealth she possessed.

Milly's royal ornament had—under pressure now not wholly mysterious—taken on the character of a symbol of differences, differences of which the vision was actually in Kate's face. It might have been in her face too that, well as she certainly would look in pearls, pearls were exactly what Merton Densher would never be able to give her.

Wasn't that the great difference that Milly to-night symbolised? She unconsciously represented to Kate, and Kate took it in at every pore, that there was nobody with whom she had less in common than a remarkably handsome girl married to a man unable to make her on any such lines as that the least little present. "All the more reason why I should commit you then to Lady Wells." "Oh but wait." It was not only that he distinguished Lady Wells from afar, that she inspired him with no eagerness, and that, somewhere at the back of his head, he was fairly aware of the question, in germ, of whether this was the kind of person he should be involved with when they were married. It was furthermore that the consciousness of something he had not got from Kate in the morning, and that logically much concerned him, had been made more keen by these very moments—to say nothing of the consciousness that, with their general smallness of opportunity, he must squeeze each stray instant hard. "That's all the more reason why I should entrust you to Lady Wells." "Oh, wait a minute." Lowder think I’ve made up my mind when I’m only with a girl who's dying? If you're right about that, about the whole situation, you’re wrong about Mrs. Lowder being content.
