Translation

He won't fool Mrs. Stringham, Milly's closest friend; and it would be very strange if Mrs. Stringham fooled Aunt Maud, who is her own. At this, Kate offered him the cold spark of an idea, one that was, in truth, worth his having kept her around for.

"Why will it be odd? I marvel at your seeing your way so little." Mere curiosity even, about his companion, had now for him its quick, its slightly quaking intensities. He had compared her once, we know, to a "new book," an uncut volume of the highest, the rarest quality; and his emotion (to justify that) was again and again like the thrill of turning the page.

Translation

"Why would that be odd? I'm amazed at how little you understand." Simple curiosity, even about her, now held a quick, slightly trembling intensity for him. He had compared her once, we know, to a "new book," an uncut volume of the highest, rarest quality; and his feeling, to justify that, was again and again like the thrill of turning the page.

"Well, you know how deeply I marvel at the way you see it!" "It doesn't in the least follow," Kate went on, "that anything in the nature of what you call deception on Mrs. Stringham's part will be what you call odd. Why shouldn't she hide the truth?"

Translation

"You know how much I admire the way you see things!" "It doesn't necessarily follow," Kate continued, "that anything you'd call deception on Mrs. Stringham's part would be odd. Why shouldn't she hide the truth?"

At this, Kate offered him the promising glimmer of an idea, one that made keeping her around worthwhile. "Why would it be strange? I'm surprised you don't understand." Even simple curiosity about her now held a certain exciting, somewhat nervous intensity.

Translation

Kate provided him with an idea that seemed full of potential, a reason to want her near. "Why should it seem strange? I'm surprised you don't get it." Even his basic interest in her had become exciting, tinged with a slight anxiety.

He'd once compared her to a "new book," a pristine volume of the finest quality, and the sensation—to validate that comparison—was like the thrill of turning the page, again and again. "Well, you know how much I admire your perspective!" "It doesn't necessarily follow," Kate continued, "that any sort of deception on Mrs. Stringham's part would be odd in the slightest.

Translation

He had, at one point, likened her to a "new book," a flawless volume of the highest caliber, and the feeling—to confirm that comparison—was like the joy of turning the page, over and over. "Well, you know how much I value your point of view!" "It doesn't logically follow," Kate went on, "that any deception on Mrs. Stringham's part would be unusual in the least."

Why shouldn't she conceal the truth?" "From Mrs. Lowder?" Densher stared. "Why should she?"

Translation

"Why shouldn't she hide the truth?"

Densher stared. "From Mrs. Lowder? Why would she?"

"To please you." "And how in the world can it please me?" Kate turned her head away as if really at last almost tired of his density. But she looked at him again as she spoke.

Translation

"To please you." "And how in the world could that possibly please me?" Kate turned her head away, as if, finally, she was almost tired of how dense he was. But then she looked at him again as she spoke.

"Well then to please Milly." And before he could question: "Don't you feel by this time that there's nothing Susan Shepherd won't do for you?" He had verily after an instant to take it in, so sharply it corresponded with the good lady's recent reception of him. It was queerer than anything again, the way they all came together round him. But that was an old story, and Kate's multiplied lights led him on and on.

Translation

"Well then, to please Milly." And before he could ask: "Don't you think by now that there's nothing Susan Shepherd won't do for you?" He actually had to stop for a moment to consider it, because it aligned so well with the good lady's recent behavior toward him. It was stranger than ever, the way they all circled around him. But that was an old story, and Kate's ever-changing perspective kept him moving.

It was with a reserve, however, that he confessed this. "She's ever so kind. Only her view of the right thing may not be the same as yours." "From Mrs.

Translation

Dalloway's point of view, I suppose?" he inquired.

"Oh, not in the least," replied Kate. "Hers is of the

very, very best."

Lowder?" Densher asked, surprised. "Why would she do that?" "To make you happy."

Translation

Lowder?" Densher asked, surprised. "Why would she do that?" "To make you happy."

"And why on earth would that make me happy?" Kate looked away, as if she was finally exasperated by his slow thinking. But she turned back to him as she spoke. "Well, then, to make Milly happy." Before he could ask another question: "Don't you realize by now that there's nothing Susan Shepherd won't do for

Translation

Milly? And you?"

Densher stared. He simply couldn't believe it. He was baffled by her.

you?" It took him a moment to process this, as it strangely connected to the woman's recent friendliness towards him. The way they all seemed to circle around him was stranger than anything. But that was a familiar pattern, and Kate's explanations kept him going.

Translation

It was her, wasn't it? He needed a second to catch up, the words oddly clicking with her new warmth. He was more perplexed than ever by the way they all revolved around him. Yet this was an old habit, and Kate had always been able to get him through.

He admitted this with some hesitation. "She's always kind. But her idea of what's right might not be the same as yours." "How can it be anything different if it's the view of serving you?"

Translation

He said this, though he was a little unsure. "She's always good-natured. But what she thinks is right might not align with your own ideas." "How could it possibly be any different, when she sees her purpose as helping you?"

Densher for an instant, but only for an instant, hung fire. "Oh the difficulty is that I don't, upon my honour, even yet quite make out how yours does serve me." "It helps you—put it then," said Kate very simply—"to serve me. It gains you time."

Translation

Densher hesitated, but only for a moment. "The trouble is, I honestly don't understand how yours benefits me." "It helps you—let's put it this way," Kate said plainly—"to help me. It buys you time."

"Time for what?" "For everything!" She spoke at first, once more, with impatience; then as usual she qualified. "For anything that may happen." Densher had a smile, but he felt it himself as strained.

Translation

"Time for what?" "For everything!" At first, she spoke with impatience again, but then, as usual, she softened. "For anything that might happen." Densher smiled, but even he felt it was forced.

"You're cryptic, love!" It made her keep her eyes on him, and he could thus see that, by one of those incalculable motions in her without which she wouldn't have been a quarter so interesting, they half-filled with tears from some source he had too roughly touched. "I'm taking a trouble for you I never dreamed I should take for any human creature." "How could it be anything else, if it's about helping you?"

Translation

"You're being mysterious, darling!" It made her focus on him, and he could see that, through one of those unpredictable shifts within her—without which she wouldn't have been nearly so fascinating—her eyes were beginning to well up, the source of her emotion obscure. "I'm enduring a hardship for you that I never imagined I would for anyone." "How could it be otherwise, if it involves helping you?"

Densher hesitated, but only for a moment. "The problem is, I honestly don't understand how your perspective actually helps me." "It helps you—let's just say," Kate said plainly, "to help me. It buys you time."

Translation

Densher paused, but just for a second. "The trouble is, I really don't see how your point of view actually benefits me." "It benefits you—let's be clear," Kate said frankly, "by helping me. It buys you time."

"Time for what?" "For everything!" She said it quickly, then, as usual, softened. "For anything that might happen." Densher smiled, but even he knew it felt forced.

Translation

"Time for what?" "For everything!" She said it quickly, then, as usual, softened. "For anything that might happen." Densher smiled, but even he knew it felt forced.

"You're being mysterious, darling!" Her gaze locked onto his, and he saw that, due to one of those unpredictable shifts within her that made her so captivating, her eyes were welling up with tears, triggered by something he'd said too bluntly. "I'm making an effort for you that I never thought I'd make for anyone." Oh it went home, making him flush for it; yet he soon enough felt his reply on his lips.

Translation

"You're being mysterious, darling!" Her eyes met his, and he understood that, in one of her sudden, unfathomable turns, the kind that made her so alluring, tears had come to her eyes, brought on by a clumsiness in his words. "I'm doing something for you I never thought I could do for anyone." The words found their mark, and he felt a blush rise to his cheeks; but quickly enough, the response formed on his own lips.

"Well, isn't my whole insistence to you now that I can conjure trouble away?" And he let it, his insistence, come out again; it had so constantly had, all the week, but its step or two to make. "There need be none whatever between us. There need be nothing but our sense of each other." It had only the effect at first that her eyes grew dry while she took up again one of the so numerous links in her close chain.

Translation

"Well, isn't my whole point now that I can make trouble disappear?" He let his point, his insistence, come out again; it had been there constantly all week, but it still had a few steps to take. "There needs to be no conflict between us. There needs to be nothing but our feeling for each other." At first, this only made her eyes dry while she picked up one of the many links in her tightly-held chain.

"You can tell her anything you like, anything whatever." "Mrs. Stringham? I have nothing to tell her."

"You can tell her about us. I mean," she wonderfully pursued, "that you do still like me." He felt embarrassed by her reaction, but a response quickly formed in his mind. "My whole point to you is that I can prevent any problems," he said, allowing his declaration to surface once more; he had repeated it often that week, but it still felt like a new point.

"Tell her about us. I mean," she said, her words taking on a charming quality, "that you still care for me." He felt a pang of awkwardness, but a reply came to him swiftly. "There doesn't have to be any conflict between us. All that matters is how we feel about each other." At first, this only made her eyes grow distant as she focused again on a well-worn aspect of their situation. "You can tell her anything, anything at all."

Translation

"We don't have to fight. All that matters is what we feel for each other." At first, this only made her eyes cloud over as she thought again about a familiar part of their situation. "You can tell her anything, anything."

Translation

Finally, she made him consider it seriously, and it was almost like a revelation, though it didn't fully hit him immediately. "You have to let me say I understand. An opportunity for something specific that I know you believe is possible. An opportunity that, I also understand, is an opportunity for you as well."

Translation

She eventually forced him to genuinely consider the possibility. It felt like a revelation, though the full impact didn't immediately register. "You need to allow me to state that I comprehend. An opening for something precise that I know you believe is within reach. An opening that, I also understand, is beneficial for you too."

"Time indeed for me as well." And encouraged visibly by his glow of concentration, she looked at him as through the air she had painfully made clear. Yet she was still on her guard. "Don't think, however, I'll do all the work for you. If you want things named you must name them."

Translation

"I need to consider the time for myself," she said. Encouraged by his focused expression, she regarded him as if through the air she had painstakingly clarified. Nevertheless, she remained cautious. "Don't assume, however, that I'll do all the work. If you want things defined, you must define them."

He had quite, within the minute, been turning names over; and there was only one, which at last stared at him there dreadful, that properly fitted. "Since she's to die I'm to marry her?" It struck him even at the moment as fine in her that she met it with no wincing nor mincing. She might for the grace of silence, for favour to their conditions, have only answered him with her eyes.

Translation

He had, in that very minute, been considering names. There was only one that, finally, stared back at him with a dreadful certainty, the name that truly fit. "Since she's to die, I am to marry her?" Even as he spoke, he was struck by the fineness of her response; she met his words without flinching or hesitation. For the sake of discretion, for the sake of their circumstances, she might have chosen to answer him with only her eyes.

But her lips bravely moved. "To marry her." "It's time for me too, I suppose." Seeing his intense focus, she seemed emboldened and looked at him as if she'd finally cleared a space in the air between them. Still, she was cautious.

Translation

But her lips bravely moved. "To marry her." "It's time for me too, I suppose." Seeing his intense focus, she seemed emboldened and looked at him as if she'd finally cleared a space in the air between them. Still, she was cautious.

"Don't imagine I'll do all the work for you. If you want things to be named, you have to name them." He had, in fact, been considering names for the past minute, and there was only one that, when he considered it, seemed truly appropriate and horrifying. "Since she's going to die, I'm supposed to marry her?"

Translation

"Don't expect me to do everything for you. If you want something named, you have to name it." He had, in fact, been thinking about names for the last minute, and only one seemed truly appropriate and horrifying. "Since she's going to die, I'm supposed to marry her?"

It impressed him at that moment how well she took the news, without flinching or trying to soften it. She might have simply answered him with her eyes, for the sake of discretion and to protect their situation. But her lips moved bravely. "To marry her."

Translation

He was struck by her reaction, how she received the information without hesitation or an attempt to make it easier. She could have chosen to simply respond with a look, a move that would have been discreet, protecting them both. Instead, her mouth formed words, brave and direct. "To marry her."

"So that when her death has taken place I shall in the natural course have money?" It was before him enough now, and he had nothing more to ask; he had only to turn, on the spot, considerably cold with the thought that all along—to his stupidity, his timidity—it had been, it had been only, what she meant. Now that he was in possession moreover she couldn't forbear, strangely enough, to pronounce the words she hadn't pronounced: they broke through her controlled and colourless voice as if she should be ashamed, to the very end, to have flinched. "You'll in the natural course have money.

Translation

"So that when she dies, I'll naturally get the money?" It was enough for him now, and he had nothing left to ask; he only had to turn, immediately, considerably chilled by the thought that all along—due to his stupidity, his timidity—that's all it had been, that's all she meant. Now that he had it, she couldn't help but say the words she hadn't said: they broke through her controlled, colorless voice as if she would be ashamed, to the very end, to have flinched. "You'll naturally have the money."

We shall in the natural course be free." "Oh, oh, oh!" Densher softly murmured. "Yes, yes, yes." But she broke off. "Come to Lady Wells."

Translation

"We will, in the natural course, be free." "Oh, oh, oh!" Densher softly murmured. "Yes, yes, yes." But she broke off. "Come to Lady Wells."

So, after her death, I will naturally inherit money? That was the key fact, now before him, and he had nothing more to ask. He simply needed to accept, immediately, that all along—due to his own foolishness and timidity—that's exactly what she intended. Now that he had the information, she couldn't help herself, surprisingly, and she finally spoke the words she'd held back.

Translation

So, I will inherit money after she dies? That was the crucial detail, finally revealed, and he didn't need to ask anything else. He just had to acknowledge, right away, that, all along, due to his own stupidity and fear, that's precisely what she'd planned. Now that he knew, she couldn't help it, surprisingly, and she finally said what she'd been withholding.

They emerged from her carefully controlled and emotionless voice as if she was ashamed, right until the very end, to have been hesitant. "You will naturally inherit money. We will naturally be free." "Oh, oh, oh!" Densher whispered softly.

Translation

They came out of her carefully controlled, emotionless voice as if she'd been ashamed, right up to the end, of her hesitation. "You will inherit money, of course. We will, of course, be free." "Oh, oh, oh!" Densher whispered.

"Yes, yes, yes." But she stopped. "Come to Lady Wells." He never budged—there was too much else. "I'm to propose it then—marriage—on the spot?"

Translation

"Yes, yes, yes." But she stopped. "Come to Lady Wells." He never moved—there was too much going on. "Am I to propose it then—marriage—right now?"

There was no ironic sound he needed to give it; the more simply he spoke the more he seemed ironic. But she remained consummately proof. "Oh I can't go into that with you, and from the moment you don't wash your hands of me I don't think you ought to ask me. You must act as you like and as you can."

Translation

He didn't need to inject any sarcasm into his voice; the plainer he spoke, the more ironic he sounded. But her resistance was absolute. "Oh, I can't discuss that with you, and since you won't just abandon me, I don't think you should be asking. Do as you please, and as you are able."

He thought again. "I'm far—as I sufficiently showed you this morning—from washing my hands of you." "Then," said Kate, "it's all right." "All right?" His eagerness flamed.

Translation

He thought it over. "I am nowhere near—as I demonstrated quite clearly this morning—washing my hands of you."

"Then," Kate said, "that's fine."

"Fine?" His enthusiasm surged.

"You'll come?" But he had had to see in a moment that it wasn't what she meant. "You'll have a free hand, a clear field, a chance—well, quite ideal." He didn't move; there was too much going on.

Translation

"You'll come?" But he instantly realized that wasn't her point. "You'll have free rein, a blank slate, an opportunity—well, perfect." He remained still; it was too much to process.

"So, I'm supposed to ask you right now, this instant, if you'll marry me?" He didn't need to inject any sarcasm into his voice; the plainer he spoke, the more sarcastic he sounded. But she remained completely composed, unfazed. "Oh, I can't discuss that with you.

Translation

"Are you expecting me to propose, right this second?" He didn't need to add anything; the simpler he put it, the more cutting it became. But she didn't react at all, completely calm. "I can't talk about that with you."

And since you're not abandoning me, I don't think you should be asking. You should do whatever you want and whatever you can." He paused again. "I'm far from abandoning you—as I made clear to you this morning."

Translation

"And since you're not leaving, I don't think you should be asking. Do whatever you want, whatever you can." He paused again. "I'm not leaving you—I made that clear this morning."

"Then," Kate said, "everything's fine." "Fine?" His excitement surged. "You'll come?" But he realized in a flash that wasn't what she meant.

Translation

"Then," Kate said, "everything's fine."

"Fine?" His excitement surged. "You'll come?" But he realized in a flash that wasn't what she meant.

"You'll have complete freedom, a clear path, an opportunity—well, an absolutely perfect one." "Your descriptions"—her "ideal" was such a touch!—"are prodigious. And what I don't make out is how, caring for me, you can like it." "I don't like it, but I'm a person, thank goodness, who can do what I don't like."

Translation

"You'll have total freedom, an open road, an opportunity—well, a completely perfect one." "Your descriptions"—her "ideal" was such a great touch!—"are impressive. And what I don't understand is how you can enjoy this, caring for me." "I don't enjoy it, but I'm a person, thank goodness, who can do things I don't enjoy."

It wasn't till afterwards that, going back to it, he was to read into this speech a kind of heroic ring, a note of character that belittled his own incapacity for action. Yet he saw indeed even at the time the greatness of knowing so well what one wanted. At the time too, moreover, he next reflected that he after all knew what he did. But something else on his lips was uppermost.

Translation

It was only later, when he thought back on it, that he would interpret the speech as having a heroic tone, a testament to character that made his own inability to act seem small. Yet, even then, he recognized the greatness of someone who knew exactly what they wanted. He also considered that he, too, knew what he wanted. But something else was on his mind.

"What I don't make out then is how you can even bear it." "Your descriptions"—her "ideal" was such a great compliment!—"are incredible. And I can't understand how you can like doing it, since you care about me." "I don't like it, but I'm, thankfully, the sort of person who can do things I don't enjoy."

Translation

"So I just don't get how you can stand it." "Your descriptions"—her "ideal" was such a huge compliment!—"are incredible. And I don't see how you can enjoy doing it, considering you care about me." "I don't enjoy it, but I'm, thankfully, the kind of person who can do things I don't like."

Later, thinking back on it, he would see a heroic quality in her words, a declaration of character that made him feel inadequate. He did recognize, though, even then, how impressive it was to know exactly what you wanted. Also, he realized that he, too, knew what he wanted. But something else was on the tip of his tongue.

Translation

Later, reflecting on it, he would recognize the heroism in her words. They were a declaration of character that made him feel unworthy. He did acknowledge, even then, how impressive it was to have such clarity of purpose. He also realized that he, too, knew what he wanted. But something else lingered, just beyond his ability to express it.

"What I don't understand is how you can stand it." "Well, when you know me better you'll find out how much I can bear." And she went on before he could take up, as it were, her too many implications. That it was left to him to know her, spiritually, "better" after his long sacrifice to knowledge—this for instance was a truth he hadn't been ready to receive so full in the face. She had mystified him enough, heaven knew, but that was rather by his own generosity than by hers.

Translation

"What I don't understand is how you can stand it." "Well, when you know me better you'll find out how much I can bear." And she walked ahead before he could respond to her many implications. That it was up to him to know her, spiritually, "better" after his long sacrifice to knowledge—this, for instance, was a truth he hadn't been ready to accept so directly. She had baffled him enough, God knows, but that was more a result of his own generosity than hers.

And what, with it, did she seem to suggest she might incur at his hands? In spite of these questions she was carrying him on. "All you'll have to do will be to stay." "And proceed to my business under your eyes?"

Translation

And what, with that, did she seem to imply she might be subjected to because of him? Despite these questions, she was still bringing him along. "All you'll have to do is stay." "And continue with my work while you're watching?"

"You'll see, when you get to know me, how much I can handle," she said, before he had a chance to respond to the many things she was implying. The fact that he was supposed to get to know her better, spiritually, after all the time he had spent trying to understand her—that was a truth he wasn't prepared to face so directly. She had confused him, certainly, but he felt that was more his doing than hers. And, furthermore, what did she mean by suggesting she might suffer because of him?

Translation

"You'll see, once you know me," she said, before he could address the many things she was suggesting, "how much I can handle." He had already spent so much time trying to understand her, and now he was supposed to know her better, spiritually? He hadn't been ready for that truth to be stated so plainly. She had confused him, it was true, but he thought he was more to blame than she was. And what had she meant when she said she might suffer because of him?

Despite these questions, she kept moving forward, leading him along. "All you need to do is stay." "And oversee my work?" "Oh dear no—we shall go."

Translation

Even with these questions swirling in his mind, she continued on, pulling him along. "All you need to do is stay put." "And supervise what I do?" "Good heavens, no—we're leaving."

"'Go?'" he wondered. "Go when, go where?" "In a day or two—straight home. Aunt Maud wishes it now."

Translation

"'Leave?'" he wondered. "Leave when? Leave where?" "In a day or two—straight home. Aunt Maud wants it now."

It gave him all he could take in to think of. "Then what becomes of Miss Theale?" "What I tell you. She stays on, and you stay with her."

Translation

That thought consumed him. "Then what happens to Miss Theale?" "What I'm telling you. She remains, and you remain with her."

He stared. "All alone?" She had a smile that was apparently for his tone. "You're old enough—with plenty of Mrs.

Translation

He gaped. "Completely alone?" Her smile seemed directed at his question. "You're old enough—and you have Mrs.

Stringham." Nothing might have been so odd for him now, could he have measured it, as his being able to feel, quite while he drew from her these successive cues, that he was essentially "seeing what she would say"—an instinct compatible for him therefore with that absence of a need to know her better to which she had a moment before done injustice. If it hadn't been appearing to him in gleams that she would somewhere break down, he probably couldn't have gone on. Still, as she wasn't breaking down there was nothing for him but to continue.

Translation

He stared. "Completely alone?" Her smile seemed to address his question. "You're old enough—and you have Mrs. Stringham." Nothing might have seemed so strange to him now, if he could have gauged it, as his capacity to sense, while he elicited these remarks from her, that he was essentially "watching her reactions"—an instinct which, for him, was consistent with that lack of a desire to know her better, a deficiency to which she'd just taken exception. If he hadn't glimpsed that she would, at some point, break down, he likely couldn't have proceeded. Nevertheless, since she wasn't breaking down, he had no option but to continue.

"Is your going Mrs. Lowder's idea?" "Oh, no, we're leaving." "Leaving?" he questioned.

Translation

"Is Mrs. Lowder behind your going?"

"Oh, no, we're leaving."

"Leaving?" he asked.

"Leaving when? Where are we going?" "In a day or two—right back home. Aunt Maud wants us there now."

Translation

"Leaving when?" he asked. "And where are we going?"

"In a day or two—right back home. Aunt Maud wants us there now."

It was a lot to process. "So what about Miss Theale?" "What I'm telling you. She's staying, and you're staying with her."

Translation

He had to think about it. "What about Miss Theale?"

"That's the situation. She's staying, and you're staying with her."

He was stunned. "All alone?" Her smile seemed amused. "You're old enough—with Mrs.

Translation

He was taken aback. "Entirely on my own?" Her smile appeared amused. "You're of age—with Mrs.

Stringham around." The strangest thing, if he could have recognized it, was his ability to feel, as she gave him these pieces of information, that he was mainly "watching what she'd say"—an instinct that allowed him to not need to understand her better, which she had just criticized. If he hadn't thought she might break down at some point, he probably couldn't have kept going. But since she wasn't breaking down, he had no choice but to continue.

Translation

He was taken aback. "Entirely on my own?" Her smile seemed amused. "You're of age—with Mrs. Stringham around." The oddest thing, had he been able to identify it, was his capacity to feel, as she presented him with this information, that he was mainly "watching what she'd say"—an instinct that allowed him not to need to understand her better, which she had just criticized. If he hadn't believed she might break down at some point, he likely wouldn't have been able to carry on. But since she wasn't breaking down, he was compelled to continue.

"Is leaving Mrs. Lowder's idea?" "Very much indeed. Of course again you see what it does for us.

Translation

"Is this Mrs. Lowder's suggestion?" "Absolutely. And, of course, you see the advantage to us."

And I don't," she added, "refer only to our going, but to Aunt Maud's view of the general propriety of it." "I see again, as you say," Densher said after a moment. "It makes everything fit." "Everything."

Translation

And I'm not just talking about our leaving. I mean Aunt Maud's opinion on whether it's the right thing to do in general. "I get it, like you said," Densher said after a pause. "It explains everything." "Everything."

The word, for a little, held the air, and he might have seemed the while to be looking, by no means dimly now, at all it stood for. But he had in fact been looking at something else. "You leave her here then to die?" "Ah she believes she won't die.

Translation

The word hung in the air for a moment, and for a time he might have appeared to be contemplating what it all signified, not vaguely now. But in reality, he was looking at something else. "So you'll leave her here to die?" "Oh, she doesn't think she's going to die."

Not if you stay. I mean," Kate explained, "Aunt Maud believes." "And that's all that's necessary?" Still indeed she didn't break down.

Translation

Not if you stay. I mean," Kate explained, "Aunt Maud believes." "And that's all that's necessary?" And still, she didn't break down.

"Didn't we long ago agree that what she believes is the principal thing for us?" Absolutely. You understand the benefit, of course. And I'm not just talking about our departure, but also Aunt Maud's opinion about whether it's the right thing to do.

Translation

"Didn't we agree a while back that what she believes is the most important thing for us?" Absolutely. You understand the benefit, of course. And I'm not just talking about our leaving, but also Aunt Maud's opinion on whether it's the right thing to do.

"I see, as you say," Densher replied after a pause. "It makes everything work." "Everything." The word lingered, and for a moment he seemed to contemplate what it meant.

Translation

"I understand," Densher said, after a pause. "It holds everything together." "Everything." The word hung in the air, and for a moment he appeared to consider its implications.

But in reality, he was focused on something else. "So you're leaving her here to die?" "She doesn't think she will. Not if you stay.

Translation

In truth, his mind was elsewhere. "So you're abandoning her to die here?" "She doesn't believe she will. Not if you remain."

I mean," Kate clarified, "Aunt Maud doesn't think so." "And that's the only thing that matters?" She remained composed. "Didn't we decide a while ago that her beliefs are what matter most to us?"

Translation

"I suppose," Kate said. "Aunt Maud doesn't think so." "And is that really the most important thing?" She didn't react. "Didn't we already agree that her feelings are what we should prioritize?"

He recalled it, under her eyes, but it came as from long ago. "Oh yes. I can't deny it." Then he added: "So that if I stay—" "It won't"—she was prompt—"be our fault."

Translation

He remembered, looking at her, but the memory felt distant. "Right, I can't argue with that." Then he said, "So, if I stay—" "It won't," she interrupted, "be our problem."

"If Mrs. Lowder still, you mean, suspects us?" "If she still suspects us. But she won't."

Translation

"If Mrs. Lowder still suspects us, you mean?" "If she still suspects us. But she won't."

Kate gave it an emphasis that might have appeared to leave him nothing more; and he might in fact well have found nothing if he hadn't presently found: "But what if she doesn't accept me?" It produced in her a look of weariness that made the patience of her tone the next moment touch him. "You can but try." "Naturally I can but try.

Translation

Kate delivered the line with an emphasis that seemed to imply there was nothing more to say. And indeed, he might have been finished if he hadn’t immediately countered with, “But what if she doesn’t accept me?” This question brought a weary look to her face, a look that made the patience in her voice the next moment all the more affecting. “You can only try.” “Of course, I can only try.”

Only, you see, one has to try a little hard to propose to a dying girl." He remembered the situation, now that she was looking at him, but it felt like a distant memory. "Yes, I remember. I can't deny it." Then he said, "So, if I stay—"

Translation

Only, you see, one has to try a little harder to propose to a dying girl.” He remembered the situation now that she was looking at him, though it felt like a distant memory. “Yes, I remember. I can’t deny it.” Then he said, “So, if I stay—”

"It won't," she interrupted, "be our fault." "If Mrs. Lowder still suspects us?" "If she still suspects us.

Translation

"It won't," she interrupted, "be our fault." "If Mrs. Lowder still suspects us?" "If she still suspects us."

But she won't." Kate's emphatic statement seemed to imply there was nothing more to say. In fact, he might have agreed if he hadn't then asked, "But what if she doesn't want me?" This question brought a weary look to her face, making her patient tone all the more moving.

Translation

"But she won't." Kate's emphatic declaration seemed to settle the matter. He might have conceded, too, if he hadn't then asked, "But what if she doesn't want me?" This question brought a weary look to her face, making her patient tone all the more affecting.

"You can only try." "Of course, I can only try. The problem is, you have to try pretty hard to propose to a girl who's dying." "She isn't for you as if she's dying." It had determined in Kate the flash of justesse he could perhaps most, on consideration, have admired, since her retort touched the truth.

Translation

"All you can do is try." "Of course, that's all I can do. The thing is, you have to try pretty hard to propose to a girl who's dying." "She's not dying, not for you, anyway." In Kate, it had triggered a moment of clarity that, on reflection, he might have admired the most, since her response was the truth.

There before him was the fact of how Milly to-night impressed him, and his companion, with her eyes in his own and pursuing his impression to the depths of them, literally now perched on the fact in triumph. She turned her head to where their friend was again in range, and it made him turn his, so that they watched a minute in concert. Milly, from the other side, happened at the moment to notice them, and she sent across toward them in response all the candour of her smile, the lustre of her pearls, the value of her life, the essence of her wealth. It brought them together again with faces made fairly grave by the reality she put into their plan.

Translation

The reality was right in front of him: how Milly had impressed him and his companion that evening. Her eyes held his, and she pursued his impression into their depths, now literally perched on this fact in triumph. She turned her head towards their friend, who was back within view, and it made him turn his, so that they watched for a minute in unison. Milly, on the other side, happened to notice them, and she sent across to them in response the full candor of her smile, the gleam of her pearls, the value of her life, the essence of her wealth. It brought them together again, their faces made fairly grave by the reality she instilled in their plan.

Kate herself grew a little pale for it, and they had for a time only a silence. The music, however, gay and vociferous, had broken out afresh and protected more than interrupted them. When Densher at last spoke it was under cover. "She's not a good match for you; it's like she's on her deathbed." This statement sparked in Kate a perfectly accurate understanding that he probably admired the most, given what he knew.

Translation

Kate herself grew a little pale because of it, and they were silent for a time. The music, lively and loud, had started up again and protected them more than it interrupted them. When Densher finally spoke, he did so quietly. "She's not a good match for you; it's like she's on her deathbed." This statement gave Kate a perfectly accurate understanding of what he probably admired most, given what he knew.

Her response hit the truth. The way Milly affected him and his friend that night was undeniable. Kate, her eyes locked on his, explored his thoughts to their core and essentially celebrated their shared understanding of the situation. She turned her head towards where their friend stood, and he followed her gaze, so they could observe Milly together for a moment.

Translation

Her reaction was spot-on. The impact Milly had on him and his friend that night was clear. Kate, her gaze fixed on his, delved into his thoughts and, in effect, reveled in their shared grasp of the matter. She turned her head in the direction of their friend, and he followed suit, allowing them to observe Milly together for a brief spell.

Milly, from across the room, noticed them and responded with all the genuine warmth of her smile, the brilliance of her jewelry, the preciousness of her life, and the symbol of her fortune. This gesture united them, their faces reflecting the seriousness of their scheme. Kate herself became a little pale because of it, and they remained silent for a while. However, the cheerful, lively music began again and served to protect rather than disturb their conversation.

Translation

Milly, from across the room, saw them and replied with the full extent of her smile's sincerity, the glitter of her jewelry, the value of her life, and the emblem of her wealth. This action bonded them, their faces mirroring the gravity of their plan. Kate's complexion paled slightly as a result, and they fell silent for a time. But the happy, buoyant music started up again, and it served to shield, rather than interrupt, their discussion.

When Densher finally spoke, he did so quietly. "I might stay, you know, without trying." "Oh to stay is to try." "To have for herself, you mean, the appearance of it?"

Translation

Densher spoke softly. "I could stay, you know, without even trying." "Oh, to stay is to try." "To have for herself, you mean, the appearance of it?"

"I don't see how you can have the appearance more." Densher waited. "You think it then possible she may offer marriage?" "I can't think—if you really want to know—what she may not offer!"

Translation

"I don't understand how you could feign it more." Densher paused. "You think it's possible she might propose marriage?" "I can't even begin to guess—if you truly want to know—what she wouldn't offer!"

"In the manner of princesses, who do such things?" "In any manner you like. So be prepared." Well, he looked as if he almost were.

Translation

"How princesses behave, you mean?" "Any way you can imagine. Just be ready for it." He seemed to be, almost.

"It will be for me then to accept. But that's the way it must come." Kate's silence, so far, let it pass; but she presently said: "You'll, on your honour, stay then?" His answer made her wait, but when it came it was distinct.

Translation

"Then I'll have to accept it. But that's just the way it has to be." Kate had been silent up to this point, letting things go; but now she said, "You will, on your word, stay then?" His answer made her wait a moment, but it was clear when it came.

"Without you, you mean?" "I could stay, you know, without putting any effort in." "Oh, to stay is to try." "To have the appearance of it for herself, you mean?"

Translation

"You mean without you?" "I could stay here without trying." "Oh, but staying is about effort." "To appear to be trying, for her sake, you mean?"

"I don't see how you could get any more of the appearance than you already have." Densher paused. "You think she might propose marriage?" "I couldn't even guess—if you really want to know—what she might not offer!"

Translation

"I don't see how you could fake it any better than you already do." Densher stopped. "You think she'll ask you to marry her?" "I couldn't begin to guess—if you must know—what she might be willing to do!"

"Like princesses, who do those sorts of things?" "In any way you can imagine. So be ready." Well, he looked like he almost was.

Translation

"Like princesses, who do those sorts of things?" "In any way you can imagine. So be ready." Well, he looked like he almost was.

"Then I'll have to accept. But that's how it has to happen." Kate didn't say anything, which indicated that she was okay with the idea for the time being. But soon after, she said, "Will you, on your word of honor, stay then?"

Translation

"Then I must agree. It's the only way." Kate remained silent, which suggested she wasn't opposed, at least for now. But shortly after, she asked, "Will you swear you'll stay?"

He took his time answering her, but when he did, it was clear. "Without you, you mean?" "Without us." "And you yourselves go at latest—?"

Translation

He didn't reply immediately, and the deliberation was obvious. "You mean, without you?" "Without us." "And you'll leave no later than—?"

"Not later than Thursday." It made three days. "Well," he said, "I'll stay, on my honour, if you'll come to me. On your honour."

Translation

"No later than Thursday." That meant three days. "Alright," he said, "I'll stay, on my honor, if you come to me. On your honor."

Again, as before, this made her momentarily rigid, with a rigour out of which, at a loss, she vaguely cast about her. Her rigour was more to him, nevertheless, than all her readiness; for her readiness was the woman herself, and this other thing a mask, a stop-gap and a "dodge." She cast about, however, as happened, and not for the instant in vain. Her eyes, turned over the room, caught at a pretext. "Lady Wells is tired of waiting: she's coming—see—to us."

Translation

Once more, as before, this stiffened her for a moment,

a rigidity from which she groped, at a loss,

for a way out. This stiffness meant more to him,

though, than all her willingness; because her willingness

was her true self, and this other thing a mask,

a temporary measure, and a "dodge." She cast about,

nonetheless, as it happened, and not in vain for

the moment. Her eyes swept over the room, seized on

an excuse. "Lady Wells is tired of waiting: she's coming—see—to

us."

Densher saw in fact, but there was a distance for their visitor to cross, and he still had time. "If you decline to understand me I wholly decline to understand you. I'll do nothing." "Without us."

Translation

Densher did see, but there was still some distance for their visitor to cover; he still had time. "If you refuse to understand me, then I refuse to understand you completely. I won't do anything." "Without us."

"And when will you be leaving, at the latest?" "No later than Thursday." That meant three days. "Alright," he said, "I'll stay, I promise, if you will come to me.

Translation

"And what's the latest you'll be gone?" "No later than Thursday." That meant three days. "Alright," he said, "I'll stay, I promise, if you come to me."

On your word of honor." Once more, she stiffened slightly, a rigidity that seemed to stem from confusion as she considered the situation. This resistance was more significant to him than her willingness; her willingness was simply her, but the stiffness was a disguise, a diversion, a tactic. She searched for an escape, and, as luck would have it, she found one immediately.

Translation

"You promise?" She subtly tensed, a rigidity born of uncertainty as she weighed the situation. This reluctance was more telling than her acquiescence; the latter was merely her nature, whereas the stiffness was a facade, a distraction, a calculated move. She sought a way out, and, fortunately, found one instantly.

Her eyes scanned the room and seized on an excuse. "Lady Wells is tired of waiting: she's coming to us." Densher saw, indeed, that she was approaching, though there was still some distance for their visitor to cover, which meant he still had time. "If you refuse to understand me, I refuse to understand you.

Translation

Her gaze swept the room, landing on a plausible escape. "Lady Wells is weary of delay: she's coming this way." Densher saw, in fact, that she was approaching, though their guest had a ways to go, buying him a little more time. "If you won't hear me, I won't hear you."

I will not do anything." "Nothing?" It was as if she tried for the minute to plead. "I'll do nothing. I'll go off before you.

Translation

"I won't do anything."

"Nothing?" It was as though she tried to plead for a moment. "I won't do anything. I'll leave before you do."

I'll go to-morrow." He was to have afterwards the sense of her having then, as the phrase was—and for vulgar triumphs too—seen he meant it. She looked again at Lady Wells, who was nearer, but she quickly came back. "And if I do understand?"

Translation

"I'll go tomorrow." Later, he would feel that she had then, as they said—and even for cheap victories—realized he was serious. She looked again at Lady Wells, who was closer, but then returned her gaze to him. "And if I do understand?"

"I'll do everything." She found anew a pretext in her approaching friend: he was fairly playing with her pride. He had never, he then knew, tasted, in all his relation with her, of anything so sharp—too sharp for mere sweetness—as the vividness with which he saw himself master in the conflict. "Well, I understand."

Translation

"I'll do everything." She seized upon her approaching friend as a new excuse: he was toying with her pride. He realized then that he had never, in their entire relationship, experienced anything so cutting—too sharp to be mere pleasure—as the vividness with which he saw himself as the victor in their struggle. "Fine, I understand."

"On your honour?" "Nothing?" It was as if she was trying to argue, even just for a moment. "I won't do anything. I'll leave before you.

Translation

"Your word?" "Nothing at all?" It was as though she was trying to press the point, if only briefly. "I won't do anything. I'll be gone before you."

I'll leave tomorrow." Later, he would remember that she had realized, as the saying goes—and even for cheap victories—that he was serious. She glanced at Lady Wells, who was closer, but quickly turned back to him. "And if I do understand what you're saying?"

Translation

"I'll be leaving tomorrow." Later, he would recall that she had understood, as they say—even for a small triumph—that he was being truthful. She glanced at Lady Wells, who was nearby, but swiftly returned her gaze to him. "And if I do understand what you mean?"

"Then I'll do whatever you want." She used her friend approaching as an excuse: he was clearly toying with her pride. He realized then that, throughout their entire relationship, he had never experienced anything so intense, so far from simple sweetness, as the feeling of being completely in control of the situation. "Okay, I understand."

Translation

"Then I'll do whatever you want," she said, using the excuse of her friend's approach. He was clearly toying with her pride. He realized then that, throughout their entire relationship, he had never experienced anything so intense, so far from simple sweetness, as the feeling of being completely in control of the situation. "Okay, I understand."

"Do you swear it?" "On my honour." "You'll come?" "I'll come."

Translation

"Do you promise?"

"On my word."

"You'll come?"

"I'll come."

Chapter 14

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
After leaving a woman, a man walks to a café instead of going home. He sits there motionless for three hours, drinking and smoking cigarettes. He decides his plan is to remain still and do nothing. For the next three weeks, he adheres to this plan. After more than twenty days have passed, he goes to the woman's palace at tea-time but is told by a gondolier that she is not receiving visitors. He sends for a servant named Eugenio, who meets him in a gallery. Eugenio tells him the ladies are a "leetle" fatigued. Eugenio then escorts him to the door, and they do not speak of him returning. The man walks through the stormy weather to the Piazza. He walks around the arcade three times before stopping in front of Florian's café, where he sees an acquaintance, Lord Mark, sitting at a table. Lord Mark turns his head and they look at each other, but they do not acknowledge one another. The man resumes walking. He circles the arcade again twice and sees Lord Mark still there. On his next pass, Lord Mark is gone. The man stays away from the palace for three days. He paces in his rooms, watching for a messenger, but no note comes. When he goes out, he walks around the Square, checking the cafés. On the afternoon of the third day, his landlady opens the door and shows in a visitor, Mrs. Stringham, who is wet from the rain.

It was after they had gone that he truly felt the difference, which was most to be felt moreover in his faded old rooms. He had recovered from the first a part of his attachment to this scene of contemplation, within sight, as it was, of the Rialto bridge, on the hither side of that arch of associations and the left going up the Canal; he had seen it in a particular light, to which, more and more, his mind and his hands adjusted it; but the interest the place now wore for him had risen at a bound, becoming a force that, on the spot, completely engaged and absorbed him, and relief from which—if relief was the name—he could find only by getting away and out of reach. What had come to pass within his walls lingered there as an obsession importunate to all his senses; it lived again, as a cluster of pleasant memories, at every hour and in every object; it made everything but itself irrelevant and tasteless. It remained, in a word, a conscious watchful presence, active on its own side, for ever to be reckoned with, in face of which the effort at detachment was scarcely less futile than frivolous.

Translation

It was only after they left that he truly felt the change, most keenly in his faded old rooms. He had partly recovered from his initial attachment to this place of contemplation, overlooking the Rialto bridge on the near side of the arch of associations, along the left side of the Canal. He had viewed it in a particular light, to which his mind and hands increasingly adapted. But the interest the place now held for him had suddenly intensified, becoming a force that completely engaged and absorbed him on the spot. He could only find relief—if that's what it was—by leaving, by getting away. What had occurred within his walls lingered there as an obsession that plagued all his senses. It relived itself as a cluster of pleasant memories, at every hour, in every object, making everything else irrelevant and tasteless. In a word, it remained a conscious, watchful presence, active on its own, always to be reckoned with. The effort to detach himself was almost as futile as it was frivolous.

Kate had come to him; it was only once—and this not from any failure of their need, but from such impossibilities, for bravery alike and for subtlety, as there was at the last no blinking; yet she had come, that once, to stay, as people called it; and what survived of her, what reminded and insisted, was something he couldn't have banished if he had wished. Luckily he didn't wish, even though there might be for a man almost a shade of the awful in so unqualified a consequence of his act. It had simply worked, his idea, the idea he had made her accept; and all erect before him, really covering the ground as far as he could see, was the fact of the gained success that this represented. It was, otherwise, but the fact of the idea as directly applied, as converted from a luminous conception into an historic truth.

Translation

Kate had come to him; it only happened once—and not because their need had failed, but because of impossibilities, for both courage and subtlety, that could not be ignored in the end; yet she had come, that one time, to stay, as people put it; and what remained of her, what reminded and insisted, was something he couldn't have gotten rid of even if he'd wanted to. Luckily, he didn't want to, even though a man might find almost a hint of something awful in such an unqualified result of his action. It had simply worked, his idea, the idea he had made her accept; and standing before him, truly dominating everything he could see, was the reality of the success this represented. Otherwise, it was just the fact of the idea as directly applied, as changed from a brilliant concept into an historical truth.

He had known it before but as desired and urged, as convincingly insisted on for the help it would render; so that at present, with the help rendered, it seemed to acknowledge its office and to set up, for memory and faith, an insistence of its own. He had in fine judged his friend's pledge in advance as an inestimable value, and what he must now know his case for was that of a possession of the value to the full. Wasn't it perhaps even rather the value that possessed him, kept him thinking of it and waiting on it, turning round and round it and making sure of it again from this side and that? He truly felt the difference after they left, particularly in his old, faded rooms.

Translation

He had known it before, but as something he desired and pushed for, something he had insisted on so convincingly for the sake of the assistance it would provide. So that now, with that assistance provided, it seemed to recognize its purpose and establish, for memory and trust, a demand of its own. He had, in short, deemed his friend's promise beforehand as invaluable, and what he now had to confirm was that he possessed that value completely. Wasn't it perhaps the value itself that possessed him, keeping him focused on it, waiting for it, circling around it, and reassuring himself of it from every angle? He truly felt the difference after they left, especially in his old, worn rooms.

He had rediscovered his fondness for this place, which offered views of the Rialto Bridge, just before that iconic arch, on the left side of the canal. He had come to see it in a specific light, a perspective that his mind and senses had adapted to. However, the place's appeal had suddenly intensified, becoming a powerful force that completely captivated him. The only escape, if one could call it that, was to leave and distance himself.

Translation

He'd rediscovered his affection for the place, with its views of the Rialto Bridge, just before the celebrated arch, on the canal's left. He'd come to see it in a specific light, a perspective his mind and senses had adjusted to. But the place's allure had abruptly intensified, becoming a powerful force that fully captivated him. The only recourse, if it could be called that, was to depart and create distance.

What had happened within his walls lingered like an obsession, demanding his attention; it resurfaced as pleasant memories in every hour and in every object, rendering everything else irrelevant. It remained a conscious, watchful presence, always a factor, against which any attempt at detachment was both futile and frivolous. Kate had come to him, only once. Not due to a lack of need, but because of insurmountable obstacles, for both boldness and subtlety.

Translation

The events within his life there had become an inescapable fixation. They were insistent, resurfacing as fond recollections, suffusing every moment, every possession, until nothing else seemed to matter. This experience remained a vigilant presence, a constant variable that rendered any effort to move on both pointless and absurd. Kate had come to him, but only once. It wasn't because there was no desire, but because of insurmountable barriers, ones that required both courage and finesse.

Yet she had come, and stayed in a manner of speaking, and what remained of her, what prompted him to remember, was something he couldn't have gotten rid of if he had wanted to. Fortunately, he didn't want to, even though the consequences of his actions might seem almost terrifying to a man. His plan had worked; the idea he had convinced her to accept. And there it was, standing before him, dominating everything he could see, the successful outcome of his plan.

Translation

And yet, she had arrived, lingering in a sense, and the residue of her, the reason he still remembered, was something he couldn't have discarded if he'd tried. Fortunately, he hadn't wanted to, even though the implications of what he'd done might appear terrifying to a person. His strategy had succeeded; the notion he'd persuaded her to embrace. And there it was, present before him, commanding everything he saw, the triumphant result of his scheme.

It was the idea realized, transformed from a brilliant concept into a historical fact. He had known it before, but as something he desired and pushed for, insisting it would help. Now that it had, it seemed to take on a life of its own, to assert itself in his memory. He had, in essence, anticipated the value of his friend's promise, and what he now needed to understand was that he possessed something of immense value.

Translation

The concept had become real, shifting from a promising notion to an established truth. He'd understood this previously, but as a goal he'd sought and advocated for, certain it would be beneficial. Now that it had come to pass, it seemed to develop its own existence, solidifying itself in his mind. He had, in effect, foreseen the importance of his friend's commitment, and what he now needed to grasp was that he held something of great worth.

Wasn't it perhaps the value that now possessed him, kept him thinking about it, waiting for it, examining it from every angle, constantly reassessing it? It played for him—certainly in this prime afterglow—the part of a treasure kept at home in safety and sanctity, something he was sure of finding in its place when, with each return, he worked his heavy old key in the lock. The door had but to open for him to be with it again and for it to be all there; so intensely there that, as we say, no other act was possible to him than the renewed act, almost the hallucination, of intimacy. Wherever he looked or sat or stood, to whatever aspect he gave for the instant the advantage, it was in view as nothing of the moment, nothing begotten of time or of chance could be, or ever would; it was in view as, when the curtain has risen, the play on the stage is in view, night after night, for the fiddlers.

Translation

Wasn't it possible that this value now possessed him, kept him occupied, waiting, examining it from every possible perspective, constantly reevaluating it? Certainly, in the wake of this triumph, it acted for him like a treasure held safely and sacredly at home, something he knew would be in its place whenever he returned and used his old, heavy key in the lock. The door only needed to open for him to be with it again, for it to be completely there; so intensely there that, as they say, no other action was possible for him except the repeated action, almost the hallucination, of intimacy. Wherever he looked or sat or stood, whatever aspect he focused on at any given moment, it was present, unlike anything born of time or chance, or anything that ever would be; it was there like the play on stage, night after night, for the fiddlers after the curtain has risen.

He remained thus, in his own theatre, in his single person, perpetual orchestra to the ordered drama, the confirmed "run"; playing low and slow, moreover, in the regular way, for the situations of most importance. No other visitor was to come to him; he met, he bumped occasionally, in the Piazza or in his walks, against claimants to acquaintance, remembered or forgotten, at present mostly effusive, sometimes even inquisitive; but he gave no address and encouraged no approach; he couldn't for his life, he felt, have opened his door to a third person. Such a person would have interrupted him, would have profaned his secret or perhaps have guessed it; would at any rate have broken the spell of what he conceived himself—in the absence of anything "to show"—to be inwardly doing. He was giving himself up—that was quite enough—to the general feeling of his renewed engagement to fidelity.

Translation

He remained, then, in his own theater, a one-man show, a perpetual orchestra for the well-rehearsed drama, the established run. He played quietly and slowly, methodically, for the most significant moments. No other visitors were allowed. He encountered people, bumped into acquaintances in the Piazza or on his walks, some remembered, some forgotten, now mostly friendly, sometimes even curious. But he gave no address and encouraged no contact. He couldn't, he felt, open his door to a third party. Such a person would have interrupted him, would have violated his secret or perhaps guessed it; they would have broken the spell of what he believed he was doing internally, since he had nothing to show. He was surrendering himself—that was enough—to the overall feeling of his renewed commitment to loyalty.

The force of the engagement, the quantity of the article to be supplied, the special solidity of the contract, the way, above all, as a service for which the price named by him had been magnificently paid, his equivalent office was to take effect—such items might well fill his consciousness when there was nothing from outside to interfere. Never was a consciousness more rounded and fastened down over what filled it; which is precisely what we have spoken of as, in its degree, the oppression of success, the somewhat chilled state—tending to the solitary—of supreme recognition. If it was slightly awful to feel so justified, this was by the loss of the warmth of the element of mystery. The lucid reigned instead of it, and it was into the lucid that he sat and stared.

Translation

The weight of his commitment, the scope of the project, the particular firmness of the agreement, and, above all, the way his role—a service for which he had been generously compensated—was about to begin: these were the things that occupied his thoughts when nothing from the outside world intruded. Never had a mind been more completely focused on its contents. This is exactly what we have described as, in a way, the burden of achievement, the somewhat cold, isolating condition of ultimate recognition. It was a little unsettling to feel so vindicated, a feeling born from the absence of the warmth of the unknown. Clarity ruled in its place, and it was into this clarity that he gazed, unblinking.

He shook himself out of it a dozen times a day, tried to break by his own act his constant still communion. It wasn't still communion she had meant to bequeath him; it was the very different business of that kind of fidelity of which the other name was careful action. In this late stage of his life, it felt like a treasure he kept safe and sacred at home. He knew he could find it there, secure and waiting, whenever he returned and used his old key to unlock the door.

Translation

He shook himself out of it a dozen times a day, attempting to interrupt his constant, internal connection. That unbroken communion wasn't what she'd intended to leave him; it was instead the very different concept of a loyalty synonymous with deliberate action. Late in his life, it felt like a treasure he kept safe and sacred at home. He knew he could find it there, secure and waiting, whenever he returned and used his old key to unlock the door.

The moment he opened the door, he would be reunited with it, and it would be completely present. He was so immersed in it that all he could do was engage in a renewed act of intimacy, almost a hallucination. Wherever he looked, sat, or stood, no matter what he focused on, it was visible, unlike anything else from that moment, anything created by time or chance. It was there like the play on stage, night after night, for the orchestra.

Translation

The instant the door swung open, it would be there again, fully realized. He was consumed by it, and the only thing he could do was surrender to the renewed intimacy, a kind of waking dream. No matter where he looked, sat, or stood, regardless of what held his attention, it was there, distinct from everything else in that moment, separate from anything forged by time or circumstance. It was present like a nightly performance for the orchestra.

He remained in his own personal theater, a one-man orchestra to the carefully structured drama, the long "run," playing slowly and quietly, as was proper for the most important scenes. No other visitors were allowed. He occasionally encountered people in the square or on walks who claimed to know him, some he remembered and some he didn't, but they were mostly overly friendly or sometimes curious. He gave no address and discouraged any approach.

Translation

He remained in his own private theater, a one-man orchestra to a meticulously constructed drama. The long "run" played slowly and quietly, as it should for the most important scenes. No other guests were permitted. He sometimes encountered people in the square or on walks who claimed to know him. Some he remembered, others he did not. They were often overly friendly or occasionally curious. He provided no address and discouraged any attempts to approach him.

He couldn't, under any circumstances, open his door to a third person. That person would have interrupted him, violated his secret, or perhaps even guessed it. They would have broken the spell of what he felt he was doing internally, given the lack of anything concrete to show. He was surrendering himself—that was enough—to the general feeling of his renewed commitment to loyalty.

Translation

Under no circumstances could he open his door to a third party. Such a person would have interrupted him, violated his secret, or perhaps even understood it. They would have broken the spell of what he felt he was doing internally, given the lack of anything concrete to present. He was surrendering himself—that was enough—to the general feeling of his renewed commitment to loyalty.

The power of this commitment, the magnitude of what he had to offer, the unique strength of the agreement, and, above all, the way it was a service for which he had been generously compensated. Performing his equivalent duty might well occupy his thoughts when nothing external intervened. Never was a mind more fully formed and fixated on what filled it, which is exactly what we mean when we speak of the oppressive weight of success, the somewhat cold, solitary state of ultimate recognition. Although it was a little unsettling to feel so validated, this came at the cost of the warmth of mystery.

Translation

The significance of his dedication, the sheer scale of his contribution, the singular force of their accord, and, most crucially, the nature of his service, for which he had been handsomely rewarded. Fulfilling his designated role could easily consume his attention when undisturbed by the outside world. Never had a mind been so completely shaped and focused on its contents, which perfectly embodies the oppressive burden of achievement, the somewhat isolating reality of ultimate validation. Although the experience of such affirmation was a bit unsettling, it came at the expense of the comforting obscurity of the unknown.

Clarity reigned instead, and he sat and stared into it. He shook himself out of it many times a day, trying to disrupt his continuous silent communication. That silent communion was not what she had intended to leave him; it was the very different act of that kind of loyalty, which was also known as careful action. Nothing, he perfectly knew, was less like careful action than the immersion he enjoyed at home.

Translation

He was completely lucid, and he simply observed it. He'd snap out of it frequently throughout the day, trying to break the spell of the perpetual silence. That silent connection was not the legacy she wanted to leave; it was the manifestation of a distinct kind of devotion, which also presented itself as measured conduct. He understood perfectly that nothing was less like measured conduct than the self-absorption he embraced within the walls of his home.

The actual grand queerness was that to be faithful to Kate he had positively to take his eyes, his arms, his lips straight off her—he had to let her alone. He had to remember it was time to go to the palace—which in truth was a mercy, since the check was not less effectual than imperative. What it came to, fortunately, as yet, was that when he closed the door behind him for an absence he always shut her in. Shut her out—it came to that rather, when once he had got a little away; and before he reached the palace, much more after hearing at his heels the bang of the greater portone, he felt free enough not to know his position as oppressively false.

Translation

The truly remarkable paradox was that, to remain devoted to Kate, he had to physically detach himself from her—he had to leave her be. He had to remind himself it was time to go to the palace—which, truthfully, was a saving grace, since the check was just as effective as it was obligatory. What it amounted to, fortunately, for now, was that when he closed the door behind him for a time, he always shut her in. Shut her out—it was more like that, really, once he was a bit distant; and before he reached the palace, even more so after hearing the large door slam behind him, he felt free enough not to consider his situation as oppressively false.

As Kate was all in his poor rooms, and not a ghost of her left for the grander, it was only on reflexion that the falseness came out; so long as he left it to the mercy of beneficent chance it offered him no face and made of him no claim that he couldn't meet without aggravation of his inward sense. This aggravation had been his original horror; yet what—in Milly's presence, each day—was horror doing with him but virtually letting him off? He shouldn't perhaps get off to the end; there was time enough still for the possibility of shame to pounce. Still, however, he did constantly a little more what he liked best, and that kept him for the time more safe.

Translation

Because Kate was entirely contained within his humble rooms, and there was no trace of her remaining for the more distinguished places, it was only through reflection that the falseness emerged. As long as he left it to the mercy of benevolent chance, it presented no challenge to him, nor did it make any demands that he couldn't handle without exacerbating his inner turmoil. This torment had been his initial fear, yet what—in Milly's presence, each day—was fear doing with him but effectively absolving him? He probably wouldn't be fully spared until the end; there was still ample time for the possibility of shame to strike. Nevertheless, he was consistently doing a bit more of what he enjoyed most, and that kept him safe, for the time being.

What he liked best was, in any case, to know why things were as he felt them; and he knew it pretty well, in this case, ten days after the retreat of his other friends. He then fairly perceived that—even putting their purity of motive at its highest—it was neither Kate nor he who made his strange relation to Milly, who made her own, so far as it might be, innocent; it was neither of them who practically purged it—if practically purged it was. Milly herself did everything—so far at least as he was concerned—Milly herself, and Milly's house, and Milly's hospitality, and Milly's manner, and Milly's character, and, perhaps still more than anything else, Milly's imagination, Mrs. Stringham and Sir Luke indeed a little aiding: whereby he knew the blessing of a fair pretext to ask himself what more he had to do.

Translation

What he liked best, regardless, was to understand the reasons behind his feelings. And he understood it fairly well, in this case, ten days after his other friends had departed. He realized then that—even giving them the benefit of the doubt—it wasn't Kate or himself who shaped his peculiar relationship with Milly, or Milly's, as far as it was, innocence. It wasn't either of them who truly purified it—if it was indeed purified. Milly herself did everything—at least as far as he was concerned—Milly herself, and Milly's house, and Milly's hospitality, and Milly's demeanor, and Milly's character, and perhaps even more than all that, Milly's imagination, though Mrs. Stringham and Sir Luke did contribute a bit: which gave him the fortunate opportunity to wonder what more he should do.

Something incalculable wrought for them—for him and Kate; something outside, beyond, above themselves, and doubtless ever so much better than they: which wasn't a reason, however—its being so much better—for them not to profit by it. Not to profit by it, so far as profit could be reckoned, would have been to go directly against it; and the spirit of generosity at present engendered in Densher could have felt no greater pang than by his having to go directly against Milly. He knew perfectly well that his home life was the opposite of careful planning. The strange thing was that in order to be true to Kate, he had to take his attention, his embraces, his kisses away from her—he had to leave her alone.

Translation

Something incalculable worked for them—for him and Kate; something outside, beyond, above themselves, and undoubtedly far better than they: which wasn't a reason, however—its being so much better—for them not to benefit from it. To not benefit from it, as far as benefit could be calculated, would have been to directly oppose it; and the generosity presently developing in Densher could have felt no greater pain than if he had to directly oppose Milly. He knew perfectly well that his home life was the opposite of careful planning. The strange thing was that in order to be true to Kate, he had to take his attention, his embraces, his kisses away from her—he had to leave her alone.

He had to remember that it was time to go to the palace—which, in truth, was a relief, since the interruption was both effective and necessary. The fortunate thing was that, for now, when he closed the door behind him to leave, he was always shutting her in. Or, rather, shutting her out—that's what it became, once he had gotten a little distance; and before he reached the palace, and even more after hearing the great door slam shut behind him, he felt free enough not to feel his situation was oppressively false. Since Kate was entirely present in his modest rooms, and there wasn't a trace of her left for the grander setting, it was only upon reflection that the falseness emerged.

Translation

He had to remember that it was time to go to the palace—which, in truth, was a relief, since the interruption was both effective and necessary. The fortunate thing was that, for now, when he closed the door behind him to leave, he was always shutting her in. Or, rather, shutting her out—that's what it became, once he had gotten a little distance; and before he reached the palace, and even more after hearing the great door slam shut behind him, he felt free enough not to feel his situation was oppressively false. Since Kate was entirely present in his modest rooms, and there wasn't a trace of her left for the grander setting, it was only upon reflection that the falseness emerged.

As long as he left it to the mercy of benevolent chance, it presented no challenge to him and made no demand that he couldn't meet without making his inner turmoil worse. This worsening of his inner feelings had been his original horror; yet what—in Milly's presence, every day—was horror doing but effectively letting him off the hook? He probably wouldn't get away with it forever; there was still plenty of time for shame to catch up with him. However, he did constantly indulge in what he liked most, and that kept him safer, for the time being.

Translation

So long as he relied on good luck, it didn't bother him, and he could handle it all without making himself feel worse. His real dread had been the way he felt inside, but what—with Milly there, all the time—was actually happening except that he was getting away with it? He knew he wouldn't be able to keep it up indefinitely; the shame would eventually come. But he was getting away with his favorite things, and that kept him safe, for now.

What he liked best, in any case, was understanding why things felt the way they did; and he understood it pretty well, in this case, ten days after his other friends had departed. He then clearly realized that—even assuming their motives were entirely pure—it was neither Kate nor he who shaped his unusual relationship with Milly, who made hers, as far as possible, innocent; it wasn't either of them who practically purified it—if it was, in fact, purified at all. Milly herself did everything—at least as far as he was concerned—Milly herself, and Milly's house, and Milly's generosity, and Milly's manner, and Milly's character, and, perhaps even more than anything else, Milly's imagination, Mrs. Stringham and Sir Luke indeed helping a little: which gave him a good excuse to ask himself what more he needed to do.

Translation

What he enjoyed most, regardless, was figuring out why he felt the way he did. In this instance, ten days after his other friends had left, he understood it well enough. He understood clearly that, even if their intentions were completely above board, neither Kate nor he had shaped his peculiar relationship with Milly, who kept her own, to the extent that it was possible, harmless. Neither of them had truly cleansed it—assuming that it was cleansed at all. Milly alone had done everything—at least as far as he was concerned—Milly herself, Milly's home, Milly's generosity, Milly's demeanor, Milly's personality, and, perhaps most of all, Milly's imagination.
