Mrs. Stringham and Sir Luke offered some assistance, which gave him a convenient reason to consider what else he needed to do.

Something indescribable worked on their behalf—for him and Kate; something outside, beyond, above them both, and undoubtedly far better than they were: which, however, wasn't a reason—because it was so much better—for them not to benefit from it. Not to benefit from it, as much as benefit could be measured, would have been to go directly against it; and the feeling of generosity that Densher now felt could have experienced no greater pain than if he had to go directly against Milly. To go with her was the thing, so far as she could herself go; which, from the moment her tenure of her loved palace stretched on, was possible but by his remaining near her. This remaining was of course on the face of it the most "marked" of demonstrations—which was exactly why Kate had required it; it was so marked that on the very evening of the day it had taken effect Milly herself hadn't been able not to reach out to him, with an exquisite awkwardness, for some account of it.

Translation

Something indescribable worked on their behalf—for him and Kate; something outside, beyond, above them both, and undoubtedly far better than they were: which, however, wasn't a reason—because it was so much better—for them not to benefit from it. Not to benefit from it, as much as benefit could be measured, would have been to go directly against it; and the feeling of generosity that Densher now felt could have experienced no greater pain than if he had to go directly against Milly. To go with her was the thing, so far as she could herself go; which, from the moment her tenure of her beloved palace stretched on, was possible only by his remaining near her. This remaining was of course on the face of it the most "marked" of demonstrations—which was exactly why Kate had required it; it was so marked that on the very evening of the day it had taken effect Milly herself hadn't been able not to reach out to him, with an exquisite awkwardness, for some account of it.

It was as if she had wanted from him some name that, now they were to be almost alone together, they could, for their further ease, know it and call it by—it being, after all, almost rudimentary that his presence, of which the absence of the others made quite a different thing, couldn't but have for himself some definite basis. She only wondered about the basis it would have for himself, and how he would describe it; that would quite do for her—it even would have done for her, he could see, had he produced some reason merely trivial, had he said he was waiting for money or clothes, for letters or for orders from Fleet Street, without which, as she might have heard, newspaper men never took a step. He hadn't in the event quite sunk to that; but he had none the less had there with her, that night, on Mrs. Stringham's leaving them alone—Mrs.

Translation

It was as if she had wanted him to name it, that thing—so that now that they were going to be almost alone, they could, for their ease going forward, know it and call it by its name. It was almost elementary that his presence, which the others' absence had made something quite different, had to have some concrete basis for him. She only wondered about the basis it had for him, and how he would describe it; that would have satisfied her—it even would have done for her, he could see, if he'd offered some trivial excuse, had he said he was waiting for money or clothes, for letters or orders from Fleet Street, without which, as she might have heard, newspapermen never took a step. He hadn't, in the end, quite stooped to that; but he had all the same offered her, that night, after Mrs. Stringham had left them alone—Mrs.

Stringham proved really prodigious—his acquaintance with a shade of awkwardness darker than any Milly could know. He had supposed himself beforehand, on the question of what he was doing or pretending, in possession of some tone that would serve; but there were three minutes of his feeling incapable of promptness quite in the same degree in which a gentleman whose pocket has been picked feels incapable of purchase. It even didn't help him, oddly, that he was sure Kate would in some way have spoken for him—or rather not so much in some way as in one very particular way. He hadn't asked her, at the last, what she might, in the connexion, have said; nothing would have induced him to put such a question after she had been to see him: his lips were so sealed by that passage, his spirit in fact so hushed, in respect to any charge upon her freedom.

Translation

Stringham revealed himself to be truly remarkable—his familiarity with a shade of discomfort more profound than any Milly could comprehend. He had, beforehand, regarding the matter of his actions or pretenses, believed himself to have a suitable demeanor ready; but for three minutes, he found himself unable to respond with the same alacrity as a gentleman who has had his pocket picked finds himself unable to make a purchase. Strangely enough, it didn't even aid him that he was certain Kate would have, in some manner, spoken on his behalf—or rather, not in some general way, but in a very specific way. He hadn't, ultimately, inquired of her what she might have said in relation to it; nothing could have made him ask such a question after her visit: his lips were so sealed by that encounter, his spirit, in truth, so subdued, concerning any imposition upon her liberty.

There was something he could only therefore read back into the probabilities, and when he left the palace an hour afterwards it was with a sense of having breathed there, in the very air, the truth he had been guessing. The most important thing was to stay with her, as much as she could. Since her time in the palace was extended, this was only possible if he remained close to her. This staying, of course, was obviously a very clear demonstration of something, which was exactly why Kate wanted it.

Translation

He could only infer certain things from the likelihood of events. When he left the palace an hour later, he felt as though he had inhaled the truth he'd been suspecting, as though it were part of the very air itself. The most crucial thing was to remain with her, as much as possible. Since her time in the palace was prolonged, this was only achievable if he stayed near her. This proximity, of course, was clearly a display of something, which was precisely what Kate desired.

It was so noticeable that on the very evening it happened, Milly herself couldn't help but reach out to him, with a delicate sense of unease, to hear his explanation. It was as if she wanted him to give a name to it, a name they could both use easily, now that they were going to be almost alone together. It seemed obvious that his presence, which was so different when the others were gone, must have some specific reason behind it. She was only curious about what that reason might be for him, and how he would explain it.

Translation

The shift was so palpable that on the evening it occurred, Milly couldn't help but reach out to him, a subtle apprehension guiding her, seeking his account. She seemed to want him to label it, to give it a shared name, now that they were to be almost exclusively in each other's company. It was clear that his presence, so markedly altered in the absence of others, must have a distinct purpose. She was simply curious about what that purpose was for him, and how he would articulate it.

That would be perfectly fine with her. It would have even been enough for her, he realized, if he had given some trivial reason, such as saying he was waiting for money or clothes, or for letters or instructions from work, since, as she might have heard, newspaper people never moved without those. He hadn't gone quite that far. Nevertheless, that night, after Mrs.

Translation

That would have been perfectly acceptable to her. It would even have been sufficient for her, he realized, if he had provided some inconsequential explanation, like claiming he was waiting for money, or clothing, or letters, or work instructions, since, as she might have heard, people in the newspaper business never relocated without those things. He hadn't gone quite that far. Regardless, that night, after Mrs.

Stringham had left them alone—Mrs. Stringham proved to be truly wonderful—he had shown her a level of awkwardness she couldn't know. He had thought beforehand, when considering what he was doing or pretending to do, that he had a tone of voice that would work. However, he had felt incapable of responding quickly, just like a gentleman who has had his pocket picked, is incapable of making a purchase.

Translation

Stringham had gone, and Mrs. Stringham had proven to be a delight, he had revealed a level of ineptitude to her that she couldn't possibly comprehend. He'd believed beforehand, considering his actions or his charade, that he had a suitable speaking style. But he had been unable to react swiftly, just like a gentleman who'd had his pocket picked, suddenly unable to make a purchase.

It didn't even help him, strangely, that he was sure Kate would have spoken on his behalf in some way, or rather, not in some way, but in a very particular way. He hadn't asked her what she might have said about it, in the end. Nothing would have made him ask such a question after she had visited him; he was bound by that visit, and his spirit was quieted, concerning anything that would restrict her freedom. Therefore, he could only read into the possibilities.

Translation

Strangely enough, it didn't help him to imagine Kate interceding for him, not just generally, but in a very specific way. He hadn't asked her what she might have said, ultimately. Nothing could have made him ask such a question after her visit; he was bound by that visit, and it calmed him, insofar as anything that might limit her freedom was concerned. Thus, he was left to speculate.

When he left the palace an hour later, he had the feeling that he had breathed the truth he had been guessing, right into the very air. Just this perception it was, however, that had made him for the time ugly to himself in his awkwardness. It was horrible, with this creature, to be awkward; it was odious to be seeking excuses for the relation that involved it. Any relation that involved it was by the very fact as much discredited as a dish would be at dinner if one had to take medicine as a sauce.

Translation

An hour after he left the palace, he felt as if he had exhaled the truth he'd suspected, right into the open air. This realization, however, made him despise his own clumsiness in that moment. It was awful to be awkward around her; it was loathsome to be searching for justifications for the connection he felt. Any connection that involved her was automatically tainted, as if a dinner dish were ruined by the addition of medicinal sauce.

What Kate would have said in one of the young women's last talks was that—if Milly absolutely must have the truth about it—Mr. Densher was staying because she had really seen no way but to require it of him. If he stayed he didn't follow her—or didn't appear to her aunt to be doing so; and when she kept him from following her Mrs. Lowder couldn't pretend, in scenes, the renewal of which at this time of day was painful, that she after all didn't snub him as she might.

Translation

What Kate would have said, during one of the young women's final conversations, was that—if Milly absolutely needed to know the truth—Mr. Densher was staying because she’d seen no other option but to make him. If he stayed, he wasn't following her—or at least didn't seem to be, according to her aunt; and when she kept him from following her, Mrs. Lowder couldn't pretend, in scenes which were painful to revisit now, that she hadn't snubbed him, as she was capable of doing.

She did nothing in fact but snub him—wouldn't that have been part of the story?—only Aunt Maud's suspicions were of the sort that had repeatedly to be dealt with. He had been, by the same token, reasonable enough—as he now, for that matter, well might; he had consented to oblige them, aunt and niece, by giving the plainest sign possible that he could exist away from London. To exist away from London was to exist away from Kate Croy—which was a gain, much appreciated, to the latter's comfort. There was a minute, at this hour, out of Densher's three, during which he knew the terror of Milly's uttering some such allusion to their friend's explanation as he must meet with words that wouldn't destroy it.

Translation

She did nothing but snub him—wouldn’t that have been part of the narrative? But Aunt Maud’s suspicions were the kind that required constant management. He had, accordingly, been reasonable enough—as he certainly could be now; he’d agreed to accommodate them, aunt and niece, by providing the clearest possible indication that he could survive outside of London. Existing outside of London meant existing away from Kate Croy—which was a benefit, greatly appreciated, for her own well-being. There was a moment, at this time, within Densher’s three, when he knew the terror of Milly making some reference to their friend’s reasoning, and that he would have to respond with words that wouldn't damage it.

To destroy it was to destroy everything, to destroy probably Kate herself, to destroy in particular by a breach of faith still uglier than anything else the beauty of their own last passage. He had given her his word of honour that if she would come to him he would act absolutely in her sense, and he had done so with a full enough vision of what her sense implied. What it implied for one thing was that to-night in the great saloon, noble in its half-lighted beauty, and straight in the white face of his young hostess, divine in her trust, or at any rate inscrutable in her mercy—what it implied was that he should lie with his lips. The single thing, of all things, that could save him from it would be Milly's letting him off after having thus scared him.

Translation

To destroy it meant destroying everything. It would probably destroy Kate herself, and specifically destroy the beauty of their last moments together through a betrayal that would be uglier than anything else. He had promised her, on his honor, that if she came to him, he would do exactly as she wished, and he’d understood completely what she wanted. What she wanted, for one thing, was that he would tonight, in the grand saloon, beautiful in the dim light, and facing his young hostess’s pale face, divine in her trust or, at the very least, inscrutable in her mercy—what it implied was that he would lie. The only thing that could save him would be if Milly would let him off the hook after having frightened him like this.

What made her mercy inscrutable was that if she had already more than once saved him it was yet apparently without knowing how nearly he was lost. It was this realization that made him feel unattractive because of his discomfort. It was awful to be awkward with her; it was repulsive to have to make excuses for the situation. Any situation that caused this awkwardness was immediately ruined, like a meal ruined by having to take medicine with it.

Translation

What made her mercy inscrutable was that she had saved him, and more than once, though it was seemingly without her realizing how close he had come to ruin. This realization made him feel unattractive because of his discomfort. It was awful to feel awkward around her; it was repulsive to have to offer excuses for the situation. Any situation that caused this awkwardness was immediately ruined, like a meal spoiled by having to take medicine with it.

As Kate would have said in one of their last conversations, if Milly absolutely needed to know the truth, Mr. Densher was staying because Kate had seen no other way to make him. If he stayed, he didn't follow her—or at least he didn't appear to be doing so to Mrs. Lowder.

Translation

As Kate would have said in one of their last talks, if Milly absolutely had to know the truth, Mr. Densher was staying because Kate had found no other way to get him to. If he stayed, he wasn't following her—or at least, he didn't seem to be doing so to Mrs. Lowder.

When she prevented him from following her, Mrs. Lowder couldn't pretend, in those uncomfortable scenes, that she wasn't still being rude to him. In fact, she did nothing but be rude to him—wouldn't that be part of the story? But Aunt Maud’s suspicions were something that had to be dealt with repeatedly.

Translation

When she kept him from following her, Mrs. Lowder couldn't deny, during those unpleasant moments, that she was still treating him badly. Indeed, she did nothing but treat him badly—wasn't that a significant part of the narrative? Yet Aunt Maud's suspicions were something that demanded constant attention.

Likewise, he had been reasonable enough—as he certainly could be now; he had agreed to help them, aunt and niece, by clearly showing that he could live apart from London. To live away from London was to live away from Kate Croy—which was a positive thing for her. There was a moment, at this time, in Densher's three hours, where he feared Milly would say something about their friend’s explanation. He knew he'd have to respond with words that wouldn't ruin it.

Translation

Similarly, he’d been reasonable—as he could certainly be now. He’d agreed to help them, aunt and niece, by proving he could live apart from London. To live away from London was to live away from Kate Croy—which was beneficial for her. There was a moment, within Densher's three hours, where he worried Milly would mention their friend’s explanation. He knew he'd have to respond with words that wouldn't spoil it.

To ruin it was to ruin everything, likely to ruin Kate herself, and to ruin in a particularly faithless way the beauty of their final time together. He had promised her that if she came to him, he would do exactly as she wanted, and he understood fully what she meant. What she meant was that tonight, in the grand, dimly lit room, facing his young hostess's pale face, which was angelic in its trust, or at least impossible to understand in its kindness, he would have to lie. The only thing that could save him would be if Milly let him off the hook after scaring him like this.

Translation

To ruin it meant ruining everything, probably even Kate, and destroying in a deeply treacherous way the beauty of their final moments. He had promised her that if she came to him, he would do exactly what she wanted, and he understood perfectly what she was asking. What she wanted was for him to lie tonight, in the large, dimly lit room, facing his young hostess's pale face, which was angelic in its trust, or at least impossible to understand in its kindness. The only thing that could save him would be if Milly let him off the hook after scaring him like this.

What made her kindness impossible to understand was that if she had saved him more than once already, she apparently did so without knowing how close he had come to losing everything. These were transcendent motions, not the less blest for being obscure; whereby yet once more he was to feel the pressure lighten. He was kept on his feet in short by the felicity of her not presenting him with Kate's version as aversion to adopt. He couldn't stand up to lie—he felt as if he should have to go down on his knees.

Translation

The incomprehensibility of her kindness stemmed from the fact that if she had saved him multiple times already, she seemed unaware of how close he had come to losing everything. These were sublime acts, no less blessed for being obscure, through which he was once again to feel the pressure ease. In short, he was kept upright by the fortunate circumstance of her not confronting him with Kate's refusal to accept. He couldn’t bring himself to lie—he felt as if he should have to prostrate himself.

As it was he just sat there shaking a little for nervousness the leg he had crossed over the other. She was sorry for his suffered snub, but he had nothing more to subscribe to, to perjure himself about, than the three or four inanities he had, on his own side, feebly prepared for the crisis. He scrambled a little higher than the reference to money and clothes, letters and directions from his manager; but he brought out the beauty of the chance for him—there before him like a temptress painted by Titian—to do a little quiet writing. He was vivid for a moment on the difficulty of writing quietly in London; and he was precipitate, almost explosive, on his idea, long cherished, of a book.

Translation

He sat there, just shaking a little, his crossed leg bouncing with nerves. She was sorry he'd been rejected, but he had nothing more to say, no lies to tell, beyond the three or four meaningless things he'd weakly rehearsed for this moment. He tried to steer clear of talking about money and clothes, letters and instructions from his manager. Instead, he highlighted the opportunity—it lay before him like a temptress painted by Titian—to do some quiet writing. He was animated for a moment, describing the difficulty of writing quietly in London. Then he became abrupt, almost explosive, talking about his long-held idea for a book.

These were profound feelings, even though he didn't fully understand them. They were a relief, even. He was able to cope because she didn't present him with Kate's rejection as a reason for her own. He couldn't lie; he felt he'd have to beg.

Translation

These feelings were significant, though he couldn't quite define them. They were almost a comfort. He could manage because she didn't blame Kate's rejection for her own actions. He was incapable of deceit; he felt he'd have to plead.

Instead, he simply sat there, a little shaky from nerves, the leg he'd crossed over the other twitching. She felt bad about his rejection, but he had nothing more to swear to, to lie about, than the few meaningless things he'd weakly prepared for this moment. He'd barely touched on money and clothes, letters and instructions from his manager. But he did emphasize how wonderful this opportunity was for him – right there, as alluring as a woman in a painting by Titian – to do some calm writing.

Translation

Instead, he just sat, a little tremulous, his crossed leg bouncing. She felt bad about the rejection, but he had no more promises to make, no lies to tell, beyond the few empty phrases he'd weakly rehearsed. He'd barely mentioned money or clothes, letters or his manager's instructions. But he had stressed how wonderful this opportunity was for him – right there, as captivating as a woman in a Titian painting – to do some quiet writing.

He was briefly passionate about how difficult it was to write calmly in London, and then he quickly, almost excitedly, mentioned his long-held idea for a book. The explosion lighted her face. "You'll do your book here?" "I hope to begin it."

Translation

He spoke briefly, passionately, about the difficulty of writing calmly in London, then he quickly, almost excitedly, mentioned his long-held idea for a book. The revelation lit up her face. "You'll do your book here?" "I hope to begin it."

"It's something you haven't begun?" "Well, only just." "And since you came?" She was so full of interest that he shouldn't perhaps after all be too easily let off.

Translation

"It's something you haven't started?" "Well, barely." "And since you've arrived?" She was so curious that he perhaps shouldn't be let off the hook so easily.

"I tried to think a few days ago that I had broken ground." Scarcely anything, it was indeed clear, could have let him in deeper. "I'm afraid we've made an awful mess of your time." "Of course you have.

Translation

"I tried to recall, a few days back, having made some progress." Almost nothing, it became evident, could have allowed him to delve further in. "I'm afraid we've greatly inconvenienced you." "Naturally."

But what I'm hanging on for now is precisely to repair that ravage." "Then you mustn't mind me, you know." "You'll see," he tried to say with ease, "how little I shall mind anything." "You'll want"—Milly had thrown herself into it—"the best part of your days."

Translation

"But what I'm clinging to right now is specifically to mend that damage." "Then you shouldn't worry about me, you know." "You'll see," he attempted to say casually, "how little I'll be bothered by anything." "You'll want"—Milly had thrown herself into the conversation—"the best part of your days."

The blast of light illuminated her face. "Will you write your book here?" "I hope to start it." "So you haven't started it yet?"

Translation

The light flashed, brightening her features. "Will you write your book here?" "I hope to begin it." "So you haven't started it?"

"Well, only just." "And since you arrived?" She was so intrigued that he shouldn't be let off the hook too easily. "A few days ago, I tried to convince myself that I'd made some progress."

Translation

"Well, just a little." "And since you got here?" She was so curious, he shouldn't get away with that. "I tried to tell myself I was making some headway a few days ago."

It was evident that nothing could have entangled him further. "I'm afraid we've ruined your schedule." "Of course you have. But I'm staying now precisely to make up for that lost time."

Translation

He was clearly in too deep to back out now. "I'm sorry, I'm sure we've messed up your plans." "You certainly have. But I'm staying, specifically to make up for the time I've already lost."

"Then you shouldn't worry about me." "You'll see," he attempted to say casually, "how little anything will bother me." "You'll need," Milly jumped in, "the best part of your days." He thought a moment: he did what he could to wreathe it in smiles.

Translation

"Then you shouldn't worry about me," he said. "You'll see," he attempted, affecting nonchalance, "how little anything will bother me." "You'll need," Milly interjected, "the best part of your days." He paused, trying his best to soften his words with a smile.

"Oh I shall make shift with the worst part. The best will be for you." And he wished Kate could hear him. It didn't help him moreover that he visibly, even pathetically, imaged to her by such touches his quest for comfort against discipline. He was to bury Kate's so signal snub, and also the hard law she had now laid on him, under a high intellectual effort.

Translation

"I'll manage with the worst of it. You deserve the best." He wished Kate could hear him. It didn't help that he pathetically imagined to her by such displays his search for comfort over rules. He would bury Kate's clear rejection, as well as the harsh boundaries she'd set, beneath a great intellectual strain.

This at least was his crucifixion—that Milly was so interested. She was so interested that she presently asked him if he found his rooms propitious, while he felt that in just decently answering her he put on a brazen mask. He should need it quite particularly were she to express again her imagination of coming to tea with him—an extremity that he saw he was not to be spared. "We depend on you, Susie and I, you know, not to forget we're coming"—the extremity was but to face that remainder, yet it demanded all his tact.

Translation

This, at the very least, was his torture—that Milly was so engaged. She was so involved that she promptly inquired if he found his lodgings suitable, while he felt that merely responding politely required him to feign confidence. He would especially need this facade if she were to reiterate her intention of visiting him for tea—an eventuality he knew he couldn’t avoid. "We're counting on you, Susie and I, you know, to remember that we’re coming"—the extreme was simply to confront this upcoming visit, and yet it demanded all of his discretion.

Facing their visit itself—to that, no matter what he might have to do, he would never consent, as we know, to be pushed; and this even though it might be exactly such a demonstration as would figure for him at the top of Kate's list of his proprieties. He could wonder freely enough, deep within, if Kate's view of that especial propriety had not been modified by a subsequent occurrence; but his deciding that it was quite likely not to have been had no effect on his own preference for tact. It pleased him to think of "tact" as his present prop in doubt; that glossed his predicament over, for it was of application among the sensitive and the kind. He wasn't inhuman, in fine, so long as it would serve.

Translation

Confronting the actual visit—that, regardless of any other obligation, he would absolutely refuse, as we know, to be pressured into; even if it happened to be precisely the sort of demonstration that would earn him praise from Kate for good behavior. He could speculate, privately, if Kate’s opinion of that particular propriety had changed because of something that happened later; but his conclusion that it probably hadn't didn't alter his own preference for tact. He liked thinking of "tact" as his current defense in his uncertainty; that smoothed over his dilemma, since it was useful in dealings with sensitive and considerate people. He wasn't heartless, after all, as long as it was helpful.

It had to serve now, accordingly, to help him not to sweeten Milly's hopes. He didn't want to be rude to them, but he still less wanted them to flower again in the particular connexion; so that, casting about him in his anxiety for a middle way to meet her, he put his foot, with unhappy effect, just in the wrong place. "Will it be safe for you to break into your custom of not leaving the house?" He paused for a moment, trying to smile.

Translation

It had to serve, then, to keep him from encouraging Milly's hopes. He didn't want to be rude, but he wanted even less for her hopes to revive within their particular relationship. So, searching frantically for a compromise, he stumbled, with unfortunate results, into the wrong course of action. "Will it be safe for you to break your habit of staying in?" He paused, attempting a smile.

"I'll handle the difficult parts. The pleasant aspects will be for you." He wished Kate could hear him. It didn't help that he clearly, even pitifully, revealed his need to find comfort in the face of hardship. He had to hide Kate's obvious rejection and the harsh rule she'd imposed on him with a great display of intellect.

Translation

"I'll take care of the hard stuff. You can have the fun parts." He wished Kate could hear him say those words. It was also apparent, and embarrassing, that he was looking for solace in the face of trouble. He had to conceal Kate's plain dismissal and the strict rules she had set for him with a great show of intelligence.

"Susie and I are counting on you to remember we're coming"—the problem was just dealing with that impending visit, but it demanded all his skill.

This, at least, was his torment—that Milly was so engaged. Her interest was such that she soon inquired whether he approved of his rooms, while he felt that a courteous reply demanded a bold front. He would need it especially if she reiterated her notion of visiting him for tea—a circumstance he saw he couldn't escape. "Susie and I are counting on you to remember we're coming"—the difficulty was simply managing that looming visit, but it taxed all his ability.

Translation

He would never, as we know, give in to the pressure of the visit, no matter what; even though it could be the very thing Kate would expect of him. He could wonder, secretly, if Kate's idea of what was right had been altered by something that had occurred in the interim; but deciding that it likely hadn't didn't alter his preference for diplomacy. It pleased him to think of "tact" as his current defense against the unknown; it eased his situation, because it functioned well with those who were sensitive and kind. In short, he wasn't cruel, as long as it worked.

It had to help him now, so that he wouldn't encourage Milly's hopes. Translation

It had to benefit him now, keeping Milly's hopes in check. He didn't want to be cruel, but he wanted even less for her expectations to be revived in that particular situation. Therefore, searching anxiously for a compromise in how to address her, he faltered, with disastrous consequences, and chose the wrong words. "Will it be safe for you to break your routine of staying home?" "'Safe'—?" For twenty seconds, she gave him a look of exquisite, pale scorn.

Oh but he didn't need it, by that time, to wince; he had winced for himself as soon as he had made his mistake. He had done what, so unforgettably, she had asked him in London not to do; he had touched, all alone with her here, the supersensitive nerve of which she had warned him. He had not, since the occasion in London, touched it again till now; but he saw himself freshly warned that it was able to bear still less. So for the moment he knew as little what to do as he had ever known it in his life.

Translation

Oh, but he didn't need any further prodding to cringe; he'd cringed inwardly the instant he'd made his blunder. He'd done precisely what she'd implored him not to do in London, a mistake etched in his memory. Alone with her here, he'd triggered the incredibly sensitive nerve she'd cautioned him about. Since their London encounter, he'd avoided that nerve entirely until now. The experience served as a fresh reminder that it was even more vulnerable than before. So, in that moment, he felt as utterly lost and unsure of himself as he ever had in his life.

He couldn't emphasise that he thought of her as dying, yet he couldn't pretend he thought of her as indifferent to precautions. Meanwhile too she had narrowed his choice. "You suppose me so awfully bad?" "Safe?" For twenty seconds, a look of exquisite, pale outrage flashed across her face.

Translation

He couldn't bring himself to say he imagined her dying, but he also couldn't act as though she wasn't concerned with safety measures. At the same time, she’d already limited his options. "You think I'm that awful?" "Careful?" A look of beautiful, pale anger flashed across her face for twenty seconds.

Oh, but he didn't need that to make him wince; he’d winced the instant he’d made his error. He'd done the very thing she'd begged him not to do in London, a mistake he'd never forget. Alone with her here, he’d poked at the most delicate spot, the one she’d warned him about. He hadn't touched it since London, but now he realized it could bear even less.

Translation

Oh, but he didn't need any of that to make him flinch. He'd flinched the instant he'd made his mistake. He'd done the very thing she'd begged him not to do in London, a mistake he'd never forget. Alone with her here, he'd prodded the most sensitive place, the one she'd warned him about. He hadn't touched it since London, but now he realized it was even more fragile.

At that moment, he was as lost as he'd ever been. He couldn't emphasize that he thought she was dying, but he couldn't pretend she didn't care about safety. She’d also limited his options. "You think I'm that awful?"

Translation

At that moment, he felt completely adrift. He couldn't say he believed she was actually dying, but he couldn't ignore her concern for her own well-being. She had also boxed him in. "Do you think I'm that terrible?"

He turned, in his pain, within himself; but by the time the colour had mounted to the roots of his hair he had found what he wanted. "I'll believe whatever you tell me." "Well then, I'm splendid." "Oh I don't need you to tell me that."

Translation

He turned inward, consumed by his own suffering. By the time the blood had rushed to the roots of his hair, he'd found his answer. "I'll believe whatever you say."

"Well then, I'm splendid."

"Oh, I don't need you to tell me that."

"I mean I'm capable of life." "I've never doubted it." "I mean," she went on, "that I want so to live—!" "Well?" he asked while she paused with the intensity of it.

"I mean I can handle life."

"I never thought you couldn't."

Translation

His strong hesitation suddenly disappeared, replaced by something profoundly odd, something he wouldn't fully understand until he was away from her. "You can come," he said, "whenever you want." "I will, I will," she replied, but her words felt empty, meaningless. He smiled, slightly bewildered.

"You really have to!" This brought her back to reality. "Alright, if you insist, why can't we come visit you?" "Will it make your life easier?"

Translation

"You absolutely must!" This yanked her back to the present. "Fine, if you're so insistent, why don't we come visit you?" "Would that make things easier for you?"

Translation

"Anything is helpful," she chuckled, "and being home is often a bore. I just don't want to miss out!" "Yes?"—her mind was elsewhere again. "Well, whenever you're ready for us."

It was astonishing what that short conversation had done to him. Translation

The short conversation had an astonishing effect on him. His serious doubts vanished, replaced by something strange, something he wouldn't fully grasp until he was no longer with her. "You can come," he said, "anytime." What had happened to him—the sudden, almost violent, discarding of everything but her presence—must have been visible on his face or in his manner. It was so obvious that she might have mistaken it for something else entirely.

"I see how you feel—that I'm an awful bore about it and that, sooner than have any such upset, you'll go. So it's no matter." "No matter? Oh!"—he quite protested now.

Translation

"I can see how you feel—that I'm being a complete pain about all this, and that you'd rather leave than deal with it. So, it's no big deal." "No big deal? Oh!"—he protested vehemently.

"If it drives you away to escape us. We want you not to go." It was beautiful how she spoke for Mrs. Stringham.

Whatever it was, he shook his head. "I won't go."

"Then I won't go!" she said, her voice bright. "You mean you won't come to me?"

Translation

But it's all right. I mean, apart from that," she went on, "that I won't do anything I oughtn't or that I'm not forced to." "Oh who can ever force you?" he asked with his hand-to-mouth way, at all times, of speaking for her encouragement. "You're the least coercible of creatures."

Translation

Translation

"So you think I'm free?" "Probably the freest person alive. You have everything." "Well," she smiled, "let's call it that."

Translation

I don't complain." At which point, despite himself, he was drawn in again. "No, I know you don't complain." The instant he said it, he heard the pity in his own voice.

His telling her she had "everything" was extravagant kind humour, whereas his knowing so tenderly that she didn't complain was terrible kind gravity. Milly felt, he could see, the difference; he might as well have praised her outright for looking death in the face. This was the way she just looked him again, and it was of no attenuation that she took him up more gently than ever. "It isn't a merit—when one sees one's way."

Translation

His saying she had "everything" was a grand, generous gesture of kindness, while his tender understanding of her silence was a terrible, deep solemnity. Milly sensed the distinction, he could see it; he may as well have openly complimented her on her ability to confront death. This was the way she looked at him once more, and it was not a mitigation that she addressed him with more gentleness than before. "It's not a virtue—when one understands the situation."

"No—never now. It's finished. But it's okay. I mean, besides the fact," she continued, "that I won't do anything wrong or that I'm not required to."

Translation

"No, never. It's over. But it's alright. I mean, setting aside," she went on, "that I won't do anything bad or that I don't have to."

Translation

"No, I know you're not upset." The moment he said it, he heard the sadness seeping into his voice. Translation

Translation

"I'm not doing a book."

"Isn't that what you said?" she asked, surprised. "You're not writing?" He already felt a sense of relief.

"I don't know, upon my honour, what I'm doing." "To a life of ease and prosperity? Well, I doubt it." "I'm talking about holding onto what you have."

Translation

"I honestly don't know what I'm doing." "Living a life of comfort and wealth? I don't think so." "I'm talking about keeping what you've got."

"That's a good definition of success. If what you already possess is worthwhile," Densher said, without thinking, "it's certainly worth the effort to keep it." "Well, that's as ambitious as I get. I'm not striving for more." Then, changing the subject, she continued, "Now, let's talk about your book."

Translation

"That's a pretty good definition of success. If what you have is worth having," Densher said, the words slipping out, "then it makes sense to try and hold onto it." "That's about as far as my ambition goes. I'm not looking for anything else." Then, shifting gears, she added, "So, tell me about your book."

"My book—?" He had completely forgotten about it. "The one you're supposed to realize that neither Susie nor I will allow you to jeopardize." He paused, then made a decision. "I'm not writing a book."

Translation

"My book—?" The very thought had vanished from his mind. "The one you’re both so worried I’ll mess up, the one you won’t let me endanger?" He hesitated, and then he made up his mind. "I'm not writing a book."

"You changed your mind?" she asked, surprised. "You're not writing anything?" He already felt a sense of relief. "Honestly, I have no idea what I'm doing."

Translation

"You changed your mind?" she asked, surprised. "You're not writing anything?" He already felt a sense of relief. "Honestly, I have no idea what I'm doing."

It made her visibly grave; so that, disconcerted in another way, he was afraid of what she would see in it. She saw in fact exactly what he feared, but again his honour, as he called it, was saved even while she didn't know she had threatened it. Taking his words for a betrayal of the sense that he, on his side, might complain, what she clearly wanted was to urge on him some such patience as he should be perhaps able to arrive at with her indirect help. Still more clearly, however, she wanted to be sure of how far she might venture; and he could see her make out in a moment that she had a sort of test.

Translation

This made her visibly serious. Thrown off balance in a new way, he was afraid of what she would make of it. She saw, in fact, exactly what he feared, but once more his sense of what was proper, as he called it, was preserved even though she wasn't aware she had threatened it. Interpreting his words as a sign that he, for his part, might be the one to complain, what she clearly wanted was to encourage him to be patient, a patience he might be able to achieve with her subtle assistance. Yet, even more clearly, she wanted to be certain of how far she could go; and he could see her realize in an instant that she had set some kind of test.

Her expression turned serious, and he was uneasy, fearing what she might understand. She understood precisely his fear, but once more, his sense of duty was preserved, even though she wasn't aware she'd tested it. Interpreting his words as a sign that he might have complaints, she clearly wanted to encourage him to be patient, perhaps with her subtle assistance. Even more obviously, she wanted to gauge how far she could go, and he could see her realize she was conducting a kind of experiment.

Translation

Her face became solemn, and he was uneasy, worried about what she might perceive. She understood his apprehension exactly, but once again, his sense of obligation remained intact, even though she didn't realize she had put it to the test. Taking his words as an indication that he might have grievances, she clearly sought to encourage his forbearance, possibly with her discreet help. Even more plainly, she wanted to assess her boundaries, and he could see her recognize that she was carrying out a kind of experiment.

"Then if it's not for your book—?" "What am I staying for?" "I mean with your London work—with all you have to do. Isn't it rather empty for you?"

Translation

"So, if it's not the book..." "What am I doing here, then?" "I mean, with your London stuff, and everything you have to get done. Doesn't it feel a little pointless?"

"Empty for me?" He remembered how Kate had held that she might propose marriage, and he wondered if this were the way she would naturally begin it. It would leave him, such an incident, he already felt, at a loss, and the note of his finest anxiety might have been in the vagueness of his reply. "Oh well—!" "I ask too many questions?" She settled it for herself before he could protest.

Translation

"Empty for me?" He recalled how Kate had suggested she might propose marriage, and he wondered if this was her way of initiating it. He already felt that such an event would leave him at a loss, and the finest expression of his anxiety might have been in the vagueness of his reply. "Oh well—!" "I ask too many questions?" She settled the matter herself before he could protest.

"You stay because you've got to." He grasped at it. "I stay because I've got to." And he couldn't have said when he had uttered it if it were loyal to Kate or disloyal. It gave her, in a manner, away; it showed the tip of the ear of her plan.

Translation

"You stay because you've got to." He latched onto that. "I stay because I've got to." He wouldn't have been able to say when he had spoken the words, whether they were an act of loyalty or betrayal. In a way, it gave her away; it exposed the smallest part of her plan.

Yet Milly took it, he perceived, but as a plain statement of his truth. He was waiting for what Kate would have told her of—the permission from Lancaster Gate to come any nearer. To remain friends with either niece or aunt he mustn't stir without it. All this Densher read in the girl's sense of the spirit of his reply; so that it made him feel he was lying, and he had to think of something to correct that.

Translation

Yet Milly took it, he perceived, as a simple declaration of his truth. He was waiting for what Kate would have told her of—the permission from Lancaster Gate to come any closer. To remain friends with either niece or aunt he mustn't make a move without it. Densher understood all this in the girl's interpretation of his response, so that it made him feel he was lying, and he had to think of something to correct that.

What he thought of was, in an instant, "Isn't it enough, whatever may be one's other complications, to stay after all for you?" "So, if it's not for your book...?" "What else would I be staying for?" "I mean, with your London work—with everything you have to do.

Translation

What he thought of in an instant was, "Isn't it enough, whatever other complications there may be, to stay here for you?" "So, if it's not for your book...?" "What else would I be staying here for?" "I mean, with your work in London—with everything you have to do."

Isn't it a bit pointless for you?" "Pointless for me?" He recalled how Kate had suggested she might propose marriage, and he wondered if this was how she'd naturally start. He already felt that such a situation would leave him bewildered, and the tone of his deepest concern might have been reflected in the vagueness of his answer. "Oh, well—!"

Translation

"Isn't it a bit pointless for you?" "Pointless for me?" He recalled how Kate had suggested she might propose marriage, and he wondered if this was how she'd naturally start. He already felt that such a situation would leave him bewildered, and the tone of his deepest concern might have been reflected in the vagueness of his answer. "Oh, well—!"

"I ask too many questions?" She answered her own question before he could object. "You're staying because you have to." He seized on it. "I'm staying because I have to." And he couldn't have said, at the moment he spoke, whether it was being true to Kate or betraying her.

Translation

"I ask too many questions?" She answered her own question before he could object. "You're staying because you have to." He seized on it. "I'm staying because I have to." And he couldn't have said, at the moment he spoke, whether it was being true to Kate or betraying her.

It exposed her, in a way; it revealed a hint of her intentions. Yet Milly accepted it, he realized, as a simple declaration of his genuine feeling. He was waiting for what Kate would have revealed—the green light from Lancaster Gate to get closer. To remain friendly with either the niece or the aunt, he couldn't move without it.

Translation

It exposed her, in a sense; it hinted at her goals. But Milly took it, he understood, as a straightforward statement of his true emotions. He was waiting for what Kate would show—the go-ahead from Lancaster Gate to get closer. To stay on good terms with either the niece or the aunt, he couldn't act without it.

Densher understood all this in the girl's understanding of his response; it made him feel like he was lying, and he had to think of a way to fix that. The thought that came to him instantly was, "Isn't it enough, regardless of any other issues, to stay here for you?" "Oh you must judge." He was by this time on his feet to take leave, and was also at last too restless.

Translation

Densher saw everything in the girl's interpretation of his reaction. He felt like a liar, and he had to figure out how to fix that. The thought that sprang to mind was, "Isn't it enough, setting aside everything else, to stay here for you?" "Oh, you must decide." By this point, he was standing up to leave, and at last, he was also too agitated to stay.

The speech in question at least wasn't disloyal to Kate; that was the very tone of their bargain. So was it, by being loyal, another kind of lie, the lie of the uncandid profession of a motive. He was staying so little "for" Milly that he was staying positively against her. He didn't, none the less, know, and at last, thank goodness, didn't care.

Translation

The speech in question, at the very least, wasn't betraying Kate; that was the core of their agreement. But, by being loyal, was it a different kind of lie, a lie born from the insincere declaration of a motive? He was staying so little "for" Milly that he was staying, in fact, against her. However, he didn't know, and thankfully, at long last, he didn't care.

The only thing he could say might make it either better or worse. "Well then, so long as I don't go, you must think of me all as judging!"

Translation

The one thing he could say might improve the situation, or it might make things worse. "Well, then, as long as I don't leave, you must think of me as a judge!"

Chapter 15

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A woman, later identified as Mrs. Susan Stringham, arrives to speak with a man named Densher. She tells him another woman is worse and has "turned her face to the wall." Densher waves away a servant who offers to take Mrs. Stringham's coat. Mrs. Stringham says she does not know how the sick woman is, which is why she has come. She asks if Densher has been wretched; he replies that he has been still for three days, and she agrees this was the best course. She asks him not to leave, and he agrees to stay for her. She says anything he does for her is also for the sick woman. Densher asks if the woman is dying. Mrs. Stringham says the sick woman has not mentioned Densher's name in three days, as if he were dead. Densher replies that he is dead, and Mrs. Stringham says she is too. Densher asks again if the woman is dying, and Mrs. Stringham asks if he knows. He says he does, and she confirms she knows as well, but "not everything." He helps her take off her cloak, and she sits down, again stating that the sick woman has "turned her face to the wall." She reports that the woman does not speak of anyone and is "grim," which is unlike her. Densher asks if the woman hates him; Mrs. Stringham says she does not know. He asks if the sick woman would see him again. When Mrs. Stringham asks if he would like to see her in her current state, he says no. She then says it is too late. Mrs. Stringham says there is one thing he can do. Densher asks about the doctor, Sir Luke Strett. Mrs. Stringham reports that she has wired Sir Luke, who will arrive on Thursday. They discuss their past positive interactions with Sir Luke. Densher states that he and Sir Luke never spoke of the sick woman. Mrs. Stringham asks Densher if he will deny what the sick woman has been made to believe if Sir Luke asks him to. When Densher asks what he must deny, she tells him to deny what Lord Mark told her. She reveals that Lord Mark told the sick woman that Densher has been engaged to Miss Croy (Kate) the entire time. Densher and Mrs. Stringham discuss Lord Mark, agreeing he came for "exasperation" after being humiliated and rejected by the sick woman months earlier. They conclude he knew she was dying and acted out of spite. Densher deduces that Lord Mark must have proposed to Kate, been refused, and came to Venice for an explanation, believing Densher was the reason for the refusal. Densher learns from Mrs. Stringham that Mrs. Lowder has written about Lord Mark's improving chances with Kate, and that Kate has not written to the sick woman. Mrs. Stringham repeats her question: If Sir Luke asks, will Densher deny what the woman believes? Densher asks if Mrs. Stringham is certain the woman believes it, and she tells him to judge. He then asks if Mrs. Stringham herself believes it. She replies that her belief depends on his action and that she will believe his denial if he makes it. He asks what exactly he is to deny, and she answers, "Of everything." Densher moans.

He didn't go home, on leaving her—he didn't want to; he walked instead, through his narrow ways and his campi with gothic arches, to a small and comparatively sequestered café where he had already more than once found refreshment and comparative repose, together with solutions that consisted mainly and pleasantly of further indecisions. It was a literal fact that those awaiting him there to-night, while he leaned back on his velvet bench with his head against a florid mirror and his eyes not looking further than the fumes of his tobacco, might have been regarded by him as a little less limp than usual. This wasn't because, before getting to his feet again, there was a step he had seen his way to; it was simply because the acceptance of his position took sharper effect from his sense of what he had just had to deal with. When half an hour before, at the palace, he had turned about to Milly on the question of the impossibility so inwardly felt, turned about on the spot and under her eyes, he had acted, by the sudden force of his seeing much further, seeing how little, how not at all, impossibilities mattered.

Translation

Leaving her, he didn't go home—he didn't want to. Instead, he walked through his narrow streets and his piazzas with gothic arches, to a small, comparatively secluded café where he had often found refreshment and a degree of peace, along with solutions that primarily and pleasantly involved further indecision. It was quite true that those who awaited him there that night, while he leaned back on his velvet bench with his head against a flamboyant mirror, his eyes fixed on the smoke from his tobacco, might have seemed to him a little less insipid than usual. This wasn't because he had found a path forward before he stood up again; it was simply because accepting his situation was made more impactful by his awareness of what he had just dealt with. When he had turned to Milly half an hour earlier, at the palace, on the question of the impossibility he felt so deeply—turned around right there, under her gaze—he had acted, driven by the sudden force of his vision, seeing how little, how not at all, impossibilities mattered.

It wasn't a case for pedantry; when people were at her pass everything was allowed. And her pass was now, as by the sharp click of a spring, just completely his own—to the extent, as he felt, of her deep dependence on him. Anything he should do or shouldn't would have close reference to her life, which was thus absolutely in his hands—and ought never to have reference to anything else. It was on the cards for him that he might kill her—that was the way he read the cards as he sat in his customary corner.

Translation

It wasn't a matter for nitpicking; when people were at her mercy, anything was permitted. And her fate was now, with the sharp snap of a closing mechanism, entirely his—to the point, he felt, of her profound reliance on him. Anything he did or didn't do would have a direct impact on her life, which was now completely in his control—and shouldn't have anything else to do with it. It was within the realm of possibility that he might kill her—that's how he interpreted the situation as he sat in his usual spot.

The fear in this thought made him let everything go, kept him there actually, all motionless, for three hours on end. He renewed his consumption and smoked more cigarettes than he had ever done in the time. What had come out for him had come out, with this first intensity, as a terror; so that action itself, of any sort, the right as well as the wrong—if the difference even survived—had heard in it a vivid "Hush!" the injunction to keep from that moment intensely still. He thought in fact while his vigil lasted of several different ways for his doing so, and the hour might have served him as a lesson in going on tiptoe.

Translation

The fear this thought produced caused him to release everything, holding him in place, motionless, for three straight hours. He resumed drinking and smoked more cigarettes than ever before. What had surfaced for him, with this initial intensity, was terror; so that any action whatsoever, both right and wrong—if the distinction even still existed—had a resounding "Hush!" within it, an order to remain intensely still. He contemplated several different approaches to his actions during his vigil, and the experience might have taught him a lesson in proceeding cautiously.

"You have to decide." He rose to leave and, at last, felt too agitated to stay. The conversation wasn't disloyal to Kate; that was the agreement they had. However, by being loyal, it was a different kind of lie, the lie of insincere motives.

Translation

"You have to decide." He stood up to go, finally too restless to remain. The discussion wasn't a betrayal of Kate; they'd agreed on that. But in being faithful, it was another sort of deception, the lie of ulterior intentions.

He was staying so little "for" Milly that he was staying practically against her. Still, he didn't know, and at last, thank goodness, didn't care. The only thing he could say might make things better or worse. "Well, as long as I don't leave, you must consider me the one making the judgment!"

Translation

He was hardly staying for Milly at all; in fact, it was almost as if he were staying to spite her. Even so, he didn't know the answer, and thankfully, he had stopped caring. The only thing he could say might improve the situation, or it might make it worse. "Alright, so long as I stay, you have to think of me as the one who's making the decision!"

II He didn't go home after leaving her—he didn't want to. Instead, he walked through the narrow streets and the squares with gothic arches to a small and secluded café where he had often found refreshment and calm, along with solutions that mostly consisted of more indecision. It was true that those waiting for him there tonight, as he leaned back on the velvet bench with his head against a decorative mirror and his eyes fixed on the smoke from his tobacco, might have seemed less dull to him than usual.

Translation

II He didn't go home after leaving her. He didn't want to. Instead, he walked through the narrow streets and the squares with gothic arches to a small, secluded café where he often found refreshment and calm, along with solutions that mostly consisted of more indecision. It was true that those waiting for him there tonight, as he leaned back on the velvet bench with his head against a decorative mirror and his eyes fixed on the smoke from his tobacco, might have seemed less dull to him than usual.

This wasn't because he had figured out what to do before getting up; it was simply because accepting his situation became sharper due to what he had just dealt with. When, half an hour earlier, at the palace, he had turned to Milly regarding the impossibility he felt so strongly, turned on the spot and under her gaze, he had acted with the sudden force of seeing much further, realizing how little, how not at all, impossibilities mattered. It wasn't a time for being rigid; when people were in her position, anything was allowed. And her position was now, like the sharp click of a spring, completely his own—to the point, he felt, of her deep reliance on him.

Translation

This wasn't because he knew what to do when he stood up; it was just that his predicament felt more acute after what he'd just been through. When, half an hour ago, in the palace, he had addressed Milly about the impossibility he felt so intensely, he had pivoted, right there, under her gaze, and acted with the sudden strength of a person seeing much further, grasping how little, how utterly insignificant, impossibilities were. It wasn't a moment for being inflexible; when people were in her situation, anything was permissible. And her situation was now, like the snap of a coiled spring, entirely his own—to the point, he felt, of her profound dependence on him.

Anything he did or didn't do would closely relate to her life, which was thus completely in his control—and should never relate to anything else. It was possible that he might destroy her—that was how he read the situation as he sat in his usual corner. The fear in this thought made him let everything go, keeping him there, motionless, for three hours straight. He consumed more drinks and smoked more cigarettes than he had ever done before.

Translation

Whatever he did or didn't do would directly impact her life, which was now entirely at his mercy—and it must never be about anything else. He might destroy her; that was his assessment as he sat in his usual corner. The fear inherent in this thought made him relinquish everything, holding him there, immobile, for three hours. He drank more and smoked more cigarettes than he ever had.

What had become clear to him had emerged with this initial intensity as terror; so that action itself, of any kind, the right as well as the wrong—if the difference even remained—had heard a vivid "Hush!" the command to stay intensely still from that moment on. In fact, while he kept watch, he thought of several different ways he could do this, and the time might have taught him a lesson in proceeding cautiously. What he finally took home, when he ventured to leave the place, was the perceived truth that he might on any other system go straight to destruction. Destruction was represented for him by the idea of his really bringing to a point, on Milly's side, anything whatever.

Translation

The realization that had struck him first took the shape of terror; therefore, any action, whether justified or not—assuming there was still a distinction—had been met with a resounding "Hush!" the order to remain perfectly still from then on. While he kept vigil, he considered various courses of action, and the intervening time might have taught him the value of caution. What he finally took with him, when he dared to leave, was the inescapable truth that any other path would lead him directly to ruin. For him, destruction was embodied in the idea of actually accomplishing, on Milly's account, anything at all.

Nothing so "brought," he easily argued, but must be in one way or another a catastrophe. He was mixed up in her fate, or her fate, if that should be better, was mixed up in him, so that a single false motion might either way snap the coil. They helped him, it was true, these considerations, to a degree of eventual peace, for what they luminously amounted to was that he was to do nothing, and that fell in after all with the burden laid on him by Kate. He was only not to budge without the girl's leave—not, oddly enough at the last, to move without it, whether further or nearer, any more than without Kate's.

Translation

Nothing so "brought," he reasoned, was not, in some way, a catastrophe. He was tangled in her destiny, or her destiny, if that was better, was tangled in his, so that a single wrong move could break the connection either way. These thoughts helped him, it was true, and gave him a sense of peace, because they illuminated the fact that he was to do nothing. And that, after all, aligned with the burden Kate had placed on him. He was not to move without the girl's permission—and, strangely, not to move without it at the end, whether to go further or closer, any more than he would without Kate's.

It was to this his wisdom reduced itself—to the need again simply to be kind. That was the same as being still—as studying to create the minimum of vibration. He felt himself as he smoked shut up to a room on the wall of which something precious was too precariously hung. A false step would bring it down, and it must hang as long as possible.

Translation

This was the crux of his wisdom—the need to simply be kind again. It was the same as being still—as striving to create the least amount of disruption. He felt, as he smoked, as though he were locked in a room where something precious hung precariously on the wall. A wrong move would bring it crashing down, and it had to stay in place as long as possible.

He was aware when he walked away again that even Fleet Street wouldn't at this juncture successfully touch him. His manager might wire that he was wanted, but he could easily be deaf to his manager. His money for the idle life might be none too much; happily, however, Venice was cheap, and it was moreover the queer fact that Milly in a manner supported him. The greatest of his expenses really was to walk to the palace to dinner.

Translation

He knew, as he left once more, that even Fleet Street couldn't truly reach him at this moment. His manager could send a telegram saying he was needed, but he could simply ignore it. He might not have much money for a life of leisure, but fortunately, Venice was inexpensive, and, oddly, Milly supported him in a way. His biggest expense was, in truth, walking to the palace for dinner.

He didn't want, in short, to give that up, and he should probably be able, he felt, to stay his breath and his hand. He should be able to be still enough through everything. When he finally went home, he understood that he was headed for disaster if he acted any other way. For him, disaster meant actually affecting Milly in any way.

Translation

In short, he didn't want to surrender that, and he supposed he could, he felt, keep himself in check, keep his actions in check. He should be capable of remaining composed, no matter what. He realized, when he finally returned home, that he was headed for catastrophe if he behaved any differently. For him, disaster meant actually influencing Milly in any manner.

Any action on his part would inevitably lead to a catastrophe. He was entangled in her fate, or perhaps her fate was entangled in his, so that any misstep could break the connection. These thoughts helped him find some peace because they clarified that he needed to do nothing, which aligned with Kate's expectations. He was not to do anything without Kate's permission, nor, strangely enough, move in any direction without it, any more than he would without Kate's permission.

Translation

Any action he took would lead to disaster, inevitably. He was tied to her destiny, or maybe their fates were intertwined, such that any mistake could sever the bond. These reflections comforted him, because they made it clear that he should do nothing, which was what Kate wanted. He was not to act without Kate's approval, nor, strangely enough, to move in any direction, no more than he would without Kate's permission.

His wisdom boiled down to the simple need to be kind. That was the same as being still, as trying to minimize any disruption. As he smoked, he felt confined, as if something precious was hanging precariously on a wall in his room. A false move would cause it to fall, and it had to stay in place as long as possible.

Translation

His guiding principle was the basic necessity of kindness. That was equivalent to stillness, to attempting to minimize any disturbance. As he smoked, he felt trapped, as if something valuable was hanging unstably on a wall in his room. A wrong action would make it fall, and it had to remain in place for as long as possible.

He knew that even Fleet Street couldn't reach him at this point. His manager might send a telegram, but he could ignore it. He might not have much money for this idle life, but luckily, Venice was inexpensive, and, strangely, Milly, in a way, was supporting him. The most significant expense was the walk to the palace for dinner.

Translation

He understood that even the press couldn't bother him now. His agent might wire him, but he could disregard it. He didn't have much money to live this leisurely life, but fortunately, Venice was cheap, and, in a peculiar sense, Milly was supporting him. The biggest cost was the walk to the palace for dinner.

He didn't want to stop that, and he felt he could stay quiet and control himself. He would be able to remain still through everything. He tried that for three weeks, with the sense after a little of not having failed. There had to be a delicate art in it, for he wasn't trying—quite the contrary—to be either distant or dull.

Translation

He didn't want to break that, and he felt he could keep silent and in control. He would be able to remain composed through it all. He tried it for three weeks, with the feeling after a while that he hadn't failed. There had to be a certain finesse to it, because he wasn't trying—quite the opposite—to be either aloof or boring.

That would not have been being "nice," which in its own form was the real law. That too might just have produced the vibration he desired to avert; so that he best kept everything in place by not hesitating or fearing, as it were, to let himself go—go in the direction, that is to say, of staying. It depended on where he went; which was what he meant by taking care. When one went on tiptoe one could turn off for retreat without betraying the manoeuvre.

Translation

That wouldn't have been "nice," which in its own way was the true rule. That, too, might have generated the disruptive energy he wanted to avoid. The best way to keep everything stable was to not hesitate or be afraid, and to, in a sense, let himself go—go, that is, in the direction of staying put. It depended on where he was going; that's what he meant by being careful. When one moved cautiously, one could retreat without revealing the strategy.

Perfect tact—the necessity for which he had from the first, as we know, happily recognised—was to keep all intercourse in the key of the absolutely settled. It was settled thus for instance that they were indissoluble good friends, and settled as well that her being the American girl was, just in time and for the relation they found themselves concerned in, a boon inappreciable. If, at least, as the days went on, she was to fall short of her prerogative of the great national, the great maidenly ease, if she didn't diviningly and responsively desire and labour to record herself as possessed of it, this wouldn't have been for want of Densher's keeping her, with his idea, well up to it—wouldn't have been in fine for want of his encouragement and reminder. He didn't perhaps in so many words speak to her of the quantity itself as of the thing she was least to intermit; but he talked of it, freely, in what he flattered himself was an impersonal way, and this held it there before her—since he was careful also to talk pleasantly.

Translation

Perfect tact—the necessity of which, as we know, he had thankfully recognized from the start—was to keep all interaction within the realm of the absolutely settled. It was settled, for example, that they were indissoluble good friends, and settled as well that her being the American girl was, at the right time and for the relationship they were in, an invaluable blessing. If, at least as time went on, she were to fail in her prerogative of great national, great maidenly ease, if she didn't divinely and responsively desire and labor to present herself as possessing it, this wouldn't have been due to Densher's failure to keep her, with his idea, on track—wouldn't have been, in short, due to his failure to encourage and remind her. He didn't perhaps, in so many words, speak to her of the quantity itself as of the thing she was least to abandon; but he talked of it, freely, in what he flattered himself was an impersonal way, and this kept it there before her—since he was also careful to talk pleasantly.

It was at once their idea, when all was said, and the most marked of their conveniences. The type was so elastic that it could be stretched to almost anything; and yet, not stretched, it kept down, remained normal, remained properly within bounds. And he had meanwhile, thank goodness, without being too much disconcerted, the sense, for the girl's part of the business, of the queerest conscious compliance, of her doing very much what he wanted, even though without her quite seeing why. She fairly touched this once in saying: "Oh yes, you like us to be as we are because it's a kind of facilitation to you that we don't quite measure: I think one would have to be English to measure it!"—and that too, strangely enough, without prejudice to her good nature.

Translation

It was, after all, their shared understanding, and the most useful aspect of their arrangement. The concept was so flexible that it could accommodate nearly anything. Yet, even without being pushed, it stayed stable, remained conventional, and stayed within appropriate limits. Meanwhile, he was relieved to sense, concerning the girl's role in their dynamic, the strangest kind of willing cooperation, her doing what he wanted, even if she didn't fully understand why. She nearly alluded to this when she said: "Oh yes, you like us to be the way we are because it makes things easier for you in ways we can't quite grasp. I think you'd have to be English to truly understand it!"—and this, strangely, without compromising her good disposition.

She might have been conceived as doing—that is of being—what he liked in order perhaps only to judge where it would take them. They really as it went on saw each other at the game; she knowing he tried to keep her in tune with his conception, and he knowing she thus knew it. Add that he again knew she knew, and yet that nothing was spoiled by it, and we get a fair impression of the line they found most completely workable. The strangest fact of all for us must be that the success he himself thus promoted was precisely what figured to his gratitude as the something above and beyond him, above and beyond Kate, that made for daily decency.

Translation

She could have been created to do—that is, to be—what he liked, perhaps just to see where it would lead them. They truly watched each other in this process. She knew he was trying to align her with his idea of things, and he knew she understood this. Add to that the fact that he again knew she understood, and yet that it didn't ruin anything, and we get a good idea of the approach they found most effective. The strangest part for us must be that the success he himself encouraged was exactly what he felt grateful for as something beyond himself, beyond Kate, that resulted in their daily decency.

There would scarce have been felicity—certainly too little of the right lubricant—had not the national character so invoked been, not less inscrutably than entirely, in Milly's chords. It made up her unity and was the one thing he could unlimitedly take for granted. He pursued this strategy for three weeks, and after a while, he felt it wasn't a failure. It required a delicate touch because he wasn't trying to be distant or boring—quite the opposite.

Translation

Happiness would have been unlikely—lacking, for sure, the necessary smoothness—if Milly hadn't been, in her own mysterious way, a vessel for the national character. This was the source of her cohesion, something he could always depend on. He followed this course for three weeks, and eventually, he decided it wasn't a mistake. He had to be careful, because he didn't want to seem aloof or dull—just the reverse.

That wouldn't have been "nice," which was the most important thing. Being too "nice" might have caused the very problem he wanted to avoid. The best approach was to avoid hesitation or fear, to allow himself to be present—to stay. His presence depended on where he directed himself, and that's what he meant by being careful.

Translation

That wouldn't have been "nice," which was the most essential thing. Being excessively "nice" could have caused the precise issue he aimed to prevent. The best tactic was to evade any hint of uncertainty or apprehension, to permit himself to be fully there—to remain. His presence hinged on where he focused his attention, and that's what he meant by exercising caution.

If he was cautious, he could retreat without anyone noticing. Perfect tact—which he'd understood from the beginning—meant keeping everything within the framework of a fixed understanding. For example, it was understood that they were close friends and that her being an American girl was a fortunate aspect of their relationship. If she didn't live up to her supposed national characteristic—the American girl's effortless ease—if she didn't want to show herself as such, it wouldn't be because Densher hadn't encouraged her to do so.

Translation

If he were careful, he could withdraw without anyone taking notice. Ideal tact—something he'd grasped from the start—meant keeping everything within the parameters of a defined understanding. For instance, it was understood that they were close friends, and that her being American was a beneficial part of their connection. If she failed to embody her supposed national trait—the American girl's natural confidence—if she didn't want to present herself that way, it wouldn't be because Densher hadn't pushed her to.

He didn't explicitly tell her to maintain this quality, but he discussed it freely, in what he believed was an objective manner, which reinforced the idea for her—especially because he spoke pleasantly. It was their mutual understanding and a major convenience. The American character was so flexible it could accommodate almost anything, and yet it remained within normal bounds. He also felt that the girl was consciously cooperating, doing what he wanted, even if she didn't fully understand why.

Translation

He never directly instructed her to maintain this quality, but he talked about it openly, in a way he believed was impartial, which solidified the idea for her—especially because he spoke kindly. It was their mutual understanding and a great advantage. The American character was so adaptable it could absorb almost anything and still remain within acceptable limits.
