He also felt that the girl was deliberately cooperating, doing what he wanted, even if she didn't completely grasp the reason.

She hinted at this once, saying, "Oh yes, you like us to be the way we are because it makes things easier for you, and we don't fully understand it. I think you'd have to be English to understand!" Strangely, this didn't diminish her good nature. She might have been doing what he liked simply to see where it would lead. They both knew they were playing a game; she knew he was trying to keep her in line with his expectations, and he knew she understood this.

Translation

She alluded to this once, remarking, "Oh yes, you prefer us to be this way because it simplifies things for you, and we don't entirely get it. I think you'd need to be English to truly comprehend!" Oddly, this didn't dampen her agreeable temperament. She might have been complying with his wishes just to see how it would unfold. They were both aware they were engaged in a performance; she knew he was attempting to mold her to his specifications, and he knew she was aware of it.

Moreover, he knew she understood, but it didn't disrupt anything, which gives a good picture of their most successful approach. The most surprising thing is that the success he orchestrated was the very thing he felt grateful for, the thing beyond him and beyond Kate that contributed to their daily harmony. There wouldn't have been genuine happiness—or enough of the right kind of ease—if the national character he'd invoked hadn't been an integral part of Milly. It defined her and was the one thing he could take completely for granted.

Translation

He also knew she understood the game, but it didn't upset the balance. That was a key to their success. What was most remarkable was that the success he'd engineered was the very thing he felt grateful for: the factor beyond him and beyond Kate that fueled their day-to-day accord. There wouldn't have been genuine joy—or even the right kind of comfort—if the national identity he'd emphasized hadn't been intrinsically linked to Milly. It defined her, and it was the one thing he could fully rely on.

He did so then, daily, for twenty days, without deepened fear of the undue vibration that was keeping him watchful. He knew in his nervousness that he was living at best from day to day and from hand to mouth; yet he had succeeded, he believed, in avoiding a mistake. All women had alternatives, and Milly's would doubtless be shaky too; but the national character was firm in her, whether as all of her, practically, by this time, or but as a part; the national character that, in a woman still so young, made of the air breathed a virtual non-conductor. It wasn't till a certain occasion when the twenty days had passed that, going to the palace at tea-time, he was met by the information that the signorina padrona was not "receiving." The announcement met him, in the court, on the lips of one of the gondoliers, met him, he thought, with such a conscious eye as the knowledge of his freedoms of access, hitherto conspicuously shown, could scarce fail to beget.

Translation

He did this every day for twenty days. He didn't allow his deepening fear of the unsettling shift to keep him from his duties. He knew, in his anxious state, that he was barely getting by, living hand to mouth. Still, he believed he'd avoided any mistakes. All women had options, and Milly's were no doubt tenuous as well. But her national character was resolute, whether it encompassed her entirely, which it practically did at this point, or only in part. This national character, especially in a woman so young, made the very air she breathed a non-conductor. It wasn't until a certain occasion, after those twenty days had passed, that he went to the palace for tea. He was informed that the signorina padrona wasn't receiving visitors. The announcement reached him in the courtyard, from the lips of one of the gondoliers. He felt it was delivered with a knowing glance, aware of the freedoms he had enjoyed in the past, which were now conspicuously denied.

Densher had not been at Palazzo Leporelli among the mere receivable, but had taken his place once for all among the involved and included, so that on being so flagrantly braved he recognised after a moment the propriety of a further appeal. Neither of the two ladies, it appeared, received, and yet Pasquale was not prepared to say that either was poco bene. He was yet not prepared to say that either was anything, and he would have been blank, Densher mentally noted, if the term could ever apply to members of a race in whom vacancy was but a nest of darknesses—not a vain surface, but a place of withdrawal in which something obscure, something always ominous, indistinguishably lived. He felt afresh indeed at this hour the force of the veto laid within the palace on any mention, any cognition, of the liabilities of its mistress.

Translation

Densher had not been among the merely acceptable at Palazzo Leporelli. He had, instead, once and for all, taken his place among the entangled and included. Upon being so flagrantly snubbed, he recognized after a moment the necessity of a further appeal. Neither of the two ladies, it seemed, was receiving visitors, and yet Pasquale wasn't ready to say that either was ill. He wasn't even ready to say that either was anything. Densher thought, he would have been at a loss if the term could ever apply to members of a race for whom emptiness was merely a nest of darknesses—not a superficial blankness, but a place of retreat in which something obscure, something always ominous, indistinguishably thrived. He felt again at this moment the force of the palace's ban on any mention, any awareness, of its mistress's troubles.

The state of her health was never confessed to there as a reason. How much it might deeply be taken for one was another matter; of which he grew fully aware on carrying his question further. This appeal was to his friend Eugenio, whom he immediately sent for, with whom, for three rich minutes, protected from the weather, he was confronted in the gallery that led from the water-steps to the court, and whom he always called, in meditation, his friend; seeing it was so elegantly presumable he would have put an end to him if he could. That produced a relation which required a name of its own, an intimacy of consciousness in truth for each—an intimacy of eye, of ear, of general sensibility, of everything but tongue.

Translation

Her health wasn't explicitly cited as the reason. How much it could be profoundly *assumed* to be the reason was a different matter altogether, something he became fully conscious of as he pursued his inquiry. This appeal was made to his friend Eugenio, whom he immediately summoned. For three precious minutes, sheltered from the elements, he met with Eugenio in the gallery that connected the water steps to the courtyard. Densher always referred to him, in his private thoughts, as his friend, recognizing how elegantly probable it was that he would have eliminated him if he could. This created a relationship demanding its own name, a true intimacy of shared awareness for each of them—an intimacy of sight, of hearing, of general sensitivity, of everything except speech.

It had been, in other words, for the five weeks, far from occult to our young man that Eugenio took a view of him not less finely formal than essentially vulgar, but which at the same time he couldn't himself raise an eyebrow to prevent. It was all in the air now again; it was as much between them as ever while Eugenio waited on him in the court. He continued this way, every day, for twenty days. He didn't become more afraid of whatever was making him so uneasy.

Translation

In other words, during those five weeks, it was quite apparent to our young man that Eugenio saw him as something that was, on the one hand, refined and formal, and on the other, inherently vulgar. Yet, he couldn't bring himself to object. It hung in the air now, between them as always, while Eugenio waited on him in the courtyard. He continued this way, every day, for twenty days. He didn't grow more afraid of whatever was causing him such unease.

He knew, feeling nervous as he was, that he was only getting by, just managing each day. Yet he believed he'd avoided any big mistakes. All women have choices, and Milly's would surely be uncertain as well. But her strong national character was evident, whether it was everything she was, practically, by then, or just a part of her.

Translation

He knew, despite his anxiety, that he was merely surviving, barely getting through each day. Still, he felt he had evaded any major blunders. All women face decisions, and Milly’s were undoubtedly fraught with doubt. Yet her resolute national character was undeniable, whether it encompassed her entire being, in practical terms, at that point, or only a portion of it.

That national character, in a woman still so young, made her seem almost untouchable. It wasn't until a certain day, after the twenty days had passed, that he went to the palace at tea time and was told that the young lady wasn't "receiving visitors." The announcement came to him in the courtyard, from the lips of one of the gondoliers. He thought the gondolier seemed aware of his usual easy access, which, until then, had been quite obvious. Densher hadn't been at Palazzo Leporelli just as a visitor.

Translation

That national character, in a woman still so young, gave her an almost unapproachable air. It wasn't until a particular day, after the twenty days had gone by, that he went to the palace at teatime and was told that the young woman wasn't "receiving." The message reached him in the courtyard, from the mouth of one of the gondoliers. He thought the gondolier seemed to recognize his previous easy access, which, up until then, had been quite apparent. Densher hadn't been at Palazzo Leporelli just as a visitor.

He'd become someone involved and included. So, when he was so obviously being blocked, he realized he needed to ask someone else. It seemed neither of the two ladies was seeing anyone, but Pasquale wasn't ready to say either was unwell. He wasn't even ready to say anything, and he would have been at a loss, Densher thought, if the term could ever apply to people whose emptiness was really a collection of hidden depths - not an empty surface, but a place of retreat where something obscure and always threatening lived, indistinguishably.

Translation

He'd become someone implicated, included in the proceedings. So, when he was so obviously being excluded, he understood he had to find another source of information. It appeared neither woman was entertaining guests, though Pasquale refrained from claiming either was ill. He was reluctant to say anything at all, and Densher reflected he would have been at a loss, if the term could ever apply to those whose hollowness was in fact a collection of hidden depths—not a vacant facade, but a place of refuge where something obscure and perpetually menacing resided, inextricably bound.

He felt the impact of the palace's ban on mentioning or acknowledging anything about his mistress's problems. Her health wasn't ever given as the reason. How much it might be secretly considered the reason was another matter, which he fully understood when he asked more questions. He then turned to his friend Eugenio.

Translation

He felt the force of the palace's order, forbidding any mention or acknowledgement of his mistress's troubles. Her health was never cited as a cause. The degree to which it was secretly perceived as such was another question, one he fully grasped once he began to probe. He then turned to his friend, Eugenio.

He immediately sent for him. He was able to talk to him for three precious minutes, protected from the weather, in the gallery that led from the water steps to the courtyard. He always called him, in his mind, his friend, even though he elegantly presumed that Eugenio would have killed him if he could. That created a relationship that needed its own name, a truly intimate understanding between them.

Translation

He summoned Eugenio at once. They spoke for three crucial minutes, sheltered from the elements in the gallery connecting the water steps to the courtyard. He always thought of Eugenio as his friend, even though he suspected, with a certain grace, that Eugenio would murder him if given the chance. That paradox forged a unique connection, a deeply personal understanding between the two men.

It was an intimacy of their eyes, their ears, their general feelings, everything except words. In other words, for those five weeks, it wasn't a secret to Densher that Eugenio had a very formal, and also essentially vulgar, opinion of him, but an opinion that Densher couldn't even object to. It was all in the air again now. It was as much between them as ever while Eugenio waited for him in the courtyard.

Translation

It was a closeness of glances, of listening, of shared senses – everything except the spoken word. Which is to say, over those five weeks, it wasn’t hidden from Densher that Eugenio held a very formal, and also fundamentally crude, opinion of him, an opinion that Densher couldn't even dispute. That sentiment hung in the air once more. It was as present between them as ever, as Eugenio waited for him in the courtyard.

The weather, from early morning, had turned to storm, the first sea-storm of the autumn, and Densher had almost invidiously brought him down the outer staircase—the massive ascent, the great feature of the court, to Milly's piano nobile. This was to pay him—it was the one chance—for all imputations; the imputation in particular that, clever, tanto bello and not rich, the young man from London was—by the obvious way—pressing Miss Theale's fortune hard. It was to pay him for the further ineffable intimation that a gentleman must take the young lady's most devoted servant (interested scarcely less in the high attraction) for a strangely casual appendage if he counted in such a connexion on impunity and prosperity. These interpretations were odious to Densher for the simple reason that they might have been so true of the attitude of an inferior man, and three things alone, accordingly, had kept him from righting himself.

Translation

The weather had been stormy since early morning, the first sea storm of the autumn, and Densher had almost spitefully led him down the outer staircase—the enormous climb, the court's most striking feature, to Milly's piano nobile. This was to pay him back—it was his only chance—for all the accusations; particularly, the accusation that the clever, so handsome and not wealthy young man from London was—in the most obvious way—aggressively pursuing Miss Theale's fortune. It was to pay him back for the further unspoken suggestion that a gentleman must consider the young lady's most devoted servant (who was scarcely less interested in her appeal) to be a strangely casual extra if he was counting on safety and success in such a connection. These interpretations were repulsive to Densher for the simple reason that they could have been so true of the attitude of a lesser man, and only three things, therefore, had prevented him from setting the record straight.

One of these was that his critic sought expression only in an impersonality, a positive inhumanity, of politeness; the second was that refinements of expression in a friend's servant were not a thing a visitor could take action on; and the third was the fact that the particular attribution of motive did him after all no wrong. It was his own fault if the vulgar view, the view that might have been taken of an inferior man, happened so incorrigibly to fit him. He apparently wasn't so different from inferior men as that came to. If therefore, in fine, Eugenio figured to him as "my friend" because he was conscious of his seeing so much of him, what he made him see on the same lines in the course of their present interview was ever so much more.

Translation

One reason was that his accuser only communicated through an impersonal, coldly polite demeanor. Another was that a visitor couldn't act on the subtle observations of a friend's servant. The third reason was that the specific accusation against him didn't actually harm him. It was his own fault if the base assessment, the assessment one might make of a lesser man, happened to fit him so perfectly. Apparently, he wasn't so different from lesser men after all. So, if Eugenio considered him "my friend" because he was aware of how much Eugenio observed him, what he showed him during their current meeting was much more of the same.

Densher felt that he marked himself, no doubt, as insisting, by dissatisfaction with the gondolier's answer, on the pursuit taken for granted in him; and yet felt it only in the augmented, the exalted distance that was by this time established between them. Eugenio had of course reflected that a word to Miss Theale from such a pair of lips would cost him his place; but he could also bethink himself that, so long as the word never came—and it was, on the basis he had arranged, impossible—he enjoyed the imagination of mounting guard. He had never so mounted guard, Densher could see, as during these minutes in the damp loggia where the storm-gusts were strong; and there came in fact for our young man, as a result of his presence, a sudden sharp sense that everything had turned to the dismal. Something had happened—he didn't know what; and it wasn't Eugenio who would tell him.

Translation

Densher felt that he was, no doubt, revealing his insistence on continuing this pursuit by expressing dissatisfaction with the gondolier's answer. Yet, he only felt this within the amplified, elevated distance that now existed between them. Eugenio had, of course, considered that a word to Miss Theale from such a source would cost him his job. But he could also know that, as long as the word never came—which, given the arrangement he'd made, was impossible—he enjoyed the fantasy of standing guard. Densher could see that he'd never stood guard as he was during these minutes in the damp loggia where the storm gusts were fierce. In fact, as a result of Eugenio's presence, our young man suddenly and sharply felt that everything had turned bleak. Something had happened—he didn't know what; and it wasn't Eugenio who would tell him.

What Eugenio told him was that he thought the ladies—as if their liability had been equal—were a "leetle" fatigued, just a "leetle leetle," and without any cause named for it. It was one of the signs of what Densher felt in him that, by a profundity, a true deviltry of resource, he always met the latter's Italian with English and his English with Italian. He now, as usual, slightly smiled at him in the process—but ever so slightly this time, his manner also being attuned, our young man made out, to the thing, whatever it was, that constituted the rupture of peace. The weather had become stormy early that morning, the first sea storm of the autumn.

Translation

Eugenio's response was that he believed the ladies—as if their responsibility in the matter was identical—were "a leetle" tired, "a leetle leetle," with no explanation offered. This was one of those clues to Densher's sense of the man; with a sort of profound, truly mischievous cleverness, Eugenio invariably responded to his Italian with English and to his English with Italian. He now, as was typical, offered a faint smile while doing so—but this time, the smile was very subtle, his demeanor seeming, the young man realized, to be in tune with whatever that element was that had broken the tranquility. The weather had turned stormy earlier that morning; the first sea storm of the autumn.

Densher had practically forced him down the exterior staircase – the impressive one, the most notable aspect of the courtyard – to Milly's grand piano room. This was an attempt to appease him, the only opportunity to counter all the accusations, especially the one that the clever, handsome, and not-so-wealthy young man from London was blatantly pursuing Miss Theale's fortune. It was also to make amends for the unspoken suggestion that a gentleman, presuming on this connection for personal gain and success, would treat the young lady's most dedicated servant – who was equally interested in her allure – as a mere, casual acquaintance. These interpretations were offensive to Densher because they could easily be applied to a lesser man.

Translation

Densher had practically dragged him down the outside staircase—the impressive one, the courtyard's centerpiece—to Milly's music room, where the grand piano sat. It was an attempt at placation, the only chance to deflect the accusations, especially the one about the clever, handsome, but not particularly rich young man from London who was obviously after Miss Theale's money. It was also an attempt to undo the unspoken implication that a gentleman, exploiting this connection for his own ends, would treat the young lady's most devoted servant—who was also captivated by her charm—as a mere acquaintance. These interpretations offended Densher because they would have suited a lesser man.

Only three things had prevented him from defending himself. First, his critic expressed himself solely through an impersonal, almost inhumane politeness. Second, a guest couldn't really take action against the refined speech of a friend's servant. Third, the specific accusation didn't actually harm him.

Translation

Three things had kept him from protesting. The first was his accuser's mode of expression: an impersonal, almost inhuman courtesy. Second, he couldn't very well challenge the genteel pronouncements of his friend's employee. And third, the particular charge leveled against him caused him no real damage.

It was his own fault if the common viewpoint, the one that could be applied to a lesser man, seemed so stubbornly accurate in his case. He apparently wasn't so different from those inferior men, after all. Therefore, if, ultimately, Eugenio saw him as "my friend" because he was aware of how much he observed, then what he was allowed to see during this particular conversation was much more. Densher sensed that he was signaling, through his dissatisfaction with the gondolier's answer, that he was indeed pursuing the expected course of action.

Translation

It was his own failing that the general assessment, the one applicable to a less accomplished person, seemed so stubbornly fitting in his situation. Evidently, he wasn’t so dissimilar from those lesser men, after all. So, if Eugenio ultimately considered him “my friend” because he knew how much he noticed, then what he was being permitted to see during this particular conversation was much greater. Densher felt that he was indicating, through his disapproval of the gondolier's reply, that he was indeed following the anticipated plan.

Yet, he only felt this through the intensified distance that had grown between them. Eugenio had surely considered that any word to Miss Theale from his lips would cost him his job. But he could also take comfort in the fact that as long as that word never came – which was impossible, given the arrangement – he could enjoy the fantasy of being a protective guard. Densher could see that Eugenio had never been so vigilant as during those moments in the damp loggia where the storm gusts were fierce.

Translation

However, Densher only felt this through the amplified distance that had developed between them. Eugenio knew that any word he might say to Miss Theale would cost him his employment. But he could also take solace in the fact that, as long as he never spoke – which, given the agreed upon plan, was impossible – he could indulge in the fantasy of being her protector. Densher could see that Eugenio had never been so watchful as during those moments in the humid loggia, when the storm's wind was raging.

In fact, the young man suddenly realized that everything had turned bleak because of his presence. Something had happened – he didn't know what – and Eugenio wouldn't tell him. What Eugenio did tell him was that he believed the ladies – as if they were equally susceptible – were a "little" tired, just a "little, little," without any stated reason. It was one of those signs, Densher thought, that with a deep, truly clever cunning, Eugenio always responded to his Italian with English and his English with Italian.

Translation

Actually, the young man now understood that his very existence had cast a pall over everything. Something had occurred—he had no idea what—and Eugenio wouldn’t share the details. What Eugenio did say was that he thought the women—as if they were both equally fragile—were just a "little" tired, just a "tiny bit," without offering any explanation. It was one of those clues, Densher realized, by which Eugenio, with his profound and truly artful cunning, always answered his Italian with English and his English with Italian.

As usual, he smiled at him slightly, but ever so slightly this time, his own demeanor also adjusted, our young man realized, to the thing, whatever it was, that had broken the peace. This manner, while they stood a long minute facing each other over all they didn't say, played a part as well in the sudden jar to Densher's protected state. It was a Venice all of evil that had broken out for them alike, so that they were together in their anxiety, if they really could have met on it; a Venice of cold lashing rain from a low black sky, of wicked wind raging through narrow passes, of general arrest and interruption, with the people engaged in all the water-life huddled, stranded and wageless, bored and cynical, under archways and bridges. Our young man's mute exchange with his friend contained meanwhile such a depth of reference that, had the pressure been but slightly prolonged, they might have reached a point at which they were equally weak.

Translation

As was his habit, he gave a small smile, though this time it was barely perceptible. The young man realized that his own attitude was also responding to this thing, whatever it was, that had shattered the tranquility. This particular way of being, as they stood facing each other for a long minute and avoiding any real conversation, contributed to the sudden disruption of Densher's feeling of safety. It was a Venice of pure evil that had sprung up for them both, so that they shared the same fear, if they were truly capable of connecting on that level. It was a Venice of cold, driving rain from a low, dark sky, of vicious winds tearing through narrow streets, of general suspension and discontinuity, with the watermen all huddled together, stranded and without work, bored and cynical, under the arches and bridges. The silent communication between the young man and his friend carried so much unspoken meaning that, had the tension lasted a little longer, they might have arrived at a state of equal vulnerability.

Each had verily something in mind that would have made a hash of mutual suspicion and in presence of which, as a possibility, they were more united than disjoined. But it was to have been a moment for Densher that nothing could ease off—not even the formal propriety with which his interlocutor finally attended him to the portone and bowed upon his retreat. Nothing had passed about his coming back, and the air had made itself felt as a non-conductor of messages. Densher knew of course, as he took his way again, that Eugenio's invitation to return was not what he missed; yet he knew at the same time that what had happened to him was part of his punishment.

Translation

Each of them did, in fact, have something on their mind that would have ruined their mutual suspicion. Faced with that possibility, they were more united than divided. But for Densher, it was a moment from which nothing could offer relief—not even the formality with which his companion finally saw him to the door and bowed as he left. Nothing had been said about his return, and the atmosphere had become a barrier to communication. As he walked away, Densher knew that it wasn’t Eugenio’s unspoken invitation that he missed. Yet, at the same time, he knew that what had happened to him was part of his punishment.

Out in the square beyond the fondamenta that gave access to the land-gate of the palace, out where the wind was higher, he fairly, with the thought of it, pulled his umbrella closer down. It couldn't be, his consciousness, unseen enough by others—the base predicament of having, by a concatenation, just to take such things: such things as the fact that one very acute person in the world, whom he couldn't dispose of as an interested scoundrel, enjoyed an opinion of him that there was no attacking, no disproving, no (what was worst of all) even noticing. One had come to a queer pass when a servant's opinion so mattered. Eugenio's would have mattered even if, as founded on a low vision of appearances, it had been quite wrong.

Translation

Out in the square, beyond the embankment that led to the land entrance of the palace, and where the wind was stronger, he quite literally, just thinking about it, pulled his umbrella down closer. It couldn’t be, his consciousness, hidden enough from others—the fundamental problem of being forced, through a series of events, to simply accept such things: things like the fact that one very perceptive person in the world, whom he couldn’t dismiss as a self-serving rogue, held an opinion of him that was unassailable, impossible to disprove, and (worst of all) impossible to even acknowledge. One had arrived at a strange point when a servant’s opinion was so significant. Eugenio’s opinion would have mattered even if, based on a limited understanding of appearances, it had been completely wrong.

It was the more disagreeable accordingly that the vision of appearances was quite right, and yet was scarcely less low. As they stood facing each other for a long moment, saying nothing, this silent interaction contributed to the sudden disruption of Densher's sense of security. It was as if a sinister version of Venice had revealed itself to both of them, uniting them in their unease, if they could have fully acknowledged it. A Venice of freezing rain falling from a dark sky, of vicious winds roaring through narrow streets, of general chaos and disruption, with the people who relied on the waterways huddled together, stranded and unemployed, bored and cynical, under arches and bridges.

Translation

That made it all the more unpleasant, given that the perception of appearances was accurate, yet still felt base. As they stood there, facing each other for a long moment, saying nothing, this silent exchange suddenly undermined Densher's sense of security. It was as if a dark side of Venice had revealed itself to them, uniting them in their discomfort, if they could have fully admitted it. A Venice of freezing rain falling from a dark sky, of violent winds howling through narrow streets, of general chaos and disruption, with the people who depended on the canals huddled together, stranded and unemployed, bored and cynical, under arches and bridges.

The silent exchange between the two young men contained so much unspoken meaning that if the tension had lasted any longer, they might have reached a point where they were equally vulnerable. Each of them had something on their mind that would have shattered any trust between them, and in the face of this potential betrayal, they were more united than divided. But for Densher, it was a moment from which nothing could offer relief—not even the polite way in which his companion eventually saw him to the door and bowed as he left. Nothing had been said about his return, and the atmosphere was devoid of any communication.

Translation

The unspoken communication between the two young men was so loaded that if the tension had persisted, they might have become equally exposed. Each possessed a secret that could destroy any bond of trust, and in the face of this potential betrayal, their shared vulnerability brought them closer. But for Densher, it was a moment from which there was no escape—not even the courteous manner in which his companion escorted him to the door and bowed as he departed. No plans were made for another meeting, and the air was thick with silence.

Densher knew, as he walked away, that it wasn't Eugenio's invitation to return that he missed; yet he knew simultaneously that what had happened to him was part of his punishment. In the square beyond the waterfront that led to the land entrance of the palace, where the wind was stronger, he actually pulled his umbrella down closer, just thinking about it. His own awareness, hidden from others, couldn't alter his unfortunate predicament—the fact that one highly perceptive person in the world, whom he couldn't simply dismiss as a greedy villain, held an unshakeable opinion of him, an opinion that he couldn't challenge, disprove, or, worst of all, even acknowledge. He had reached a strange point when a servant's opinion mattered so much.

Translation

As he walked away, Densher knew it wasn't Eugenio's unsaid invitation to return that he missed. Yet, he also knew that what had happened was part of his punishment. In the square beyond the waterfront, where the wind was stronger, he actually lowered his umbrella, just thinking about it. His own awareness, hidden from everyone else, couldn't change his unfortunate situation—the fact that one highly perceptive person in the world, whom he couldn't dismiss as a simple villain, had an unshakeable opinion of him. An opinion he couldn't challenge, disprove, or, worst of all, even acknowledge. He'd reached a strange point when a servant's opinion mattered so much.

Eugenio's opinion would have been important even if, based on a shallow understanding of appearances, it had been completely wrong. It was all the more unpleasant that this shallow understanding of appearances was quite accurate, yet still felt demeaning. Such as it was, at any rate, Densher shook it off with the more impatience that he was independently restless. He had to walk in spite of weather, and he took his course, through crooked ways, to the Piazza, where he should have the shelter of the galleries.

Translation

Eugenio's opinion would have been significant even if it were entirely incorrect, based on a superficial assessment of things. It was all the more disagreeable that this superficial understanding of appearances was, in fact, correct, yet still felt degrading. At any rate, Densher dismissed it with the added impatience caused by his own inner restlessness. He had to keep walking, regardless of the weather, and he proceeded through winding streets toward the Piazza, where he could take shelter in the galleries.

Here, in the high arcade, half Venice was crowded close, while, on the Molo, at the limit of the expanse, the old columns of the Saint Theodore and of the Lion were the frame of a door wide open to the storm. It was odd for him, as he moved, that it should have made such a difference—if the difference wasn't only that the palace had for the first time failed of a welcome. There was more, but it came from that; that gave the harsh note and broke the spell. The wet and the cold were now to reckon with, and it was to Densher precisely as if he had seen the obliteration, at a stroke, of the margin on a faith in which they were all living.

Translation

Here, in the high arcade, half of Venice was packed together. Meanwhile, on the Molo, at the edge of the open space, the ancient columns of Saint Theodore and the Lion framed a doorway wide open to the storm. It was strange to him, as he moved, that it should have made such a difference—if the difference wasn't merely that the palace had, for the first time, not offered a welcome. There was more to it, but it came from that; that was what produced the harsh note and shattered the illusion. Now, the wet and the cold had to be considered, and it was as if Densher had witnessed the instant erasure of the boundary of a faith that they all shared.

The margin had been his name for it—for the thing that, though it had held out, could bear no shock. The shock, in some form, had come, and he wondered about it while, threading his way among loungers as vague as himself, he dropped his eyes sightlessly on the rubbish in shops. There were stretches of the gallery paved with squares of red marble, greasy now with the salt spray; and the whole place, in its huge elegance, the grace of its conception and the beauty of its detail, was more than ever like a great drawing-room, the drawing-room of Europe, profaned and bewildered by some reverse of fortune. He brushed shoulders with brown men whose hats askew, and the loose sleeves of whose pendent jackets, made them resemble melancholy maskers.

Translation

The margin—that's what he had called it—described the thing that, though it had held, couldn’t endure any kind of jolt. The jolt, in one form or another, had arrived, and he pondered it while weaving through aimless people. He lowered his gaze, his eyes passing over the trash in the shops without really seeing it. There were sections of the gallery paved with red marble squares, now slick with the salty spray. And the entire space, with its immense elegance, its graceful design and beautiful details, resembled a grand drawing-room more than ever before—the drawing-room of Europe, defiled and confused by some turn of events. He bumped into men with brown skin, their hats askew, the loose sleeves of their drooping jackets giving them the appearance of sorrowful masqueraders.

The tables and chairs that overflowed from the cafés were gathered, still with a pretence of service, into the arcade, and here and there a spectacled German, with his coat-collar up, partook publicly of food and philosophy. These were impressions for Densher too, but he had made the whole circuit thrice before he stopped short, in front of Florian's, with the force of his sharpest. His eye had caught a face within the café—he had spotted an acquaintance behind the glass. The person he had thus paused long enough to look at twice was seated, well within range, at a small table on which a tumbler, half-emptied and evidently neglected, still remained; and though he had on his knee, as he leaned back, a copy of a French newspaper—the heading of the Figaro was visible—he stared straight before him at the little opposite rococo wall.

Translation

The tables and chairs spilling out from the cafes were gathered within the arcade, still arranged with a pretense of service. Here and there, a spectacled German with his coat collar turned up, publicly engaged with food and philosophy. These were impressions for Densher as well, but he had walked the entire circuit three times before stopping short in front of Florian's, arrested by his sharpest instincts. His eye had caught a face inside the cafe—he had spotted an acquaintance behind the glass. The person he had paused long enough to look at twice was seated, well within view, at a small table. A half-empty tumbler, evidently forgotten, still sat there. Though he had a copy of a French newspaper on his knee, the heading of *Le Figaro* visible, he stared straight ahead at the small rococo wall across from him.

Densher had him for a minute in profile, had him for a time during which his identity produced, however quickly, all the effect of establishing connexions—connexions startling and direct; and then, as if it were the one thing more needed, seized the look, determined by a turn of the head, that might have been a prompt result of the sense of being noticed. This wider view showed him all Lord Mark—Lord Mark as encountered, several weeks before, the day of the first visit of each to Palazzo Leporelli. For it had been all Lord Mark that was going out, on that occasion, as he came in—he had felt it, in the hall, at the time; and he was accordingly the less at a loss to recognise in a few seconds, as renewed meeting brought it to the surface, the same potential quantity. Densher, restless as he was, dismissed his unease.

Translation

Densher had him in profile for a minute. He had him for a time during which his identity, however quickly, created all the effect of establishing connections—connections startling and direct. Then, as if it were the one thing more needed, Densher seized the look, determined by a turn of the head, that might have been a prompt result of the sense of being noticed. This wider view showed him all of Lord Mark—Lord Mark as encountered several weeks before, the day of their first visit to Palazzo Leporelli. For it had been all of Lord Mark that was going out on that occasion, as Densher came in—he had felt it in the hall at the time. Accordingly, he was less at a loss to recognize, in a few seconds, as the renewed meeting brought it to the surface, the same potential quantity. Restless as he was, Densher dismissed his unease.

He needed to walk, regardless of the weather, and he headed through narrow streets toward the Piazza, where the galleries offered shelter. The arcade was crowded, filled with people. At the edge of the expanse, the ancient columns of Saint Theodore and the Lion framed an opening to the storm. It struck him as strange that a single thing could make such a difference—if the difference wasn't simply that the palace had, for the first time, not welcomed him.

Translation

He needed to walk, no matter the weather, and he went through narrow streets towards the Piazza, where the galleries offered shelter. The arcade was crowded, filled with people. At the edge of the expanse, the old columns of Saint Theodore and the Lion framed an opening to the storm. It struck him as odd that a single thing could make such a difference—if the difference wasn't simply that the palace had, for the first time, not welcomed him.

There was more to it, but it stemmed from that. That was the jarring note, the disruption of the spell. Now, the wet and cold were a factor, and it felt to Densher as though the foundation of their shared belief had been erased. The foundation had been his word for it, for the thing that, though it had endured, could withstand no shock.

Translation

There was more to it, of course, but it all came from that initial thing. That was the discordant element, the thing that broke the magic. Now, the rain and cold played a role, and Densher felt as if the bedrock of their mutual faith had been destroyed. His word had been the bedrock, for the thing that, though it had held, couldn’t endure any sort of blow.

The shock, in some form, had arrived, and he pondered it, weaving through aimless figures, his gaze drifting over the displays in shops. Sections of the gallery were paved with red marble, now slick with sea spray. The entire place, in its grand elegance, the grace of its design and beauty of its details, resembled a grand drawing room, the drawing room of Europe, now marred and confused by a misfortune. He bumped into brown-skinned men, their hats askew and the loose sleeves of their jackets making them appear like mournful masqueraders.

Translation

The blow, in one way or another, had landed, and he turned it over in his mind, threading his way through the aimless crowds, his eyes moving across the shop windows. Parts of the arcade were paved with red marble, now glossy with the mist. The whole place, in its grand elegance, the grace of its design and the beauty of its details, resembled a magnificent drawing room, the drawing room of Europe, now disfigured and bewildered by a disaster. He jostled with brown-skinned men, their hats askew and the loose sleeves of their jackets making them look like dejected revelers.

Tables and chairs spilled out from the cafes and were arranged within the arcade, with the pretense of service. Here and there, a bespectacled German, his coat collar turned up, publicly consumed food and engaged in philosophical discussion. These were all observations for Densher too, but he had circled the space three times before he halted abruptly, in front of Florian's, with the force of his sharpest attention. He'd seen a face within the café—he'd spotted an acquaintance behind the glass.

Translation

Cafes had pushed their tables and chairs out into the arcade, faking the existence of service. A German with glasses, collar turned up, ate and talked philosophy in public here and there. Densher observed all of this, too, but he circled the space three times before stopping sharply in front of Florian's, his attention fully engaged. He had seen a face inside the cafe—an acquaintance, spotted through the glass.

The person he had paused to observe was seated at a small table, a neglected glass half-empty, and though he had a French newspaper on his knee—the heading of the Figaro was visible—he stared directly ahead at the rococo wall across from him. Densher saw his profile, and for a moment, the identity of the man sparked connections—startling and direct. Then, as if this was all that was needed, he caught the look, determined by a turn of the head, that may have resulted from the feeling of being observed. This full view revealed Lord Mark—Lord Mark as they had met, weeks before, on the day of their first visit to Palazzo Leporelli.

Translation

The man was at a small table, a half-empty glass in front of him. He had a French newspaper on his lap, the *Figaro*'s masthead showing, but he was staring at the rococo wall opposite him. Densher saw his profile, and for a moment, the man's identity triggered connections—startling and immediate. Then, as if this was all it took, he saw the glance, determined by a turn of the head, that might have been caused by the feeling of being watched. This full view revealed Lord Mark—Lord Mark as they had met weeks earlier, the day of their first visit to Palazzo Leporelli.

Lord Mark had been on his way out when he had arrived—he had felt it then, in the hall. He was therefore less surprised to recognize, in a few seconds, as this renewed encounter brought it to the surface, the same potential energy. It was a matter, the whole passage—it could only be—but of a few seconds; for as he might neither stand there to stare nor on the other hand make any advance from it, he had presently resumed his walk, this time to another pace. It had been for all the world, during his pause, as if he had caught his answer to the riddle of the day.

Translation

Lord Mark had been about to leave when he arrived—he had felt it in the hall. Therefore, he was less surprised to recognize, in a few seconds, as this renewed encounter brought it to the surface, the same potential energy. The whole episode—it could only be—was a matter of a few seconds; for he could neither stand there staring nor, on the other hand, advance in any way, so he had quickly resumed his walk, this time at a different pace. During his pause, it had been as if he had caught his answer to the riddle of the day.

Lord Mark had simply faced him—as he had faced him, not placed by him, not at first—as one of the damp shuffling crowd. Recognition, though hanging fire, had then clearly come; yet no light of salutation had been struck from these certainties. Acquaintance between them was scant enough for neither to take it up. That neither had done so was not, however, what now mattered, but that the gentleman at Florian's should be in the place at all.

Translation

Lord Mark had simply faced him—as he had faced him, not positioned by him, not at first—as if he were one of the damp, shuffling crowd. Recognition, though slow to ignite, had then clearly come; yet no spark of greeting had been struck from these certainties. Acquaintance between them was slight enough for neither to initiate contact. That neither had done so was not, however, what now mattered, but that the gentleman at Florian's should be present at all.

He couldn't have been in it long; Densher, as inevitably a haunter of the great meeting-ground, would in that case have seen him before. He paid short visits; he was on the wing; the question for him even as he sat there was of his train or of his boat. He had come back for something—as a sequel to his earlier visit; and whatever he had come back for it had had time to be done. He might have arrived but last night or that morning; he had already made the difference.

Translation

He couldn't have been there for long; Densher, who was invariably a presence in that central gathering place, would have noticed him sooner. The man made brief appearances; he was passing through. Even as he sat, his thoughts were occupied with his train or his ship. He'd returned for something—a follow-up to his previous visit. Whatever the reason for his return, he'd had time to accomplish it. He might have arrived just last night or this morning, but he had already made an impact.

It was a great thing for Densher to get this answer. He held it close, he hugged it, quite leaned on it as he continued to circulate. It kept him going and going—it made him no less restless. But it explained—and that was much, for with explanations he might somehow deal.

Translation

Receiving that answer was a turning point for Densher. He clutched at it, embraced it, leaned on it as he continued his rounds. It buoyed him, kept him moving—though his restlessness persisted. But it clarified things—and that was significant, because with explanations, he could find a way forward.

The vice in the air, otherwise, was too much like the breath of fate. The weather had changed, the rain was ugly, the wind wicked, the sea impossible, because of Lord Mark. It was because of him, a fortiori, that the palace was closed. Densher went round again twice; he found the visitor each time as he had found him first.

Translation

The oppressive feeling in the atmosphere, besides, felt like the inescapable hand of destiny. The weather had shifted: the rain was ugly, the wind cruel, the sea impassable—all due to Lord Mark. It was because of him, and even more so, that the palace was shut down. Densher circled the premises twice more, finding the visitor in the same place he'd found him initially.

Once, that is, he was staring before him; the next time he was looking over his Figaro, which he had opened out. Densher didn't again stop, but left him apparently unconscious of his passage—on another repetition of which Lord Mark had disappeared. He had spent but the day; he would be off that night; he had now gone to his hotel for arrangements. These things were as plain to Densher as if he had had them in words.

Translation

First, he was staring straight ahead. The next moment, he was reading his *Figaro*, which he'd unfolded. Densher didn't pause again, but left him seemingly unaware of his passing—on his next circuit, Lord Mark was gone. He'd only spent the day; he was leaving that night; he'd gone to his hotel to make arrangements. These things were as clear to Densher as if he'd been told them.

The obscure had cleared for him—if cleared it was; there was something he didn't see, the great thing; but he saw so round it and so close to it that this was almost as good. He had been looking at a man who had done what he had come for, and for whom, as done, it temporarily sufficed. The man had come again to see Milly, and Milly had received him. His visit would have taken place just before or just after luncheon, and it was the reason why he himself had found her door shut.

Translation

The fog had lifted for him—if it had lifted at all; there was something he didn't grasp, the most important thing; but he understood it so well, and he was so close to understanding it, that it was nearly the same. He had been looking at a man who had accomplished his goal, and for whom, now that it was done, it was enough, for the moment. The man had returned to see Milly, and Milly had received him. His visit had occurred just before or just after lunch, and that was why he himself had found her door closed.

The whole thing had happened in a matter of seconds. He couldn't just stand there and stare, but he also couldn't approach the man, so he resumed walking, at a different pace this time. During that pause, it felt as though he'd found the solution to the day's puzzle. Lord Mark had simply faced him—he'd faced him first, not positioned by him—as if he were just another person in the crowd.

Translation

The entire situation had unfolded in a flash. He couldn't just stand there gawking, but he also couldn't bring himself to approach the man. So, he started walking again, this time at a different speed. In that moment of hesitation, it felt as though he'd stumbled upon the answer to the day's mystery. Lord Mark had simply confronted him—he'd been the one to initiate the confrontation, not the other way around—as though he were just another face in the throng.

Although he seemed hesitant at first, recognition had clearly come; yet there had been no sign of greeting from either of them. They barely knew each other well enough to acknowledge each other. But it wasn't the lack of acknowledgment that mattered now. It was the fact that the gentleman from Florian's was even there at all.

Translation

Even if he'd seemed unsure, the recognition was there, unmistakable. Still, there had been no overture of any kind. They barely knew each other well enough to nod. But that lack of recognition wasn't the issue. The real question was why the man from Florian's was even present.

He couldn't have been there long; Densher, who frequented this place, would have seen him sooner. He made quick visits; he was in transit; the only thing he was concerned with was his train or his boat. He had returned for something—as a follow-up to his earlier visit; and whatever he'd returned for, he'd had time to accomplish. He might have arrived last night or that morning, but he had already made an impact.

Translation

He couldn't have been there for long. Densher, a regular here, would have noticed him sooner. He was making brief stops, passing through. All that mattered to him was his train or his ship. He’d come back for something—as a continuation of his previous visit. And whatever he’d returned for, he’d already had time to do. He might have arrived last night or this morning, but he’d already made his presence felt.

It was a significant breakthrough for Densher to have this answer. He held onto it, embraced it, and relied on it as he continued to walk. It kept him going, and going—but it also made him uneasy. However, it explained things—and that was helpful because he could somehow manage with explanations.

Translation

The answer was a real breakthrough for Densher. He clung to it, embraced it, and depended on it as he kept walking. It sustained him, kept him moving—but it also made him uneasy. Still, it explained things—and that was helpful because he could somehow cope with explanations.

Otherwise, the atmosphere was like a dark omen. The weather had changed, the rain was awful, the wind was fierce, and the sea was impossible, all because of Lord Mark. It was because of him, undeniably, that the palace was closed. Densher went around twice more; each time, he found the visitor in the same spot.

Translation

The air felt thick with dread. The weather had turned; the rain was torrential, the wind howled, and the sea was a raging beast, all somehow because of Lord Mark. It was his fault, beyond question, that the palace remained shuttered. Densher circled the building again and again, but the visitor remained in the same place.

Once, he was staring straight ahead; the next time, he was looking at his newspaper, which he'd opened. Densher didn't stop again but left him seemingly unaware of his presence—and on another pass, Lord Mark had disappeared. He had only spent the day; he would be leaving that night; he had probably gone to his hotel to make arrangements. These things were as clear to Densher as if he'd been told them.

Translation

One moment, the man was gazing directly forward; the next, he was focused on his open newspaper. Densher did not stop again, instead departing, leaving the man seemingly oblivious to his presence—and on another pass, Lord Mark was gone. He had only been here for the day. He would be departing tonight. He had likely gone to his hotel to make arrangements. All of this was as obvious to Densher as if he had been explicitly told.

The mystery had been solved for him—or so it seemed; there was one major thing he didn't understand, but he saw so much around it and so close to it that it was almost as good. He had been looking at a man who had accomplished what he'd come for, and for whom, having done so, it was temporarily sufficient. The man had come again to see Milly, and Milly had received him. His visit must have taken place just before or just after lunch, and that was the reason why he himself had found her door closed.

Translation

The puzzle was solved, or so it appeared. There was one significant aspect he didn't grasp, but he understood so much else, so closely related, that it hardly mattered. He'd observed a man who had achieved his objective, and for whom, having done so, that was enough, for now. The man had returned to see Milly, and Milly had welcomed him. The visit must have occurred just before or after lunch, which explained why he'd found her door closed.

He said to himself that evening, he still said even on the morrow, that he only wanted a reason, and that with this perception of one he could now mind, as he called it, his business. His business, he had settled, as we know, was to keep thoroughly still; and he asked himself why it should prevent this that he could feel, in connexion with the crisis, so remarkably blameless. He gave the appearances before him all the benefit of being critical, so that if blame were to accrue he shouldn't feel he had dodged it. But it wasn't a bit he who, that day, had touched her, and if she was upset it wasn't a bit his act.

Translation

He told himself that evening, and continued to tell himself the next day, that he only needed a justification, and with this understanding of one, he could now, as he put it, tend to his own affairs. His plan, as we know, was to remain utterly passive, and he wondered why that plan should be disrupted because he felt so exceptionally innocent regarding the recent events. He gave the circumstances every opportunity to be critical, so if blame were to be assigned, he wouldn't feel he'd avoided it. But it wasn't him at all who had been involved with her that day, and if she was upset, it wasn't because of anything he had done.

The ability so to think about it amounted for Densher during several hours to a kind of exhilaration. The exhilaration was heightened fairly, besides, by the visible conditions—sharp, striking, ugly to him—of Lord Mark's return. His constant view of it, for all the next hours, of which there were many, was as a demonstration on the face of it sinister even to his own actual ignorance. He didn't need, for seeing it as evil, seeing it as, to a certainty, in a high degree "nasty," to know more about it than he had so easily and so wonderfully picked up.

Translation

Densher's ability to think about it all amounted to a sort of exhilaration for several hours. This exhilaration was, in fact, further amplified by the visible conditions of Lord Mark's return—sharp, striking, and ugly, as far as Densher was concerned. His consistent view of it, for the many hours that followed, was as a demonstration of something sinister, even given his own actual ignorance. He didn't need any more information than he had so easily and wonderfully acquired in order to see it as evil, to see it, with certainty, as exceedingly "nasty."

You couldn't drop on the poor girl that way without, by the fact, being brutal. Such a visit was a descent, an invasion, an aggression, constituting precisely one or other of the stupid shocks he himself had so decently sought to spare her. Densher had indeed drifted by the next morning to the reflexion—which he positively, with occasion, might have brought straight out—that the only delicate and honourable way of treating a person in such a state was to treat her as he, Merton Densher, did. With time, actually—for the impression but deepened—this sense of the contrast, to the advantage of Merton Densher, became a sense of relief, and that in turn a sense of escape.

Translation

You couldn't treat the poor girl that way without being brutal. Such a visit was a descent, an invasion, an act of aggression, representing the exact kind of stupid shocks he had tried so hard to protect her from. Densher had drifted by the next morning to the thought—which he might have voiced directly, given the circumstances—that the only delicate and honorable way to treat someone in such a state was to treat her as he, Merton Densher, did. In time, as the impression only intensified, this sense of contrast, to Merton Densher's advantage, became a feeling of relief, and that in turn, a feeling of escape.

It was for all the world—and he drew a long breath on it—as if a special danger for him had passed. Lord Mark had, without in the least intending such a service, got it straight out of the way. It was he, the brute, who had stumbled into just the wrong inspiration and who had therefore produced, for the very person he had wished to hurt, an impunity that was comparative innocence, that was almost like purification. The person he had wished to hurt could only be the person so unaccountably hanging about.

Translation

It was as if—and he drew a deep breath—a specific danger to him had vanished. Lord Mark, without intending to be helpful, had cleared it away. He, the brute, had blundered into the perfect, wrong idea, and, as a result, had created for the very person he'd wanted to harm an exemption, a comparative innocence, a sort of cleansing. The person he had wished to hurt could only be the person who was so inexplicably lingering.

To keep still meanwhile was, for this person, more comprehensively, to keep it all up; and to keep it all up was, if that seemed on consideration best, not, for the day or two, to go back to the palace. That evening, and even the next morning, he told himself that he just needed a reason. With that understanding, he could now focus on what he considered his own responsibilities. His responsibility, as we know, was to remain completely uninvolved.

Translation

To remain still, in the meantime, was, for this person, in a more comprehensive sense, to perpetuate everything; and to perpetuate everything was, if that seemed the best option upon consideration, to abstain from returning to the palace for a day or two. That evening, and even the following morning, he reasoned that he simply required a justification. With that understanding, he could now center his attention on what he deemed his own obligations. His obligation, as we are aware, was to remain entirely uninvolved.

He wondered why it should prevent him from doing so, considering he felt remarkably innocent in relation to the crisis. He gave the situation every benefit of the doubt, so that if there were any blame, he wouldn't feel he'd avoided it. But he hadn't touched her that day, and if she was upset, it wasn't his fault. This way of thinking gave Densher a kind of excitement for several hours.

Translation

He couldn't see any reason why he shouldn't do it, given how blameless he felt about the whole affair. He gave the circumstances every possible advantage, so he wouldn't be accused of shirking responsibility. But he hadn't touched her that day, and if she was unhappy, it wasn't his fault. This line of thought filled Densher with a sort of exhilaration for several hours.

This excitement was also fueled by the obvious circumstances—sharp, striking, and unpleasant to him—of Lord Mark's return. His persistent view of it, for many hours afterward, was that it was clearly sinister, even with his ignorance of the facts. He didn't need to know more than he'd so easily and wonderfully learned to see it as evil, as undeniably "nasty." You couldn't treat the poor girl that way without being brutal. Such a visit was a descent, an invasion, an act of aggression, representing precisely the sort of rude shock he himself had been carefully trying to avoid.

Translation

This exhilaration was further heightened by the obvious circumstances of Lord Mark's return, which were sharp, striking, and deeply unpleasant to Densher. For many hours afterward, his persistent view was that this return was clearly sinister, even without knowing the details. He didn't need to know more than what he already knew so easily and wonderfully, to see it as evil, as undeniably "nasty." You couldn't treat the poor girl that way without being brutal. Such a visit was a descent, an invasion, an act of aggression, representing exactly the sort of rude shock he had been carefully trying to avoid.

The next morning, Densher found himself thinking—a thought he might have spoken out loud—that the only delicate and honorable way to treat a person in such a state was to treat her as he, Merton Densher, did. With time—as the impression only deepened—this sense of contrast, to Merton Densher's advantage, became a sense of relief, which turned into a sense of escape. It was as if—and he took a deep breath—a specific danger for him had passed. Lord Mark, without intending to do so, had cleared it away.

Translation

The following morning, Densher thought, perhaps even audibly, that the only gentle and respectable way to treat someone in her situation was how he, Merton Densher, treated her. Over time, as the impression only intensified, this contrast worked in Merton Densher's favor. It became a sense of relief that evolved into a feeling of escape. It was as if—and he drew a deep breath—a specific danger for him had vanished. Lord Mark, unintentionally, had eliminated it.

He, the brute, had stumbled upon the wrong idea and therefore caused, for the very person he had wanted to hurt, an immunity that was comparative innocence, that was almost like purification. The person he had wanted to hurt could only be the person who was so inexplicably hanging around. To stay uninvolved in the meantime was, for this person, to comprehensively keep it all going; and to keep it all going was, if that seemed best after consideration, not to return to the palace for a day or two. The day or two passed—stretched to three days; and with the effect, extraordinarily, that Densher felt himself in the course of them washed but the more clean.

Translation

He, the brute, had landed on the wrong conclusion and therefore produced, for the very person he had intended to harm, a form of protection akin to innocence, almost a cleansing. The person he had wanted to hurt could only be the person who was inexplicably staying put. To remain uninvolved in the interim was, for this person, to comprehensively sustain everything; and to sustain everything was, if that seemed the wisest course after contemplation, not to return to the palace for a day or two. The day or two elapsed—extended to three days; and with the result, remarkably, that Densher felt himself during that time further purified.

Some sign would come if his return should have the better effect; and he was at all events, in absence, without the particular scruple. It wouldn't have been meant for him by either of the women that he was to come back but to face Eugenio. That was impossible—the being again denied; for it made him practically answerable, and answerable was what he wasn't. There was no neglect either in absence, inasmuch as, from the moment he didn't get in, the one message he could send up would be some hope on the score of health.

Translation

Some sign would appear if his return proved beneficial; and at least, in his absence, he was free of this specific concern. Neither of the women intended for him to return only to confront Eugenio. That was impossible—to be rejected again; it would make him effectively accountable, and he refused to be accountable. There was no neglect in his absence either, because, from the moment he stayed away, the only message he could send would be a hopeful report about her health.

Since accordingly that sort of expression was definitely forbidden him he had only to wait—which he was actually helped to do by his feeling with the lapse of each day more and more wound up to it. The days in themselves were anything but sweet; the wind and the weather lasted, the fireless cold hinted at worse; the broken charm of the world about was broken into smaller pieces. He walked up and down his rooms and listened to the wind—listened also to tinkles of bells and watched for some servant of the palace. He might get a note, but the note never came; there were hours when he stayed at home not to miss it.

Translation

Since that sort of expression was absolutely forbidden to him, he had only to wait. His feeling, with the passage of each day, actually helped him do so, growing more and more taut. The days themselves were anything but pleasant. The wind and weather persisted, and the fireless cold suggested something worse. The shattered charm of the world around him fragmented further. He paced his rooms, listening to the wind and also to the occasional tinkling of bells, watching for a palace servant. He might receive a note, but it never arrived. There were hours he stayed home specifically so as not to miss it.

When he wasn't at home he was in circulation again as he had been at the hour of his seeing Lord Mark. He strolled about the Square with the herd of refugees; he raked the approaches and the cafés on the chance the brute, as he now regularly imaged him, might be still there. He could only be there, he knew, to be received afresh; and that—one had but to think of it—would be indeed stiff. He had gone, however—it was proved; though Densher's care for the question either way only added to what was most acrid in the taste of his present ordeal.

Translation

When he wasn't at home, he was out and about again, just as he'd been when he first saw Lord Mark. He wandered around the Square with the other refugees. He scanned the streets and cafes, hoping the brute—as he now thought of him—might still be there. He knew the brute could only be there to be met again, and that—just thinking about it—would be difficult. The brute was gone, however—that was certain. Yet Densher's concern about the situation either way only made his current ordeal even more bitter.

It all came round to what he was doing for Milly—spending days that neither relief nor escape could purge of a smack of the abject. What was it but abject for a man of his parts to be reduced to such pastimes? What was it but sordid for him, shuffling about in the rain, to have to peep into shops and to consider possible meetings? What was it but odious to find himself wondering what, as between him and another man, a possible meeting would produce?

Translation

Everything came down to what he was doing for Milly—spending days that neither relief nor escape could cleanse of a hint of the degrading. What else was it but degrading for a man of his talents to be brought so low by these activities? What else was it but sordid for him, shuffling around in the rain, to have to peek into shops and consider potential encounters? What else was it but repulsive to find himself wondering what a potential meeting between him and another man would produce?

There recurred moments when in spite of everything he felt no straighter than another man. And yet even on the third day, when still nothing had come, he more than ever knew that he wouldn't have budged for the world. The day or two passed, stretching into three days. Surprisingly, Densher felt that he was becoming more clearheaded during this time.

Translation

Moments resurfaced when, despite everything, he felt no different than any other man. And yet, even on the third day, when nothing had yet materialized, he knew, more than ever, that he wouldn't have backed down for anything. The day or two blurred together, stretching into three days. Surprisingly, during this time, Densher felt he was becoming more clearheaded.

He expected some signal to come if his absence was having a positive effect. At any rate, in his current absence, he had no particular concerns. Neither woman would have expected him to return just to confront Eugenio. That was impossible – to be turned away again.

Translation

He anticipated some indication if his absence was yielding the desired results. At the very least, he had no pressing worries while he was gone. Neither woman would have wanted him to come back simply to challenge Eugenio. That was out of the question—to be rejected again.

It would make him responsible, and he wasn't responsible. There was no neglect in his absence either, because the only message he could send would be hopeful news about her health. Since he was explicitly forbidden from doing that, he simply had to wait. He was, in fact, helped in this by feeling more and more focused as each day passed.

Translation

That would make him liable, and he wasn't. There was no negligence in his absence, either, because the only message he could send would be good news about her health. Since he was expressly forbidden from doing that, he simply had to wait. He was, in fact, aided in this by feeling more and more centered as each day passed.

The days themselves were far from pleasant. The wind and cold persisted, and the lack of a fire hinted at worse to come. The broken enchantment of the world around him was shattered into even smaller pieces. He paced in his rooms, listening to the wind, also listening for the tinkling of bells and watching for a servant from the palace.

Translation

The days were anything but pleasant. Wind and cold were constant companions, and the absence of a fire suggested even worse things on the horizon. The already-fragile spell of the world around him had fractured into even smaller pieces. He paced his rooms, listening to the wind and also listening for the sound of bells, while watching for a palace servant.

He might get a note, but none came. There were hours when he stayed home so as not to miss it. When he wasn't at home, he was out and about again, as he had been when he saw Lord Mark. He strolled through the square with the other refugees.

Translation

No note came. He spent hours at home, not wanting to miss it. When he wasn't at home, he was out and about, just like when he saw Lord Mark. He walked through the square with the other refugees.

He searched the approaches and the cafes, hoping the brute, as he now pictured him, might still be there. He knew the brute could only be there to be greeted again. That would be difficult. However, the brute had gone – that was proven.

Translation

He looked everywhere: the streets, the coffee shops, hoping the brute, as he now imagined him, was still around. He knew the brute's only purpose for being there was to be met again. That would be hard. But the brute was gone – that was clear.

Densher's concern about the situation, one way or another, only made the taste of his present ordeal more bitter. It all came down to what he was doing for Milly, spending days that neither relief nor escape could cleanse of a feeling of utter degradation. What else was it but degrading for a man of his intelligence to be reduced to such pastimes? What else was it but sordid for him to shuffle around in the rain, peeking into shops, and contemplating possible meetings?

Translation

Densher's worry about the situation, whatever the outcome, only made his current suffering more painful. It all boiled down to what he was doing for Milly, wasting days that neither solace nor freedom could wash clean of a feeling of complete humiliation. What else was it but degrading for a man of his intellect to be brought so low, indulging in such empty pursuits? What else was it but sordid for him to trudge around in the rain, peering into shop windows, and pondering possible encounters?

What else was it but hateful to find himself wondering what a possible meeting between him and another man would bring? There were moments when, despite everything, he felt no better than any other man. And yet, even on the third day, when nothing had come, he knew more than ever that he wouldn't have changed anything for the world. He thought of the two women, in their silence, at last—he at all events thought of Milly—as probably, for her reasons, now intensely wishing him to go.

Translation

What else was it but hateful to find himself wondering what a possible encounter between him and another man would entail? There were moments when, despite everything, he felt no different than anyone else. And yet, even on the third day, when nothing had come of it, he knew more than ever that he wouldn't have altered a thing. He thought of the two women, in their silence, at last—or at least he thought of Milly—as probably, for her own reasons, now desperately wanting him to leave.

The cold breath of her reasons was, with everything else, in the air; but he didn't care for them any more than for her wish itself, and he would stay in spite of her, stay in spite of odium, stay in spite perhaps of some final experience that would be, for the pain of it, all but unbearable. That would be his one way, purified though he was, to mark his virtue beyond any mistake. It would be accepting the disagreeable, and the disagreeable would be a proof; a proof of his not having stayed for the thing—the agreeable, as it were—that Kate had named. The thing Kate had named was not to have been the odium of staying in spite of hints.

Translation

Her motivations, like everything else, hung in the air, a chilling presence. He dismissed them utterly, just as he dismissed her desires. He would remain, regardless of her objections, regardless of the potential for hatred, even if a final confrontation brought unbearable suffering. This, in his newly purified state, would be the undeniable proof of his virtue. It would be an embrace of the unpleasant, and the unpleasant would serve as confirmation. It would demonstrate that he was not staying for the thing—the agreeable outcome, so to speak—that Kate had alluded to. The thing Kate had named was not to become the despised object of staying despite subtle cues.

It was part of the odium as actual too that Kate was, for her comfort, just now well aloof. These were the first hours since her flight in which his sense of what she had done for him on the eve of that event was to incur a qualification. It was strange, it was perhaps base, to be thinking such things so soon; but one of the intimations of his solitude was that she had provided for herself. She was out of it all, by her act, as much as he was in it; and this difference grew, positively, as his own intensity increased.

Translation

Part of the resentment, and as real as anything else, was that Kate, to her comfort, was now safely distant. These were the first hours since her escape in which his sense of what she had done for him on the eve of that event began to be qualified. It was strange, perhaps even base, to be thinking such things so soon; but one of the signs of his solitude was that she had taken care of herself. She was out of it all, by her actions, as much as he was in it; and this difference grew, concretely, as his own intensity increased.
