She had said in their last sharp snatch of talk—sharp though thickly muffled, and with every word in it final and deep, unlike even the deepest words they had ever yet spoken: "Letters? Never—now. Think of it. Impossible." So that as he had sufficiently caught her sense—into which he read, all the same, a strange inconsequence—they had practically wrapped their understanding in the breach of their correspondence.

Translation

She had said in their last bitter exchange—bitter despite its muffled quality, every word final and profound, unlike even the most meaningful words they’d ever shared: "Letters? Never—now. Consider it. Impossible." So that, having fully grasped her meaning—in which he nonetheless detected an odd inconsistency—they had effectively sealed their understanding through a cessation of their correspondence.

He had moreover, on losing her, done justice to her law of silence; for there was doubtless a finer delicacy in his not writing to her than in his writing as he must have written had he spoken of themselves. That would have been a turbid strain, and her idea had been to be noble; which, in a degree, was a manner. Only it left her, for the pinch, comparatively at ease. And it left him, in the conditions, peculiarly alone.

Translation

Furthermore, upon losing her, he had honored her decree of silence. There was undoubtedly a greater refinement in his not writing to her than there would have been had he written as he surely would have had he spoken about them. That would have been a muddy affair, and her intention had been to be dignified; which, in a way, it was. Only it left her, in this predicament, relatively at peace. And it left him, under the circumstances, extraordinarily isolated.

He was alone, that is, till, on the afternoon of his third day, in gathering dusk and renewed rain, with his shabby rooms looking doubtless, in their confirmed dreariness, for the mere eyes of others, at their worst, the grinning padrona threw open the door and introduced Mrs. Stringham. That made at a bound a difference, especially when he saw that his visitor was weighted. It appeared part of her weight that she was in a wet waterproof, that she allowed her umbrella to be taken from her by the good woman without consciousness or care, and that her face, under her veil, richly rosy with the driving wind, was—and the veil too—as splashed as if the rain were her tears.

Translation

He was alone, that is, until, on the afternoon of his third day, as dusk gathered and rain returned, with his shabby rooms surely appearing at their dreariest, even at their worst, just for the sake of anyone else's eyes, the grinning landlady flung open the door and announced Mrs. Stringham. That immediately changed everything, particularly when he noticed his visitor was burdened. Part of her burden was that she wore a wet raincoat, that she let the good woman take her umbrella without noticing or caring, and that her face, beneath her veil, richly flushed from the driving wind, was—as was the veil—as splattered as though the rain were her tears.

He considered the two women, now silent—or at least, he thought of Milly—and assumed they were both, for their own reasons, intensely wishing him to leave. The chilling reality of their motives was palpable, but he disregarded them, including Milly's wish for him to go. He would stay, defying any disapproval, regardless of potential negative consequences, even if enduring an unbearable final experience. This was the only way he could definitively prove his integrity, even though he had been purified.

Translation

He assessed the two women, now quiet—or, at least, he considered Milly—and figured they both, for their own individual reasons, desperately wanted him gone. The stark truth of their feelings hung in the air, but he dismissed them, including Milly's desire for him to depart. He would remain, ignoring any disapproval, no matter the fallout, even if it meant suffering through an excruciating end. This was the sole means of definitively asserting his virtue, despite having been cleansed.

It meant embracing the unpleasantness, which would serve as proof that he wasn't staying for the attractive aspect Kate had mentioned. The attractive aspect Kate had named wasn't to be the disapproval of staying despite warnings. It was part of the actual disapproval that Kate was, for her own comfort, currently distant. These were the first few hours since her departure where his appreciation for what she had done for him before she left had become complicated.

Translation

He would have to endure the unpleasantness. This would prove he wasn't staying because of the appealing reason Kate had alluded to. The appealing reason Kate had mentioned wasn't the disapproval of remaining, despite the warnings. It was part of the very disapproval that Kate was now, for her own sake, currently distant from. These were the first few hours since her departure where his appreciation for what she had done for him, before she left, had become more complex.

It was odd, maybe even despicable, to think these things so soon. But solitude made him realize she had taken care of herself. She was removed from the situation because of her actions, while he was still immersed in it. This disparity grew stronger as his own intensity intensified.

Translation

It was strange, possibly even reprehensible, to think these thoughts so quickly. But being alone made him understand that she had looked out for herself. She was gone from the situation because of her choices, while he was still stuck in it. This difference became more pronounced as his own feelings grew more intense.

In their last tense conversation—though hushed and every word final and profound, unlike anything they had ever said before—she had declared, "Letters? Never—now. Consider it. Impossible." So, as he understood her perspective—though he still detected a strange inconsistency—they had effectively agreed to end their communication.

Translation

During their final, strained exchange—soft-spoken and with each word carrying significant weight, unlike any prior conversation—she had stated, "Letters? Absolutely not—not anymore. Think about it. Out of the question." Therefore, as he grasped her viewpoint—even while recognizing a subtle contradiction—they had tacitly agreed to cease contact.

Furthermore, after she left, he had respected her demand for silence. Not writing to her was arguably more sensitive than writing the kind of letter he would have sent if they had discussed their situation. A letter would have created turmoil, and her intention had been to act nobly, which was, in a sense, a performance. But it also allowed her to be relatively at ease in the difficult situation, which left him alone.

Translation

Moreover, after she departed, he honored her wish for silence. Refraining from writing her was arguably a more considerate gesture than the kind of letter he might have composed had they discussed their circumstances. A letter would have stirred up trouble, and her aim had been to behave nobly—a performance of sorts. But this also enabled her to navigate the difficult situation with relative ease, leaving him isolated.

He was alone, until, on the afternoon of the third day, as dusk gathered and rain returned, and his shabby rooms seemed at their worst, the landlady flung open the door and announced Mrs. Stringham. This immediately changed everything, particularly when he saw she was burdened. She was wearing a wet raincoat, and she let the landlady take her umbrella without noticing or caring.

Translation

He was alone, until, on the afternoon of the third day, as dusk descended and the rain returned, and his dismal rooms seemed at their most wretched, the landlady flung open the door and announced Mrs. Stringham. This instantly changed everything, especially when he saw that she was weighed down. She was wearing a soaked raincoat and allowed the landlady to take her umbrella without acknowledging or seeming to care.

Her face, under her veil, was flushed from the wind, and her veil was as wet as if the rain were her tears.

Translation

Beneath the veil, her face was red with windburn, and the veil itself was saturated, as though the rain were her own weeping.

Chapter 16

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
On a Thursday, as the weather improves from a storm to sunshine, a man named Densher goes to the train station to meet Sir Luke Strett. He arrives early and paces the platform. When the train arrives, Densher approaches Sir Luke's compartment. Sir Luke does not appear to recognize him at first, but then does. Outside the station, a servant named Eugenio is waiting with a gondola. Densher refuses a seat in the gondola, telling Sir Luke, "I don't go there now." Sir Luke says, "Oh," and departs in the gondola. Densher watches it leave, stands for a while, and then walks away. For the next few days, Densher waits in his lodgings. After several days, Sir Luke visits him. They spend the following days together until Saturday, walking around Venice, looking at art, visiting shops, and sitting at cafés. They do not mention Milly. On Saturday morning, Densher goes to the station to see Sir Luke off. Eugenio is also present. As Sir Luke is about to depart, he tells Densher he will return within the month. He then delivers a message from Milly Theale, asking Densher to go and see her. Sir Luke confirms that she is able to receive him. As the train starts to move, Densher says he will go that day and asks, "Then she's better?" Sir Luke replies, "Yes, she's better." The train pulls away, and Densher remains on the platform, observed by Eugenio.

They came to it almost immediately; he was to wonder afterwards at the fewness of their steps. "She has turned her face to the wall." "You mean she's worse?" The poor lady stood there as she had stopped; Densher had, in the instant flare of his eagerness, his curiosity, all responsive at sight of her, waved away, on the spot, the padrona, who had offered to relieve her of her mackintosh.

Translation

They found the situation almost instantly; he would later marvel at how few steps it took them to arrive. "She has turned her face to the wall." "You mean she's worse?" The poor lady stood exactly where she had stopped; Densher, in the sudden burst of his excitement and curiosity, which were both awakened by the sight of her, had waved away the padrona who had offered to take off her raincoat.

She looked vaguely about through her wet veil, intensely alive now to the step she had taken and wishing it not to have been in the dark, but clearly, as yet, seeing nothing. "I don't know how she is—and it's why I've come to you." "I'm glad enough you've come," he said, "and it's quite—you make me feel—as if I had been wretchedly waiting for you." They arrived at the situation almost right away.

Translation

She glanced vaguely around, her vision blurred by the rain. She was acutely aware of the decision she'd made, regretting that she'd done it without a clear view, but evidently, she still saw nothing. "I don't know how she is—that's why I've come to you." "I'm glad you're here," he said, "and it's… you make me feel… as if I'd been miserably waiting for you." They quickly understood the circumstances.

Later, he would marvel at how few steps it took. "She has turned her face to the wall." "You mean she's worse?" The poor woman remained standing as she was.

Translation

Later, he would be astonished at how few steps it took. "She's turned her face to the wall." "You mean she's gotten worse?" The poor woman stayed standing exactly as she was.

In a burst of eagerness and curiosity, Densher had dismissed the padrona, who had offered to take her raincoat. She looked around vaguely, her veil damp, keenly aware of her action. She wished she hadn't taken the step in the dark, but she clearly saw nothing yet. "I don't know how she is—that's why I came to you."

Translation

With a surge of enthusiasm and curiosity, Densher had waved away the padrona, who had been about to take her raincoat. She looked about her, unfocused, her veil damp, sharply conscious of what she'd done. She wished she hadn't taken the plunge in the dark, but she still saw nothing clearly. "I don't know how she is—that's why I came to you."

"I'm so glad you're here," he said. "You make me feel as though I'd been miserably waiting for you." She showed him again her blurred eyes—she had caught at his word. "Have you been wretched?"

Translation

"I'm so glad you're here," he said. "You make me feel like I'd been waiting for you, and it was awful." She looked up at him again, her eyes still unfocused—she'd latched onto his words. "Have you been miserable?"

Now, however, on his lips, the word expired. It would have sounded for him like a complaint, and before something he already made out in his visitor he knew his own trouble as small. Hers, under her damp draperies, which shamed his lack of a fire, was great, and he felt she had brought it all with her. He answered that he had been patient and above all that he had been still.

Translation

The word died on his lips. It would have sounded like a complaint, and before whatever it was he saw in his visitor, his own problems seemed insignificant. Hers, beneath her wet clothes, which made him feel ashamed of not having a fire, was immense, and he sensed she'd brought it all with her. He replied that he'd been patient and, above all, that he'd been still.

"As still as a mouse—you'll have seen it for yourself. Stiller, for three days together, than I've ever been in my life. It has seemed to me the only thing." This qualification of it as a policy or a remedy was straightway for his friend, he saw, a light that her own light could answer.

Translation

"As still as a mouse—you'll have seen it for yourself. Stiller, for three days straight, than I've ever been in my life. It's felt like the only way." This framing of it, as a policy or a cure, was immediately a beacon to his friend, he saw, a light that her own could match.

"It has been best. I've wondered for you. But it has been best," she said again. She looked at him with her unfocused eyes—she had latched onto his word.

Translation

"It has been the best course. I've worried about you. But it truly has been the best," she repeated. Her gaze, unfixed, fell upon him; she had seized upon his statement.

"Have you been miserable?" But the word died on his lips. It would have sounded like a lament, and faced with something he sensed in her, his own struggles seemed insignificant. Hers, veiled by her sadness, which made him feel ashamed of his comfortable surroundings, was immense, and he felt she'd brought it all with her.

Translation

"Were you unhappy?" The question caught in his throat. It would have sounded like a complaint, and in the face of whatever he sensed in her, his own troubles felt small. Hers, hidden behind her sadness, which made him embarrassed by his own ease, was vast, and he felt as though she carried it with her always.

He replied that he'd been enduring and, above all, quiet. "As still as a mouse—you'll have noticed. Still, for three consecutive days, more so than I've ever been. It seemed the only option."

Translation

He answered that he'd been enduring, and above all, quiet. "As still as a mouse—you'll have noticed. Still, for three days running, more so than ever before. It seemed the only way."

This framing of his behavior as a strategy or solution immediately provided an insight for his friend, he realized, a perspective that resonated with her own. "It's been the best course. I've worried about you. But it has been best," she repeated.

Translation

This explanation of his actions as a deliberate choice, a way forward, clicked for his friend instantly, he understood, striking a chord with her own experiences. "You've done the right thing. I was concerned. But you made the right decision," she reiterated.

"Yet it has done no good?" "I don't know. I've been afraid you were gone." Then as he gave a headshake which, though slow, was deeply mature: "You won't go?" "Is to 'go,'" he asked, "to be still?"

Translation

"But has it helped?"

"I don't know. I was worried you'd disappeared."

Then, he shook his head slowly, but with a deep, knowing weight. "You won't leave?"

"Is 'leaving'," he asked, "the same as being still?"

"Oh I mean if you'll stay for me." "I'll do anything for you. Isn't it for you alone now I can?" She thought of it, and he could see even more of the relief she was taking from him.

Translation

"Oh, I mean, if you'll stay for me." "I'll do anything for you. Isn't it only for you now that I can?" She considered it, and he saw even more of the relief she was finding in him.

His presence, his face, his voice, the old rooms themselves, so meagre yet so charged, where Kate had admirably been to him—these things counted for her, now she had them, as the help she had been wanting: so that she still only stood there taking them all in. With it however popped up characteristically a throb of her conscience. What she thus tasted was almost a personal joy. It told Densher of the three days she on her side had spent.

Translation

His presence, his face, his voice, the old rooms themselves—so meager yet so potent—where Kate had been so admirable to him: these things mattered to her, now that she had them, like the assistance she had been craving. She simply stood there, absorbing it all. Along with this, though, a pang of her conscience surfaced, as it always did. What she was experiencing was almost a selfish pleasure. It spoke to Densher of the three days she, for her part, had spent.

"Well, anything you do for me—is for her too. Only, only—!" "So it hasn't helped?" "I don't know.

Translation

"Well, anything you do for me—is for her too. Only, only—!" "So it hasn't helped?" "I don't know."

I was worried you'd left." He slowly shook his head, a gesture heavy with experience. "You won't leave, will you?" "Is 'leaving' the same as being still?" he asked.

Translation

"I was concerned you'd gone." He slowly moved his head, the motion carrying the weight of his past. "You won't go, will you?" "Is 'staying' the same as being motionless?" he asked.

"No, I mean if you'll stay with me." "I'll do anything for you. Isn't it solely for you that I can even do anything at all now?" She considered this, and he saw how much his presence was comforting her.

Translation

"No, I mean will you stay with me," she said. "I'll do anything for you. Isn't it only because of you that I can still do anything at all?" She thought about it, and he saw how much he was helping her just by being there.

His presence, his face, his voice, the familiar rooms—so plain, yet so full of meaning, where Kate had been so good to him—these things were exactly the help she'd been seeking, and she was simply taking it all in. But then, as always, her conscience stirred. What she felt was almost personal happiness. It revealed to Densher the past three days she had spent.

Translation

His presence, his face, his voice, the familiar rooms—so unremarkable, yet so significant, the rooms where Kate had been so kind to him—these were precisely the support she’d been searching for, and she was simply absorbing it all. But then, as always, her conscience nudged her. What she was experiencing was almost personal joy. It revealed to Densher the previous three days of her life.

"Well, anything you do for me... is also for her. But, only—!" "Only nothing now matters?"

Translation

"Well, anything you do for me... is also for her. But, only—!"

"Only nothing now matters?"

She looked at him a minute as if he were the fact itself that he expressed. "Then you know?" "Is she dying?" he asked for all answer. Mrs.

Translation

"She, then, knows," she said, looking at him as if he were the very embodiment of the thing he was saying. "You understand?" "Is she dying?" he asked, not answering her statement. Mrs.

Stringham waited—her face seemed to sound him. Then her own reply was strange. "She hasn't so much as named you. We haven't spoken."

Translation

Stringham waited, as if her face was trying to read him. Then her own reply was strange. "She hasn't even mentioned you. We haven't spoken about it."

"Not for three days?" "No more," she simply went on, "than if it were all over. Not even by the faintest allusion." "Oh," said Densher with more light, "you mean you haven't spoken about me?"

Translation

"Not for three days?" "No more," she simply went on, "than if it were

all over. Not even by the faintest hint." "Oh," said Densher, understanding better, "you mean

you haven't spoken about me?"

"About what else? No more than if you were dead." "Well," he answered after a moment, "I am dead." "Then I am," said Susan Shepherd with a drop of her arms on her waterproof.

Translation

"About what else? Not a whisper, as if you were gone." "Right," he replied after a pause, "I am gone." "Then so am I," said Susan Shepherd, her arms falling to her sides, resting on her waterproof.

"So, nothing matters anymore?" She stared at him, as if he embodied the very words he spoke. "Then you're aware of it?" "Is she dying?" he asked, not offering any other response.

Translation

"So, nothing matters anymore?" She stared at him, as if he was the embodiment of the words he spoke. "Then you're aware of it?" "Is she dying?" he asked, offering no further response.

Mrs. Stringham hesitated, studying his expression. Then, her own reply was peculiar. "She hasn't mentioned you, not even once.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham paused, considering his face. Then, her response was odd. "She hasn't spoken your name, not even in passing."

We haven't discussed it." "Not in three days?" "It's as if it's all finished," she continued simply. "Not even a hint."

Translation

"We haven't talked about it," he said. "Not in three days?" She continued, plainly, "It's as if everything is over. Not even a mention."

"Oh," Densher said, understanding a bit better, "you mean you haven't brought me up?" "What else would I be talking about? It's as if you were dead." "Well," he replied after a moment, "in a way, I am dead."

Translation

"Oh," Densher said, starting to understand, "You mean you haven't mentioned me?" "What else would I be discussing? It's as if you were gone." "Well," he replied after a moment, "in a way, I am."

"Then so am I," said Susan Shepherd, her arms dropping limply to her side, resting on her coat. It was a tone that, for the minute, imposed itself in its dry despair; it represented, in the bleak place, which had no life of its own, none but the life Kate had left—the sense of which, for that matter, by mystic channels, might fairly be reaching the visitor—the very impotence of their extinction. And Densher had nothing to oppose it withal, nothing but again: "Is she dying?" It made her, however, as if these were crudities, almost material pangs, only say as before: "Then you know?"

Translation

"Then so am I," Susan Shepherd said, her arms falling limply to her sides, resting on her coat. The tone, for the moment, imposed itself with its dry despair; it represented, in the bleak place, that had no life of its own, none but the life Kate had left—the sense of which, for that matter, by mystic channels, might fairly be reaching the visitor—the very impotence of their extinction. And Densher had nothing to oppose it with, nothing but to ask again: "Is she dying?" It made her, however, as if these were crudities, almost material pangs, only say as before: "Then you know?"

"Yes," he at last returned, "I know. But the marvel to me is that you do. I've no right in fact to imagine or to assume that you do." "You may," said Susan Shepherd, "all the same.

Translation

"Yes," he finally replied, "I do know. But the incredible thing to me is that you do. I actually have no right to imagine or to assume that you do." "You may," said Susan Shepherd, "all the same."

I know." For the moment, her tone of voice held sway; it was a dry and desolate despair. In this barren place, a place with no inherent vibrancy, a place devoid of anything other than what Kate had brought to it—and the visitor, by some mysterious means, might even be picking up on that—her voice expressed the stark reality of their fading existence. Densher had nothing to counter it with, nothing but to ask again, "Is she dying?"

Translation

"I understand." For the time being, her voice set the tone: a tone of dry, desolate despair. In this barren space, a place with no innate life, a place empty of everything except what Kate had brought to it—and the visitor, somehow, could even be sensing that—her voice articulated the grim reality of their dwindling existence. Densher had nothing to respond with, nothing but to ask again, "Is she dying?"

Her response, as if those questions were crude and almost physical pains, was merely to repeat, "Then you know?" "Yes," he finally replied, "I do know. But what surprises me is that you do. I really have no right to think or to suppose you're aware."

Translation

Her answer, as though those questions were somehow crass, even painful to endure, was simply to repeat, "So you understand?" "Yes," he said at last, "I do understand. But what I don't understand is you. I had no reason to believe, or even to imagine, that you were aware."

"You may," Susan Shepherd said, "all the same. I know." "Everything?" Her eyes, through her veil, kept pressing him.

Translation

"You might," Susan Shepherd said, "even so. I know." "Everything?" Her eyes, visible through her veil, continued to scrutinize him.

"No—not everything. That's why I've come." "That I shall really tell you?" With which, as she hesitated and it affected him, he brought out in a groan a doubting "Oh, oh!" It turned him from her to the place itself, which was a part of what was in him, was the abode, the worn shrine more than ever, of the fact in possession, the fact, now a thick association, for which he had hired it. That was not for telling, but Susan Shepherd was, none the less, so decidedly wonderful that the sense of it might really have begun, by an effect already operating, to be a part of her knowledge.

Translation

"No—not everything. That's why I'm here." "That I will actually tell you?" As she paused, affecting him, he let out a doubtful groan, "Oh, oh!" It turned him away from her and toward the place itself, which was a part of what was inside him. It was the abode, the worn shrine more than ever, of the fact in possession, the fact that was now a thick association, the reason he'd rented it. That wasn't for telling, but Susan Shepherd was, nonetheless, so decidedly wonderful that the feeling of it might really have started, through an already operating effect, to be a part of her knowledge.

He saw, and it stirred him, that she hadn't come to judge him; had come rather, so far as she might dare, to pity. This showed him her own abasement—that, at any rate, of grief; and made him feel with a rush of friendliness that he liked to be with her. The rush had quickened when she met his groan with an attenuation. "Everything?"

Translation

He saw, and it moved him, that she hadn't come to judge him. Instead, she had come, to the extent that she dared, to pity. This revealed her own humility—or, at least, her grief—and made him feel, in a rush of friendliness, that he enjoyed her company. This rush had accelerated when she responded to his groan with a softening. "Everything?"

Her eyes, visible through her veil, kept urging him. "No—not everything. That's why I'm here." "That I will actually tell you?" As she hesitated, and it disturbed him, he let out a groan of doubt, "Oh, oh!" It turned his attention away from her and to the place itself, which was a part of him, the dwelling, the worn-out sanctuary more than ever, of the existing truth, the truth, now a strong connection, for which he'd rented it.

Translation

Her eyes, visible through the veil, kept urging him. "No—not everything. That's why I'm here." "That I will actually tell you?" As she hesitated, and it disturbed him, he groaned, a sound of doubt, "Oh, oh!" It turned his attention away from her and to the place itself, which was a part of him, the dwelling, the worn-out sanctuary more than ever, of the existing truth, the truth, now a strong connection, for which he'd rented it.

That wasn't for revealing, but Susan Shepherd was, nonetheless, so truly remarkable that the feeling of it might really have begun, by an effect already in motion, to be a part of her understanding. He saw, and it moved him, that she hadn't come to condemn him; had come instead, as far as she was able, to sympathize. This revealed her own humility—that, at any rate, of sorrow; and made him feel, with a surge of warmth, that he enjoyed being with her. The surge intensified when she responded to his groan with a softened tone.

Translation

That wasn't something to be revealed, but Susan Shepherd was, regardless, so truly remarkable that the feeling of it might, in fact, have started, by an effect already underway, to become part of her understanding. He saw, and it moved him, that she hadn't come to condemn him; she'd come instead, to the best of her ability, to sympathize. This revealed her own humility—at least, the humility of sorrow; and made him feel, with a surge of warmth, that he enjoyed her company. The surge grew stronger when she responded to his groan with a softened tone.

"We shall at all events—if that's anything—be together." It was his own good impulse in herself. "It's what I've ventured to feel. It's much." She replied in effect, silently, that it was whatever he liked; on which, so far as he had been afraid for anything, he knew his fear had dropped.

Translation

"We will at least—if that means anything—be together." It was her own good impulse, reflected in herself. "It's what I've dared to feel. It's a great deal." She responded, essentially without speaking, that it was whatever he wanted it to be; at which point, as far as he'd been afraid of anything, he knew his fear had vanished.

The comfort was huge, for it gave back to him something precious, over which, in the effort of recovery, his own hand had too imperfectly closed. Kate, he remembered, had said to him, with her sole and single boldness—and also on grounds he hadn't then measured—that Mrs. Stringham was a person who wouldn't, at a pinch, in a stretch of confidence, wince. It was but another of the cases in which Kate was always showing.

Translation

The relief was immense, because it restored something valuable to him, something that his own efforts to heal had failed to fully grasp. He recalled Kate telling him, with her singular audacity—and for reasons he hadn't fully understood at the time—that Mrs. Stringham was someone who, even when pushed, wouldn't flinch, even in a moment of trust. It was just another example of Kate's insight.

"You don't think then very horridly of me?" "At the very least—if that's worth anything—we'll be together." It was a good feeling, reflected in her. "That's what I've hoped.

Translation

Stringham was someone who wouldn't back down, no matter what. That was another instance of Kate's intuition. "So, you don't think very poorly of me?" And her response was even more meaningful because it wasn't a nervous outpouring—as if she understood what he might have thought.

She turned over in fact what she thought, and that was what helped him. "Oh you've been extraordinary!" It made him aware the next moment of how they had been planted there. She took off her cloak with his aid, though when she had also, accepting a seat, removed her veil, he recognised in her personal ravage that the words she had just uttered to him were the one flower she had to throw.

Translation

She actually considered her thoughts, and that's what helped him. "Oh, you've been extraordinary!" It made him realize, in the next moment, how they had ended up there. She took off her cloak with his help, and when she also sat down and removed her veil, he saw in her personal ruin that the words she had just said to him were the only gesture she could offer.

They were all her consolation for him, and the consolation even still depended on the event. She sat with him at any rate in the grey clearance, as sad as a winter dawn, made by their meeting. The image she again evoked for him loomed in it but the larger. "She has turned her face to the wall."

Translation

Her response was the more profound for its lack of sentimentality. She seemed to grasp his unspoken thoughts. She contemplated the circumstances, and that was a comfort to him. "Oh, you've been extraordinary!"

That statement immediately made him realize how they had ended up there. She took off her cloak with his help. When she sat down and removed her veil, he saw how distraught she was. He understood that her words were the only comfort she could offer.

Translation

The realization of their predicament struck him immediately. She accepted his assistance in removing her cloak. As she sat and lifted her veil, he saw her distress. He understood that her words were all the solace she could provide.

They were her way of consoling him, and even that comfort hinged on the outcome. She sat with him in the dim, gray space of their meeting, as melancholy as a winter sunrise. The image she brought to mind loomed even larger. "She has turned her face to the wall."

Translation

Her words were her way of consoling him, and even that comfort depended on what happened. She sat with him in the dim, gray room where they met, as sad as a winter sunrise. The image she conjured was even more imposing. "She has turned her face to the wall."

He saw with the last vividness, and it was as if, in their silences, they were simply so leaving what he saw. "She doesn't speak at all? I don't mean not of me." "Of nothing—of no one." And she went on, Susan Shepherd, giving it out as she had had to take it.

Translation

He saw with final clarity, and it was as if, in their shared silences, they were merely abandoning what he witnessed. "She doesn't speak at all? I don't mean about me." "About nothing—about no one." And she continued, Susan Shepherd, relaying it as she had been forced to receive it.

"She doesn't want to die. Think of her age. Think of her goodness. Think of her beauty.

"She doesn't want to die. Consider her age. Consider her kindness. Consider her beauty."

Think of all she is. Think of all she has. She lies there stiffening herself and clinging to it all. So I thank God—!" the poor lady wound up with a wan inconsequence.

Translation

Consider everything she embodies. Consider everything she possesses. There she lies, stiffening in resistance, desperately holding on. So I thank God—!" the poor woman finished, her words fading into a weak, inconsequential breath.

He continued to be mystified. "Is she truly still?" "She's beyond quiet. She's severe."

It's what she has never been. So you see—all these days. I can't tell you—but it's better so. It would kill me if she were to tell me."

It's what she's never been. That's the thing. So you see—all these days. I can't explain—but it's for the best. It would destroy me if she were to tell me.

Translation

The very nature of her despair, so clear and decisive, ignited a fire within him. "But the doctor, all this time—?" "Tacchini? Oh, he's a good man."

He comes. He's proud of having been approved and coached by a great London man. He hardly in fact goes away; so that I scarce know what becomes of his other patients. He thinks her, justly enough, a great personage; he treats her like royalty; he's waiting on events.

Translation

He's coming. He's proud of having been endorsed and mentored by a renowned London physician. He practically never leaves, so I barely know what happens with his other patients. He thinks she's a remarkable person, which is fair; he treats her like she's royalty, waiting to see what will happen.

But she has barely consented to see him, and, though she has told him, generously—for she thinks of me, dear creature—that he may come, that he may stay, for my sake, he spends most of his time only hovering at her door, prowling through the rooms, trying to entertain me, in that ghastly saloon, with the gossip of Venice, and meeting me, in doorways, in the sala, on the staircase, with an agreeable intolerable smile. We don't," said Susan Shepherd, "talk of her." Her initial hope dissolved instantly. "I don't know what you can do."

Translation

But she's hardly agreed to see him, and, though she's told him—kindly, because she's thinking of me, the dear girl—that he can come, that he can stay, for my sake, he mostly just hovers by her door, wanders the rooms, trying to amuse me, in that awful drawing room, with Venetian gossip, encountering me in doorways, in the main hall, on the staircase, with a pleasant, unbearable smile. "We don't talk about her," said Susan Shepherd. Her first hope disappeared immediately. "I don't know what you can do."

"Me neither. But she might." Mrs. Stringham pondered.

Translation

"Me neither. But she might," Mrs. Stringham considered.

Translation

"But the doctor, all this time—?" "Tacchini? Oh, he's a nice man. He visits."

He's pleased that a respected London doctor approved and advised him. He practically never leaves; I don't know how he manages with his other patients. He correctly believes she's a remarkable person; he treats her like royalty; he's waiting to see what happens. Translation

He's glad a well-regarded doctor in London gave his blessing and provided guidance. The doctor is almost always here; I don't know how he deals with his other patients. We don't," Susan Shepherd said, "discuss her." "By her request?" "Absolutely. I don't do what she doesn't wish.

"We don't," Susan Shepherd said, "talk about her." "At her request?" "Precisely. I don't do anything she doesn't want."

We discuss the cost of food." "At her request, as well?" "Definitely. She suggested it as a topic when, the first time, she said that he could stay with us as long as we wanted, if it would be any comfort to me."
