Densher took it all in. "But he isn't any comfort to you!" "None whatever. That, however," she added, "isn't his fault."

Nothing's any comfort." "Certainly," Densher observed, "as I but too horribly feel, I'm not." "No. But I didn't come for that."

Translation

"Nothing offers any solace." "Of course," Densher remarked, "I'm certainly not, as I understand all too well, any kind of comfort." "No. But that's not why I'm here."

"You came for me." "Well then call it that." But she looked at him a moment with eyes filled full, and something came up in her the next instant from deeper still. "I came at bottom of course—" "At her request?"

Translation

"You came for me." "If you want to put it that way." But she looked at him for a moment, her eyes brimming, and something welled up inside her the next instant, from an even deeper place. "I came, at bottom, of course—" "At her request?"

"Yes, definitely. I don't do anything she doesn't want. We discuss the cost of food." "At her request, too?"

Translation

"Absolutely. I don't do anything she doesn't want me to. We talk about how much groceries cost." "At her request, as well?"

"Absolutely. She brought it up as a topic when she first said that he could stay as long as we wanted, if it would make me feel better." Densher absorbed this. "But he doesn't make you feel better!"

Translation

"Absolutely. She was the one who first mentioned it, when she said he could stay as long as we liked, if it would make me feel better." Densher took that in. "But he doesn't!"

"Not at all. However," she added, "that's not his fault. Nothing offers any comfort." "Indeed," Densher stated, "and I'm a prime example of that, as I'm painfully aware."

Translation

"Not at all. Although," she continued, "it isn't his fault. Nothing helps, nothing provides any solace." "Precisely," Densher responded, "and I'm living proof of that, as I know all too well."

"No. But that's not why I came." "You came for me." "Well, if you want to put it that way." But she gazed at him for a moment, her eyes brimming, and something welled up within her the next instant, from an even deeper place.

Translation

"No. That's not why I'm here." "You came for me." "If you want to look at it like that." But she looked at him, her eyes filling, and in the next instant, something surged from within her, from an even deeper place.

"The real reason I came, of course..." "You came at bottom of course for our friend herself. But if it's, as you say, too late for me to do anything?" She continued to look at him, and with an irritation, which he saw grow in her, from the truth itself.

Translation

"The real reason I came, of course..." "You came, fundamentally, for our friend. But if, as you say, it's too late for me to do anything?" She continued to look at him, and with an irritation, which he saw grow in her, born of the truth itself.

"So I did say. But, with you here"—and she turned her vision again strangely about her—"with you here, and with everything, I feel we mustn't abandon her." "God forbid we should abandon her." "Then you won't?" His tone had made her flush again.

Translation

"That's what I said. But, now that you're here"—and she looked around the room in a peculiar way—"now that you're here, with everything, I feel we can't give up on her." "God, I hope we don't give up on her." "So you won't?" Her face flushed again at his tone.

"How do you mean I 'won't,' if she abandons me? What can I do if she won't see me?" "But you said just now you wouldn't like it." "I said I shouldn't like it in the light of what you tell me.

Translation

"What do you mean 'won't'? What can I do if she walks away? What happens if she won't see me?" "But you just said you wouldn't want that." "I said I wouldn't want that, considering what you've told me."

I shouldn't like it only to see her as you make me. I should like it if I could help her. But even then," Densher pursued without faith, "she would have to want it first herself. And there," he continued to make out, "is the devil of it.

Translation

I wouldn't like it just to see her in the way you're describing. I would like it if I could help her. But even then," Densher continued without any hope, "she would have to want it first. And that," he continued to consider, "is the real problem.

She won't want it herself. She can't!" You came here, of course, because of our friend. But if, as you say, there's nothing I can do?

Translation

She won't want to. She can't! You came here, of course, because of our friend. But if, as you say, there's nothing I can do?

She kept looking at him, and he saw her frustration grow, stemming from the truth itself. "Yes, I did say that. But, with you here"—and she looked around strangely—"with you here, and with everything, I feel we mustn't give up on her." "God, no, we shouldn't give up on her."

Translation

He watched her, and saw her growing vexation, a product of the facts. "Yes, I did say that. But, with you here"—she looked around, oddly—"with you here, and with everything, I feel we have to keep trying for her." "No, we have to keep trying."

"So you won't?" His tone had made her blush again. "What do you mean 'won't,' if she abandons me? What can I do if she refuses to see me?" "But you just said you wouldn't like it."

Translation

"So, you won't?" His question brought a blush to her cheeks. "What do you mean, 'won't'? What can I do if she leaves me? What am I supposed to do if she won't even see me?" "But you just said you wouldn't like it."

"I said I wouldn't like it given what you've told me. I wouldn't like it just to see her as you've described. I would like it if I could help her. But even then," Densher continued without much hope, "she would have to want it first.

Translation

"I said I wouldn't like it, based on what you've told me. I wouldn't enjoy seeing her in the state you've described. I would like it if I could help her. But even then," Densher continued, sounding doubtful, "she would have to want it first."

And that," he continued, trying to understand, "is the problem. She won't want it. She can't!" He had got up in his impatience of it, and she watched him while he helplessly moved.

Translation

And that, he continued, attempting to grasp the situation, is the crux of the issue. She won't desire it. She's incapable! He rose, his agitation overcoming him, and she observed him as he moved about, utterly at a loss.

"There's one thing you can do. There's only that, and even for that there are difficulties. But there is that." He stood before her with his hands in his pockets, and he had soon enough, from her eyes, seen what was coming. She paused as if waiting for his leave to utter it, and as he only let her wait they heard in the silence, on the Canal, the renewed downpour of rain.

Translation

"There's one thing you can do. It's the only thing, though it's fraught with its own complications. But it exists." He stood before her, hands in his pockets. He saw in her eyes what was about to come. She hesitated, as though waiting for his permission to speak. He remained silent, and in that silence, they heard the rain begin again, pelting the canal.

She had at last to speak, but, as if still with her fear, she only half-spoke. "I think you really know yourself what it is." He did know what it was, and with it even, as she said—rather!—there were difficulties. He turned away on them, on everything, for a moment; he moved to the other window and looked at the sheeted channel, wider, like a river, where the houses opposite, blurred and belittled, stood at twice their distance.

Translation

She had to speak at last, but, as if still caught in her fear, she only half-spoke. "I think you really know yourself what it is." He did know what it was, and with it, as she said—rather!—there were difficulties. He turned away from them, from everything, for a moment; he moved to the other window and looked at the sheeted channel, wider, like a river, where the houses opposite, blurred and diminished, stood at twice their distance.

Mrs. Stringham said nothing, was as mute in fact, for the minute, as if she had "had" him, and he was the first again to speak. When he did so, however, it was not in straight answer to her last remark—he only started from that. He said, as he came back to her, "Let me, you know, see—one must understand," almost as if he had for the time accepted it.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham remained silent, completely mute, actually, for a moment, as if she had "won" him, and he was the first to speak again. However, when he did, he didn't directly respond to her last comment—he only used it as a starting point. He said, as he moved back toward her, "Let me, you know, see—one must understand," almost as though he'd temporarily accepted it.

And what he wished to understand was where, on the essence of the question, was the voice of Sir Luke Strett. If they talked of not giving her up shouldn't he be the one least of all to do it? "Aren't we, at the worst, in the dark without him?" He stood up, unable to contain himself any longer, and she watched him as he aimlessly walked about.

Translation

And what he wanted to understand was where, at the heart of the matter, Sir Luke Strett's voice was. If they were discussing not abandoning her, shouldn't he be the last person to do so? "At worst, aren't we lost without him?" He stood up, unable to restrain himself any longer, and she watched him as he aimlessly paced.

"There's one thing you could do. It's the only option, although it presents its own problems. But it's there." He stood before her with his hands in his pockets, and he quickly understood, from her gaze, what she was about to say. She hesitated, as though waiting for his permission to speak, and because he remained silent, they heard the rain starting again on the Canal.

Translation

"You could do one thing. It's the only way, though it's not without its drawbacks. But it's available." He stood in front of her with his hands shoved in his pockets, and he immediately knew, from her expression, what she was going to suggest. She paused, as though waiting for his consent to speak, and since he said nothing, they heard the rain begin again on the Canal.

Eventually, she had to speak, but she seemed hesitant, as if still afraid, and her words were incomplete. "I think you already know what it is." He did know what it was, and as she said, there were indeed problems. He briefly turned away, overwhelmed.

Translation

She finally spoke, though she sounded unsure, as if she were still frightened, her sentences unfinished. "I think you already know what it is." He did know, and as she’d said, there were, in fact, complications. Briefly, he looked away, consumed by it all.

He moved to the other window and looked out at the rain-swept waterway, which resembled a river. The houses across from them, blurred and diminished, appeared much further away. Mrs. Stringham said nothing, remaining silent, for a moment, as though she had won, and he was the first to speak again.

Translation

He went to the other window and gazed at the rain-lashed channel, which could have been a river. The houses opposite, hazy and indistinct, seemed miles away. Mrs. Stringham didn't say anything, silent for a moment, as though she'd prevailed, and he was the one to speak first.

However, he didn't directly respond to her last comment; he began elsewhere. As he returned to her, he said, "Let me, you know, understand—one must understand," almost as if he had accepted the idea. What he wanted to understand was where, at the heart of the matter, Sir Luke Strett stood. If they were discussing not giving her up, shouldn't he be the one least likely to do so?

Translation

He didn't address her last remark head-on, but changed course. As he turned back to her, he said, "Let me, you know, grasp—one must grasp," as if he'd conceded the point. What he wanted to understand was Sir Luke Strett's position, at its core. If they were talking about keeping her, shouldn't he be the last person to consider it?

"Aren't we, at the very least, lost without him?" "Oh," said Mrs. Stringham, "it's he who has kept me going. I wired the first night, and he answered like an angel.

Translation

"Wouldn't we, at the very least, be in a bad way without him?" "Oh," said Mrs. Stringham, "he's the one who's kept me going. I sent a telegram that first night, and he answered like an angel."

He'll come like one. Only he can't arrive, at the nearest, till Thursday afternoon." "Well then that's something." She considered.

Translation

"He'll be here, no question. The soonest he could get here is Thursday afternoon." "Alright, that's progress, I suppose." She paused, considering.

"Something—yes. She likes him." "Rather! I can see it still, the face with which, when he was here in October—that night when she was in white, when she had people there and those musicians—she committed him to my care.

Translation

"Something, definitely. She's into him." "You can say that again! I can still picture it, the look on her face when he was here in October—that night she wore white, when she had everyone over with the musicians—she practically entrusted him to my care."

It was beautiful for both of us—she put us in relation. She asked me, for the time, to take him about; I did so, and we quite hit it off. That proved," Densher said with a quick sad smile, "that she liked him." "Oh," Mrs.

Translation

It was beautiful for both of us—she connected us. For a while, she asked me to show him around. I did, and we got along quite well. That proved," Densher said with a quick, sad smile, "that she liked him." "Oh," Mrs.

Stringham said, "he's the reason I'm holding it together. I sent him a telegram the first night, and he responded like a savior. He'll come here like a savior. But the earliest he can get here is Thursday afternoon."

Translation

Stringham said, "he's the reason I'm coping. I wired him that first night, and he answered like a lifesaver. He'll arrive here like a savior. But the soonest he can get here is Thursday afternoon."

"Well, that's a good thing." She paused. "Yes, it is. She likes him."

Translation

"Good." She paused. "Yes, she does. She likes him."

"Of course! I still see her face from October—that night when she was wearing white, when she had guests and the musicians—when she entrusted him to me. It was wonderful for both of us; she created a connection between us. She asked me to look after him for a while; I did, and we got along quite well.

Translation

"Absolutely! I can still picture her from October—that night she wore white, with her guests and the musicians—the night she put him in my care. It was a beautiful thing for both of us; she forged a link between us. She asked me to watch over him for a time; I did, and we got along famously."

That showed," Densher said with a quick, melancholic smile, "that she liked him." "He liked you," Susan Shepherd presently risked. "Ah I know nothing about that." "You ought to then.

Translation

"That much was clear," Densher said with a quick, sad smile, "that she cared for him." "He cared for you," Susan Shepherd ventured. "Oh, I have no idea about that." "You should know, though."

He went with you to galleries and churches; you saved his time for him, showed him the choicest things, and you perhaps will remember telling me myself that if he hadn't been a great surgeon he might really have been a great judge. I mean of the beautiful." "Well," the young man admitted, "that's what he is—in having judged her. He hasn't," he went on, "judged her for nothing.

Translation

He went with you to galleries and churches; you saved him time, showed him the best things, and you might even remember telling me yourself that if he hadn't been a great surgeon, he might have been a great judge. I mean, of beauty.” “Well,” the young man admitted, “that’s what he is—in having judged her. He hasn’t,” he went on, “judged her for nothing.”

His interest in her—which we must make the most of—can only be supremely beneficent." He still roamed, while he spoke, with his hands in his pockets, and she saw him, on this, as her eyes sufficiently betrayed, trying to keep his distance from the recognition he had a few moments before partly confessed to. "I'm glad," she dropped, "you like him!" Susan Shepherd tentatively offered, "He liked you."

Translation

"We must take full advantage of his interest in her; it can only be a good thing." He continued to wander as he spoke, his hands in his pockets, and she saw him, as her eyes clearly showed, trying to avoid the realization he'd partially admitted to moments before. "I'm glad you like him!" Susan Shepherd offered hesitantly, "He liked you."

"Oh, I wouldn't know about that," came the reply. "You should know. He went with you to museums and cathedrals. You saved him time, showed him the best things.

Translation

"Oh, I wouldn't know," came the reply. "You should know, though. He went to museums and cathedrals with you. You saved him the trouble, pointed out the highlights."

You even told me yourself that if he hadn't been a brilliant surgeon, he could have been a great art critic. A great judge of beauty." The young man conceded, "Well, that's what he is, in having judged her." He continued, "He hasn't judged her for no reason. His interest in her – which we must capitalize on – can only be a good thing."

Translation

"You even told me that if he hadn't been an exceptional surgeon, he could have been a remarkable art critic, a true connoisseur of beauty." The younger man admitted, "Yes, well, that's essentially what he's done, in judging her." He went on, "His judgment isn't arbitrary. His interest in her—and we need to exploit this—can only be beneficial."

He paced as he spoke, hands in his pockets. She saw him trying to avoid acknowledging something he had partially admitted a few moments ago, as her eyes revealed. "I'm glad," she said quietly, "you like him!" There was something for him in the sound of it.

Translation

He paced as he spoke, hands in his pockets. She saw him trying to avoid acknowledging something he had partially admitted a few moments ago, as her eyes revealed. "I'm glad," she said quietly, "you like him!" There was something for him in the sound of it.

"Well, I do no more, dear lady, than you do yourself. Surely you like him. Surely, when he was here, we all liked him." "Yes, but I seem to feel I know what he thinks.

Translation

"Well, I'm not doing anything more than you are, dear. You certainly like him. Surely, when he was here, we all liked him." "Yes, but I feel like I know what he thinks."

And I should think, with all the time you spent with him, you'd know it," she said, "yourself." Densher stopped short, though at first without a word. "We never spoke of her. Neither of us mentioned her, even to sound her name, and nothing whatever in connexion with her passed between us."

Translation

"Well, with all the time you spent with him, I'd think you'd know it," she said. Densher stopped, though at first he didn't say anything. "We never spoke of her. Neither of us mentioned her, not even to say her name, and nothing about her ever came up between us."

Mrs. Stringham stared up at him, surprised at this picture. But she had plainly an idea that after an instant resisted it. "That was his professional propriety."

Translation

Mrs. Stringham looked up at him, surprised by this description. But it was clear she had an idea that she immediately dismissed. "That was his professional discretion."

The way she said it meant something to him. "Well, I'm doing exactly what you're doing. You like him, don't you? When he was here, we all liked him."

Translation

Her tone was significant. "Well, I'm doing the same thing as you, then. You like him, don't you? When he was here, we all did."

"Yes, but I feel like I know what he's thinking. And, considering how much time you spent with him, I would think you'd know too," she replied. Densher paused, initially speechless. "We never talked about her.

Translation

"Yes, but I feel like I understand what he's thinking. And, considering how much time you spent with him, I would assume you would too," she answered. Densher hesitated, at first unable to speak. "We never discussed her."

Neither of us brought her up, not even to say her name. Nothing related to her ever came up between us." Mrs. Stringham looked up at him, surprised.

Translation

"Neither of us ever mentioned her, not even to speak her name. Nothing about her was ever brought up between us." Mrs. Stringham looked up at him, surprised.

But it was clear that she had an idea that she quickly dismissed. "That was just proper behavior for him, professionally." "Precisely. But it was also my sense of that virtue in him, and it was something more besides." And he spoke with sudden intensity.

Translation

But it was evident she'd had a thought she immediately discarded. "That was just his professional propriety." "Exactly. But it was also my perception of that quality in him, and it was something more." He spoke with sudden passion.

"I couldn't talk to him about her!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd. "I can't talk to any one about her." "Except to me," his friend continued.

Translation

"I couldn't talk to him about her!" "Oh!" said Susan Shepherd. "I can't talk to anyone about her." "Except to me," his friend continued.

"Except to you." The ghost of her smile, a gleam of significance, had waited on her words, and it kept him, for honesty, looking at her. For honesty too—that is for his own words—he had quickly coloured: he was sinking so, at a stroke, the burden of his discourse with Kate. His visitor, for the minute, while their eyes met, might have been watching him hold it down. And he had to hold it down—the effort of which, precisely, made him red.

Translation

"Except to you." The ghost of her smile, a meaningful glint, lingered on her words, and it compelled him, for the sake of honesty, to keep his gaze fixed on her. Honesty—that is, in regard to his own words—had quickly brought a flush to his face: he was sinking fast, at once, beneath the weight of his conversation with Kate. For that moment, while their eyes met, his visitor might have been watching him suppress it. And he had to suppress it—the very effort of which made him blush.

He couldn't let it come up; at least not yet. She might make what she would of it. He attempted to repeat his statement, but he really modified it. "Sir Luke, at all events, had nothing to tell me, and I had nothing to tell him.

Translation

He couldn't allow himself to bring it up, not yet anyway. She might interpret it however she chose. He tried to repeat his statement, but in truth, he changed it. "Sir Luke, at any rate, had nothing to tell me, and I had nothing to tell him."

Make-believe talk was impossible for us, and—" "Exactly. But it was also my perception of his good qualities, and there was something else, too." He spoke with sudden passion. "I couldn't speak to him about her!"

Translation

"We couldn't fake anything, ever, and—" "Exactly. But it was also that I saw the good in him, and there was something else, too." He spoke with sudden passion. "I couldn't talk to him about her!"

"Oh!" said Susan Shepherd. "I can't speak to anyone about her." "Except to me," his friend added. "Except to you." A hint of her smile, an expression of understanding, accompanied her words, and this forced him to look at her, for the sake of honesty.

Translation

"Oh!" Susan Shepherd said. "I can't talk to anyone about her."

"Except to me," his friend added.

"Except to you." A flicker of a smile, an expression of comprehension, accompanied her words, compelling him to meet her gaze, to be truthful.

Because of his own words, he quickly blushed: he was, in a single moment, undermining the weight of his conversation with Kate. For that instant, as their eyes met, she might have been watching him suppress his feelings. And he had to suppress them—the very effort of which caused him to redden. He couldn't let it surface; at least not yet.

Translation

His face flushed, the words he'd just spoken suddenly a betrayal of his exchange with Kate. In that instant, as their eyes locked, she might have seen him struggling to hide his true emotions. And he had to hide them, the very act of which brought a flush to his cheeks. He couldn't allow them to show, not yet.

She could interpret it as she pleased. He tried to repeat his statement, but he actually changed it. "Sir Luke, in any case, had nothing to tell me, and I had nothing to tell him. Pretending to talk was impossible for us, and—"

Translation

She was free to make of it what she would. He tried to repeat what he'd said, but the words came out differently. "In any case, Sir Luke had nothing to say to me, and I had nothing to say to him. Pretending to talk was impossible for us, and—"

"And real"—she had taken him right up with a huge emphasis—"was more impossible still." No doubt—he didn't deny it; and she had straightway drawn her conclusion. "Then that proves what I say—that there were immensities between you. Otherwise you'd have chattered." "I dare say," Densher granted, "we were both thinking of her."

Translation

"And real," she'd interrupted him, stressing the word, "was even more impossible." No question about it—he didn't disagree. She immediately drew her conclusion. "That proves what I'm saying—there was a vast gulf between you. Otherwise, you would have chattered." "I suppose," Densher conceded, "we were both thinking of her."

"You were neither of you thinking of any one else. That's why you kept together." Well, that too, if she desired, he took from her; but he came straight back to what he had originally said. "I haven't a notion, all the same, of what he thinks." She faced him, visibly, with the question into which he had already observed that her special shade of earnestness was perpetually flowering, right and left—"Are you very sure?"—and he could only note her apparent difference from himself.

Translation

"Neither of you was thinking about anyone else. That's why you stuck together." He accepted that too, if she wanted him to; but he immediately returned to his original point. "Even so, I have no idea what he's thinking."

She faced him, visibly, with the question that he'd already noticed always bloomed, right and left, from her particular brand of seriousness—"Are you very sure?"—and he could only note how different she seemed from him.

"You, I judge, believe that he thinks she's gone." "And 'real'," she cut him off with heavy emphasis, "was even more impossible." He didn't disagree—of course not. And she immediately jumped to her conclusion. "That proves my point—that a huge gap existed between the two of you.

Translation

"You, I'd guess, think he believes she's left." "And 'real'," she interrupted with heavy emphasis, "was even more impossible." He didn't disagree—of course not. And she immediately jumped to her conclusion. "That proves my point—that a huge gap existed between the two of you.

Otherwise, you would have talked." "I suppose," Densher conceded, "we were both thinking about her." "You weren't thinking about anyone else. That's why you stayed together."

Translation

"Otherwise, you would have spoken," she said. "I suppose," Densher admitted, "we were both occupied with her." "You weren't occupied with anyone else. That's why you remained united."

Alright, if that's what she wanted, he would accept it, but he immediately returned to his original point. "I still have no idea what he's thinking." She turned to face him, the particular brand of seriousness he'd seen constantly blooming in her, appearing now—"Are you absolutely certain?"—and he could only observe how different she was from him. "You, I gather, believe he thinks she's dead." She took it, but she bore up.

Translation

Fine, if that’s what she wanted, he’d accept it, but he immediately returned to his original point. "I still have no idea what he's thinking." She turned to face him, the particular brand of seriousness he'd seen constantly blooming in her, appearing now—"Are you absolutely certain?"—and he could only observe how different she was from him. "You, I gather, believe he thinks she's dead." She took it, but she bore up.

"It doesn't matter what I believe." "Well, we shall see"—and he felt almost basely superficial. More and more, for the last five minutes, had he known she had brought something with her, and never in respect to anything had he had such a wish to postpone. He would have liked to put everything off till Thursday; he was sorry it was now Tuesday; he wondered if he were afraid.

Translation

"It doesn't matter what I believe." "Well, we shall see"—and he felt almost shamefully superficial. More and more, for the last five minutes, he had known she had brought something with her, and never in respect to anything had he had such a wish to postpone. He would have liked to put everything off till Thursday; he was sorry it was now Tuesday; he wondered if he were afraid.

Yet it wasn't of Sir Luke, who was coming; nor of Milly, who was dying; nor of Mrs. Stringham, who was sitting there. It wasn't, strange to say, of Kate either, for Kate's presence affected him suddenly as having swooned or trembled away. Susan Shepherd's, thus prolonged, had cast on it some influence under which it had ceased to act.

Translation

Yet it wasn't about Sir Luke, who was on his way; nor about Milly, who was dying; nor about Mrs. Stringham, who was sitting there. Strangely enough, it wasn't about Kate either, as Kate’s presence seemed suddenly to have faded or dissolved. Susan Shepherd's presence, prolonged, had exerted some influence, under which it had ceased to function.

She was as absent to his sensibility as she had constantly been, since her departure, absent, as an echo or a reference, from the palace; and it was the first time, among the objects now surrounding him, that his sensibility so noted her. He knew soon enough that it was of himself he was afraid, and that even, if he didn't take care, he should infallibly be more so. "Meanwhile," he added for his companion, "it has been everything for me to see you." She slowly rose at the words, which might almost have conveyed to her the hint of his taking care. She stood there as if she had in fact seen him abruptly moved to dismiss her.

Translation

She was as absent to his feelings as she had always been since she left, absent like an echo or a memory, from the place; and it was the first time, among the things around him, that his feelings had noticed her like that. He knew soon enough that it was himself he was afraid of, and that even if he wasn't careful, he would inevitably be more so. "Meanwhile," he added for his companion, "it has meant everything to me to see you."

She slowly stood up at the words, which might almost have suggested that he wanted her to leave. She stood there as if she had, in fact, seen him suddenly moved to send her away.

But the abruptness would have been in this case so marked as fairly to offer ground for insistence to her imagination of his state. It would take her moreover, she clearly showed him she was thinking, but a minute or two to insist. Besides, she had already said it. "Will you do it if he asks you?

Translation

But the abruptness would have been so pronounced in this instance that it would practically invite her to dwell on his condition, her imagination latching onto it. Furthermore, she made it clear she was considering, it would only take her a minute or two to press the issue. Besides, she had already asked. "Will you do it if he asks you?"

I mean if Sir Luke himself puts it to you. And will you give him"—oh she was earnest now!—"the opportunity to put it to you?" She took the question, but she remained composed. "What I believe doesn't matter."

Translation

I mean, if Sir Luke himself asks you. And will you give him—oh, she was sincere now!—the opportunity to ask you?" She considered the question, but she remained calm. "What I believe doesn't matter."

"We'll see," he replied, feeling almost shamefully shallow. Increasingly, for the past five minutes, he'd known she had something to tell him, and he'd never wanted to put off a conversation so much. He would have preferred to wait until Thursday; he was annoyed it was only Tuesday. He wondered if he was afraid.

Translation

"We'll see," he said, feeling almost embarrassingly superficial. For the past five minutes, he'd had a growing certainty she had something to tell him, and he'd never wanted to postpone a conversation so badly. He would have preferred to wait until Thursday; he was irritated it was only Tuesday. He wondered if he was afraid.

Yet it wasn't of Sir Luke, who was coming; nor of Milly, who was dying; nor of Mrs. Stringham, who was present. Strangely, it wasn't of Kate either, because Kate's presence suddenly seemed to have faded away. Susan Shepherd's prolonged presence, on the other hand, had exerted some influence, and Kate's presence had ceased to affect him.

Translation

Still, his thoughts weren't on Sir Luke, who was arriving soon. They weren't on Milly, who was dying, or Mrs. Stringham, who was right there. Oddly, Kate wasn't on his mind, either, because her presence had somehow receded. Susan Shepherd, however, had been around for a while, and her influence had diminished Kate's ability to affect him.

She was as absent from his awareness as she had consistently been since her departure, absent, like a distant memory, from his thoughts. And this was the first time, amidst his present surroundings, that his feelings had registered her absence so keenly. He realized soon enough that he was afraid of himself, and that if he wasn't careful, he'd inevitably become even more so. "In the meantime," he told her, "it's been wonderful to see you."

Translation

She was as good as gone, just as she had been ever since she left, like a half-forgotten dream in his mind. And this was the first time, in the midst of everything that was happening now, that he really felt her absence so strongly. He quickly understood that he was afraid of what he might do, and that if he wasn't careful, he'd only get more scared. "Anyway," he said to her, "it's been great seeing you."

She slowly stood up at his words, which might have given her the impression that he was trying to get rid of her. She stood there as if she believed he was about to dismiss her abruptly. But such abruptness would have been so obvious that it would have given her imagination too much to work with regarding his state of mind. Furthermore, she was clearly thinking that it would take her only a minute or two to press the issue.

Translation

She rose slowly to her feet, his words perhaps giving her the sense he was trying to usher her out. She stood there as if she thought he was about to dismiss her out of hand. But such a blunt move would have been so transparent, it would have offered her imagination too much to chew on regarding his actual state of mind. Moreover, she was clearly calculating that it would take her only a minute or two to push the matter further.

Besides, she had already asked the question. "Will you do it if he asks you? I mean if Sir Luke himself asks you. And will you give him"—oh, she was serious now!—"the chance to ask you?"

Translation

Furthermore, the question was already posed. "Will you agree if he asks? I mean, if Sir Luke himself asks. And will you give him"—now she was in earnest—"the opportunity to ask?"

"The opportunity to put what?" "That if you deny it to her, that may still do something." Densher felt himself—as had already once befallen him in the quarter of an hour—turn red to the top of his forehead. Turning red had, however, for him, as a sign of shame, been, so to speak, discounted: his consciousness of it at the present moment was rather as a sign of his fear.

Translation

"The opportunity to put what?" "That if you deny it to her, that may still do something." Densher felt himself—as had already happened to him once in the last fifteen minutes—flush crimson, all the way up to his forehead. Flushing crimson had, for him, as a sign of shame, been, so to speak, disregarded: his awareness of it at the present moment was more of a sign of his fear.

It showed him sharply enough of what he was afraid. "If I deny what to her?" Hesitation, on the demand, revived in her, for hadn't he all along been letting her see that he knew? "Why, what Lord Mark told her."

Translation

It revealed to him, quite clearly, what he was afraid of. "If I deny what to her?" The question, the demand, caused her hesitation to return, because hadn't he been showing her all along that he knew? "Why, what Lord Mark told her."

"And what did Lord Mark tell her?" Mrs. Stringham had a look of bewilderment—of seeing him as suddenly perverse. "I've been judging that you yourself know." And it was she who now blushed deep.

Translation

"And what did Lord Mark tell her?" Mrs. Stringham looked bewildered, as though he had abruptly become unreasonable. "I've been assuming that you already know." And it was she who now blushed deeply.

"The opportunity to do what?" "That if you refuse, it might still have an effect." Densher felt himself—as he had a short while earlier—blush all the way up to his hairline. However, for him, blushing as a sign of shame had, so to speak, lost its meaning.

Translation

"The opportunity to do what?" "That if you refuse, it could still make a difference." Densher felt himself—as he had a short time before—blush all the way up to his hairline. But, for him, blushing as a sign of shame had, so to speak, lost its meaning.

He was more aware of it now as a sign of his fear. It showed him very clearly what he was afraid of. "If I refuse what to her?" Hesitation, prompted by the question, returned to her, because hadn't he been letting her see all along that he knew?

Translation

He recognized the blush now as a symptom of fear. It clarified what terrified him. "If I refuse her what?" Uncertainty, provoked by the question, came back to her, because hadn't he been showing her all along that he understood?

"Why, what Lord Mark told her." "And what did Lord Mark tell her?" Mrs. Stringham looked bewildered—as though seeing him become suddenly difficult.

Translation

"Why, what Lord Mark told her." "And what did Lord Mark tell her?" Mrs. Stringham looked bewildered—as though she found him being suddenly difficult.

"I've been assuming you already know." And it was she who now blushed deeply. It quickened his pity for her, but he was beset too by other things. "Then you know—" "Of his dreadful visit?" She stared.

Translation

"I've been figuring you already knew." And it was her turn to flush crimson. It amplified his sympathy for her, but he was also preoccupied by other matters. "So you're aware—" "Of his awful visit?" She gaped.

"Why it's what has done it." "Yes—I understand that. But you also know—" He had faltered again, but all she knew she now wanted to say.

Translation

"Why this is what caused it." "Yes—I understand that. But you also know—" He had faltered again, but she now wanted to say everything she knew.

"I'm speaking," she said soothingly, "of what he told her. It's that that I've taken you as knowing." "Oh!" he sounded in spite of himself. It appeared to have for her, he saw the next moment, the quality of relief, as if he had supposed her thinking of something else.

Translation

"I'm talking," she said gently, "about what he told her. That's what I assumed you knew." "Oh!" he exclaimed, startled. He saw in the next moment that it seemed to bring her relief, as if he had thought she was focused on something else.

Thereupon, straightway, that lightened it. "Oh you thought I've known it for true!" Her light had heightened her flush, and he saw that he had betrayed himself. Not, however, that it mattered, as he immediately saw still better.

Translation

Immediately, that made things better. "Oh, you thought I knew it to be true!" The relief in her eyes heightened her blush, and he realized he'd given himself away. But, as he instantly understood even more clearly, it didn't matter.

There it was now, all of it at last, and this at least there was no postponing. They were left with her idea—the one she was wishing to make him recognise. He had expressed ten minutes before his need to understand, and she was acting after all but on that. Only what he was to understand was no small matter; it might be larger even than as yet appeared.

Translation

It was all coming to a head, finally, and there was no putting it off any longer. They were left with her idea—the one she wanted him to acknowledge. He’d said, ten minutes prior, that he needed to understand, and she was responding directly to that. Except what he was to understand wasn’t trivial; it might be even bigger than he thought.

His sympathy for her increased, but he was preoccupied with other matters. "So, you know—" "About his terrible visit?" She looked at him intently. "That's what caused this."

Translation

His compassion for her grew, though his mind was elsewhere. "So, you are aware—" "Of his awful visit?" She fixed him with a stare. "That's what started this."

"Yes, I understand that. But you also know—" He hesitated again, but she was now eager to clarify everything she knew. "I'm talking," she said gently, "about what he told her.

Translation

"Yes, I understand that. But you also know—" He paused again, but she seemed keen to clarify everything she knew. "I'm talking," she said gently, "about what he told her."

That's what I assumed you were aware of." "Oh!" he exclaimed, unable to stop himself. He realized in the next moment that this seemed to bring her relief, as if he had been imagining something different. Then, instantly, things became clearer.

Translation

"I thought as much." "Oh!" he blurted out, unable to contain himself. He saw in the next second that this seemed to ease her mind, as though he'd been thinking something else. Then, everything clicked into place.

"Oh, you thought I believed it to be true!" Her excitement had made her blush more deeply, and he saw that he had given himself away. But, as he instantly realized, it didn't really matter. There it was now, the entire situation laid bare, and at least this couldn't be delayed any longer.

Translation

"Oh, you thought I actually believed that!" Her enthusiasm brought a deeper flush to her cheeks, and he knew he'd given himself away. But, as he immediately understood, it didn't really change anything. The whole thing was out in the open now, and at least they couldn't put it off any longer.

They were left with her interpretation—the one she wanted him to accept. He had expressed, ten minutes earlier, his need to understand, and she was, after all, simply responding to that. However, what he was to understand was no small thing; it might be even more significant than it seemed. He took again one of his turns, not meeting what she had last said; he mooned a minute, as he would have called it, at a window; and of course she could see that she had driven him to the wall.

Translation

They were stuck with her version of events—the one she was pushing him to believe. He’d told her, not even ten minutes ago, that he needed to understand, and she was just trying to help, really. But what she wanted him to understand was no small matter; it could be even more important than it seemed. He turned away again, avoiding her last words. He stared out the window for a moment, lost in thought, and she could tell, of course, that she’d backed him into a corner.

She did clearly, without delay, see it; on which her sense of having "caught" him became as promptly a scruple, which she spoke as if not to press. "What I mean is that he told her you've been all the while engaged to Miss Croy." He gave a jerk round; it was almost—to hear it—the touch of a lash; and he said—idiotically, as he afterwards knew—the first thing that came into his head. "All what while?"

Translation

She saw it, clearly and without delay. Her certainty of having “caught” him immediately became a doubt, which she voiced as if to avoid pressure. "What I mean is, he told her you've been engaged to Miss Croy all along." He flinched, as if struck by a whip. He then said—idiotically, as he later realized—the first thing that came to mind. "All along?"

"Oh it's not I who say it." She spoke in gentleness. "I only repeat to you what he told her." He paused, not directly responding to her last words. He stared out the window for a moment, and she could tell she'd cornered him.

Translation

"Oh, it's not me who's saying it," she said softly. "I'm only telling you what he told her." He hesitated, not addressing her words directly. He looked out the window for a moment, and she knew she had him.

She realized this instantly, but her feeling of having "trapped" him immediately became a pang of conscience, which she expressed tentatively. "I mean, he told her that you and Miss Croy have been engaged all along." He spun around, as if stung. He then said the first thing that came to his mind—and he later recognized how foolish it sounded.

Translation

She saw the shift in him immediately, but the satisfaction of having gotten him where she wanted him quickly morphed into guilt, which she voiced uncertainly. "I just mean, he told her that you and Miss Croy were secretly engaged." He whipped around, as if someone had slapped him. And then the first words out of his mouth—words he would later regret.

"All what while?" "Oh, I'm not the one saying it." She spoke softly. "I'm just telling you what he told her." Densher, from whom an impatience had escaped, had already caught himself up.

Translation

"All this time?" "Oh, I'm not the one who said it." She spoke softly. "I'm just telling you what he told her." Densher, from whom a flash of impatience had escaped, had already caught himself.

"Pardon my brutality. Of course I know what you're talking about. I saw him, toward the evening," he further explained, "in the Piazza; only just saw him—through the glass at Florian's—without any words. In fact I scarcely know him—there wouldn't have been occasion.

Translation

"Forgive my bluntness. Naturally, I understand. I saw him, late in the afternoon," he continued, "in the Piazza; I only glimpsed him—through the window at Florian's—we didn't speak. In truth, I hardly know him—there's never been a need."

It was but once, moreover—he must have gone that night. But I knew he wouldn't have come for nothing, and I turned it over—what he would have come for." Oh so had Mrs. Stringham.

Translation

It was only that once, besides—he must have left that night. But I knew he wouldn't have come for no reason, and I considered—what he would have come for.” Oh, Mrs. Stringham had done the same.

"He came for exasperation." Densher approved. "He came to let her know that he knows better than she for whom it was she had a couple of months before, in her fool's paradise, refused him." Densher, who had shown a moment of impatience, immediately corrected himself.

Translation

"He came out of exasperation." Densher agreed. "He came to let her know that he knows better than she did—the person she had, a couple of months before, in her fool's paradise, refused." Densher, who had shown a moment of impatience, immediately corrected himself.

"I apologize for being blunt. Of course I understand what you mean. I saw him this evening, in the Piazza; I only glimpsed him through the window at Florian's, without speaking to him. Actually, I barely know him—there's never been a reason to.

Translation

"I'm sorry to be so direct. Of course, I see your point. I saw him tonight, in the Piazza; I only caught a glimpse of him through the window at Florian's, without actually talking to him. Really, I hardly know him—there's never been any cause to."

Besides, it was only that one time—he must have left that night. But I realized he wouldn't have come here without a purpose, so I considered what that purpose might be." Mrs. Stringham concurred.

Translation

Stringham almost smiled. "I know that—but I don't know the good it does him." "The good, he thinks, if he has patience—not too much—may be to come. He doesn't know what he has done to her.

Stringham almost smiled. "I know that—but I don't know what good it does him." "The good, he thinks, if he's patient—not too patient—may be in the future. He doesn't know what he's done to her."

Only we, you see, do that." He saw, but he wondered. "She kept from him—what she felt?" "She was able—I'm sure of it—not to show anything.

Translation

"Only we, you understand, do that." He understood, but he was skeptical. "She hid from him—what she was feeling?" "She was capable—I'm certain of it—of showing nothing."

He dealt her his blow, and she took it without a sign." Mrs. Stringham, it was plain, spoke by book, and it brought into play again her appreciation of what she related. "She's magnificent." Densher again gravely assented.

Translation

He struck, and she bore the assault without a flicker. Mrs. Stringham, it was clear, was speaking from a script, which in turn seemed to intensify her admiration for the story. "She is remarkable." Densher once more solemnly agreed.

"Magnificent!" "And he," she went on, "is an idiot of idiots." "An idiot of idiots." For a moment, on it all, on the stupid doom in it, they looked at each other. "Yet he's thought so awfully clever."

Translation

"Magnificent!"

"And he," she went on, "is an idiot of idiots."

"An idiot of idiots." For a moment, on it all, on the stupid doom in it, they looked at each other.

"Yet he's thought so awfully clever."

"How do you know?" Mrs. Stringham almost smiled. "I know that—but I don't know how it helps him." "The benefit, he believes, if he's patient—not overly so—might arrive later.

Translation

"How do you know?" Mrs. Stringham almost smiled. "I know that—but I don't know how it helps him." "The benefit, he believes, if he's patient—not overly so—might arrive later.

He doesn't realize what he's done to her. Only we, you understand, are aware of that." He understood, but he was puzzled. "She concealed from him—what she felt?"

Translation

"He's blind to the consequences of his actions. Only we, the observers, grasp the gravity of it all." He registered the information, yet found it perplexing. "She kept her feelings hidden—from him?"

"She was capable—I'm certain of it—of revealing nothing. He struck his blow, and she endured it without any reaction." Mrs. Stringham, it was obvious, was relaying a well-rehearsed account, which reactivated her appreciation for the story. "She's remarkable."

Translation

She was able to—I am sure of it—show nothing. He struck, and she bore it without a single response. Mrs. Stringham, it was clear, was delivering a practiced narrative, which rekindled her interest in the telling of it. "She's extraordinary."

Densher agreed seriously once more. "Remarkable!" "And he," she continued, "is an absolute fool." "An absolute fool." For an instant, considering the foolishness and the tragedy, they exchanged a glance.

Densher agreed seriously once more. "Remarkable!" "And he," she continued, "is an absolute fool." "An absolute fool." For a moment, considering the foolishness and the tragedy, they exchanged a glance.

"Yet people consider him extraordinarily intelligent." "So awfully—it's Maud Lowder's own view. And he was nice, in London," said Mrs. Stringham, "to me.

Translation

"Even so, people think he's incredibly smart." "Yes, terribly—that's Maud Lowder's opinion. And he was pleasant to me in London," Mrs. Stringham said.

One could almost pity him—he has had such a good conscience." "That's exactly the inevitable ass." "Yes, but it wasn't—I could see from the only few things she first told me—that he meant her the least harm. He intended none whatever."

Translation

"The thing is," Densher said, though he, at that moment, had more on his mind than he’d yet had to contend with, "how, at the end of the day, does he know? I mean, know enough." "And what, precisely, do you consider enough?" Mrs. Stringham asked.

"He can only have acted—it would have been his sole safety—from full knowledge." "What do you mean by full knowledge?"

Translation

"He could only have acted—it would have been his only protection—with complete awareness." Translation

"But, really," Densher asked, now that he was juggling more than enough thoughts, "how did he learn? I mean, how much did he actually learn?" "What would you call enough?" Mrs. Stringham asked.

"He could only have pretended—that was the only way he could have protected himself—with complete awareness." "What do you mean by 'complete awareness'?"

Densher met it indirectly. "Where has he been since October?" "I think he has been back to England. He came in fact, I've reason to believe, straight from there."

Translation

Densher sidestepped the question. "Where has he been since October?" "I think he's been back in England. In fact, I have reason to believe he came straight from there."

"Straight to do this job? All the way for his half-hour?" "Well, to try again—with the help perhaps of a new fact. To make himself possibly right with her—a different attempt from the other.

Translation

"Straight here to do this? Just for his half-hour?" "Well, to try again—maybe with the help of a new piece of information. To possibly make amends with her—a different approach than the last time."

He had at any rate something to tell her, and he didn't know his opportunity would reduce itself to half an hour. Or perhaps indeed half an hour would be just what was most effective. It has been!" said Susan Shepherd. Her companion took it in, understanding but too well; yet as she lighted the matter for him more, really, than his own courage had quite dared—putting the absent dots on several i's—he saw new questions swarm.

Translation

At the very least, he had something to tell her. He hadn't expected his window to shrink to just thirty minutes. Or maybe, in fact, thirty minutes would be the perfect amount of time. "It has been!" said Susan Shepherd. Her companion absorbed this, understanding all too well. Yet, as she illuminated the situation for him—more than his own nerve had dared—connecting the dots for him, he saw new questions arise.

They had been till now in a bunch, entangled and confused; and they fell apart, each showing for itself. The first he put to her was at any rate abrupt. "Have you heard of late from Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

Up until now, they'd been a jumbled mess, tangled and confused. Now, they were falling apart, each person revealing their own thoughts. The first thing he asked her was, at the very least, blunt. "Have you heard anything recently from Mrs. Lowder?"

Densher approached the topic circuitously. "Where has he been since October?" "I believe he's been back to England. In fact, I understand he came directly from there."

Translation

Densher steered clear of the direct approach. "Where has he been since October?"

"I believe he's been back in England. In fact, I understand he came directly from there."

"Straight here to do this? He traveled all that way for his brief visit?" "Well, to try again—perhaps with some new information. To possibly resolve things with her—a different approach this time.

Translation

"Just to get here and do this? He crossed the ocean for a quick trip?" "Well, to try again, maybe with some new knowledge. To possibly settle things with her—a different tack this time."

He had something to tell her, but he didn't know his chance would be so short. Or perhaps a brief visit was the most effective approach. And it was!" said Susan Shepherd. Her companion absorbed this, understanding completely.

Translation

He had a message for her, but he hadn't expected his time would be so limited. Or maybe a quick visit was the best way to handle it. And it was! Susan Shepherd stated. Her companion considered this, nodding in comprehension.

Translation

As she continued to explain, elaborating on aspects he hadn't dared to contemplate, he found himself with new questions, each one distinct. "Have you heard from Mrs. Lowder recently?" "Oh yes, two or three times. She depends naturally upon news of Milly."

Translation

"Have you heard from Mrs. Lowder lately?" "Oh, yes, two or three times. Of course, she's very reliant on news of Milly."

He hesitated. "And does she depend, naturally, upon news of me?" His friend matched for an instant his deliberation. "I've given her none that hasn't been decently good.

Translation

He paused. "And, of course, does she need to hear about me?" His friend considered for a moment, mirroring his hesitation. "I haven't told her anything that wasn't reasonably positive."

This will have been the first." "'This'?" Densher was thinking. "Lord Mark's having been here, and her being as she is." He thought a moment longer.

"This will have been the first time." "'This'?" Densher wondered. "Lord Mark's visit, and her current state." He paused for a moment.

Then she said something." "And what did she say?" Mrs. Stringham produced it with an effort.

Translation

"She said he was 'a link.'" "A link?" I pressed. Mrs. Stringham affirmed with a nod, still struggling.

"Well it was in reference to Miss Croy. That she thought Kate was thinking of him. Or perhaps I should say rather that he was thinking of her—only it seemed this time to have struck Maud that he was seeing the way more open to him." Yes, a couple of times.

Translation

"Well, it concerned Miss Croy. That Mrs. Stringham believed Kate was interested in him. Or, perhaps it's more accurate to say he was interested in her—only it seemed, this time, to have dawned on Maud that he saw his chances improving." Yes, a couple of times.

She's expecting updates about Milly, of course." He paused. "And is she expecting to hear about me?" His friend considered for a moment, matching his caution.

Translation

"Naturally, she wants to know about Milly." He hesitated. "Does she expect to hear about me, as well?" His friend paused, considering the question with a matching level of caution.

"I've only given her positive news, until now. This will be the first time I haven't." "'This'?" Densher wondered. "Lord Mark's visit, and Milly's current condition."

Translation

"Up until now, I've only told her good things. This is the first time that won't be true." "'This'?" Densher asked. "Lord Mark's visit, and Milly's situation right now."

He considered further. "What did Mrs. Lowder write about him? Did she mention that he was there?"

Translation

He kept thinking. "What did Mrs. Lowder say in her letter? Did she say anything about his being there?"

"She mentioned him once, in the letter before the last one. She said something then." "What did she say?" Mrs.

Translation

"She mentioned him once, in the letter before the last one. She said something then." "What did she say?" Mrs.

Stringham struggled to remember. "Well, it was about Miss Croy. She thought Kate was interested in him. Or perhaps I should say he was interested in her.

Translation

Stringham tried to recall. "Well, it was about Miss Croy. She thought Kate was interested in him. Or, perhaps it's more accurate to say he was interested in her."

But this time, it seemed to Maud that he saw his chances improving." Densher listened with his eyes on the ground, but he presently raised them to speak, and there was that in his face which proved him aware of a queerness in his question. "Does she mean he has been encouraged to propose to her niece?" "I don't know what she means."

Translation

But this time, Maud felt he perceived his opportunities increasing. Densher listened, his gaze fixed on the floor, but then lifted his eyes to speak. Something in his expression revealed an awareness of the oddness of his question. "Does she mean he's been given reason to believe he could propose to her niece?" "I have no idea what she means."

"Of course not"—he recovered himself; "and I oughtn't to seem to trouble you to piece together what I can't piece myself. Only I 'guess,'" he added, "I can piece it." She spoke a little timidly, but she risked it. "I dare say I can piece it too."

Translation

"Certainly not," he recovered himself. "And I shouldn't seem to bother you trying to put together what I can't put together myself. Only I 'guess,'" he added, "I can put it together." She spoke a little timidly, but she risked it. "I daresay I can put it together, too."

It was one of the things in her—and his conscious face took it from her as such—that from the moment of her coming in had seemed to mark for him, as to what concerned him, the long jump of her perception. They had parted four days earlier with many things, between them, deep down. But these things were now on their troubled surface, and it wasn't he who had brought them so quickly up. Women were wonderful—at least this one was.

Translation

It was one of her qualities—and his observant expression registered it as such—that from the moment she entered, her perception had seemingly leaped forward in relation to him. They had separated four days prior, with many unspoken matters between them, buried deep. But these issues were now on the surface, and it wasn't him who had brought them up so quickly. Women were remarkable—at least, this woman was.

But so, not less, was Milly, was Aunt Maud; so, most of all, was his very Kate. Well, he already knew what he had been feeling about the circle of petticoats. They were all such petticoats! It was just the fineness of his tangle.

Translation

But Milly was no less so, nor was Aunt Maud; and most of all, his own Kate was the same. Well, he already knew what he felt about the female figures around him. They were all such figures! It was simply the nuance of his entanglement.

The sense of that, in its turn, for us too, might have been not unconnected with his putting to his visitor a question that quite passed over her remark. "Has Miss Croy meanwhile written to our friend?" Densher listened, his gaze fixed on the floor. He lifted his head, his expression revealing that he understood his question was strange.

Translation

The feeling of this, for us as well, could have been related to his asking his visitor a question that completely ignored her comment. "Has Miss Croy written to our friend in the meantime?" Densher listened, his eyes fixed on the floor. He lifted his head, his expression showing that he understood his question was odd.

"Does she mean he was pushed to propose to her niece?" "I have no idea what she means." "Of course not," he replied, regaining his composure. "And I shouldn't bother you to figure out something I can't figure out myself.

Translation

"Does she mean he was pressured into proposing to her niece?" "I haven't the slightest clue what she means." "Certainly not," he replied, recovering himself. "And I shouldn't trouble you to decipher something I can't even figure out."

But I suspect I can piece it together." She spoke hesitantly, but she took the risk. "I imagine I can piece it together too." It was one of her qualities—and he recognized it—that, from the moment she entered the room, she seemed to have grasped his concerns immediately.

Translation

"However, I think I can figure it out." She hesitated, but she forged ahead. "I suspect I can figure it out, as well." It was one of her strengths, and he acknowledged it: the way she seemed to understand his worries the instant she entered a room.

They had separated four days prior with many buried issues between them. But now, these issues were right there, on the surface, and it wasn't him who had brought them up so quickly. Women were remarkable—or at least this one was. But so too, in their own ways, were Milly, and Aunt Maud; and most of all, so was Kate herself.

Translation

Four days after their separation, a multitude of unspoken problems lingered. Now, those problems were out in the open, and he hadn't been the one to introduce them so abruptly. Women were extraordinary, or at least this particular woman was. Milly and Aunt Maud had their own remarkable qualities too, but Kate was exceptional.

Well, he already knew what he felt about all the women involved. They were all such women! It was the complexity of his situation. The significance of that, for us too, might have been connected to his asking his visitor a question that ignored her remark.

Translation

He knew what he felt about all the women. They were all just… women. The real problem was the convoluted situation he was in. The importance of that complexity, for us as well, could be seen in the fact that he’d just asked his visitor a question that completely disregarded her previous comment.

"Has Miss Croy written to our friend in the meantime?" "Oh," Mrs. Stringham amended, "her friend also. But not a single word that I know of."

Translation

“Has Miss Croy written to our friend in the meantime?” “Oh,” Mrs. Stringham corrected herself, “to her friend, too. But not a single word, as far as I know.”

He had taken it for certain she hadn't—the thing being after all but a shade more strange than his having himself, with Milly, never for six weeks mentioned the young lady in question. It was for that matter but a shade more strange than Milly's not having mentioned her. In spite of which, and however inconsequently, he blushed anew for Kate's silence. He got away from it in fact as quickly as possible, and the furthest he could get was by reverting for a minute to the man they had been judging.

Translation

He'd assumed she hadn't written. It was, when you thought about it, only slightly stranger than the fact that he hadn't mentioned Kate to Milly in six weeks. And, actually, only slightly stranger than the fact that Milly hadn't mentioned her, either. Despite all that—however illogical it was—he blushed again at Kate's silence. He quickly tried to escape the thought, and the furthest he could get was by briefly turning his attention back to the man they'd been talking about.

"How did he manage to get at her? She had only—with what had passed between them before—to say she couldn't see him." "Oh," Mrs. Stringham corrected, "her friend too.

Translation

"How did he manage to get to her? All she had to do—given what had happened between them before—was say she couldn't see him."

"Oh," Mrs. Stringham corrected, "her friend too."

But not a single word, as far as I know." He'd assumed she hadn't—which was only slightly stranger than him never mentioning the young woman to Milly in six weeks. In fact, it was just a little stranger than Milly's own silence. Despite this, and for some reason he couldn't explain, he felt embarrassed all over again by Kate's secret.

Translation

But, as far as I could tell, she said nothing. He had assumed she wouldn't—which was only a bit more odd than him never bringing up the young woman to Milly in six weeks. Actually, it was just a little more strange than Milly's own quietness. Regardless, and for reasons he didn't understand, he felt embarrassed all over again by Kate's secret.

He tried to escape the feeling as fast as possible, and the farthest he could go was to return, for a moment, to the man they had been discussing. "How did he manage to see her? All she had to do—after what had happened between them before—was say no." "Oh she was disposed to kindness.

Translation

He wanted to shake off the feeling immediately, so he flashed back, if only for a second, to the man they'd been talking about. "How did he even see her? All she had to do—after what had transpired—was say no." "Oh, she was the forgiving type."

She was easier," the good lady explained with a slight embarrassment, "than at the other time." "Easier?" "She was off her guard. There was a difference."

Translation

She was easier," the woman explained, a little embarrassed. "Than before." "Easier?" "She wasn't expecting it. That made a difference."

"Yes. But exactly not the difference." "Exactly not the difference of her having to be harsh. Perfectly.

Translation

"Yes. But not exactly the point." "Not the point of her needing to be harsh. Precisely."

She could afford to be the opposite." With which, as he said nothing, she just impatiently completed her sense. "She had had you here for six weeks." "Oh!" Densher softly groaned. "Besides, I think he must have written her first—written I mean in a tone to smooth his way.

Translation

She could allow herself to be the opposite.

Since he didn't respond, she simply, impatiently, finished her thought. "She's had you here for six weeks." "Oh!" Densher softly groaned. "Besides, I believe he must have written to her first—written, I mean, in a way that would make things easier for him."

That it would be a kindness to himself. Then on the spot—" "On the spot," Densher broke in, "he unmasked? The horrid little beast!"

Translation

That it would be a kindness to himself. Then on the spot—" "On the spot," Densher broke in, "he unmasked? The horrid little beast!"

"Oh, she was more inclined to be kind. She was more relaxed," the woman explained, a little awkwardly, "than before." "More relaxed?" "She wasn't being cautious.

Translation

"Oh, she was more inclined to be kind. She was more relaxed," the woman explained, a little awkwardly, "than before." "More relaxed?" "She wasn't being cautious.

There was a change." "Yes. But not quite the change you'd expect." "Not the change of her having to be difficult.

Translation

There was a shift. "Yes. But it wasn't exactly what you'd anticipate." "Not that she'd have to be difficult."

Exactly. She could afford to be the opposite." Since he didn't respond, she simply finished her thought impatiently, "She had already had you here for six weeks." "Oh!" Densher groaned softly. "Also, I think he must have written to her first—written, I mean, in a way that would make things easier for him.

Translation

Precisely. She could afford to be the opposite." Because he didn't say anything, she just finished her thought impatiently, "She'd already had you here for six weeks." "Oh!" Densher groaned softly. "Also, I think he must have written to her first—written, I mean, in a way that would make things easier for him.

That it would be a favor to himself. Then, right then—" "Right then," Densher interrupted, "he showed his true colors? The awful little man!"

Translation

"A favor to himself. And then, at that moment—"

"At that very moment," Densher cut in, "he revealed himself? The wretched little man!"

It made Susan Shepherd turn slightly pale, though quickening, as for hope, the intensity of her look at him. "Oh he went off without an alarm." "And he must have gone off also without a hope." "Ah that, certainly."

Translation

It caused Susan Shepherd to become a little pale, but also seemed to intensify the way she looked at him, as though she were hoping for something. "Oh, he left without anyone noticing." "And he must have left without any hope, too." "Yes, that’s certainly true."

"Then it was mere base revenge. Hasn't he known her, into the bargain," the young man asked—"didn't he, weeks before, see her, judge her, feel her, as having for such a suit as his not more perhaps than a few months to live?" Mrs. Stringham at first, for reply, but looked at him in silence; and it gave more force to what she then remarkably added.

Translation

"Then it was just petty revenge. Didn't he know her, too?" the young man asked. "Didn't he see her, judge her, feel her weeks before, and understand that she didn't have much longer to live, perhaps only a few months, if he were to pursue her?" Mrs. Stringham didn't immediately reply, instead she simply looked at him silently; and it lent greater weight to what she said next, which was quite striking.

"He has doubtless been aware of what you speak of, just as you have yourself been aware." Susan Shepherd's face paled a bit, though her gaze sharpened, as if anticipating something. "He left without warning." "And he must have also left without any hope."

Translation

"He was certainly aware of the situation you're describing, just as you have been." Susan Shepherd's face lost some color, but her eyes focused intently, as if she were expecting something. "He departed without a word." "And he must have left without any expectation of a positive outcome, as well."

"Yes, that's true." "Then it was simply spite. And besides," the young man asked, "didn't he know her? Weeks ago, didn't he see her, understand her, and realize that she might only have a few months left if he were to pursue her?"

Translation

"Yes, that's correct." "So it was just spite, then. And furthermore," the young man asked, "didn't he know her? Didn't he see her weeks ago, understand her, and realize that she might only have a few months to live if he were to pursue her?"

Mrs. Stringham initially offered no response, but simply looked at him silently. This silence made her later words all the more impactful. "He has undoubtedly been aware of what you're saying, just as you yourself have been aware."

Translation

Mrs. Stringham offered no immediate answer, instead simply observing him. The ensuing silence amplified her eventual statement. "He's certainly known what you're saying, just as you've known it yourself."

"He has wanted her, you mean, just because—?" "Just because," said Susan Shepherd. "The hound!" Merton Densher brought out. He moved off, however, with a hot face, as soon as he had spoken, conscious again of an intention in his visitor's reserve.

Translation

"You mean he wanted her, just because—?" "Just because," said Susan Shepherd. "The bastard!" Merton Densher blurted. He turned away, flushing, immediately aware of a purpose behind his visitor's restraint.

Dusk was now deeper, and after he had once more taken counsel of the dreariness without he turned to his companion. "Shall we have lights—a lamp or the candles?" "Not for me." "Nothing?"

Translation

The dusk had deepened by this point, and after considering the desolate atmosphere outside, he turned to his companion. "Shall we turn on some lights—a lamp or the candles?" "Not for me." "Nothing?"

"Not for me." He waited at the window another moment and then faced his friend with a thought. "He will have proposed to Miss Croy. That's what has happened."

Translation

"Not for me." He lingered by the window a moment longer, then turned to his friend, a thought taking hold. "He will have proposed to Miss Croy. That's the reason."

Her reserve continued. "It's you who must judge." "Well, I do judge. Mrs.

Translation

"It's you who must decide." "Well, I do decide. Mrs.

Lowder will have done so too—only she, poor lady, wrong. Miss Croy's refusal of him will have struck him"—Densher continued to make it out—"as a phenomenon requiring a reason." "You mean he wanted her, simply because—?" "Simply because," Susan Shepherd replied.

Translation

Lowder will have acted, too—except for her, poor woman, it was a mistake. Miss Croy's rejection of him will have appeared to him"—Densher kept deciphering—"as an oddity that demanded explanation." "You mean he desired her, merely because—?" "Merely because," Susan Shepherd answered.

"The jerk!" Merton Densher exclaimed. But he quickly moved away, his face flushed, aware of an unspoken motive in his visitor's silence. The twilight had deepened, and after he’d once more considered the gloom outside, he turned back to his companion. "Shall we turn on the lights—a lamp or the candles?"

Translation

"The cad!" Merton Densher exclaimed. But he quickly retreated, his face reddening, conscious of a hidden reason for his guest's stillness. The dusk had intensified, and after he’d again taken note of the shadows beyond, he turned back to his companion. "Should we switch on the lights—a lamp or the candles?"

"Not for me." "Nothing?" "Nothing for me." He lingered at the window for another moment before facing his friend with a thought.

Translation

"Not for me," the man said. "Nothing?" "Nothing for me." He stood at the window a moment longer, then turned toward his friend, a thought forming.

"He will have proposed to Miss Croy. That's what's happened." She remained reserved. "It’s you who must decide."

Translation

"He must have proposed to Miss Croy. That's what it is." She remained composed. "You are the one who must decide."

"Well, I am deciding. Mrs. Lowder will have come to the same conclusion—though she, poor woman, will be wrong. Miss Croy's rejection of him will have seemed to him"—Densher continued to imagine it—"as a strange event demanding an explanation."

Translation

"Well, I am deciding. Mrs. Lowder will have arrived at the same conclusion—though she, poor woman, will be incorrect. Miss Croy's refusal of him will have appeared to him"—Densher continued to picture it—"as a bizarre occurrence in need of clarification."

"And you've been clear to him as the reason?" "Not too clear—since I'm sticking here and since that has been a fact to make his descent on Miss Theale relevant. But clear enough. He has believed," said Densher bravely, "that I may have been a reason at Lancaster Gate, and yet at the same time have been up to something in Venice."

Translation

"And you've told him I'm the reason?" "Not too explicitly—because I'm still here, and because that's what made his pursuit of Miss Theale important. But clear enough. He's believed," Densher said boldly, "that I might have been a reason at Lancaster Gate, but also, that I was involved in something here in Venice."

Mrs. Stringham took her courage from his own. "'Up to' something? Up to what?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham drew strength from his honesty. "'Up to' something? What do you mean?"

"God knows. To some 'game,' as they say. To some deviltry. To some duplicity."

Translation

"Who can say. Some sort of 'game,' as they call it. Some mischief. Some deceit."

"Which of course," Mrs. Stringham observed, "is a monstrous supposition." Her companion, after a stiff minute—sensibly long for each—fell away from her again, and then added to it another minute, which he spent once more looking out with his hands in his pockets. This was no answer, he perfectly knew, to what she had dropped, and it even seemed to state for his own ears that no answer was possible. She left him to himself, and he was glad she had declined, for their further colloquy, the advantage of lights.

Translation

"Which, of course," Mrs. Stringham remarked, "is a ridiculous idea." Her companion, after a tense pause—which felt impossibly long to each of them—withdrew from her again, then added another minute to the silence, once more staring out the window with his hands in his pockets. He knew perfectly well this wasn't an answer to her comment; it seemed to declare, even to himself, that an answer was impossible. She left him to his thoughts, and he was relieved she'd foregone the benefit of the lights for their continued conversation.

These would have been an advantage mainly to herself. Yet she got her benefit too even from the absence of them. It came out in her very tone when at last she addressed him—so differently, for confidence—in words she had already used. "If Sir Luke himself asks it of you as something you can do for him, will you deny to Milly herself what she has been made so dreadfully to believe?"

Translation

These advantages would have served mostly to benefit her. However, she also gained something even from their absence.
