It showed in her voice when she finally spoke to him—with such a different tone, born of confidence—using the same words she'd used before. "If Sir Luke himself asks you to do this as a favor to him, will you deny Milly what she has been made to believe so dreadfully?"

"And you told him plainly why?" "Not entirely—since I'm still here and since that's made his visit to Miss Theale make sense. But I was clear enough. He believed," Densher said bravely, "that I might have been a reason for her staying at Lancaster Gate, but also up to something here in Venice."

Translation

"And you explained exactly why?" "Not completely—because I'm still around, and that explains why he came to see Miss Theale. But I was pretty straightforward. He figured," Densher said, sounding courageous, "that I might have been a reason for her staying at Lancaster Gate, but also up to something here in Venice."

Mrs. Stringham took strength from his words. "'Up to' something? Up to what?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham found his words reassuring. "'Up to' something? What do you mean?"

"Who knows. Some sort of 'game,' as they say. Some trickery. Some deceit."

Translation

"Who can say. Some kind of 'game,' as they call it. Some sort of trick. Some lie."

"Which of course," Mrs. Stringham said, "is a terrible idea." After a silent minute—which felt long to both of them—he moved away from her again, adding another minute, as he stood with his hands in his pockets, looking out the window. He knew perfectly well that wasn't an answer to her question, and it even seemed to declare that no answer was possible. She left him to himself, and he was glad she hadn't turned on the lights for their conversation.

Translation

"Which of course," Mrs. Stringham said, "is a terrible idea." After a silent minute—which felt long to both of them—he moved away from her again, adding another minute, as he stood with his hands in his pockets, looking out the window. He knew perfectly well that wasn't an answer to her question, and it even seemed to declare that no answer was possible. She left him to himself, and he was glad she hadn't turned on the lights for their conversation.

That would have helped her more than him. Yet she gained something even from their absence. It showed in her voice when she finally spoke to him—in a tone of intimacy—using words she'd already said. "If Sir Luke asks you to do this for him, will you deny Milly what she has been made to believe?"

Translation

That would have been of more use to her than it would to him. Even so, she benefited from their silence. It was evident in her voice when she finally addressed him—in a confidential tone—repeating words she’d already spoken. “If Sir Luke asks you to do this for him, will you deny Milly what she has come to believe?”

Oh how he knew he hung back! But at last he said: "You're absolutely certain then that she does believe it?" "Certain?" She appealed to their whole situation. "Judge!"

Translation

Oh, how he knew he hesitated! But at last he said, "So, you're absolutely certain she believes it?" "Certain?" She appealed to the gravity of their circumstances. "Judge for yourself!"

He took his time again to judge. "Do you believe it?" He was conscious that his own appeal pressed her hard; it eased him a little that her answer must be a pain to her discretion. She answered none the less, and he was truly the harder pressed.

Translation

He took his time once more, considering. "Do you believe it?" He understood that his question put her in a difficult position; it gave him some comfort that answering would be painful for her. Nonetheless, she did answer, and the result was he felt even more trapped.

"What I believe will inevitably depend more or less on your action. You can perfectly settle it—if you care. I promise to believe you down to the ground if, to save her life, you consent to a denial." "But a denial, when it comes to that—confound the whole thing, don't you see!—of exactly what?"

Translation

"My beliefs

are going to change, based on what you do. You're the one who can decide; it's all up to you. I swear

I'll believe you completely if you just say you didn't do it, to save her life." "But a denial, when it comes to that—damn

the whole thing, don't you see!—what am I denying, exactly?"

He knew he was hesitating. But finally, he asked, "Are you absolutely sure she believes it?" "Sure?" She gestured to their entire predicament. "Figure it out!"

Translation

He knew he was wavering. At last, he asked, "Are you certain she'll believe that?" "Certain?" She indicated their entire situation with a sweep of her hand. "Work it out!"

He took a moment to consider. "Do you believe it?" He realized his question put her in a difficult position; it slightly comforted him that her response would be awkward. Nevertheless, she answered, and the pressure on him increased.

Translation

He paused, considering. "Do you believe it?" He understood the question placed her in a bind; it was a small consolation that her answer would be uncomfortable. Yet, she replied, and the weight on him grew.

"What I believe will depend on what you do. You can resolve this—if you want to. I promise to believe you completely if you deny it to save her." "But a denial, when it comes to that—damn it all, don't you see!—of precisely what?"

Translation

"My belief hinges on your actions. You have the power to fix this—if you choose to. I swear I'll believe you, completely, if you deny it to protect her."

"But a denial, when it comes down to it—damn it, don't you understand!—a denial of *what* exactly?"

It was as if he were hoping she would narrow; but in fact she enlarged. "Of everything." Everything had never even yet seemed to him so incalculably much. "Oh!" he simply moaned into the gloom.

Translation

It was as if he was hoping she would be more specific, but in reality, she broadened the scope. "Everything." Everything had never seemed so impossibly vast. "Oh!" he simply moaned into the darkness.

Chapter 17

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Merton Densher meets Kate at Lancaster Gate. Kate asks why he has not contacted her in the two weeks since his return. He explains he was following their "system" and avoiding haste. He arranged the visit by first writing to Kate's Aunt Maud. Kate had then wired him to arrive fifteen minutes before tea, which is scheduled for five o'clock. Densher asks for recent news of Miss Theale (Milly). He states he has heard nothing, but knows Kate's aunt has been in contact with Mrs. Stringham. Surprised by his lack of information, Kate confirms her aunt has recent news. Densher asks if Miss Theale is alive. When Kate looks at him without speaking, he asks if she is dead. Kate shakes her head. He asks, "Not yet?" He tells Kate that Milly is dying. He then reveals that Lord Mark visited Milly and told her that Densher and Kate are secretly engaged. Densher states that this news caused Milly to give up her will to live. Kate turns pale and asks if Densher could have denied the story to save Milly. He replies that he could not lie, as it would have required him to break his engagement with her. He also explains that Milly refused to see him for days after Lord Mark's visit. Densher recounts that he stayed in Venice, and Milly eventually sent for him. He met with her for twenty minutes, during which she asked him to leave Venice and not wait for her to die. He left that same night. They discuss how Sir Luke Strett, a doctor, has returned to Milly's side, which Densher says means it is the end. Densher explains that it was Sir Luke who convinced Milly to see him for that final meeting. As the clock strikes five, Kate prepares tea. She stands close to Densher and tells him they have succeeded, stating that Milly will not have loved him for nothing, and he will not have loved Kate for nothing.

The near Thursday, coming nearer and bringing Sir Luke Strett, brought also blessedly an abatement of other rigours. The weather changed, the stubborn storm yielded, and the autumn sunshine, baffled for many days, but now hot and almost vindictive, came into its own again and, with an almost audible paean, a suffusion of bright sound that was one with the bright colour, took large possession. Venice glowed and plashed and called and chimed again; the air was like a clap of hands, and the scattered pinks, yellows, blues, sea-greens, were like a hanging-out of vivid stuffs, a laying-down of fine carpets. Densher rejoiced in this on the occasion of his going to the station to meet the great doctor.

Translation

The following Thursday, as it drew closer and with it Sir Luke Strett, also brought a welcome easing of other hardships. The weather shifted, the relentless storm subsided, and the autumn sunshine, held back for days, now hot and almost unforgiving, returned to its former glory. It filled the air with a nearly audible hymn, a flood of bright sound that matched the brilliant color, and took over completely. Venice once again glowed, splashed, called out, and chimed; the air felt like a clap of hands, and the scattered pinks, yellows, blues, and sea-greens resembled a display of vibrant fabrics, a laying out of fine carpets. Densher found joy in this as he went to the station to meet the renowned doctor.

He went after consideration, which, as he was constantly aware, was at present his imposed, his only, way of doing anything. That was where the event had landed him—where no event in his life had landed him before. He had thought, no doubt, from the day he was born, much more than he had acted; except indeed that he remembered thoughts—a few of them—which at the moment of their coming to him had thrilled him almost like adventures. But anything like his actual state he had not, as to the prohibition of impulse, accident, range—the prohibition in other words of freedom—hitherto known.

Translation

He proceeded with deliberation, a state he was acutely conscious of, because it was now his dictated, his sole, method of operation. That was the place where this circumstance had deposited him—a place unlike any other in his life. He had likely spent his life thinking far more than he had acted; save for the remembrance of certain thoughts—a handful of them—that, when they first came to him, had exhilarated him like actual experiences. However, anything akin to his current state, with its prohibition of impulse, of happenstance, of choices—in essence, the prohibition of freedom—was entirely new to him.

The great oddity was that if he had felt his arrival, so few weeks back, especially as an adventure, nothing could now less resemble one than the fact of his staying. It would be an adventure to break away, to depart, to go back, above all, to London, and tell Kate Croy he had done so; but there was something of the merely, the almost meanly, obliged and involved sort in his going on as he was. That was the effect in particular of Mrs. Stringham's visit, which had left him as with such a taste in his mouth of what he couldn't do.

Translation

The great oddity was that if he had initially perceived his arrival, just a few weeks prior, as an adventure, nothing now seemed less like one than the fact of his continued stay. It would be an adventure to break free, to leave, to return, above all, to London, and tell Kate Croy he had done so; but there was something merely, almost meanly, obligatory and constrained in his present course. That was the specific consequence of Mrs. Stringham's visit, which had left him with the bitter aftertaste of all he was unable to accomplish.

It had made this quantity clear to him, and yet had deprived him of the sense, the other sense, of what, for a refuge, he possibly could. He seemed to be hoping she would become less expansive, but in reality, she became more so. "Of everything." Everything had never seemed so overwhelming to him.

Translation

It had clarified this for him, while simultaneously taking away any sense of what might serve as his escape. He seemed to hope her openness would diminish, but in fact, it only increased. "Of everything." Nothing had ever seemed so overwhelming.

"Oh!" he simply groaned into the darkness. IV The approaching Thursday, which would bring Sir Luke Strett, also thankfully brought a reduction in other difficulties. The weather improved, the unrelenting storm subsided, and the autumn sunshine, which had been blocked for many days, but now hot and almost intense, returned and, with an almost audible celebratory song, a flood of bright sound that matched the bright colors, took over the scene.

Translation

"Oh!" he simply groaned into the darkness.

The approaching Thursday, which would bring Sir Luke Strett, also thankfully brought a reduction in other difficulties. The weather improved, the unrelenting storm subsided, and the autumn sunshine, which had been blocked for many days, but now hot and almost intense, returned and, with an almost audible celebratory song, a flood of bright sound that matched the bright colors, took over the scene.

Venice glowed and sparkled and called out and chimed again; the air felt like clapping hands, and the scattered pinks, yellows, blues, and sea-greens looked like vibrant fabrics hung out to dry, a display of beautiful carpets. Densher was happy about this when he went to the train station to meet the famous doctor. He went after thinking about it, which, as he was constantly aware, was currently his enforced, his only, way of doing anything. That was where the situation had led him—where no event in his life had led him before.

Translation

Venice was ablaze with light, shimmering and beckoning, the bells ringing out; the air itself seemed to applaud, and the pastel hues scattered across the city resembled brilliant textiles drying in the sun, a stunning array of carpets. Densher felt a surge of joy as he headed to the train station to meet the renowned doctor. He went only after carefully considering it, which, he knew well, was now his unavoidable, his sole, method of action. This was where his circumstances had brought him—a place no experience in his life had ever led him before.

He had probably thought, from the day he was born, much more than he had acted; except that he remembered thoughts—a few of them—which had thrilled him almost like adventures when they occurred to him. But he had never known anything like his current state regarding the restrictions on impulse, chance, and options—in other words, the restriction of freedom. The biggest oddity was that if he had seen his arrival, just a few weeks earlier, as an adventure, nothing could now be less like one than the fact that he was staying. It would be an adventure to leave, to depart, to go back, above all, to London, and tell Kate Croy he had done so; but there was something of the simply, the almost ignobly, obligated and entangled nature in his continuing as he was.

Translation

He had likely spent his life thinking more than doing, though he did recall a handful of thoughts that, when they struck him, had felt like genuine adventures. But he had never experienced anything like his current state of constrained impulse, chance, and choice—in essence, the constraint of freedom. The greatest paradox was that if he had viewed his arrival, only weeks prior, as an adventure, his continued presence was now the opposite. Leaving would be an adventure, departing, returning, above all, to London, to tell Kate Croy he had gone; but remaining as he was felt simply, almost ignobly, obligatory and trapped.

That was the specific effect of Mrs. Stringham's visit, which had left him with the feeling of what he couldn't do. It had made this amount clear to him, and yet had taken away his sense, the other sense, of what he possibly could do for refuge. It was but a small make-believe of freedom, he knew, to go to the station for Sir Luke.

Translation

That was the precise consequence of Mrs. Stringham's visit, which had left him focused on his limitations. It had made this reality apparent, yet had simultaneously eroded his sense—the other sense—of potential recourse. He understood that going to the station to meet Sir Luke was merely a superficial illusion of freedom.

Nothing equally free, at all events, had he yet turned over so long. What then was his odious position but that again and again he was afraid? He stiffened himself under this consciousness as if it had been a tax levied by a tyrant. He hadn't at any time proposed to himself to live long enough for fear to preponderate in his life.

Translation

He hadn’t yet turned over anything equally free, at least not for so long. So what was his awful situation if not the fact that he was afraid, again and again? He stiffened himself in response to this realization, as if it were a tax imposed by a tyrant. He had never imagined he would live long enough for fear to dominate his life.

Such was simply the advantage it had actually got of him. He was afraid for instance that an advance to his distinguished friend might prove for him somehow a pledge or a committal. He was afraid of it as a current that would draw him too far; yet he thought with an equal aversion of being shabby, being poor, through fear. What finally prevailed with him was the reflexion that, whatever might happen, the great man had, after that occasion at the palace, their young woman's brief sacrifice to society—and the hour of Mrs.

Translation

That was simply the upper hand it held over him. For example, he feared that an approach to his esteemed friend might somehow obligate or commit him. He feared it as a current that would sweep him too far out to sea; and yet, he thought with equal distaste of being seen as stingy, of being impoverished, due to fear. What finally convinced him was the thought that, no matter what might happen, the great man possessed, since that incident at the palace, their young woman’s fleeting offering to society—and the hour of Mrs.

Stringham's appeal had brought it well to the surface—shown him marked benevolence. Mrs. Stringham's comments on the relation in which Milly had placed them made him—it was unmistakeable—feel things he perhaps hadn't felt. It was in the spirit of seeking a chance to feel again adequately whatever it was he had missed—it was, no doubt, in that spirit, so far as it went a stroke for freedom, that Densher, arriving betimes, paced the platform before the train came in.

Translation

Stringham's appeal

had brought it well to the surface—shown him

marked benevolence. Mrs. Stringham's comments on

the relation in which Milly had placed them made

him—it was unmistakeable—feel things he perhaps

hadn't felt. It was in the spirit of seeking a chance

to feel again adequately whatever it was he had missed—it

was, no doubt, in that spirit, so far as it went

a stroke for freedom, that Densher, arriving betimes,

paced the platform before the train came in.

Only, after it had come and he had presented himself at the door of Sir Luke's compartment with everything that followed—only, as the situation developed, the sense of an anti-climax to so many intensities deprived his apprehensions and hesitations even of the scant dignity they might claim. He could scarce have said if the visitor's manner less showed the remembrance that might have suggested expectation, or made shorter work of surprise in presence of the fact. He knew it was just a small illusion of freedom to go to the train station to meet Sir Luke. He hadn't dwelled on anything as freely as he had on this.

Translation

However, after the train arrived and he'd appeared at the door of Sir Luke's compartment, with everything that subsequently transpired—after the situation unfolded, the feeling of an anti-climax, given all the preceding intensity, robbed his anxieties and hesitations of whatever little dignity they might have possessed. He could barely tell if the visitor's demeanor indicated a lack of recognition that might have fostered anticipation, or if it simply cut short any surprise upon seeing him. He knew that going to the train station to meet Sir Luke had just been a fleeting illusion of freedom. He hadn't dwelled on anything as freely as he'd dwelled on this.

What, then, was his awful situation if not that he was constantly afraid? He braced himself against this awareness as if it were a tax imposed by a cruel ruler. He had never planned to live long enough for fear to dominate his life. But that was precisely the advantage fear had gained over him.

Translation

So, what exactly was his wretched predicament, if not that he was in a constant state of fear? He steeled himself against this realization, as if it were a levy imposed by a heartless tyrant. He'd never intended to live long enough for fear to seize control of his life. But that was exactly the upper hand fear had gained over him.

For example, he feared that approaching his important friend might somehow obligate or commit him. He feared it like a current that would sweep him too far; yet, he equally hated being seen as lacking or appearing impoverished because of fear. What ultimately persuaded him was the thought that, whatever happened, the great man had, after their young woman's brief sacrifice to society at the palace—an occasion that Mrs. Stringham's plea had brought into sharp focus—shown him notable kindness.

Translation

For instance, he worried that approaching his important friend could somehow obligate or compromise him. He feared it like a strong tide pulling him away; still, he hated being perceived as lacking or appearing diminished because of fear. What finally convinced him was the thought that, whatever the outcome, the great man had, after their young woman's brief sacrifice to society at the palace—an occasion that Mrs. Stringham's plea had brought into sharp focus—shown him notable kindness.

Mrs. Stringham's observations on Milly's relationship with them made him—without a doubt—experience feelings he might not have felt otherwise. It was in the spirit of seeking an opportunity to adequately feel again whatever he had missed—undoubtedly in that spirit, which was, to some extent, a move for freedom—that Densher, arriving early, walked the platform before the train arrived. But, after it arrived and he stood at the door of Sir Luke's compartment and everything that followed—only, as the situation unfolded, the feeling that it was an anticlimax to all his previous intense emotions robbed his anxieties and hesitations of even the little dignity they might have possessed.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham's remarks about Milly's relationship with them definitely stirred in him feelings he wouldn't have otherwise. It was in the spirit of trying to feel again, with sufficient intensity, whatever he'd missed—undoubtedly that spirit, which was, in a way, a step toward freedom—that Densher, arriving early, paced the platform before the train came. But, after the train arrived and he stood at the door of Sir Luke's compartment and everything that happened after—it was only, as the situation developed, the feeling that it was an anticlimax to all his earlier intense emotions that stripped his anxieties and hesitations of what little dignity they might have had.

He could hardly say if the visitor's demeanor revealed less of the memory that might have created expectation, or made quicker work of surprise at seeing him. Sir Luke had clean forgotten—so Densher read—the rather remarkable young man he had formerly gone about with, though he picked him up again, on the spot, with one large quiet look. The young man felt himself so picked, and the thing immediately affected him as the proof of a splendid economy. Opposed to all the waste with which he was now connected the exhibition was of a nature quite nobly to admonish him.

Translation

Densher couldn't tell whether Sir Luke's expression showed less of a memory that would have led to anticipation, or if he was simply less surprised to see him. Sir Luke had completely forgotten—or so Densher interpreted—the somewhat striking young man he'd once known, though he immediately recognized him with a single, long, calm gaze. The young man felt himself scrutinized, and this affected him at once as evidence of a magnificent efficiency. In contrast to all the chaos he was now involved in, this display was designed to nobly rebuke him.

The eminent pilgrim, in the train, all the way, had used the hours as he needed, thinking not a moment in advance of what finally awaited him. An exquisite case awaited him—of which, in this queer way, the remarkable young man was an outlying part; but the single motion of his face, the motion into which Densher, from the platform, lightly stirred its stillness, was his first renewed cognition. If, however, he had suppressed the matter by leaving Victoria he would at once suppress now, in turn, whatever else suited. The perception of this became as a symbol of the whole pitch, so far as one might one's self be concerned, of his visit.

Translation

The distinguished traveler, on the train, had used the hours as he wished, without a thought for what was to come. An exquisite affair awaited him—of which, in a strange way, the remarkable young man was a distant piece; but the single movement of his face, the movement that Densher, from the platform, lightly stirred from stillness, was his first renewed awareness. If, however, he had dismissed the matter by leaving Victoria, he would instantly dismiss now, in turn, whatever else suited him. The understanding of this became a symbol of the whole situation, as far as one's own concerns went, regarding his visit.

One saw, our friend further meditated, everything that, in contact, he appeared to accept—if only, for much, not to trouble to sink it: what one missed was the inward use he made of it. Densher began wondering, at the great water-steps outside, what use he would make of the anomaly of their having there to separate. Eugenio had been on the platform, in the respectful rear, and the gondola from the palace, under his direction, bestirred itself, with its attaching mixture of alacrity and dignity, on their coming out of the station together. Densher didn't at all mind now that, he himself of necessity refusing a seat on the deep black cushions beside the guest of the palace, he had Milly's three emissaries for spectators; and this susceptibility, he also knew, it was something to have left behind.

Translation

One saw, our friend further contemplated, everything that, in contact, he seemed to accept—even if, for a lot, he didn’t bother to absorb it: what one couldn’t see was how he internally processed it. Densher began wondering, at the expansive water-steps outside, how he would process the oddity of their needing to separate there. Eugenio had been on the platform, in the respectful background, and the gondola from the palace, under his direction, busied itself, with its accompanying blend of eagerness and decorum, as they exited the station together. Densher didn’t mind at all now that, with him refusing a seat on the deep black cushions beside the palace’s guest, he had Milly’s three emissaries as observers; and this sensitivity, he also knew, was something he’d left behind.

All he did was to smile down vaguely from the steps—they could see him, the donkeys, as shut out as they would. "I don't," he said with a sad headshake, "go there now." Densher read that Sir Luke had completely forgotten about the rather interesting young man he used to know, but then he immediately recognized him with a single, calm glance. The young man felt singled out, and it immediately struck him as proof of admirable efficiency.

Translation

He merely smiled vaguely down from the steps—they could see him, the donkeys, as shut out as they would be. "I don't," he said, shaking his head sadly, "go there now." Densher realized that Sir Luke had completely forgotten about the rather interesting young man he used to know, but then he immediately recognized him with a single, calm glance. The young man felt singled out, and it immediately struck him as proof of admirable efficiency.

Compared to all the waste he was currently involved with, the display was designed to be a noble reminder. The distinguished traveler, during the train journey, had used his time as needed, never considering what might finally await him. An exquisite situation awaited him—and in this strange way, the remarkable young man was a small part of it; but the simple movement of his face, the movement into which Densher gently broke the stillness from the platform, was his first renewed awareness. However, if he had prevented the issue by leaving Victoria, he would now similarly suppress anything else that suited him.

Translation

The display was meant to be a noble reminder compared to all the waste he was currently mired in. The distinguished traveler had used his time as needed during the train journey, never considering what might ultimately await him. An exquisite situation awaited him—and the remarkable young man was, in this strange way, a small part of it; but the simple movement of his face, the movement into which Densher gently broke the stillness from the platform, was his first renewed awareness. However, if he had prevented the issue by leaving Victoria, he would now similarly suppress anything else that suited him.

Realizing this became a symbol of the entire situation, as far as he was personally concerned, of his visit. One saw, our friend continued to consider, everything that, in contact, he seemed to accept—even if, for a lot, he didn’t bother to acknowledge it; what was missing was how he internally processed it. Densher began to wonder, at the large steps leading to the water outside, what use he would make of the odd situation of their having to separate there. Eugenio had been on the platform, respectfully in the background, and the gondola from the palace, under his supervision, readied itself, with its combination of eagerness and grace, as they emerged from the station together.

Translation

This realization became symbolic of the entire situation, as far as he was concerned, of his visit. He observed, our friend continued to muse, everything that, in contact, he seemed to accept—even if, in many instances, he didn't bother to acknowledge it; what was missing was how he internally processed it. Densher began to wonder, at the wide steps leading to the water outside, how he would navigate their peculiar parting. Eugenio had been on the platform, respectfully in the background, and the gondola from the palace, under his supervision, readied itself, with its combination of eagerness and grace, as they exited the station together.

Densher didn't mind at all now that, since he couldn't sit on the black cushions next to the palace guest, he had Milly’s three representatives as observers; and he knew this sensitivity was something he had left behind. All he did was smile vaguely from the steps—they could see him, the "donkeys" (as he privately referred to them), as shut out as they would be. "I don’t," he said with a sad shake of his head, "go there now." "Oh!" Sir Luke Strett returned, and made no more of it; so that the thing was splendid, Densher fairly thought, as an inscrutability quite inevitable and unconscious.

Translation

Densher didn't mind that, since he couldn't sit with the palace guest on the black cushions, he had Milly’s three representatives as observers. He knew this sensitivity was a thing of the past. All he did was offer a vague smile from the steps—the "donkeys," as he privately called them, could see him, as shut out as they were. "I don’t," he said, shaking his head sadly, "go there now." "Oh!" Sir Luke Strett replied, and let it go at that, so that it was splendid, Densher thought, in its inevitable and unconscious inscrutability.

His friend appeared not even to make of it that he supposed it might be for respect to the crisis. He didn't moreover afterwards make much more of anything—after the classic craft, that is, obeying in the main Pasquale's inimitable stroke from the poop, had performed the manoeuvre by which it presented, receding, a back, so to speak, rendered positively graceful by the high black hump of its felze. Densher watched the gondola out of sight—he heard Pasquale's cry, borne to him across the water, for the sharp firm swerve into a side-canal, a short cut to the palace. He had no gondola of his own; it was his habit never to take one; and he humbly—as in Venice it is humble—walked away, though not without having for some time longer stood as if fixed where the guest of the palace had left him.

Translation

His friend didn't seem to consider that he might be acting out of respect for the crisis. He didn't make much of anything else either—after the classic craft, following Pasquale's inimitable stroke from the stern, executed the maneuver, receding, presenting a back, so to speak, rendered positively graceful by the high black hump of its cabin. Densher watched the gondola disappear—he heard Pasquale's cry, carried to him across the water, for the sharp, firm swerve into a side canal, a shortcut to the palace. He didn't have a gondola of his own; it was his habit never to take one; and he humbly—as it is humble in Venice—walked away, though not before he'd stood for some time, as if fixed, where the palace guest had left him.

It was strange enough, but he found himself as never yet, and as he couldn't have reckoned, in presence of the truth that was the truest about Milly. He couldn't have reckoned on the force of the difference instantly made—for it was all in the air as he heard Pasquale's cry and saw the boat disappear—by the mere visibility, on the spot, of the personage summoned to her aid. He hadn't only never been near the facts of her condition—which counted so as a blessing for him; he hadn't only, with all the world, hovered outside an impenetrable ring fence, within which there reigned a kind of expensive vagueness made up of smiles and silences and beautiful fictions and priceless arrangements, all strained to breaking; but he had also, with every one else, as he now felt, actively fostered suppressions which were in the direct interest of every one's good manner, every one's pity, every one's really quite generous ideal. It was a conspiracy of silence, as the cliché went, to which no one had made an exception, the great smudge of mortality across the picture, the shadow of pain and horror, finding in no quarter a surface of spirit or of speech that consented to reflect it.

Translation

It was odd, but he discovered himself, as he never had before and couldn't have predicted, in the presence of the truth that was the truest about Milly. He couldn't have anticipated the power of the shift that happened instantly—because it was all in the air as he heard Pasquale's shout and watched the boat vanish—brought about by the simple fact of seeing the person summoned to her aid. Not only had he never been close to the reality of her condition—which he considered a blessing; not only had he, along with everyone else, remained outside an impenetrable barrier, within which an expensive vagueness reigned, composed of smiles, silences, beautiful lies, and priceless accommodations, all stretched to the breaking point; but also, along with everyone else, as he now felt, he had actively supported the repressions that were in the direct interest of everyone's good behavior, everyone's compassion, everyone's genuinely generous ideals. It was a conspiracy of silence, as the cliché went, to which no one had made an exception, the vast smudge of mortality across the canvas, the shadow of pain and horror, failing to find in any place a surface of spirit or speech willing to acknowledge it.

"The mere aesthetic instinct of mankind—!" our young man had more than once, in the connexion, said to himself; letting the rest of the proposition drop, but touching again thus sufficiently on the outrage even to taste involved in one's having to see. So then it had been—a general conscious fool's paradise, from which the specified had been chased like a dangerous animal. What therefore had at present befallen was that the specified, standing all the while at the gate, had now crossed the threshold as in Sir Luke Strett's person and quite on such a scale as to fill out the whole precinct. Densher's nerves, absolutely his heart-beats too, had measured the change before he on this occasion moved away.

Translation

"The mere aesthetic instinct of mankind—!" our young man had more than once said to himself, in this context, leaving the rest of the thought unsaid, but acknowledging the offense of having to witness the truth. So it had been—a general conscious fool's paradise, from which the specified had been chased like a dangerous animal. What had happened now, therefore, was that the specified, standing all the while at the gate, had now crossed the threshold in the form of Sir Luke Strett and on such a grand scale as to occupy the entire space. Densher's nerves, even his heartbeats, had registered the change before he moved away this time.

"Oh!" Sir Luke Strett replied, and didn't elaborate. Densher found this behavior to be quite wonderful, a perfect example of inscrutability that was both inevitable and unconscious. His friend didn't seem to think it was about respecting the crisis. Nor did he comment further afterward.

Translation

"Oh!" Sir Luke Strett responded, offering no further explanation. Densher found this fascinating, an ideal display of opacity, both natural and unintentional. His friend didn't appear to be concerned with solemnity. Nor did he speak again.

The classic craft, obeying Pasquale's signature move from the back, performed the maneuver that showed, as it receded, its back, which was made graceful by the high, black hump of its cabin. Densher watched the gondola disappear, hearing Pasquale's call across the water as it made a sharp turn into a side canal, a shortcut to the palace. He didn't own a gondola, as it was his habit not to use one. He humbly—as one must be in Venice—walked away, though he had stood fixed for some time where the palace guest had left him.

Translation

The classic craft, responding to Pasquale's practiced push from behind, executed the turn that revealed, as it moved away, its rear, made elegant by the high, dark swell of its cabin. Densher watched the gondola vanish, hearing Pasquale's shout across the water as it sharply angled into a side canal, a quick route to the palace. He didn't have a gondola, as was his practice, never employing one. He walked away humbly—as one must in Venice—though he had stood still for some time where the palace guest had left him.

It was strange, but he found himself, like never before, face-to-face with the truest truth about Milly. He hadn't expected the immediate impact of the change. It was clear as he heard Pasquale's call and the boat vanished, simply because of the visible presence of the person summoned to help her. Not only had he never been close to the facts of her condition—which he considered a blessing—he had also, along with the rest of the world, stayed outside an impenetrable ring fence.

Translation

It was peculiar, but he was now, as never before, confronted with the most fundamental truth about Milly. He hadn't anticipated the immediate effect of the alteration. It became evident, as he listened to Pasquale’s call and the boat disappeared, precisely because of the obvious presence of the individual summoned to assist her. Not only had he remained distant from the specifics of her situation—which he deemed fortunate—but he had also, along with everyone else, stayed outside an impenetrable barrier.

Within it existed a kind of expensive vagueness made of smiles, silences, beautiful fictions, and priceless arrangements, all stretched to their breaking point. He, like everyone else, had actively fostered the kind of suppressions that everyone’s good manners, pity, and generous ideals demanded. It was a conspiracy of silence, as the cliché went, to which no one had made an exception. The great blot of mortality across the picture, the shadow of pain and horror, found no place where the spirit or speech would reflect it.

Translation

Inside that barrier was a sort of expensive haziness, built from smiles, silences, pleasant lies, and invaluable compromises, all strained to the absolute limit. He, like everyone else, had deliberately encouraged the types of evasions that good manners, compassion, and high-minded principles required. It was a conspiracy of silence, as the saying went, and no one had broken the pact. The great stain of mortality on the image, the shadow of pain and terror, had no space where the spirit or language would acknowledge it.

"The mere aesthetic instinct of mankind—!" he had said to himself more than once, leaving the rest of the thought unfinished, alluding to the outrage of having to witness such things. It had been a general conscious delusion from which the harsh truth had been banished like a dangerous animal. And now the harsh truth, which had been waiting at the gate all along, had crossed the threshold in Sir Luke Strett's person and on such a scale that it filled the whole area. Densher's nerves, even his heartbeat, had measured the change before he finally moved away.

Translation

"The mere aesthetic instinct of mankind—!" he had repeated to himself more than once, unable to finish the thought, referring to the offense of witnessing such occurrences. It had been a shared, conscious delusion where the ugly truth was exiled like a dangerous beast. And now the ugly truth, which had been waiting at the entrance all along, had entered in Sir Luke Strett's presence and on such a grand scale that it dominated the entire space. Densher's senses, even his pulse, had registered the shift before he finally stepped back.

The facts of physical suffering, of incurable pain, of the chance grimly narrowed, had been made, at a stroke, intense, and this was to be the way he was now to feel them. The clearance of the air, in short, making vision not only possible but inevitable, the one thing left to be thankful for was the breadth of Sir Luke's shoulders, which, should one be able to keep in line with them, might in some degree interpose. It was, however, far from plain to Densher for the first day or two that he was again to see his distinguished friend at all. That he couldn't, on any basis actually serving, return to the palace—this was as solid to him, every whit, as the other feature of his case, the fact of the publicity attaching to his proscription through his not having taken himself off.

Translation

The stark realities of physical suffering, of unrelenting pain, of the tragically limited possibilities, had become, in an instant, overwhelming, and this was now how he would experience them. The clearing of the air, in short, making a clear view not only possible but unavoidable, the one remaining source of gratitude was the breadth of Sir Luke's shoulders, which, if one could manage to stay aligned with, might offer some measure of protection. However, it wasn't clear to Densher, for the first couple of days, that he would see his esteemed friend again. That he couldn't, on any practical grounds, return to the palace—this was as undeniable to him as the other aspect of his situation, the fact that his exclusion had become widely known because he hadn't left.

He had been seen often enough in the Leporelli gondola. As, accordingly, he was not on any presumption destined to meet Sir Luke about the town, where the latter would have neither time nor taste to lounge, nothing more would occur between them unless the great man should surprisingly wait upon him. His doing that, Densher further reflected, wouldn't even simply depend on Mrs. Stringham's having decided to—as they might say—turn him on.

Translation

He'd been spotted frequently in the Leporelli gondola. Since he wasn't expected to run into Sir Luke around town—where the latter wouldn't have the time or inclination to be idle—nothing more would happen between them unless the great man decided to pay him a visit, which would be a surprise. Densher also thought that such a visit wouldn't even simply depend on whether Mrs. Stringham had decided to, as they might put it, put him in the picture.

It would depend as well—for there would be practically some difference to her—on her actually attempting it; and it would depend above all on what Sir Luke would make of such an overture. Densher had for that matter his own view of the amount, to say nothing of the particular sort, of response it might expect from him. He had his own view of the ability of such a personage even to understand such an appeal. To what extent could he be prepared, and what importance in fine could he attach?

Translation

It would also depend—since it would make a difference to her—on whether she actually tried it. And above all, it would depend on Sir Luke's reaction to such an offer. For that matter, Densher had his own ideas about the amount, not to mention the specific kind, of response he might expect from him. He had his own view of that person's ability to even understand such an appeal. How prepared could he be, and finally, how much importance could he assign?

Densher asked himself these questions, in truth, to put his own position at the worst. He should miss the great man completely unless the great man should come to see him, and the great man could only come to see him for a purpose unsupposable. Therefore he wouldn't come at all, and consequently there was nothing to hope. The realities of physical agony, of constant pain, of drastically limited chances had suddenly become overwhelming, and he was now destined to feel them intensely.

Translation

Densher, in all honesty, posed these questions to himself to consider his situation at its bleakest. He would lose the great man entirely unless the great man decided to visit him, and the great man would only visit for a reason that was inconceivable. Thus, he wouldn't come at all, and by extension, there was nothing to look forward to. The reality of physical suffering, persistent pain, and severely constrained opportunities had suddenly become crushing, and he was now fated to experience them fully.

With everything exposed, making everything visible and unavoidable, the only thing to be thankful for was the breadth of Sir Luke’s shoulders, which, if he could keep pace with them, might offer some protection. However, for the first couple of days, it was far from clear to Densher that he would see his esteemed friend again. That he couldn’t return to the palace on any practical grounds was just as certain as the other undeniable fact of his situation: the public awareness of his isolation because he hadn't left. He’d been seen often enough in the Leporelli gondola.

Translation

With everything laid bare, rendering everything apparent and inescapable, the sole consolation was the imposing width of Sir Luke's shoulders, which, if he could keep up with them, might provide some shelter. Yet, for the initial few days, it was far from obvious to Densher that he would see his respected friend again. His inability to return to the palace, for any practical purpose, was as sure as the other undeniable truth of his predicament: the public's perception of his seclusion, stemming from his continued absence. He had been seen often enough in the Leporelli gondola.

Since he wasn't expected to meet Sir Luke around the city, where the latter would have neither the time nor inclination to relax, nothing more would happen between them unless the great man surprisingly decided to visit him. Densher further considered that whether Sir Luke would visit wouldn't simply depend on Mrs. Stringham's decision to—as they might say—"send him over." It would also depend on her actually trying; there might be some difficulty for her. And it would depend most of all on how Sir Luke would respond to such a gesture.

Translation

Given that he couldn't expect to run into Sir Luke anywhere in the city, where the man would be too busy and disinclined to socialize, nothing more would transpire between them unless the esteemed gentleman unexpectedly took it upon himself to visit. Densher thought further that whether Sir Luke actually came would depend not just on Mrs. Stringham's decision to—as one might put it—"send him over." It would also depend on her making a genuine effort; she could face some obstacles. And, most importantly, it would depend on how Sir Luke himself would react to such an invitation.

Densher had his own opinion of the amount, not to mention the specific kind, of response he could anticipate. He had his own view of whether such a personage could even grasp such an appeal. To what extent could he be prepared, and finally, how much importance could he give it? Densher asked himself these questions, truly to make his situation seem as hopeless as possible.

Translation

Densher had his own ideas about the kind and degree of Sir Luke's potential reaction. He doubted whether such a man could even understand the nature of the request. To what degree could he be prepared, and ultimately, how seriously would he take it? Densher posed these questions to himself, largely to convince himself that the situation was entirely hopeless.

He would miss the great man completely unless the great man came to see him, and the great man could only come to see him for an unimaginable purpose. Therefore, he wouldn't come at all, and consequently, there was nothing to hope for. It wasn't in the least that Densher invoked this violence to all probability; but it pressed on him that there were few possible diversions he could afford now to miss. Nothing in his predicament was so odd as that, incontestably afraid of himself, he was not afraid of Sir Luke.

Translation

He would have to rely on the great man to make the first move, and that would only happen for a reason he couldn't even fathom. So, it wouldn't happen, and there was no point in hoping. It wasn't that Densher was actively willing this outcome; rather, it struck him that there were very few other avenues of distraction he could still allow himself. The strangest thing about his situation was that, though undeniably afraid of his own impulses, he wasn't afraid of Sir Luke.

He had an impression, which he clung to, based on a previous taste of the visitor's company, that he would somehow let him off. The truth about Milly perched on his shoulders and sounded in his tread, became by the fact of his presence the name and the form, for the time, of everything in the place; but it didn't, for the difference, sit in his face, the face so squarely and easily turned to Densher at the earlier season. His presence on the first occasion, not as the result of a summons, but as a friendly whim of his own, had had quite another value; and though our young man could scarce regard that value as recoverable he yet reached out in imagination to a renewal of the old contact. He didn't propose, as he privately and forcibly phrased the matter, to be a hog; but there was something he after all did want for himself.

Translation

He had a feeling, which he held onto, based on his previous experience with the visitor, that somehow he would be spared. The truth about Milly was a weight on his shoulders, echoed in his every step, and with his arrival, became the name and form of everything in the house, for the time being. But that weight didn't register in his face, a face that had once turned to Densher so openly and easily. His presence the first time, not because he was called, but as a friendly gesture, had been very different. And even though the young man could hardly expect that to happen again, he still longed in his mind for a return to their earlier connection. He didn't intend, as he thought in private, to be a brute; but there was still something he wanted for himself.

It was something—this stuck to him—that Sir Luke would have had for him if it hadn't been impossible. These were his worst days, the two or three; those on which even the sense of the tension at the palace didn't much help him not to feel that his destiny made but light of him. He had never been, as he judged it, so down. In mean conditions, without books, without society, almost without money, he had nothing to do but to wait.

Translation

It was something—this thing that clung to him—that Sir Luke would have offered him if it hadn't been impossible. These were his worst days, those two or three; days where even the tension at the palace did little to distract him from feeling that his fate held him in low regard. He had never been, as he assessed it, so disheartened. In reduced circumstances, without books, without company, almost without money, he had nothing to do but wait.

His main support really was his original idea, which didn't leave him, of waiting for the deepest depth his predicament could sink him to. Fate would invent, if he but gave it time, some refinement of the horrible. It was just inventing meanwhile this suppression of Sir Luke. When the third day came without a sign he knew what to think.

Translation

His primary source of strength was the core concept, which remained with him, of enduring the most profound depths his situation could inflict. Fate would devise, if he only allowed it, some variation of the awful. It was merely inventing, in the meantime, this absence of Sir Luke. When the third day arrived with no indication, he understood what to believe.

He had given Mrs. Stringham during her call on him no such answer as would have armed her faith, and the ultimatum she had described as ready for him when he should be ready was therefore—if on no other ground than her want of this power to answer for him—not to be presented. The presentation, heaven knew, was not what he desired. It wasn't that Densher necessarily caused this whole situation, but it occurred to him that he couldn't afford to miss many opportunities.

Translation

He hadn't provided Mrs. Stringham with any response during her visit that would have solidified her confidence. As a result, the final offer she'd mentioned, intended for him when he was ready, would not be offered. This was the case, even if only because she lacked the ability to speak on his behalf. God knew, he didn't want the offer. It wasn't that Densher was the direct cause of all this, but it occurred to him that he couldn't afford to let many opportunities pass by.

The strangest thing about his predicament was that, even though he was definitely afraid of himself, he wasn't afraid of Sir Luke. He had a feeling, which he held onto, based on their previous meetings, that Sir Luke would somehow let him off the hook. The truth about Milly, which weighed on him and was reflected in his actions, was, due to Sir Luke's presence, the embodiment of everything in that place. However, it wasn't visible on his face, the face that had been so open and friendly to Densher earlier.

Translation

The oddest part of it all was that, though he was certainly afraid of his own impulses, he wasn't afraid of Sir Luke. He had a hunch, which he trusted, based on their past interactions, that Sir Luke would ultimately give him a pass. The truth about Milly, which burdened him and influenced his behavior, represented, because of Sir Luke's presence, everything that existed in that environment. Yet it wasn't apparent in his expression, the expression that had previously been so open and welcoming to Densher.

Sir Luke's first visit, which he'd initiated himself, had been completely different; and although Densher couldn't see how he could get back to that point, he still imagined a return to that old connection. He didn't intend, as he put it privately and emphatically, to be a complete fool; but there was something he still wanted for himself. He was sure that it was something Sir Luke would have gotten for him, if it had been possible. These were his worst days, those two or three days when even the tension at the palace couldn't distract him from feeling that his fate was treating him poorly.

Translation

Sir Luke's initial visit, which he'd arranged, had been entirely unlike this; and although Densher couldn't see how to recapture that feeling, he still envisioned a restoration of their previous bond. He had no intention, as he put it to himself with conviction, of being a total idiot; but there was still something he desired. He was convinced that it was something Sir Luke would have secured for him, had it been feasible. These were his most difficult days, those two or three days when even the stress at the palace couldn't keep him from feeling that his destiny was unkind.

He had never felt so low. In these difficult circumstances, without books, without friends, almost without money, all he could do was wait. His main support was his original idea, which never left him, of waiting for the lowest point his predicament could reach. Fate would create, if he gave it time, some new level of horror.

Translation

He'd never been so miserable. In this dire situation, with no books, no friends, and hardly any money, all he could do was wait. The only thing that sustained him was his initial thought, which he clung to: waiting for his situation to bottom out. Fate would devise, if he gave it enough time, a new depth of despair.

And it was in the process of creating this suppression of Sir Luke. When the third day passed without a word, he knew what to think. He hadn't given Mrs. Stringham any answer during her visit that would reassure her, and the ultimatum she said was waiting for him when he was ready would therefore—if only because she couldn't vouch for him—not be delivered.

Translation

And so it was that the plan to cut off Sir Luke took shape. When three days went by without a word, he understood what that meant. He hadn't said anything to Mrs. Stringham during her visit that would reassure her, and the ultimatum she said was waiting for him when he was ready would thus—simply because she couldn't speak for him—never be offered.

The presentation of the ultimatum, he knew, was not what he wanted. That was not, either, we hasten to declare—as Densher then soon enough saw—the idea with which Sir Luke finally stood before him again. For stand before him again he finally did; just when our friend had gloomily embraced the belief that the limit of his power to absent himself from London obligations would have been reached. Four or five days, exclusive of journeys, represented the largest supposable sacrifice—to a head not crowned—on the part of one of the highest medical lights in the world; so that really when the personage in question, following up a tinkle of the bell, solidly rose in the doorway, it was to impose on Densher a vision that for the instant cut like a knife.

Translation

He knew that he didn't want the ultimatum presented. That wasn't, either—as Densher soon realized—the intention that Sir Luke finally had when he appeared before him again. Because appear before him again he finally did; just when our friend had gloomily accepted the belief that he had reached the limit of his power to avoid London obligations. Four or five days, not including travel, was the largest possible sacrifice—for a man who was not a king—on the part of one of the most brilliant medical minds in the world. So that when the man in question, after a single ring of the doorbell, stood solid in the doorway, it was to give Densher a vision that, for the moment, cut like a knife.

It spoke, the fact, and in a single dreadful word, of the magnitude—he shrank from calling it anything else—of Milly's case. The great man had not gone then, and an immense surrender to her immense need was so expressed in it that some effect, some help, some hope, were flagrantly part of the expression. It was for Densher, with his reaction from disappointment, as if he were conscious of ten things at once—the foremost being that just conceivably, since Sir Luke was still there, she had been saved. Close upon its heels, however, and quite as sharply, came the sense that the crisis—plainly even now to be prolonged for him—was to have none of that sound simplicity.

Translation

It spoke, this fact, and in a single, terrible word, of the magnitude—he recoiled from calling it anything else—of Milly's condition. The great man hadn't left, and an immense surrender to her immense need was so expressed in it that some effect, some help, some hope, were flagrantly part of the expression. It was to Densher, with his reaction from disappointment, as if he were conscious of ten things at once—the foremost being that, just conceivably, since Sir Luke was still there, she had been saved. Close upon its heels, however, and quite as sharply, came the sense that the crisis—plainly even now to be prolonged for him—was to have none of that sound simplicity.

Not only had his visitor not dropped in to gossip about Milly, he hadn't dropped in to mention her at all; he had dropped in fairly to show that during the brief remainder of his stay, the end of which was now in sight, as little as possible of that was to be looked for. The demonstration, such as it was, was in the key of their previous acquaintance, and it was their previous acquaintance that had made him come. He was not to stop longer than the Saturday next at hand, but there were things of interest he should like to see again meanwhile. It was for these things of interest, for Venice and the opportunity of Venice, for a prowl or two, as he called it, and a turn about, that he had looked his young man up—producing on the latter's part, as soon as the case had, with the lapse of a further twenty-four hours, so defined itself, the most incongruous, yet most beneficent revulsion.

Translation

Not only had his visitor not come to chat about Milly, he hadn't come to mention her at all; he had come, essentially, to make clear that during the short time he had left, which was now drawing to a close, they were to expect as little of that as possible. The display, such as it was, was in line with their prior relationship, and it was that relationship that had brought him. He wasn't staying past the coming Saturday, but there were some things that interested him, which he'd like to see again before he left. It was for these things of interest, for Venice and the opportunities it offered, for an excursion or two, as he put it, a stroll around, that he had sought out the young man—and in the young man, once the situation had become clear after another twenty-four hours, produced the most incongruous, yet beneficial, change of heart.

Nothing could in fact have been more monstrous on the surface—and Densher was well aware of it—than the relief he found during this short period in the tacit drop of all reference to the palace, in neither hearing news nor asking for it. That was what had come out for him, on his visitor's entrance, even in the very seconds of suspense that were connecting the fact also directly and intensely with Milly's state. He had come to say he had saved her—he had come, as from Mrs. Stringham, to say how she might be saved—he had come, in spite of Mrs.

Translation

Nothing could, in fact, have been more monstrous on the surface—and Densher was well aware of it—than the relief he found during this short period in the tacit drop of all reference to the palace, in neither hearing news nor asking for it. That was what had come out for him, on his visitor's entrance, even in the very seconds of suspense that were connecting the fact also directly and intensely with Milly's state. He had come to say he had saved her—he had come, as from Mrs. Stringham, to say how she might be saved—he had come, in spite of Mrs.

Stringham, to say she was lost: the distinct throbs of hope, of fear, simultaneous for all their distinctness, merged their identity in a bound of the heart just as immediate and which remained after they had passed. It simply did wonders for him—this was the truth—that Sir Luke was, as he would have said, quiet. Sir Luke’s reappearance, as Densher quickly realized, wasn't about the subject they'd discussed before. Densher had reluctantly accepted that he’d reached the limit of how long he could avoid his responsibilities in London.

Translation

Stringham, to say she was lost: the distinct throbs of hope, of fear, simultaneous despite their differences, merged their identity in a bound of the heart that was just as immediate and that remained after they had passed. It simply did wonders for him—this was the truth—that Sir Luke was, as he would have said, quiet. Sir Luke’s reappearance, as Densher quickly realized, wasn't about the subject they'd discussed before. Densher had reluctantly accepted that he’d reached the limit of how long he could avoid his responsibilities in London.

Four or five days, not counting travel, was the most time he could expect the world-renowned doctor to sacrifice. When Sir Luke, summoned by a bell, stood in the doorway, the sight initially shocked Densher. It immediately signaled, in a single, frightening word, the severity—Densher didn't want to call it anything else—of Milly's condition. The doctor hadn't left, and the fact that he was still there suggested a major concession to her immense needs, hinting at some potential positive outcome.

Translation

Four or five days, not including travel, was the maximum time he could expect the celebrated doctor to give up. When Sir Luke, prompted by a bell, stood in the doorway, the sight initially startled Densher. It immediately signaled, in a single, terrifying word, the seriousness—Densher refused to call it anything else—of Milly's condition. The doctor hadn't departed, and the fact that he was still present suggested a significant concession to her considerable needs, implying some possible favorable development.

Densher, rebounding from his disappointment, was aware of multiple things at once. First, the possibility, since Sir Luke was still present, that she had been spared. However, the feeling that the crisis, which would obviously continue to affect him, wouldn't have a simple resolution followed quickly. His visitor hadn't come to discuss Milly; in fact, he hadn't come to mention her at all.

Translation

Densher, recovering from his disappointment, was conscious of several things simultaneously. Firstly, the possibility, given Sir Luke's continued presence, that she had been saved. But the feeling that the crisis, which would inevitably continue to impact him, wouldn't have an easy resolution quickly followed. His visitor hadn't come to discuss Milly; in fact, he hadn't come to mention her at all.

He had come to make it clear that during the remainder of his stay, which was ending soon, there would be as little discussion of her as possible. The doctor’s appearance was consistent with their previous encounters, and it was their existing relationship that brought him there. He wouldn't be staying past the coming Saturday, but he wanted to revisit some interesting places. He was looking for Densher to discuss these things, Venice and its opportunities, to take a few walks, as he put it, and look around.

Translation

He'd come to make it known that for the rest of his time there, which was almost over, there would be as little talk about her as he could manage. The doctor looked the same as he always did when they met, and it was their existing acquaintance that had brought him. He wouldn't be staying past the upcoming Saturday, but he wanted to revisit some interesting places. He wanted Densher to talk about these things, Venice and its prospects, to go for some walks, as he phrased it, and do some sightseeing.

This produced in Densher, after another day, a contradictory but beneficial reaction. On the surface, nothing could have been more absurd—and Densher knew it—than the relief he experienced during this brief time, as the subject of the palace was tacitly dropped. He neither heard any news nor asked for it. That was what emerged for him when the doctor entered, even in the moments of suspense directly connected to Milly’s situation.

Translation

The doctor's announcement triggered a strange, yet helpful, response in Densher, which occurred the following day. Superficially, it made no sense, and Densher was aware of this. He felt relief in the brief time that followed, as the topic of the palace was silently avoided. He neither received updates nor sought them out. This was his experience, even during moments of intense worry regarding Milly, when the doctor visited.

He had come to say he had saved her; he had come, as though sent by Mrs. Stringham, to say how she could be saved; he had come, despite Mrs. Stringham, to say she was lost. The distinct beats of hope and fear, separate yet concurrent, merged their identities in an immediate surge of emotion that lingered even after they subsided.

Translation

He had arrived to declare he had rescued her; he had come, as if dispatched by Mrs. Stringham, to explain how she could be saved; he had arrived, in spite of Mrs. Stringham, to announce she was doomed. The distinct pulses of hope and dread, existing independently yet simultaneously, fused their identities in an instantaneous flood of feeling, which persisted even after they diminished.

The truth was that it simply did wonders for him that Sir Luke was, as he would have put it, “quiet.” The result of it was the oddest consciousness as of a blest calm after a storm. He had been trying for weeks, as we know, to keep superlatively still, and trying it largely in solitude and silence; but he looked back on it now as on the heat of fever. The real, the right stillness was this particular form of society.

Translation

The truth was that it did him good to have Sir Luke around, as he would have said, “quiet.” The effect was a strange sense of blessed calm after a storm. He had spent weeks, as we know, trying to be perfectly still, mostly alone and silent; but he now saw that as a feverish struggle. The true, the real stillness was this specific kind of social setting.

They walked together and they talked, looked up pictures again and recovered impressions—Sir Luke knew just what he wanted; haunted a little the dealers in old wares; sat down at Florian's for rest and mild drinks; blessed above all the grand weather, a bath of warm air, a pageant of autumn light. Once or twice while they rested the great man closed his eyes—keeping them so for some minutes while his companion, the more easily watching his face for it, made private reflexions on the subject of lost sleep. He had been up at night with her—he in person, for hours; but this was all he showed of it and was apparently to remain his nearest approach to an allusion. The extraordinary thing was that Densher could take it in perfectly as evidence, could turn cold at the image looking out of it; and yet that he could at the same time not intermit a throb of his response to accepted liberation.

Translation

They walked and talked together, revisiting artwork and refreshing their memories—Sir Luke was decisive in his intentions. He frequented the antique dealers. He rested at Florian's for light refreshments, and above all, he appreciated the beautiful weather, a warm embrace of air, a spectacle of autumnal light. Once or twice, during their breaks, the older man closed his eyes, keeping them shut for several minutes while his companion, the better able to observe his features, privately contemplated the issue of lost sleep. Densher had spent hours awake with her, personally present during the night. But this was all he revealed, and it was apparently destined to be his closest reference to the matter. The remarkable aspect was that Densher could readily accept this as evidence, could be chilled by the unseen imagery it evoked, and yet, simultaneously, not lessen the surge of his reaction to the newfound freedom.

The liberation was an experience that held its own, and he continued to know why, in spite of his deserts, in spite of his folly, in spite of everything, he had so fondly hoped for it. He had hoped for it, had sat in his room there waiting for it, because he had thus divined in it, should it come, some power to let him off. He was being let off; dealt with in the only way that didn't aggravate his responsibility. The beauty was also that this wasn't on system or on any basis of intimate knowledge; it was just by being a man of the world and by knowing life, by feeling the real, that Sir Luke did him good.

Translation

The freedom was its own reward, and he still understood why, despite his failings, his mistakes, everything, he had desired it so much. He had hoped for it, sat alone in his room, waiting for it, because he sensed that it would, if it arrived, somehow absolve him. He was being absolved; it was being handled in a way that didn't worsen his guilt. The remarkable thing was that it wasn't due to any established plan or personal familiarity; it was simply that Sir Luke, being a worldly man and a student of life, did him good, by feeling what was real.

There had been in all the case too many women. A man's sense of it, another man's, changed the air; and he wondered what man, had he chosen, would have been more to his purpose than this one. He was large and easy—that was the benediction; he knew what mattered and what didn't; he distinguished between the essence and the shell, the just grounds and the unjust for fussing. One was thus—if one were concerned with him or exposed to him at all—in his hands for whatever he should do, and not much less affected by his mercy than one might have been by his rigour.

Translation

There had been too many women involved in the whole situation. The way a man understood it, another man's perspective, altered everything. He wondered which man, had he been given a choice, would have served his needs better than this one. This man was big and relaxed—that was the saving grace. He knew what was important and what wasn't; he could tell the difference between what truly mattered and what was superficial, between valid and invalid reasons for getting upset. Thus, if one was concerned with him, or in any way exposed to him, one was at his mercy, subject to whatever he chose to do, and as influenced by his compassion as one might have been by his severity.

The grand thing—it did come to that—was the way he carried off, as one might fairly call it, the business of making odd things natural. Nothing, if they hadn't taken it so, could have exceeded the unexplained oddity, between them, of Densher's now complete detachment from the poor ladies at the palace; nothing could have exceeded the no less marked anomaly of the great man's own abstentions of speech. He made, as he had done when they met at the station, nothing whatever of anything; and the effect of it, Densher would have said, was a relation with him quite resembling that of doctor and patient. One took the cue from him as one might have taken a dose—except that the cue was pleasant in the taking.

Translation

The amazing thing—it really came down to that—was the way he managed to pull off, or so one could say, the trick of making unusual things seem ordinary. If they hadn't accepted it so easily, nothing could have been more strangely unexplained than Densher’s current, total detachment from the women at the palace. Nothing could have exceeded the equally obvious strangeness of the great man’s own silence. Just as he had done when they met at the station, he made absolutely nothing of anything. And the effect of it, Densher would have said, created a relationship with him much like that of doctor and patient. One took his lead as one might have taken a dose of medicine—except that taking his lead was enjoyable.

The result was an unusual feeling, like a blessed calm after a storm. He had been trying for weeks, as we know, to remain perfectly still, mostly alone and silent, but he now saw that period as a fever dream. The true, the correct stillness was this specific form of companionship. They strolled together and talked, revisited art and refreshed their impressions—Sir Luke always knew what he wanted; he frequented the antique dealers; he sat at Florian's for rest and light drinks; and most of all, he appreciated the beautiful weather, the warmth of the air, and the spectacle of autumn light.

Translation

The outcome was a strange sense of serenity, as if a storm had finally passed. For weeks, as we know, he had striven for stillness, mostly in solitude and silence, but now he saw that time as a feverish vision. The real, the proper stillness existed in this particular kind of fellowship. They walked together and spoke, revisited art and renewed their perspectives—Sir Luke always had a clear vision; he frequented the antique shops; he sat at Florian's for respite and light refreshments; and, above all, he cherished the lovely weather, the warmth of the air, and the display of autumnal light.

Once or twice while they rested, the older man closed his eyes—keeping them closed for several minutes while his companion, easily observing him, privately considered the lack of sleep. He had stayed up at night with her—he himself, for hours; but this was all he revealed and was apparently the closest he would come to mentioning it. The remarkable thing was that Densher could understand it completely as evidence, could feel a chill at the image it presented; and yet, at the same time, he did not lessen his response to this accepted freedom. The freedom was a powerful experience, and he continued to understand why, despite his mistakes, his foolishness, and everything else, he had longed for it so much.

Translation

Once or twice as they took a break, the older man shut his eyes, keeping them closed for several minutes while his companion, watching him carefully, privately thought about his lack of sleep. He had stayed up all night with her—he himself, for hours; but that was all he let on, and seemed to be the nearest he’d get to saying anything about it. The strange thing was that Densher understood it perfectly as a sign, could feel a shiver at the picture it painted; and yet, at the same time, he didn’t soften his reaction to this accepted liberty. The freedom was a potent feeling, and he still understood why, despite his errors, his foolishness, and everything else, he’d wanted it so badly.

He had hoped for it, had sat in his room waiting for it, because he had sensed in it, if it came, a way to be forgiven. He was being forgiven; treated in the only way that did not increase his guilt. The beautiful part was that this was not based on any system or personal knowledge; it was simply because Sir Luke was a man of the world and understood life, by recognizing reality, that he was helping him. There had been too many women involved in the whole situation.

Translation

He had anticipated it, sat alone in his room, anticipating it. He saw it, if it came, as a path to absolution. He was being absolved; treated in a way that didn’t compound his shame. The beauty of it was that it was uncalculated, not based on any plan or personal connection. It was simply because Sir Luke was worldly and understood life, because he saw the truth of things, that he was helping him. There had been too many women tangled up in all of this.

The perspective of a man, of another man, changed the atmosphere; and he wondered which man, if he had a choice, would have served his needs better than this one.
