Sir Luke was large and easygoing—that was the blessing; he knew what mattered and what didn't; he distinguished between the essential and the superficial, the justified and unjustified reasons for making a fuss. One was thus—if one was associated with him at all—in his care for whatever he should do, and almost as affected by his mercy as one might have been by his severity. The best part—it came down to that—was how he managed to make odd things seem natural.

Translation

The presence of another man—of any man, really—shifted the dynamic. He found himself wondering, if he could choose, which man would have better served his purposes. Sir Luke's relaxed demeanor was a godsend; he understood what was important and what wasn't. He separated the core issues from the trivial, and the justifiable from the petty complaints. Anyone associated with him benefited from his careful consideration of their actions, almost as much as they would have been affected by his condemnation. Ultimately, the most remarkable thing about him was his ability to normalize the strange.

Nothing, if they hadn't accepted it so, could have been stranger than Densher's complete detachment from the women at the palace; nothing could have been stranger than the older man's own silence. He made nothing of anything, as he had when they met at the station; and the effect of it, Densher would have said, was a relationship with him much like that of a doctor and patient. One followed his lead as one might take a medicine—except that taking the lead was pleasant. That was why one could leave it to his tacit discretion, why for the three or four days Densher again and again did so leave it; merely wondering a little, at the most, on the eve of Saturday, the announced term of the episode.

Translation

Nothing could have been stranger than Densher's total separation from the women at the palace, if they hadn't accepted it so; nothing could have been stranger than the older man's own silence. He made nothing of anything, as he had when they met at the station; and the effect of it, Densher would have said, was a relationship with him much like that of a doctor and patient. One followed his lead as one might take a medicine—except that taking the lead was pleasant. That was why one could leave it to his tacit discretion, why for the three or four days Densher again and again did so leave it; merely wondering a little, at the most, on the eve of Saturday, the announced term of the episode.

Waiting once more on this latter occasion, the Saturday morning, for Sir Luke's reappearance at the station, our friend had to recognise the drop of his own borrowed ease, the result, naturally enough, of the prospect of losing a support. The difficulty was that, on such lines as had served them, the support was Sir Luke's personal presence. Would he go without leaving some substitute for that?—and without breaking, either, his silence in respect to his errand? Densher was in still deeper ignorance than at the hour of his call, and what was truly prodigious at so supreme a moment was that—as had immediately to appear—no gleam of light on what he had been living with for a week found its way out of him.

Translation

Waiting again on this Saturday morning for Sir Luke to show up at the station, our friend had to admit his borrowed ease was gone, the obvious result of losing support. The problem was that, in the way things had been arranged, the support was Sir Luke's physical presence. Would he leave without providing some replacement for that?—and without breaking his silence about his mission? Densher was even more in the dark than when he'd been summoned, and what was truly remarkable at this crucial moment was that—as would immediately become clear—no insight into what he’d been dealing with for a week emerged from him.

What he had been doing was proof of a huge interest as well as of a huge fee; yet when the Leporelli gondola again, and somewhat tardily, approached, his companion, watching from the water-steps, studied his fine closed face as much as ever in vain. It was like a lesson, from the highest authority, on the subject of the relevant, so that its blankness affected Densher of a sudden almost as a cruelty, feeling it quite awfully compatible, as he did, with Milly's having ceased to exist. And the suspense continued after they had passed together, as time was short, directly into the station, where Eugenio, in the field early, was mounting guard over the compartment he had secured. The strain, though probably lasting, at the carriage-door, but a couple of minutes, prolonged itself so for our poor gentleman's nerves that he involuntarily directed a long look at Eugenio, who met it, however, as only Eugenio could.

Translation

What he had been doing was evidence of both a tremendous interest and a tremendous fee. Yet when the Leporelli gondola again, and somewhat late, drew near, his companion, watching from the water steps, studied his finely composed face, as futile as ever. It was like a lesson, from the highest authority, on the subject of the relevant, so that its emptiness affected Densher suddenly almost as cruelty, feeling it quite terribly compatible, as he did, with Milly's having ceased to exist. And the suspense continued after they had passed together, as time was short, directly into the station, where Eugenio, already on the scene, was guarding the compartment he had secured. The strain, though lasting probably only a couple of minutes at the carriage door, prolonged itself so for our poor gentleman's nerves that he involuntarily gave a long look at Eugenio, who met it, however, as only Eugenio could.

Sir Luke's attention was given for the time to the right bestowal of his numerous effects, about which he was particular, and Densher fairly found himself, so far as silence could go, questioning the representative of the palace. It didn't humiliate him now; it didn't humiliate him even to feel that that personage exactly knew how little he satisfied him. Eugenio resembled to that extent Sir Luke—to the extent of the extraordinary things with which his facial habit was compatible. By the time, however, that Densher had taken from it all its possessor intended Sir Luke was free and with a hand out for farewell.

Translation

For the moment, Sir Luke was occupied with carefully arranging his many belongings, a task he took seriously. Densher, confined by silence, essentially questioned the palace’s representative. It didn't embarrass him now; it didn’t even embarrass him to feel that Eugenio knew exactly how little he pleased him. Eugenio was, in that way, like Sir Luke—in that his facial expression was compatible with the most extraordinary things. But by the time Densher understood all that Sir Luke intended, Sir Luke was free, extending a hand in farewell.

He offered the hand at first without speech; only on meeting his eyes could our young man see that they had never yet so completely looked at him. It was never, with Sir Luke, that they looked harder at one time than at another; but they looked longer, and this, even a shade of it, might mean on his part everything. It meant, Densher for ten seconds believed, that Milly Theale was dead; so that the word at last spoken made him start. That's why Densher could trust Sir Luke's judgment and discretion.

Translation

He offered his hand silently at first. Only when their eyes met did the young man understand that Sir Luke had never truly looked at him so completely. It wasn't that Sir Luke looked more intently at any given moment than any other, but that he looked longer. Even the slightest degree of this could mean everything on his part. Densher believed for ten seconds that this meant Milly Theale was dead, and the spoken word that followed made him jump. That was why Densher could trust Sir Luke's judgement and discretion.

For several days, he did just that, though he couldn't help but wonder, at most, on the eve of Saturday, the day the episode was supposed to end. Waiting again that Saturday morning for Sir Luke to reappear at the train station, Densher noticed his own relief and ease had vanished. That was because he was about to lose a critical support. The problem was, the support they had relied on was Sir Luke's personal presence.

Translation

For several days, he did exactly that, though he couldn't help but be curious, at most, the evening before Saturday, the day the situation was expected to resolve. Waiting again that Saturday morning for Sir Luke to arrive at the train station, Densher realized his own relief and composure had disappeared. This was because he was about to lose an essential pillar of support. The difficulty was, the support they had depended on was Sir Luke's physical presence.

Would he leave without providing a replacement? And would he continue to be silent about his mission? Densher knew even less than he had at the beginning of this arrangement. What was truly astonishing at this critical moment was that not a single clue emerged about what he had spent the last week involved in.

Translation

Would he depart without leaving someone else in his place? And would he maintain his secrecy regarding his purpose? Densher was now even more in the dark than when this whole thing began. The truly remarkable thing at this crucial juncture was that not a single hint had surfaced about what he’d been occupied with for the past week.

He had been occupied with something of great importance, for which he was being paid handsomely. Yet, when the Leporelli gondola finally arrived, his companion, watching from the steps, studied the doctor's composed expression, but learned nothing. It was like a lesson in secrecy from the highest authority. The blankness of Sir Luke's face suddenly felt cruel to Densher.

Translation

He’d been busy with something crucial, and getting paid a lot of money to do it. But when the Leporelli gondola finally pulled up, his friend, watching from the steps, studied the doctor's calm face, and found out nothing. It was like a master class in keeping secrets. Sir Luke's expressionless face suddenly felt cruel to Densher.

He found it shockingly possible that Milly had passed away. The suspense continued after they entered the station. Time was short, but the strain on Densher's nerves was intense. He involuntarily glanced at Eugenio, who responded in his usual way.

Translation

He found the possibility of Milly’s death shockingly real. The uncertainty persisted after they were inside the train station. Though they were pressed for time, the tension was unbearable for Densher. He couldn’t help but look at Eugenio, who reacted in his typical fashion.

Sir Luke was busy arranging his many belongings, a task he took seriously. Densher, silent as could be, found himself questioning the man from the palace. It didn't embarrass him now. He wasn't even embarrassed to feel that Eugenio knew exactly how unsatisfactory he found him.

Translation

Sir Luke was meticulously organizing his possessions, a chore he treated with utmost seriousness. Densher, maintaining complete silence, began to critically assess the man from the palace. He felt no shame in doing so now. He wasn't even ashamed to sense that Eugenio fully understood how displeased he was with him.

Eugenio was like Sir Luke in that his face was capable of expressing an extraordinary range of emotions. However, by the time Densher had gotten everything he could from Eugenio's expression, Sir Luke was ready to leave, hand outstretched for a farewell. He offered his hand without speaking at first. Only when Densher met his gaze did he see that Sir Luke had never looked at him so intently.

Translation

Eugenio shared with Sir Luke the ability to display a remarkably varied palette of emotions across his face. But by the time Densher had fully mined Eugenio’s expression, Sir Luke was poised to depart, his hand extended in farewell. He offered his hand without speaking, initially. It was only when Densher met his gaze that he saw Sir Luke had never looked at him so intently before.

Sir Luke's stare wasn't always more intense at one moment than another, but this time he looked longer. That subtle difference could mean everything. Densher believed for ten seconds that Milly Theale was dead, so the words Sir Luke finally spoke startled him. "I shall come back."

Translation

Sir Luke didn't always fix Densher with a more penetrating gaze at one moment than another, but this time he held it. That subtle difference could mean everything. Densher believed for ten seconds that Milly Theale was dead, so the words Sir Luke finally spoke startled him. "I shall come back."

"Then she's better?" "I shall come back within the month," Sir Luke repeated without heeding the question. He had dropped Densher's hand, but he held him otherwise still. "I bring you a message from Miss Theale," he said as if they hadn't spoken of her.

Translation

"So, she's better?"

"I shall come back within the month," Sir Luke repeated, ignoring the question. He had released Densher's hand, but he continued to hold him in place. "I bring you a message from Miss Theale," he said, as if they hadn't been discussing her.

"I'm commissioned to ask you from her to go and see her." Densher's rebound from his supposition had a violence that his stare betrayed. "She asks me?" Sir Luke had got into the carriage, the door of which the guard had closed; but he spoke again as he stood at the window, bending a little but not leaning out.

Translation

"She's asked me to request you to go and see her." Densher's reaction to his own assumption was intense, and his gaze revealed it. "She asks me?" Sir Luke had entered the carriage, the door of which the guard had shut; but he spoke again as he stood by the window, bending slightly but not leaning out.

"She told me she'd like it, and I promised that, as I expected to find you here, I'd let you know." "I will return." "Then she's doing better?" "I will return within the month," Sir Luke repeated, ignoring the question.

Translation

"She said she'd like that, and I promised, since I figured I'd find you, I'd tell you." "I'll go back." "So she's feeling better?" "I'll return within the month," Sir Luke repeated, not answering the question.

He had released Densher's hand, but he continued to hold him in place. "I have a message for you from Miss Theale," he said, as if they hadn't been discussing her. "She asked me to ask you to go and see her." Densher's reaction to the unexpected information was intense, visible in his gaze.

Translation

He'd let go of Densher's hand, but he kept him standing there. "I have a message for you from Miss Theale," he said, as if they hadn't been talking about her at all. "She asked me to ask you to go see her." Densher's response to the surprising news was strong, evident in his eyes.

"She wants to see me?" Sir Luke was already inside the carriage, the door closed by the guard, but he spoke again from the window, leaning in slightly but not fully extending himself. "She said she would like you to visit, and since I expected to find you here, I promised I'd let you know." Densher, on the platform, took it from him, but what he took brought the blood into his face quite as what he had had to take from Mrs.

Translation

"She wants to see me?" Sir Luke was already in the carriage, the door shut by the guard. But he spoke again from the window, leaning in slightly, not fully outside. "She said she would like you to visit, and since I expected to find you here, I promised I'd let you know." Densher, on the platform, accepted this. But what he accepted brought a rush of blood to his face, just as much as what he'd had to accept from Mrs.

Stringham. And he was also bewildered. "Then she can receive—?" "She can receive you."

Translation

Stringham. And he was also bewildered. "Then she can receive—?" "She can receive you."

"And you're coming back—?" "Oh because I must. She's not to move. She's to stay.

Translation

"And you're returning—?" "Oh, of course. She can't leave. She has to stay."

I come to her." "I see, I see," said Densher, who indeed did see—saw the sense of his friend's words and saw beyond it as well. What Mrs. Stringham had announced, and what he had yet expected not to have to face, had then come.

Translation

"I'm coming to her." "I see, I see," said Densher, who did understand—understood the meaning of his friend's words and saw even more than that. What Mrs. Stringham had revealed, and what he'd hoped he wouldn't have to confront, had arrived.

Sir Luke had kept it for the last, but there it was, and the colourless compact form it was now taking—the tone of one man of the world to another, who, after what had happened, would understand—was but the characteristic manner of his appeal. Densher was to understand remarkably much; and the great thing certainly was to show that he did. "I'm particularly obliged, I'll go to-day." He brought that out, but in his pause, while they continued to look at each other, the train had slowly creaked into motion. There was time but for one more word, and the young man chose it, out of twenty, with intense concentration.

Translation

Sir Luke had saved it for the end, but there it was, and the colorless, tightly-wound shape it was now assuming—the tone one worldly man uses with another, who, after all that had occurred, would comprehend—was just the typical style of his request. Densher was meant to understand a great deal; and the key thing, surely, was to demonstrate that he did. "I'm very grateful, I'll go today." He managed that, but during the pause, while they continued to regard each other, the train had slowly begun to move. There was time for only one more word, and the young man selected it, from among twenty, with intense focus.

"Then she's better?" Densher, standing on the platform, took the message. The information caused a rush of blood to his face, just as something he had already been told by Mrs. Stringham had.

Translation

"So, is she doing better?" Densher, still on the platform, received the message. The news brought a flush to his cheeks, just like something Mrs. Stringham had told him earlier.

He was also confused. "So, she can have visitors—?" "She can have you." "And you're coming back—?"

Translation

He was also confused. "So, she's allowed visitors—?" "She's allowed you." "And you're coming back—?"

"Oh yes, I have to. She's not supposed to move. She must stay. I'm going to her."

Translation

"Of course, I have to. She's not supposed to move. She has to stay put. I'm going to her."

"I see, I see," said Densher, who did understand—he grasped the simple meaning of his friend's words, and he understood even more than that. What Mrs. Stringham had revealed, and what he had been hoping he wouldn't have to confront, had arrived. Sir Luke had saved it for the end, but now it was here, taking on a clear, concise shape—the tone of one sophisticated man speaking to another, who, after everything that had happened, would know what he meant—it was just the way he appealed to Densher.

Translation

"I understand," Densher replied, and in fact, he did understand—he saw the surface meaning of his friend's statement, and he understood even more than that. The thing Mrs. Stringham had hinted at, the thing he had hoped to avoid, had arrived. Sir Luke had kept it for the end, but now it was here, taking on a clear, distinct form—the way a knowledgeable man speaks to another, who, after everything they’d been through, would comprehend him—that’s how he addressed Densher.

Densher was expected to understand a great deal; and the most important thing, undoubtedly, was to demonstrate that he did. "I'm very grateful, I'll go today." He managed to say that, but as they paused, staring at each other, the train slowly began to move. There was only time for one more word, and the young man chose it, out of many possibilities, with intense focus. "Then she's better?"

Translation

Densher was meant to understand a great deal, and the most crucial thing, without question, was to prove that he did. "I'm very grateful. I'll go today." He forced the words out, but as they stood there, locked in a gaze, the train started to pull away. They only had time for a single word more, and the young man chose it, with intense focus, from the many options available to him. "Then she's better?"

Sir Luke's face was wonderful. "Yes, she's better." And he kept it at the window while the train receded, holding him with it still. It was to be his nearest approach to the utter reference they had hitherto so successfully avoided. If it stood for everything; never had a face had to stand for more.

Translation

Sir Luke's face was extraordinary. "Yes, she's better."

And he remained there, by the window, as the train moved away, still holding Densher's attention. This was the closest they had come to the explicit discussion they'd carefully dodged. If it was to represent everything; never had a face been tasked with more significance.

So Densher, held after the train had gone, sharply reflected; so he reflected, asking himself into what abyss it pushed him, even while conscious of retreating under the maintained observation of Eugenio.

Translation

So Densher, held back after the train departed, thought sharply. He reflected, asking himself into what abyss it was pushing him, even while conscious of retreating under Eugenio's continued observation.

Chapter 18

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Aunt Maud interrupts a conversation between Densher and Kate, who are standing by a fire. Kate and Densher separate as she enters. Kate speaks to her aunt and then leaves. Over the following week, Densher has several conversations with Aunt Maud over tea. They discuss his recent experiences in Venice and speak of a girl named Milly, referring to her in the past tense. Densher tells Aunt Maud things about the experience that he has not told Kate. One morning, Densher goes to a post office and sends a telegram to Kate. Later that day, he goes to a park and waits for her. Kate arrives. He takes her arm and they walk to a spot under a tree. He says they should get married the next day and announce it. Kate questions him, saying they should wait. She then tells him that if he confirms he "knows something," she will agree to marry him immediately. Densher replies that he knows nothing. She says she would go home and announce the marriage that moment if he could give her an "idea" in good faith. After his appeal fails, Kate puts her hand on him and makes him sit down with her in a pair of chairs.
Chapter I

"Then it has been—what do you say? a whole fortnight?—without your making a sign?" Kate put that to him distinctly, in the December dusk of Lancaster Gate and on the matter of the time he had been back; but he saw with it straightway that she was as admirably true as ever to her instinct—which was a system as well—of not admitting the possibility between them of small resentments, of trifles to trip up their general trust. That by itself, the renewed beauty of it, would at this fresh sight of her have stirred him to his depths if something else, something no less vivid but quite separate, hadn't stirred him still more.

Translation

"So it's been—what do you call it? a whole two weeks?—without you reaching out?" Kate asked him directly, in the December twilight of Lancaster Gate, concerning how long he'd been back. But he understood immediately that she was, as always, flawlessly true to her instinct—which was also a strategy—of not allowing for the possibility of minor grievances between them, of trivial matters undermining their overall faith. That alone, the renewed beauty of it, would have moved him profoundly at the sight of her again, if something else, something equally intense but entirely different, hadn't moved him even more.

It was in seeing her that he felt what their interruption had been, and that they met across it even as persons whose adventures, on either side, in time and space, of the nature of perils and exiles, had had a peculiar strangeness. He wondered if he were as different for her as she herself had immediately appeared: which was but his way indeed of taking in, with his thrill, that—even going by the mere first look—she had never been so handsome. That fact bloomed for him, in the firelight and lamplight that glowed their welcome through the London fog, as the flower of her difference; just as her difference itself—part of which was her striking him as older in a degree for which no mere couple of months could account—was the fruit of their intimate relation. If she was different it was because they had chosen together that she should be, and she might now, as a proof of their wisdom, their success, of the reality of what had happened—of what in fact, for the spirit of each, was still happening—been showing it to him for pride.

Translation

It was seeing her that made him realize the nature of their separation, and that they were meeting across that chasm, like people whose separate journeys—filled with dangers and exiles—had taken on a strange character. He wondered if he seemed as changed to her as she immediately seemed to him: his way of acknowledging, with a thrill, that even at first glance, she had never been so beautiful. That fact blossomed for him in the firelight and lamplight that welcomed them through the London fog, like the flower of her transformation; just as her difference—including the fact that she seemed older, by an amount that couldn’t be explained by just a couple of months—was the fruit of their intimate connection. If she was different, it was because they had chosen it together, and she might now, as a testament to their wisdom, their success, and the reality of what had happened—of what was, in fact, still happening for each of them in spirit—be showing it to him out of pride.

His having returned and yet kept, for numbered days, so still, had been, he was quite aware, the first point he should have to tackle; with which consciousness indeed he had made a clean breast of it in finally addressing Mrs. Lowder a note that had led to his present visit. He had written to Aunt Maud as the finer way; and it would doubtless have been to be noted that he needed no effort not to write to Kate. Venice was three weeks behind him—he had come up slowly; but it was still as if even in London he must conform to her law.

Translation

He knew that his return and subsequent stillness, for a specific period of time, would be the initial matter he'd have to address. Aware of this, he’d already confessed everything by writing a note to Mrs. Lowder, which had resulted in this meeting. He had, in fact, written to Aunt Maud, which he considered a more refined approach. It should be noted that he experienced no struggle to avoid writing to Kate. Venice was three weeks past—he'd traveled at a leisurely pace—yet he still felt as if he had to abide by her rules, even in London.

That was exactly how he was able, with his faith in her steadiness, to appeal to her feeling for the situation and explain his stretched delicacy. He had come to tell her everything, so far as occasion would serve them; and if nothing was more distinct than that his slow journey, his waits, his delay to reopen communication had kept pace with this resolve, so the inconsequence was doubtless at bottom but one of the elements of intensity. He was gathering everything up, everything he should tell her. That took time, and the proof was that, as he felt on the spot, he couldn't have brought it all with him before this afternoon.

Translation

That's precisely how he could, trusting in her consistency, appeal to her understanding of the situation and articulate his strained sensitivity. He had come to tell her everything, as far as the circumstances would allow; and if nothing was clearer than the fact that his slow journey, his pauses, his delay in resuming contact had been aligned with this decision, then the seeming lack of importance was surely just another aspect of the gravity of the situation. He was assembling all the details, everything he planned to tell her. That required time, and the evidence was that, as he realized in the moment, he couldn't have presented it all to her before this afternoon.

He had brought it, to the last syllable, and, out of the quantity it wouldn't be hard—as he in fact found—to produce, for Kate's understanding, his first reason. Sir Luke's face was extraordinary. "Yes, she's doing better." He remained at the window as the train moved away, as if it were still holding him there.

Translation

He had prepared it, word for word, and from the wealth of information available—as he discovered—it wouldn't be difficult to convey his initial reasoning for Kate's understanding. Sir Luke's expression was remarkable. "Yes, she's improving." He stayed by the window as the train departed, as if it still held him in place.

This was the closest he'd come to discussing the subject they'd deliberately avoided until now. His face expressed everything; it had never had to convey so much. Densher considered this sharply after the train had gone. He wondered what kind of trouble this put him in, even while realizing Eugenio was still watching him.

Translation

This was the closest he'd gotten to talking about the thing they'd been intentionally ignoring. His face showed everything; it had never been asked to communicate so much. Densher considered this carefully after the train was gone. He wondered what kind of trouble this caused him, even while understanding Eugenio was still watching him.

**BOOK TEN** **I** "So, it's been—what, a whole two weeks?—without you contacting me?" Kate asked him this directly, in the December twilight of Lancaster Gate, referring to how long he'd been back.

Translation

But he immediately saw that she was, as always, true to her nature—which was also a strategy—of not allowing small resentments or minor issues to disrupt their overall trust. That alone, the renewed beauty of it, would have deeply moved him upon seeing her again, if something else, something equally striking but completely separate, hadn't moved him even more. Seeing her, he realized the extent of their separation and that they were meeting again as people whose experiences, on both sides, with their perils and exiles, had been remarkably strange. He wondered if he seemed as different to her as she immediately seemed to him: which was simply his way of recognizing, with his excitement, that—even at first glance—she had never been more beautiful.

Translation

But he immediately understood that she was, as always, true to herself—a strategy, too—of not letting small resentments or minor issues get in the way of their overall trust. That alone, the renewed beauty of it, would have deeply moved him upon seeing her again, if something else, something equally striking but completely separate, hadn't moved him even more. Seeing her, he realized the extent of their separation, and that they were meeting again as people whose experiences, on both sides, with their perils and exiles, had been remarkably strange. He wondered if he seemed as different to her as she immediately seemed to him: which was simply his way of recognizing, with his excitement, that—even at first glance—she had never been more beautiful.

That fact blossomed for him, in the warm glow of the firelight and lamplight that welcomed them through the London fog, like the most beautiful part of her difference; just as her difference itself—part of which was her looking significantly older, which couldn't be explained by just a couple of months—was the result of their intimate relationship. Translation

That truth bloomed for him in the warm light of the fire and lamps, which greeted them through the London fog, like the most beautiful aspect of her transformation. Her difference—part of which was looking considerably older, more than a few months could account for—was a product of their intimacy. If she had changed, it was a change they'd chosen together. Perhaps she was demonstrating this, as validation of their wisdom, their triumph, the reality of what had occurred—what still lived in their hearts—out of a sense of pride. This was precisely how he was able, with his faith in her steadiness, to appeal to her understanding of the situation and explain his cautious approach.

Translation

That truth blossomed for him in the warm light of the fire and lamps, which greeted them through the London fog, like the most beautiful aspect of her transformation. Her difference—part of which was looking considerably older, more than a few months could account for—was a product of their intimacy. If she had changed, it was a change they'd chosen together. Perhaps she was demonstrating this, as validation of their wisdom, their triumph, the reality of what had occurred—what still lived in their hearts—out of a sense of pride. He understood that his return, followed by several days of silence, was the first matter he would have to address. He was aware of this when he finally wrote a note to Mrs. Lowder that led to his current visit. He'd written to Aunt Maud as the more sensible choice, and it was certainly worth noting that he didn't need any effort not to write to Kate. He'd left Venice three weeks ago—he'd traveled slowly—but it was still as if he had to obey her rules even in London. This was precisely how he was able, with his faith in her steadiness, to appeal to her understanding of the situation and explain his cautious approach.

He had come to tell her everything, as much as their circumstances would allow; and while nothing was clearer than that his slow journey, his pauses, and his delay in resuming communication had been in line with this decision, the lack of logic was probably just another element of the intensity. He was gathering everything, everything he would tell her. This took time, and the proof was that, as he felt then, he couldn't have brought it all with him before this afternoon. He'd brought it all, down to the last word, and, from the abundance of it, it wouldn't be difficult—as he found—to give Kate his first reason.

Translation

He had come to tell her everything, as much as their situation permitted; and while it was obvious that his slow journey, his hesitations, and his delay in contacting her again aligned with this decision, the lack of logic was probably just another aspect of their entanglement. He was accumulating everything, everything he would tell her. This took time, and the proof was that, as he felt then, he couldn't have brought it all with him before this afternoon. He had brought it all, down to the last word, and, from its fullness, it wouldn't be hard—as he discovered—to give Kate his first reason.

"A fortnight, yes—it was a fortnight Friday; but I've only been keeping in, you see, with our wonderful system." He was so easily justified as that this of itself plainly enough prevented her saying she didn't see. Their wonderful system was accordingly still vivid for her; and such a gage of its equal vividness for himself was precisely what she must have asked. He hadn't even to dot his i's beyond the remark that on the very face of it, she would remember, their wonderful system attached no premium to rapidities of transition. "I couldn't quite—don't you know?—take my rebound with a rush; and I suppose I've been instinctively hanging off to minimise, for you as well as for myself, the appearances of rushing.

Translation

"A fortnight, yes—it was a fortnight last Friday; but I've only been keeping in, you see, with our wonderful system." He was so easily justified that this alone prevented her from saying she didn't understand. Their wonderful system was still vivid for her; and such proof of its equal vividness for him was precisely what she must have asked. He didn't even have to clarify beyond the remark that she would remember, their wonderful system didn't put a premium on rapid transitions. "I couldn't quite—you know?—take my rebound with a rush; and I suppose I've been instinctively hanging off to minimize, for you as well as for myself, the appearance of rushing."

There's a sort of fitness. But I knew you'd understand." It was presently as if she really understood so well that she almost appealed from his insistence—yet looking at him too, he was not unconscious, as if this mastery of fitnesses was a strong sign for her of what she had done to him. He might have struck her as expert for contingencies in the very degree of her having in Venice struck him as expert. He smiled over his plea for a renewal with stages and steps, a thing shaded, as they might say, and graduated; though—finely as she must respond—she met the smile but as she had met his entrance five minutes before.

Translation

There's a certain appropriateness to it. But I knew you'd understand." Soon after, she seemed to understand so thoroughly that she nearly challenged his persistence. But as she looked at him, he was aware, as if this expertise in appropriateness confirmed the impact she'd had on him. He might have appeared to her as skilled in handling unexpected situations, the same way she had seemed skilled to him in Venice. He smiled at his case for a slow, measured, and gradual return, nuanced, as they might put it, and carefully planned. Yet—however subtly she responded—she acknowledged the smile the same way she had received his arrival five minutes earlier.

Her soft gravity at that moment—which was yet not solemnity, but the look of a consciousness charged with life to the brim and wishing not to overflow—had not qualified her welcome; what had done this being much more the presence in the room, for a couple of minutes, of the footman who had introduced him and who had been interrupted in preparing the tea-table. It had been two weeks, yes, two weeks last Friday; but I’ve only been staying in, you see, adhering to our amazing plan. He was so easily satisfied that this alone prevented her from saying she didn’t understand. Their amazing plan was therefore still fresh in her mind, and that it was equally fresh in his was precisely what she needed to confirm.

Translation

Her gentle seriousness at that moment—which wasn’t solemn, but the look of a mind overflowing with life and trying not to spill over—hadn't changed her welcome. What had changed it was more the presence, for a few minutes, of the footman who had let him in, who’d been busy setting up the tea table. It had been two weeks, yes, two weeks last Friday; but I’ve just been staying in, you see, sticking to our amazing plan. He was so easily pleased that this alone kept her from saying she didn’t understand. Their amazing plan was, therefore, still fresh in her memory, and that it was equally fresh in his was precisely what she needed to verify.

He didn’t even need to elaborate beyond pointing out that, obviously, she would remember that their amazing plan didn’t encourage any sudden changes. “I couldn’t exactly—you know?—jump back into things right away. I suppose I’ve been holding back to reduce the appearance of rushing, for you as well as for me. It seemed appropriate.

Translation

He didn't need to explain further than to point out the obvious: she would recall their amazing plan forbade any sudden changes. "I couldn't just—you know?—jump back in right away. I suppose I've been holding back to avoid seeming to rush, for your sake as well as mine. It seemed appropriate."

But I knew you’d understand.” It was soon as if she understood so well that she nearly tried to avoid his explanation. Looking at him, he was aware that this focus on appropriateness was a powerful indicator for her of the impact she had had on him. He seemed as prepared for anything as she had seemed prepared in Venice. He smiled at his argument for a gradual return, something subtle and measured, though—even though she had to respond gracefully—she returned the smile in the same way she had received his arrival five minutes before.

Translation

"But I knew you'd understand." It was almost as though she understood so well that she wanted to skip his explanation. Looking at him, he realized this emphasis on what was proper was a strong sign, for her, of how much she’d affected him. He seemed as ready for anything as she had in Venice. He smiled at his justification for a slow return, something nuanced and controlled, even though she had to react with poise; she returned the smile in the way she had greeted his arrival five minutes earlier.

Her gentle seriousness at that moment—which wasn’t solemnity, but the look of someone fully aware, wanting not to reveal too much—hadn’t lessened her welcome. What had done so was more the presence in the room for a couple of minutes of the footman who had brought him in and had been interrupted while setting the tea table. Mrs. Lowder's reply to Densher's note had been to appoint the tea-hour, five o'clock on Sunday, for his seeing them.

Translation

Her quiet intensity, which wasn't grim but rather the expression of someone perceptive, trying to remain reserved, hadn't diminished her warmth. What had diminished it was more the fact that the footman, who had shown him in and had been in the middle of setting the tea table, had been in the room for a couple of minutes. Mrs. Lowder’s response to Densher’s note had been to set the time for tea—five o’clock on Sunday—as the time for his visit.

Kate had thereafter wired him, without a signature, "Come on Sunday before tea—about a quarter of an hour, which will help us"; and he had arrived therefore scrupulously at twenty minutes to five. Kate was alone in the room and hadn't delayed to tell him that Aunt Maud, as she had happily gathered, was to be, for the interval—not long but precious—engaged with an old servant, retired and pensioned, who had been paying her a visit and who was within the hour to depart again for the suburbs. They were to have the scrap of time, after the withdrawal of the footman, to themselves, and there was a moment when, in spite of their wonderful system, in spite of the proscription of rushes and the propriety of shades, it proclaimed itself indeed precious. And all without prejudice—that was what kept it noble—to Kate's high sobriety and her beautiful self-command.

Translation

Kate had then wired him, without a signature, "Come on Sunday before tea—about fifteen minutes, which will help us"; and so he had arrived precisely at twenty minutes to five. Kate was alone in the room and hadn't hesitated to tell him that Aunt Maud, as she'd happily learned, would be, for a short but precious time, occupied with an old servant, now retired and receiving a pension, who had been visiting and would be leaving for the suburbs within the hour. They would have that small amount of time to themselves after the footman left, and there was a moment when, despite their perfect plan, despite avoiding hurried actions and maintaining appropriate decorum, it revealed itself as truly valuable. And all without harm to—that was what kept it honorable—Kate's clear-headedness and her admirable self-control.

If he had his discretion she had her perfect manner, which was her decorum. Mrs. Stringham, he had, to finish with the question of his delay, furthermore observed, Mrs. Stringham would have written to Mrs.

Translation

Lowder of his having quitted the place; so that it wasn't as if he were hoping to cheat them. They'd know he was no longer there. Mrs. Lowder's response to Densher's note was to schedule a meeting for tea, at five o'clock on Sunday.

Translation

Lowder that he had left. It wasn't as though he was trying to deceive them. They would know he wasn't there anymore. In response to Densher's note, Mrs. Lowder proposed a meeting over tea, at five o'clock on Sunday.

Kate then sent him a telegram, unsigned, saying, "Come on Sunday before tea—about fifteen minutes, which will help us." He arrived promptly at twenty minutes to five. Kate was alone in the room, and she immediately told him that Aunt Maud, fortunately, would be occupied during that time—a short but valuable period—with an old, retired servant who was visiting and would be leaving for the suburbs within the hour. They would have a few minutes alone, after the footman left, and there was a moment when, despite their careful planning, and the rule against haste, this time felt truly special. Translation

Kate then sent him an unsigned telegram that read, "Come on Sunday before tea—about fifteen minutes, which will help us." He arrived precisely at twenty minutes to five. Kate was alone in the room, and she told him at once that Aunt Maud, luckily, would be occupied during that time—a brief but significant period—with an elderly, retired servant who was visiting and would be departing for the suburbs within the hour. They would have a few minutes alone, after the footman left, and there was a moment when, in spite of their careful planning, and the rule against haste, this time felt truly special. And all without compromising—that's what made it elegant—Kate's clarity and her admirable self-control.

While he had his prudence, she had her perfect composure, which was her sense of what was proper. Densher added that Mrs. Stringham, regarding his delay, would have informed Mrs. Lowder that he'd left the area.

Translation

He, for his part, had his caution, while she possessed impeccable self-possession, which stemmed from her understanding of propriety. Densher added that Mrs. Stringham, upon noticing his tardiness, would have notified Mrs. Lowder that he was no longer nearby.

So, it wasn't as if he was trying to deceive them. They knew he wasn't there anymore. "Yes, we've known it." "And you continue to hear?"

Translation

Thus, he wasn't attempting to mislead them. They were aware of his absence. "Yes, we've known." "And you're still informed?"

"From Mrs. Stringham? Certainly. By which I mean Aunt Maud does."

"So, you have any fresh news?" Her expression was filled with surprise. "Up to a day or two ago, I think. But you don't?"

There was nothing but for him to ask what he wanted. "Is Miss Theale alive?" Kate's look at this was large. "Don't you know?"

Translation

"I'm pretty sure Mrs. Lowder does, though." He followed up with, "So you already know, of course." He waited, assuming she would share whatever information she had. Instead, she simply displayed an undeniable, silent surprise. He had no other choice but to ask the direct question. "Is Miss Theale still alive?"

Kate's reaction to this was intense. "Don't you know?" "How should I, my dear—in the absence of everything?" And he himself stared as for light. "She's dead?" Then as with her eyes on him she slowly shook her head he uttered a strange "Not yet?"

Translation

Kate reacted with intensity. "Don't you know?" "How would I, my dear—in the absence of any information?" He stared, searching for some clarity. "She's dead?" Then, as she slowly shook her head while keeping her eyes on him, he uttered a strange "Not yet?"

It came out in Kate's face that there were several questions on her lips, but the one she presently put was: "Is it very terrible?" "The manner of her so consciously and helplessly dying?" He had to think a moment. "Well, yes—since you ask me: very terrible to me—so far as, before I came away, I had any sight of it. But I don't think," he went on, "that—though I'll try—I can quite tell you what it was, what it is, for me.

Translation

Kate's expression revealed several questions she wanted to ask, but the one she did ask was, "Is it very terrible?" "The way she died, so aware and helpless?" He paused to consider. "Well, yes—since you ask: very terrible, to me—as much as I saw before I left. But I don't think," he continued, "that—though I'll try—I can quite explain what it was, what it is, for me."

That's why I probably just sounded to you," he explained, "as if I hoped it might be over." "How can I possibly know, my dear—considering I have no information?" Translation

"That's probably why I sounded like I just wanted it to be over," he said.

"How can I know, my dear—considering I have no idea?" He seemed confused, looking for clarity.

It was evident from Kate's expression that she had several questions, but the one she asked was: "Is it awful?" "The way she's dying, so aware and helpless?" He paused to consider. Translation

Kate's face showed she had many questions, but the one she voiced was: "Is it awful?" "The way she's dying, so conscious and unable to do anything?" He stopped, thinking. "Yes, since you ask—it was awful for me, based on what I saw before I left. But I don't think," he added, "that I can fully explain it to you, though I'll try."

That's why I probably sounded," he explained, "like I was hoping it would be finished." She gave him her quietest attention, but he by this time saw that, so far as telling her all was concerned, she would be divided between the wish and the reluctance to hear it; between the curiosity that, not unnaturally, would consume her and the opposing scruple of a respect for misfortune. The more she studied him too—and he had never so felt her closely attached to his face—the more the choice of an attitude would become impossible to her. There would simply be a feeling uppermost, and the feeling wouldn't be eagerness.

Translation

"That's probably why I sounded like I wanted it to be over," he said. She listened closely, and he could see that she was torn about hearing everything. She was split between wanting to know and not wanting to. The curiosity would naturally eat away at her, but there would also be a hesitation born of respect for the suffering. The more she studied him—and he'd never felt her so focused on his face—the more difficult it would become for her to decide how to react. A single feeling would dominate, and it wouldn't be eagerness.

This perception grew in him fast, and he even, with his imagination, had for a moment the quick forecast of her possibly breaking out at him, should he go too far, with a wonderful: "What horrors are you telling me?" It would have the sound—wouldn't it be open to him fairly to bring that out himself?—of a repudiation, for pity and almost for shame, of everything that in Venice had passed between them. Not that she would confess to any return upon herself; not that she would let compunction or horror give her away; but it was in the air for him—yes—that she wouldn't want details, that she positively wouldn't take them, and that, if he would generously understand it from her, she would prefer to keep him down. Nothing, however, was more definite for him than that at the same time he must remain down but so far as it suited him. Something rose strong within him against his not being free with her.

Translation

This sense quickly intensified, and he even momentarily envisioned her erupting at him, should he push too far, with a dramatic, "What horrors are you telling me?" It would sound—wouldn't it be permissible for him to elicit that response himself?—like a rejection, out of pity and almost embarrassment, of everything that had transpired between them in Venice. Not that she would admit to any self-recrimination, not that she would allow remorse or horror to betray her; but it was palpable to him—yes—that she wouldn't want details, that she absolutely wouldn't accept them, and that, if he were to understand her generously, she would prefer him to keep it subdued. However, nothing was more certain to him than that he must simultaneously remain subdued, but only to the degree that it suited him. Something within him surged powerfully against not being candid with her.

She had been free enough about it all, three months before, with him. That was what she was at present only in the sense of treating him handsomely. "I can believe," she said with perfect consideration, "how dreadful for you much of it must have been." She listened to him with her usual calm attentiveness, but he realized that when it came to hearing everything, she'd be torn.

Translation

She'd been open enough about it all, three months prior, with him. In the present, she was only free in the sense that she was being kind to him. "I can imagine," she said, with perfect composure, "how dreadful much of it must have been for you." She listened to him with her usual calm attentiveness, but he knew that when it came to hearing everything, she would be conflicted.

She'd be caught between wanting to know and not wanting to know; between her natural curiosity and her hesitation to pry into someone's misfortune. Also, the more she studied him—and he'd never felt her gaze so intently on him—the harder it would become for her to know how to respond. A single overriding emotion would dominate, and that emotion wouldn't be eagerness. This realization struck him quickly.

Translation

She'd be torn. Part of her would crave the details, and part of her would want to avoid them. Her inherent inquisitiveness would clash with her reluctance to dwell on his suffering. Moreover, the closer she examined him—and he'd never felt so scrutinized—the more uncertain she'd become about her reaction. One primary feeling would take over, and that feeling wouldn't be enthusiasm. This truth dawned on him swiftly.

He even imagined her possibly exclaiming, if he revealed too much, with a shocked: "What are you saying?" The way she said it—couldn't he, in a way, say it himself?—would sound like a rejection, motivated by pity and a sense of shame, of everything that had happened between them in Venice. Not that she would admit to regretting anything, or that she'd let guilt or horror betray her. But he sensed that she wouldn't want the details, that she wouldn't accept them. If he could understand her wishes, she'd prefer him to keep quiet.

Translation

He could picture her reacting with a horrified, "What are you saying?" If he went too far, he thought, that's what she might say. And the way she said it—wasn't it the same way he might say it himself?—would be a rejection, driven by pity and embarrassment, of everything they’d shared in Venice. Not that she'd confess to regrets, or let guilt or revulsion show. But he felt she wouldn't want the details, that she wouldn't accept them. If he knew what she wanted, he'd stay silent.

Nevertheless, he was certain that he had to remain reserved, but only as much as he wanted to be. Something within him resisted not being open with her. She'd been quite open about everything with him, three months earlier. That openness was only evident now in the form of her gracious treatment of him.

Translation

Still, he knew he had to keep things to himself, but only to the degree he desired. Something inside him rebelled against keeping secrets from her. She had been completely candid with him, three months before. That openness was now manifested solely in her kindness toward him.

"I can imagine," she said with thoughtful sympathy, "how awful much of this must have been for you." He didn't however take this up; there were things about which he wished first to be clear. Stringham's news is "real", then what do you think of Lord Mark's? She didn't think anything. "Lord Mark's?" "I believe she is," Kate said.

Translation

They stared at each other for a long moment. Then, rather unexpectedly, he said, "Oh, you don't know!"

"I understand. You would have known. You did know." "Of course I knew."

Translation

"I see. You would have figured it out. You did, didn't you?" "Naturally, I knew."

Another pause ensued. Densher eventually broke it. "If you don't think Mrs. Stringham's news is 'true,' what do you make of Lord Mark's?"

Translation

Another pause followed. Densher was the one to break it, eventually. "If you don't think Mrs. Stringham's news is 'true,' then what do you make of Lord Mark's?"

She didn't think anything. "Lord Mark's?" "You haven't seen him?" "Not since he saw her."

Translation

She had no opinion. "Lord Mark's?" "You haven't seen him?" "Not since he saw her."

Translation

Translation

"And have you known," Densher went on, "the rest?" Kate was curious. "What rest?" "Why, everything."

It was his visit that she couldn't stand—it was what then took place that simply killed her." "Oh!" Kate seriously breathed. But she had turned pale, and he saw that, whatever her degree of ignorance of these connexions, it wasn't put on. "Mrs.

Stringham?" he asked, "did she have, you mean, a bad

time?"

Stringham hasn't said that." He observed none the less that she didn't ask what had then taken place; and he went on with his contribution to her knowledge. "The way it affected her was that it made her give up. She has given up beyond all power to care again, and that's why she's dying."

Translation

She turned her face to the wall. “Poor Milly!” Kate said. Even the slightest gesture of hers was imbued with a certain elegance. She took another moment for thought. "It wasn't through anything you did—whatever that may have been—that she gained her certainty. It was by the conviction she got from me." He observed her reaction, which intensified her already serious beauty.

Translation

Even though it was understated, her beauty gave it a certain elegance. He went on, "She understood it all too fast, when we had wanted her to never realize it. Translation

"Her certainty didn't come from anything you did—whatever that was—it came from what she learned from me." "Oh, it's very generous of you to take your share!" Densher said. Her look and her tone made him, for a moment, regret his comment, which had, in fact, been the first thing that came out, a direct response to what they would have called, between themselves, her frankness.

Her straightness, visibly, was all his own loyalty could ask. Still, that was comparatively beside the mark. "Of course I don't suppose anything but that we're together in our recognitions, our responsibilities—whatever we choose to call them. It isn't a question for us of apportioning shares or distinguishing invidiously among such impressions as it was our idea to give."

Translation

Her integrity, it was plain to see, was everything his loyalty could want. Even so, that was almost beside the point. "Of course, I assume nothing except that we're united in what we understand, our obligations—whatever we want to call them. It's not a matter for us of dividing up portions or making unfair distinctions among the impressions we decided to create."

"Oh, that's very generous of you," Densher said, "to take your share!" "Do you think," Kate asked, "that I would ever deny it?" Her expression and voice made him immediately regret his remark. It was the first thing that came out of his mouth because of her honesty, as they would have called it.

Translation

"That's very gracious of you," Densher said, "to take your share."

"Do you think," Kate asked, "that I would ever deny it?"

Her expression and tone caused him to instantly regret what he'd said. It was the first thing that came out of his mouth because of her honesty, as they would have called it.

Translation

Her honesty was all the fidelity he needed. But that was beside the point. "Of course I don't think anything except that we agree on what we acknowledge, what we are answerable for—whatever we want to call it. "It wasn't your idea to give impressions," said Kate. He met this with a smile that he himself felt, in its strained character, as queer. "Don't go into that!" It was perhaps not as going into it that she had another idea—an idea born, she showed, of the vision he had just evoked.

Translation

"You didn't set out to create impressions," Kate said. A smile touched his face, a strained expression that struck even him as odd. "Let's not go there!" "Wouldn't it have been possible, then, to deny the truth of the information? I mean, regarding Lord Mark's." Densher wondered. "Possible for whom?"

"Why, for you." "To tell her he was lying?" "To tell her he was wrong." Densher stared, dumbfounded. The "possible" Kate had alluded to was precisely the option he'd had to confront in Venice, and ultimately reject.

Translation

"I mean that to convince you, I would have insisted or somehow proven—!" Kate seemed momentarily confused. "To convince 'me'?" "I wouldn't have denied it, under those circumstances, only to later take it back."

With this, understanding dawned on her quickly, and her face flushed. "Oh, you would have ended our relationship to make your denial true? You would have 'dumped' me"—she embraced the idea perfectly—"to protect your conscience?" "I couldn't have done anything else," said Merton Densher.

Translation

Realization came to her then, and her cheeks turned red. "You mean, you would have ended our relationship just to make your lie stick? You would have 'dumped' me"—she fully grasped the concept—"to ease your own mind?" "I would have had no other choice," Merton Densher said.

"So you see how right I was not to commit myself, and how little I could dream of it. If it ever again appears to you that I might have done so, remember what I say." Kate again considered, but not with the effect at once to which he pointed. "You've fallen in love with her."

Translation

"You see then why I was correct in not committing, and how impossible such a thing was. Should it ever seem again that I might have, remember what I've said." Kate thought it over once more, but without the immediate result he had hoped for. "You've fallen in love with her."

"Well then say so—with a dying woman. Why need you mind and what does it matter?" It came from him, the question, straight out of the intensity of relation and the face-to-face necessity into which, from the first, from his entering the room, they had found themselves thrown; but it gave them their most extraordinary moment. "Wait till she is dead!

Translation

Translation

"If you ever think again that I might have been involved, remember what I'm telling you." Kate considered this again, but not the way he anticipated. "You've fallen in love with her." "Alright, say it then—with a dying woman."

Why does it bother you, and what does it change?" The question came from him, right out of the depth of their connection and the unavoidable closeness they had been thrown into from the moment he entered the room; but it was their most remarkable moment. "Wait until she's dead! Mrs.

Translation

Why does it matter to you, and what difference does it make?" The question came from him, straight from the heart of their connection and the unavoidable intimacy they'd been thrust into from the moment he walked in; but it was their most significant moment. "Wait until she's dead! Mrs.

Stringham," Kate added, "is going to send a telegram." Then, in a different tone, she asked, "Why did Milly call for you?" "It was what I tried to make out before I went. I must tell you moreover that I had no doubt of its really being to give me, as you say, a chance. She believed, I suppose, that I might deny; and what, to my own mind, was before me in going to her was the certainty that she'd put me to my test.

Translation

"Mrs. Stringham is going to send a telegram," Kate added. Then, in a different tone, she asked, "Why did Milly call for you?" "It was what I tried to figure out before I left. I have to tell you, too, that I had no doubt she was really trying to give me, as you put it, a chance. I suppose she thought I might deny it. And what I knew I was facing when I went to her was the certainty that she’d put me to the test."

She wanted from my own lips—so I saw it—the truth. But I was with her for twenty minutes, and she never asked me for it." "She never wanted the truth"—Kate had a high headshake. "She wanted you.

Translation

"She wanted—I could see it—the truth from my own lips. But I was with her for twenty minutes, and she never asked me for it." Kate shook her head, lifting it high. "She never wanted the truth. She wanted you."

She would have taken from you what you could give her and been glad of it, even if she had known it false. You might have lied to her from pity, and she have seen you and felt you lie, and yet—since it was all for tenderness—she would have thanked you and blessed you and clung to you but the more. For that was your strength, my dear man—that she loves you with passion." That's what I was trying to figure out before I went to see her.

Translation

She would have taken from you whatever you were willing to give, and she would have been happy to receive it, even if she knew it wasn't true. You could have lied to her out of pity, and she would have known you were lying, she would have felt it, and yet—because it was all done out of tenderness—she would have thanked you and blessed you and clung to you even more. That was your power, my dear, the way she loves you with such passion." That's what I was trying to understand before I went to see her.

I should also tell you that I was certain she wanted to give me an opportunity, as you said. She probably thought I might deny it. For me, going to her meant I was certain she'd put me to the test. She wanted the truth from me personally, or so I believed.

Translation

I should add that I was sure she was giving me a chance, just as you said. She likely anticipated that I might refuse. Going to see her, I felt certain she'd put me through something of a trial. I thought she wanted the truth from me, specifically.

But I was with her for twenty minutes, and she never asked me for it. Kate shook her head emphatically, "She never wanted the truth. She wanted you. She would have gladly accepted whatever you gave her, even if she knew it was a lie.

Translation

But I was with her for twenty minutes, and she didn't ask me for it. Kate shook her head emphatically, "She never wanted the truth. She wanted you. She would have gladly taken whatever you offered, even if she knew it was a lie.

You could have lied to her out of pity, and she would have understood and felt you were lying, and yet, since it was all done out of tenderness, she would have thanked you, blessed you, and clung to you even more. That was your strength, my dear—she loves you passionately." "Oh my 'strength'!" Densher coldly murmured. "Otherwise, since she had sent for you, what was it to ask of you?" And then—quite without irony—as he waited a moment to say: "Was it just once more to look at you?"

Translation

You could have lied to her out of pity, and she would have known you were lying, and yet, since it was done with kindness, she would have thanked you, blessed you, and loved you even more. That was your strength, my dear—she loves you passionately." "Oh my 'strength'!" Densher said coldly. "Otherwise, since she had sent for you, what was it she wanted of you?" Then—without any irony—he paused a moment before asking: "Was it just to look at you one more time?"

"She had nothing to ask of me—nothing, that is, but not to stay any longer. She did to that extent want to see me. She had supposed at first—after he had been with her—that I had seen the propriety of taking myself off. Then since I hadn't—seeing my propriety as I did in another way—she found, days later, that I was still there.

Translation

"She didn't need anything from me—nothing, that is, except for me not to stay. She wanted to see me that much. At first—after he'd been with her—she'd assumed I'd understood that it was proper for me to leave. Then, because I hadn't—because I considered my own propriety differently—she realized, days later, that I was still there."

This," said Densher, "affected her." "Of course it affected her." Again she struck him, for all her dignity, as glib. "If it was somehow for her I was still staying, she wished that to end, she wished me to know how little there was need of it.

Translation

"This," Densher said,

"affected her." "Of course it affected her." Once again, for all her composure, she struck him as facile. "If the reason I was still here was somehow for her, she wanted that to end. She wanted me to understand how little it was needed."

And as a manner of farewell she wished herself to tell me so." "Oh, my so-called 'strength'," Densher said flatly. "So, since she asked for you, what exactly did she want from you?" And then—without a hint of sarcasm—he paused before adding, "Was it simply to look at you one more time?" "She had nothing to ask me—nothing, that is, except for me to leave.

Translation

"And as a way of saying goodbye, she wanted to tell me that."

"Oh, my so-called 'strength'," Densher said, his voice toneless. "So, since she asked for you, what exactly did she want from you?" Then, without a trace of sarcasm, he paused, adding, "Was it just to see you one last time?"

"She had nothing to ask me—nothing, that is, except for me to leave."

To that extent, she did want to see me. She'd assumed, at first—after he'd been with her—that I'd understand the proper thing to do was to leave. Then, since I didn't—since I saw my own reasons for staying—she realized, several days later, that I was still here. This," Densher explained, "bothered her."

Translation

To that degree, she did want to see me. She had thought, at first—after he had visited her—that I would understand that the proper thing to do was leave. Then, since I didn't—since I had my own reasons for staying—she realized, some days later, that I was still here. This, Densher explained, bothered her.

"Of course it bothered her." Again, despite her composure, she sounded too quick with her words. "If it was because of her that I was still here, she wanted that to stop; she wanted me to know how unnecessary it was. And as a final goodbye, she wanted to tell me so herself."

Translation

"Of course it bothered her." Even though she was composed, her words were too sharp. "If my presence was because of her, she wanted it to end; she wanted me to understand how pointless it was. And, as a final farewell, she wanted to tell me herself."

"And she did tell you so?" "Face-to-face, yes. Personally, as she desired." "And as you of course did."

Translation

"And she actually said that to you?"

"Yes, in person. Exactly as she wanted."

"And you, of course, went along with it."

"No, Kate," he returned with all their mutual consideration; "not as I did. I hadn't desired it in the least." "You only went to oblige her?" "To oblige her.

Translation

"No, Kate," he replied, using their shared understanding, "not like I did. I didn't want it, not at all." "You just did it to please her?" "To please her."

And of course also to oblige you." "Oh for myself certainly I'm glad." "'Glad'?"—he echoed vaguely the way it rang out. "I mean you did quite the right thing.

Translation

"And of course, also to do you a favor." "Oh, I'm certainly happy for myself." "'Happy'?"—he repeated, sounding slightly unsure of the word. "I mean, you did the right thing, completely."

You did it especially in having stayed. But that was all?" Kate went on. "That you mustn't wait?" "That was really all—and in perfect kindness."

Translation

You did the right thing, especially by staying. But that was it?” Kate continued. “You weren’t supposed to wait?” “That was really it—and done with perfect kindness.”

"Ah kindness naturally: from the moment she asked of you such a—well, such an effort. That you mustn't wait—that was the point," Kate added—"to see her die." "And she told you that directly?" "Yes, she did.

Translation

In person, as she wanted." "And you, of course, were willing." "No, Kate," he replied, mindful of their mutual understanding, "I wasn't. I didn't want to."

Translation

"Face to face, just as she wished." "And you, naturally, agreed." "No, Kate," he answered, remembering the terms they'd set, "I didn't. I didn't want to."

"You only went to make her happy?" "Yes. And of course, to make you happy as well." "Oh, I'm certainly happy for myself."

Translation

"So you only did it to please her?" "Yes. And, naturally, to please you, too." "Well, I'm certainly pleased for my own sake."

"'Happy'?" He repeated the word, puzzled by how it sounded. "I mean, you did the right thing. You did it especially by staying. But that was it?" Kate continued.

Translation

"'Happy'?" He repeated the word, clearly unsure of its meaning. "I mean, you acted correctly. You did it, above all, by staying. But that was all?" Kate pressed on.

"That you shouldn't wait?" "That was really it—and she was being perfectly kind." "Of course, kindness: From the moment she asked you for such a—well, such an effort. That you shouldn't wait—that was the main thing," Kate added—"to watch her die."

Translation

"That you shouldn't wait?" "That was the long and short of it—and she was being completely gracious." "Of course, graciousness: From the moment she asked you for such a—well, such an undertaking. That you shouldn't wait—that was the key," Kate added—"to watch her die."

"That was the point, my dear," Densher said. "And it took twenty minutes to make it?" He thought a little. "I didn't time it to a second.

Translation

"That was the whole idea, darling," Densher said. "And it took you twenty minutes to realize?" He considered it. "I didn't keep track of the time exactly."

I paid her the visit—just like another." "Like another person?" "Like another visit." "Oh!" said Kate.

Translation

I went to see her—it was just like any other time. "Like you would see someone else?" "Like any other visit." "Oh!" Kate said.

Which had apparently the effect of slightly arresting his speech—an arrest she took advantage of to continue; making with it indeed her nearest approach to an enquiry of the kind against which he had braced himself. "Did she receive you—in her condition—in her room?" "Not she," said Merton Densher. "She received me just as usual: in that glorious great salone, in the dress she always wears, from her inveterate corner of her sofa." And his face for the moment conveyed the scene, just as hers equally embraced it.

Translation

Which seemed to briefly interrupt his words—an interruption she seized upon to continue, in what was her closest approximation of the sort of question he'd been steeling himself against. "Did she see you—in her condition—in her room?" "No," said Merton Densher. "She received me exactly as she always does: in that magnificent great salon, in the dress she always wears, from her usual corner on the sofa." And his face, for a moment, evoked the scene, just as hers equally understood it.

"Do you remember what you originally said to me of her?" "That was the whole idea, darling," Densher said. "And it took twenty minutes to get to the point?" He paused, considering.

Translation

"Do you remember what you first told me about her?" "That was the whole plan, darling," Densher said. "And it took twenty minutes to get there?" He paused, considering.

"I didn't actually check the time. I just paid her a visit, like any other." "Like visiting anyone else?" "Like any other visit."

Translation

"I didn't really look at the clock. I just went to see her, like I would anyone." "Like you visit other people?" "Like any other visit."

"Oh!" Kate responded. This seemed to briefly stop him—a pause she used to keep going, edging towards the kind of question he'd been steeling himself against. "Did she meet with you—given her circumstances—in her own room?" "No," Merton Densher said.

Translation

"Oh!" Kate said. It seemed to make him stop for a moment—a pause she used to keep going, inching toward the question he'd been getting ready to answer. "Did she see you—under the circumstances—in her room?" "No," Merton Densher said.

Well, she didn't." "So that it was really almost happy?" It took him a long time to answer, occupied as he partly was in feeling how nobody but Kate could have invested such a question with the tone that was perfectly right. She meanwhile, however, patiently waited.

"Did she show any emotion? I mean," Kate clarified, "did she feel betrayed?" She didn't push him, certainly; but he had just said he would have preferred to avoid the subject. "She only showed her beauty and her strength."

If it had been only illness it would have made no difference with her." She didn't push him, certainly; but he'd just said he would have preferred things to be easy. "She only showed her beauty and her resilience." "So," his companion asked, "what good was her strength?"

Translation

"If it had been just the illness, it wouldn't have mattered to her." She didn't press him, that was for sure; but he'd just admitted he'd have liked things to be simple. "She only showed off her beauty and her toughness." "So," his friend inquired, "what was the point of her strength?"

He seemed to search for a use he could point out, but he gave up quickly. "She has to die, my dear, in her own unique way." "Of course. But I still don't understand how you can prove she was ever distant."

Translation

Translation

She shifted her focus to the tea table. Aunt Maud's massive silver kettle, left on the burner, hissed too loudly. She hadn't noticed it soon enough. "Well, isn't this something!" she exclaimed, pouring slightly too much tea into the pot. Her friend noticed the misstep. He watched her for a moment, approaching the table as she added the boiling water. "Care for some?"

He hesitated. "Hadn't we better wait—?" "For Aunt Maud?" She saw what he meant—the deprecation, by their old law, of betrayals of the intimate note. "Oh you needn't mind now.

He hesitated. "Shouldn't we wait—?" "For Aunt Maud?" She understood what he was getting at—that, according to their old code, you weren't supposed to betray intimacies. "Oh, it doesn't matter now."

Densher mechanically accepted his tea. He was thinking of something else, and his thought in a moment came out. "What a brute then I must be!" "A brute—?"

Densher took his tea without thinking. He was distracted, and his thought surfaced immediately. "What a terrible person I am, then!" "Terrible—?"

"Won her over. You've made her happy." Densher took his tea without really thinking about it. He was focused on something else, and his thoughts quickly surfaced.

"Then I must be a terrible person!"

"Terrible—?"

"To have pleased so many people."

Translation

"I don't get it—would you like some sugar?" "Yes, please." "What I can't figure out," she continued after handing him the sugar, "is what changed her mind. She turned you down for so long, so what convinced her to come back?"

She asked the question with her own cup in her hand, but it found him ready enough in spite of his sense of the ironic oddity of their going into it over the tea-table. "It was Sir Luke Strett who brought her back. His visit, his presence there did it." "He brought her back then to life."

Translation
