"Ah, and made her understand? I see," she went on as he said nothing. "But how did he convince her?" Densher put down his cup and turned away.

Translation

"Oh, and did you get her to see it your way? I understand," she continued, since he didn't respond. "But what did he say to change her mind?" Densher set down his cup and looked away.

"You must ask Sir Luke." He stood looking at the fire and there was a time without sound. "The great thing," Kate then resumed, "is that she's satisfied. Which," she continued, looking across at him, "is what I've worked for."

Translation

"You'll have to ask Sir Luke," he said. He stood there, staring into the fire, and a moment of silence passed. "The important thing," Kate continued, "is that she's happy. Which," she added, looking over at him, "is what I was aiming for."

"Satisfied to die in the flower of her youth?" "Well, at peace with you." "Oh 'peace'!" he murmured with his eyes on the fire. "The peace of having loved."

Translation

"Happy to die young?" "Well, at peace with you." "Oh, 'peace'!" he murmured, staring at the fire. "The peace of having loved."

"So you pleased him as well? Is that what it was?" "He understood," said Densher. "But understood what, exactly?"

Translation

"So you satisfied him, too? Is that it?" "He understood," Densher said. "But understood what, precisely?"

He paused. "That I had the best of intentions." "Oh, and you made her understand that? I see," she continued, as he didn't respond.

Translation

He hesitated. "That I meant well." "Oh, and you convinced her of that? I understand," she went on, since he offered no reply.

"But how did he manage to convince her?" Densher set down his cup and turned away. "You should ask Sir Luke." He stood, gazing at the fire, and a silent moment passed.

Translation

"But how did he pull it off, getting her to believe him?" Densher put his cup down and turned his head. "You ought to ask Sir Luke." He stood there, looking into the fire, and a quiet moment went by.

"The important thing," Kate resumed, "is that she's content. Which," she continued, looking at him, "is what I was aiming for." "Content to die while she's still young?" "Well, at peace with you."

Translation

"The main thing," Kate went on, "is that she's happy. And," she added, looking at him, "that's what I was hoping for." "Happy enough to die young?" "Well, at peace with you."

"Oh, 'peace'!" he muttered, eyes still on the fire. "The peace of having loved." He raised his eyes to her. "Is that peace?"

Translation

"Oh, 'peace'!" he muttered, his gaze still fixed on the fire. "The peace that comes from having loved." He lifted his eyes to meet hers. "Is that peace, really?"

"Of having been loved," she went on. "That is. Of having," she wound up, "realised her passion. She wanted nothing more.

Translation

"Of having been loved," she continued. "That's it. Of having," she concluded, "fulfilled her passion. She desired nothing else."

She has had all she wanted." Lucid and always grave, she gave this out with a beautiful authority that he could for the time meet with no words. He could only again look at her, though with the sense in so doing that he made her more than he intended take his silence for assent. Quite indeed as if she did so take it she quitted the table and came to the fire.

Translation

"She has had everything she ever desired." Clear-headed and consistently serious, she stated this with a captivating confidence that left him speechless. He could only look at her again, though with the feeling that in doing so, he allowed her to misinterpret his silence as agreement. And it was as if she did precisely that, leaving the table and approaching the fireplace.

"You may think it hideous that I should now, that I should yet"—she made a point of the word—"pretend to draw conclusions. But we've not failed." He looked up at her. "Is that peace?"

Translation

"You might find it appalling, the fact that I would, that I still would," she emphasized the word, "claim to have reached conclusions. But we haven't failed." He looked up at her. "Is that peace?"

"It's from having been loved," she continued. "That is. From having," she concluded, "lived her passion. She desired nothing more.

Translation

"It comes from having been loved," she continued. "That's it. From having," she concluded, "lived her passion. She desired nothing more."

She had everything she wanted." Clear and always serious, she delivered this with a beautiful conviction that left him speechless. He could only look at her again, though he felt his silence might be mistaken for agreement. She seemed to take it that way, because she left the table and went to the fireplace.

Translation

"She possessed everything she ever wanted." Her tone was clear and perpetually earnest, and she stated this with a captivating certainty that rendered him mute. He could only continue to gaze at her, despite the sensation that his stillness might be misconstrued as assent. She appeared to interpret it in that manner, for she departed the table and approached the hearth.

"You might find it awful that I should now, that I should still"—she emphasized the word—"pretend to draw conclusions. But we haven't failed." "Oh!" he only again murmured. She was once more close to him, close as she had been the day she came to him in Venice, the quickly returning memory of which intensified and enriched the fact.

Translation

"You might think it terrible that I'm, that I'm still"—she stressed the word—"pretending to draw conclusions. But we haven't failed." "Oh!" he could only murmur again. She was near him once more, as close as she had been the day she came to him in Venice, the quickly returning memory of which intensified and enriched the present.

He could practically deny in such conditions nothing that she said, and what she said was, with it, visibly, a fruit of that knowledge. "We've succeeded." She spoke with her eyes deep in his own. "She won't have loved you for nothing." It made him wince, but she insisted. "And you won't have loved me."

Translation

He could hardly disagree with anything she said in this situation, and what she was saying was clearly a product of that knowledge. "We've succeeded." Her gaze was locked onto his. "She won't have loved you for nothing." He flinched, but she pressed on. "And you won't have loved me."

Chapter 19

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
On Christmas Eve, something happens to a man in his apartment. After staying awake all night thinking about it, he becomes determined. On Christmas morning, he bathes, has breakfast, dresses more formally than usual, and goes out. He walks to Sir Luke Strett's house. When he arrives, he sees a brougham (a carriage) parked outside, which causes him to stop. He recognizes the coachman and realizes the carriage belongs to Mrs. Lowder. He approaches the carriage window and sees Lord Mark, a man he recognizes from Venice, sitting inside. The two men exchange a look of recognition. The man turns away, walks up the steps of the house, and rings the bell. Mrs. Lowder opens the door and dismisses the butler. On the steps, she and the man, Densher, confirm they have both received news of a death. Mrs. Lowder says her news came late the previous night and invites Densher to dine with her that evening. He asks if she will be alone, without Kate Croy. Mrs. Lowder explains that Kate left her house the day before to be with her sister in Chelsea because their father has shown up, causing a crisis. After the conversation, Mrs. Lowder gets into the brougham with Lord Mark, and it drives away. Densher tells her he might come to dinner. When she asks if he is going to church, he says yes and turns away. He walks south, deciding to follow Kate. He then stops, realizing he lied about going to church. Noticing he is near the Brompton Oratory, he walks to it and goes inside as a service is beginning.
The hinges were the problem, of course. They were old, rusted shut, and stubbornly attached to the frame. He tried the screwdriver, then the crowbar. He sweated, grunted, swore under his breath. The metal didn’t budge. She watched him, her face illuminated by the weak beam of the flashlight, the shadows dancing across the walls. He felt her gaze, the unspoken question. He took a step back, breathing heavily. "We'll need something stronger." She didn't speak, just handed him the sledgehammer. It was heavy in his hands. He raised it, and brought it down on the door. The wood splintered, the sound echoing through the house. He swung again, and again, until the door gave way, collapsing inwards in a shower of dust and debris. They stood there, side-by-side, in the doorway, staring at the destruction. The air was thick with the smell of old wood and something else, something metallic and sharp. "Now what?" she asked, her voice barely a whisper. He looked at her. Her eyes were wide, reflecting the faint light from the moon that spilled through the broken opening. He didn't know.

He was to remain for several days under the deep impression of this inclusive passage, so luckily prolonged from moment to moment, but interrupted at its climax, as may be said, by the entrance of Aunt Maud, who found them standing together near the fire. The bearings of the colloquy, however, sharp as they were, were less sharp to his intelligence, strangely enough, than those of a talk with Mrs. Lowder alone for which she soon gave him—or for which perhaps rather Kate gave him—full occasion. What had happened on her at last joining them was to conduce, he could immediately see, to her desiring to have him to herself.

Translation

He would dwell on that extended conversation for days, experiencing a deep and lasting effect. The conversation, which seemed to stretch on indefinitely, was cut short, so to speak, by the arrival of Aunt Maud, who found them standing together near the fireplace. Despite the clear significance of their discussion, it held less meaning for him, surprisingly, than a subsequent conversation with Mrs. Lowder alone. An opportunity for this meeting was quickly provided, whether by Mrs. Lowder herself or, perhaps, by Kate. He immediately understood that Kate's eventual arrival meant she wanted to speak with him privately.

Kate and he, no doubt, at the opening of the door, had fallen apart with a certain suddenness, so that she had turned her hard fine eyes from one to the other; but the effect of this lost itself, to his mind, the next minute, in the effect of his companion's rare alertness. She instantly spoke to her aunt of what had first been uppermost for herself, inviting her thereby intimately to join them, and doing it the more happily also, no doubt, because the fact she resentfully named gave her ample support. "Had you quite understood, my dear, that it's full three weeks—?" And she effaced herself as if to leave Mrs. Lowder to deal from her own point of view with this extravagance.

Translation

No doubt, as the door opened, Kate and he had separated with a certain abruptness, causing her to shift her sharp, refined gaze from one to the other. However, this moment’s impact faded quickly in his mind, overtaken by the effect of his companion’s uncommon attentiveness. She immediately addressed her aunt, speaking of the matter that was foremost in her own thoughts, inviting her warmly to join them. She did this all the more readily, undoubtedly, because the thing she resentfully mentioned provided her with ample justification. "Did you fully understand, my dear, that it’s been a full three weeks—?" And with that, she withdrew, as if to allow Mrs. Lowder to address the situation from her own perspective.

Densher of course straightway noted that his cue for the protection of Kate was to make, no less, all of it he could; and their tracks, as he might have said, were fairly covered by the time their hostess had taken afresh, on his renewed admission, the measure of his scant eagerness. Kate had moved away as if no great showing were needed for her personal situation to be seen as delicate. She had been entertaining their visitor on her aunt's behalf—a visitor she had been at one time suspected of favouring too much and who had now come back to them as the stricken suitor of another person. It wasn't that the fate of the other person, her exquisite friend, didn't, in its tragic turn, also concern herself: it was only that her acceptance of Mr.

Translation

Densher, of course, immediately realized that his role in protecting Kate was to exploit the situation fully. Their actions, as he might have put it, were essentially concealed by the time their hostess, upon his renewed introduction, had gauged his lukewarm enthusiasm. Kate had distanced herself, as if her personal situation was perceived as delicate without requiring an elaborate display. She had been entertaining their visitor on her aunt's behalf—a visitor whom she was once suspected of favoring too much, and who had now returned to them as the heartbroken suitor of someone else. It wasn't that the fate of the other person, her exquisite friend, didn't also concern her in its tragic turn; it was only that her acceptance of Mr.

Densher as a source of information could scarcely help having an awkwardness. She invented the awkwardness under Densher's eyes, and he marvelled on his side at the instant creation. It served her as the fine cloud that hangs about a goddess in an epic, and the young man was but vaguely to know at what point of the rest of his visit she had, for consideration, melted into it and out of sight. "Oh!" he just murmured again.

Translation

Densher's role as a source of information was inherently awkward. She fabricated that awkwardness right in front of Densher, who was astonished by its instantaneous nature. It functioned for her like the ethereal cloud surrounding a goddess in an epic poem, and the young man would only vaguely understand when during the remainder of his visit she had, thoughtfully, dissolved into it, becoming invisible. "Oh!" he just murmured again.

She was near him again, as close as she had been the day she came to him in Venice. That memory returned quickly, intensifying and enriching the present moment. He could practically refuse nothing she said in these circumstances, and what she said was clearly a result of that knowledge. "We've succeeded." Her eyes met his, intense.

Translation

She was near him again, as close as she had been the day she'd come to him in Venice. That memory returned quickly, intensifying and enriching the present moment. He could practically refuse nothing she said in these circumstances, and what she said was clearly a result of that knowledge. "We've succeeded." Her eyes met his, intense.

"She won't have loved you for nothing." It made him wince, but she insisted. "And you won't have loved me." II He would remain for several days deeply affected by this complete conversation, so luckily prolonged from moment to moment, but interrupted at its peak, by the entrance of Aunt Maud, who found them standing together near the fireplace.

Translation

"She won't have loved you for nothing." The statement made him flinch, but she pressed on. "And you won't have loved me, either." He would spend days reeling from the complete conversation, so fortuitously drawn out, moment by moment, only to be cut short at its height by the appearance of Aunt Maud, who found them standing together near the fireplace.

The implications of their talk, however sharp, were surprisingly less clear to him than those of a conversation with Mrs. Lowder alone, which she soon arranged for him—or rather, perhaps, which Kate arranged for him. What had happened when she finally joined them was, he immediately realized, the reason she wanted to speak to him privately. When the door opened, Kate and he had probably moved apart with a certain suddenness, so that she had turned her hard, fine eyes from one to the other.

Translation

The ramifications of their discussion, however pointed, affected him less than the intricacies of a private meeting with Mrs. Lowder, which soon occurred. Perhaps, though, Kate orchestrated it. The instant she joined them, he understood why she needed to speak to him alone. When the door opened, he and Kate had likely separated abruptly, causing her to shift her sharp gaze between the two of them.

But this was overshadowed by the effect of his companion's rare alertness. She immediately spoke to her aunt about the thing that had been most important to her, inviting her to join them. She did this more happily because the fact she resentfully mentioned gave her strong support. "Did you fully understand, my dear, that it's been three full weeks—?" And she stepped aside, as if to let Mrs.

Translation

But this was overshadowed by the effect of his companion's unusual attentiveness. She immediately spoke to her aunt about the matter that had been most important to her, inviting her to join them. She did this with more pleasure, because the thing she'd resentfully mentioned gave her strong backing. "Did you fully understand, my dear, that it's been three full weeks—?" And she stepped aside, as if to let Mrs.

Lowder deal with this extravagance. Densher immediately noted that his role in protecting Kate was to make as much of it as he could. They covered their tracks, as he might have said, by the time their hostess had, on his renewed agreement, taken the measure of his slight enthusiasm. Kate had moved away as if her personal situation was delicate and needed no great display.

Translation

Lowder could now address this extravagance. Densher immediately realized that his job was to play up his part in protecting Kate. They covered their tracks, so to speak, as their hostess, with his renewed assent, took stock of his mild enthusiasm. Kate had moved away, as if her personal situation was a sensitive matter that didn’t require any dramatic performance.

She had been entertaining their visitor on her aunt's behalf—a visitor she had once been suspected of favoring too much, and who had now returned as the rejected suitor of another person. It wasn't that the fate of the other person, her exquisite friend, didn't also concern her in its tragic turn. It was only that her acceptance of Mr. Densher as a source of information was awkward.

Translation

She'd been keeping their guest occupied at her aunt's behest—the same guest she’d once been accused of favoring, who had since returned, spurned by another. It wasn’t that she was unmoved by the other person’s plight, her exquisite friend, and the tragic turn of events. It was simply that accepting Mr. Densher as a source of information was a delicate matter.

She invented the awkwardness before Densher's eyes, and he marveled at the instant creation. It served her like the fine cloud that surrounds a goddess in an epic, and the young man would only vaguely know at what point during the rest of his visit she had, for consideration, vanished into it. He was taken up promptly with another matter—the truth of the remarkable difference, neither more nor less, that the events of Venice had introduced into his relation with Aunt Maud and that these weeks of their separation had caused quite richly to ripen for him. She had not sat down to her tea-table before he felt himself on terms with her that were absolutely new, nor could she press on him a second cup without her seeming herself, and quite wittingly, so to define and establish them.

Translation

She conjured the awkwardness right in front of Densher, and he was amazed at how quickly it appeared. It enveloped her like the ethereal mist around a goddess in an epic poem, and the young man would only vaguely recall when during the rest of his visit she had, for consideration, disappeared into it. He was promptly occupied with something else—the truth of the significant shift, no more and no less, that the events in Venice had brought about in his relationship with Aunt Maud and that these weeks of separation had allowed to flourish. She hadn’t even sat down at the tea table before he felt their relationship was entirely new, nor could she offer him a second cup without it seeming as if she were, quite knowingly, defining and solidifying it.

She regretted, but she quite understood, that what was taking place had obliged him to hang off; they had—after hearing of him from poor Susan as gone—been hoping for an early sight of him; they would have been interested, naturally, in his arriving straight from the scene. Yet she needed no reminder that the scene precisely—by which she meant the tragedy that had so detained and absorbed him, the memory, the shadow, the sorrow of it—was what marked him for unsociability. She thus presented him to himself, as it were, in the guise in which she had now adopted him, and it was the element of truth in the character that he found himself, for his own part, adopting. She treated him as blighted and ravaged, as frustrate and already bereft; and for him to feel that this opened for him a new chapter of frankness with her he scarce had also to perceive how it smoothed his approaches to Kate.

Translation

She regretted it, but she completely understood that whatever was happening had forced him to delay. After hearing he was gone, according to poor Susan, they had been hoping to see him soon. Naturally, they would have been interested in him coming straight from the source. Yet, she didn't need to be reminded that the source itself—by which she meant the tragedy that had held him back and consumed him, the memory, the shadow, the sorrow of it—was what made him seem unsociable. She presented him to himself, in a way, in the form she had now assigned him. And it was the element of truth in that character that he found himself taking on, too. She treated him as if he was ruined and destroyed, as frustrated and already grieving. To feel that this opened a new era of honesty with her, he also barely needed to perceive how it eased his interactions with Kate.

It made the latter accessible as she hadn't yet begun to be; it set up for him at Lancaster Gate an association positively hostile to any other legend. It was quickly vivid to him that, were he minded, he could "work" this association: he had but to use the house freely for his prescribed attitude and he need hardly ever be out of it. Stranger than anything moreover was to be the way that by the end of a week he stood convicted to his own sense of a surrender to Mrs. Lowder's view.

Translation

It made Kate approachable in a way she hadn't been before; it established for him at Lancaster Gate a connection that was actively opposed to any other perception. It became immediately clear to him that, if he chose to, he could "exploit" this connection: he only needed to use the house freely to maintain his designated persona, and he would hardly ever need to leave it. Furthermore, the strangest thing was how, by the end of a week, he felt he'd been forced to submit to Mrs. Lowder's perspective.

He had somehow met it at a point that had brought him on—brought him on a distance that he couldn't again retrace. He had private hours of wondering what had become of his sincerity; he had others of simply reflecting that he had it all in use. His only want of candour was Aunt Maud's wealth of sentiment. She was hugely sentimental, and the worst he did was to take it from her.

Translation

He had somehow encountered this perspective at a point that advanced him, carrying him a distance he couldn't retrace. He spent private hours wondering what had happened to his sincerity, and others simply reflecting that he put it all to use. His only lack of candor concerned Aunt Maud's wealth of sentiment. She was profoundly sentimental, and the worst thing he did was to take it from her.

He wasn't so himself—everything was too real; but it was none the less not false that he had been through a mill. He immediately became preoccupied with something else: the stark difference that his experiences in Venice had created in his relationship with Aunt Maud. This separation of several weeks had allowed this difference to fully develop. He realized, almost as soon as they sat down to tea, that he was on entirely new terms with her.

Translation

He wasn't quite himself—everything felt too immediate; but it was nonetheless true that he'd been through a lot. He immediately became absorbed by something else: the sharp difference his time in Venice had created in his relationship with Aunt Maud. This separation of several weeks had given this difference a chance to fully develop. He realized, almost as soon as they sat down to tea, that he was on entirely new terms with her.

When she offered him a second cup, it was as if she consciously defined and solidified these terms. She regretted, but understood, that his recent experiences had forced him to withdraw. After hearing that he had left, they'd hoped to see him soon. They would have been interested to hear about his journey from the scene itself.

Translation

When she offered him a second cup, it was as if she consciously defined and solidified these terms. She regretted, but understood, that his recent experiences had forced him to withdraw. After hearing that he had left, they'd hoped to see him soon. They would have been interested to hear about his journey from the scene itself.

However, she knew that the scene—the tragedy that had held him captive, the memory, the shadow, the sorrow—was precisely what made him seem withdrawn. She was now presenting him to himself in a way that he was beginning to adopt. She saw him as devastated, wounded, frustrated, and already in mourning. He realized that this opened a new chapter of honesty with her.

Translation

Yet, she understood that the event—the tragedy that held him, the memory, the shadow, the grief—was the very thing that kept him distant. She was now showing him a version of himself that he was starting to accept. She saw him as broken, hurt, angry, and already grieving. He understood that this marked a new stage of honesty between them.

He also saw how it smoothed his path to Kate. It made Kate more approachable than she had been before. It established an atmosphere at Lancaster Gate that was hostile to any other kind of narrative. He quickly realized that he could "work" this situation if he chose.

Translation

He also realized how it cleared the way for him with Kate. It made her easier to reach than she had been. It fostered an environment at Lancaster Gate that was unwelcoming to any other kind of story. He understood immediately that he could exploit the situation if he wanted to.

He could use the house as a stage for his prescribed persona and hardly ever need to leave it. Even stranger was the way he found himself, by the end of the week, accepting Mrs. Lowder's perspective. Somehow, he had embraced it and advanced, moving to a point he could not undo.

Translation

He could use the house as a stage, performing the role he’d chosen for himself, and rarely have to go anywhere else. Even stranger was how, by the end of the week, he had begun to share Mrs. Lowder’s point of view. Somehow, he had come to accept it, and in doing so, he had moved forward in a way he couldn't take back.

He had private moments of wondering what had happened to his sincerity, and others of simply reflecting that he was taking advantage of the situation. His only lack of honesty stemmed from Aunt Maud's abundant sentimentality. She was overwhelmingly sentimental, and the worst thing he did was accept it from her. He wasn't like that himself—everything was too real.

Translation

He had private moments where he wondered what had become of his sincerity, and other times when he simply reflected that he was exploiting the situation. His only dishonesty sprang from Aunt Maud’s overflowing sentimentality. She was excessively sentimental, and the worst thing he did was accept it from her. He wasn’t like that himself—everything was too real.

But it was nevertheless true that he had been through a great deal. It was in particular not false for instance that when she had said to him, on the Sunday, almost cosily, from her sofa behind the tea, "I want you not to doubt, you poor dear, that I'm with you to the end!" his meeting her halfway had been the only course open to him. She was with him to the end—or she might be—in a way Kate wasn't; and even if it literally made her society meanwhile more soothing he must just brush away the question of why it shouldn't. Was he professing to her in any degree the possession of an aftersense that wasn't real?

Translation

Yet, he had truly suffered. For example, when she said to him on Sunday, almost comfortingly from her sofa with tea, "I want you to know, my dear, that I'm with you to the end!" it wasn't a lie that his only option was to reciprocate. She was with him—or could be—in a way Kate wasn't. Even if her presence soothed him, he would have to ignore why it shouldn't. Was he falsely pretending to her that he had feelings he didn't?

How in the world could he, when his aftersense, day by day, was his greatest reality? Such only was at bottom what there was between them, and two or three times over it made the hour pass. These were occasions—two and a scrap—on which he had come and gone without mention of Kate. Now that almost as never yet he had licence to ask for her, the queer turn of their affair made it a false note.

Translation

How could he, when his afterthought, day by day, was his most real experience? This was essentially the core of their relationship, and it allowed the time to pass on a few occasions. These were times—two or three, maybe—when he'd come and gone without mentioning Kate. Now that he almost never had the opportunity to ask about her, the strange twist of their situation made it feel wrong.

It was another queer turn that when he talked with Aunt Maud about Milly nothing else seemed to come up. He called upon her almost avowedly for that purpose, and it was the queerest turn of all that the state of his nerves should require it. He liked her better; he was really behaving, he had occasion to say to himself, as if he liked her best. The thing was absolutely that she met him halfway.

Translation

It was another odd thing that when he spoke with Aunt Maud about Milly, nothing else ever came up. He visited her almost specifically for that reason, and the strangest part of it all was that his nerves required it. He enjoyed her company more; he was genuinely acting, he had to admit to himself, as if he liked her best. The essential truth was that she reciprocated.

Nothing could have been broader than her vision, than her loquacity, than her sympathy. It appeared to gratify, to satisfy her to see him as he was; that too had its effect. It was all of course the last thing that could have seemed on the cards, a change by which he was completely free with this lady; and it wouldn't indeed have come about if—for another monstrosity—he hadn't ceased to be free with Kate. Thus it was that on the third time in especial of being alone with her he found himself uttering to the elder woman what had been impossible of utterance to the younger.

Translation

Nothing could have been more expansive than her perspective, her volubility, her compassion. It seemed to give her pleasure, to fulfill her, to see him as he was; that, too, had its impact. This was, of course, the last thing that might have seemed likely, a shift in which he was entirely unreserved with this woman; and it wouldn't have happened if—for yet another strange turn of events—he hadn't stopped being unreserved with Kate. So it was that on the third occasion, in particular, of being alone with her, he found himself saying to the older woman what he'd never been able to say to the younger.

Mrs. Lowder gave him in fact, on the ground of what he must keep from her, but one uneasy moment. That was when, on the first Sunday, after Kate had suppressed herself, she referred to her regret that he mightn't have stayed to the end. He found his reason difficult to give her, but she came after all to his help.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder actually only made him uneasy once, given what he had to hide from her. That was the first Sunday, when Kate had kept quiet, and Mrs. Lowder expressed her regret that he hadn't stayed longer. He struggled to explain himself, but she ended up helping him out.

It was undoubtedly true that when she had told him on Sunday, almost comfortably, from her sofa with tea, "I want you to know, my dear, that I support you fully!" that his agreeing with her was his only option. She was with him fully—or she might be—in a way that Kate wasn't. Even if her company was more soothing, he had to ignore the question of why it shouldn't be. Was he pretending to her that he had hidden feelings that weren't real?

Translation

He certainly hadn't had a choice when she'd told him on Sunday, almost casually, from her sofa over tea, "I want you to know, darling, that I completely support you!" Agreeing was the only move he could make. She was with him, fully—or she could be—in a way that Kate wasn't. Even though her presence was more relaxing, he had to ignore the question of why it shouldn't be. Was he pretending to her that he had hidden feelings that didn't exist?

How could he, when his hidden feelings were his greatest reality? That's all that was truly between them, and it made the time pass two or three times. These were occasions—two and a bit—where he came and went without mentioning Kate. Now that he had permission to ask about her, the strange nature of their relationship felt wrong.

Translation

How could he pretend, when his hidden feelings were the most real thing about him? That was the only thing that truly connected them, and it made time go faster. There were a couple of times—a few, really—where he came and went without mentioning Kate. Now that he could ask about her, the strange nature of their relationship felt off-kilter.

It was another odd thing that when he spoke with Aunt Maud about Milly, nothing else came up. He practically announced that was why he was visiting, and it was the strangest thing of all that his nerves needed it. He liked her more; he was acting, he admitted to himself, as if he liked her best. The truth was that she met him halfway.

Translation

It was another strange thing: whenever he talked to Aunt Maud about Milly, nothing else ever came up. He practically announced that was the whole reason for his visit, and it was the strangest thing of all that his anxieties needed it. He liked her more; he was acting, he admitted to himself, as though he liked her best. The truth was, she met him halfway.

Nothing could have been more open than her outlook, her talkativeness, her sympathy. It seemed to please her to see him as he was; that had an effect too. It was the last thing he would have expected, a change where he was completely comfortable with this woman; and it wouldn't have happened if—in another strange turn—he hadn't stopped being comfortable with Kate. So, on the third time especially that he was alone with her, he found himself telling the older woman what he couldn't tell the younger.

Translation

Her openness, her loquacity, her empathy—nothing could have been more apparent. She appeared to take pleasure in seeing him as he was, which also had an impact. The shift, the ease he felt with this woman, was the last thing he would have anticipated; it wouldn’t have happened if—in another peculiar twist—he hadn't grown uncomfortable with Kate. Thus, particularly on their third private meeting, he found himself confiding in the older woman what he couldn't share with the younger.

Mrs. Lowder, because of what he had to keep from her, gave him only one uneasy moment. That was when, on the first Sunday, after Kate had stayed away, she said she was sorry he hadn't stayed until the end. He found it difficult to explain, but she helped him out after all.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder caused him only one moment of discomfort, given everything he had to conceal. It happened on the first Sunday, after Kate had left, when she told him she was sorry he hadn't stayed longer. He struggled to find an explanation, but she ultimately assisted him.

"You simply couldn't stand it?" "I simply couldn't stand it. Besides you see—!" But he paused. "Besides what?" He had been going to say more—then he saw dangers; luckily however she had again assisted him.

Translation

"You just couldn't bear it?" "I just couldn't bear it. Also, you see—!"

But he stopped. "Also what?" He'd been about to say more—then he saw the pitfalls; luckily though, she helped him out again.

"Besides—oh I know!—men haven't, in many relations, the courage of women." "They haven't the courage of women." "Kate or I would have stayed," she declared—"if we hadn't come away for the special reason that you so frankly appreciated." Densher had said nothing about his appreciation: hadn't his behaviour since the hour itself sufficiently shown it?

Translation

"Besides—oh, I know!—men don't, in many relationships, have the courage women do." "They don't have the courage women do." "Kate or I would have stayed," she declared—"if we hadn't left for the specific reason that you so openly admired." Densher hadn't said anything about his admiration: hadn't his actions since that moment made it clear enough?

But he presently said—he couldn't help going so far: "I don't doubt, certainly, that Miss Croy would have stayed." And he saw again into the bargain what a marvel was Susan Shepherd. She did nothing but protect him—she had done nothing but keep it up. In copious communication with the friend of her youth she had yet, it was plain, favoured this lady with nothing that compromised him. Milly's act of renouncement she had described but as a change for the worse; she had mentioned Lord Mark's descent, as even without her it might be known, so that she mustn't appear to conceal it; but she had suppressed explanations and connexions, and indeed, for all he knew, blessed Puritan soul, had invented commendable fictions.

Translation

But presently he said—he couldn't help pushing it that far: "I don't doubt, certainly, that Miss Croy would have stayed." And he saw again, in addition, what a marvel Susan Shepherd was. She did nothing but protect him—she had done nothing but keep it up. In her ample communication with her childhood friend, it was still plain that she hadn't shared anything with this lady that would compromise him. She had described Milly's renunciation only as a turn for the worse; she had mentioned Lord Mark's social decline, since even without her it might be known, so that she wouldn't appear to be concealing it; but she had suppressed explanations and relationships, and in fact, for all he knew, that blessed, puritanical soul had invented commendable lies.

Thus it was absolutely that he was at his ease. Thus it was that, shaking for ever, in the unrest that didn't drop, his crossed leg, he leaned back in deep yellow satin chairs and took such comfort as came. She asked, it was true, Aunt Maud, questions that Kate hadn't; but this was just the difference, that from her he positively liked them. He had taken with himself on leaving Venice the resolution to regard Milly as already dead to him—that being for his spirit the only thinkable way to pass the time of waiting.

Translation

Thus, he was completely at ease. Thus, forever shaking, with the unease that never subsided, his crossed leg, he leaned back in deep yellow satin chairs and took whatever comfort he could. She, Aunt Maud, did ask questions that Kate hadn't; but this was precisely the difference—he positively enjoyed them. He had resolved, upon leaving Venice, to consider Milly as already dead to him, this being, for his peace of mind, the only conceivable way to pass the waiting period.

He had left her because it was what suited her, and it wasn't for him to go, as they said in America, behind this; which imposed on him but the sharper need to arrange himself with his interval. Suspense was the ugliest ache to him, and he would have nothing to do with it; the last thing he wished was to be unconscious of her—what he wished to ignore was her own consciousness, tortured, for all he knew, crucified by its pain. Knowingly to hang about in London while the pain went on—what would that do but make his days impossible? His scheme was accordingly to convince himself—and by some art about which he was vague—that the sense of waiting had passed.

Translation

He had left her because it was what she needed, and he wouldn't pursue, as they said in America, this; which only made him feel the need to arrange himself with his time apart even more intensely. Suspense caused him the most discomfort, and he wanted nothing to do with it; the last thing he wanted was to be unaware of her—what he wanted to ignore was her own consciousness, tormented, for all he knew, crucified by its pain. Purposefully lingering in London while her pain continued—wouldn't that just make his days unbearable? His plan, therefore, was to convince himself—and in some way he wasn't sure of—that the feeling of waiting had passed.

"What in fact," he restlessly reflected, "have I any further to do with it? Let me assume the thing actually over—as it at any moment may be—and I become good again for something at least to somebody. I'm good, as it is, for nothing to anybody, least of all to her." He consequently tried, so far as shutting his eyes and stalking grimly about was a trial; but his plan was carried out, it may well be guessed, neither with marked success nor with marked consistency. The days, whether lapsing or lingering, were a stiff reality; the suppression of anxiety was a thin idea; the taste of life itself was the taste of suspense.

Translation

"What, in fact," he reflected restlessly, "do I have to do with any of this anymore? Let me assume it's actually over—as it could be at any moment—and then I can at least be good for something, to someone. As it is, I'm good for nothing, to anyone, and least of all to her." He consequently tried, to the extent that shutting his eyes and pacing grimly could be considered a trial. But his plan was carried out, as one might guess, neither with notable success nor with consistent follow-through. The days, whether they sped by or dragged, were a harsh reality; the suppression of anxiety was a flimsy concept; and the very taste of life was the taste of suspense.

That he was waiting was in short at the bottom of everything; and it required no great sifting presently to feel that if he took so much more, as he called it, to Mrs. Lowder this was just for that reason. "You simply couldn't handle it?" "I simply couldn't handle it.

Translation

The fact that he was waiting was, in essence, the root of it all. It didn't take much reflection to understand that if he were to exert himself further, as he put it, for Mrs. Lowder, it would be precisely because of his waiting. "You just couldn't deal with it?" "I just couldn't deal with it."

Besides, you see—!" But he stopped. "Besides what?" He'd been about to say more—then he saw the potential problems; luckily, however, she had helped

Translation

Besides, you see—!" But he stopped. "Besides what?" He'd been about to say more—then he saw the potential problems; luckily, however, she had helped.

him out again. "Besides—oh, I get it!—men don't have the courage of women in many relationships." "They don't have the courage of women."

Translation

He let him off the hook again. "Besides—oh, I see!—men often lack women's courage in relationships." "They don't have the courage of women."

"Kate or I would have stayed," she declared—"if we hadn't left for the specific reason that you understood so well." Densher hadn't said anything about understanding:

Translation

"Kate or I would have stayed," she declared, "if we hadn't left for the very reason you understood so well." Densher hadn't said a word about understanding:

hadn't his actions since that moment shown it clearly enough? But he soon said—he couldn't help going that far: "I don't doubt, certainly, that Miss Croy would have stayed." And he understood, in addition, what a remarkable person Susan Shepherd was.

Translation

Hadn't his actions since then demonstrated his understanding? But he couldn't resist speaking, going so far as to say, "I have no doubt Miss Croy would have stayed." Furthermore, he realized what a remarkable person Susan Shepherd was.

She did nothing but protect him—she had done nothing but maintain the pretense. In abundant communication with the friend

Translation

She had only ever shielded him—she had only ever kept up the act. In extensive communication with her friend.

of her youth, she had, it was clear, not given this lady any information that would harm him. She had described Milly's act of giving up as a turn for the worse; she'd mentioned Lord Mark's sudden arrival, which

Translation

revealed his connection; and she had, as well, made reference to the young man's lack of money, all of this, in a manner, as the friend herself had put it, that was like the touch of a feather.

could be discovered without her assistance, ensuring she appeared transparent. However, she had omitted details and context, and for all he knew, this admirable, virtuous woman might have fabricated outright falsehoods.

It was precisely this that made him feel at ease. It was this that made him shake his leg constantly, unable to relax, and lean back in the deep yellow satin chairs, enjoying

He had decided when leaving Venice to consider Milly as already dead to him—that being the only way his mind could bear the wait. He had left her because it was what she wanted, and it wasn't his place to question it,

would it accomplish except make his own days unbearable? Therefore, his plan was to convince himself—and through some unknown means—that the sensation of waiting was over.

"What, actually," he thought restlessly, "do I have to do with any of it anymore? Let me assume it's over—as it could be at any moment—and I'll become useful
