was the taste of suspense. In short, his waiting was the underlying reason for everything; and it took no great effort to realize that if he was giving so much time to Mrs. Lowder, it was precisely for that reason. She helped him to hold out, all the while that she was subtle enough—and he could see her divine it as what he wanted—not to insist on the actuality of their tension.

Translation

was the taste of suspense. In short, his waiting was the underlying reason for everything; and it took no great effort to realize that if he was giving so much time to Mrs. Lowder, it was precisely for that reason. She helped him to hold out, all the while that she was subtle enough—and he could see her divine it as what he wanted—not to insist on the actuality of their tension.

His nearest approach to success was thus in being good for something to Aunt Maud, in default of any one better; her company eased his nerves even while they pretended together that they had seen their tragedy out. They spoke of the dying girl in the past tense; they said no worse of her than that she had been stupendous. On the other hand, however—and this was what wasn't for Densher pure peace—they insisted enough that stupendous was the word. It was the thing, this recognition, that kept him most quiet; he came to it with her repeatedly; talking about it against time and, in particular, we have noted, speaking of his supreme personal impression as he hadn't spoken to Kate.

Translation

His closest brush with success, therefore, was in being useful to Aunt Maud, in the absence of anyone better. Her presence soothed his nerves, even as they pretended together that they had endured their tragedy. They spoke of the dying girl in the past tense, saying nothing worse of her than that she had been stupendous. However—and this was what prevented pure peace for Densher—they maintained that stupendous was the key word. It was this shared understanding that kept him most subdued. He returned to it with her again and again, discussing it compulsively and, specifically, as we have seen, sharing his deepest personal impression as he had not done with Kate.

It was almost as if she herself enjoyed the perfection of the pathos; she sat there before the scene, as he couldn't help giving it out to her, very much as a stout citizen's wife might have sat, during a play that made people cry, in the pit or the family-circle. What most deeply stirred her was the way the poor girl must have wanted to live. She aided him in maintaining composure, and she was clever enough to understand—and he could tell she knew it was what he desired—not to dwell on the reality of their strain. His closest brush with success, therefore, was in being a benefit to Aunt Maud, since no one else was available.

Translation

It was almost as if she reveled in the perfection of the pathos. She sat before the scene, as he was compelled to present it to her, much like the wife of a portly citizen might sit in the pit or family circle during a play designed to make people weep. What moved her most was the way the poor girl must have wanted to live. She helped him stay composed, and she was clever enough to understand—and he knew she knew it was what he wanted—not to focus on the reality of their stress. His closest brush with success, therefore, was in being a benefit to Aunt Maud, since no one else was available.

Her presence calmed his nerves, even as they pretended together that they had endured their tragedy. They referred to the deceased girl in the past tense; they only said that she had been amazing. However—and this was what prevented Densher from complete peace—they did insist that "amazing" was the appropriate word. It was this acknowledgment that kept him the most subdued; he returned to it with her repeatedly, discussing it to pass the time and, as we've noted, focusing on his strongest personal feeling, as he hadn't done with Kate.

Translation

Her presence soothed his anxiety, even as they jointly feigned their survival of tragedy. They spoke of the dead girl in the past tense, saying only that she had been amazing. Yet—and this was what denied Densher true peace—they insisted "amazing" was the correct descriptor. This agreement held him most in check; he returned to it with her again and again, dissecting it to fill the hours, and, as we know, focusing on his most profound personal sentiment, as he had not done with Kate.

It was almost as if she reveled in the perfection of the sadness; she sat there before the scene, as he couldn't help but describe it to her, much as a common woman might sit, during a play that made people weep, in the cheaper seats. What moved her the most was how desperately the unfortunate girl must have wished to live. "Ah yes indeed—she did, she did: why in pity shouldn't she, with everything to fill her world? The mere money of her, the darling, if it isn't too disgusting at such a time to mention that—!"

Translation

It was nearly as if she took pleasure in the sadness's flawless quality. She sat there, confronting the scene—as he couldn't help but describe it to her—in the same way a woman of modest means might sit in the cheap seats during a play, reveling in the tears it drew. What affected her most was the unfortunate girl's desperate wish to go on living. "Oh yes, absolutely—she did, she did. Why shouldn't she, with the world brimming with possibilities? Even her money, the dear one, if it isn't too vulgar to bring that up now—!"

Aunt Maud mentioned it—and Densher quite understood—but as fairly giving poetry to the life Milly clung to: a view of the "might have been" before which the good lady was hushed anew to tears. She had had her own vision of these possibilities, and her own social use for them, and since Milly's spirit had been after all so at one with her about them, what was the cruelty of the event but a cruelty, of a sort, to herself? That came out when he named, as the horrible thing to know, the fact of their young friend's unapproachable terror of the end, keep it down though she would; coming out therefore often, since in so naming it he found the strangest of reliefs. He allowed it all its vividness, as if on the principle of his not at least spiritually shirking.

Translation

Aunt Maud brought it up—and Densher completely understood—as though she were giving a kind of poetry to the life Milly clung to: a vision of the "might have been," which left the good lady speechless, again in tears. She had her own vision of these possibilities, and her own use for them in social situations, and since Milly's spirit had been completely aligned with her on this, the cruelty of what happened was, in a way, cruelty to herself. That became clear when he described the horrible thing to know, their young friend's utter terror of the end, though she tried to hide it. It came out often, since in naming it he found the strangest relief. He let it have its full vividness, as if to show he wasn't, at least spiritually, shirking.

Milly had held with passion to her dream of a future, and she was separated from it, not shrieking indeed, but grimly, awfully silent, as one might imagine some noble young victim of the scaffold, in the French Revolution, separated at the prison-door from some object clutched for resistance. Densher, in a cold moment, so pictured the case for Mrs. Lowder, but no moment cold enough had yet come to make him so picture it to Kate. And it was the front so presented that had been, in Milly, heroic; presented with the highest heroism, Aunt Maud by this time knew, on the occasion of his taking leave of her.

Translation

Milly had passionately clung to her dream of a future, and she was cut off from it. Not screaming, certainly, but grimly, terribly silent, like a noble young victim of the guillotine in the French Revolution, separated at the prison door from some object they clutched for defiance. In a detached moment, Densher envisioned it this way for Mrs. Lowder, but no such moment had yet arrived to allow him to describe it so to Kate. And it was that stoic front that had been heroic in Milly, displayed with the utmost heroism, as Aunt Maud now understood, when he took his leave of her.

He had let her know, absolutely for the girl's glory, how he had been received on that occasion: with a positive effect—since she was indeed so perfectly the princess that Mrs. Stringham always called her—of princely state. Yes, indeed, she did. Why shouldn't she, with everything at her disposal?

Translation

He had told her, entirely for the girl's sake, how he had been welcomed on that occasion: with a definite impact—since she was, in fact, so perfectly the princess that Mrs. Stringham always called her—of regal dignity. Yes, indeed, she did. Why shouldn't she, with all the advantages she had?

The money alone, bless her heart—if it's not too crude to mention that at a time like this...!" Aunt Maud brought it up—and Densher understood perfectly—because it gave a kind of beauty to the life Milly had held onto. It was a vision of what might have been, a prospect that brought the good lady to tears again. She'd had her own ideas about those possibilities and how she could use them socially.

Translation

The money, God bless her soul—if it's not too blunt to bring that up now...!" Aunt Maud raised the subject—and Densher understood why, as it gave a certain beauty to Milly's life, the life she'd clung to. It was a vision of what could have been, a prospect that again brought the good woman to tears. She'd had her own ideas about those possibilities and how she could exploit them socially.

Since Milly had shared her views on these matters, wouldn't the tragedy feel like a personal blow? That feeling came out when he described the awful truth—the young woman's overwhelming fear of dying, which she struggled to hide. And so it came out often, since talking about it gave him a strange sense of relief. He let it all be as vivid as possible, as if he refused to shy away from it, at least in spirit.

Translation

Since Milly had expressed her opinions on these things, wouldn't the tragedy feel like a personal loss? That feeling emerged when he described the awful truth—the young woman's immense fear of dying, which she worked hard to conceal. And so it came up frequently, as discussing it brought him a strange sense of comfort. He let it all be as vivid as possible, as if he refused to avoid it, at least in his mind.

Milly had clung passionately to her dream of a future, and now she was separated from it, not screaming, but grimly, terribly silent, like a noble young victim of the French Revolution, separated at the prison door from something they desperately clutched for protection. Densher, in a detached moment, imagined it like that for Mrs. Lowder, but he hadn't reached a point where he could describe it to Kate in such terms. It was that brave facade Milly had put on that had been heroic, the highest form of heroism, as Aunt Maud now understood, after his final farewell.

Translation

Milly had clung desperately to the hope of a future, and now she was cut off from it. Not with a scream, but with a terrible, grim silence, like a noble young victim of the French Revolution, separated at the prison door from the thing they desperately clung to for protection. Densher, in a moment of detachment, imagined it like that for Mrs. Lowder, but he couldn't yet bring himself to describe it to Kate in those terms. The heroic act had been Milly’s brave front, the ultimate form of heroism, as Aunt Maud now understood it, after his final farewell.

He'd told her, purely to celebrate the girl's glory, how he'd been received on that occasion: with a regal dignity, since she was truly the princess Mrs. Stringham always called her. Before the fire in the great room that was all arabesques and cherubs, all gaiety and gilt, and that was warm at that hour too with a wealth of autumn sun, the state in question had been maintained and the situation—well, Densher said for the convenience of exquisite London gossip, sublime. The gossip—for it came to as much at Lancaster Gate—wasn't the less exquisite for his use of the silver veil, nor on the other hand was the veil, so touched, too much drawn aside.

Translation

He'd described to her, purely to honor the girl's triumph, how he'd been received on that day: with regal bearing, because she was genuinely the princess Mrs. Stringham always called her. Before the fire in the grand room filled with arabesques and cherubs, brimming with joy and gold, and also warmed at that hour by an abundance of autumn sunlight, the formality in question had been preserved, and the situation—well, Densher said for the sake of London gossip's delight, sublime. The gossip—since it came down to that at Lancaster Gate—was no less delightful for his use of the silver veil, and neither was the veil, so touched, drawn too far back.

He himself for that matter took in the scene again at moments as from the page of a book. He saw a young man far off and in a relation inconceivable, saw him hushed, passive, staying his breath, but half understanding, yet dimly conscious of something immense and holding himself painfully together not to lose it. The young man at these moments so seen was too distant and too strange for the right identity; and yet, outside, afterwards, it was his own face Densher had known. He had known then at the same time what the young man had been conscious of, and he was to measure after that, day by day, how little he had lost.

Translation

For his part, he sometimes took in the scene as if from a page. He saw a young man, distant and in an incomprehensible relationship, hushed, passive, holding his breath, only half understanding, yet dimly aware of something immense, painfully composed so as not to lose it. This young man, as seen in these moments, was too far away and too strange to be properly identified, and yet, later, in the outside world, it was his own face Densher knew. He understood then, at the same time, what the young man had been aware of, and he was to measure from then on, day by day, how little he had lost.

At present there with Mrs. Lowder he knew he had gathered all—that passed between them mutely as in the intervals of their associated gaze they exchanged looks of intelligence. This was as far as association could go, but it was far enough when she knew the essence. The essence was that something had happened to him too beautiful and too sacred to describe.

Translation

Presently, in the company of Mrs. Lowder, he realized he possessed everything—all that transpired between them unspoken, as their shared gazes met and they exchanged knowing glances. This was the limit of their connection, but it was sufficient, for she understood the core of it. The core was that something had occurred to him, too beautiful and too sacred to be put into words.

He had been, to his recovered sense, forgiven, dedicated, blessed; but this he couldn't coherently express. It would have required an explanation—fatal to Mrs. Lowder's faith in him—of the nature of Milly's wrong. So, as to the wonderful scene, they just stood at the door.

Translation

To his renewed understanding, he felt absolved, consecrated, favored. However, he couldn't articulate this clearly. To do so would have demanded an explanation of Milly's offense, an explanation that would have destroyed Mrs. Lowder's belief in him. Therefore, in regard to the extraordinary situation, they simply remained at the doorway.

They had the sense of the presence within—they felt the charged stillness; after which, their association deepened by it, they turned together away. Before the fireplace in the grand room, adorned with arabesques, cherubs, and gilded ornamentation, which radiated warmth from the autumn sunlight, a certain arrangement had been preserved. The situation was, as Densher put it, for the amusement of sophisticated London society, "sublime." The rumors—for that's what it amounted to at Lancaster Gate—weren't diminished by his veiled language. Nor, conversely, was the veil, though touched, fully removed.

Translation

They were aware of what was inside—they felt the charged quiet. Then, their relationship made stronger by it, they left together. In the ornate grand room, in front of the fireplace, decorated with arabesques, cherubs, and gold, which glowed warmly from the autumn sunlight, a particular scene had been maintained. The situation, as Densher said, for the enjoyment of high society London, was "sublime." The gossip—because that's what it was at Lancaster Gate—wasn't lessened by his vague words. And, similarly, the secrecy, though affected, wasn't fully gone.

At times, he viewed the scene as if it were a passage from a book. He observed a young man, distant and involved in an unimaginable way, quiet and still, holding his breath, only partially understanding, yet vaguely aware of something immense. The young man at those moments was too far away and unfamiliar to be clearly identified. However, afterward, it was his own face that Densher recognized.

Translation

Sometimes, he saw the scene as if it were a passage from a book. He watched a young man, detached and caught up in something unimaginable, silent and unmoving, holding his breath, only grasping a part of it, yet vaguely aware of something enormous. The young man at those moments was too distant and unknown to be clearly identified. But later, Densher recognized his own face.

He had understood what the young man was aware of and would later assess, day after day, how little he had forgotten. Now, with Mrs. Lowder, he felt that he had grasped everything—a silent understanding passed between them as they exchanged knowing glances. This was the extent of their shared understanding, but it was sufficient since she grasped the core.

Translation

He understood the young man’s awareness, and he would later reflect on how little of it he’d lost. In the present, with Mrs. Lowder, he felt a complete grasp, an unspoken understanding passing between them in shared, knowing looks. This was the limit of their shared understanding, but it was enough, since she grasped the essential.

The core was that something had happened to him that was too beautiful and sacred to articulate. He felt forgiven, dedicated, blessed; but he couldn't explain it. Doing so would have required a damaging disclosure to Mrs. Lowder about the nature of Milly's transgression.

Translation

The crux of the matter was that he'd experienced something too exquisite and hallowed to put into words. He felt absolved, consecrated, favored; yet he couldn't elucidate. To do so would have demanded that he reveal to Mrs. Lowder the specific offense Milly had committed, which would have been detrimental.

So, regarding the extraordinary scene, they simply stood in the doorway. They felt the presence inside, the charged silence; then, their connection deepened, and they turned away together. That itself indeed, for our restless friend, became by the end of a week the very principle of reaction: so that he woke up one morning with such a sense of having played a part as he needed self-respect to gainsay. He hadn't in the least stated at Lancaster Gate that, as a haunted man—a man haunted with a memory—he was harmless; but the degree to which Mrs.

Translation

Lowder had taken for granted his harmlessness was a thing he already measured and that, in a manner, was his current reason for existence.

Lowder accepted, admired and explained his new aspect laid upon him practically the weight of a declaration. What he hadn't in the least stated her own manner was perpetually stating; it was as haunted and harmless that she was constantly putting him down. There offered itself however to his purpose such an element as plain honesty, and he had embraced, by the time he dressed, his proper corrective. They were on the edge of Christmas, but Christmas this year was, as in the London of so many other years, disconcertingly mild; the still air was soft, the thick light was grey, the great town looked empty, and in the Park, where the grass was green, where the sheep browsed, where the birds multitudinously twittered, the straight walks lent themselves to slowness and the dim vistas to privacy.

Translation

Lowder accepted, admired, and explained that his new disposition, practically, carried the weight of a pronouncement. What he hadn't, in the least, articulated, her own behavior continually expressed; she was constantly belittling him, as though haunted and harmless. Still, plain honesty presented itself as an element he could use, and by the time he was dressed, he had embraced his own remedy. Christmas was approaching, but this year's, like so many other London Christmases, was unsettlingly mild; the air was still and soft, the thick light was grey, the great city looked deserted, and in the Park, where the grass was green, where sheep grazed, where the birds twittered in great numbers, the straight paths encouraged slowness and the dim views offered privacy.

He held it fast this morning till he had got out, his sacrifice to honour, and then went with it to the nearest post-office and fixed it fast in a telegram; thinking of it moreover as a sacrifice only because he had, for reasons, felt it as an effort. Its character of effort it would owe to Kate's expected resistance, not less probable than on the occasion of past appeals; which was precisely why he—perhaps innocently—made his telegram persuasive. It had, as a recall of tender hours, to be, for the young woman at the counter, a trifle cryptic; but there was a good deal of it in one way and another, representing as it did a rich impulse and costing him a couple of shillings. There was also a moment later on, that day, when, in the Park, as he measured watchfully one of their old alleys, he might have been supposed by a cynical critic to be reckoning his chance of getting his money back.

Translation

He clutched the telegram until he was outside, a sacrifice to principle. Then he went to the nearest post office and sent it, considering it a sacrifice solely because he had, for his own reasons, perceived it as a strain. That sense of effort was due to Kate's likely objections, no less likely than they had been in the past, which was precisely why he—perhaps innocently—made the telegram persuasive. As a reminder of cherished times, it needed to be slightly obscure to the woman behind the counter. But there was a lot to it, representing, as it did, a powerful impulse and costing him two shillings. There was a moment later that day, as he paced one of their old paths in the Park, when a cynical critic might have thought he was calculating his odds of recouping his investment.

He was waiting—but he had waited of old; Lancaster Gate as a danger was practically at hand—but she had risked that danger before. Besides it was smaller now, with the queer turn of their affair; in spite of which indeed he was graver as he lingered and looked out. For our restless friend, this situation became the very source of his rebellion after a week. He woke up one morning feeling like he had been acting, a feeling he needed to overcome to maintain his self-respect.

Translation

He was waiting—but he'd waited before. Lancaster Gate was practically a hazard, but she'd faced that hazard before. Besides, it was less so now, given the odd course of their relationship; despite which, he was in fact more serious as he lingered and looked out. For our restless friend, this situation became the very foundation of his rebellion a week later. He woke up one morning feeling like he'd been acting, a feeling he needed to overcome to preserve his self-respect.

He hadn't explicitly told anyone at Lancaster Gate that, as a man haunted by a memory, he was harmless. However, Mrs. Lowder's acceptance, admiration, and explanations of his new behavior essentially made it a public declaration. What he hadn't said, her behavior was constantly implying.

Translation

He hadn’t announced to anyone at Lancaster Gate that, as a man burdened by the past, he posed no threat. Nevertheless, Mrs. Lowder’s embrace, her praise, and the reasons she gave for his altered conduct amounted to a public proclamation. What he’d kept silent, her actions constantly suggested.

She was consistently treating him as someone haunted and harmless. Fortunately, he found plain honesty to be helpful. By the time he got dressed, he had adopted the correct course of action. Christmas was approaching, but like many other years in London, the weather was unusually mild.

Translation

She treated him as if he were a ghost, incapable of causing harm. Thankfully, straightforwardness was a relief. By the time he was ready, he’d decided on the proper approach. Christmas was near, but the weather in London remained, as it often did, unseasonably warm.

The air was still and soft, the light was dim and grey, and the city seemed empty. In the Park, where the grass was green, sheep were grazing, and birds were chirping, the straight paths encouraged slow pacing, and the dim views offered privacy. He clung to his plan this morning until he was outside, his tribute to his integrity, and then went to the nearest post office. There, he sealed it in a telegram, considering it a sacrifice only because it felt like an effort.

Translation

The air hung still and gentle, the light muted and grey, the city seeming deserted. In the Park, where the grass was green, sheep grazed, and birds chirped, the straight paths invited slow walks, and the obscured views offered privacy. He stuck to his plan that morning until he was outside, the outward sign of his integrity, and then he went to the nearest post office. There, he sealed it in a telegram, thinking of it as a sacrifice only because it felt like work.

Its feeling of effort came from Kate's expected resistance, which was as likely as it had been with his past requests. That was precisely why he made his telegram persuasive—perhaps even innocently so. As a reminder of their affectionate moments, the telegram had to be somewhat mysterious to the young woman at the counter. But it was quite long and conveyed a deep emotion, costing him two shillings.

Translation

The effort stemmed from Kate's anticipated reluctance, something he had faced with previous requests. That's why he crafted the telegram carefully, perhaps even deceptively. To the young woman behind the counter, it had to seem cryptic, a reference to their shared intimacy. But it was lengthy and full of feeling, setting him back two shillings.

Later that day, while in the Park, carefully walking along one of their old paths, a cynical observer might have thought he was calculating his chances of getting his money's worth. He was waiting—but he had waited before. Lancaster Gate, as a potential threat, was practically at hand—but she had faced that threat before. Besides, it seemed less significant now, given the strange twist their relationship had taken.

Translation

Later that day, strolling in the Park along one of their old paths, a cynical person might have imagined he was assessing his chances of getting a good return. He was waiting—but he’d waited before. Lancaster Gate, a potential obstacle, was nearly upon him—but she’d dealt with that before. Moreover, it appeared less important now, given the unusual direction their relationship had taken.

Despite this, he appeared more serious as he lingered and observed. Kate came at last by the way he had thought least likely, came as if she had started from the Marble Arch; but her advent was response—that was the great matter; response marked in her face and agreeable to him, even after Aunt Maud's responses, as nothing had been since his return to London. She had not, it was true, answered his wire, and he had begun to fear, as she was late, that with the instinct of what he might be again intending to press upon her she had decided—though not with ease—to deprive him of his chance. He would have of course, she knew, other chances, but she perhaps saw the present as offering her special danger.

Translation

Nonetheless, he seemed more focused as he stood there, watching. Kate finally arrived from the direction he’d least expected, as if she’d set out from Marble Arch. But her arrival was a reaction—that was the crucial thing. A reaction was evident in her expression, and it pleased him, even after Aunt Maud’s reactions, as nothing else had since his return to London. She hadn’t, it was true, responded to his telegram, and he’d begun to worry, as she was late, that with a sense of what he might again try to impose on her, she’d decided—though not without difficulty—to deny him the opportunity. He would, of course, she knew, have other opportunities, but perhaps she saw the present one as particularly threatening to her.

This, in fact, Densher could himself feel, was exactly why he had so prepared it, and he had rejoiced, even while he waited, in all that the conditions had to say to him of their simpler and better time. The shortest day of the year though it might be, it was, in the same place, by a whim of the weather, almost as much to their purpose as the days of sunny afternoons when they had taken their first trysts. This and that tree, within sight, on the grass, stretched bare boughs over the couple of chairs in which they had sat of old and in which—for they really could sit down again—they might recover the clearness of their prime. It was to all intents however this very reference that showed itself in Kate's face as, with her swift motion, she came toward him.

Translation

This, in fact, Densher could feel himself, was precisely why he’d arranged it like this, and he’d been pleased, even while waiting, with everything the circumstances revealed about their easier, better times. Even if it was the shortest day of the year, it was, due to the weather, almost as ideal for their purpose as the sunlit afternoons when they’d first met. This tree and that tree, within sight, on the grass, extended bare branches over the pair of chairs where they had once sat and in which—for they really could sit down again—they might regain the clarity of their early days. However, it was this very memory that appeared on Kate's face as she approached him, moving quickly.

It helped him, her swift motion, when it finally brought her nearer; helped him, for that matter, at first, if only by showing him afresh how terribly well she looked. It had been all along, he certainly remembered, a phenomenon of no rarity that he had felt her, at particular moments, handsomer than ever before; one of these for instance being still present to him as her entrance, under her aunt's eyes, at Lancaster Gate, the day of his dinner there after his return from America; and another her aspect on the same spot two Sundays ago—the light in which she struck the eyes he had brought back from Venice. In the course of a minute or two now he got, as he had got it the other times, his apprehension of the special stamp of the fortune of the moment. Kate finally arrived, taking the route he least expected.

Translation

Her quick movement assisted him when she finally drew closer. It helped him, for that matter, initially, if only by showing him anew how remarkably attractive she appeared. He clearly recalled that it had consistently been a frequent occurrence for him to find her more beautiful than ever at specific instances. One of these moments, for example, remained vivid in his memory—her entrance at Lancaster Gate, under her aunt’s gaze, on the day of his dinner there following his return from America; and another, her appearance in the same location just two Sundays prior—the light in which she struck the eyes he had brought back from Venice. Within a minute or two, he grasped, as he had grasped it those other times, his understanding of the unique character of the current situation. Kate arrived at last, taking the path he least anticipated.

It was as if she'd come from the Marble Arch. But her arrival was a response, and that was the crucial thing. Her reaction was visible and pleasing to him, even after Aunt Maud's responses. It was unlike anything he had experienced since his return to London.

Translation

She looked as if she’d emerged from the Marble Arch. However, her arrival was a response, and that was the essential point. Her reaction was evident and gratifying to him, even after Aunt Maud’s responses. It was unlike anything he’d encountered since returning to London.

She hadn't, it was true, replied to his telegram, and he had begun to worry, as she was late, that she, sensing what he might try to convince her of again, had decided—though with some difficulty—to deny him the opportunity. Of course, she knew he would have other chances, but perhaps she saw this moment as especially dangerous for her. Densher himself felt this was precisely why he had arranged it, and he had been delighted, even while waiting, by all that the circumstances reminded him of their happier, simpler past. It might be the shortest day of the year, but due to a quirk of the weather, it served their purpose almost as well as the sunny afternoons when they had first met.

Translation

It was true that she hadn't answered his telegram, and he'd started to worry, given her lateness, that she, intuiting what he might try to persuade her of again, had made up her mind—though with some reluctance—to refuse him the chance. Naturally, she knew he'd have other opportunities, but perhaps she saw this moment as particularly perilous for her. Densher himself felt this was exactly why he'd set it up, and he'd been pleased, even while waiting, by all the circumstances that recalled their happier, simpler past. It might be the shortest day of the year, but a trick of the weather meant it suited their purposes almost as well as the sunny afternoons when they'd first met.

Some trees on the lawn had bare branches visible above the two chairs where they'd once sat. They could sit there again, and in doing so, recover the clarity of their first connection. But this reference was also visible in Kate's face as she approached, moving quickly. Her speed assisted him, once she was closer. It helped him, at first, simply by showing him again how exceptionally beautiful she was.

He clearly remembered that he had often felt her to be more stunning than ever at certain times. One of these moments, for instance, was her entrance, under her aunt's gaze, at Lancaster Gate, the day of his dinner there after his return from America. Another was her appearance in the same place two Sundays ago—the way she looked to the eyes he had brought back from Venice. Within a minute or two, he understood, as he had understood those other times, the specific nature of this moment's significance.

Translation

He distinctly recalled how he'd often found her more breathtaking than ever before at specific points in time. One such instance, for example, was when she entered the room at Lancaster Gate, under her aunt's watchful eye, on the day of his dinner there after he'd returned from America. Another was her appearance in the same location just two Sundays prior—the way she looked to the eyes he'd brought back from Venice. In a minute or two, he grasped, just as he had in those other instances, the particular quality of this moment's importance.

Whatever it had been determined by as the different hours recurred to him, it took on at present a prompt connexion with an effect produced for him in truth more than once during the past week, only now much intensified. This effect he had already noted and named: it was that of the attitude assumed by his friend in the presence of the degree of response on his part to Mrs. Lowder's welcome which she couldn't possibly have failed to notice. She had noticed it, and she had beautifully shown him so; wearing in its honour the finest shade of studied serenity, a shade almost of gaiety over the workings of time.

Translation

Whatever had dictated it, as the various hours returned to him, now connected immediately to an effect he'd experienced more than once in the past week, only now it was greatly intensified. He had already identified and labeled this effect: it was the attitude his friend took when confronted with the degree of his response to Mrs. Lowder's welcome, something she couldn't have failed to notice. She had noticed it, and she had beautifully shown him so; honoring it with the finest shade of calculated composure, a shade that was almost jovial when considering the passage of time.

Everything of course was relative, with the shadow they were living under; but her condonation of the way in which he now, for confidence, distinguished Aunt Maud had almost the note of cheer. She had so by her own air consecrated the distinction, invidious in respect to herself though it might be; and nothing, really, more than this demonstration, could have given him had he still wanted it the measure of her superiority. It was doubtless for that matter this superiority alone that on the winter noon gave smooth decision to her step and charming courage to her eyes—a courage that deepened in them when he had presently got to what he did want. He had delayed after she had joined him not much more than long enough for him to say to her, drawing her hand into his arm and turning off where they had turned of old, that he wouldn't pretend he hadn't lately had moments of not quite believing he should ever again be so happy.

Translation

Everything was, of course, relative, considering the circumstances they were enduring. Her acceptance of his way of singling out Aunt Maud, for the sake of establishing trust, was almost a note of optimism. By her manner, she had validated the distinction, even if it put her at a disadvantage. Nothing, truly, could have given him a greater sense of her superiority, assuming he still needed it. It was, no doubt, this very superiority that lent her step its decisive grace and her eyes their charming resolve on that winter afternoon. This courage intensified when he eventually broached what he desired. After she joined him, he had lingered only long enough to draw her hand into his arm and turn them in the familiar direction, saying he wouldn’t pretend he hadn’t lately had moments where he doubted he'd ever be so happy again.

She answered, passing over the reasons, whatever they had been, of his doubt, that her own belief was in high happiness for them if they would only have patience; though nothing at the same time could be dearer than his idea for their walk. It was only make-believe of course, with what had taken place for them, that they couldn't meet at home; she spoke of their opportunities as suffering at no point. He had at any rate soon let her know that he wished the present one to suffer at none, and in a quiet spot, beneath a great wintry tree, he let his entreaty come sharp. Whatever the reasons, as he thought about the various times they had met, it now immediately connected to something that had happened to him more than once in the past week, and was now much stronger.

Translation

She replied, ignoring the basis for his doubt, whatever it might have been, and said that she believed they could be ecstatically happy if they were just patient. Even so, nothing could have been more important than the idea of their walk. It was, of course, a pretense, given what had transpired, that they couldn’t meet at home. She said their chances were never in jeopardy. He’d made it clear that he wanted this moment to be safe as well, and in a secluded place, under a massive winter tree, he made his request directly. Regardless of the reasons, as he thought about their previous meetings, it immediately triggered something that had happened to him more than once in the past week, and it was now much more intense.

He had already noticed and described this effect: it was his friend’s behavior when she saw how enthusiastically he responded to Mrs. Lowder's welcome, which she definitely couldn’t have missed. He'd already noted and commented on it: his friend’s reaction to his enthusiastic response to Mrs. Lowder’s greeting, which she couldn’t have failed to notice. She had seen it, and she'd shown him—exquisitely. She wore, acknowledging it, the most elegant kind of carefully cultivated serenity, bordering on joy, despite everything. She had, with her own manner, validated the distinction, even though it could be seen as unfair to her; and really, this demonstration, more than anything else, gave him the measure of her superiority, if he had still needed it. No doubt, it was this superiority alone that, on that winter afternoon, gave a smooth decisiveness to her step and a charming courage to her eyes—a courage that grew stronger when he finally got to what he wanted. Translation

She had, in her own way, confirmed the difference, even if it might have seemed unjust to her. And in truth, this display, more than anything, showed him how much better she was, if he’d needed any proof. Undoubtedly, it was this inherent superiority that, on that winter afternoon, gave her step its graceful certainty and her eyes their appealing boldness—a boldness that intensified when he finally got to the point. He had waited until she’d come over to him, then, taking her arm and turning toward their old route, he told her he wouldn’t pretend he hadn’t had moments, lately, when he’d doubted he would ever be this happy again. She responded, disregarding the causes, whatever they were, of his doubt, that she believed they would find great happiness if they were patient. Nonetheless, nothing could be more wonderful than his suggestion for their walk.

Of course, with what had happened to them, it was just pretense that they couldn't meet at home; she said their opportunities were not limited in any way. At any rate, he soon let her know that he wanted the present one to be undisturbed, and in a quiet spot, under a large winter tree, he made his urgent request. "We've played our dreadful game and we've lost. We owe it to ourselves, we owe it to our feeling for ourselves and for each other, not to wait another day.

Translation

Naturally, given their circumstances, it was merely a formality that they couldn’t meet at home; she insisted their options were limitless. Regardless, he quickly made it known that he wanted this particular moment to be free of interruption, and in a secluded space, beneath a towering winter tree, he made his earnest plea. “We’ve played our terrible game, and we’ve lost. We owe it to ourselves, we owe it to our feelings for ourselves and for each other, not to delay another day.”

Our marriage will—fundamentally, somehow, don't you see?—right everything that's wrong, and I can't express to you my impatience. We've only to announce it—and it takes off the weight." "To 'announce' it?" Kate asked. She spoke as if not understanding, though she had listened to him without confusion.

Translation

"Our marriage will—fundamentally, somehow, don't you see?—fix everything that’s wrong, and I can't express how impatient I am. We only have to announce it—and it removes the burden." "To 'announce' it?" Kate asked. She spoke as if she didn't understand, even though she’d been listening without any confusion.

"To accomplish it then—to-morrow if you will; do it and announce it as done. That's the least part of it—after it nothing will matter. We shall be so right," he said, "that we shall be strong; we shall only wonder at our past fear. It will seem an ugly madness.

Translation

"So, just get it done—tomorrow, if you want. Do it and announce it as finished. That's the easy part—after that, nothing else will matter. We'll be so good, he said, that we'll be strong; we'll only be surprised at how scared we were before. It will feel like a terrible delusion."

It will seem a bad dream." We've gone through this awful ordeal, and we've failed. We owe it to ourselves, to our sense of self-respect and our feelings for each other, to act immediately. This marriage will—somehow, fundamentally, don't you see?—fix everything that's broken, and I'm practically bursting with anticipation.

Translation

It will feel like a nightmare." We've endured this terrible trial, and we've lost. We owe it to ourselves, to our self-esteem and our affection for one another, to take action right away. All we have to do is announce it—and the burden will be lifted. "Announce it?" Kate asked. She spoke as though she hadn't understood, even though she'd listened to him without any difficulty. "Or, even better, just do it—tomorrow, if you like; just do it and then announce it as a done deal.

Translation

All we have to do is make the announcement, and the weight will be gone. "Announce it?" Kate asked. She sounded as though she hadn't understood, even though she'd followed everything he said. "Or, better yet, just do it—tomorrow, if you want; just do it, and then announce it as a fait accompli."

That's the easiest part—after that, nothing will matter. We'll be so completely in the right," he said, "that we'll be strong; we'll only marvel at the fear we once felt. It will seem like a terrible delusion. It will be like a bad dream."

Translation

That's the simplest step. After that, nothing else will be significant. We'll be so completely vindicated, he said, that we'll be strong. We'll only be astonished by the fear we once felt. It will seem like a terrible illusion. It will be like a nightmare.

She looked at him without flinching—with the look she had brought at his call; but he felt now the strange chill of her brightness. "My dear man, what has happened to you?" "Well, that I can bear it no longer. That's simply what has happened.

Translation

She looked at him without a flicker—with the expression she'd adopted when he summoned her; but now he felt the unsettling cold of her radiance. "My dear, what's become of you?" "Well, I can't take it anymore. That's simply what's happened."

Something has snapped, has broken in me, and here I am. It's as I am that you must have me." He saw her try for a time to appear to consider it; but he saw her also not consider it. Yet he saw her, felt her, further—he heard her, with her clear voice—try to be intensely kind with him.

Translation

Something inside me has come undone, shattered, and here I am. You'll have to take me as I am." He saw her try for a moment to feign consideration; but he also saw that she wasn't considering it. "I don't see, you know, what has changed." She had a large strange smile. "We've been going on together so well, and you suddenly desert me?" She met his gaze without hesitation—with the expression she'd worn when he summoned her. But now, he felt a peculiar coldness emanating from her radiance.

Translation

"I don't see, you know, what's changed." Her smile was broad and strange. "We've been doing so well together, and now you're abandoning me?" She met his eyes without flinching—with the same expression she'd had when he'd called for her. But now, he felt an unusual coldness radiating from her beauty.

"My dear, what's wrong?" "Well, I can't take it anymore. That's the simple truth. Something inside me has given way, shattered, and here I am.

Translation

"Darling, what is it?" "I can't do this anymore. It's as simple as that. Something inside me has broken, shattered, and here I am."

You'll have to accept me as I am." He watched her attempt to appear thoughtful for a moment, but he also saw that she wasn't truly considering it. Still, he perceived her, felt her, and even heard her clear voice trying to be exceedingly kind. "I don't understand, you know, what's changed." Her smile was broad and strange.

Translation

"You'll have to take me as I am." He saw her pretend to consider it for a second, but knew she wasn't. Yet he saw her, felt her, and heard the overly gentle tone of her voice. "I don't understand what's different." Her smile was wide and unsettling.

"We've been doing so well together, and now you're abandoning me?" It made him helplessly gaze. "You call it so 'well'? You've touches, upon my soul—!"

Translation

"We've been getting along so well, and now you're leaving me?" He couldn't help but stare. "You call this 'well'? You've laid hands upon my soul—!"

"I call it perfect—from my original point of view. I'm just where I was; and you must give me some better reason than you do, my dear, for your not being. It seems to me," she continued, "that we're only right as to what has been between us so long as we do wait. I don't think we wish to have behaved like fools." He took in while she talked her imperturbable consistency; which it was quietly, queerly hopeless to see her stand there and breathe into their mild remembering air.

Translation

"I call it perfect—from my perspective. I haven't changed at all. And you'll need to give me a better reason than you have, dear, for why you're not staying. It seems to me," she continued, "that things are only right as long as we're patient. I don't think we want to act foolishly." He took in her unchanging consistency as she spoke; it was quietly, strangely, hopeless to see her stand there, her words becoming part of their gentle shared memories.

He had brought her there to be moved, and she was only immoveable—which was not moreover, either, because she didn't understand. She understood everything, and things he refused to; and she had reasons, deep down, the sense of which nearly sickened him. She had too again most of all her strange significant smile. "Of course if it's that you really know something—?" It was quite conceivable and possible to her, he could see, that he did.

Translation

He had brought her there to be moved, and she was only unyielding—which wasn't, furthermore, because she didn't understand. She understood everything, and the things he refused to; and she had reasons, deep down, the sense of which nearly sickened him. She had, again most of all, her strange, significant smile. "Of course, if it's that you really know something—?" It was quite conceivable and possible to her, he could see, that he did.

But he didn't even know what she meant, and he only looked at her in gloom. His gloom however didn't upset her. "You do, I believe, only you've a delicacy about saying it. Your delicacy to me, my dear, is a scruple too much.

Translation

But he didn't even grasp her meaning, and he just stared at her dejectedly. However, his dejection didn't bother her. "You do know, I believe, only you're hesitant to say it. Your hesitancy toward me, my dear, is an excess of caution."

I should have no delicacy in hearing it, so that if you can tell me you know—" He couldn't help but stare at her. "You think it's 'well'? You truly do!"

Translation

"I should be fine with hearing it, so if you can just tell me you know…" He couldn't help but stare at her. "You think it's 'well'? You actually do!"

"I think it's perfect, considering my original perspective. I'm still where I was. You need to give me a better reason, darling, for you not being in the same place. I believe," she continued, "that our choices have been correct as long as we continue to wait.

Translation

"I think it's ideal, given my initial position. I haven't changed my mind. You need to convince me, darling, why you feel differently. I believe," she went on, "that we've made the right decisions as long as we keep waiting."

I don't think we want to have acted foolishly." While she spoke, he observed her unwavering consistency. It was quietly, oddly disheartening to witness her standing there, existing peacefully within their shared memories. He'd brought her there to be affected, and she remained completely unmoved, not because she didn't grasp the situation. She understood everything, including things he refused to acknowledge, and she had deep-seated reasons for her stance, the implications of which almost made him ill.

Translation

"We can't afford to be reckless," he thought. He watched her, seeing how steadfast she was. It was strange, and a little depressing, to see her so content, existing quietly within their past. He'd wanted to shake her, to make her feel something. She showed no reaction, not because she didn't understand. She understood everything, including things he refused to accept, and her reasons for this position were so profound that they sickened him.

She possessed, above all, that strange, meaningful smile. "Of course, if you genuinely know something...?" He could see she found the idea plausible. But he didn't even understand what she was implying, and he simply looked at her gloomily. His gloom didn't faze her.

Translation

She had, more than anything, that peculiar, knowing smile. "Well, if you actually know something...?" He could tell she considered the possibility. Yet he couldn't grasp her meaning, and he just stared at her, despondent. His dejection didn't bother her.

"You do know, I think, but you're being delicate about saying it. Your concern for me, my dear, is excessive. I'd be perfectly fine hearing it, so if you can tell me you know..." "Well?" he asked as she still kept what depended on it.

Translation

"I think you understand, but you're being cautious about saying it. You worry about me too much, my dear. I'll be fine hearing it, so if you can tell me what you know..." "Well?" he asked, as she still held back what it depended on.

"Why then I'll do what you want. We needn't, I grant you, in that case wait; and I can see what you mean by thinking it nicer of us not to. I don't even ask you," she continued, "for a proof. I'm content with your moral certainty."

Translation

"Alright, I'll do what you want. I agree that we don't have to wait in that case. And I understand why you think it would be better if we didn't. I won't even ask for proof," she continued. "Your word is good enough for me."

By this time it had come over him—it had the force of a rush. The point she made was clear, as clear as that the blood, while he recognised it, mantled in his face. "I know nothing whatever." "You've not an idea?"

Translation

He was overwhelmed, swept by a sudden force. Her point was obvious, as obvious as the blush he felt rising in his cheeks, even though he knew he was blushing. "I know nothing at all." "You haven't a clue?"

"I've not an idea." "I'd consent," she said—"I'd announce it to-morrow, to-day, I'd go home this moment and announce it to Aunt Maud, for an idea: I mean an idea straight from you, I mean as your own, given me in good faith. There, my dear!"—and she smiled again. "I call that really meeting you."

Translation

"I haven't the slightest idea." "I'd agree," she said. "I'd announce it tomorrow, today, I'd go home this instant and announce it to Aunt Maud, for an idea: I mean an idea straight from you, I mean as your own, given to me in good faith. There, my dear!" And she smiled again. "I call that really meeting you."

"Well?" he asked, since she still hesitated. "Alright, I'll do as you wish. We don't have to wait, I agree. I understand your point about it being better if we don't.

Translation

"Well?" he asked again, because she was still wavering. "Fine, I'll do it your way. We don't have to wait, I agree with you. I understand your point about it being better if we don't."

I won't even ask you," she continued, "for proof. I'm satisfied with your word." Suddenly it hit him, with the impact of a wave. Her point was clear, as clear as the flush that he felt on his face.

Translation

"I won't even ask," she went on, "for proof. I trust your word." It hit him then, like a physical blow. Her meaning was obvious, as obvious as the heat rising in his cheeks.

"I have no idea whatsoever." "You don't have any inkling?" "Not a single one." "I would agree," she said.

Translation

"I have no idea at all."

"You have no clue?"

"Not even a little bit."

"I concur," she said.

"I would announce it tomorrow, or even today. I would go home this very minute and tell Aunt Maud, just based on an idea. An idea straight from you, as your own, given to me honestly. There you go, my dear!" And she smiled again.

Translation

"I'd reveal it tomorrow, maybe even today. I'd go home this instant and tell Aunt Maud, just based on a hunch. A hunch that came straight from you, as your own, given to me honestly. There you go, my dear!" And she smiled again.

"That's what I call a real compromise." If it was then what she called it, it disposed of his appeal, and he could but stand there with his wasted passion—for it was in high passion that he had from the morning acted—in his face. She made it all out, bent upon her—the idea he didn't have, and the idea he had, and his failure of insistence when it brought up that challenge, and his sense of her personal presence, and his horror, almost, of her lucidity. They made in him a mixture that might have been rage, but that was turning quickly to mere cold thought, thought which led to something else and was like a new dim dawn.

Translation

"That's what I call a real compromise." If that's what she called it, then it rendered his appeal useless. He could only stand there, his wasted passion—because he had been acting in high passion since morning—written all over his face. She understood everything, fixed on her—the idea he lacked, the idea he possessed, and his failure to press the issue when she posed the challenge, his sense of her personal presence, and his almost horrified reaction to her clarity. It all combined in him, creating something that might have been rage, but quickly shifted to cold thought, thought that led elsewhere and resembled a new, dim dawn.

It affected her then, and she had one of the impulses, in all sincerity, that had before this, between them, saved their position. When she had come nearer to him, when, putting her hand upon him, she made him sink with her, as she leaned to him, into their old pair of chairs, she prevented irresistibly, she forestalled, the waste of his passion. She had an advantage with his passion now. If that was truly how she saw it, his argument was dismissed, and he could only stand there, his frustrated feelings—for he had been consumed by them since morning—written across his face.

Translation

It affected her then, and she had one of those impulses, in all sincerity, that had, prior to this, preserved their relationship. As she drew closer to him, placing her hand on him, causing him to sink with her into their old pair of chairs as she leaned in, she inevitably prevented, she forestalled, the waste of his passion. She held an advantage because of his passion now. If that was truly her perspective, his argument was irrelevant, and he could only stand there, his frustrated feelings—because he had been consumed by them since morning—etched across his face.

She understood everything—the thoughts he didn't have, the ones he did, his failure to push harder when challenged, his awareness of her presence, and his almost horrified reaction to her clarity. These things combined within him to create something that could have been anger, but quickly transformed into cold logic, a logic that led to a new understanding, like a faint sunrise. It affected her then, and she experienced one of the genuine impulses that had, in the past, salvaged their relationship. As she drew closer to him, placing her hand on him and guiding him to sink with her into their familiar chairs, she inevitably prevented the further waste of his passion.

Translation

She understood everything—the thoughts he didn't voice, the ones he did, his unwillingness to press his point, his consciousness of her, and his near-dismay at her perceptiveness. These elements mingled within him, potentially forming anger, which then swiftly reconfigured into a detached rationale, a logic that generated a fresh comprehension, like a subtle dawn. It moved her, prompting one of those authentic instincts that had, on previous occasions, preserved their connection. As she moved toward him, reaching out to touch him and lead him down into their customary chairs, she invariably stopped the continued dissipation of his passion.

She now held an advantage over his emotions.

Translation

She now had a hold over how he felt.

Chapter 20

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
A man, Densher, goes from a church to his club, where he sleeps for an hour. Before sleeping, he writes a note and sends it with a messenger to be hand-delivered to a woman named Kate. At four o'clock, Densher knocks on Mrs. Condrip's door and meets Kate in the drawing-room. He is relieved to learn she received his note. Kate lights candles on the mantelpiece. Densher tells Kate that Mrs. Lowder received a telegram the previous night from Mrs. Stringham about an "event" that had occurred, but that he himself has received no communication from Mrs. Stringham. Kate confirms that Mrs. Lowder told her nothing. Densher relays that Sir Luke will be back tomorrow. Kate informs Densher that Milly's trustee has already arrived to be with Mrs. Stringham. Kate asks Densher why he went to see Sir Luke that morning. Densher says he will tell her but first asks if something bad has brought her to this house. He gets up and stands by the fire. She offers to help him with his trouble, and he admits that he is in trouble. He explains that he received a letter. He says the postmark is recent, but he believes the letter itself was written earlier. He confirms it is a letter addressed to him in the deceased woman's handwriting, which he recognizes perfectly. He then looks out the window before turning back to Kate. He tells her he received the letter the previous night and has it with him to show her. He then admits that he has not read it. Kate asks how she can help him with it. Densher paces and then asks her to tell him what Lord Mark was doing with her and her aunt, and how Lord Mark knew that he and Kate were engaged.

He had said to her in the Park when challenged on it that nothing had "happened" to him as a cause for the demand he there made of her—happened he meant since the account he had given, after his return, of his recent experience. But in the course of a few days—they had brought him to Christmas morning—he was conscious enough, in preparing again to seek her out, of a difference on that score. Something had in this case happened to him, and, after his taking the night to think of it he felt that what it most, if not absolutely first, involved was his immediately again putting himself in relation with her. The fact itself had met him there—in his own small quarters—on Christmas Eve, and had not then indeed at once affected him as implying that consequence.

Translation

He'd told her in the Park, when she'd pressed him on the subject, that nothing had "happened" to him to explain his sudden proposal—nothing, he meant, since he'd described his recent experience after returning. But in a few days—leading up to Christmas morning—he was aware enough, as he prepared to find her again, that things had changed. Something had happened to him this time, and after spending the night considering it, he felt that what it primarily, if not solely, meant was that he had to immediately contact her again. The thing itself had come to him there—in his small apartment—on Christmas Eve, and at the time, hadn't immediately seemed to imply that consequence.

So far as he on the spot and for the next hours took its measure—a process that made his night mercilessly wakeful—the consequences possibly implied were numerous to distraction. His spirit dealt with them, in the darkness, as the slow hours passed; his intelligence and his imagination, his soul and his sense, had never on the whole been so intensely engaged. It was his difficulty for the moment that he was face to face with alternatives, and that it was scarce even a question of turning from one to the other. They were not in a perspective in which they might be compared and considered; they were, by a strange effect, as close as a pair of monsters of whom he might have felt on either cheek the hot breath and the huge eyes.

Translation

As far as he could tell, right then and for the next few hours—a process that kept him mercilessly awake all night—the possible consequences were distractingly numerous. His spirit wrestled with them in the dark as the slow hours crept by; his intellect, imagination, soul, and senses had never been so intensely involved. His difficulty at the moment was that he was confronted with alternatives, and it wasn’t even a matter of choosing one over the other. They weren’t in a perspective where they could be compared and considered; by a strange trick, they were as close as a pair of monsters whose hot breath and huge eyes he could feel on either cheek.

He saw them at once and but by looking straight before him; he wouldn't for that matter, in his cold apprehension, have turned his head by an inch. So it was that his agitation was still—was not, for the slow hours a matter of restless motion. He lay long, after the event, on the sofa where, extinguishing at a touch the white light of convenience that he hated, he had thrown himself without undressing. He stared at the buried day and wore out the time; with the arrival of the Christmas dawn moreover, late and grey, he felt himself somehow determined.

Translation

He saw them immediately, but only by looking straight ahead; he wouldn’t have turned his head an inch, for that matter, in his cold apprehension. His agitation was still—was not, for the slow hours, a matter of restless motion. He lay long after the event, on the sofa where, extinguishing at a touch the white light of convenience that he hated, he had thrown himself without undressing. He stared at the buried day and wore out the time; with the arrival of the Christmas dawn, late and grey, he felt himself somehow determined.

The common wisdom had had its say to him—that safety in doubt was not action; and perhaps what most helped him was this very commonness. In his case there was nothing of that—in no case in his life had there ever been less: which association, from one thing to another, now worked for him as a choice. He acted, after his bath and his breakfast, in the sense of that marked element of the rare which he felt to be the sign of his crisis. And that is why, dressed with more state than usual and quite as if for church, he went out into the soft Christmas day.

Translation

The received advice had spoken to him—that remaining uncertain wasn't a course of action; and perhaps this very conventionality aided him most. In his instance, nothing of that applied—never in his life had there been less: this connection, linking one thing to another, now served him as a decision. He acted, following his bath and breakfast, in accord with that distinct element of the unusual he perceived as the mark of his crisis. And for this reason, dressed with more care than usual and as if heading to church, he stepped out into the gentle Christmas day.

III He had told her in the Park when she questioned him that nothing had "happened" to him to explain his proposal—happened, meaning since he had described his recent experiences after his return. But within a few days—leading up to Christmas morning—he was aware of a change when preparing to find her again. Something had happened to him, and after thinking about it all night, he felt the most important thing, if not the only thing, was to immediately reconnect with her.

Translation

III. He'd told her in the Park, when she asked him, that nothing had "happened" to him to explain his proposal—happened, meaning since he'd described his recent experiences after his return. But within a few days—leading up to Christmas morning—he was aware of a change when preparing to find her again. Something had happened to him, and after thinking about it all night, he felt the most important thing, if not the only thing, was to immediately reconnect with her.

The event itself had found him in his own small apartment on Christmas Eve, and at the time, it hadn't immediately seemed to have any particular consequences. As much as he could tell at the time and in the following hours—a process that kept him awake all night—the potential outcomes were overwhelming. His mind wrestled with them in the darkness as the long hours passed. His intellect and imagination, his soul and his senses had never been so intensely involved.

Translation

The event found him in his own tiny apartment on Christmas Eve, and at the time, it didn't seem to have any immediate impact. As far as he could tell at the time and in the hours that followed—a process that kept him awake all night—the potential outcomes were overwhelming. His mind grappled with them in the darkness as the long hours ticked by. His intellect and imagination, his soul and his senses had never been so intensely engaged.

His problem was that he faced several options, and it wasn't even a matter of choosing between them. They weren't arranged in a way that allowed him to compare and consider them. By a strange turn of events, they were as close as two monstrous figures, whose hot breath and enormous eyes he could feel on either cheek. He saw them both at once, simply by looking straight ahead.

Translation

His problem was that he had multiple choices, and it wasn't even about selecting one. They weren't organized in a way that let him compare them. Strangely, they were as close as two monstrous shapes, their hot breath and huge eyes on either side of his face. He saw them both simultaneously, just by looking forward.

He wouldn't have turned his head even an inch, given his fearful state. So his agitation was still—it didn't involve restless movement during those long hours. He lay for a long time on the sofa after it happened. After turning off the cold white light that he hated, he had thrown himself down without getting undressed.

Translation

He wouldn't have moved a muscle, given his fear. His unease remained, unexpressed in the form of motion during those protracted hours. He stayed for a considerable amount of time on the sofa after it occurred. After killing the harsh white light that he despised, he'd collapsed onto the cushions without bothering to remove his clothes.

He stared at the fading day and waited for time to pass. With the arrival of Christmas dawn, late and gray, he felt he had made a decision. The common sense he had been taught was that caution in doubt wasn't action. Perhaps it was this very commonness that helped him most.

Translation

He watched the day wane and marked the passage of time. As the Christmas dawn broke, late and gray, he felt he had made a decision. The wisdom he'd been given said that hesitancy in uncertainty wasn't action. Perhaps it was this very commonality that aided him most.

In his case, there was none of that—his life had never been less cautious. This association, from one thing to another, now served as his choice. After his bath and breakfast, he acted according to the distinctive element of the unusual that he felt marked his crisis. And that's why, dressed more formally than usual, as if going to church, he went out into the gentle Christmas day.

Translation

In his situation, caution held no sway—his life had never been less restrained. This connection, from one thought to the next, now dictated his path. After his bath and breakfast, he proceeded in accordance with the unusual character that defined his moment of crisis. And so, dressed more formally than usual, as though going to church, he stepped out into the tranquil Christmas day.

Action, for him, on coming to the point, it appeared, carried with it a certain complexity. We should have known, walking by his side, that his final prime decision hadn't been to call at the door of Sir Luke Strett, and yet that this step, though subordinate, was none the less urgent. His prime decision was for another matter, to which impatience, once he was on the way, had now added itself; but he remained sufficiently aware that he must compromise with the perhaps excessive earliness. This, and the ferment set up within him, were together a reason for not driving; to say nothing of the absence of cabs in the dusky festal desert.

Translation

Action, as it turned out, held a degree of complexity for him. If we'd been with him, we'd have known that his primary, decisive move hadn't been to visit Sir Luke Strett. Nevertheless, this step, though secondary, was still pressing. His chief decision concerned something else entirely, now compounded by impatience as he proceeded. However, he was still aware that he had to accommodate the perhaps excessive earliness. This, along with the turmoil within him, was a reason not to take a cab, not to mention the lack of them in the dim, holiday emptiness.

Sir Luke's great square was not near, but he walked the Distance without seeing a hansom. He had his interval thus to turn over his view—the view to which what had happened the night before had not sharply reduced itself; but the complexity just mentioned was to be offered within the next few minutes another item to assimilate. Before Sir Luke's house, when he reached it, a brougham was drawn up—at the sight of which his heart had a lift that brought him for the instant to a stand. This pause wasn't long, but it was long enough to flash upon him a revelation in the light of which he caught his breath.

Translation

Sir Luke's square was not close, but he walked the distance without seeing a cab. This gave him time to consider his perspective—a perspective that hadn't been entirely altered by the previous night; but the previously mentioned complexity was about to be presented with another matter to resolve. Before Sir Luke's house, when he arrived, a brougham was parked—the sight of which gave him a jolt that stopped him in his tracks. This pause was brief, but it was long enough to bring him a revelation, one that caused him to catch his breath.

The carriage, so possibly at such an hour and on such a day Sir Luke's own, had struck him as a sign that the great doctor was back. This would prove something else, in turn, still more intensely, and it was in the act of the double apprehension that Densher felt himself turn pale. His mind rebounded for the moment like a projectile that has suddenly been met by another: he stared at the strange truth that what he wanted more than to see Kate Croy was to see the witness who had just arrived from Venice. He wanted positively to be in his presence and to hear his voice—which was the spasm of his consciousness that produced the flash.

Translation

The carriage, possibly Sir Luke's own at such an hour on such a day, had made him think the great doctor was back. This, in turn, would prove something else, something even more intense, and it was in the act of this double fear that Densher felt himself turn pale. His mind recoiled for a moment, like a projectile suddenly met by another: he stared at the strange truth that he wanted, more than anything, to see Kate Croy, to see the witness who had just arrived from Venice. He positively wanted to be in his presence and to hear his voice—which was the spasm of his consciousness that produced the flash.

Fortunately for him, on the spot, there supervened something in which the flash went out. He became aware within this minute that the coachman on the box of the brougham had a face known to him, whereas he had never seen before, to his knowledge, the great doctor's carriage. The carriage, as he came nearer, was simply Mrs. Lowder's; the face on the box was just the face that, in coming and going at Lancaster Gate, he would vaguely have noticed, outside, in attendance.

Translation

Fortunately for him, at that moment, something happened that extinguished the flash. He realized within that minute that the coachman on the brougham's box had a face he knew, whereas he had never, to his knowledge, seen the great doctor's carriage before. The carriage, as he drew closer, was simply Mrs. Lowder's; the face on the box was merely the face that, in his comings and goings at Lancaster Gate, he would have vaguely noticed in attendance outside.

With this the rest came: the lady of Lancaster Gate had, on a prompting not wholly remote from his own, presented herself for news; and news, in the house, she was clearly getting, since her brougham had stayed. Sir Luke was then back—only Mrs. Lowder was with him. When he had to make a move, it seemed complicated for him.

Translation

This was followed by the rest: the woman from Lancaster Gate, prompted by a reason not entirely unlike his own, had arrived seeking information. And she was clearly receiving it within the house, given that her carriage remained. Sir Luke was then back—only Mrs. Lowder was with him. When he needed to leave, it seemed complex for him.

Even if we'd been walking with him, we'd have known that his main decision wasn't to visit Sir Luke Strett. Still, that step, though secondary, was still important. His primary decision involved something else, a matter that he was now eager to address. But he knew he'd have to deal with this early visit.

Translation

Even if we had accompanied him, we would have known that his primary objective wasn't to see Sir Luke Strett. Nevertheless, that visit, though of lesser importance, was still significant. His foremost concern involved something else, a matter he now wished to handle. However, he knew he'd have to manage this initial visit first.

The situation, along with his inner turmoil, meant he shouldn't take a carriage. And besides, there weren't any cabs around in the dim, celebratory emptiness. Sir Luke's square wasn't close by, but he walked the distance without spotting a taxi. This allowed him time to consider things—things that hadn't fully crystallized after what happened the night before.

Translation

The circumstances and his inner disquietude ruled out a carriage ride. Furthermore, the subdued, festive quiet offered no taxis. Though not immediately local, Sir Luke's square was a walk away, and he found himself traveling the whole distance without any sign of a cab. This gave him the opportunity to mull things over—things that remained murky after the previous night's events.

But the complexity he'd felt was about to gain another component. When he got to Sir Luke's house, a brougham was parked outside, and that sight made his heart jump, causing him to stop momentarily. This pause was brief, but long enough for him to have a sudden understanding, which made him catch his breath. The carriage, perhaps Sir Luke's own at this hour and on this day, seemed like a sign that the great doctor was back.

Translation

However, the intricate situation he was in was about to get even more complicated. Upon arriving at Sir Luke's residence, he saw a brougham parked out front. This sight startled him, causing him to halt momentarily. The pause was short-lived, but long enough for a sudden realization to hit him, making him gasp. The carriage, possibly belonging to Sir Luke, present at this time and on this day, felt like a signal that the esteemed doctor had returned.

This, in turn, implied something else even more intensely, and as he grasped this double realization, Densher felt himself turn pale. His mind recoiled momentarily, as if it had collided with something: he was stunned by the strange truth that he wanted to see the witness who had just arrived from Venice more than he wanted to see Kate Croy.
