He absolutely wanted to be present and to hear his voice—it was this sudden awareness that caused the flash of insight. Luckily, something else happened on the spot, and the flash faded.

Translation

This, in turn, implied something even more potent, and the double realization made Densher blanch. His mind recoiled for a moment, as though it had struck an obstacle: he was stunned by the strange truth that he wanted to see the witness who had just arrived from Venice more than he wanted to see Kate Croy. He absolutely wanted to be present and to hear his voice—this sudden understanding was what sparked the insight. Fortunately, something else happened then, and the flash receded.

He realized within that minute that the coachman on the brougham's box had a familiar face, while he'd never seen the great doctor's carriage before, as far as he knew. The carriage, as he got closer, belonged to Mrs. Lowder; the face on the box was the one he vaguely remembered from his comings and goings at Lancaster Gate, waiting outside. With this, the rest followed: the lady of Lancaster Gate, prompted by a reason not entirely different from his own, had come for news; and it was clear she was receiving news in the house, since her brougham remained.

Translation

In that moment, he recognized the coachman on the brougham's seat. He didn't think he'd ever seen the doctor's carriage. As he approached, he saw it belonged to Mrs. Lowder, and the driver was the same one he vaguely remembered from his visits to Lancaster Gate, always waiting outside. With this, the rest clicked into place: the Lancaster Gate lady had come for news, for reasons similar to his own. And she was clearly receiving news inside the house, since her carriage was still there.

Sir Luke was back, but only Mrs. Lowder was with him. It was under the influence of this last reflexion that Densher again delayed; and it was while he delayed that something else occurred to him. It was all round, visibly—given his own new contribution—a case of pressure; and in a case of pressure Kate, for quicker knowledge, might have come out with her aunt.

Translation

Sir Luke had returned, but only Mrs. Lowder accompanied him. It was due to this line of thought that Densher paused again, and while he hesitated, another idea occurred to him. Considering his new piece of the puzzle, it was all clearly a matter of pressure. And in a situation of pressure, Kate might have come outside with her aunt for information, faster.

The possibility that in this event she might be sitting in the carriage—the thing most likely—had had the effect, before he could check it, of bringing him within range of the window. It wasn't there he had wished to see her; yet if she was there he couldn't pretend not to. What he had however the next moment made out was that if some one was there it wasn't Kate Croy. It was, with a sensible shock for him, the person who had last offered him a conscious face from behind the clear plate of a café in Venice.

Translation

The chance that she might be in the carriage—the most probable scenario—had drawn him toward the window before he could stop himself. He hadn’t wanted to find her there, but if she was, he couldn't feign indifference. What he saw in the next moment, however, was that if anyone was there, it wasn't Kate Croy. It was, to his astonishment, the person who had last offered him a conscious gaze from behind the clean glass of a café in Venice.

The great glass at Florian's was a medium less obscure, even with the window down, than the air of the London Christmas; yet at present also, none the less, between the two men, an exchange of recognitions could occur. Densher felt his own look a gaping arrest—which, he disgustedly remembered, his back as quickly turned, appeared to repeat itself as his special privilege. He mounted the steps of the house and touched the bell with a keen consciousness of being habitually looked at by Kate's friend from positions of almost insolent vantage. He forgot for the time the moment when, in Venice, at the palace, the encouraged young man had in a manner assisted at the departure of the disconcerted, since Lord Mark was not looking disconcerted now any more than he had looked from his bench at his café.

Translation

The immense glass at Florian's was less hazy, even with the window down, than the air of London during Christmas; and yet, in that moment, a mutual recognition passed between the two men. Densher felt his own gaze freeze in surprise—which, he realized with disgust, he had turned away from almost immediately, as if it were his special prerogative. He went up the steps of the house and rang the bell, keenly aware of being watched by Kate's friend from a position of almost insolent superiority. He forgot, for the time being, the moment in Venice, at the palace, when the emboldened young man had in a way overseen the departure of the man who was discomposed, since Lord Mark didn't appear discomposed now, any more than he had from his café bench.

Densher was thinking that he seemed to show as vagrant while another was ensconced. He was thinking of the other as—in spite of the difference of situation—more ensconced than ever; he was thinking of him above all as the friend of the person with whom his recognition had, the minute previous, associated him. The man was seated in the very place in which, beside Mrs. Lowder's, he had looked to find Kate, and that was a sufficient identity.

Translation

Densher was thinking that he seemed to be the wandering one, while the other was settled. He was thinking of the other as—despite the different circumstances—more settled than ever. Above all, he was thinking of him as the friend of the person with whom his recognition had, the previous minute, linked him. The man was seated in the very place where he had expected to find Kate, next to Mrs. Lowder, and that was enough to identify him.

Meanwhile at any rate the door of the house had opened and Mrs. Lowder stood before him. It was something at least that she wasn't Kate. She was herself, on the spot, in all her affluence; with presence of mind both to decide at once that Lord Mark, in the brougham, didn't matter and to prevent Sir Luke's butler, by a firm word thrown over her shoulder, from standing there to listen to her passage with the gentleman who had rung.

Translation

In the meantime, at any rate, the house's door had opened, and Mrs. Lowder stood before him. It was something, at least, that she wasn't Kate. She was herself, right there, in all her affluence; with enough presence of mind to decide at once that Lord Mark, in the brougham, didn't matter, and to prevent Sir Luke's butler, with a firm word thrown over her shoulder, from standing there to listen to her exchange with the gentleman who had rung the bell.

"I'll tell Mr. Densher; you needn't wait!" And the passage, promptly and richly, took place on the steps. Densher hesitated again, influenced by that last thought. While he paused, something else occurred to him.

Translation

"I'll tell Mr. Densher; you needn't wait!"

And the exchange, quick and decisive, happened on the steps. Densher hesitated once more, affected by that final thought. While he paused, something else came to mind.

Considering his new role in the situation, it was clearly a case of pressure. Kate, likely eager for information, might have come to her aunt for quicker answers. The possibility of her being in the carriage, which seemed probable, had caused him to approach the window before he could stop himself. He hadn't intended to find her there, but he couldn't pretend not to notice if she was.

Translation

Given his new position in all this, it was evidently a matter of her exerting pressure. Kate, probably impatient for news, might have gone to her aunt to get the information sooner. The likelihood of her being in the carriage, which seemed to him the most likely scenario, had made him move to the window before he could stop himself. He hadn't meant to see her there, but he couldn't act as if he hadn't if she was.

However, what he saw was not Kate Croy. He was taken aback to see the man who had last offered him a knowing look from behind the glass of a Venice cafe. The great window at Florian's was less obscure than the London air at Christmastime, yet even now, a recognition passed between them. Densher felt his own stare, an open-mouthed moment of surprise, which he recalled with annoyance, quickly mirrored itself as if it were a special privilege.

Translation

However, the person he saw was not Kate Croy. He was surprised to see the man who had last given him an knowing look through the window of a cafe in Venice. The large window at Florian's was less hazy than the London air at Christmastime, yet even now, they acknowledged each other. Densher felt his own stare, an open-mouthed moment of surprise, which he remembered with annoyance, was immediately reflected back at him, as if it was a special privilege.

He climbed the steps to the house and rang the bell, fully aware that Kate's friend was probably watching him from a position of almost arrogant superiority. He temporarily forgot the moment in Venice, at the palace, when the encouraged young man had seemed to assist in the departure of the other, since Lord Mark didn't look disconcerted now any more than he had at the cafe. Densher was thinking that he appeared to be the vagrant while the other was settled. He was thinking of the other as being—despite the difference in their circumstances—more secure than ever; and, above all, he was thinking of him as the friend of the person with whom his recognition had just connected him.

Translation

He went up the steps and rang the bell, knowing full well that Kate’s friend was likely observing him with a kind of smug superiority. He momentarily forgot the instance in Venice, at the palace, when the amenable young man seemed to have helped in the other man's exit. Lord Mark appeared no more troubled now than he had at the cafe. Densher considered himself the outsider, while the other man was at home. He thought of the other as being, regardless of their different situations, more secure than ever before; and above all, he thought of him as the friend of the woman whose acquaintance he had just re-established.

The man was sitting in the very place where he had expected to find Kate, beside Mrs. Lowder, and that was enough to identify him. Meanwhile, the door of the house had opened, and Mrs. Lowder stood before him.

Translation

The man occupied the very spot where he’d anticipated finding Kate, seated next to Mrs. Lowder, and that alone was enough to confirm his identity. At that moment, the house’s door swung inward, and Mrs. Lowder stood before him.

At least it wasn't Kate. Mrs. Lowder was there herself, in all her wealth. She was quick-witted enough to decide immediately that Lord Mark in the carriage was irrelevant and to prevent Sir Luke's butler, by speaking firmly over her shoulder, from listening to her conversation with the gentleman who had rung the bell.

Translation

At least Kate wasn't there. Mrs. Lowder stood before him, in all her affluence. She was sharp enough to realize instantly that Lord Mark in the carriage was of no importance and, by speaking sharply over her shoulder, to stop Sir Luke's butler from eavesdropping on her conversation with the gentleman who'd rung the bell.

"I'll tell Mr. Densher; you needn't wait!" And the conversation, prompt and rich with meaning, took place on the steps. "He arrives, travelling straight, to-morrow early. I couldn't not come to learn."

Translation

"I'll tell Mr. Densher; you needn't wait!" And the conversation, immediate and brimming with significance, began on the steps. "He arrives, travelling directly, first thing tomorrow. I couldn't not come to hear."

"No more," said Densher simply, "could I. On my way," he added, "to Lancaster Gate." "Sweet of you." She beamed on him dimly, and he saw her face was attuned. It made him, with what she had just before said, know all, and he took the thing in while he met the air of portentous, of almost functional, sympathy that had settled itself as her medium with him and that yet had now a fresh glow.

Translation

"Neither could I," Densher said plainly. "I'm on my way," he added, "to Lancaster Gate." "That's lovely of you." She gave him a faint smile, and he saw her face was in sync. With what she had just said, it made him understand everything, and he absorbed it while he registered the air of ominous, almost procedural, sympathy that had become her method with him and that now held a new warmth.

"So you have had your message?" He knew so well what she meant, and so equally with it what he "had had" no less than what he hadn't, that, with but the smallest hesitation, he strained the point. "Yes—my message." He's arriving tomorrow morning, without stopping.

Translation

"So you've received your message?" He understood perfectly what she was implying, and equally, what he "had" and "hadn't," so with the slightest pause, he took the bait. "Yes—my message." He's arriving tomorrow morning, non-stop.

I had to come and find out." "Me neither," Densher said plainly. "I'm on my way," he added, "to Lancaster Gate." "How nice of you." She smiled at him faintly, and he saw that her face was prepared.

Translation

"I had to come and see." "Same here," Densher said simply. "I'm heading over there," he added, "to Lancaster Gate." "How kind of you." She gave him a small smile, and he saw her face was ready.

It made him, along with what she had just said, understand everything. He grasped the situation while he faced the air of significant, almost dutiful, sympathy that had become her usual attitude toward him, but that now had a new warmth. "So you've gotten your message?" He understood exactly what she meant, and equally understood both what he *had* learned and what he *hadn't*.

Translation

It all clicked for him, especially considering what she’d just said. He saw the whole picture, even as he was confronted with her usual air of knowing, almost obliging, sympathy—an attitude she generally took with him. Only now, there was something new, a certain warmth. "So, the message has come through for you?" He knew precisely what she was talking about and understood both the things he *did* know and the things he *didn’t*.

So, with only a tiny pause, he stretched the truth a little. "Yes—my message." "Our dear dove then, as Kate calls her, has folded her wonderful wings." "Yes—folded them."

Translation

He hesitated only a moment before embellishing the truth. "Yes—my message." "So, our dear dove, as Kate calls her, has closed her wonderful wings." "Yes—closed them."

It rather racked him, but he tried to receive it as she intended, and she evidently took his formal assent for self-control. "Unless it's more true," she accordingly added, "that she has spread them the wider." He again but formally assented, though, strangely enough, the words fitted a figure deep in his own imagination. "Rather, yes—spread them the wider."

Translation

It bothered him quite a bit, but he tried to take it the way she meant it, and she clearly interpreted his stiff agreement as composure. "Unless it's more accurate," she then added, "that she's opened them even further." Again, he gave only formal agreement, although, strangely enough, the words resonated with an image deep within his own thoughts. "More like, yes—opened them even further."

"For a flight, I trust, to some happiness greater—!" "Exactly. Greater," Densher broke in; but now with a look, he feared, that did a little warn her off. "You were certainly," she went on with more reserve, "entitled to direct news.

Translation

"For a flight, I trust, to some greater happiness—!" "Exactly. Greater," Densher interjected; but now

with a look, he feared, that might have pushed her away a bit. "You were certainly," she continued, with more caution,

"entitled to direct news.

Ours came late last night: I'm not sure otherwise I shouldn't have gone to you. But you're coming," she asked, "to me?" Our sweet girl, as Kate calls her, has stopped working. "Yes, she has."

Translation

Ours arrived late last night. I'm not sure I wouldn't have come to you otherwise. But you're coming, she asked, to me? Our sweet girl, as Kate calls her, has stopped working. Yes, she has.

It was painful for him, but he tried to react the way she wanted. She seemed to think his agreement meant he was keeping it together. "Or," she added, "maybe it's more accurate to say that she's expanded her horizons." He agreed again, though the words oddly described something he was already thinking.

Translation

It hurt him, but he forced himself to respond as she expected. Her reaction seemed to indicate that his compliance was a sign of composure. "Or," she continued, "perhaps it's more accurate to say that she's broadened her perspectives." He agreed again, despite the fact that those words strangely reflected a thought that was already in his head.

"Yes, I suppose so – expanded her horizons." "I hope she's flying off to something even better—!" "Exactly. Better," Densher interrupted, but he worried that his expression might have made her uncomfortable.

Translation

"Yes, I suppose you could say that – she's broadened her horizons." "I hope she's flying off to something even better—!" "Exactly. Better," Densher interrupted, but he worried that his expression might have made her uncomfortable.

"You should definitely have the right to hear it from me directly," she continued more carefully. "We got the news late last night. Otherwise, I might have come to you sooner. Are you coming to me?"

Translation

"You absolutely deserve to hear this from me personally," she continued, more cautiously. "We found out last night. Otherwise, I would have come to you earlier. Are you coming to see me?"

He had had a minute by this time to think further, and the window of the brougham was still within range. Her rich "me," reaching him moreover through the mild damp, had the effect of a thump on his chest. "Squared," Aunt Maud? She was indeed squared, and the extent of it just now perversely enough took away his breath.

Translation

By now, he’d had a moment to think, and the brougham's window was still in view. Her opulent "me," carried to him on the soft mist, struck him like a blow to the chest. "Squared," Aunt Maud? She was, and the scope of it, perversely enough, left him breathless.

His look from where they stood embraced the aperture at which the person sitting in the carriage might have shown, and he saw his interlocutress, on her side, understand the question in it, which he moreover then uttered. "Shall you be alone?" It was, as an immediate instinctive parley with the image of his condition that now flourished in her, almost hypocritical. It sounded as if he wished to come and overflow to her, yet this was exactly what he didn't. The need to overflow had suddenly—since the night before—dried up in him, and he had never been aware of a deeper reserve.

Translation

His gaze, fixed from their position, took in the opening where the carriage's occupant might appear. He saw his conversational partner, from her perspective, grasp the import of his question, which he then voiced. "Will you be alone?" It was almost hypocritical, an instant, instinctive dialogue with the vision of his own circumstances, which were now vividly present in her mind. It sounded like he wanted to come and inundate her, but this was precisely what he didn't want. The urge to overflow had, suddenly—since the previous night—vanished in him, and he had never known such profound restraint.

He'd had a moment by now to think more about it, and the window of the carriage was still visible. Her luxurious "me," reaching him also through the gentle dampness, felt like a blow to the chest. "Resolved," Aunt Maud? She was, in fact, resolved, and the scale of it, oddly enough, took his breath away.

Translation

He'd had time to consider it further, and the carriage window was still in view. Her opulent self, reaching him through the soft mist, felt like a physical impact. "Resolved," Aunt Maud? She was, in fact, resolved, and the sheer magnitude of it, strangely enough, left him breathless.

From where he stood, his gaze took in the window where the person in the carriage might appear, and he saw his conversation partner understand the question his look contained, which he then voiced. "Will you be alone?" As an immediate, instinctive negotiation with the idea of his situation that was currently clear to her, it was almost hypocritical. It sounded as though he wanted to come and share his feelings with her, yet that was precisely what he didn't want. The need to express his feelings had abruptly—since the previous night—vanished within him, and he'd never felt so withdrawn.

Translation

From his position, his eyes found the carriage window where she might appear, and he saw his conversation partner understand the question his glance posed, which he then spoke aloud. "Will you be alone?" As a swift, instinctive bargaining with the truth of his circumstances, which she now comprehended, it was nearly hypocritical. It sounded as though he wanted to confide in her, but that was exactly what he didn't want. The impulse to share his feelings had suddenly—since the previous night—vanished within him, and he'd never felt so isolated.

But she had meanwhile largely responded. "Completely alone. I should otherwise never have dreamed; feeling, dear friend, but too much!" Failing on her lips what she felt came out for him in the offered hand with which she had the next moment condolingly pressed his own. "Dear friend, dear friend!"—she was deeply "with" him, and she wished to be still more so: which was what made her immediately continue.

Translation

But she had largely answered in the interim. "Completely alone. Otherwise, I would never have dared. I feel, dear friend, far too much!" The words themselves failing her, what she felt manifested for him in the offered hand, which she used in the next moment to press his in a consoling gesture. "Dear friend, dear friend!"—she was deeply "with" him, and she wanted to be even more so, which is why she immediately continued.

"Or wouldn't you this evening, for the sad Christmas it makes us, dine with me tête-à-tête?" It put the thing off, the question of a talk with her—making the difference, to his relief, of several hours; but it also rather mystified him. This however didn't diminish his need of caution. "Shall you mind if I don't tell you at once?"

Translation

"Or wouldn't you, considering how sad Christmas feels, dine with me alone tonight?" The invitation postponed their conversation, giving him several hours of relief, but it also puzzled him. This didn't lessen his need for caution. "Would you mind if I didn't answer you right away?"

But she had, in the meantime, responded significantly. "Completely alone. I wouldn't have even considered it otherwise. I feel so much, dear friend!" What she felt couldn't be spoken, but it was conveyed by her hand as she offered it to him and squeezed his.

Translation

However, she had already offered a meaningful response. "Absolutely alone. I wouldn't have proposed it any other way. I am feeling so much, dear friend!" The nature of her feelings was unspoken, but her hand spoke volumes as she extended it and grasped his.

"Dear friend, dear friend!"—she was utterly in sympathy with him, and she wanted to be even more so. That's why she immediately went on. "Or would you like to dine with me this evening, just the two of us, given how sad this Christmas makes us?" It delayed the matter, the question of a conversation with her—which, to his relief, provided a respite of several hours.

Translation

"My dear, my dear friend!" She empathized with him completely and wanted to connect with him even more. Thus, she immediately continued, "Or, since this Christmas is making us both so sad, would you like to have dinner with me this evening, just the two of us?" The invitation postponed their conversation, a conversation with her that gave him, thankfully, a reprieve of several hours.

But it also rather confused him. However, this didn't make him less cautious. "Would you mind if I didn't tell you right away?" "Not in the least—leave it open: it shall be as you may feel, and you needn't even send me word.

Translation

But it also left him somewhat bewildered. Still, he didn't lower his guard. "Would you be alright if I didn't answer you immediately?" "Not at all—leave it open. Do as you feel, and you don't even have to let me know."

I only will mention that to-day, of all days, I shall otherwise sit there alone." Now at least he could ask. "Without Miss Croy?" "Without Miss Croy.

Translation

"I'll just say that today, of all days, I'd be sitting there alone, otherwise." Now he could finally ask. "Without Miss Croy?" "Without Miss Croy."

Miss Croy," said Mrs. Lowder, "is spending her Christmas in the bosom of her more immediate family." He was afraid, even while he spoke, of what his face might show. "You mean she has left you?"

Translation

"Miss Croy," Mrs. Lowder said, "is spending her Christmas with her closest family." He worried, even as he spoke, about betraying himself. "You mean she's gone?"

Aunt Maud's own face for that matter met the enquiry with a consciousness in which he saw a reflexion of events. He was made sure by it, even at the moment and as he had never been before, that since he had known these two women no confessed nor commented tension, no crisis of the cruder sort would really have taken form between them: which was precisely a high proof of how Kate had steered her boat. The situation exposed in Mrs. Lowder's present expression lighted up by contrast that superficial smoothness; which afterwards, with his time to think of it, was to put before him again the art, the particular gift, in the girl, now so placed and classed, so intimately familiar for him, as her talent for life.

Translation

Aunt Maud’s face, for that matter, registered the question with a knowingness that mirrored the situation. He was certain, even then and as he’d never been before, that throughout his acquaintance with the two women, no overt tension or crude conflict would have ever surfaced between them; precisely this was a testament to Kate’s adeptness. The circumstances revealed in Mrs. Lowder’s present expression illuminated by contrast that surface composure; which later, when he had time to consider it, would present him again with the artistry, the singular skill, possessed by the girl, now so situated and categorized, so intimately familiar to him, as her aptitude for life.

The peace, within a day or two—since his seeing her last—had clearly been broken; differences, deep down, kept there by a diplomacy on Kate's part as deep, had been shaken to the surface by some exceptional jar; with which, in addition, he felt Lord Mark's odd attendance at such an hour and season vaguely associated. The talent for life indeed, it at the same time struck him, would probably have shown equally in the breach, or whatever had occurred; Aunt Maud having suffered, he judged, a strain rather than a stroke. Of these quick thoughts, at all events, that lady was already abreast. "She went yesterday morning—and not with my approval, I don't mind telling you—to her sister: Mrs.

Translation

The peace, within a day or two—since he had last seen her—had clearly been disrupted. Underlying differences, kept suppressed by a diplomacy on Kate’s part that ran just as deep, had been stirred to the surface by some exceptional jolt. He felt vaguely connected to this, in addition to Lord Mark's unusual presence at that time and in that situation. The talent for life, it occurred to him, would likely have been just as apparent in the crisis, or whatever had taken place; Aunt Maud, he surmised, had experienced a strain rather than a stroke. That lady was already in tune with these quick thoughts. “She left yesterday morning—and not with my approval, I don’t mind telling you—to visit her sister: Mrs.

Condrip, if you know who I mean, who lives somewhere in Chelsea. My other niece and her affairs—that I should have to say such things to-day!—are a constant worry; so that Kate, in consequence—well, of events!—has simply been called in. My own idea, I'm bound to say, was that with such events she need have, in her situation, next to nothing to do." "Not at all—leave it open: it will be as you wish, and you don't even have to let me know.

Translation

Condrip, if you know who I mean, who lives somewhere in Chelsea. My other niece and her affairs—that I should have to say such things today!—are a constant worry; so that Kate, in consequence—well, of events!—has simply been called in. My own idea, I'm bound to say, was that with such events she need have, in her situation, next to nothing to do." "Not at all—leave it open: it will be as you wish, and you don't even have to let me know.

I'll just mention that, today of all days, I would otherwise be alone." Now, he could finally ask. "Without Miss Croy?" "Without Miss Croy.

Translation

"I should point out that, of all days, I would have been alone otherwise." Now, he was able to ask. "Without Miss Croy?" "Without Miss Croy."

Miss Croy," Mrs. Lowder said, "is spending her Christmas with her immediate family." He was worried, even as he spoke, about what his face might reveal. "You mean she has left you?"

Translation

"Miss Croy," Mrs. Lowder said, "is spending her Christmas with her immediate family." He was worried, even as he spoke, about what his face might reveal. "You mean she has left you?"

Aunt Maud's face reflected the situation with an awareness that showed him the truth. He understood, as he never had before, that during the time he had known these two women, there had never been an open conflict or obvious crisis between them. This, in itself, proved how skillfully Kate had managed things. The situation exposed in Mrs.

Translation

Lowder's words, the fact that Miss Croy was not present, was a sign of a carefully constructed plan. Maud, more than anyone, knew the game Kate played. He saw it in the lines around her eyes, a subtle tightening of her lips. It was clear: Kate had orchestrated a retreat, a strategic withdrawal, leaving Mrs. Lowder to confront the fallout. The absence spoke volumes, confirming his unspoken fears, revealing the carefully concealed tensions that had simmered beneath the surface of their lives.

Lowder's expression illuminated that previously smooth exterior. Later, when he had time to think, it would highlight again the art, the specific talent, of the girl, now so thoroughly understood, her gift for living. The peace, within the last couple of days—since he last saw her—had clearly been disrupted. Underlying tensions, kept hidden by Kate's equally deep diplomacy, had been shaken to the surface by some unusual event.

Translation

Lowder's face exposed what had been hidden. Later, when he had time to process it, he would again appreciate the skill, the particular talent of the woman he now understood so well, her talent for life. The calm of the last few days—since he last saw her—had obviously been shattered. The unspoken tensions, hidden by Kate's considerable diplomatic skill, had been brought to the surface by some unforeseen event.

He vaguely felt that Lord Mark's unusual presence at this time was somehow connected to it. The talent for living, he realized, would likely be evident even in this break, or whatever had occurred. Aunt Maud, he believed, had experienced a strain rather than a complete breakdown. Of these quick thoughts, at any rate, she was already aware.

Translation

He had a vague sense that Lord Mark’s unexpected appearance at this moment was somehow connected. The talent for living, he realized, would likely be evident even in this break, or whatever had occurred. Aunt Maud, he believed, had experienced a strain rather than a complete breakdown. Of these quick thoughts, at any rate, she was already aware.

"She left yesterday morning—and not with my approval, I don't mind telling you—to go to her sister, Mrs. Condrip, if you know who I mean, who lives somewhere in Chelsea. My other niece and her problems—that I should have to discuss such things today!—are a constant worry. So Kate, in consequence—well, because of recent events!—has simply been called in.

Translation

"She left yesterday morning, and I'm not happy about it. She went to her sister, Mrs. Condrip—do you know her? She lives in Chelsea somewhere. My other niece and her issues… I can't believe I'm having to talk about this today! Anyway, Kate was called in because of everything that's happened."

My own belief, I must say, was that she should have had, given her position, very little to do with such events." "But she differed with you?" "She differed with me. And when Kate differs with you—!"

Translation

My personal opinion, I have to admit, was that, considering her status, she shouldn't have been involved with such matters at all. "But she disagreed with you?" "She did. And when Kate disagrees with you—!"

"Oh I can imagine." He had reached the point in the scale of hypocrisy at which he could ask himself why a little more or less should signify. Besides, with the intention he had had he must know. Kate's move, if he didn't know, might simply disconcert him; and of being disconcerted his horror was by this time fairly superstitious. "I hope you don't allude to events at all calamitous."

Translation

"Oh, I can imagine." He had arrived at that place on the scale of hypocrisy where he could wonder why a little more or less should make any difference. Besides, given his intentions, he had to know. Kate's actions, if he didn't know about them, might just throw him off; and by this point, his fear of being thrown off was almost superstitious. "I hope you aren't referring to anything too disastrous."

"No—only horrid and vulgar." "Oh!" said Merton Densher. Mrs. Lowder's soreness, it was still not obscure, had discovered in free speech to him a momentary balm.

Translation

"No—just awful and common." "Oh!" said Merton Densher. Mrs. Lowder's resentment, which was still obvious, had found in their unreserved conversation a temporary relief.

"They've the misfortune to have, I suppose you know, a dreadful horrible father." "But she disagreed with you?" "She disagreed with me. And when Kate disagrees with you—!"

Translation

"They're unfortunate enough to have, I imagine you know, a terrible, horrible father." "But she didn't agree with you?" "She didn't agree with me. And when Kate disagrees with you—!"

"Oh, I can imagine." He'd arrived at the level of deception where he could wonder if a little more or less really mattered. Besides, given his plans, he should already know. If he didn't, Kate's actions could simply throw him off; and he was now superstitiously afraid of being thrown off. "I hope you're not referring to anything disastrous."

Translation

"I understand." He had reached a point of deception where he could rationalize the insignificance of minor variations. Besides, his plans required him to know already. If he didn't, Kate's behavior could derail him; and he was now unnerved by the prospect. "I hope you're not implying anything terrible."

"No—just awful and distasteful." "Oh!" said Merton Densher. Mrs. Lowder's resentment, which was still obvious, seemed to find momentary relief in speaking frankly to him.

Translation

"No, just awful and distasteful." "Oh!" said Merton Densher. Mrs. Lowder's resentment, which was still obvious, seemed to find momentary relief in speaking frankly to him.

"They have the misfortune, as you probably know, of having a dreadful, horrible father." "Oh!" said Densher again. "He's too bad almost to name, but he has come upon Marian, and Marian has shrieked for help." Densher wondered at this with intensity; and his curiosity compromised for an instant with his discretion.

Translation

"They have the misfortune, as you likely know, of having a dreadful, horrible father." "Oh!" said Densher again. "He's almost too awful to mention, but he's come upon Marian, and Marian has shrieked for help." Densher pondered this intently; and his curiosity momentarily outweighed his discretion.

"Come upon her—for money?" "Oh for that of course always. But, at this blessed season, for refuge, for safety: for God knows what. He's there, the brute.

Translation

"Come upon her—for money?" "Oh, yes, always for that. But, at this blessed season, for refuge, for safety: for God knows what. He's there, the brute."

And Kate's with them. And that," Mrs. Lowder wound up, going down the steps, "is her Christmas." She had stopped again at the bottom while he thought of an answer.

Translation

And Kate's with them. And that," Mrs. Lowder concluded, descending the steps, "is her Christmas." She paused at the bottom, awaiting his response.

"Yours then is after all rather better." "It's at least more decent." And her hand once more came out. "But why do I talk of our troubles? Come if you can."

Translation

"Yours is, after all, rather better." "It's at least more decent." And her hand reached out once more. "But why am I talking about our troubles? Come, if you can."

"Oh!" Densher repeated. "He's awful, I almost don't want to say his name. But he showed up at Marian's, and she screamed for help." Densher was intensely curious, and for a moment, his desire to know outweighed his caution.

Translation

"Oh!" Densher repeated. "He's awful, I almost can't bring myself to say his name. But he appeared at Marian's, and she screamed for help." Densher was intensely curious, and for a moment, his desire to know overcame his caution.

"Showed up—for money?" "Oh, of course, that's always it. But, especially now, for a place to stay, for security, for who knows what? He's there, the monster.

Translation

"He showed up—for money?" "Oh, naturally, it always comes down to that. But, especially now, for a roof over his head, for safety, for who knows what else? He's there, the beast."

And Kate's with them. And that," Mrs. Lowder concluded, starting down the steps, "is her Christmas." She paused at the bottom while he considered a response.

Translation

And Kate is with them too. And that," Mrs. Lowder said, beginning to walk down the stairs, "is her Christmas." She stopped at the bottom and waited for him to say something.

"Yours is actually a bit better, then." "It's at least more respectable." And she extended her hand again. "But why am I dwelling on our problems? Come if you can."

Translation

"Yours is a bit better, actually." "At least it's more respectable." She offered her hand again. "But why am I focusing on our issues? Come if you can."

He showed a faint smile. "Thanks. If I can." "And now—I dare say—you'll go to church?"

Translation

He offered a weak smile. "Thanks. If I can." "And now—I suppose—you'll attend church?"

She had asked it, with her good intention, rather in the air and by way of sketching for him, in the line of support, something a little more to the purpose than what she had been giving him. He felt it as finishing off their intensities of expression that he found himself to all appearance receiving her hint as happy. "Why yes—I think I will": after which, as the door of the brougham, at her approach, had opened from within, he was free to turn his back. He heard the door, behind him, sharply close again and the vehicle move off in another direction than his own.

Translation

She had asked it with good intentions, almost as an afterthought, and as a way of providing him with something more useful than what she had offered so far. He felt that she was concluding their intense exchange, and that he appeared to welcome her suggestion. "Yes, I believe I will," he replied. After which, the door of the brougham had opened from within as she approached, and he was free to turn his back. He heard the door close sharply behind him, and the vehicle moved away in a direction opposite to his own.

He gave a small smile. "Thank you. If I can manage it." "And now—I suppose—you'll go to church?"

Translation

He offered a small smile. "Thank you. If I can." "And now—I suppose—you'll go to church?"

She'd asked the question, with good intentions, almost absently, as if suggesting something more helpful than what she'd offered him so far. He felt the hint as the final word in their intense exchange, and seemed pleased by it. "Yes—I believe I will": after which, as the brougham's door opened for her, he was free to turn away. He heard the door slam shut behind him and the carriage move off in the opposite direction.

Translation

She posed the question with genuine kindness, almost without thinking, as though proposing a solution more practical than anything she’d suggested up until that point. He detected the subtext as the final word in their heated discussion and appeared to welcome it. "Yes, I believe I will," he responded. After which, as the brougham's door was opened for her, he was free to depart. He heard the door shut with a bang behind him, and the carriage moved away in the opposite direction.

He had in fact for the time no direction; in spite of which indeed he was at the end of ten minutes aware of having walked straight to the south. That, he afterwards recognised, was, very sufficiently, because there had formed itself in his mind, even while Aunt Maud finally talked, an instant recognition of his necessary course. Nothing was open to him but to follow Kate, nor was anything more marked than the influence of the step she had taken on the emotion itself that possessed him. Her complications, which had fairly, with everything else, an awful sound—what were they, a thousand times over, but his own?

Translation

In truth, he had no destination for the moment, but nonetheless, after ten minutes, he realized he had been walking directly south. He understood later that this was because, even while Aunt Maud was still speaking, he had instantly recognized the direction he must take. He had no option but to follow Kate, and nothing was more clear than the effect of her action on his own feelings. Her troubles, which, along with everything else, sounded dreadful—what were they, over and over, if not his own?

His present business was to see that they didn't escape an hour longer taking their proper place in his life. He accordingly would have held his course hadn't it suddenly come over him that he had just lied to Mrs. Lowder—a term it perversely eased him to keep using—even more than was necessary. To what church was he going, to what church, in such a state of his nerves, could he go?—he pulled up short again, as he had pulled up in sight of Mrs.

Translation

His current goal was to prevent them from delaying, even by an hour, their inevitable incorporation into his life. Thus, he would have continued forward, if it hadn't suddenly occurred to him that he had just lied to Mrs. Lowder—a phrase he strangely found comforting to repeat—more than he needed to. To what church was he going, and moreover, which church, given his agitated state, could he even attend? He abruptly halted, just as he had when he had seen Mrs.

Lowder's carriage, to ask it. And yet the desire queerly stirred in him not to have wasted his word. He was just then however by a happy chance in the Brompton Road, and he bethought himself with a sudden light that the Oratory was at hand. He had but to turn the other way and he should find himself soon before it.

Translation

Lowder's carriage, to inquire about it. Yet the wish surprisingly welled up inside him not to have spoken in vain. However, by a stroke of luck, he was in Brompton Road at that moment, and it occurred to him with sudden clarity that the Oratory was nearby. He only needed to turn the other direction, and he would soon find himself in front of it.

At the door then, in a few minutes, his idea was really—as it struck him—consecrated: he was, pushing in, on the edge of a splendid service—the flocking crowd told of it—which glittered and resounded, from distant depths, in the blaze of altar-lights and the swell of organ and choir. It didn't match his own day, but it was much less of a discord than some other things actual and possible. The Oratory in short, to make him right, would do. He actually had no specific plan at that moment.

Translation

At the door, then, in a few minutes, his idea was truly—as he considered it—confirmed: he was, pushing inside, on the brink of a magnificent service—the gathering crowd signaled it—that glittered and echoed, from unseen depths, in the glow of altar lights and the surge of the organ and choir. It didn't fit his own day, but it was far less discordant than some other real and potential things. The Oratory, in short, to set him straight, would suffice. He genuinely had no specific plan at that moment.

Despite this, he realized after ten minutes that he had walked directly south. He later understood that this was primarily because he'd instantly known his necessary path, even while Aunt Maud was talking. He had no other option but to follow Kate, and the impact of her decision on his own emotions was undeniable. Her problems, which, like everything else, seemed terrible, were essentially his own, weren't they?

Translation

Despite this, ten minutes later, he realized he'd walked straight south. He later understood that this was largely due to the fact that he'd immediately known his necessary path, even while Aunt Maud was talking. He had no other choice but to follow Kate, and the impact of her decision on his own emotions was undeniable. Her problems, which, like everything else, seemed terrible, were essentially his own, weren't they?

His immediate goal was to ensure they didn't continue to evade their proper place in his life. He would have stayed on course, had he not suddenly realized he had just lied to Mrs. Lowder—a phrase he strangely found comforting to keep using—more than necessary. To which church could he go, in his current state of anxiety?

Translation

His immediate objective was to stop them from perpetually avoiding their rightful roles in his life. He would have maintained his direction, had he not abruptly realized he'd just lied to Mrs. Lowder—a phrase he oddly found reassuring to repeat—more than he should have. Considering his current state of distress, which church could he possibly attend?

He stopped abruptly to consider the question, just as he had when he saw Mrs. Lowder's carriage. Yet, he felt a strange urge not to have spoken in vain. Fortunately, he was on the Brompton Road, and it suddenly occurred to him that the Oratory was nearby.

Translation

He halted, considering the question, just as he had when he spotted Mrs. Lowder's carriage. Still, he felt a strange compulsion to ensure his words had not been wasted. Luckily, he was on Brompton Road, and it suddenly occurred to him that the Oratory was close.

He only needed to turn around, and he'd find himself there quickly. At the entrance, his plan, as he saw it, was truly confirmed: he entered on the cusp of a magnificent service—the gathering crowd indicated as much—that shone and echoed from afar, amidst the glow of altar lights and the music of the organ and choir. It didn't align with his current situation, but it was less jarring than other real and potential circumstances. The Oratory, in short, would serve his purpose.

Translation

He only needed to turn around and he'd arrive swiftly. At the entrance, his plan was confirmed: he entered just as a magnificent service was beginning—the assembled crowd signaled this—shining and echoing from a distance, amidst the glow of altar lights and the music of the organ and choir. It didn't suit his present state, but it was less disturbing than other real and potential situations. In short, the Oratory would serve his purpose.

Chapter 21

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
Kate rises and asks a man, Densher, if he is accusing her of telling someone a secret. He denies it but questions why Lord Mark is with Mrs. Lowder on Christmas morning. Kate explains that Lord Mark is staying at Mrs. Lowder's London house, Lancaster Gate, after having to rent out his own rooms. She further explains that Lord Mark stayed in town to keep her aunt, Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud), company. Densher places his hands on Kate's shoulders, shakes her gently, and kisses her cheek. Kate then reveals that while Densher was in Venice, Lord Mark spoke openly to her, but she refused him. She explains that it was Milly who ultimately convinced Lord Mark that Densher was in love with her (Milly), a story Lord Mark then told to Aunt Maud. Densher takes out a sealed letter and changes the subject, asking about Kate's father. Kate says her father is at her house, having arrived in a state of terror, and asks Densher not to question her about him. Densher then offers Kate the letter, which is from Milly. Kate notes it is unopened. He asks her to open it, but she refuses, guessing that it announces Milly has left Densher a fortune. After Densher offers the letter to her as a tribute, Kate takes it, turns to the fireplace, and throws it into the flames. They watch it burn, and she tells him he will get the official news from New York. Two months later, after Densher has received a legal document from New York, he sends it to Kate, who then visits him. She arrives with the opened envelope. Densher tells her he had hoped she would return it to him unopened and asks for her consent to refuse the inheritance. He states he will not act without her consent, which forces her to choose between him or the money. Kate then gives him an ultimatum: she will consent if he gives his word of honor that he is not in love with Milly's memory. Densher replies, "I'll marry you... in an hour... As we were." Kate turns to the door, shakes her head, and says, "We shall never be again as we were!"

The difference was thus that the dusk of afternoon—dusk thick from an early hour—had gathered when he knocked at Mrs. Condrip's door. He had gone from the church to his club, wishing not to present himself in Chelsea at luncheon-time and also remembering that he must attempt independently to make a meal. This, in the event, he but imperfectly achieved: he dropped into a chair in the great dim void of the club library, with nobody, up or down, to be seen, and there after a while, closing his eyes, recovered an hour of the sleep he had lost during the night.

Translation

The difference, therefore, was that the afternoon dusk—a dusk that thickened from a relatively early hour—had already settled when he knocked on Mrs. Condrip's door. He'd gone from the church to his club, not wanting to show up in Chelsea at lunchtime, and also remembering that he needed to try and eat something on his own. In the end, he didn't quite manage it: he slumped into a chair in the vast, shadowy emptiness of the club library, with no one around, and after a while, closing his eyes, he managed to recover an hour of the sleep he'd missed the night before.

Before doing this indeed he had written—it was the first thing he did—a short note, which, in the Christmas desolation of the place, he had managed only with difficulty and doubt to commit to a messenger. He wished it carried by hand, and he was obliged, rather blindly, to trust the hand, as the messenger, for some reason, was unable to return with a gage of delivery. When at four o'clock he was face to face with Kate in Mrs. Condrip's small drawing-room he found to his relief that his notification had reached her.

Translation

Before going to Mrs. Condrip's, he had written a short note—the first thing he did—which he'd struggled to get to a messenger in the desolate Christmas atmosphere. He wanted it delivered by hand and had to trust the messenger blindly, as for some reason, the messenger couldn't confirm delivery. When he met Kate in Mrs. Condrip's small drawing-room at four o'clock, he was relieved to find that she had received his message.

She was expectant and to that extent prepared; which simplified a little—if a little, at the present pass, counted. Her conditions were vaguely vivid to him from the moment of his coming in, and vivid partly by their difference, a difference sharp and suggestive, from those in which he had hitherto constantly seen her. He had seen her but in places comparatively great; in her aunt's pompous house, under the high trees of Kensington and the storied ceilings of Venice. He had seen her, in Venice, on a great occasion, as the centre itself of the splendid Piazza: he had seen her there, on a still greater one, in his own poor rooms, which yet had consorted with her, having state and ancientry even in their poorness; but Mrs.

Translation

She was expectant, prepared to a degree. This made things easier—slightly, if "slightly" mattered at this moment. He'd grasped her situation, vaguely but vividly, from the instant he entered. The situation was clear, in part because it was so different from the circumstances in which he'd always known her. He'd known her only in places that were, comparatively, grand. In her aunt's opulent house, beneath the tall trees of Kensington, and the storied ceilings of Venice. He'd seen her, in Venice, at a major event, as the central figure in the magnificent Piazza. He'd seen her there again, at an even grander occasion, in his own modest rooms, which, though humble, had suited her perfectly, possessing an air of dignity and age even in their shabbiness. But Mrs.

Condrip's interior, even by this best view of it and though not flagrantly mean, showed itself as a setting almost grotesquely inapt. Pale, grave and charming, she affected him at once as a distinguished stranger—a stranger to the little Chelsea street—who was making the best of a queer episode and a place of exile. The extraordinary thing was that at the end of three minutes he felt himself less appointedly a stranger in it than she. IV

Translation

Condrip's home, even considering its best aspects, and despite not being overtly shabby, revealed itself as a setting that was almost comically unsuitable. Pale, serious, and captivating, she struck him immediately as a distinguished outsider—a stranger to the small Chelsea street—who was making the best of a strange situation and a place of banishment. The remarkable thing was that after three minutes, he felt less like a stranger there than she did. IV

The difference was that the late afternoon—already dark for the time of day—had arrived when he knocked on Mrs. Condrip's door. He had gone from the church to his club, not wanting to show up in Chelsea at lunchtime, and also remembering that he had to try to find something to eat. In the end, he didn't do this very well.

Translation

The difference was that it was late afternoon—already dark, considering the time of day—when he knocked on Mrs. Condrip's door. He'd gone from the church to his club, not wanting to arrive in Chelsea at lunchtime, and also because he remembered he needed to find something to eat. In the end, he hadn't managed to do that very well.

He fell into a chair in the big, dim emptiness of the club library, where there was no one to be seen, and after a while, he closed his eyes and managed to recover an hour of sleep he had lost the night before. Before doing this, he had written—it was the first thing he did—a short note, which, in the depressing atmosphere of the club during the Christmas season, he had only managed to send with difficulty and doubt to a messenger. He wanted it delivered by hand, and he was forced, rather blindly, to trust the messenger, as for some reason the messenger couldn't return with a confirmation of delivery. When he finally met Kate in Mrs.

Translation

He slumped into a chair in the large, dimly lit emptiness of the club library, where no one was around. After a while, he closed his eyes and managed to recover an hour of sleep he'd lost the previous night. Before that, the first thing he'd done was write a short note. He'd sent it with difficulty and doubt to a messenger, given the depressing atmosphere of the club during the Christmas season. He wanted it hand-delivered and had to trust the messenger, somewhat blindly, as for some reason, the messenger couldn't come back with confirmation of delivery. When he finally met Kate in Mrs.

Condrip's small living room at four o'clock, he was relieved to find that his note had reached her. She was expecting him and, to that extent, prepared, which simplified things a little—if a little, at this point, mattered. Her situation was vaguely clear to him from the moment he entered, and vivid partly because it was so different from the situations in which he had always seen her before. He had only seen her in places that were comparatively grand: in her aunt's impressive house, under the tall trees of Kensington, and in the ornate rooms of Venice.

Translation

He was relieved to find that his note had gotten to her when he met Kate in Mrs. Condrip's small living room at four o'clock. She was expecting him and, to that extent, prepared, which made things a little easier—if a little mattered at this point. Her situation was vaguely apparent to him from the moment he entered, and striking in part because it was so different from the situations he'd always seen her in. He'd only seen her in relatively grand places: her aunt's impressive house, under the tall trees of Kensington, and in the ornate rooms of Venice.

He had seen her in Venice on a grand occasion, as the center of the beautiful Piazza; he had seen her there on an even greater one, in his own humble rooms, which still seemed to suit her, possessing dignity and age even in their simplicity. But Mrs. Condrip's interior, even seen at its best, and though not obviously cheap, showed itself to be an almost absurdly unsuitable setting. Pale, serious, and charming, she struck him immediately as a distinguished stranger—a stranger to the little Chelsea street—who was making the best of a strange situation and a place of exile.

Translation

He had seen her in Venice, the focal point of a splendid event in the Piazza. He’d seen her there again at an even more significant moment, in his own modest rooms. Those rooms, though humble, still seemed to complement her, exhibiting a sense of age and dignity despite their simplicity. But Mrs. Condrip’s interior, even in its most flattering light, and though not overtly cheap, revealed itself as a comically inadequate backdrop. Pale, solemn, and charming, she struck him at once as a distinguished outsider—a stranger to this small Chelsea street—making the best of an unfamiliar situation, a place of exile.

The extraordinary thing was that after only three minutes, he felt less like a stranger in it than she did. A part of the queerness—this was to come to him in glimpses—sprang from the air as of a general large misfit imposed on the narrow room by the scale and mass of its furniture. The objects, the ornaments were, for the sisters, clearly relics and survivals of what would, in the case of Mrs. Condrip at least, have been called better days.

Translation

The remarkable thing was that after just a few minutes, he felt less like an outsider there than she did. He would gradually understand that some of the oddness came from the sense of a grand mismatch. This feeling was imposed on the cramped room by the size and weight of the furnishings. The objects and ornaments were, for the sisters, obviously remnants and survivals of what Mrs. Condrip, at least, would have called better days.

The curtains that overdraped the windows, the sofas and tables that stayed circulation, the chimney-ornaments that reached to the ceiling and the florid chandelier that almost dropped to the floor, were so many mementoes of earlier homes and so many links with their unhappy mother. Whatever might have been in itself the quality of these elements Densher could feel the effect proceeding from them, as they lumpishly blocked out the decline of the dim day, to be ugly almost to the point of the sinister. They failed to accommodate or to compromise; they asserted their differences without tact and without taste. It was truly having a sense of Kate's own quality thus promptly to see them in reference to it.

Translation

The curtains that draped over the windows, the sofas and tables that obstructed movement, the chimney ornaments that reached for the ceiling, and the ornate chandelier that nearly touched the floor were all relics of previous residences and reminders of their unhappy mother. Regardless of their intrinsic merit, Densher could feel the effect they produced as they clumsily obscured the fading daylight, becoming ugly to the point of being almost sinister. They refused to accommodate or compromise; they emphasized their disparity without consideration or subtlety. It was, in truth, an indication of Kate’s own character to immediately perceive them in relation to her.

But that Densher had this sense was no new thing to him, nor did he in strictness need, for the hour, to be reminded of it. He only knew, by one of the tricks his imagination so constantly played him, that he was, so far as her present tension went, very specially sorry for her—which was not the view that had determined his start in the morning; yet also that he himself would have taken it all, as he might say, less hard. He could have lived in such a place; but it wasn't given to those of his complexion, so to speak, to be exiled anywhere. It was by their comparative grossness that they could somehow make shift.

Translation

But Densher's feeling of this wasn't new to him, nor did he strictly need a reminder at that moment. He only knew, by one of the tricks his imagination so often played on him, that he was, so far as her current stress was concerned, especially sorry for her—which wasn't the perspective that had driven him that morning. Yet he also knew that he himself would have handled it all, so to speak, less severely. He could have lived in such a place; but it wasn't the disposition of someone like him to be exiled anywhere. It was through their comparative resilience that they were somehow able to manage.

His natural, his inevitable, his ultimate home—left, that is, to itself—wasn't at all unlikely to be as queer and impossible as what was just round them, though doubtless in less ample masses. As he took in moreover how Kate wouldn't have been in the least the creature she was if what was just round them hadn't mismatched her, hadn't made for her a medium involving compunction in the spectator, so, by the same stroke, that became the very fact of her relation with her companions there, such a fact as filled him at once, oddly, both with assurance and with suspense. If he himself, on this brief vision, felt her as alien and as ever so unwittingly ironic, how must they not feel her and how above all must she not feel them? Part of the unsettling nature of the room—something that gradually dawned on him—came from the feeling that the furniture was too large for the space.

Translation

His natural, his inevitable, his ultimate home—left to itself—wasn't at all unlikely to be as strange and impossible as the environment surrounding them, though presumably in less voluminous quantities. Furthermore, as he considered how Kate wouldn't have been the person she was if her surroundings hadn't been mismatched with her, hadn't created an atmosphere that elicited compunction in the observer, that very circumstance defined her relationship with the people she was with, a fact that strangely filled him with both confidence and uncertainty. If he himself, on this brief observation, perceived her as alien and unknowingly ironic, how must they perceive her, and above all, how must she perceive them? Part of the unsettling quality of the room—something that gradually occurred to him—arose from the sense that the furniture was too large for the room.

The objects and decorations were, for the sisters, clearly relics from a time, especially in the case of Mrs. Condrip, that they would have considered better. The curtains draped over the windows, the sofas and tables that took up too much room, the ornaments on the mantelpiece that reached the ceiling, and the elaborate chandelier that nearly touched the floor were reminders of past homes and links to their unhappy mother. Regardless of their individual qualities, Densher could sense the effect these things had on the room, as they awkwardly blocked out the fading light, creating a sense of ugliness that was almost sinister.

Translation

For the sisters, the objects and decorations were obviously relics from a time they would have deemed superior, particularly in Mrs. Condrip's case. The curtains hung across the windows, the sofas and tables that consumed too much space, the ornaments on the mantelpiece that stretched towards the ceiling, and the ornate chandelier that almost brushed the floor all served as reminders of previous homes and their connection to their unhappy mother. Densher could sense the effect these objects had on the room, regardless of their individual characteristics. They awkwardly obstructed the fading light, producing a sense of ugliness that bordered on sinister.

They didn't fit in or try to blend; they emphasized their differences in a way that lacked both tact and good taste. Understanding Kate's character meant seeing these things in relation to her. But Densher already understood Kate, and he didn't need to be reminded of her now. He simply knew, thanks to a trick of his imagination, that he felt especially sorry for her, given her current state—which wasn't how he had felt when he started his day.

Translation

They didn't belong, and they didn't try to. They highlighted their otherness with a lack of subtlety and elegance. To understand Kate, one had to see these things as connected to her. But Densher already understood Kate, and he didn't need a refresher. He just knew, through some quirk of his own mind, that he felt a specific sense of pity for her, given how things were at the moment—which wasn't the way he'd felt earlier.

But he also knew that he, himself, would have handled the situation, you could say, with less difficulty. He could have lived in such a place, but he realized that people like him weren't destined to be outcasts. It was their comparative lack of refinement that allowed them to cope. His natural, inevitable, and ultimate home—if left to its own devices—was likely to be just as odd and impossible as the environment surrounding them, although probably on a smaller scale.

Translation

He also knew that he, personally, would have managed the situation with more ease. He could have lived in that kind of place, but he understood that people like him weren't meant to be outsiders. It was their lack of subtlety that made it possible for them to get by. His natural home—the place he would inevitably end up in if left to his own instincts—was probably going to be just as strange and impossible as the world around him, though likely in a more contained way.

And as he realized that Kate wouldn't be the same person if the things around her didn't clash with her, didn't create a situation that caused the observer to feel compassion, he understood that this was the very essence of her relationship with the people she was with, a fact that filled him with both confidence and uncertainty. If he, in this short visit, saw her as distant and unintentionally ironic, how must they feel about her, and, above all, how must she feel about them? Densher could ask himself that even after she had presently lighted the tall candles on the mantel-shelf. This was all their illumination but the fire, and she had proceeded to it with a quiet dryness that yet left play, visibly, to her implication between them, in their trouble and failing anything better, of the presumably genial Christmas hearth.

Translation

And as he grasped that Kate wouldn't be the same if the things around her didn't grate against her, if they didn't create circumstances that evoked compassion in an observer, he understood that this was the very core of her relationships with the people she was with, a realization that filled him with both assurance and unease. If he, in this brief visit, perceived her as detached and unintentionally sarcastic, how must they perceive her, and, most importantly, how must she perceive them? Densher could ponder this even after she had lit the tall candles on the mantelpiece. This was their only light besides the fire, and she had gone about it with a quiet composure that still allowed a visible element of play to her implication between them, in their trouble and failing everything else, of the presumably cheerful Christmas hearth.

So far as the genial went this had in strictness, given their conditions, to be all their geniality. He had told her in his note nothing but that he must promptly see her and that he hoped she might be able to make it possible; but he understood from the first look at her that his promptitude was already having for her its principal reference. "I was prevented this morning, in the few minutes," he explained, "asking Mrs. Lowder if she had let you know, though I rather gathered she had; and it's what I've been in fact since then assuming.

Translation

As far as friendliness went, this was, strictly speaking, all the friendliness they could muster, given their circumstances. In his note, he had only said that he had to see her immediately and that he hoped she could make it happen. However, he understood from the moment he saw her that his urgency was already the most significant thing to her. "I was prevented this morning, in those few minutes," he explained, "from asking Mrs. Lowder if she had informed you, though I rather assumed she had. And that's what I've been assuming ever since."

It was because I was so struck at the moment with your having, as she did tell me, so suddenly come here." Densher could wonder about this even after she lit the tall candles on the mantel. This, along with the fire, was their only light. She had gone about it with a quiet efficiency that still allowed for a sense of connection between them, considering their problem, and in the absence of anything else, the supposed cheer of the Christmas fire.
