Translation

"She hasn't said a word to me. But that doesn't change anything—if that's what you mean." "It's partially what I mean," Densher said; but whatever he was going to say next, after a pause, during which she waited, wasn't the rest of it. "She received a telegram from Mrs.

Stringham; late last night. But she hasn't wired me. The event," he added, "will have happened yesterday, and Sir Luke, leaving immediately, as one would imagine, and travelling without delay, will return tomorrow morning. So that Mrs.

Translation

Stringham is practically back. I haven't heard from her. The occasion," he continued, "will have occurred yesterday, and Sir Luke, departing immediately, as one might expect, and travelling without pause, will be back tomorrow morning. Which means Mrs.

Stringham, I assume, is left to deal with the situation that's been left to her, all alone. But of course," he finished, "Sir Luke couldn't stay." Her look at him might have had in it a vague betrayal of the sense that he was gaining time. "Was your telegram from Sir Luke?"

Translation

Stringham, I suppose, is left to handle the problem, entirely on her own. But of course," he finished, "Sir Luke couldn't stay." The way she looked at him may have vaguely suggested that she felt he was stalling. "Was your telegram from Sir Luke?"

"No—I've had no telegram." She wondered. "But not a letter—?" "Not from Mrs.

Translation

"No—I haven't received a telegram." She paused, considering. "But a letter—?" "Not from Mrs. Erdleigh."

Stringham—no." He failed again however to develop this—for which her forbearance from another question gave him occasion. From whom then had he heard? He might at last, confronted with her, really have been gaining time; and as if to show that she respected this impulse she made her enquiry different. "Should you like to go out to her—to Mrs.

Translation

"Stringham—no." However, he couldn't expand on this, a fact that her patience with his silence allowed. Then, from whom had he heard? He might have been stalling, finally, when faced with her; and as if to show she respected this impulse, she phrased her question differently. "Would you like to visit her—Mrs.

Stringham?" About that at least he was clear. "Not at all. She's alone, but she's very capable and very courageous.

Translation

Stringham?" At least he knew the answer to that. "Not at all. She's alone, but she's very capable and very courageous."

Besides—!" He had been going on, but he dropped. Her expression hinted, perhaps unconsciously, that he was stalling. "Did you get a telegram from Sir Luke?" "No, I haven't received any telegrams."

Translation

"Besides—!" He had been saying more, but then he stopped. Her expression suggested, perhaps without her realizing it, that he was evading the issue. "Did you receive a telegram from Sir Luke?" "No, I haven't gotten any telegrams."

She was puzzled. "Not even a letter?" "Not from Mrs. Stringham, no." He didn't elaborate, and she refrained from asking another question, giving him an opening.

Translation

She was confused. "Not even a letter?" "No, not from Mrs. Stringham." He didn't offer any more information, and she didn't press him, leaving him room to speak.

So, who had he heard from? He might actually have been buying time in her presence. As if acknowledging his need for it, she changed her line of questioning. "Would you want to visit her—Mrs.

Translation

Stringham—if you could?" The question hung in the air. He looked at her, considering. "Yes," he said. "I would."

Stringham?" He was definite on this point. "Not at all. She's alone, but she's resourceful and brave.

Translation

Stringham? Absolutely not. She's alone, but she's resourceful and brave.

Besides—!" He stopped abruptly. "Besides," she said, "there's Eugenio? Yes, of course one remembers Eugenio." She had uttered the words as definitely to show them for not untender; and he showed equally every reason to assent.

Translation

Besides—!" He cut himself off. "Besides," she said, "there's Eugenio? Yes, naturally one remembers Eugenio." She spoke the words to prove they weren't unkind; and he showed every sign of agreeing.

"One remembers him indeed, and with every ground for it. He'll be of the highest value to her—he's capable of anything. What I was going to say," he went on, "is that some of their people from America must quickly arrive." On this, as happened, Kate was able at once to satisfy him.

Translation

"One does remember him, absolutely, and for good reason. He'll be incredibly helpful to her—he's capable of anything. What I was about to say," he continued, "is that some of their people from America need to get here quickly." On this point, as it happened, Kate was immediately able to reassure him.

"Mr. Someone-or-other, the person principally in charge of Milly's affairs—her first trustee, I suppose—had just got there at Mrs. Stringham's last writing." "Ah that then was after your aunt last spoke to me—I mean the last time before this morning.

Translation

"Mr. So-and-So, the man primarily responsible for Milly's affairs—her first trustee, I believe—had just arrived when Mrs. Stringham last wrote." "Oh, so that was after your aunt last spoke to me—I mean, the last time before this morning."

I'm relieved to hear it. So," he said, "they'll do." "And," she added, "there's Eugenio? Certainly, one remembers Eugenio."

Translation

I'm glad to hear that. So," he said, "they'll work out." "And," she added, "there's Eugenio? Of course, one remembers Eugenio."

She spoke the words with a gentleness that was clear to see. He, in turn, readily agreed. "Yes, I remember him, and with good reason. He'll be extremely helpful to her—he can handle anything.

Translation

Her words were spoken with a palpable softness. He, for his part, assented at once. "Yes, I remember him, and for good cause. He'll be extraordinarily helpful to her—he can manage anything."

What I was about to say," he continued, "is that some of their relatives from America should be arriving soon." To this, as luck would have it, Kate had an immediate answer. "Mr. So-and-so, the man primarily responsible for Milly's affairs—her primary advisor, I imagine—had just arrived at Mrs.

Translation

"What I was going to say," he continued, "is that some of their relatives from America are expected soon." By chance, Kate had an immediate reply. "Mr. So-and-so, the man primarily in charge of Milly's affairs—her main advisor, I suppose—had just arrived at Mrs.

Stringham's last communication." "Oh, so that was after your aunt last spoke to me—I mean, the last time before this morning. I'm glad to hear it. Well," he said, "then they'll be fine."

Translation

"The last Mrs. Stringham heard from him," Kate responded. "The man who handled Milly's business, her main contact, I imagine, had just arrived."

"Oh, so that was after my aunt last spoke to me—I mean, the last time before this morning. I'm glad to hear it. Well," he said, "then they'll be fine."

"Oh they'll do." And it came from each still as if it wasn't what each was most thinking of. Kate presently got however a step nearer to that. "But if you had been wired to by nobody what then this morning had taken you to Sir Luke?" "Oh something else—which I'll presently tell you.

Translation

"Oh, they'll be alright." The words seemed to slip out, each speaker implying they weren't the central thought. But Kate soon approached the real issue. "But if you hadn't gotten a telegram, what then would have brought you to Sir Luke this morning?" "Oh, something else—I'll tell you presently."

It's what made me instantly need to see you; it's what I've come to speak to you of. But in a minute. I feel too many things," he went on, "at seeing you in this place." He got up as he spoke; she herself remained perfectly still. His movement had been to the fire, and, leaning a little, with his back to it, to look down on her from where he stood, he confined himself to his point.

Translation

That’s what made me have to see you immediately; it's what I've come to talk to you about. But not yet. I'm feeling too many things," he continued, "being here and seeing you in this place." He stood up as he said this; she stayed completely still. He had moved toward the fire, and he leaned a little, with his back to it, looking down at her from where he was standing, and he focused on what he wanted to say.

"Is it anything very bad that has brought you?" "Oh, they'll be fine," they both said, almost like it wasn't the main thing on their minds. Kate soon came closer to the actual question. "But if no one had contacted you, what would have led you to Sir Luke this morning?"

Translation

"Is something terrible the reason you're here?"

"Oh, it's nothing," they both said, as if it was a minor detail. Kate then moved closer to the point. "But if no one had reached out to you, what would have brought you to Sir Luke this morning?"

"Oh, something else—which I'll tell you in a moment. It's what made me have to see you immediately; it's what I've come to discuss. But not just yet. I'm feeling too many things," he continued, "being here with you." He stood up as he spoke, but she remained perfectly still.

Translation

"Something else—I'll get to it in a second. It's the reason I needed to see you right away, what I'm here to talk about. But not yet. I'm feeling too much," he continued, "being here with you." He stood, but she didn't move.

He moved toward the fireplace, and, leaning a little, with his back to it, he looked down at her. He then focused on his question. "Has something bad happened to bring you here?" He had now in any case said enough to justify her wish for more; so that, passing this matter by, she pressed her own challenge.

Translation

He went over to the fireplace, and, slanting his body, he leaned against it, gazing down at her. He then prepared himself for his question. "Did something awful occur to bring you here?" He had by this point spoken enough to validate her wanting to hear more; therefore, she bypassed this subject and immediately issued her own challenge.

"Do you mean, if I may ask, that she, dying—?" Her face, wondering, pressed it more than her words. "Certainly you may ask," he after a moment said. "What has come to me is what, as I say, I came expressly to tell you. I don't mind letting you know," he went on, "that my decision to do this took for me last night and this morning a great deal of thinking of.

Translation

"Are you asking," she began, as if hesitant, "if—I mean, did she, dying—?" Her expression of inquiry said more than her words. "You certainly may ask," he replied after a moment. "What I have to say is, as I mentioned, the very reason I'm here. I don't mind telling you," he continued, "that making this decision involved a great deal of thought on my part, last night and this morning."

But here I am." And he indulged in a smile that couldn't, he was well aware, but strike her as mechanical. She went straighter with him, she seemed to show, than he really went with her. "You didn't want to come?" He had spoken sufficiently to encourage her curiosity, and she seized the opportunity, ignoring the previous topic.

Translation

"But here I am." He offered a smile, fully aware it would seem forced. She was more direct with him, he thought, than he was with her. "You didn't want to come?" He'd piqued her interest, and she took the chance, abandoning their previous subject.

"Are you saying," she asked, her expression questioning, "that she, in her dying moments—?" Her face conveyed her curiosity more than her words. "Certainly, you can ask," he replied after a pause. Translation

"Are you suggesting," she asked, her expression questioning, "that she, in her final moments—?" Her face revealed her curiosity more than her words. "Of course, you can ask," he replied after a pause. "I came here specifically to tell you what happened. I don't mind sharing," he continued, "that the decision to do this took a lot of consideration last night and this morning."

But here I am." He offered a smile that, he knew, must appear forced. She confronted him directly, appearing more candid than he felt himself. "You didn't want to come?" "It would have been simple, my dear"—and he continued to smile—"if it had been, one way or the other, only a question of 'wanting.' It took, I admit it, the idea of what I had best do, all sorts of difficult and portentous forms.

Translation

"But here I am." He gave a smile that he knew was unconvincing. She looked at him directly, appearing more honest than he felt. "You didn't want to come?" "It would have been easy, my dear"—and he kept smiling—"if it had just been a question of 'wanting.' It became, I admit, a question of what I ought to do, with all sorts of complex and ominous considerations."

It came up for me really—well, not at all for my happiness." This word apparently puzzled her—she studied him in the light of it. "You look upset—you've certainly been tormented. You're not well."

Translation

"It wasn't about me, not really—well, not at all for my own good." That word seemed to make her think—she considered him in light of it. "You look troubled—you've clearly been through something. You're not yourself."

"Oh—well enough!" But she continued without heeding. "You hate what you're doing." "My dear girl, you simplify"—and he was now serious enough.

Translation

"Oh, fine!" But she kept going, not paying any attention. "You hate what you're doing." "My dear, you're making this too simple"—and he was actually serious now.

"It isn't so simple even as that." She had the air of thinking what it then might be. "I of course can't, with no clue, know what it is." She remained none the less patient and still. "If at such a moment she could write you one's inevitably quite at sea.

Translation

"It's not even that simple." She seemed to be considering what it could be. "I obviously can't know, not having a clue."

She remained nonetheless patient and still. "If at a moment like that she could write you, one's inevitably quite lost."

One doesn't, with the best will in the world, understand." And then as Densher had a pause which might have stood for all the involved explanation that, to his discouragement, loomed before him: "You haven't decided what to do." "It would have been easy, my dear"—and he kept smiling—"if it had simply been about 'wanting' something. The idea of what I should do, I confess, took on all kinds of complex and serious forms. It really came down to me—well, not concerning my happiness at all."

Translation

"One simply doesn't understand, no matter how hard one tries." Then, during Densher's pause, which could have been interpreted as all the intricate explanations that, frustratingly, lay ahead: "You still haven't made a decision." "It would have been so easy, my dear"—he kept smiling—"if it had simply been a matter of 'wanting' something. The idea of what I should do, I admit, took on so many complex and serious forms. It really came down to me—well, not concerning my happiness at all."

This word seemed to confuse her—she examined him carefully, trying to understand. "You seem troubled—you've clearly been distressed. You don't look well." "Oh—I'm fine!"

Translation

The word seemed to puzzle her. She studied him closely, searching for answers. "You appear troubled, distressed even. You don't look well." "Oh, I'm fine!"

But she didn't pay attention. "You hate what you're doing." "My dear, you're making it too easy"—and he was now quite serious. "It's not that simple."

Translation

She disregarded him. "You hate your work." "Darling, you're making this too simple"—and now his tone was earnest. "It's not that easy."

She seemed to be wondering what it actually was, then. "I can't possibly know, not having any idea." She remained patient and quiet. "If at a moment like this, she could write to you...it's inevitable that one is utterly confused. Even with the best intentions, one doesn't understand." Then, as Densher paused, allowing for all the complicated explanations that lay before him, to his frustration: "You haven't decided what to do."

Translation

She appeared to be considering the truth of the matter. "I can't possibly know, because I haven't the slightest clue." She remained composed and silent. "If, at a moment like this, she could write to you...it's inevitable that one is utterly confused. Even with the best of intentions, one doesn't understand." Then, as Densher paused, expecting all of the complex explanations that were still to come, much to his irritation: "You haven't made up your mind."

She had said it very gently, almost sweetly, and he didn't instantly say otherwise. But he said so after a look at her. "Oh yes—I have. Only with this sight of you here and what I seem to see in it for you—!" And his eyes, as at suggestions that pressed, turned from one part of the room to another.

Translation

She had spoken very softly, almost tenderly, and he didn't immediately disagree. But he did after looking at her. "Oh yes, I have. Only with the sight of you here and what I seem to see in it for you—!" And his eyes, as if responding to a multitude of unspoken implications, darted around the room.

"Horrible place, isn't it?" said Kate. It brought him straight back to his enquiry. "Is it for anything awful you've had to come?" "Oh that will take as long to tell you as anything you may have.

Translation

"Terrible place, isn't it?" Kate said. It pulled him right back to his question. "Is it something awful that brought you here?" "Oh, that'll take as long to tell you as whatever it is you have."

She had spoken very softly, almost sweetly, and he didn't immediately disagree.

Translation

"Pay no mind," she continued, "to my being here, or whatever may befall me—which is more than I understand yet. And consider, too, that if you're in trouble, I'd like to help you a bit. Perhaps I even can." She spoke very softly, almost kindly, and he didn't immediately object.

But he did after looking at her. "Oh yes—I have. Except with seeing you here, and considering what this might mean for you—!" His eyes, as if responding to various suggestions, moved around the room. "It's a terrible place, isn't it?" said Kate.

Translation

But he did object after looking at her. "Oh yes—I have. Except for seeing you here, and considering what this might mean for you—!" His eyes, as if responding to various suggestions, moved around the room. "It's a terrible place, isn't it?" said Kate.

Her comment immediately redirected him to his question. "Did you have to come here because of something awful?" "That will take just as long to explain as anything you might have. Don't worry about 'seeing me here,' or whatever—which I still don't know—'it' might mean for me.

Translation

He immediately refocused on his own question. "Did something terrible bring you here?" "Explaining that would take just as long as anything you might want to explain. Don't worry about 'seeing me here,' or whatever—which I still don't understand—'it' might mean for me."

And please consider that, after all, if you're in trouble, I might want to help you a little. Perhaps I can actually do it." "My dear child, it's just because of the sense of your wish—! Translation

"And please consider that, after all, if you're in trouble, I might want to help you a little. Perhaps I can actually do it." "My dear child, it's just because of the sense of your wish—! I suppose I'm in trouble—I suppose that's it." He said this with such odd, sudden simplicity that she could only stare at him—which he as promptly saw.

So he turned off as he could his vagueness. "And yet I oughtn't to be." Which sounded indeed vaguer still. She waited a moment. "Is it, as you say for my own business, anything very awful?"

Translation

So he tried to drop his evasiveness. "And yet I shouldn't be." Which actually sounded even more vague. She paused. "Is it, as you say, my business that's so awful?"

"Well," he slowly replied, "you'll tell me if you find it so. I mean if you find my idea—" He was so slow that she took him up. "Awful?" A sound of impatience—the form of a laugh—at last escaped her.

Translation

"Well," he replied slowly, "you'll let me know if you think so. I mean, if you think my idea—" He was so hesitant that she cut him off. "Awful?"

A sound of impatience—the shape of a laugh—finally escaped her.

"I can't find it anything at all till I know what you're talking about." "My dear, it's because I understand your wishes!" He then abruptly stated, "I suppose I'm in trouble. I suppose that's the situation." His sudden candor was so unusual that she could only gawk at him, a reaction he immediately noticed. Quickly, he attempted to hide his uncertainty.

Translation

"I can't even begin to have an opinion until I know what you're referring to." "Darling, it's because I understand what you want!" He then said abruptly, "I suppose I'm in trouble. I guess that's the reality of it." His sudden honesty was so unexpected that she could only stare at him, a reaction he immediately registered. Quickly, he attempted to mask his uncertainty.

"And yet, I shouldn't be." But this sounded even more vague. She paused, waiting. "Is this regarding my own affairs? Is it something truly terrible?"

Translation

"And yet, I shouldn't be," he said, which sounded even more ambiguous than before. She waited, letting the silence hang. "Is this about me? About something awful?"

He responded slowly, "Well, you will be the judge of that. I mean, if you find my idea—" He was speaking so slowly that she interrupted him. "Terrible?" Annoyance—a slight laugh—finally escaped her.

Translation

He answered slowly, "Well, you'll be the one to decide. I mean, if you think my idea—" He was speaking so slowly that she cut him off. "Terrible?" Annoyance—a slight laugh—finally escaped her.

"I can't judge it until I know what you're talking about." It brought him then more to the point, though it did so at first but by making him, on the hearthrug before her, with his hands in his pockets, turn awhile to and fro. There rose in him even with this movement a recall of another time—the hour in Venice, the hour of gloom and storm, when Susan Shepherd had sat in his quarters there very much as Kate was sitting now, and he had wondered, in pain even as now, what he might say and mightn't. Yet the present occasion after all was somehow the easier.

Translation

"I can't form an opinion until I know what you're suggesting." This prompted him to be more direct, though initially, it only caused him to pace back and forth on the hearthrug in front of her, his hands in his pockets. This movement even triggered a memory—that time in Venice, during a dark and stormy hour, when Susan Shepherd had been seated in his quarters much like Kate was now, and he had struggled, just as he was now, to decide what he could and couldn't say. But, when it came down to it, this current situation was somehow easier.

He tried at any rate to attach that feeling to it while he stopped before his companion. "The communication I speak of can't possibly belong—so far as its date is concerned—to these last days. The postmark, which is legible, does; but it isn't thinkable, for anything else, that she wrote—!" He dropped, looking at her as if she'd understand. It brought him to the point, although it initially made him pace back and forth on the hearth rug in front of her, his hands in his pockets.

Translation

He tried, at any rate, to pin down that feeling as he stopped before his companion. "The communication I'm talking about can't possibly have happened—as far as its date goes—in the last few days. The postmark, which is readable, does; but it's unthinkable, otherwise, that she wrote—!" He trailed off, looking at her as if she'd know what he meant. It got him to the point, even though it started him pacing back and forth on the hearth rug in front of her, his hands in his pockets.

This movement evoked a memory—the gloomy, stormy hour in Venice when Susan Shepherd had sat in his lodgings much like Kate was sitting now. He had agonized then, as he was now, over what he could and couldn't say. Yet, somehow, the current situation was easier. He tried to cling to that feeling as he stopped before his companion.

Translation

The gesture triggered a memory—the dark, tempestuous evening in Venice when Susan Shepherd had been in his rooms, positioned much like Kate was now. He had been tormented then, just as he was currently, by what he could and couldn't express. However, the present circumstances felt, in some way, less fraught. He attempted to hold onto that sensation as he paused before her.

"The message I'm talking about definitely doesn't relate to these last few days, date-wise. The postmark does, but it's impossible that she wrote—!" He trailed off, looking at her as if she would understand. It was easy to understand. "On her deathbed?" But Kate took an instant's thought.

Translation

"The message I'm talking about definitely isn't from the last few days, in terms of the date. The postmark is relevant, but there's no way she wrote—!" He stopped, looking at her like she'd know. It was easy to follow. "On her deathbed?"

Kate considered it for a moment.

"Aren't we agreed that there was never any one in the world like her?" "Yes." And looking over her head he spoke clearly enough. "There was never any one in the world like her." Kate, from her chair, always without a movement, raised her eyes to the unconscious reach of his own.

Translation

"Don't we all

agree that there was no one in the world like

her?" "Yes." And looking over her head he spoke clearly

enough. "There was no one in the world like

her." Kate, from her chair, always motionless,

raised her eyes to the unconscious reach of his own.

Then when the latter again dropped to her she added a question. "And won't it further depend a little on what the communication is?" "A little perhaps—but not much. It's a communication," said Densher.

Translation

Then, when the second woman turned her attention back to her, she added a question. "And won't it also depend, at least a little, on the content of the message?" "Perhaps a little, but not much. It's a message," Densher replied.

"Do you mean a letter?" "Yes, a letter. Addressed to me in her hand—in hers unmistakeably." Kate thought.

Translation

"You mean a letter?" "Yes, a letter. Written to me in her own hand—undeniably hers." Kate considered this.

"Do you know her hand very well?" It was simple to grasp. "On her deathbed?" Kate paused for a moment.

Translation

"Do you recognize her handwriting?" It was easy to understand. "While she was dying?" Kate hesitated.

"Don't we all agree that there was nobody else like her?" "Yes." He looked over her head and spoke clearly. "There was nobody else like her." Kate, still seated, never moving, lifted her eyes to meet his.

Translation

"Wouldn't we all concur that she was one of a kind?" "Yes." He looked past her and spoke with clarity. "She was one of a kind." Kate, remaining seated, motionless, raised her gaze to meet his.

Then, when his gaze returned to her, she asked another question. "And won't it also depend a bit on what the message is?" "Maybe a little—but not much. It's a message," Densher said.

Translation

When he looked back at her, she asked another question. "And doesn't it also depend on the message?" "Maybe a little, but not much. It's a message," Densher said.

"You mean a letter?" "Yes, a letter. Written by her—in her own hand, undeniably." Kate considered this.

Translation

"You mean a letter?" "Yes, a letter. Written by her—in her own hand, undeniably." Kate considered this.

"Do you know her handwriting very well?" "Oh perfectly." It was as if his tone for this prompted—with a slight strangeness—her next demand. "Have you had many letters from her?"

Translation

"Are you familiar with her handwriting?" "Completely." It was as if his answer, with a subtle peculiarity, spurred her next question. "Have you received many letters from her?"

"No. Only three notes." He spoke looking straight at her. "And very, very short ones." "Ah," said Kate, "the number doesn't matter.

Translation

"No. Just three notes." He looked directly at her. "And they were very, very brief." "Ah," said Kate, "the number doesn't matter."

Three lines would be enough if you're sure you remember." "I'm sure I remember. Besides," Densher continued, "I've seen her hand in other ways. I seem to recall how you once, before she went to Venice, showed me one of her notes precisely for that.

Translation

"Three lines would be enough if you're certain you recall them." "I am certain. Also," Densher continued, "I've seen her handwriting in other contexts. I seem to remember that you once, before she traveled to Venice, showed me one of her notes for that exact reason."

And then she once copied me something." "Oh," said Kate almost with a smile, "I don't ask you for the detail of your reasons. One good one's enough." To which however she added as if precisely not to speak with impatience or with anything like irony: "And the writing has its usual look?" "Yes, absolutely."

Translation

"And then she once copied me something."

"Oh," Kate said, almost smiling, "I don't need you to give me all the reasons. One good one is enough." But then she added, as if trying not to sound impatient or even ironic: "And the handwriting looks the same?"

"Yes, absolutely."

It was as if his tone had triggered—somewhat surprisingly—her next question. "Have you received many letters from her?" "No. Only three short notes." He spoke, looking directly at her.

Translation

It was as if his inflection had somehow prompted her next question. "Have you gotten many letters from her?" "No. Just three brief notes." He replied, meeting her gaze.

"Very, very brief ones." "Oh," Kate said. "The number isn't important. Three lines would be sufficient if you remember them clearly."

Translation

"Very, very brief ones," he repeated. "Oh," Kate said. "The quantity isn't significant. Three lines are enough if you recall them well."

"I do remember. Furthermore," Densher continued, "I've seen her handwriting in other contexts. I seem to recall how you once, before she went to Venice, showed me one of her notes specifically to demonstrate that. And she once copied something for me."

Translation

"I do," Densher went on. "Plus, I've seen her handwriting in other places. I think you actually showed me one of her notes at some point, before she went to Venice, just to prove the point. And she copied something for me once."

"Oh," Kate said, almost smiling. "I'm not asking for all the specific reasons. One good reason is enough." However, she added, as though determined not to sound impatient or sarcastic: "And the handwriting looks the same as always?" Densher answered as if even to better that description of it.

Translation

"Oh," Kate said, almost smiling, "I'm not asking for all the reasons. One good one is enough." But then, as if she were determined not to sound impatient or sarcastic, she added, "And the handwriting looks the same as always?" Densher answered, almost as if to improve upon that description of it.

"It's beautiful." "Yes—it was beautiful. Well," Kate, to defer to him still, further remarked, "it's not news to us now that she was stupendous. Anything's possible."

Translation

"It's beautiful." "Yes—it was beautiful. Well," Kate added, still deferring to him, "it's no surprise to us that she was amazing. Anything's possible."

"Yes, anything's possible"—he appeared oddly to catch at it. "That's what I say to myself. It's what I've been believing you," he a trifle vaguely explained, "still more certain to feel." She waited for him to say more, but he only, with his hands in his pockets, turned again away, going this time to the single window of the room, where in the absence of lamplight the blind hadn't been drawn.

Translation

"Yes, anything's possible"—he seemed oddly fixated on the thought. "That's what I tell myself. It's what I've been believing, you see," he explained, a little vaguely, "I'm even more sure of it." She waited for him to continue, but he just turned away, his hands in his pockets, and walked over to the single window in the room, where the blind hadn't been drawn, since there was no lamplight.

He looked out into the lamplit fog, lost himself in the small sordid London street—for sordid, with his other association, he felt it—as he had lost himself, with Mrs. Stringham's eyes on him, in the vista of the Grand Canal. It was present then to his recording consciousness that when he had last been driven to such an attitude the very depth of his resistance to the opportunity to give Kate away was what had so driven him. His waiting companion had on that occasion waited for him to say he would; and what he had meantime glowered forth at was the inanity of such a hope.

Translation

He gazed out at the lamplit fog, immersing himself in the squalid little London street—because, considering his other associations, he perceived it as such—just as he'd become lost in the panorama of the Grand Canal, with Mrs. Stringham’s gaze upon him. It struck his reflective consciousness then that the last time he’d adopted this stance, it had been the very intensity of his reluctance to betray Kate that had propelled him to it. On that occasion, his companion had waited for him to agree; and what he had been glaring at in the meantime was the utter futility of such an expectation.

Kate's attention, on her side, during these minutes, rested on the back and shoulders he thus familiarly presented—rested as with a view of their expression, a reference to things unimparted, links still missing and that she must ever miss, try to make them out as she would. The result of her tension was that she again took him up. "You received—what you spoke of—last night?" Densher responded as if to amplify that assessment.

Translation

During those moments, Kate's focus remained on the back and shoulders he presented so casually. She seemed to study their unspoken language, the secrets they held, the connections still missing and that she would never fully grasp, no matter how hard she tried. The consequence of her intense concentration was that she addressed him again. "Did you receive—what you mentioned—last night?" Densher responded as if to emphasize that exact point.

"It's beautiful." "Yes—it was beautiful. Well," Kate added, still trying to accommodate him, "it's not news to us now that she was amazing. Anything's possible."

Translation

"It's beautiful." "Yes—it was beautiful. Well," Kate added, still trying to understand him, "it's not new information to us that she was amazing. Anything's possible."

"Yes, anything's possible"—he seemed to seize upon it in a strange way. "That's what I tell myself. It's what I've been believing you," he said, sounding a bit vague, "and growing more certain of." She waited for him to elaborate, but he only turned away, hands in his pockets, and went to the room's single window, where the blind hadn't been pulled down because there was no lamplight.

Translation

"Yes, anything's possible"—he latched onto the phrase in a peculiar manner. "That's what I keep telling myself. That's what I've been believing, you see," he said, his voice a little distant, "and becoming more and more sure of." She waited for him to say more, but he just turned away, his hands shoved in his pockets, and walked over to the room's sole window, where the blind wasn't drawn because there wasn't any light from a lamp.

He gazed out into the fog, illuminated by streetlights, losing himself in the small, dingy London street—he thought of it as dingy, associating it with other things—just as he had lost himself in the view of the Grand Canal, while Mrs. Stringham watched him. He realized that the last time he'd taken up that stance, he'd been driven to it by his strong resistance to the idea of giving Kate up. His waiting companion had, on that occasion, waited for him to agree to it; and what he'd been glaring at was the absurdity of such a hope.

Translation

He stared out at the fog, lit by the streetlights, and lost himself in the little, gloomy London street—he considered it gloomy, connecting it to other things—the same way he'd lost himself looking at the Grand Canal, while Mrs. Stringham watched him. He understood that the last time he'd stood like this, he'd been driven to it by his complete refusal to accept the idea of losing Kate. On that occasion, the person waiting for him had been waiting for him to agree; and what he'd been glaring at was how ridiculous that hope was.

Kate, meanwhile, focused on his back and shoulders, presented so familiarly to her—studying their expression, considering unsaid things, missing connections that she would always miss, no matter how hard she tried to understand. Her intense focus led her to speak again. "Did you get—what you mentioned—last night?" It made him turn round.

Translation

Kate, in the meantime, was concentrating on his back and shoulders, so familiar to her—examining the way they looked, thinking about unspoken things, the links she would always miss, no matter how hard she tried to understand them. The intensity of her focus made her speak again. "Did you get—the thing you mentioned—last night?" This made him turn around.

"Coming in from Fleet Street—earlier by an hour than usual—I found it with some other letters on my table. But my eyes went straight to it, in an extraordinary way, from the door. I recognised it, knew what it was, without touching it." "One can understand." She listened with respect.

Translation

"I got it when I came in from Fleet Street, an hour earlier than I usually do. I found it on my table with a few other letters. But my eyes went right to it the second I walked in the door, in this really strange way. I knew it, I knew what it was, without even picking it up." "That's understandable," she said, listening respectfully.

His tone however was so singular that she presently added: "You speak as if all this while you hadn't touched it." "Oh yes, I've touched it. I feel as if, ever since, I'd been touching nothing else. I quite firmly," he pursued as if to be plainer, "took hold of it."

Translation

However, his tone was so odd that she added, "You speak as if you hadn't touched it all this time." "Oh yes, I've touched it. I feel as if I've been touching nothing else ever since. I definitely," he continued, as if to be clearer, "picked it up."

"Then where is it?" "Oh I have it here." "And you've brought it to show me?" He turned around, compelled.

Translation

"So, where is it?" "Right here." "And you brought it to show me?" He spun around, pulled by something.

"Arriving from Fleet Street—an hour sooner than normal—I found it with some other mail on my desk. But my eyes went directly to it, in a remarkable manner, from the doorway. I recognized it, knew what it was, without even picking it up." "That's understandable." She listened attentively.

Translation

"It came from Fleet Street, an hour early, and I found it with the rest of the mail on my desk. But my eyes went straight to it, in a remarkable way, as soon as I entered the room. I knew what it was, recognized it, without even touching it." "I see." She listened with interest.

His voice was so peculiar that she soon added, "You speak as though you hadn't touched it all this time." "Oh yes, I have touched it. I feel as if, since then, I've been touching nothing else. I definitely," he continued as if to clarify, "picked it up."

Translation

His voice was strange enough that she quickly commented, "You sound like you haven't touched it since." "Oh, but I have. I feel like I've been touching nothing *but* it ever since. I definitely," he went on, as if to make it clear, "picked it up."

"So where is it?" "Oh, I have it here." "And you brought it to show me?" "I've brought it to show you."

Translation

"So, where is it?"

"Oh, I have it here."

"And you brought it to show me?"

"I've brought it to show you."

So he said with a distinctness that had, among his other oddities, almost a sound of cheer, yet making no movement that matched his words. She could accordingly but offer again her expectant face, while his own, to her impatience, seemed perversely to fill with another thought. "But now that you've done so you feel you don't want to." "I want to immensely," he said.

Translation

He said it clearly, with a kind of enthusiasm that was one of his eccentricities, though he didn't actually move. Therefore, she could only give him her expectant look, while his face, to her annoyance, seemed to be occupied with another thought. "But now that you've done this, you feel you don't want to." "I want to very much," he said.

"Only you tell me nothing." She smiled at him, with this, finally, as if he were an unreasonable child. "It seems to me I tell you quite as much as you tell me. You haven't yet even told me how it is that such explanations as you require don't come from your document itself." Then as he answered nothing she had a flash.

Translation

"You just don't tell me anything." She smiled at him, finally, as if he were being a difficult child. "It seems to me I tell you just as much as you tell me. You haven't even explained to me how the answers you need aren't in the document itself." When he didn't respond, she had a sudden realization.

"You mean you haven't read it?" "I brought it to show you." He spoke with unusual clarity, almost cheerful, but didn't actually move. She just looked at him expectantly, while he seemed to be considering something else entirely.

Translation

"You mean you haven't read it?" "I brought it to show you." His voice was unusually clear, almost cheerful, but he didn't actually move. She just stared at him expectantly, while he seemed to be considering something else entirely.

"But now that you have it, you're not sure you want to." "I absolutely do," he said. "But you haven't told me anything." She smiled at him, acting as if he was being a bit childish.

Translation

"But now that you have it, you're not sure you want to." "I absolutely do," he said. "But you haven't told me anything." She smiled at him, acting as if he was being a bit childish.

"I think I'm telling you just as much as you're telling me. You haven't even told me why the answers you need aren't in the document itself." When he didn't reply, she suddenly understood. "You mean you haven't read it?" "I haven't read it."

Translation

"I believe I'm sharing just as much as you are. You haven't even explained why the information you need isn't already in the document." When he didn't respond, she realized something. "You mean you haven't read it?" "I haven't."

She stared. "Then how am I to help you with it?" Again leaving her while she never budged he paced five strides, and again he was before her. "By telling me this.

Translation

She stared, bewildered. "Then how can I assist you?" He walked away, leaving her standing there, and took five paces before returning to her. "By telling me this."

It's something, you know, that you wouldn't tell me the other day." She was vague. "The other day?" "The first time after my return—the Sunday I came to you.

Translation

"It's something, you know, you wouldn't tell me the other day." She seemed uncertain. "The other day?" "The first time I returned—the Sunday I came to see you."

What's he doing," Densher went on, "at that hour of the morning with her? What does his having been with her there mean?" "Of whom are you talking?" "Of that man—Lord Mark of course.

Translation

"What's he up to?" Densher continued. "Being with her that early? What's it mean, him being there with her?" "Who are you talking about?" "That man—Lord Mark, obviously."

What does it represent?" "Oh with Aunt Maud?" "Yes, my dear—and with you. It comes more or less to the same thing; and it's what you didn't tell me the other day when I put you the question."

Translation

"What is it supposed to signify?" "Oh, in relation to Aunt Maud?" "Yes, my dear—and with you as well. It's essentially the same, and it's what you failed to disclose to me the other day when I directly asked you."

"I haven't read it." She looked at him blankly. "Then how can I assist you with it?" He left her where she stood, and walked five paces.

Translation

"I haven't read it." She stared at him, uncomprehending. "Then how can I help you with it?" He walked away, leaving her there, after taking five steps.

Then he was back in front of her. "By informing me of this. It's something, you understand, that you wouldn't tell me the other day." She seemed distant.

Translation

He was suddenly standing before her again. "By telling me about this. Something, you know, you weren't sharing with me earlier." She appeared withdrawn.

"The other day?" "The first time I returned—the Sunday I visited you. What is he doing," Densher continued, "at that hour of the morning with her? What does his presence with her there signify?"

Translation

"The other day?" "The first time I came back—the Sunday I saw you. What's he doing," Densher went on, "with her at that hour of the morning? What does his being there with her mean?"

"Who are you talking about?" "That man—Lord Mark, obviously. What does it signify?" "Oh, with Aunt Maud?"

Translation

"Who are you talking about?"

"That man—Lord Mark, obviously. What does it signify?"

"Oh, with Aunt Maud?"

"Yes, my dear—and with you. It's essentially the same, and it's what you didn't tell me the other day when I asked you about it." Kate tried to remember the other day. "You asked me nothing about any hour."

Translation

"Yes, darling—and with you. It's essentially the same, and it's what you failed to mention the other day when I inquired about it." Kate tried to recall the other day. "You didn't ask me anything about a specific time."

"I asked you when it was you last saw him—previous, I mean, to his second descent at Venice. You wouldn't say, and as we were talking of a matter comparatively more important I let it pass. But the fact remains, you know, my dear, that you haven't told me." Two things in this speech appeared to have reached Kate more distinctly than the others.

Translation

"I asked when you last saw him—before his second appearance in Venice. You wouldn't tell me, and because we were discussing something more important, I let it go. But the truth is, you haven't told me." Two things in this speech seemed to have struck Kate more clearly than the rest.

"I 'wouldn't say'?—and you 'let it pass'?" She looked just coldly blank. "You really speak as if I were keeping something back." "Well, you see," Densher persisted, "you're not even telling me now. All I want to know," he nevertheless explained, "is whether there was a connexion between that proceeding on his part, which was practically—oh beyond all doubt!—the shock precipitating for her what has now happened, and anything that had occurred with him previously for yourself.

Translation

"I 'wouldn't say'?"—and you "let it pass?" She simply wore a look of cold blankness. "You really speak as if I were withholding information." "Well, you see," Densher persisted, "you're still not telling me. All I want to know," he nevertheless explained, "is whether there was a connection between that action of his, which was practically—oh, beyond all doubt!—the shock precipitating for her what has now happened, and anything that had happened with him previously for yourself."

How in the world did he know we're engaged?" Kate tried to recall the other day. "You didn't ask me anything about a specific time." "I asked when you last saw him—before his second trip to Venice.

Translation

"How on earth did he find out we're engaged?" Kate tried to remember what had happened the other day. "You didn't ask me anything about a specific date." "I asked when you last saw him—before his second trip to Venice."

You wouldn't tell me, and because we were discussing something more important, I let it go. But the truth is, you haven't told me." Two things in this speech seemed to strike Kate more than the others. "I 'wouldn't say'?—and you 'let it go'?" She looked completely expressionless.

Translation

"You wouldn't tell me, and because we were talking about something else, I didn't press the issue. But the fact is, you never told me." Two things in what he said seemed to hit Kate harder than anything else. "'Wouldn't say'?—and you 'let it go'?" Her face was utterly blank.

"You're really talking as if I'm hiding something." "Well, you still aren't telling me," Densher insisted, "All I want to know is whether there was a connection between what he did, which was almost certainly the thing that caused her current situation, and anything that had happened between you and him before. How did he know we were engaged?"

Translation

"You're acting like I'm keeping something from you," she said.

"Well, you still aren't telling me," Densher pressed. "All I want to know is if what he did—which likely caused her current condition—was connected to anything that happened between you two beforehand. How did he know we were engaged?"

Chapter 22

Chapter Summary (Click to expand)
No summary available.

Kate slowly rose; it was, since she had lighted the candles and sat down, the first movement she had made. "Are you trying to fix it on me that I must have told him?" She spoke not so much in resentment as in pale dismay—which he showed he immediately took in. "My dear child, I'm not trying to 'fix' anything; but I'm extremely tormented and I seem not to understand.

Translation

Kate rose slowly. It was the first movement she had made since lighting the candles and sitting down. "Are you trying to make it my fault, that I must have been the one to tell him?" Her words weren't so much an expression of anger as of pale dismay—a reaction he immediately perceived. "My dear child, I'm not trying to 'make' anything your fault, but I'm extremely troubled and I don't seem to understand."

What has the brute to do with us anyway?" "What has he indeed?" Kate asked. She shook her head as if in recovery, within the minute, of some mild allowance for his unreason. There was in it—and for his reason really—one of those half-inconsequent sweetnesses by which she had often before made, over some point of difference, her own terms with him.

Translation

"What does he have to do with us, anyway?" "What does he, indeed?" Kate asked. She shook her head, as if recovering, within a minute, from some small concession to his irrationality. There was a certain half-inconsequential charm to it—and, really, for his sake—the kind of charm that she had often used before, in the midst of a disagreement, to come to terms with him.

Practically she was making them now, and essentially he was knowing it; yet inevitably, all the same, he was accepting it. She stood there close to him, with something in her patience that suggested her having supposed, when he spoke more appealingly, that he was going to kiss her. He hadn't been, it appeared; but his continued appeal was none the less the quieter. "What's he doing, from ten o'clock on Christmas morning, with Mrs.

Translation

She was, in effect, arranging their lives now, and he knew it fundamentally, even though he was, regardless, accepting it. She stood close to him, a quality of her patience implying that when he'd spoken more endearingly, she'd assumed he was going to kiss her. It turned out he hadn't been, but his continued appeal was nevertheless more subdued. "What's he doing, from ten o'clock on Christmas morning, with Mrs.

Lowder?" V Kate slowly stood up; it was the first time she had moved since she had lit the candles and sat down. "Are you implying that I must have been the one who told him?"

Translation

"What is he doing, starting at ten o'clock Christmas morning, with Mrs. Lowder?" V Kate slowly rose; it was the first time she’d moved since lighting the candles and sitting down. “Are you suggesting that I must have been the one to tell him?”

She spoke more in pale shock than anger—which he immediately recognized. "My dear, I'm not implying anything. But I am extremely troubled, and I don't understand. Why is that horrible man even involved with us?"

Translation

Her voice conveyed shock, a pallid cast replacing the anger he'd expected, and he registered it instantly. "My dear, I'm not suggesting anything. However, I am deeply disturbed, and I'm at a loss. Why is that loathsome man mixed up in our affairs?"

"Why is he, indeed?" Kate asked. She shook her head, as if recovering from a touch of his irrationality. It held—and, truly, for his sake—one of those slightly illogical pleasantnesses by which she had often, in the past, made peace with him over a disagreement. In essence, she was doing that now, and he was fully aware of it.

Translation

"Why, indeed?" Kate asked. She shook her head, as if she were trying to shake off some of his irrationality. There was—and, really, for his benefit—a hint of that slightly illogical charm she had used in the past to defuse arguments with him. Essentially, that's what she was doing now, and he knew it.

Yet inevitably, he accepted it. She stood near him, with a hint of patient expectation, as if she had thought, when he sounded more pleading, that he was going to kiss her. He hadn't, it seemed; but his continued plea was no less subdued. "What is he doing with Mrs.

Translation

He conceded, as he always did. She remained close, a touch of unspoken anticipation about her, as if she had expected a kiss when his tone turned desperate. He hadn't, though his persistent inquiry was no less muted. "What is he doing with Mrs. Willoughby?"

Lowder, starting at ten o'clock on Christmas morning?" Kate looked surprised. "Didn't she tell you he's staying there?" "At Lancaster Gate?" Densher's surprise met it.

Translation

"Lowder, starting at ten o'clock on Christmas morning?" Kate looked surprised. "Didn't she tell you he's staying there?" "At Lancaster Gate?" Densher’s surprise mirrored hers.

"'Staying'?—since when?" "Since day before yesterday. He was there before I came away." And then she explained—confessing it in fact anomalous. "It's an accident—like Aunt Maud's having herself remained in town for Christmas, but it isn't after all so monstrous.

Translation

"'Staying'—since when?" "Since the day before yesterday. He was there before I left." And then she explained—admitting, actually, that it was unusual. "It's an accident—like Aunt Maud remaining in town for Christmas, but it's not so terrible, when you think about it."

We stayed—and, with my having come here, she's sorry now—because we neither of us, waiting from day to day for the news you brought, seemed to want to be with a lot of people." "You stayed for thinking of—Venice?" "Of course we did. For what else?

Translation

We stayed—and, because I came here, she regrets it now—because neither of us, waiting day after day for the news you brought, seemed to want to be around a lot of people." "You stayed to think of—Venice?" "Of course we did. What else would we have stayed for?

And even a little," Kate wonderfully added—"it's true at least of Aunt Maud—for thinking of you." He appreciated. "I see. Nice of you every way.

Translation

And also, a little bit," Kate added, sounding delighted, "it's true, at least for Aunt Maud, we stayed to think of you." He was appreciative. "I see. Very kind of you all.

But whom," he enquired, "has Lord Mark stayed for thinking of?" Kate showed her surprise. "Didn't she tell you he's staying there?" Densher's surprise matched hers.

Translation

"But," he asked, "who is Lord Mark staying for?" Kate looked surprised. "Didn't she tell you he was staying?" Densher's surprise equaled hers.

"At Lancaster Gate?" He asked. "'Staying'? Since when?" "Since the day before yesterday.

Translation

"At Lancaster Gate?" he repeated. "'Staying'? How long has he been here?" "Since the day before yesterday."

He was there before I left." She then offered an explanation, admitting it was a bit odd. "It was unexpected, like Aunt Maud staying in town for Christmas. But it isn't so strange when you think about it. We stayed—and, because I came here, she regrets it now—because neither of us, waiting for news from you, wanted to be around a lot of people."

Translation

"He was there before I left." She offered an explanation, admitting it seemed a little strange. "It was unexpected, like Aunt Maud spending Christmas in the city. But it isn't so odd when you consider it. We stayed—and, because I came here, she regrets it now—because neither of us, waiting for news from you, wanted to be surrounded by crowds."

"You stayed to think about—Venice?" "Of course, we did. What else? And a little," Kate added, sounding sincere, "at least in Aunt Maud's case, to think about you."

Translation

"You stayed to think about—Venice?" "Naturally. What else? And a bit," Kate added, her tone convincing, "or, at least, in Aunt Maud's case, to think about you."

He understood. "I see. Very thoughtful of you both. But," he asked, "who is Lord Mark staying for?"

Translation

He understood. "I see. Very thoughtful of you both. But," he asked, "who is Lord Mark staying for?"

"His being in London, I believe, is a very commonplace matter. He has some rooms which he has had suddenly some rather advantageous chance to let—such as, with his confessed, his decidedly proclaimed want of money, he hasn't had it in him, in spite of everything, not to jump at." Densher's attention was entire. "In spite of everything?

Translation

"I believe his presence in London is quite ordinary," she said. "He has some rooms he's had a sudden, rather fortunate opportunity to rent out. Given his admission, his very frank declaration of a lack of funds, he couldn't resist. Despite everything." Densher was completely focused. "Despite everything?"

In spite of what?" "Well, I don't know. In spite, say, of his being scarcely supposed to do that sort of thing." "To try to get money?"

Translation

"Despite what?" "Well, I don't know. Despite, let's say, his not being expected to do that kind of thing." "To try and get money?"

"To try at any rate in little thrifty ways. Apparently however he has had for some reason to do what he can. He turned at a couple of days' notice out of his place, making it over to his tenant; and Aunt Maud, who's deeply in his confidence about all such matters, said: 'Come then to Lancaster Gate—to sleep at least—till, like all the world, you go to the country.' He was to have gone to the country—I think to Matcham—yesterday afternoon: Aunt Maud, that is, told me he was." I understand he's in London quite frequently.

Translation

"To try, at any rate, in small, careful ways. Apparently, though, he's had to do what he can for some reason. He was forced out of his place with just a couple days' notice, and handed it over to his tenant. And Aunt Maud, who's very close to him when it comes to things like that, said, 'Come to Lancaster Gate, at least to sleep, until, like everyone else, you go to the country.' He was supposed to go to the country—I think to Matcham—yesterday afternoon: Aunt Maud told me so. I understand he's in London quite often."

He recently had the good fortune to rent out some rooms—a chance he couldn't pass up, given his admitted lack of funds. Densher was fully engaged. "In spite of everything? In spite of what?"

Translation

He had, of late, been fortunate enough to let out some rooms—an opportunity he couldn't afford to refuse, considering his confessed lack of money. Densher was completely absorbed. "Regardless of everything? Regardless of what?"

"Well, I'm not sure. In spite of, perhaps, not being the type to do that sort of thing." "To try to make money?" "To try, at least, in small, practical ways.

Translation

"Well, I'm not sure. Though, perhaps, I'm not the type to do that sort of thing." "To try to make money?" "To try, at least, in small, practical ways."

But apparently, for some reason, he's had to do what he can. He vacated his residence on short notice, handing it over to his renter. Aunt Maud, who is privy to all his financial affairs, said: 'Come to Lancaster Gate, at least to sleep, until you, like everyone else, go to the country.' He was supposed to have gone to the country—I believe to Matcham—yesterday afternoon; Aunt Maud told me so." Kate had been somehow, for her companion, through this statement, beautifully, quite soothingly, suggestive.

Translation

But it seems that, for some reason, he's had to improvise. He moved out of his place with little warning, giving it over to his tenant. Aunt Maud, who knows everything about his finances, said, "Come to Lancaster Gate, at least to sleep, until you, like everyone else, goes to the country." He was supposed to have gone to the country—to Matcham, I believe—yesterday afternoon; Aunt Maud told me." Kate had been somehow, for her companion, through this statement, beautifully, quite soothingly, suggestive.

"Told you, you mean, so that you needn't leave the house?" "Yes—so far as she had taken it into her head that his being there was part of my reason." "And was it part of your reason?" "A little if you like.

Translation

"You mean she told you so you wouldn't have to leave the house?" "Yes—as far as she believed his presence there was one of my reasons." "And was it?" "A little, if you like."

Yet there's plenty here—as I knew there would be—without it. So that," she said candidly, "doesn't matter. I'm glad I am here: even if for all the good I do—!" She implied however that that didn't matter either. "He didn't, as you tell me, get off then to Matcham; though he may possibly, if it is possible, be going this afternoon.

Translation

"But there's still plenty here, as I knew there would be, even without him. So that," she said frankly, "doesn't matter. I'm glad I'm here: even if for all the good I do—!" She implied, however, that even that didn't matter. "He didn't, as you say, go to Matcham then; though he might possibly, if it's possible, be going this afternoon."

But what strikes me as most probable—and it's really, I'm bound to say, quite amiable of him—is that he has declined to leave Aunt Maud, as I've been so ready to do, to spend her Christmas alone. If moreover he has given up Matcham for her it's a procédé that won't please her less. It's small wonder therefore that she insists, on a dull day, in driving him about. I don't pretend to know," she wound up, "what may happen between them; but that's all I see in it."

Translation

But what seems most likely to me—and it's really quite kind of him, I have to say—is that he's refused to leave Aunt Maud, as I've been so eager to do, to spend Christmas alone. If he has also given up Matcham for her, that’s a move she'll surely appreciate. So it’s no surprise that she insists on driving him around on a boring day. I don’t claim to know," she finished, "what might develop between them; but that’s all I can see in it.

Kate's words, after her earlier comment, were beautifully and reassuringly insightful for her companion. "You mean, she told you so you wouldn't have to leave the house?" "Yes, as much as she thought his presence was the reason I stayed." "And was it?"

Translation

Kate's words were a comforting revelation to the other person, following their prior discussion. "So, you think she told you so you wouldn't feel obligated to leave?" "Yes, she seemed to think my staying was because of him." "And was it?"

"A little, perhaps. But there's plenty here, as I expected, without him. So that," she said frankly, "doesn't really matter. I'm happy to be here, even if I don't do much good!" However, she suggested that didn't matter either.

Translation

"Maybe, a little. But there's a lot here, like I thought, even without him. So, that," she said without hesitation, "doesn't really matter. I'm glad to be here, even if I'm not that helpful!" Though, she implied that didn't matter, either.

"As you said, he didn't go to Matcham. He might, possibly, go this afternoon. But what seems most likely, and it's quite kind of him, really, is that he refused to abandon Aunt Maud, since I was so eager to do so, and leave her alone for Christmas. Furthermore, if he's given up Matcham for her, she'll certainly be pleased.

Translation

"Like you said, he didn't go to Matcham. He might, maybe, go this afternoon. Besides, if he's skipped Matcham for her, she'll definitely be happy."

It's no surprise she wants to drive him around on a boring day. I don't claim to know," she concluded, "what will happen between them, but that's all I gather from it." "You see in everything, and you always did," Densher returned, "something that, while I'm with you at least, I always take from you as the truth itself." She looked at him as if consciously and even carefully extracting the sting of his reservation; then she spoke with a quiet gravity that seemed to show how fine she found it.

Translation

It's not surprising she wants to drive him around on a dull day. I don't pretend to know," she finished, "what will happen between them, but that's the gist of it as I see it." She looked at him as if deliberately and even carefully removing the barb of his doubt; then she spoke with a quiet seriousness that seemed to indicate how much she appreciated it.

"Thank you." It had for him, like everything else, its effect. They were still closely face to face, and, yielding to the impulse to which he hadn't yielded just before, he laid his hands on her shoulders, held her hard a minute and shook her a little, far from untenderly, as if in expression of more mingled things, all difficult, than he could speak. Then bending his head he applied his lips to her cheek. He fell, after this, away for an instant, resuming his unrest, while she kept the position in which, all passive and as a statue, she had taken his demonstration.

Translation

"Thank you." It had an effect on him, like everything else. They were still close together, face-to-face, and, giving in to the impulse he'd resisted just moments before, he put his hands on her shoulders, held her tightly for a moment, and gave her a little shake, not unkindly, as if expressing more complicated and difficult feelings than he could articulate. Then, he bent his head and kissed her cheek. He withdrew for a moment after that, returning to his restlessness, while she remained in the same position, still and passive, like a statue, having received his display of affection.

It didn't prevent her, however, from offering him, as if what she had had was enough for the moment, a further indulgence. She made a quiet lucid connexion and as she made it sat down again. "Thank you." The words affected him, as all her words did. "And why you are." It was almost, in its extremely affirmative effect between them, the note of recrimination; or it would have been perhaps rather if it hadn't been so much more the note of truth. It was sharp because it was true, but its truth appeared to impose it as an argument so conclusive as to permit on neither side a sequel. That made, while they faced each other over it without speech, the gravity of everything. It was as if there were almost danger, which the wrong word might start.

Translation

"And why you are." The statement, in its profoundly assertive effect between them, was nearly a recrimination. Perhaps it would have been more so, if it hadn't been even more a statement of truth. It was sharp because it was true, but its truth seemed to impose itself as an argument so conclusive that it left no room for further discussion on either side. That created, as they faced each other in silence, the gravity of the situation. There was almost a sense of danger, as if the wrong word could trigger something.

Densher accordingly at last acted to better purpose: he drew, standing there before her, a pocket-book from the breast of his waistcoat and he drew from the pocket-book a folded letter to which her eyes attached themselves. He restored then the receptacle to its place and, with a movement not the less odd for being visibly instinctive and unconscious, carried the hand containing his letter behind him. What he thus finally spoke of was a different matter. "Did I understand from Mrs.

Translation

Densher finally did something more productive. Standing before her, he pulled a notepad from his waistcoat pocket, and from the notepad, he produced a folded letter to which her eyes immediately fastened. Then, he put the notepad back and, with a motion that was no less peculiar for being clearly instinctive and unconscious, moved the hand holding the letter behind him. What he then spoke of was unrelated. "Did I understand from Mrs.

Lowder that your father's in the house?" "Milly?" Densher repeated, his voice echoing distantly. "That you were genuine. That it was her you loved." Her words hit him so hard that he immediately turned, finding himself back at his window.

Translation

Lowder that your father's in the house?" "Milly?" Densher repeated, his voice echoing distantly. "That you were genuine. That it was her you loved." Her words hit him so hard that he immediately turned, finding himself back at his window.

"Aunt Maud, when he came back," she went on, "heard it from him. And that's why you're on good terms with Aunt Maud now." He stared out the window silently for a moment, then turned away. "And why you are." It almost sounded like a sharp accusation, but it would have been more accurate to say it was the sound of pure truth.

Translation

"Aunt Maud heard it from him when he returned," she continued. "That's the reason you and Aunt Maud get along now." He gazed out the window without a word for a time, then shifted his gaze. "And the reason you do, too." It was almost as though she were accusing him sharply, though it would have been more precise to say that the sound was one of unvarnished truth.

It was cutting because it was true, but that truth seemed to settle the matter so definitively that there was nothing left to say. This shared understanding, unspoken, was the weight of the moment. There was almost a sense of danger, as if the wrong word could trigger something terrible. So Densher finally acted; he pulled a pocketbook from his waistcoat pocket, and took out a folded letter, which she watched intently.

Translation

The statement stung because it was accurate, yet its truth seemed to resolve the situation so completely that further discussion was impossible. This mutual, tacit agreement defined the gravity of the present. An atmosphere of near-menace hung in the air, as if a single ill-chosen word could unleash a catastrophe. Densher, at last, took action: he withdrew a wallet from his waistcoat and removed a folded letter, which she observed with unwavering focus.

Then he put the pocketbook back, and, in a gesture that seemed both natural and unconscious, hid the hand holding the letter behind him. What he said next was something else entirely. "Did I understand from Mrs. Lowder that your father's here?"

Translation

He returned the wallet to his pocket. Then, in a movement that looked both instinctive and unintentional, he concealed the hand that held the letter behind his back. The words that followed were unexpected. "Did I gather from Mrs. Lowder that your father is here?"

If it never had taken her long in such excursions to meet him it was not to take her so now. "In the house, yes. But we needn't fear his interruption"—she spoke as if he had thought of that. "He's in bed."

If she usually found him quickly on these sorts of trips, it wouldn't take her long this time either. "In the house, yes. But we don't have to worry about him interrupting"—she said this as if he'd been thinking about it. "He's in bed."

"Do you mean with illness?" She sadly shook her head. "Father's never ill. He's a marvel.

"Do you mean he's sick?" She shook her head, a sad gesture. "Father never gets sick. He's amazing."

Of a person—of a thing. He desires, he claims, to be composed. Yet his composure is disturbing." She endured, but he had to inquire.

Translation

"What's he do?" Even Kate was taken aback. "He weeps." He paused again, but then he took the chance.

"What has he done?" It made her slowly rise, and they were once more fully face to face. Her eyes held his own and she was paler than she had been. "If you love me—now—don't ask me about father."

Translation

But her eyes, even as he presented the letter, didn't move past the gesture. "You haven't even opened it!" She seemed wounded, but he pressed on, unable to stop himself. "What does he do for you?"

Translation

Kate hesitated. "He cries." He paused, then took a chance. "What did he do?"

She rose slowly, and they stood facing each other once more. Her gaze met his, and she appeared even more ashen than before. "If you love me—now—don't ask about my father." He waited a beat.

Translation

"I love you. I'm here because I love you. And because I love you, I got this for you." He held out the letter he'd been carrying. But her eyes—though he offered it—wouldn't look at the paper.

"You haven't even opened it!" "If I had broken the seal—exactly—I should know what's within. It's for you to break the seal that I bring it." She looked—still not touching the thing—inordinately grave.

Translation

"You haven't even opened it!"

"If I had opened it, I would already know what's inside. It's for you to open, since I'm the one who brought it."

She looked at the letter, still not touching it, and was strangely serious.

"To break the seal of something to you from her?" "Ah precisely because it's from her. I'll abide by whatever you think of it." "I don't understand," said Kate.

Translation

"To break the seal of something to you from her?" "Ah, precisely because it's from her. I'll abide by whatever you think of it." "I don't understand," said Kate.

"What do you yourself think?" And then as he didn't answer: "It seems to me I think you know. You have your instinct. You don't need to read. It's the proof."

Translation

"What do you think?" And then, since he didn't reply: "I feel like you already know. You have your instincts. You don't need to read anything. It's the proof."

Densher faced her words as if they had been an accusation, an accusation for which he was prepared and which there was but one way to face. "I have indeed my instinct. It came to me, while I worried it out, last night. It came to me as an effect of the hour." He held up his letter and seemed now to insist more than to confess.

Translation

Densher met her words head-on, as if they were a charge. A charge he was ready for. There was only one way to deal with it. “I do have my instinct, yes. It came to me while I was turning this over, last night. It came to me as a product of the moment.” He raised his letter and seemed to be making a point more than admitting something.

"This thing had been timed." If I had opened the letter myself—carefully—I would know what it says. But I haven't. I'm asking you to open it for me."

Translation

"This had been planned." If I had opened the letter myself—carefully—I would know its contents. But I haven't. I'm asking you to open it for me."

Kate stared at the letter, still not touching it, looking extremely serious. "You want me to break the seal on something that came from her?" "Yes, exactly because it came from her. I'll do whatever you think is best."

Translation

Kate scrutinized the letter without reaching for it, her expression grave. "You want me to break the seal on something that came from her?"

"Yes, precisely because it's from her. I'll defer to your judgment."

"I don't understand," Kate said. "What do you think yourself?" And then, since he didn't answer, she continued, "I think you already know. You have a feeling. You don't need to read the letter.

Translation

"I don't understand," Kate said. "What do you believe?" And when he didn't respond, she went on, "I think you already know. You have a sense. You don't need to read the letter."

Your instinct tells you everything." Densher treated her words as if they were an accusation, an accusation he had anticipated and which could only be addressed in one way. "I do have a feeling. It came to me while I was thinking about this last night.

Translation

"Your intuition is your guide." Densher reacted to her statement as if it were a direct challenge, one he'd been expecting and could only counter with a specific response. "I do have a sense, yes. It occurred to me while I was considering this last night."

It came to me at a particular moment." He held up the letter and seemed to be emphasizing rather than simply admitting. "This letter was carefully timed." "For Christmas Eve?" "For Christmas Eve."

Translation

"It came to me at a specific moment." He held up the letter, appearing to emphasize, not simply acknowledge. "This letter was carefully timed." "For Christmas Eve?" "For Christmas Eve."

Kate had suddenly a strange smile. "The season of gifts!" After which, as he said nothing, she went on: "And had been written, you mean, while she could write, and kept to be so timed?" Only meeting her eyes while he thought, he again didn't reply. "What do you mean by the proof?"

Translation

Kate suddenly wore a strange smile. "The season of gifts!" Then, since he said nothing, she continued, "And it was written, you mean, while she was still able to write, and kept to be so timed?" Only meeting her gaze while he considered, he again didn't respond. "What do you mean by the proof?"

"Why of the beauty with which you've been loved. But I won't," she said, "break your seal." "You positively decline?" "Positively.

Translation

"Of the beauty with which you've been loved. But I won't," she said, "break your seal." "You absolutely refuse?" "Absolutely.

Never." To which she added oddly: "I know without." He had another pause. "And what is it you know?" "That she announces to you she has made you rich."

Translation

"Never." She added, strangely, "I know without." He paused again. "And what do you know?" "That she is telling you she has made you rich."

His pause this time was longer. "Left me her fortune?" "Not all of it, no doubt, for it's immense. But money to a large amount.

Translation

His pause stretched this time. "Left me her fortune?" "Not everything, certainly, for it's vast. But a great deal of money."

I don't care," Kate went on, "to know how much." And her strange smile recurred. "I trust her." "For Christmas Eve?" "For Christmas Eve."

Translation

"I don't care," Kate continued, "how much." And her peculiar smile returned. "I trust her." "For Christmas Eve?" "For Christmas Eve."

Kate's expression shifted to a peculiar smile. "The season of presents!" When he remained silent, she continued, "And it was written, you believe, while she was still able to write, and kept to be opened at this time?" Looking directly at her while considering, he remained silent again. "What are you referring to as proof?"

Translation

Kate's smile was peculiar. "The season of presents!" When he didn't respond, she went on, "And it was written, you believe, while she could still write, and kept to be opened at this time?" He looked at her, considering, and remained silent. "What do you consider to be proof?"

"The proof of how beautifully you were loved. But I won't," she said, "violate your privacy." "You absolutely refuse?" "Absolutely.

Translation

"The proof of how beautifully you were loved. But I won't," she said, "violate your privacy." "You absolutely refuse?" "Absolutely."
