Never." She added, strangely, "I already know." He hesitated again. "And what is it that you know?" "That she is telling you she has made you wealthy."

Translation

"Never." She added, strangely, "I already know." He hesitated again. "And what is it that you know?" "That she is telling you she has made you wealthy."

He paused for a longer time this time. "Left me her fortune?" "Not entirely, no doubt, because it's enormous. But a substantial sum of money.

Translation

He was silent for a significantly extended period. "Left me her fortune?" "Not entirely, I'd wager, because it's massive. But a considerable amount of money."

I don't need," Kate continued, "to know the amount." Her strange smile returned. "I trust her." "Did she tell you?" Densher asked. "Never!" Kate visibly flushed at the thought.

Translation

"I don't need to know the amount," Kate continued. Her odd smile returned. "I trust her." "Did she tell you?" Densher asked. "Never!" Kate visibly blushed at the thought.

"That wouldn't, on my part, have been playing fair with her. And I did," she added, "play fair." Densher, who had believed her—he couldn't help it—continued, holding his letter, to face her. He was much quieter now, as if his torment had somehow passed.

Translation

"That wouldn't have been fair of me to her. And I did play fair," she added. Densher, who had believed her—he couldn't help it—continued to face her, holding his letter. He was much quieter now, as if his torment had somehow passed.

"You played fair with me, Kate; and that's why—since we talk of proofs—I want to give you one. I've wanted to let you see—and in preference even to myself—something I feel as sacred." She frowned a little. "I don't understand."

Translation

"You were fair to me, Kate; and that's why—since we're discussing proof—I want to offer you one. I've wanted to show you—before even I see it myself—something I consider sacred." She frowned slightly. "I don't understand."

"I've asked myself for a tribute, for a sacrifice by which I can peculiarly recognise—" "Peculiarly recognise what?" she demanded as he dropped. "Did she tell you?" Densher inquired. "Never!" Kate's face reddened noticeably at the mere idea.

Translation

"I've demanded a tribute from myself, a sacrifice by which I can uniquely recognise—" "Uniquely recognise what?" she pressed as he trailed off. "Did she tell you?" Densher asked. "Never!" Kate's cheeks flushed at the very thought.

"That would have been dishonest of me. And I was," she clarified, "honest." Densher, who had trusted her—he couldn't help it—remained facing her, clutching his letter. He seemed calmer now, as though his suffering had subsided.

Translation

"That would have been dishonest of me. And I was," she clarified, "honest." Densher, who had trusted her—he couldn't help it—remained facing her, clutching his letter. He seemed calmer now, as though his suffering had subsided.

"You were honest with me, Kate; and that's why—since we're discussing evidence—I want to offer you some. I've wanted to show you—before even admitting it to myself—something I consider sacred." She looked slightly confused. "I don't understand."

Translation

"You were honest with me, Kate, and that's why—since we're talking about evidence—I want to give you some. I've wanted to show you—before I even admitted it to myself—something I consider sacred." She seemed a little puzzled. "I don't understand."

"I've demanded something of myself, a sacrifice that will specifically help me to recognize—" "Recognize what, exactly?" she pressed him as he trailed off. "The admirable nature of your own sacrifice. You were capable in Venice of an act of splendid generosity."

Translation

"I've demanded something of myself, a sacrifice that will specifically help me to recognize—" "Recognize what, exactly?" she pressed him as he trailed off. "The admirable nature of your own sacrifice. You were capable in Venice of an act of splendid generosity."

"And the privilege you offer me with that document is my reward?" He made a movement. "It's all I can do as a symbol of my attitude." She looked at him long.

Translation

"And the privilege that document offers me, that's my reward?" He stirred. "It's all I can do, as a symbol of my attitude." She watched him for a long moment.

"Your attitude, my dear, is that you're afraid of yourself. You've had to take yourself in hand. You've had to do yourself violence." "So it is then you meet me?"

Translation

"Your attitude, my dear, is that you're afraid of yourself. You've had to get a grip. You've had to hurt yourself." "So that's how you see me?"

She bent her eyes hard a moment to the letter, from which her hand still stayed itself. "You absolutely desire me to take it?" "I absolutely desire you to take it." "To do what I like with it?"

Translation

She fixed her gaze on the letter for a moment, her hand still hovering over it. "You really want me to take it?" "I really want you to take it." "And do whatever I want with it?"

"Short of course of making known its terms. It must remain—pardon my making the point—between you and me." Your sacrifice was amazing. You were capable of a truly generous act in Venice.

Translation

"Except, of course, for revealing its contents. It

needs to stay—if you'll allow me to emphasize—between

the two of us." Your sacrifice was incredible. You were able to do something genuinely selfless in Venice.

Is the privilege you're offering me with that document my reward? He shifted. "It's all I can do to represent my feelings." She gazed at him for a long time.

Translation

Is the document's contents the prize you're offering? He stirred. "It's the only way I can express what I feel." She studied him for a long moment.

"Your feelings, my dear, are that you're afraid of yourself. You've had to control yourself. You've had to force yourself." "Is this how you see me now?"

Translation

"What you feel, darling, is fear of your own nature. You've had to maintain control. You've had to be someone you aren't."

"Is that your perception of me now?"

She looked intensely at the letter, her hand still resting on it. "You really want me to take it?" "I absolutely want you to take it." "And do whatever I want with it?"

Translation

She stared intently at the letter, her hand still resting on it. "You truly want me to take it?" "I absolutely do." "And do whatever I wish with it?"

"Except, of course, revealing its contents. It must remain—I apologize for being so clear—between you and me." She had a last hesitation, but she presently broke it. "Trust me." Taking from him the sacred script she held it a little while her eyes again rested on those fine characters of Milly's that they had shortly before discussed.

Translation

"Except, of course, for revealing what's inside. It has to stay—I'm sorry to be so blunt—between the two of us." She paused for a final moment, but then she steeled herself. "Trust me." She accepted the letter from him, this precious thing, holding it for a moment as her eyes fell again upon Milly's elegant script, the very words they'd just been discussing.

"To hold it," she brought out, "is to know." "Oh I know!" said Merton Densher. "Well then if we both do—!" She had already turned to the fire, nearer to which she had moved, and with a quick gesture had jerked the thing into the flame. He started—but only half—as to undo her action: his arrest was as prompt as the latter had been decisive.

Translation

"To hold it," she stated, "is to know."

"Oh, I know!" Merton Densher responded. "Well then, if we both do—!"

She had already turned toward the fire, getting closer to it, and with a swift motion, she had thrown the letter into the flames. He flinched—but only halfway—as if to stop her action: his halt was as immediate as hers had been decisive.

He only watched, with her, the paper burn; after which their eyes again met. "You'll have it all," Kate said, "from New York." She hesitated one last time, but then she overcame her reluctance. "Trust me." She took the letter from him, the precious manuscript, and held it, her eyes once again fixed on Milly's delicate handwriting, which they had just been discussing.

Translation

He simply watched the paper burn with her. Afterward, their eyes met again. "You'll have everything," Kate said, "from New York." She paused, then pushed past her hesitation. "Trust me." She took the letter from him, the precious manuscript, and held it, her gaze once again fixed on Milly's delicate handwriting, which they had been discussing.

"To hold it," she said, "is to understand." "Oh, I understand!" Merton Densher replied. "Then, if we both do—!" She had already turned to the fireplace, moving closer, and with a swift movement, she threw the letter into the flames. He flinched, almost as if to stop her, but his reaction was as immediate as hers had been decisive.

Translation

"To hold it," she said, "is to understand." "Oh, I understand!" Merton Densher replied. "Then, if we both do—!" She had already turned towards the fireplace, moving closer, and with a swift movement, she threw the letter into the flames. He flinched, almost as if to stop her, but his reaction was as immediate as hers had been decisive.

He simply watched the paper burn with her, and then their eyes met again. "You'll get everything," Kate said, "from New York." It was after he had in fact, two months later, heard from New York that she paid him a visit one morning at his own quarters—coming not as she had come in Venice, under his extreme solicitation, but as a need recognised in the first instance by herself, even though also as the prompt result of a missive delivered to her. This had consisted of a note from Densher accompanying a letter, "just to hand," addressed him by an eminent American legal firm, a firm of whose high character he had become conscious while in New York as of a thing in the air itself, and whose head and front, the principal executor of Milly Theale's copious will, had been duly identified at Lancaster Gate as the gentleman hurrying out, by the straight southern course, before the girl's death, to the support of Mrs.

Translation

He simply watched the paper burn with her, and then their eyes met again. "You'll get everything," Kate said, "from New York." It was after he had, in fact, two months later, heard from New York that she paid him a visit one morning at his own quarters—coming not as she had come in Venice, under his extreme solicitation, but as a need recognized in the first instance by herself, even though also as the prompt result of a missive delivered to her. This had consisted of a note from Densher accompanying a letter, "just to hand," addressed to him by an eminent American legal firm, a firm of whose high character he had become conscious while in New York as of a thing in the air itself, and whose head and front, the principal executor of Milly Theale's copious will, had been duly identified at Lancaster Gate as the gentleman hurrying out, by the straight southern course, before the girl's death, to the support of Mrs.

Stringham. Densher's act on receipt of the document in question—an act as to which and to the bearings of which his resolve had had time to mature—constituted in strictness, singularly enough, the first reference to Milly, or to what Milly might or might not have done, that had passed between our pair since they had stood together watching the destruction, in the little vulgar grate at Chelsea, of the undisclosed work of her hand. They had at the time, and in due deference now, on his part, to Kate's mention of her responsibility for his call, immediately separated, and when they met again the subject was made present to them—at all events till some flare of new light—only by the intensity with which it mutely expressed its absence. They were not moreover in these weeks to meet often, in spite of the fact that this had, during January and a part of February, actually become for them a comparatively easy matter.

Translation

Densher’s action upon receiving the document in question—an action regarding which, and its implications, his decision had time to solidify—constituted, surprisingly enough, the first mention of Milly, or of what Milly might or might not have done, that had been exchanged between them since they had stood together, observing the destruction, in the small, common fireplace in Chelsea, of the undisclosed work of her hand. At the time, and in due deference to Kate’s mention of her responsibility for his summons, they had immediately separated, and when they met again the subject was present to them—at least until some new revelation—only through the intensity with which its absence was expressed. Furthermore, during those weeks, they didn’t meet often, despite the fact that doing so had, during January and a part of February, become comparatively easy for them.

Kate's stay at Mrs. Condrip's prolonged itself under allowances from her aunt which would have been a mystery to Densher had he not been admitted, at Lancaster Gate, really in spite of himself, to the esoteric view of them. "It's her idea," Mrs. Lowder had there said to him as if she really despised ideas—which she didn't; "and I've taken up with my own, which is to give her her head till she has had enough of it.

Translation

Kate's stay at Mrs. Condrip's was prolonged, thanks to her aunt's accommodations. These would have been a mystery to Densher, had he not been given the inside scoop, at Lancaster Gate, really against his will. "It's her idea," Mrs. Lowder had said to him there, as if she really despised ideas—which she didn't. "And I've taken up with my own, which is to give her her head until she's had enough of it."

She has had enough of it, she had that soon enough; but as she's as proud as the deuce she'll come back when she has found some reason—having nothing in common with her disgust—of which she can make a show. She calls it her holiday, which she's spending in her own way—the holiday to which, once a year or so, as she says, the very maids in the scullery have a right. So we're taking it on that basis. But we shall not soon, I think, take another of the same sort.

Translation

She has had enough of it, she had that soon enough; but because she's as proud as can be, she'll come back when she has found some reason—having nothing to do with her disgust—that she can show off. She calls it her holiday, which she's spending her own way—the holiday that, once a year or so, as she says, even the maids in the scullery have a right to. So we're dealing with it that way. But I don't think we'll soon deal with another one like it.

Besides, she's quite decent; she comes often—whenever I make her a sign; and she has been good, on the whole, this year or two, so that, to be decent myself, I don't complain. She has really been, poor dear, very much what one hoped; though I needn't, you know," Aunt Maud wound up, "tell you, after all, you clever creature, what that was." Two months after he received the news from New York, she paid him a visit one morning at his residence. This time, she came not as she had in Venice, at his strong urging, but because she recognized a need to do so.

Translation

Furthermore, she's fairly well-behaved; she visits often, whenever I signal her. She's also been, on the whole, agreeable these past couple of years, so that, to be polite myself, I don't lodge any complaints. She's really been, bless her heart, very much what one would have wanted; though, you know, Aunt Maud concluded, "I don't need to tell you, of all people, you clever thing, what that was." Two months after he received the news from New York, she paid him a visit one morning at his home. This time, she came not as she had in Venice, because he'd strongly encouraged it, but because she acknowledged a need to do so.

This need arose directly from a letter sent to her. This letter was accompanied by a note from Densher, saying the letter had “just arrived.” The letter itself came from a prominent American law firm. He had become aware of their excellent reputation while in New York, as if it was common knowledge. The head of the firm, and principal executor of Milly Theale's large will, had been observed leaving Lancaster Gate in haste, heading south, before the girl's death, to support Mrs.

Translation

This necessity was a direct result of a letter she received. The letter was accompanied by a note from Densher, stating the letter had “just come.” The letter itself originated from a well-known American law firm. He had learned of their stellar reputation while in New York, as though it were common knowledge. The firm’s lead, and the primary executor of Milly Theale’s substantial will, had been seen departing Lancaster Gate in a rush, heading south, before the girl’s passing, to support Mrs.

Stringham. Densher's action upon receiving the document in question—an action that he had time to consider the implications of—was, surprisingly, the first mention of Milly, or what she might have done, between the two of them since they had stood together and watched her work being burned in the small, ugly fireplace in Chelsea. They had separated immediately after, in deference to Kate's acknowledgement of her responsibility for his call. When they met again, the subject was present, at least until a new understanding emerged, only through the intensity of its unspoken absence.

Translation

Densher's response to the document—an action he’d had time to weigh—was surprisingly the first mention of Milly, or what she might have done, between them since they’d watched her work burn in the ugly fireplace in Chelsea. They’d separated right after, in acknowledgment of Kate's responsibility for his call. When they met again, the subject was there, at least until a new understanding formed, only through the force of its unspoken absence.

Furthermore, they did not meet often during these weeks, even though it had become relatively easy for them during January and part of February. Kate's stay at Mrs. Condrip's was extended. Her aunt provided her with allowances that would have been a mystery to Densher, had he not been privy to the exclusive understanding of them at Lancaster Gate.

Translation

Moreover, they didn't see each other much during those weeks, even though getting together had been fairly simple for them in January and part of February. Kate's stay at Mrs. Condrip's was prolonged. Her aunt gave her an allowance that would have baffled Densher, had he not known all about their private arrangement at Lancaster Gate.

"It's her idea," Mrs. Lowder had said to him there, as if she despised ideas, which she did not. "And I've adopted my own, which is to let her do as she pleases until she's had enough of it. She did have enough of it soon enough.

Translation

"It's her idea," Mrs. Lowder had said to him, there, as if she despised ideas, which she did not. "And I've adopted my own, which is to let her do as she pleases until she's had enough of it." She did have enough of it soon enough.

But since she's as proud as can be, she'll return when she finds some reason—having nothing to do with her disgust—that she can present. She calls it her holiday, which she's spending her own way—the holiday that, as she says, even the maids in the scullery have a right to once a year. So, we're operating on that basis. But I don't think we'll have another one like it soon.

Translation

But because she's incredibly proud, she'll come back when she can justify it. It won't have anything to do with her being fed up. She calls it her holiday. She's doing it her way, the holiday that, as she puts it, even the kitchen staff are entitled to once a year. That's the idea, anyway. But I don't see us doing this again anytime soon.

Besides, she's quite well-behaved. She visits often—whenever I signal to her. And she has been good, on the whole, in the past couple of years, so to be decent myself, I don't complain. She has really been, poor dear, very much what one hoped for; though I needn't, you know," Aunt Maud concluded, "tell you, after all, you clever creature, what that was."

Translation

Moreover, she's quite well-mannered. She visits often, whenever I call for her. And she's generally been good these past two years, so to be decent myself, I don't complain. She's really been, poor dear, everything one could have wished for; though I don't need to tell you, you know," Aunt Maud concluded, "after all, you clever creature, what that was."

It had been partly in truth to keep down the opportunity for this that Densher's appearances under the good lady's roof markedly, after Christmas, interspaced themselves. The phase of his situation that on his return from Venice had made them for a short time almost frequent was at present quite obscured, and with it the impulse that had then acted. Another phase had taken its place, which he would have been painfully at a loss as yet to name or otherwise set on its feet, but of which the steadily rising tide left Mrs. Lowder, for his desire, quite high and dry.

Translation

Densher's visits to the good lady's house had become less frequent after Christmas, partly to avoid that very opportunity. The part of his situation that had caused him to visit almost constantly for a short time after his return from Venice was now completely gone, along with the motivation that had driven it. Another phase had begun, one he couldn't yet name or fully grasp. But the rising tide of this new phase left Mrs. Lowder high and dry, as far as his desires were concerned.

There had been a moment when it seemed possible that Mrs. Stringham, returning to America under convoy, would pause in London on her way and be housed with her old friend; in which case he was prepared for some apparent zeal of attendance. But this danger passed—he had felt it a danger, and the person in the world whom he would just now have most valued seeing on his own terms sailed away westward from Genoa. He thereby only wrote to her, having broken, in this respect, after Milly's death, the silence as to the sense of which, before that event, their agreement had been so deep.

Translation

There was a moment when it seemed Mrs. Stringham might return to America under armed protection, stopping in London on her way, and staying with her old friend. In that case, he was ready to show an enthusiastic attentiveness. But that risk passed—he had considered it a risk, and the person he most wanted to see on his own terms sailed west from Genoa. Instead, he simply wrote to her, breaking, in this instance, the silence concerning which their agreement had been so profound before Milly’s death.

She had answered him from Venice twice, and had had time to answer him twice again from New York. The last letter of her four had come by the same post as the document he sent on to Kate, but he hadn't gone into the question of also enclosing that. His correspondence with Milly's companion was somehow already presenting itself to him as a feature—as a factor, he would have said in his newspaper—of the time whatever it might be, long or short, in store for him; but one of his acutest current thoughts was apt to be devoted to his not having yet mentioned it to Kate. She had put him no question, no "Don't you ever hear?"—so that he hadn't been brought to the point.

Translation

She had replied to him from Venice twice and had had time to reply to him twice again from New York. The last of her four letters had arrived in the same mail as the document he sent on to Kate, but he hadn't considered including that as well. His correspondence with Milly's companion was somehow already beginning to seem to him like a defining characteristic—like a factor, he would have said in his journalistic writing—of the period, however long or short it might be, that lay ahead of him; but one of his most pressing present concerns was his not having yet mentioned it to Kate. She hadn't asked him anything, no "Don't you ever hear?"—so that he hadn't been forced to the issue.

This he described to himself as a mercy, for he liked his secret. It was as a secret that, in the same personal privacy, he described his transatlantic commerce, scarce even wincing while he recognised it as the one connexion in which he wasn't straight. He had in fact for this connexion a vivid mental image—he saw it as a small emergent rock in the waste of waters, the bottomless grey expanse of straightness. The fact that he had on several recent occasions taken with Kate an out-of-the-way walk that was each time to define itself as more remarkable for what they didn't say than for what they did—this fact failed somehow to mitigate for him a strange consciousness of exposure.

Translation

He told himself this was fortunate, because he enjoyed his secret. It was as a secret that, in the same private intimacy, he characterized his transatlantic communication, barely flinching as he acknowledged it as the one connection in which he was being dishonest. He actually had a vivid mental picture of this connection—he saw it as a small rock emerging in the vastness of the water, the bottomless grey expanse of honesty. The fact that on several recent occasions he had taken an unusual walk with Kate that each time proved to be more remarkable for what they didn't say than for what they did—this fact somehow failed to alleviate his strange feeling of vulnerability.

There was something deep within him that he had absolutely shown to no one—to the companion of these walks in particular not a bit more than he could help; but he was none the less haunted, under its shadow, with a dire apprehension of publicity. It was as if he had invoked that ugliness in some stupid good faith; and it was queer enough that on his emergent rock, clinging to it and to Susan Shepherd, he should figure himself as hidden from view. That represented no doubt his belief in her power, or in her delicate disposition to protect him. Only Kate at all events knew—what Kate did know, and she was also the last person interested to tell it; in spite of which it was as if his act, so deeply associated with her and never to be recalled nor recovered, was abroad on the winds of the world.

Translation

There was something profound inside him that he had revealed to absolutely no one—certainly not to the companion of their walks, not a bit more than he could avoid; yet he was haunted by a dire fear of exposure, dwelling under its shadow. It was as if he had conjured that ugliness through some stupid act of good faith. And it was odd that on his emergent rock, clinging to it and to Susan Shepherd, he should imagine himself as hidden. This likely represented his belief in her power, or in her gentle inclination to protect him. Only Kate, at any rate, knew—what Kate knew, and she was also the last person interested in revealing it. Despite this, it was as if his act, so deeply intertwined with her and never to be undone or recovered, was spreading across the world.

His honesty, as he viewed it with Kate, was the very element of that menace: to the degree that he saw at moments, as to their final impulse or their final remedy, the need to bury in the dark blindness of each other's arms the knowledge of each other that they couldn't undo. The frequency of Densher's visits to the good woman's home had decreased after Christmas, partly to avoid certain opportunities. The part of their relationship that had made him visit frequently after he returned from Venice was now gone, along with the motivation behind it. A new phase had begun, which he struggled to define or understand, but the rising trend of it left Mrs.

Translation

Densher's honesty, as he saw it with Kate, was the very core of that threat. He sometimes felt, as to their ultimate purpose or their ultimate solution, the need to bury in the dark oblivion of each other's embrace the knowledge they couldn't undo. The frequency of Densher's visits to the good woman's home had lessened after Christmas, partially to avoid certain chances. The aspect of their relationship that had driven his frequent visits after he returned from Venice was now gone, along with the motivation for it. A new phase had begun, which he struggled to define or grasp, but the direction it was taking left Mrs.

Lowder on the sidelines of his desires. There was a time when Mrs. Stringham was expected to return to America and possibly stop in London to stay with her old friend, and Densher had prepared to visit frequently. But this didn't happen - he'd felt it was a danger - and the person he most wanted to see, on his own terms, had sailed away from Genoa.

Translation

Lowder was no longer central to his desires. There had been a moment when Mrs. Stringham was supposed to come back to America, perhaps stopping in London to see her friend, and Densher had planned to see her often. But that didn't happen - he'd considered it a risk - and the person he most wanted to see, on his own terms, had departed from Genoa.

He only wrote to her, breaking a silence that had been agreed upon before Milly's death. She had written back twice from Venice, and then twice again from New York. Her last letter arrived in the same mail as the document he sent to Kate, but he didn't include it. His communication with Milly's companion was starting to seem like a defining characteristic of this period, whatever length it turned out to be.

Translation

He only wrote to her, breaking a silence they'd both accepted before Milly's death. She’d written back twice from Venice, then twice again from New York. Her last letter arrived in the same mail as the document he sent to Kate, but he didn’t include it. His communication with Milly's companion was beginning to feel like a defining feature of this period, however long it lasted.

A major concern for him was that he hadn't told Kate about it. She hadn't asked, "Do you ever hear from her?" - so he hadn't been forced to say anything. He was grateful for this, as he liked keeping his secret. He viewed his transatlantic communication with her as a secret.

Translation

A significant worry for him was that he hadn't confided in Kate. She hadn't inquired, "Do you ever hear from her?" - and so he'd evaded any disclosure. He was thankful for this, as he enjoyed his secrecy. He regarded his communications with her across the ocean as a clandestine affair.

He saw it as a small rock in the vast sea of his otherwise truthful life. He'd taken unusual walks with Kate recently, which became notable for what they didn't say rather than what they did, but this didn't ease his sense of vulnerability. He hadn't shared his deepest feelings with anyone, especially not with his walking companion. Yet, he was haunted by a fear of exposure.

Translation

He considered it a minor deception in an otherwise honest existence. Though his recent walks with Kate were marked by what remained unspoken, rather than their conversations, this did not alleviate his unease. He had confided in no one, especially not his walking partner, about his innermost thoughts. Still, the fear of discovery lingered.

It was as if he had brought about this problem unknowingly. It was strange that on his isolated rock, clinging to her and Susan Shepherd, he should think of himself as hidden. This likely reflected his belief in her power, or in her careful nature to protect him. Only Kate knew - what Kate knew, and she was the least likely to reveal it; despite this, it was as though his act, which was deeply tied to her and could never be reversed, was being broadcast to the world.

Translation

He felt as though he'd inadvertently created this situation. It was odd that he, isolated and dependent on her and Susan Shepherd, should feel concealed. This probably stemmed from his faith in her influence, or in her instinct to shield him. Only Kate knew—knew what Kate knew, and she was the last person who would expose it; yet, his action, inextricably linked to her and irreversible, felt as though it were being broadcast for all to see.

His honesty, as he saw it with Kate, was what made the threat so strong. He sometimes thought that they needed to hide in each other's arms, in the dark, to bury the knowledge they shared that they couldn't change. Save indeed that the sense in which it was in these days a question of arms was limited, this might have been the intimate expedient to which they were actually resorting. It had its value, in conditions that made everything count, that thrice over, in Battersea Park—where Mrs.

Translation

His honesty, in his view, was the source of the threat's power, especially with Kate. He occasionally felt they should hide together, in each other's arms, in the darkness, to bury the unchangeable truth they shared. Except that the idea of "arms" was restricted now, this might have been the intimate solution they were turning to. It had its importance, in circumstances where everything mattered, that, on three different occasions, in Battersea Park—where Mrs.

Lowder now never drove—he had adopted the usual means, in sequestered alleys, of holding her close to his side. She could make absences, on her present footing, without having too inordinately to account for them at home—which was exactly what gave them for the first time an appreciable margin. He supposed she could always say in Chelsea—though he didn't press it—that she had been across the town, in decency, for a look at her aunt; whereas there had always been reasons at Lancaster Gate for her not being able to plead the look at her other relatives. It was therefore between them a freedom of a purity as yet untasted; which for that matter also they made in various ways no little show of cherishing as such.

Translation

Lowder now never drove—he had adopted the usual means, in secluded alleys, of holding her close to his side. She could disappear, given her current situation, without having to give too many excuses at home—which was precisely what gave them, for the first time, a meaningful advantage. He supposed she could always claim she was in Chelsea—though he didn't insist—that she had been across town, decently, to visit her aunt; whereas there had always been reasons at Lancaster Gate why she couldn't claim to be seeing her other relatives. Therefore, they shared a freedom of an untried purity, which, for that matter, they also showed off in various ways as if they cherished it.

They made the show indeed in every way but the way of a large use—an inconsequence that they almost equally gave time to helping each other to regard as natural. He put it to his companion that the kind of favour he now enjoyed at Lancaster Gate, the wonderful warmth of his reception there, cut in a manner the ground from under their feet. He was too horribly trusted—they had succeeded too well. He couldn't in short make appointments with her without abusing Aunt Maud, and he couldn't on the other hand haunt that lady without tying his hands.

Translation

They put on the show in every way except for actual intimacy—a consequence they both spent a lot of time convincing each other was normal. He told her that the kind of favor he now enjoyed at Lancaster Gate, the wonderful warmth of his welcome there, essentially undermined their relationship. He was trusted too much—they'd been too successful. In short, he couldn't make dates with her without betraying Aunt Maud, and he couldn't, on the other hand, spend time with Aunt Maud without limiting himself.

Kate saw what he meant just as he saw what she did when she admitted that she was herself, to a degree scarce less embarrassing, in the enjoyment of Aunt Maud's confidence. It was special at present—she was handsomely used; she confessed accordingly to a scruple about misapplying her licence. Mrs. Lowder then finally had found—and all unconsciously now—the way to baffle them.

Translation

Kate understood his point, just as he understood hers when she admitted that she, too, was in a similar and almost equally awkward position, enjoying Aunt Maud's trust. It was particularly favorable right now; she was being treated handsomely. She confessed to feeling a certain hesitancy about abusing that privilege. Mrs. Lowder had, at last—and completely without realizing it—managed to outmaneuver them.

It wasn't however that they didn't meet a little, none the less, in the southern quarter, to point for their common benefit the moral of their defeat. They crossed the river; they wandered in neighbourhoods sordid and safe; the winter was mild, so that, mounting to the top of trams, they could rumble together to Clapham or to Greenwich. If at the same time their minutes had never been so counted it struck Densher that by a singular law their tone—he scarce knew what to call it—had never been so bland. Not to talk of what they might have talked of drove them to other ground; it was as if they used a perverse insistence to make up what they ignored.

Translation

Nevertheless, they did meet, just a bit, down in the southern part of the city, to consider the lessons of their mutual failure. They crossed the river; they wandered through neighborhoods both grim and secure; the winter was gentle. They could ride the open-topped trams and rattle together to Clapham or Greenwich. Though their time together had never been so carefully measured, Densher was struck that their mood—he could barely describe it—had never been so serene. Avoiding the subjects they might have discussed pushed them elsewhere; it was as if they used a perverse determination to replace what they wouldn’t acknowledge.

They concealed their pursuit of the irrelevant by the charm of their manner; they took precautions for the courtesy they had formerly left to come of itself; often, when he had quitted her, he stopped short, walking off, with the aftersense of their change. He would have described their change—had he so far faced it as to describe it—by their being so damned civil. That had even, with the intimate, the familiar at the point to which they had brought them, a touch almost of the droll. What danger had there ever been of their becoming rude—after each had long since made the other so tremendously tender?

Translation

They hid their pursuit of unimportant things behind their pleasant demeanor. They took care to be polite, something they had once let happen naturally. Often, after he left her, he would stop abruptly, walking away with the lingering awareness of their altered state. He would have described their change—if he had faced it enough to describe it—as being excessively civil. With the intimate and familiar state they had reached, there was even something almost comical about it. What was the risk of them ever becoming impolite, after they had already made each other so incredibly tender?

Such were the things he asked himself when he wondered what in particular he most feared. Except that the conflict wasn't a literal battle, this might have been the core strategy they were using. It was valuable, in a situation where everything mattered, that he had, three times in Battersea Park—where Mrs. Lowder no longer went—employed the standard tactics of getting close to her in secluded paths.

Translation

These were the questions he posed whenever he contemplated his deepest fears. Minus the actual fighting, this might have been their central approach. It was advantageous, given how much was at stake, that he had, on three occasions in Battersea Park—a park Mrs. Lowder no longer frequented—utilized the common method of getting close to her in isolated areas.

She could take time away, given their current relationship, without having to explain herself excessively at home—which was precisely what gave them a significant advantage for the first time. He imagined she could always say in Chelsea—though he didn't press her—that she'd been across town, appropriately, to see her aunt; whereas there had always been reasons at Lancaster Gate why she couldn't claim she was visiting her other relatives. Therefore, they had a freedom they'd never experienced before, which they also showed in various ways they valued. They showed this in every way except actually utilizing it extensively—a contradiction they spent equal time helping each other consider normal.

Translation

She could take time for herself, considering their current relationship, without needing to over-explain things at home, which was precisely what gave them a real edge for the first time. He figured she could always say in Chelsea—though he didn’t push it—that she’d been on the other side of the city, properly, to see her aunt; whereas at Lancaster Gate, there had always been reasons why she couldn’t claim she was visiting her other relatives. As a result, they had a freedom they’d never known before, which they also showed in various ways they appreciated. They showed this in every way except for actually using it extensively—a contradiction they spent an equal amount of time helping each other normalize.

He told her that the kind of favor he now enjoyed at Lancaster Gate, the wonderful warmth of his welcome there, essentially undermined their plans. He was too horribly trusted—they'd been too successful. In short, he couldn't make arrangements with her without betraying Aunt Maud, and he couldn't spend time with that woman without limiting his options. Kate understood what he meant, just as he understood what she meant when she admitted that she herself, almost as embarrassingly, was trusted by Aunt Maud.

Translation

He told her the favors he now received at Lancaster Gate, the wonderful warmth of his welcome there, essentially ruined their plans. He was trusted far too much—they’d been too successful. In short, he couldn't make arrangements with her without betraying Aunt Maud, and he couldn't spend time with that woman without limiting his options. Kate understood, just as he understood when she admitted that she, almost as embarrassingly, was trusted by Aunt Maud.

It was a unique situation now—she was being treated well; she confessed she hesitated to misuse her freedom. Mrs. Lowder had finally found—and without realizing it—a way to defeat them. However, they still met occasionally in the southern part of town, to discuss their shared failure.

Translation

The situation had changed dramatically—Kate was being treated kindly, and she confessed that she was hesitant to abuse her liberty. Mrs. Lowder, without realizing it, had finally found a way to undermine them. Nevertheless, they still met from time to time in the southern part of the city to discuss their mutual defeat.

They crossed the river; they walked in poor, safe neighborhoods; the winter was mild, so they could ride the trams together to Clapham or Greenwich. Though their time together had never been so carefully monitored, it struck Densher that by a strange rule, their tone—he hardly knew what to call it—had never been so pleasant. Avoiding the topics they might have discussed pushed them to other subjects; it was as if they deliberately focused on what they were ignoring. They hid their pursuit of unimportant things through their charm; they took steps to ensure the courtesy that they used to let happen naturally; often, after he left her, he paused, walking away, reflecting on their change.

Translation

They crossed the river. They strolled through the poor, safe neighborhoods. The winter was gentle, allowing them to take the trams together to Clapham or Greenwich. Though their time together was now more closely observed than ever, Densher felt that, paradoxically, their manner—he wasn't sure what else to call it—had never been so agreeable. Sidestepping the topics they had once gravitated towards steered them toward other subjects; it was as if they were intentionally spotlighting what they were avoiding. They cloaked their pursuit of trivial matters in charm. They took pains to cultivate a courtesy that used to come effortlessly. Frequently, after parting ways with her, he would pause, walking away, and reflect on their shift.

He would have described their change—if he'd been willing to analyze it—as their being so damn civil. That, in their intimate, familiar relationship, which they'd carefully cultivated, was almost comical. What risk was there that they would become rude—after each had long been so incredibly affectionate toward the other? Those were the questions he asked himself when he wondered what he feared most.

Translation

He would have characterized their transformation—if he'd been inclined to dissect it—as a descent into unbearable civility. The effect, within their close, longstanding connection, which they had fostered with care, was almost absurd. What threat was there that they might become impolite—after each had been, for so long, so profoundly devoted to the other? Those were the questions that arose whenever he contemplated his deepest anxieties.

Yet all the while too the tension had its charm—such being the interest of a creature who could bring one back to her by such different roads. It was her talent for life again; which found in her a difference for the differing time. She didn't give their tradition up; she but made of it something new. Frankly moreover she had never been more agreeable nor in a way—to put it prosaically—better company: he felt almost as if he were knowing her on that defined basis—which he even hesitated whether to measure as reduced or as extended; as if at all events he were admiring her as she was probably admired by people she met "out." He hadn't in fine reckoned that she would still have something fresh for him; yet this was what she had—that on the top of a tram in the Borough he felt as if he were next her at dinner.

Translation

But even then the strain had its allure—that was the appeal of a woman who could bring him back to her in such varied ways. It was her gift for living, which found in her a variation for the changing times. She didn't abandon their established ways; she simply made something new of them. Frankly, she had never been more pleasant, or in a way—to put it plainly—better company. He almost felt as if he were getting to know her on that defined basis, which he didn't know whether to consider diminished or enlarged. He felt as if, at any rate, he was admiring her the way people she met "out" probably did. In short, he hadn't anticipated that she would still have something new for him, and yet she did—that on top of a tram in the Borough, he felt as if he were beside her at dinner.

What a person she would be if they had been rich—with what a genius for the so-called great life, what a presence for the so-called great house, what a grace for the so-called great positions! He might regret at once, while he was about it, that they weren't princes or billionaires. She had treated him on their Christmas to a softness that had struck him at the time as of the quality of fine velvet, meant to fold thick, but stretched a little thin; at present, however, she gave him the impression of a contact multitudinous as only the superficial can be. She had throughout never a word for what went on at home.

Translation

What a woman she would have been if they'd had money—what a flair for the so-called glamorous life, what a fitting presence in a so-called grand house, what elegance in the so-called high circles! He could lament, while he was at it, that they weren't royalty or billionaires. During their Christmas, she'd treated him with a gentleness that had felt at the time like fine velvet, meant to be thick but spread a little thin; now, though, she gave him the impression of a connection as widespread as only superficiality allows. She never said a word about what went on at home.

She came out of that and she returned to it, but her nearest reference was the look with which, each time, she bade him good-bye. The look was her repeated prohibition: "It's what I have to see and to know—so don't touch it. That but wakes up the old evil, which I keep still, in my way, by sitting by it. I go now—leave me alone!—to sit by it again.

Translation

She emerged from that and then returned to it, but the thing she referenced most closely was the way she looked at him whenever she said goodbye. That look was her constant warning: "It's what I have to see and to know—so don't touch it. That only awakens the old evil, which I keep contained, in my way, by sitting next to it. I'm leaving now—leave me alone!—to sit next to it again."

The way to pity me—if that's what you want—is to believe in me. If we could really do anything it would be another matter." But even then, the emotional pressure was appealing—such was the captivating nature of someone who could draw him back in so many different ways. It was her ability to embrace life, adapting herself to the ever-changing times.

Translation

The way to pity me—if that's what you desire—is to have faith in me. If we were truly capable of anything, it would be a different story." Yet, even then, the emotional strain held a certain allure—such was the captivating power of someone who could draw him back in so many different ways. It was her capacity to embrace life, adjusting to the constant flux of the world around them.

She didn't abandon their shared values; instead, she reshaped them in a new way. Honestly, she had never been more pleasant, nor, to put it plainly, better company. He almost felt as though he was getting to know her on a clear, distinct level, and he wasn't sure whether to see it as a narrowing or an expansion of their relationship. He was, at any rate, admiring her in the way he imagined she was admired by the people she met "out there." He hadn't expected her to still have something new to offer him.

Translation

She didn't discard their principles, but she did recontextualize them. Truthfully, she'd never been more agreeable, or, to be blunt, more enjoyable to be around. He felt like he was rediscovering her on a fresh, focused level, and he couldn't decide if it was a contraction or an evolution of their connection. At the very least, he was appreciating her in the manner he assumed she was appreciated by those she encountered "out there." He hadn't anticipated her still having something novel to show him.

Yet that was what she had. He felt like he was seated next to her at a formal dinner, even when they were on the top of a bus in the working-class neighborhood. What a remarkable person she would be if they were wealthy—imagine her brilliance in the so-called glamorous world, her presence in a grand home, her elegance in high society! He might as well, while he was at it, wish that they were royalty or billionaires.

Translation

And that's what she possessed. He felt the same way, as if he were sitting next to her at a formal dinner, even when they were riding on top of a bus in a working-class neighborhood. What an extraordinary person she would be if they were rich—imagine her intellect in the so-called glamorous world, her presence in a mansion, her poise in high society! He might as well, while he was at it, wish that they were royalty or billionaires.

During their Christmas gathering, she had shown him a tenderness that had seemed to him like fine velvet, meant to be thick and rich, but a little stretched thin. Now, however, she gave him the impression of a contact that was as shallow as could be. She never mentioned what went on at home. She emerged from that life and returned to it, but the closest she came to acknowledging it was the look she gave him each time they parted.

Translation

During their Christmas get-together, she had shown him a tenderness that had felt to him like fine velvet, meant to be thick and rich, but a little overstretched. Now, though, she gave him the impression of a connection that was as superficial as could be. She never spoke of what went on at home. She emerged from that life and went back to it, but the closest she got to acknowledging it was the look she gave him each time they said goodbye.

The look was her constant warning: "It's what I have to face and understand—so don't interfere. That just stirs up the old problems, which I keep under control, in my own way, by dealing with them. I'm going now—leave me alone!—to face them again. If you want to feel sympathy for me—if that's what you want—believe in me.

Translation

That look was her steady warning: "This is what I have to confront and comprehend—so don't get involved. Interference only reignites the old issues, which I manage to keep in check, in my own way, by confronting them. I'm leaving now—leave me be!—to face them again. If you want to feel sympathy for me—if that's what you're after—believe in me."

If we could truly do something, it would be different." He watched her, when she went her way, with the vision of what she thus a little stiffly carried. It was confused and obscure, but how, with her head high, it made her hold herself! He really in his own person might at these moments have been swaying a little aloft as one of the objects in her poised basket.

Translation

"If we could actually do something, it would be different." He watched her walk away, picturing what she carried, slightly stiffly. It was indistinct and unclear, but it made her hold herself so straight, her head high! At that moment, he felt as if he, himself, was swaying slightly aloft, one of the objects balanced in her poised basket.

It was doubtless thanks to some such consciousness as this that he felt the lapse of the weeks, before the day of Kate's mounting of his stair, almost swingingly rapid. They contained for him the contradiction that, whereas periods of waiting are supposed in general to keep the time slow, it was the wait, actually, that made the pace trouble him. The secret of that anomaly, to be plain, was that he was aware of how, while the days melted, something rare went with them. This something was only a thought, but a thought precisely of such freshness and such delicacy as made the precious, of whatever sort, most subject to the hunger of time.

Translation

The passage of weeks sped by, almost rhythmically, before Kate climbed his stairs; no doubt, this feeling was due to something he was now aware of. He found it contradictory because, even though waiting is typically meant to slow things down, it was the wait itself that troubled him. The simple truth of this contradiction was that he knew something precious was being lost as the days vanished. This “something” was merely a thought, but it was a thought with such freshness and delicacy that it made anything of value, of any sort, especially vulnerable to time's appetite.

The thought was all his own, and his intimate companion was the last person he might have shared it with. He kept it back like a favourite pang; left it behind him, so to say, when he went out, but came home again the sooner for the certainty of finding it there. Then he took it out of its sacred corner and its soft wrappings; he undid them one by one, handling them, handling it, as a father, baffled and tender, might handle a maimed child. But so it was before him—in his dread of who else might see it.

Translation

The thought was entirely his own, and the person closest to him would have been the last one he would confide in. He held it close like a cherished pain; he left it behind when he went out, but he returned home sooner, certain he would find it there. Then, he retrieved it from its hidden place, its soft coverings. He unwrapped them one by one, handling them, handling it, as a father, confused and gentle, might handle an injured child. But so it was before him—in his fear of who else might witness it.

Then he took to himself at such hours, in other words, that he should never, never know what had been in Milly's letter. The intention announced in it he should but too probably know; only that would have been, but for the depths of his spirit, the least part of it. The part of it missed for ever was the turn she would have given her act. This turn had possibilities that, somehow, by wondering about them, his imagination had extraordinarily filled out and refined.

Translation

Then, at such moments, he resolved that he would never, ever learn what was written in Milly's letter. He would likely know the intention announced in it; yet that, for all that he held within, would have been the least important part. The part he would miss forever was the direction she would have given to her actions. This direction held possibilities that, through contemplating them, his imagination had remarkably expanded and defined.

It had made of them a revelation the loss of which was like the sight of a priceless pearl cast before his eyes—his pledge given not to save it—into the fathomless sea, or rather even it was like the sacrifice of something sentient and throbbing, something that, for the spiritual ear, might have been audible as a faint far wail. This was the sound he cherished when alone in the stillness of his rooms. He sought and guarded the stillness, so that it might prevail there till the inevitable sounds of life, once more, comparatively coarse and harsh, should smother and deaden it—doubtless by the same process with which they would officiously heal the ache in his soul that was somehow one with it. It moreover deepened the sacred hush that he couldn't complain.

Translation

It had rendered the loss of them a revelation, like watching a priceless pearl—which he was pledged not to retrieve—being tossed before his eyes into the bottomless sea. More precisely, it was like sacrificing something sentient and throbbing, something that, for the spiritual ear, might have been heard as a distant, faint wail. This was the sound he cherished when alone in the stillness of his rooms. He sought and guarded the stillness, so that it might persist there until the inevitable sounds of life, once more comparatively coarse and harsh, would smother and deaden it—undoubtedly by the same process with which they would officiously heal the ache in his soul that was somehow one with it. It further deepened the sacred hush he could not protest.

He had given poor Kate her freedom. He watched her as she walked away, focusing on what she carried, slightly stiffly. The vision was unclear, but her posture, with her head held high, was striking. He felt like he was floating, a part of the contents of her metaphorical basket.

Translation

He had set poor Kate free. He watched her walk away, focusing on what she carried, slightly stiff. The image was blurred, but her posture, head held high, was remarkable. He felt like he was floating, a part of the contents of her metaphorical basket.

The weeks leading up to Kate's visit seemed to fly by, an unexpected speed. Waiting, normally a slow process, felt strangely rapid. The reason, simply, was that he knew something precious was fading with each passing day. It was just a thought, but it was fresh and delicate, making the precious, whatever it was, vulnerable to time's passage.

Translation

The weeks before Kate's visit had an unexpected velocity. He hadn't expected time to move so fast. Anticipation, which was usually drawn out, felt unusually compressed. The reason was simple: he knew something precious was slipping away with each new day. The feeling was present, light, and delicate, making the precious thing, whatever it was, fragile against the march of time.

He kept this thought to himself, unwilling to share it, especially with his closest companion. He kept it hidden, bringing it back with him as a comfort. He brought it out carefully, like a father attending to a wounded child, terrified of anyone else seeing it. He knew he would never know what was in Milly's letter.

Translation

He kept this thought to himself, unwilling to speak it aloud, most of all to his closest friend. He concealed it, drawing it close as a source of solace. He revealed it with caution, like a father tending to a wounded child, afraid of exposure. He knew he would never understand the contents of Milly’s letter.

He would probably know the announced intention, but that was the least important part. What he would miss forever was how she would have carried out her plan. This held exciting possibilities that his imagination had elaborated on. It had become a revelation, and its loss was like watching a priceless pearl, a promise made not to retrieve it, sink into the ocean.

Translation

He’d likely be aware of the stated plan, though that was the least significant aspect. What he’d be bereft of indefinitely was the execution of her design. This held exhilarating potential, which his imagination had embellished. It had transformed into an epiphany, and its absence felt akin to witnessing a priceless pearl, a vow to leave it undisturbed, vanish into the sea.

It was like sacrificing something alive and beating, something that, for his inner self, might have sounded like a distant, faint cry. This was the sound he loved when he was alone in the quiet of his rooms. He sought and protected the silence, so it would remain until the unavoidable sounds of life, coarse in comparison, smothered and quieted it. The silence deepened the feeling that he could not complain.

Translation

It was as though he were sacrificing something living, something that throbbed, something that, to his inner being, might have sounded like a faint, distant cry. This was the sound he cherished when alone in the stillness of his rooms. He sought and preserved the silence, so that it might remain until the inevitable sounds of life, crude by comparison, overwhelmed and silenced it. The silence deepened the conviction that he could not protest.

He had given Kate her freedom. The great and obvious thing, as soon as she stood there on the occasion we have already named, was that she was now in high possession of it. This would have marked immediately the difference—had there been nothing else to do it—between their actual terms and their other terms, the character of their last encounter in Venice. That had been his idea, whereas her present step was her own; the few marks they had in common were, from the first moment, to his conscious vision, almost pathetically plain.

Translation

He had given Kate her freedom. The most significant and apparent thing, from the moment she stood there on the occasion previously mentioned, was that she now possessed it fully. This alone would have demonstrated the distinction—had there been nothing else to indicate it—between their present relationship and their previous one, the nature of their final meeting in Venice. That had been his plan, whereas her current action was her own; the few shared characteristics they still had were, from the beginning, tragically clear to him.

She was as grave now as before; she looked around her, to hide it, as before; she pretended, as before, in an air in which her words at the moment itself fell flat, to an interest in the place and a curiosity about his "things"; there was a recall in the way in which, after she had failed a little to push up her veil symmetrically and he had said she had better take it off altogether, she had acceded to his suggestion before the glass. It was just these things that were vain; and what was real was that his fancy figured her after the first few minutes as literally now providing the element of reassurance which had previously been his care. It was she, supremely, who had the presence of mind. She made indeed for that matter very prompt use of it.

Translation

She was as serious now as she had been before; she glanced around her to conceal it, just as she had before; she feigned, as she had done previously, an interest in the location and a curiosity about his possessions, a demeanor in which her words at that moment fell flat. There was a familiar echo in the way she had, after struggling a bit to adjust her veil symmetrically, and after he suggested she remove it completely, complied with his suggestion in front of the mirror. It was precisely these things that were pointless; what was genuine was that his imagination portrayed her, after the initial few minutes, as now quite literally offering the element of reassurance that had, earlier, been his responsibility. It was she, above all, who possessed presence of mind. And she made rather prompt use of it, too.

"You see I've not hesitated this time to break your seal." The most striking thing, as soon as she was there on that occasion we mentioned, was that she was now fully in control. This alone would have demonstrated the difference between their current situation and their previous one, the nature of their last meeting in Venice. That had been his plan, but her current action was her own.

Translation

"You see, I haven't hesitated this time to break your seal." The most striking thing, as soon as she was there on that occasion we mentioned, was that she was now fully in control. This alone would have demonstrated the difference between their current situation and their previous one, the nature of their last meeting in Venice. That had been his plan, but her current action was her own.

The few shared traits they had were, to his aware perception, almost pathetically clear from the start. She was as serious now as she had been before; she looked around, to conceal her feelings, as before. She feigned, as before, an interest in the location and curiosity about his "possessions" with a tone that made her words sound hollow. There was a familiar quality in the way she agreed to his suggestion, after struggling to adjust her veil and he’d advised her to simply remove it.

Translation

The few things they had in common were, as far as he could tell, painfully obvious from the beginning. She was as composed now as she had been then; she surveyed the surroundings to hide her emotions, just like before. She pretended, as she had before, to be interested in the place and curious about his belongings, her voice making her words sound empty. There was something familiar in the way she agreed to his suggestion, after struggling with her veil, which he’d told her to simply take off.

It was these affectations that were pointless. The reality was that, after a few minutes, he pictured her as now providing the reassurance that he'd once been so focused on. She, above all else, possessed her composure. She promptly put it to good use.

Translation

These pretenses were useless. The truth was, after only a few minutes, he imagined her now offering the comfort he had once craved. Above all else, she had her composure. She immediately put it to work.

"You see, I haven't hesitated this time to break your seal." She had laid on the table from the moment of her coming in the long envelope, substantially filled, which he had sent her enclosed in another of still ampler make. He had however not looked at it—his belief being that he wished never again to do so; besides which it had happened to rest with its addressed side up. So he "saw" nothing, and it was only into her eyes that her remark made him look, declining any approach to the object indicated.

Translation

"You see, I didn't hesitate to break your seal this time." She had placed the long, filled envelope on the table as soon as she arrived. He had sent it to her inside another, even larger envelope. However, he hadn't looked at it, believing he never wanted to see it again. Also, it had happened to be lying with the address facing up. So he "saw" nothing, and her comment only made him look at her eyes, avoiding any approach to the indicated object.

"It's not 'my' seal, my dear; and my intention—which my note tried to express—was all to treat it to you as not mine." "Do you mean that it's to that extent mine then?" "Well, let us call it, if we like, theirs—that of the good people in New York, the authors of our communication. If the seal is broken well and good; but we might, you know," he presently added, "have sent it back to them intact and inviolate.

Translation

"It's not 'my' seal, my dear. My intention—as I tried to express in my note—was to treat it as though it wasn't mine."

"So, does that mean it's mine, then?"

"Well, let's say it's theirs, if you prefer—the good people in New York, the ones who sent us this correspondence. If the seal is broken, fine. But, you know," he added after a moment, "we could have sent it back to them, untouched."

Only accompanied," he smiled with his heart in his mouth, "by an absolutely kind letter." From the moment she arrived, she'd placed the large, full envelope he'd sent her—itself inside another, even larger one—on the table. He hadn't looked at it, believing he never wanted to see it again. Also, it happened to be lying face up.

Translation

Only accompanied," he smiled nervously, "by an exceedingly kind letter." From the moment she arrived, she'd placed the large, full envelope he'd sent her—itself inside another, even larger one—on the table. He hadn't looked at it, believing he never wanted to see it again. It also happened to be lying face up.

Therefore, he didn't "see" anything, and it was only her words that made him look at her, refusing to approach the object she indicated. "It's not my seal, my dear; and my intention—as my note tried to explain—was to give it to you as if it weren't mine." "So, you mean it's mine?" "Well, if you wish, let's say it belongs to them—the kind people in New York who sent it.

Translation

Consequently, he didn't "see" anything. It was only her words that compelled him to look at her, refusing to approach the object she indicated. "It's not my seal, my dear; and my intention—as my note attempted to explain—was to give it to you as if it wasn't mine." "So, you mean it's mine?" "Well, if you want, let's say it belongs to them—the kind people in New York who sent it."

It's fine if the seal's broken, but we could have sent it back to them untouched, you know," he added, then smiled nervously, "only with a very polite letter." Kate took it with the mere brave blink with which a patient of courage signifies to the exploring medical hand that the tender place is touched. He saw on the spot that she was prepared, and with this signal sign that she was too intelligent not to be, came a flicker of possibilities. She was—merely to put it at that—intelligent enough for anything.

Translation

"It doesn't matter if the seal is broken," he added, then gave a nervous smile. "We could have sent it back to them, you know, untouched, along with a very polite letter." Kate accepted the object, the way a brave patient blinks when the doctor touches a sensitive area. He saw immediately that she was ready, and with this sign, that she was intelligent enough to anticipate, came a glimmer of possibilities. She was—to put it simply—intelligent enough for anything.

"Is it what you're proposing we should do?" "Ah it's too late to do it—well, ideally. Now, with that sign that we know—!" "But you don't know," she said very gently.

Translation

"Is that what you're suggesting we do?"

"Ah, it's too late to do that—well, ideally. Now, given that sign that we know—!"

"But you don't know," she said very gently.

"I refer," he went on without noticing it, "to what would have been the handsome way. Its being dispatched again, with no cognisance taken but one's assurance of the highest consideration, and the proof of this in the state of the envelope—that would have been really satisfying." Kate received his words with the stoic courage of someone enduring a doctor's examination of a sensitive area. He immediately understood that she was ready, and this understanding, coupled with the knowledge of her intelligence, sparked a range of possibilities in his mind.

Translation

"What I mean," he continued, not realizing he was doing so, "is the proper approach. To send it back, with no acknowledgment beyond the assurance of our utmost respect, and confirmed by the appearance of the envelope—that would have been truly gratifying." Kate met his words with the grim fortitude of a patient undergoing a medical examination. He grasped instantly that she was prepared, and this realization, combined with his awareness of her intelligence, ignited a multitude of ideas in his thoughts.

She was, to put it simply, intelligent enough for anything. "Are you asking if we should do it?" "Oh, it's too late to do it properly—ideally. Now, knowing what we know—!"

Translation

She possessed, frankly, the intellect for any task. "Are you suggesting we proceed?" "Well, it's impossible to execute it ideally, at this juncture. Given what we understand—!"

"But you don't know," she said softly. "I mean," he continued, not registering her interruption, "the ideal way. To send it back, pretending we hadn't seen it, simply assuring them of our utmost respect, proven by the condition of the envelope—that would have been truly satisfying." She thought an instant.

Translation

"You don't understand," she whispered. "What I'm saying is," he went on, ignoring her, "the perfect approach. To return it, acting as if we'd never opened it, and conveying our highest regard through the untouched envelope—that would have been incredibly gratifying." She paused, considering.

"The state of the envelope proving refusal, you mean, not to be based on the insufficiency of the sum?" Densher smiled again as for the play, however whimsical, of her humour. "Well yes—something of that sort." "So that if cognisance has been taken—so far as I'm concerned—it spoils the beauty?"

Translation

"You mean," she said, "that the envelope's condition demonstrates our refusal, not because the amount wasn't enough?" Densher smiled again, appreciating the whimsical nature of her humor. "It makes the difference that I'm disappointed in the hope—which I confess I entertained—that you'd bring the thing back to me as you had received it." "You didn't express that hope in your letter." "I didn't want to. I wanted to leave it to yourself.

"The disappointment," she said, "comes from the hope—which, admittedly, I had—that you would return it to me in the same state you found it." "You didn't say that in your letter." "I didn't want to. I wanted to leave it to you."

Translation

"I wanted—yes, if that's what you're asking—to see what you would do." "You wanted to test how far I would stray from propriety?" He remained composed now; a kind of ease—from the presence, as in the air, of something he couldn't yet have named—had come to him. "Well, I wanted—in so good a case—to test you."

She was struck—it showed in her face—by his expression. "It is a good case. I doubt whether a better," she said with her eyes on him, "has ever been known." "The better the case then the better the test!"

Translation

The look on her face betrayed her surprise. "This is a good case, I would even say, perhaps the best," she said, her eyes fixed on him. "And the better the case, the better the test, wouldn't you say?"

"How do you know," she asked in reply to this, "what I'm capable of?" "I don't, my dear! Only with the seal unbroken I should have known sooner." "I see"—she took it in.

Translation

"How do you know," she asked in response, "what I can do?" "I don't, my dear! If the seal hadn't been broken, I would have known sooner." "I see"—she understood.

"But I myself shouldn't have known at all. And you wouldn't have known, either, what I do know." He was more composed now; a sense of relaxation had settled over him, something he couldn't quite define, but felt it was there. "Well, I wanted to see how you'd handle this situation."

Translation

"Even I wouldn't have known. And you certainly wouldn't have known what I know." He was calmer now; a feeling of ease had come over him, something he couldn't quite name, but he felt it nonetheless. "Well, I wanted to see how you'd manage."

She was clearly taken aback by his words. "It's a very good situation. I doubt there's ever been a better one," she said, her eyes fixed on him. "The better the situation, the better the test!"

Translation

Her surprise was evident. "It's a perfect setup. Truly, the best possible," she said, staring intently. "The better the setup, the better the challenge!"

"How do you know," she asked him, "what I'm capable of?" "I don't, my dear! If things had gone differently, I'd have figured it out sooner." "I understand," she said, considering his words.

Translation

"How do you know what I can do?" she asked him. "I don't, my dear! If things had played out differently, I would have found out sooner." "I see," she said, considering his words.

"But I wouldn't have known myself. And you still wouldn't know what I know now." "Let me tell you at once," he returned, "that if you've been moved to correct my ignorance I very particularly request you not to." She just hesitated.

Translation

"Even I wouldn't have understood. And you still wouldn't grasp what I understand now." "Allow me to be frank," he responded, "if your intention is to enlighten me, I implore you to reconsider." She paused.

"Are you afraid of the effect of the corrections? Can you only do it by doing it blindly?" He waited a moment. "What is it that you speak of my doing?"

Translation

"Are you afraid of how the corrections will impact things? Can you only make them without seeing their consequences?" He paused. "What exactly are you accusing me of doing?"

"Why the only thing in the world that I take you as thinking of. Not accepting—what she has done. Isn't there some regular name in such cases? Not taking up the bequest."

"Why the only thing in the world I take you to be preoccupied with. Not accepting—what she's done. Isn't there a standard term for something like that? Not claiming the inheritance."

"You're overlooking something," he said after a pause. "My request that you participate with me in this." Her surprise softened her, but it didn't make her less resolute. "How can I 'participate' in a matter that doesn't concern me?"

"I'll be frank," he replied, "if you're planning to educate me, I'm asking you not to." She paused. "Are you worried about how these corrections will change things? Do you only want to proceed without knowing?"

Translation

Translation

I do nothing." "That, as I understand, is accepting." Densher paused. "I do nothing formal."

"Any one who wants or who can." Again a little she said nothing: she might say too much. But by the time she spoke he had covered ground. "How can I touch it but through you?"

Translation

"Anyone who wants to, or who is able." Again, she said nothing for a moment: she might say too much. But by the time she spoke, he had moved on. "How else can I get to it, except through you?"

"How? With a single word." "And what word is that?" "Your agreement to my quitting."

"How? With a single word." "And what word would that be?" "Your agreement to my leaving."

"My agreement is meaningless when I can't stop you." "You absolutely can stop me. Understand that," he said. It sounded like a threat to her.

"My agreement is irrelevant, since I can't prevent you." "You absolutely can stop me. Understand that," he said. It sounded like a threat to her.

"You mean you won't quit if I don't agree?" "Yes. I'll do nothing." "That, as I understand it, means you're accepting."

Translation

"So you won't back down unless I give the okay?" "That's right. I won't do a thing." "Which, as I see it, means you're consenting."
