Translation

The statement had a definitive quality, despite the way he’d been approaching it. "Who, then, will?" "Anyone who’s willing and capable." Once more, she was silent for a beat; she was perhaps revealing too much.

But before she spoke, he had already anticipated her. "How can I touch it except through you?" "You can't. Any more," he added, "than I can renounce it except through you."

Translation

But before she could speak, he already knew what she was going to say. "How can I interact with it without you?" "You can't. Not anymore," he clarified, "just as I can't reject it except through you."

"Oh ever so much less! There's nothing," she explained, "in my power." "I'm in your power," Merton Densher said. "In what way?"

Translation

"Infinitely less! I have no power," she explained. "I'm in your power," Merton Densher said. "How so?"

You can't give it up any more," he added, "than I can give it up except by your help." "Oh, much less! There's nothing I can do," she explained. "I'm in your power," Merton Densher said.

Translation

"You can't abandon it," he continued, "any more than I can, unless you help me." "Oh, not at all! There's nothing I can do," she said. "I'm in your power," Merton Densher stated.

Translation

"How so?" "In the manner I demonstrate—the only way I ever have. When have I ever behaved otherwise?" he demanded, abruptly testy. "You must perceive—without feeling compelled to feign concern—the degree to which I am yours."

"It's very kind of you, my dear," she laughed nervously, "to be so clear about it!" "I'm not being clear about anything. I didn't even hint that you had the opportunity, as I said earlier, to gain by helping that situation. You are therefore completely free in every way."

Translation

"That's very nice of you, darling," she said, laughing a little. "To put it so plainly!" "I'm not putting anything plainly. I didn't even imply that you could benefit from aiding that matter, as I've already pointed out. So you're entirely unburdened."

It had come to the point really that they showed each other pale faces, and that all the unspoken between them looked out of their eyes in a dim terror of their further conflict. Something even rose between them in one of their short silences—something that was like an appeal from each to the other not to be too true. Their necessity was somehow before them, but which of them must meet it first? "Thank you!" Kate said for his word about her freedom, but taking for the minute no further action on it.

Translation

They had reached a point where they showed each other wan expressions, and all the unspoken words between them appeared in their eyes as a vague fear of their next disagreement. Something even surfaced in their short silences—something like a plea from each to the other not to be entirely honest. Their unavoidable fate was somehow present, but which of them would be forced to confront it first? "Thank you!" Kate said for his words about her freedom, but she made no immediate move to act on it.

It was blest at least that all ironies failed them, and during another slow moment their very sense of it cleared the air. There was an effect of this in the way he soon went on. "You must intensely feel that it's the thing for which we worked together." Their situation had become so dire that they revealed their distress to each other, their unspoken thoughts evident in their terrified gazes.

Translation

At least they were spared any more ironies, and in the next drawn-out pause, they both seemed to understand. His voice changed as he continued. "You must strongly believe it's what we were striving for." Their situation had grown so desperate that they showed each other their anguish, their unspoken fears plain in their horrified looks.

During brief moments of silence, an unspoken plea emerged – a desperate request not to be overly honest. Their unavoidable fate loomed, but who would face it first? "Thank you," Kate said, acknowledging his words about her independence, though she didn't act on them immediately. It was a relief that sarcasm held no power over them, and the simple understanding of that fact cleared the tension.

Translation

In the short lulls, an unspoken appeal arose, a desperate plea for a lack of brutal honesty. Their shared destiny was inevitable, yet who would be the first to confront it? "Thank you," Kate said, as a gesture of acknowledgment of his words regarding her autonomy, though she didn’t act on them right away. It was a comfort that sarcasm held no sway over them, and the simple understanding of this reality dissolved the tension.

This was evident in his next words. "You must believe with all your heart that this is what we were striving for together." She took up the remark, however, no more than if it were commonplace; she was already again occupied with a point of her own. "Is it absolutely true—for if it is, you know, it's tremendously interesting—that you haven't so much as a curiosity about what she has done for you?"

Translation

His next words made it clear. "You have to believe with all your heart that this is what we've been working toward together." She received his statement as though it were unremarkable, already preoccupied with her own thoughts. "Is it absolutely true—because if it is, you know, it's incredibly interesting—that you aren't even curious about what she's done for you?"

"Would you like," he asked, "my formal oath on it?" "No—but I don't understand. It seems to me in your place—!" "Ah," he couldn't help breaking in, "what do you know of my place?

Translation

"Do you want me," he asked, "to swear an oath?" "No, but I don't get it. I feel like if I were you—!" "Oh," he interjected, unable to help himself, "what do you know about being me?"

Pardon me," he at once added; "my preference is the one I express." She had in an instant nevertheless a curious thought. "But won't the facts be published?" "'Published'?"—he winced.

Translation

"Pardon me," he added immediately, "my preference is the one I'm stating." Despite this, she had a strange thought almost instantly. "But won't the facts be published?" "'Published'?" he winced.

"I mean won't you see them in the papers?" She addressed the comment as though it were completely ordinary, already absorbed in her own train of thought. "Is it really true—because it would be fascinating if it is—that you aren't even curious about what she's done for you?" "Would you like me to swear an oath?" he asked.

Translation

"I mean, won't you see them in the papers?" She asked the question as though it was perfectly normal, already lost in her own thoughts. "Is it really true—because it would be fascinating if it is—that you aren't even curious about what she's done for you?" "Do you want me to swear to it?" he asked.

"No—but I don't understand. If I were you—!" "Oh," he interrupted, unable to contain himself, "what do you know of my situation? Please forgive me," he immediately added; "my preference is what I've stated."

Translation

"No, I just don't get it. If I were you—!" "Oh," he cut her off, unable to hold back, "what do you understand about my circumstances? Please, I beg your pardon," he added quickly; "my preference is what I've told you."

Suddenly, a strange idea occurred to her. "But won't the details be made public?" "'Public'?" he winced. "I mean, won't you read about them in the newspapers?"

Translation

A peculiar thought entered her mind. "But won't the details be made public?" He recoiled. "'Public'?" "I mean, won't you read about them in the newspapers?"

"Ah never! I shall know how to escape that." It seemed to settle the subject, but she had the next minute another insistence. "Your desire is to escape everything?"

Translation

"Never! I'll know how to avoid that." The matter appeared settled, but in the next moment, she pressed further. "You want to escape everything?"

"Everything." "And do you need no more definite sense of what it is you ask me to help you to renounce?" "My sense is sufficient without being definite. I'm willing to believe that the amount of money's not small."

Translation

"Everything." "And don't you need a clearer idea of exactly what

you're asking me to help you give up?" "My idea is good enough without being specific. I'm willing to believe it's a significant sum of money."

"Ah there you are!" she exclaimed. "If she was to leave me a remembrance," he quietly pursued, "it would inevitably not be meagre." Kate waited as for how to say it. "It's worthy of her.

Translation

"There you are!" she exclaimed. "If she were to leave me something to remember her by," he continued quietly, "it wouldn't be a small amount." Kate paused, considering how to phrase it. "It's what she deserves."

It's what she was herself—if you remember what we once said that was." He hesitated—as if there had been many things. But he remembered one of them. "Stupendous?"

Translation

"It's what she was, herself—if you recall what we once spoke about." He paused, as if there were a multitude of such things. But he remembered one. "Magnificent?"

"Never! I will find a way out of this." That seemed to end the discussion, but she immediately brought it up again. "You want to escape everything?"

Translation

"Never! I will find a way out of this." That seemed to settle the matter, but she immediately returned to it. "Do you want to escape everything?"

"Everything." "And you don't need a clearer idea of what you're asking me to help you give up?" "My idea is clear enough, even if it's not specific. I'm willing to believe the money will be a substantial amount."

Translation

"Everything." "And you don't need a clearer idea of what you're asking me to help you abandon?" "My idea is clear enough, even if it's vague. I'm willing to believe the money will be a substantial amount."

"There you go!" she exclaimed. "If she were to leave me a gift," he continued calmly, "it would undoubtedly be generous." Kate paused, thinking about how to phrase it. "It's appropriate for her.

Translation

"That's the spirit!" she exclaimed. "If she were to leave me something," he continued evenly, "I have no doubt it would be quite a sum." Kate hesitated, considering her words. "It suits her."

It reflects who she was—if you recall what we once said about her." He paused, as though there were many things to recall. But he remembered one. "Amazing?"

Translation

It's a testament to her character, remembering what we used to say about her." He stopped, as if there was a great deal to remember. But he singled one thing out. "Astonishing?"

"Stupendous." A faint smile for it—ever so small—had flickered in her face, but had vanished before the omen of tears, a little less uncertain, had shown themselves in his own. His eyes filled—but that made her continue. She continued gently. "I think that what it really is must be that you're afraid.

Translation

"Stupendous." A faint smile, so small, had flickered on her face, but it had vanished before the threat of tears, a little less uncertain, had appeared in his own. His eyes filled—but that made her continue. She continued gently. "I think that what it really is must be that you're afraid."

I mean," she explained, "that you're afraid of all the truth. If you're in love with her without it, what indeed can you be more? And you're afraid—it's wonderful!—to be in love with her." "I never was in love with her," said Densher.

Translation

"I mean," she explained, "that you're afraid of the whole truth. If you love her without it, what more could you possibly be? And you're afraid—it's wonderful!—to be in love with her." "I was never in love with her," said Densher.

She took it, but after a little she met it. "I believe that now—for the time she lived. I believe it at least for the time you were there. But your change came—as it might well—the day you last saw her; she died for you then that you might understand her.

Translation

She accepted that, but she countered it after a moment. "I believe that now—for the time she was alive. I believe it, at least, for the time you were with her. But your shift came—as it easily could—the day you last saw her; she died for you then, so that you could understand her."

From that hour you did." With which Kate slowly rose. "And I do now. She did it for us." Densher rose to face her, and she went on with her thought. "I used to call her, in my stupidity—for want of anything better—a dove.

Translation

"From that hour, you did." With that, Kate slowly rose. "And I do now. She did it for us." Densher rose to face her, and she continued her thought. "I used to call her, in my stupidity—for lack of anything better—a dove."

Well she stretched out her wings, and it was to that they reached. They cover us." "Amazing." A tiny smile touched her face, but it disappeared before the hint of tears, a little less certain, appeared in his own eyes. His eyes filled—but that made her keep going.

Translation

"Well, she stretched out her wings, and it was to that they reached. They cover us." "Amazing." A tiny smile touched her face, but it disappeared before the hint of tears, a little less certain, appeared in his own eyes. His eyes filled—but that made her keep going.

She spoke softly. "I think the real issue is that you're scared. I mean," she clarified, "that you're scared of the whole truth. If you love her without it, how can it get any stronger?

Translation

She spoke quietly. "I think the real problem is that you're afraid. I mean," she explained, "you're afraid of the whole picture. If you love her without knowing everything, how can your feelings deepen?"

And you're afraid—it's remarkable!—to be in love with her." "I was never in love with her," Densher said. She accepted it, but then she disagreed. "I believe that now—for the time she was alive.

Translation

And you're afraid—it's remarkable!—to be in love with her." Densher said, "I was never in love with her." She accepted it, but then she disagreed. "I believe that now—for the time she was alive."

I believe it at least for the time you knew her. But your change happened—as it was destined to—the day you last saw her; she died for you then so you could understand her. From that moment, you did." With that, Kate slowly stood up. "And I do now.

Translation

I believe it, at least for the period you knew her. But your change happened—as it was meant to—the day you last saw her; she died for you then, so you could understand her. From that moment, you did." With that, Kate slowly rose. "And I do now.

She did it for us." Densher stood to face her, and she continued. "I used to call her, in my ignorance—because I didn't know what else to say—a dove. Well, she spread her wings, and that's what they did. They protect us."

Translation

"She did it for us." Densher stood and faced her. She went on, "I used to call her a dove, in my ignorance—because I didn't know what else to say. Well, she spread her wings, and that's what they did. They protect us."

"They cover us," Densher said. "That's what I give you," Kate gravely wound up. "That's what I've done for you." His look at her had a slow strangeness that had dried, on the moment, his tears.

Translation

"They shield us," Densher said. "That's what I'm offering you," Kate solemnly concluded. "That's what I've done for you." His gaze at her possessed a slow strangeness that had, in that instant, dried his tears.

"Do I understand then—?" "That I do consent?" She gravely shook her head. "No—for I see. You'll marry me without the money; you won't marry me with it.

Translation

"Do I understand then—?" "That I do consent?" She gravely shook her head. "No—for I see. You'll marry me without the money; you won't marry me with it."

If I don't consent you don't." "You lose me?" He showed, though naming it frankly, a sort of awe of her high grasp. "Well, you lose nothing else. I make over to you every penny."

Translation

"If I don't agree, you won't either." "You'll leave me?" Though he stated it plainly, he seemed somewhat in awe of her superior understanding. "Well, you lose nothing else. I transfer every penny to you."

Prompt was his own clearness, but she had no smile this time to spare. "Precisely—so that I must choose." "You must choose." "They protect us," Densher said.

Translation

Prompt understood his own clarity, but she didn't have a smile to offer this time. "Precisely—so that I have to choose." "You must choose." "They protect us," Densher said.

"That's what I'm offering you," Kate solemnly concluded. "That's what I've done for you." His gaze at her had a slow surprise that immediately stopped his tears. "So, do I understand then—?"

Translation

"That is what I am presenting to you," Kate finished with gravitas. "It's what I've done for you." His eyes held her with a slow shock that immediately halted his tears. "So, do I understand, then—?"

"That I'm agreeing?" She solemnly shook her head. "No—because I see now. You'll marry me without the money; you won't marry me with it. If I don't agree, you won't."

Translation

"That I'm agreeing?" She shook her head solemnly. "No—because I understand now. You'll marry me regardless of the money; you won't marry me if I have it. If I don't agree, you won't."

"You'll lose me?" Though he stated it plainly, he showed a kind of reverence for her sharp understanding. "Well, you won't lose anything else. I'll give you every penny." His response was immediate and clear, but she didn't have a smile for him this time.

Translation

"You'll lose me?" Though he stated it plainly, he showed a kind of reverence for her sharp understanding. "Well, you won't lose anything else. I'll give you every penny." His response was immediate and clear, but she didn't smile at him this time.

"Exactly—so that I have to make a choice." "You have to choose." Strange it was for him then that she stood in his own rooms doing it, while, with an intensity now beyond any that had ever made his breath come slow, he waited for her act. "There's but one thing that can save you from my choice."

Translation

"Precisely—meaning I have to make a choice." "You do have to choose." It struck him as odd, then, that she was doing this in his own rooms, and he waited for her decision with an intensity that had never before made him breathe so slowly. "There's only one thing that can save you from my choice."

"From your choice of my surrender to you?" "Yes"—and she gave a nod at the long envelope on the table—"your surrender of that." "What is it then?" "Your word of honour that you're not in love with her memory."

Translation

"From your choice of me surrendering to you?" "Yes"—and she gestured towards the long envelope on the table—"your surrender of that." "What is it then?" "Your word of honor that you're not in love with her memory."

"Oh—her memory!" "Ah"—she made a high gesture—"don't speak of it as if you couldn't be. I could in your place; and you're one for whom it will do. Her memory's your love.

Translation

"Oh—her memory!" "Ah"—she gestured emphatically—"don't speak of it as if you were incapable. I could be, were I in your position; and you are someone for whom it is ideal. Her memory is your love."

You want no other." He found it odd that she was there in his rooms, doing this. He waited for her action with a degree of intensity he had never felt before, his breath coming in slow measured gasps. "Only one thing can prevent me from choosing."

Translation

"You want no other." It struck him as strange that she was present in his rooms, doing this. He awaited her move with a level of focus he’d never experienced, his breathing slow and deliberate. "Only one thing could stop me from choosing."

"From choosing that I give in to you?" "Yes." She gestured toward the long envelope on the table. "You must surrender that." "Surrender what?"

Translation

"From choosing to yield to you?" "Yes." She indicated the long envelope on the table. "You must relinquish that." "Relinquish what?"

"Your word of honor that you are not in love with her memory." "Oh, her memory!" "Don't speak of it as though it's impossible. I could be in your position.

Translation

"Your word of honor that you're not in love with her memory." "Oh, her memory!" "Don't act like it's impossible. I could be in your position."

And you are someone for whom it would be possible. Her memory is your love. You desire no other." He heard her out in stillness, watching her face but not moving.

Translation

And you, you're the type to do it. Her memory is what you love. You don't want anyone else." He listened quietly, studying her face, but without shifting.

Then he only said: "I'll marry you, mind you, in an hour." "As we were?" "As we were." But she turned to the door, and her headshake was now the end.

Translation

Then he only said, "I'll marry you, mind you, in an hour." "As we were?" "As we were." But she turned toward the door, and her headshake was now the end.

"We shall never be again as we were!"

Translation

"We'll never go back to how things were before!"
